Notes on the Literature in Proteomics

Vol 1: 19xx-2006

This is the first in a series of documents containing notes (more than abstracts but less than the full published reports) on the data and results in papers relevant to research on methods and methodologies in proteomics, or in which proteomics is used as a tool. The (HTML) titles for these documents are:

  • Notes on the Literature in Proteomics (Vol 1: 19xx-2006)
    [this document: ProteomicsLit(19xx-2006).html]
  • Notes on the Literature in Proteomics (Vol 2: 2007-)
    [document: ProteomicsLit(2007-).html]

mucins, oligosaccharides

Carlson DM, Blackwell C (1968) J. Biol. Chem. 243, 515-526.

Structures and Immunochemical Properties of Oligosaccharides Isolated from Pig Submaxillary Mucins

Work on pig gastric mucosa has shown the following blood group substances A, H, and AH. Pig type A is thought to have identical glycan structure to human type A. Extracts of porcine submaxillary glands show serologically similar to gastric secretions, being A, H, AH, and I (the absence of A or H). In this study sialic acid is determined by resorcinol; after sialidase treatment, thiobarbituric acid method is used. The Dische and Shettles method is used to determine fucose, galactose by orcinol-sulfuric acid.

Oligosaccharides were first reduced with sodium borohydride in alkaline conditions: 1 g mucin is placed in 50 mM KOH with 1.0 M NaBH4 for 15 h at 45° in 400 ml volume. Borohydride is eliminated with slow addition of 4 M acetic acid to pH 5. This is then passed through 4 × 40 cm Dowex 50-X8 (H+, 200-400 mesh). The effluent evapd on rotovap and B(OH)3 removed as methyl borate. A clear syrup is dissolved in 250 ml water and sialic acid-containing oligosaccharides adsorbed to 2 × 30 cm Dowex 1-X2 (Cl−, 50-100 mesh). Neutral sugars are washed off column unbound until eluate is negative to anthrone reagent; these are then fractionated on 3 × 4 cm charcoal-Celite. N-acetylgalactosaminitol and oligosaccharide V are batch-eluted with steps of 100 ml 5% EtOH then 100 ml 15% EtOH. Sialic acid oligosaccharides are eluted from Dowex 1 with a 1.8 L total volume 0 to 100 mM NaCl gradient in water, with 1 ml/min flow and fractionated 5 ml per. Resorcinol and anthrone were used to test fractions. Fracs 46-139 had sialic acid and hexose (pooled 46-105, and 106-140), 141-230 had sialic acid. Pools were evapd, redissolved in water, desalted on Biogel P-2. Neutral sugars can be separated using charcoal-Celite, but paper chromatography was required for sialic acid sugars. Chromatography on Schleicher & Schuell No. 589 Green Ribbon was done with 6:4:3 n-butanol:pyridine:water (solvent A). Periodate-benzidine was used to show spots, which are eluted with water and cleaned up on Dowex 50-X8 (H+ 200-400 mesh).

Results. Mucins which are immunochemically distinct A+-PSM and A−-PSM were obtained from pig submaxillary gland extracts which were treated at pH 4.5 and precipitated as highly charged polyanionic mucins with cetylpyridinium chloride. The aggregate clot was redissolved in physiological saline and then fractionated using EtOH. In the ultracentrifuge the mucins were monodisperse but not pure/homogeneous. Carbohydrate compositions were determined for the different glands. Per 100 g mucin, there are 23.4 g GalNAc, 8.5 g fucose, 11.5 g galactose, and 14.6 g N-glycolylneurmaninic acid (N-GN). There was less GalNAc, fucose, galactose and more N-GN in H and I glands.

Carbohydrate structure of glycoproteins is facilitated by release of sugar chains with minimum of degradation. Previous research used alkaline conditions involving 5-7 d incubations at room temperature but yields were low with significant degradation. Released of reduced sugars by hydroxide worked sufficiently well. there are high recoveries of sialic acid and fucose and total loss of hexosamine. Hydrolysis of A+-PSM showed recoveries of GalNAc of 30-40%. Galactose is recovered at 70-85%. Chromatography on charcoal-Celite or Biogel P-2 gives better than 90% yield.

Saccharide fractions show homogeneity in at least 5 chromatographic solvent systems tried and in borate buffered electrophoresis. Oligosaccharides II, III, V, and VI are obtained from A--PSM, with no I and IV oligosaccharides. A+-PSM has all six. Oligosaccharide I is a pentasaccharide with equimolar amounts of GalNAc, galactose, fucose, N-GN, and N-acetylgalactosaminitol. All other oligosaccharides lack one or more of these, but all contain the alcohol of GalNAc. The fucose is isolated as a syrup and has a rotation of −73° with reported rotation −76°; the phenylhydrazone melts at 170-172° with 169-172° observed; moreover a mix of the phenylhydrazone of pure fucose and the phenylhydrazone of the isolated syrup was 169-171°. The fractions of Gal and GalNAc compared against the standards in Gal oxidase reaction system.

Fraction VI passed through Dowex-1 chloride and is eluted from charcoal-Celite with 5% EtOH. In three paper chromatographic solvents and in borate electrophoresis it moves with N-acetylgalactosaminitol. Material crystallized from ethanol melts at 174-175°, while pure GalNAc reduced with sodium borohydride to produce N-acetylgalactosaminitol produced a crystal melting at 174-176°. A mixture of the Frac VI sugar and the reduced standard also had the same melting point. Both Frac VI and the standard are treated with periodate, then borohydride, and these products have Rf values identical with N-acetylserinol in three solvent systems.

Frac V oligosaccharide is mildly acid hydrolyzed and liberates 89% of the fucose, monitored by increases in reducing substances and no detectable release of galactose or N-acetylgalactosaminitol. Charcoal-Celite separated fucose from galactosyl→N-acetylgalactosaminitol. The latter has a rotation of −48°, and is destroyed by β-galactosidase. The trisaccharide with a high negative rotation (−115°) suggests fucose is α-linked. The trisaccharide is active to galactose oxidase and methylation gives 3,4,6-trimethylgalactose, suggesting that the C2 of galactose is substituted (methylations are done with 5-20 µmol oligosaccharide dried in a PTFE-lined screw cap to which 0.5 ml DMF, 0.5 ml DMSO, 250 mg BaO, 100 mg Ba(OH)2, and 0.25 ml CH3I is added along with glass beads and the contents shaken vigorously 24 h at RT. BaO and CH3I are added again and shaking done another 24 h. Methylated sugars are extracted to chloroform, and the organic phase is dried. Biogel P-2 chromatography further purifies, and the anthrone is used to detect derivatives. These are hydrolyzed to methylated monosaccharides with 2 N H2SO4 for 3 h, the hydrolysates passed over Dowex 1 carbonate form (to neutralize), and amino sugars removed with Dowex 50-H+

phosphoproteins

Cutting JA, Roth TF (1973) Anal. Biochem. 54, 386-394.

Staining of Phospho-Proteins on Acrylamide Gel Electropherograms

Many phosphorylated proteins are found abundant in nature: caseins in mammalian milk, phosvitins in eggs. A specific stain is necessary.

0.6 × 10 cm tube 7% gels after Davis were prepared and cast. Electrophoresis is done to 1 cm from the end with the tracer dye. Chicken yolk phosvitin is purified using the Mecham and Olcott method using freshly laid infertile eggs from White Leghorn hens.

The Fiske-SubbaRow reagent was first tried using dilute NaOH solutions; use of 1 N NaOH, extended hydrolysis at 80°, and as much as 200 µg phosvitin would normally show the presence of phosphate in solution. The basic dye method for sensitivity enhancement of the ammonium molybdate reagent was tried, using methyl green in place of malachite green. Methyl green was incompatible with TCA, so 10% sulfosalicylic acid is used in the fix. (For details on the ammonium molybdate method, see Akamatsu, J. Biochem. 39: 203, 1952; Itawa and Ui, Clin Chim Acta 14: 361, 1966; the methyl green recommendations comes from Van Belle, Anal. Biochem. 33: 132, 1970.)

Gels with 54 µg phosvitin were treated with 1 N NaOH at 80° for 1 h then treated with a mixture of 3 vol 0.2% methyl green in water and 1 vol 4.2% ammonium molybdate in 4.5 N HCl (a final concentration of 0.15% methyl green, ~1% ammomium molybdate, and ~ 1.1 N HCl). After 15 min, gels are transferred to 10% SSA and show a broad green band where phosvitin should be. If 50 mM CaCl2 is included in 10% SSA prior to hydrolysis, a calcium phosphate precipitate forms to prevent phosphate ion diffusion.

Because only staining is happening at the surface rather than throughout the band. To compensate, a nitrophospho-molybdo complex is produced by adding ammonium molybdate in nitric acid. Because methyl green is insoluble in all mineral acids like HNO3, the dye is dissolved in 7% acetic acid to complex it, and this produces a sharp well defined band.

The following procedure was developed.

  1. Fix gels in 10% sulfosalicylic acid (SSA). The time of fixation should be sufficient to allow any free phosphate and low MW phospho compounds to diffuse out of the gel. In serum samples, this could take as long as 12 h with several changes of fixative; the step can be omitted when no phosphate is present.
  2. Gels are transferred to fresh 10% SSA containing 0.5 M calcium chloride for 1 h or longer. (Note several concentrations of calcium chloride were tested and 0.5 M was optimal.)
  3. Gels are rapidly rinsed in deionized water to remove surface presence of calcium chloride, which could cause irregular staining.
  4. The gel is placed in 0.5 N NaOH at 60° for 30 min. Note the gel shrinks as hydrolysis ensues, a function of time and temperature of incubation and of hydroxide concentration. Different concentrations (0.1, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0) of hydroxide, times (30, 60, 120 min), and temperatures (37, 60, 80°) were all tried.
  5. Rinse twice for 10 min each with 1% ammonium molybdate, letting the ions penetrate gel before decreasing pH, which forms the phospho-molybdate complex. If acidification occurs prior to molybdate complexation, the calcium phosphate solubilization occurs with the result of broader bands and missing fine bands. The second molybdate rinse is done to reduce the level of NaOH.
  6. Gels are transferred to 1% ammonium molybdate in 1 N nitric acid for 30 min.
  7. Transfer to a 0.5% methyl green in 7% acetic acid solution for 30 min.
  8. Destain with several changes of 10% SSA.
  9. Gels are best kept in 7% acetic acid.

As little as 0.3 µg phosvitin was detectable, and because it has 10% phosphate, this means as little as 1 nmol phosphate was detected.

protein folding

Go N, Taketomi H (1978) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 75, 559-563.

Respective roles of short- and long-range interactions in protein folding

Long-range interaction in protein folding are important because large protein fragments do not conserve the same conformation that they possess when made part of a native structure of a larger or intact protein. Thus interfragment (long-range) interactions are important. It is also observed that denaturing transitions in globular proteins occur in an all-or-none manner, whereas if short-range transitions were dominant, denaturation would be seen as a gradient of states. Consider a 2D square lattice in a computer. The protein molecule is a self-avoiding chain polyer of N units connected linearly by bonds with length same as lattice constant of square lattice. Conformations taken depend on bond angle, and two forces govern long- and short-range interaction.

In the long-range interaction, system energy decreases by ε when a preassigned pair of units occupies nearest-neighbor lattice points. Assignment of pairs of interactable units defines specificity of long-range interactions. Consider polymer chain of 49 units linked linearly. Three different specificities are assumed: specificity A (strong limit), specificity B (intermediate), and specificity C (weak limit). For specificity A, there are only 36 pairs of units occurring in nearest-neighbor lattice points in conformation shown in Fig 1. For example, unit 1 has nearest neighbor units 4, 6, and 8, so interactions 1-4, 1-6, 1-8 are specificity A (strong). With all units determined, there are 36 strong interactions, so the long-range interaction energy is −36ε. Other conformations grossly different will have interaction energy much closer to zero. With specificity C all 552 pairs of units that can be geometrically occupy nearest-neighbor lattice points are assigned. Thus all conformations compactly folded into a 7×7 square have same lowest energy, −36ε. And no particular conformation will be chosen as a native structure. With specificity B, randomly selected 148 pairs as well as 36 pairs that are assigned with specificity A, are assigned; as a result 184 pairs are assigned. As an example, unit 1 is interactable with units 4, 6, 8, 14, 22, and 28. 184 is one-third of 552 pairs of specificity C, so most of the conformations are compactly folded into a 7×7 square are expected to have interaction energy of about −12ε (1/3 of −36ε). Because pairs of specificity A are retained for specificity B, the native structure at low temperature is expected for specificity B as well as A.

For specificity A, reversible all-orn-none type transition between native and denatured are observed. With specificity C, compact (globular) but not specific conformations are stable at low temperatures. The globule-coil transition is reversible but of the diffuse type, as in helix-coil transition. Long-range interaction specificity is essential for all-or-none character of the transition. Specificity B is regarded as the most realistic of the three, stable at low temp and a transition to denatured state occurs quickly, again being all-or-none. In the cited report, transition was not reversible within time range of computer experiment, so the present paper assumes specificity B is a long-range interaction.

For short-range interaction the energy term is function of a bond angle of each unit. The bond angle is teh angle between two bond vectors, one pointing from (i − 1)th unit to the ith unit, and the other from ith unit to the (i + 1)th unit. Bond angle can thus be 90°, 180°, and 270° in the square conformation. The bond energy of the ith unit is lower by ε′ than two other possible cases of the value of the angle (i = 2,3,...,48). The Monte Carlo method is used. Four different ratios of values ε and ε′: (ε, ε′) = (0.75ε0,0.25ε0), (0.5ε0,0.5ε0), (0.25ε0,0.75ε0), and (0,0.25ε0). ε0 is the interaction energy, which will be used to defined the dimensionless temperature T* = kT/ε0. The case of (ε,ε′) = (ε0,0) is same as case of specificity B in previous paper.

For each ratio of ε and ε′, computer analysis of conformational changes were done for different T* values to learn the transition temperature T*m. Two different initial conformations are chosen at each temperature, the native and one that is 49 units of a straight line (representing denatured). After reaching T*m, more computer analysis is done at T* = T*m. Four figures show the plotted results of the analysis, for the four (ε,ε′). On the abscissa is a trial number, which is approximately proportional to physical time. The ordinate value reports the degree of the order of the system, each unit (−ε0) representing the interaction energy. A dashed line is drawn in the plot to indicate expected count m of short-range interaction energies at the high temp limit. At any finite temperatures average values of the count of short-range interaction energies are higher than these values. At low temperature T* = 0.3 for (ε, ε′) = (0.75ε0,0.25ε0), the folding into native conformation is not found within 150,000 trials; the lattice polymer is trapped in a local minimum with about m = 25 and cannot get out of it. For (ε, ε′) = (0.5ε0,0.5ε0), the folding into native conformation occurs at trial 60,000. For (ε, ε′) = (0.25ε0,0.75ε0), folding into native occurs quickly within 20,000 trials. And for For (ε, ε′) = (0,ε0), it is even more rapid.

At temps close to T*m both folding and unfolding occur as can be seen in one plot. The transitions are rare, indicating an all-or-none character in transition. With (ε, ε′) = (0.5ε0,0.5ε0), transitions occur more frequently and with (ε, ε′) = (0.25ε0,0.75ε0), they are so frequent that populations at intermediate states are as significant as those of completely folded or unfolded conformations. With (ε,ε′) = (0,ε0) there are no long-range interactions except for self-avoidance of the chain, and lattice value fluctuates around the average value of m = 34.

These results all shows that folding to native form is possible but could not happen when only long-range interactions with specificity B are assumed. Short-range interactions are required to accelerate the process. Giving greater weight to short-range accelerated folding. Another effect of the short range is to make the transition diffuse: in fact when only short-range interactions are involved, the transition is not one where there is clear line between native and denatured. Thus long-range interactions are essential for the all-or-none type transitions, which occur as fact.

mass spectrometry detectors

Wiza JL (1979) Nuclear Instr. Meth. 162, 587-601.

Microchannel Plate Detectors

An MCP is an array of about 104-107 miniature electron multipliers oriented parallel to one another. Channel diam are 10-100 µm and the length-to-diameter ratio (α) is about 40-100. Axes of the channle are normal or slightly biased (8° to surface). The skeleton is lead glass treated to optimize secondardy emission. Each channel is a continuous dynode acting as its own dynode resistor chain. A nichrome or inconel metalling coating on the front and back surfaces is connected to input and output electrodes. Total resistance is about 109 Ω between electrodes. Gain factors of 104-107 are achieved in ultra time resolution of < 100 ps. Spatial resolution is based on channel dimensions (diam. typically 12 µm) and interchannel spacings (15 µm center-to-center typically).

Detection of charged particles and photons is possible (X-ray and EUV for photons). Farnsworth (1930) provided the idea for this system but it was not until the 1960s until the first prototypes emerged. This followed with the development of glass fiber drawing technology with which to make microchannels. Multiple fibers are bonded together to construct the plate array.

Electron multiplier theory is well developed. A consideration is given to the angle of the channel to the normal. Consider a straight channel (exactly normal). The incident electron produced δ secondary electrons, and each of these produces δ secondaries. Thus the gain is G = δ The gain can be related as follows:

( AV )4Vα2/V
2αV0l / 2

where V is total channel voltage, V0 is initial energy of emitted secondary electron (~1 eV), α is the length-to-diameter ratio, and A is a proportionality constant such that δ = AVc½. Vc is electron collision energy in eV and A ~ 0.2. With increases in V, the secondary electron yield δ increases, since each collision occurs with higher Vc. Also the count of collisions must decrease so that there is an extremum in the G vs. V characteristic. There is also an extremum in α: for V = 1000 V, GM = 1635 and αM = 60. According to Guest αM = V / 22 = 45. In any case, a range of 40-60 is suitable for image intensification. The charge height pulse distribution shows that the statistics of the channel multiplication process approximate a negative exponential (plot log counts vs. channel number for a straight line). As for energies of emergent electrons with α=60 and V=1000 V, median energy is 32.5 eV with many having in excess of 100 eV. Increases in the gain are likely to cause positive ions in the high charge density region, typical when residual gas molecules are present or when desorbed from channel wall (ion feedback).

Suppression of ion feedback allows higher gains and the charge pulse height distribution changes from a negative exponential to quasi-Gaussian with full width half maximum of 108 or more (compared to 103-105 for the straight channel with no ion suppression). This shows space charge saturation at channel output. A state of dynamic equilibrium is reached as yields are not multipiled (δ ~ 1) when kinetic energy of electrons is reduced by wall interaction. Channel gain is thus limited by geometry and overall voltage: maximum gain from space-charge saturated channel for fixed V and α is proportional to channel diameter. While a 1 mm channel saturates at 108, and 10 µm one saturates at 106. That MCPs with typical 25 µm pores have gains slightly above 106 verifies theory here. Pulse height distributions that have a negative exponential do not permit the use of a channel for counting since they are sensitive to shifts in gain.

Ion feedback suppression can be achieved simply by curving the channel. The chevron is typically used, formed from the use of two juxtaposed plates. The bias angle is either 8°/8° or 0°/15°., large enough to inhibit positive ion formation at end of the channel. The plates themselves are separated by 50-150 µm and each has its own voltage for gains of 104. Gains of 107 or better are achieved with the chevron because the number of excited channels increases between plates 1 and 2.

Other attempts to reduce ion feedback include use of angled electrostatic fields created by channel walls with insulating strips. These strips become charged however with a time-dependent reduction in gain.

colorimmetric protein assay

Hazra AK, Chock SP, Albers RW (1984) Anal. Biochem. 137, 437-443.

Protein Determination with Trinitrobenzene Sulfoate, A Method Relatively Independent of Amino Acid Composition

Fluorescence and spectrophotometric techniques can be susceptible to variability in fluorescence yields and stability of amino acid derivatives. Although a precision ninhydrin continuous flow method has been reported, ninhydrin is sensitive to oxygen and can produce the same molar absorbance with ammonia and an amino acid. 2,4,6-trinitrobenzene sulfonate (TNBS) is well known for primary determination of primary amines and is used in protein determination here. Unlike other methods, the one used in protein hydrosylates here is independent of amino acid composition and uses a method with short hydrolysis time.

For this method the Pierce Chemical amino acids standard kit 22 and Sequanal-grade constant boiling HCl. Fatty acid-free BSA and other proteins were used here. Grade I and II TNBS from Sigma is used; grade II is yellowish in color becomes white with crystallization. Recrystallization is done with 1-25 g TNBS dissolved in one part water (w/w) by heating. HCl (1.18 spec grav 1.18) is added to about 2 M. Crystalline solid emerges with cooling and is washed on filter with cold 1 M HCl and dried in dessicator. The following reagents are prepared: (1) 0.25 M borate buffer, made with 9.54 g Na2B4O7 • 10 H2O in 100 ml (crystals might fall out of solution over time and are re-dissolved by warming and stirring); (2) 2.5 M NaOH, 10 g NaOH in 100 ml; (3) 0.2 M KH2PO4, made as 2.72 g per 100 ml. (4) TNBS in borate buffer: 35 mg recrystalled TNBS is added to 1 ml of 0.25 M borate buffer just before use. (5) Reagent A: a mix of 20 vols 0.25 M borate to 1 vol 2.5 M NaOH; (6) Reagent B: To 100 ml of 0.2 potassium phosphate add 62.5 mg K2SO3, just before use. The following steps are carried out in the standard procedure:

  1. Samples of protein from 25-100 µg are placed in 6×50 mm borosilicate glass and dried in centrifugal evaporator.
  2. Add 100 µl constant boiling HCl
  3. Flush tube and seal with nitrogen
  4. Heat for 1 h at 145° in aluminum heating block.
  5. Centrifuge for 1 min at 1000 rpm to settle the HCl from the side of the tube.
  6. Transfer a 3-5 µl aliquot (equivalent to 3-5 µg) from hydrolysis tube to 10 × 75 mm plastic or borosilicate tube and dry down in centrifugal vacuum evaporator.
  7. To each tube, add 100 µl of Reagent A.
  8. Follow this quickly with 5 µl of fresh TNBS reagent.
  9. After 10 min, add 900 µl of Reagent B
  10. Read absorbance at 416 nm. The yellow color is stable for several hours at room temperature.

For the micro method, it similar to the standard method with the following notes and points:

  1. Using 1-10 µg, add only 10 µl HCl to the container.
  2. Do not transfer the hydrolysate to a separate tube: rather dry the hydrolysate down entirely to evaporate the HCl and other volatiles.
  3. Reagent A and TNBS reagent are added as above.
  4. Transfer the volume after yellow color development to 10 × 75 mm tube containing 800 µl reagent B. Rinse hydrolysis tube with 100 µl Reagent B to get the balance and transfer to get the 1 ml volume.

In addition a fluorescamine method by Stowel et al was used. Also the Markwell et al modification of the Lowry protein method was used.

proline-rich phosphoproteins

Saitoh E, Isemura S, Sanada K (1985) Arch. Oral Biol. 30, 641-643.

Inhibition of Calcium-Carbonate Precipitation by Human Salivary Proline-Rich Phosphoproteins

Human saliva contains proline-rich proteins (PRP) I, II, III, and IV and also staherin. These proteins inhibit calcium phosphate precipitation or crystal growth, keeping it super-saturated. In the early 70s, lyophilized parotid saliva was dissolved in 50 mM TrisHCl pH 8.0 with 50 mM NaCl and purified over DEAE-Sephadex A-25 and then purity checked on anionic polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. To measure precipitation rates, 5 ml of 20 mM CaCl2 is mixed with 5 ml 20 mM sodium bicarbonate pH 8.7 and 50 µl of PRP or water control is added and absorbance at 570 nm measured (pH can also be monitored). Another test system mimicking saliva conditions can be used to measure precipitation. In PRP absence, absorbance is increased and pH decreased rapidly. With PRP IV added, absorbance increases are markedly reduced. The absorbance-vs-time curve was shifted to the right. PRP III also prevented nucleation and precipitation was in progress.

codon usage

Sharp PM, Li W-H (1987) Nucl. Acid Res. 15, 1281-1295.

The codon adaptation index - a measure of directional synonymous codon usage bias, and its potential applications

There is a clear bias in the use of codons where multiple codons can specify a single amino acid, indicating no randomness. McLachlan had quantified this with a codon preference bias. Sharp et al. proposed using the chi square value as a measure of the deviation from randomness and scaling that to gene length (total number of codons) to permit comparisons between genes.

It is clear that any nonrandom pattern of codon preference in any particular gene is determined by natural selection and mutation. Selection pressure comes from translational efficiency. Where expression of genes is at a high level, there appears to be the greatest synonymous use of codons. Differences in codon usage that are detected in highly expressed genes are likely attributable to differences in translational efficiency. We construct a table of relative synonymous codon usage (RSCU) values specific to highly expressed genes: an RSCU value for a codon is the observed frequency of that codon divided by the frequency expected given equal usage:

RSCUij = xij
1 Σni j=1 xij
ni

where xij is the count of occurrences of the jth codon for the ith amino acid, and ni is the count (from 1 to 6) of the alternative codons of the ith amino acid. The relative adaptivness of a codon, wij, is the frequency of use of a codon compared to the frequency of the optimal codon for an amino acid:

wij = RSCUij / RSCUimax − xij / ximax

where RSCUimax and ximax are the RSCU and x are values for the most frequently used codons for the ith amino acid.

27 genes from E. coli were identified as highly expressed, including 17 ribosomal proteins, four outer membranes, and four elongation factors. 24 genes in yeast identified as highly expressed, including 16 ribosomal, one EF, and seven loci of very abundant enzymes.

The Codon Adaptation Index (CAI) for a gene is then determined to be the geometric mean of the RSCU values for each codon divided by the maximum possible CAI for a gene of the same amino acid composition:

CAI = CAIobs / CAImax

where

CAIobs = (ΠL k=1 RSCUk)1/L

CAImax = (ΠL k=1 RSCUkmax)1/L

where RSCUk is the RSCU value for the kth codon for the gen, RSCUkmax is the maxium RSCU value for the amino acid encoded by the kth codon in the gene, and L is the number of codons in the gene. The CAI for a codon never used in a reference set becomes zero if it appears in any other gene, and so xij is set to 0.5 to overcome this problem. The count of AUG and UGG codons are subtracted from L as RSCU values for these codons are fixed at 1.0 and do not factor into CAI.

An example of calculation can be seen with the rpsU from E. coli. There are 70 codons excluding the initiation codon, and sequence starts:

.CCG.GTA.ATT.AAA.GTA. . . . .

From a table of reference values, the following equations apply:

CAIobs = (3.288 × 1.111 × 0.466 × 1.596 × 1.111 × .....)1/70
CAImax = (3.288 × 2.244 × 2.525 × 1.596 × 2.244 × .....)1/70

Note that the equation for CAI = CAIobs/CAImax is equivalent to

CAI = (ΠL k=1 wk)1/L

where wk is the w value for the kth codon in the gene. Hence:

CAI = (1.00 × 0.495 × 0.185 × 1.000 × 0.495 × .....)1/70

A more computable value (to avoid real number underflow) is

CAI = exp [ (1/L) ΣL j=1 ln wk ]

There are parallels in CAI values and expression levels. Ribosomal genes are highly expressed and have high CAI values. The yeast ribosomal gene S33 is the only one with CAI < 0.6, but it is a very short gene (L = 65). Operons are a good example: expression levels for these operons are rpsU >> rpoD >> dnaG and the CAI values for genes are 0.726, 0.582, and 0.271, respectively. This is especially seen for the genes of the unc operon, in which 8 of the 9 genes code for subunits of the F0 and F1 assemblies of the H+-ATPase complex, and the CAI values rank in the same order as the levels of expression. One complex gene has a very low CAI, but it is a very short gene.

Experimental evidence exists that codon usage affects expression level. AGG codon use has been shown to control translation rate in E coli. For a heterologous gene to achieve maximal expression in any host, codon usage in that host is important. CAI is only an approximate indicator of codon suitability in synthetic selection.

Viral genes have no difficulty expressing themselves as foreign genes in hosts.

laser desorption/ionization multiphoton ionization, mass spectrometry

Grotemeyer J, Schlag EW (1988) Organic Mass Spectrom. 23, 388-396.

Peptides Investigated by Laser Desorption-Multiphoton Ionization Mass Spectrometry

Multiphoton ionization (MUPI) is a means of producing ionized molecules for the MS, useful in chemical analysis and ion chemistry. Resonance-enhanced multiphoton ionization (REMPI) is but a form of this useful in soft ionization. Laser desorption is used as the means of producing gas phase molecules using infrared (IR) photons. A pulsed IR laser produces rapid heating before decomposition can occur. Because more neutrals than ions are formed in the process (by 10,000:1), a better ionization technique is used. Peptides are molecules of interest in this case. MUPI combines the possibility of soft ionization and tuning the fragmentation intensity. Gas phase neutrals absorb two photons with the energy rather small (wavelength-dependent), optimized to produce an ion with mininal fragmentation. Other adjustments include laser intensity; power density increases clearly affect fragmentation.

The mass spectrometer is a laser desorption, laser ionization, and reflection ToF MS. Samples are dissolved in solvent (typically MeOH) and deposited on a probe tip. The probe tip is mounted in vacuum after solvent evaporation close to pulsed valve nozzle. An LP30 CO2 laser provides IR photons, and desorbed neutrals are injected into supersonic beam of noble gas emitted from nozzle of pulsed valve. The beam passes through a Lambda Physics FL 2001 pulsed, frequency-doubled dye laser pumped by a Lambda Physics EMG 102. The right wavelength is selected to excite appropriate to intermediate level. Ionization efficiency is 0.1-10%, where impact ionization methods would have a lower efficiency of 0.01-0.5%. The wavelength used was 2681 Å close to 0-0 transition of π-electrons of toluene.

Mass spectra were obtained for pure dipeptides Leu-Phe and Gln-Phe in 1:1 mixture. Most intense signals aer m/z 278 and 293 for the parent ions. Ionization is formed by absorption of two photons, and fragmentation induced by third photon, something that can be optimized. With fragmentation there is a [M-H2O]+ at m/z 240 formed from Leu-Phe, with additional signals at m/z 87 and 86.

[more to be read on this paper]

capillary zone electrophoresis (CZE)

Huang X, Gordon MJ, Zare RN (1988) Anal. Chem. 60, 1837-1838.

Current-Monitoring Method for Measuring the Electroosmotic Flow Rate in Capillary Zone Electrophoresis

One method for measuring EOF is by the use of uncharged (electrically neutral) marker solute that has no interaction with the silica capillary wall and which can be detected with the current systems. Another is to measure the mass of electrolyte moved from inlet to outlet over a timed interval, but this requires a digital balance and means to prevent evaporation. Another means is to record the time history of current in the CZE. A circuit diagram below shows how to set up the measuring system: 

                ___________
               |           |
    +----------| HV Supply |-----------------------------+
    |          |___________|                             |
    |                                                    |
    |                                                    |
    | Pt                                                 |
    |wire                                                |
    |        ________________________  Pt                |
    |       | ______________________ | wire   10k ohm    |
    |______ ||     capillary        || ______/\/\/\/\____+
           |||                      |||     |resistor|   |
         ! |||!                    !|||!    |        | -----
         ! |""!                    !""|!    |        |  ---
         !____!                    !___!   _|________|_  - ground
                                          |signal/chart|
           R1                        R2   |  recorder  |
                                          |____________|

Two reservoirs R1 and R2 hold the capillary. Polarity must be chosen so that the EOF is from R1 to R2: this usually means that the R1 electrode is positive because uncoated caps cause flow toward the cathode. The capillary is filled with a buffer at concentration C and this is placed in R2. R1 is filled with the same buffer but at concentration C′. During CZE, the tube filled with C will change to C′, and so will the electrical resistance in the tube. The current I can be followed. A resistor of 10 kΩ (2 W) is inserted between the R2 electrode and the ground: the use of the 10 kΩ resistor means a 1 µA current change produces a 10 mV potential drop across the resistor. A signal or chart recorder is connected across the resistor. A difference between C and C′ need not be great (as little as 5%). C is 20 mM sodium phosphate pH 7 and C′ is 0.95C. The power supply can deliver 19-21 kV and the capillary is 75 µm × 63 cm, which creates a current of 40 µA.

The results show that the current falls with time as the electrolyte C is displaced with C′. If EOF is reversed, then there is no current change. The time interval Δt is the time required for EOF from R1 to fill the capillary. The EOF, veo is essentially L / Δt, the capillary length divided by the time.

Is EOF a function of electrolyte concentration (or the difference between the reservoirs? In a first experiment R1 was given C and R2 and the capillary C′. The current trace was not different than before the concentrations were reversed. EOF could also be assessed by evaluating conductivity changes as a function of time: there was no difference between conductivity changes and current changes. Pyridine was also placed as a neutral marker and the UV followed. With a field strength of 300 V/cm and the R1, R2 and capillary filled with identical buffer the appearance of the UV peak indicated an EOF of 0.15 cm/s. The same result was found for different concentrations placed in R1 and R2 and in the capillary as indicated above when the neutral marker was used but was 0.015 cm/s for the current-monitoring method.

laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry

Karas M, Hillenkamp F (1988) Anal. Chem. 60, 2299-2301.

Laser Desorption Ionization of Proteins with Molecular Masses Exceeding 10,000 Daltons

Correspondence. For bioorganic molecules greater than 10,000 Da plasma desorption mass spectrometry (PDMS) has been the usual. Tanaka et al showed laser desorption of proteins up to a mass of 34,000 Da of lysozyme. A pulsed nitrogen laser with metal powder matrix was used, finely dispersed in glycerol.

In this process reflector-type ToF MS with Q-switched quadrupole Ng-Yag laser (10 ns pulse, 266 nm wavelength, with 10-50 µm spot diameter. Samples are dissolved in water at 10 µM. 1 µl (10 pmol) of samples is mixed with 1 µl 1 mM nictonic acid. The sample covered about 5 mm2 on a metallic substrate. Laser shots are aimed at one spot 20-50 times (collected over 2-5 min, at 10 scans/min or one per 6 seconds, with 1 Hz firing rate). Data collection was also limited by the PC data acquisition rate. A LAMMA 1000 was used with microprobe for inorganic and organic in the low mass range. Ion kinetic energy is 3 keV and postacceleration potential is 9000 V. For lysozyme (MW 14306) the velocity at the conversion electrode is 11000 m/s and lower for ions of higher mass; a minimum 17,000 m/s in PDMS work had been found necessary to detect insulin. A Biomation transient recorder with acquisition memory of 2048 channels (very low time resolution in high mass range) was used, which limits mass calibration accuracy. Calibration was with sodium and matrix signals in the low mass range.

Spectra of hen egg white lysoszyme, bovine milk β-lactoglobulin A, and bovine albumin were obtained. The effective mass range was controlled by an analog-to-digital time resolution of 200 ns/channel from m/z 0 to 16,000. For higher mass molecules, a time lag is imposed before detection is turned on, or the detector is adjusted to reduce time resolution. In addition to the molecular ion (M+), a dimer and a doubly charged ion, as well as a 3M2+ signal in the lysozyme spectrum, and also found in the lactoglobulin spectrum. Peak centroids are marked on the m/z scale of the raw spectra. For porcine trypsin a 500 ns/channel time resolution was used.

Results show that laser desorption will produce ions in a mass range inaccessible to PDMS. Multiply charged ions are observed in all spectra, something not seen in LDI. These are common in PDMS for high mass proteins, indicating the stability of charge centers rather than anything in the excitation mechanism. The FWHM of ion peaks is larger than expected for the mass resolution of 600 in the low mass range. A resolution of the molecular ion signal expected to show both protonated and cationized species is not possible, but due partly to low time resolution of the recorder (one channel of 200 ns is 15 Da in a 14000 Da protein).

peptide, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), circular dichroism (CD)

Fry DC, Byler DM, Susi H, Brown EM, Kuby SA, Mildvan AS (1988) Biochemistry 27, 3588-3598.

Solution Structure of the 45-Residue MgATP-Binding Peptide of Adenylate Kinase As Examined by 2-D NMR, FTIR, and CD Spectroscopy

Peptide 1-45 is the synthetic N-terminal sequence of the rabbit muscle adenylate kinase (catalyzes MgATP + AMP ⇔ MgADP + ADP) which binds the MgATP substrate. Proton NMR was used and the binding of MgATP was confirmed using time-dependent intramolecular NOEs. Cr(III)-ATP was used as a paramagnetic T1 probe as well as intermolecular NOEs were used together to show the interaction sites. This information was used to place MgATP within the solved crystal structure of the porcine enzyme. Recent development of 2D-NMR methods allows solution structure determination of up to 100 amino acid long polypeptides. Peptide at 4-5 mM in 150 mM NaCl and 40 mM 2-mercaptoEtOH in 90:10 water:D2O at pH 5.6 was made into a 400 µl volume for NMR work: the peptide was made 1:1 with MgATP when it was present. COSY and NOESY were done at 500 MHz: a 90° pulse with sweep widths of 4386 Hz in both dimensions, collecting 512 FIDs each with 2000 data points for COSY or 256 FIDs with 1000 data points for NOESY. For each FID there were 128 (COSY) or 208 (NOESY) transients plus two dummy transients with 230 ms (COSY) and 120 ms (NOESY) per transient. A 900 ms relaxation delay precedes each transient. H2O resonance was suppressed by direct irradiation at 10 dB below 200 mW durin the relaxation delay, and at 50 dB below 200 mW during mixing time in NOESY. Mixing time of 400 ms in NOESY allows NOE development and varied randomly ±5% to avoid COSY-type cross peaks. The 2D data were zero-filled to final size of 2000 × 2000 points for COSY and 1000 × 1000 for NOESY, the Fourier-transformed, using multiplication by unshifted sine-bell functions in both dimensions.

Peptide was made up at 8.4 mM in the same NaCl-reducing buffer in a 50 µl volume. Samples were made up in D2O using lyophilization twice. Spectra were collected at 29.5±1° using variable path cell with CaF2 windows with path of 75 µm. Interferometer: Nicolet 7199 with water-cooled Globar source and wide range MCT (Hg/Cd/Te) detector. 4000 interferograms were co-added, phase-corrected, zero-filled one time, apodized with Happ-Genzel function, and Fourier-transformed. Nominal resolution was 2 cm-1. CD spectra were acquired at 25 ± 1° C using Jasco 41C spectropolarimeter calibrated with d-10-camphorsulfonic acid. 0.5 mg/ml peptide in 0.15 M NaCl was placed in 20 mm path cylindrical cell. 16 scans from 260-185 nm with sensitivity of 0.005 deg/cm were obtained with 1 s time constant, 0.2 nm spectral step, and 2 nm bandwidth.

Results. Fig 1 shows 1 D NMR of the 1-45 peptide. Fig 2 is the COSY spectrum zoomed in on the aliphatic region. Peak assignments were aided by 1D spectrum particularly through a full pH range titration, and also by 1D and 2D spectra of peptide 31-45 reported by us earlier. Table 1 shows all the chemical shift assigments for every proton in the peptide. A secondary structure map is shown from the results of NMR with and without the MgATP. NOESY spectra pfovide the information about distant bond interactions.

From FTIR, the amide I band shows 6-9 components, some detected only by curve fitting.

deglycosylation

E. Horvath, A. M. Edwards, J. C. Bell, and P. E. Braun (1989) J. Neurosci. Res. 24, 398-401.

Chemical Deglycosylation on a Micro-Scale of Membrane Glycoproteins With Retention of Phosphoryl-Protein Linkages

TFMS was obtained in 10 ml sealed ampules and cooled in dry ice before opening. Anisole was stored over molecular sieve at −70°. Samples of protein (5-50 µg) are precipitated with 15% TCA, then acetone washed, then thoroughly dried in dessicator. 5 µl anisole and 45 µl TFMS are added, samples nitrogen flushed, and tightly capped. After vortexing they are left on ice 2 h. Ice cold diethyl ether (800µl) is added, samples left on dry ice 2 min, then pyridine added dropwise (100 µl).

mass spectrometry

Beavis RC, Chait BT (1990) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 87, 6873-6877.

Rapid, Sensitive Analysis of Protein Mixtures by Mass Spectrometry

A mixture of commercially purified proteins was analyzed by a user-built mass spectrometry system. The laser is a frequency tripled output of a Q-switched Lumonics HY400 Nd/Yt aluminum garnet laser (355 nm, 10 ns pulse). Product ions are accelerated in a 30 kV source into a 2 m tube in a 30 µPa vacuum.

small angle neutron scattering

Haris PI, Chapman D, Harrison RA, Smith KF, Perkins SJ (1990) Biochemistry 29, 1377-1380.

Conformational Transition Between Native and Reactive Center Cleaved Forms of α1-Antitrypsin by Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscropy and Small-Angle Neutron Scattering

Serpin family supermembers include many plasma proteinase inhibitors and present reactive site as ideal substrate to target proteinases. The reaction produces a 1:1 complex of proteinase and inhibitor with reactive site cleaved (split). Crystal structures of the split form or α1-antitrypsin (a1-AT) show significant conformational change with Met-358 and Ser-359 at the split being 70 Å apart. FTIR provides information on secondary structure and has advantage over CD in that it provides a baseline, the spectrum is clearly resolved, and amide proton exchange rates can be monitored to show H-bonding identifications. Neutron scattering is more beneficial than X-ray scattering as sample transmission in pure 2H2O (2 mm path) is reduced only 3% in 1.8 M phosphate relative to 50 mM phosphate., while for X-rays (1 mm path) it is reduced 81% in 1.2 M phosphate. Combined results offer sufficient information to propose mechanism as to how split is stabilized.

a1-AT protein was dialyzed over 36 h in sodium phosphate ranging from 50 mM to 1.80 M in 100% 2H2O at 6° with four buffer changes. A Perkin-Elmer 1750 FTIR with TGS detector was used to see spectra along with P-E Model 7300 data station. 23-25 mg/ml a1-AT based on A280 = 5.4 (relative to 1% solution in 1 cm path) was scanned 400 times (1 h accumulation) at spectral rez = 4/cm with sample pathlength of 50 µm (teflon spacer). The Perkin-Elmer ENHANCE (Haris et al 1986) was used for spectral deconvolution and analogous to Kauppinen et al (1981) method using deconv. parameters σ = 8 and k = 2.25. Second derivative calculated over 13/cm range. Neutron scattering is done at 20° on small-angle scattering instrument D17 at Institut Laue Langevin with λ = 1.105 nm (wavelength spread Δλ/λ of 10%) and sample-detector distance of 3.396 m with Q range of 0.07-0.60/nm (Q = 4π sin θ / λ; 2θ = scattering angle. 2 mm-thick Hellma cells are used for data collection. Control data for scattering of buffer dialysate, cadmium, H2O, and empty Hellma quartz cell with measurement of sample and buffer transmissions. Radius of gyration RG and forward scattering at zero scattering angle I(0) were determined from plot of Gunnier equation: ln I(Q) = ln I(0) − RG2 Q2/3 in domain of Q from 0.15-0.58 per nm except for native a1-AT above 1.2 M phosphate, where it was 0.15-0.41 per nm.

Results. FTIR spectra show the amide I band maxima for native and split a1-AT at 1636 cm−1. Maximum at 1568-1570 cm−1 is -COO−1 side chain feature, while 1516 cm−1 generally is a Tyr side chain absorption. Both samples show an amide I band consistent with β-sheet. The split form contains additional features at 1650 and 1693 cm−1 seen in both high and low phosphate concentrations (0.05, 0.50, 0.80, 1.25, 1.60, and 1.80 M); these are revealed in second derivative spectra. Main β-sheet is seen in 1633-1634 cm−1 seen in native and split. Split form show more intense β-sheet and α-helix bands at 1694 and 1652 cm−1, with broader 1633 cm−1 band. Bands at 1650 and 1690 cm−1 have been attributed to α-helix and anti-parallel β-sheet, respectively. For native and split a1-AT weaker features are observed near 1646, 1662, and 1674-1682 cm−1. The feature at 1646 cm−1 is likely represenative of disordered structure. Turn structures are likely at 1662 and 1674-1682 cm−1, but overlap from β-sheet and 310 helices can occur. Deconvolution for resolution enhancement led to similar results. These FTIR data show significantly enhanced α-helical and β-sheet content with reactive site cleavage. Curve fitting of the amide I band absorption changes is not sufficiently accurate to do quantitative assessment of content differences. Crystal structure of split a1-AT reveals 32% α-helix and 40% β-sheet and suggests that strand A4 in native form is withdrawn from β-sheet. If 20-30 more H-bonds form in the split in a β-sheet structure, this would account for a greater strength at 1694 cm−1. Increased α-helix would not be expected. The crystal structure shows that helices A and B flank strand B6, helices D, E, and F alternate with strands A2, A1 and A3, and helices H and I flank strand A6. The infrared of the native form says either helices are not formed or they are distorted along length while at same time β-sheet is incompletely formed. But with splitting, there is a drive to tighter bonding of both helices and sheets.

The amide II band at 1552 cm−1 is a check on the 1H-2H exchange of backbone NH protons. Identical and simultaenous dialysis in 2H2O shows that the native is 15% lower than split form. Deconvoluted spectra show at 1550 cm−1 visible for split a1-AT but not native, showing exchange was more complete for native. This would be so if the split form represents a more closed, stable structure. 400 MHz 1H-NMR confirms this on the same samples: integration of spectra downfield of 195 aromatic proton signals show 11% of 377 NH protons are not exchanged in native a1-AT and 19% of protons were not exchanged in split form. Other NMR spectral differences include observation of narrower line widths in split form and rearranged patterns in ring current shifted methyl proton signals at high field end, both consistent with structural and dynamic differences.

For small-angle neutron scattering, plots of Gunnier RG and I(0)/cTs against phosphate concentration from 0.05 to 1.8 M were made, where c is also the variation in a1-AT from 3-12 mg/ml and Ts is sample transmission. Extrapolations to zero c are made. Up to 0.80 M phosphate, no differences can be seen between native and split forms. For hemoglobin, aspartate transcarbamylase, and hexokinase, conformational changes after ligation are seen from Gunnier analyses. Folded tertiary structures of native and split a1-AT are essentially similar, and an upper limit on structural changes in polypeptide backbone are seen in FTIR, CD, and NMR.

High phosphate concentrations are used in the crystallization of a1-AT, and so FTIR spectra are obtained at 1.25, 1.60, and 1.80 M phosphate. No significant diference at high concentrations and 0.05 and 0.50 M phosphate are seen. But neutron scattering data show that above 1 M phosphate the I(0)/c increase to double the low phosphate concentration values (see plots) for native form while unchanged in the split. This shows that native a1-AT will dimerize in 1.8 M phosphate. The RG rise in parallel for the native. Hence the presence of many amino acids on the surface of the native not seen in the split form is demonstrated.

FAB-MS, HLPC

van Breemen RB, Canjura FL, Schwartz SJ (1991) J. Chromatog. 542, 373-383.

High Performance Liquid Chromatography Continuous Flow Fast Atom Bombardment Mass Spectrometry of Chlorophyll Derivatives

Mass spectra have been acquired on chlorophylls with a variety of ionization techniques. Laser desorption, field desorption, plasma desorption, fast atom bombardment, and in-beam (desorption) electron impact. FAB is often preferred for MS/MS studies because of a continuous stream of ions produced, and it is the only one coupled to HPLC separations. In FAB, a solution of low volatility (high glycerol component) is bombarded with Xe or Ar atoms accelerated to 3-10 keV (in a variation, the fast atoms are subsituted for fast ions, called liquid secondary-ion MS). When coupled to HPLC, the elution from the HPLC column is mixed with a matrix suitable to promote FAB and then the mix is passed to the ion source. The matrix usually contains glycerol and the post-column mixing is preferred without the need to affect chromatographic methods. Effluent from HPLC is passed to fused silica capillary, through a stainless steel frit in the ion source for frit-FAB. The gun is aimed on the outflow frit end. Solvent from the frit rapidly evaporates and is pumped away from the system.

Chlorophyll from spinach leaves was extracted and measured. Incubation of leaves at 65° for 30 min activates the enzyme chlorophyllase, converting them to chlorophyllides a and b. These are extracted in acetone, and pheophytins extracted using Et-O-Et from the acidified chlorophyll extract. Pyropheophytins were obtained by extraction of spinach puree treated at 145° for 7 min.

HPLC was an ABi system using Vydac 2.1 × 150 mm C18 with 5 µm particles having a 300 Å pore. Flow was 70 µl/min. Positive-ion FAB spectra were obtained from JEOL JMS-HX110HF double-focusing MS employing an HPLC-frit-FAB-MS interface with 6 keV Xe atoms. Accelerating voltage is 10 keV with a resolution of 1000. Scanning of the m/z 300-1000 took 7 seconds; for pyropheophytins the scan time was 15 s. Profiling was recorded as continuum spectra, but HPLC-frit-FAB mode was centroided. Eluate from the HPLC was split so that a 5 µl/min flow entered the interface (14:1 split). Ion source temp was 40° to prevent solvent freezing on the frit.

Different matrices have been tried in the past for chlorophylls. 3-nitrobenzyl alcohol produces good M+ ions. [M+H]+ and [M-H]+ ions (protonated and deprotonated) are seen at lower relative abundance. DTT and DTE or thioglycerol are more acidic and produce effective protonation. Glycerol was used because of its proven compatibility and greater volatility than 3NBA. It is not useful for hydrophobic compounds nor in the standard probe used for FAB-MS of chlorophylls. Used with ethyl acetate and MeOH from the mobile phase the glycerol provided a suitable condition for ionization of a wide variety of chlorophyll degradation products.

[There is more to this paper that was not read largely because of absence of an FAB-MS system.]

chlorophyll, mass spectrometry

van Breemen RB, Canjura FL, Schwartz SJ (1991) J. Agric. Food Chem. 39, 1452-1456.

Identification of Chlorophyll Derivatives by Mass Spectrometry

salivary proteomics

Isemura S, Saitoh E, Sanada K, Minakata K (1991) J. Biochem. 110, 648-654.

Identification of Full-Sized Forms of Salivary (S-Type) Cystatins (Cystatin SN, Cystatin SA, Cystatin S, and Two Phosphorylated Forms of Cystatin S) in Human Whole Saliva and Determination of Phosphorylation Sites of Cystatin S

Saliva was collected in an ice-cold medium with lots of protease inhibitors A total of 10 ml per person was collected and pooled. Precipitation was with 4 vols cold MeOH. MeOH evaporated and the protein was lyophilized. Proteins were loaded to DE32 and gradient-eluted with a 100 × 100 mol A and B system where B contains 3% NaCl (~0.5 M NaCl). From this we ran polyacrylamide gels and transblotted to nitrocellulose. In some cases, we pre-treated with alkaline phosphatase before this work-up. Blots were then worked up with anti-cystatin S. Several bands were illuminated. In some cases bands were missing that had been treated with alkaline phosphatase, indicating a net loss of a negative charge (generally the phosphate).

It is well known that degradative enzymes are present in saliva that rapidly breakdown proteins. The N-terminal portions of cystatins are broken down rapidly in particular. Use of rapid precipitation techniques (MeOH) help to eliminate proteolytic activity.

Certain mammary gland casein kinases (including casein kinase II) have been proposed to phosphorylated sequences such as SX[E/S(p)] and SXX[E/S(p)], where the first serine gets phosphorylated, and the C-side residue is an anionic residue like glutamic acid or a phosphorylated serine.

Cystatin superfamily is composed of three familes (designated 1-3), distinguished by structural homology. Family 2 cystatin are secreted cysteine protease inhibitors which have two disulfide bonds and molecular weights of 15 kDa. Cystatins S, SA, and SN belong to family 2 and obtained from whole human saliva; these have about 90% sequence homology. Saliva also contains cystatin C as family 2 member with 50% homology to S type. Family 2 is composed of a multigene family: CST1 coding cystatin SN, CST2 coding cystatin SA, CST3 coding cystatin C, CST4 coding cystatin S and two pseudogenes, CSTP1 and CST5 (CSTP2). A 7th gene has been found but not its expression product.

silver staining

Rabilloud T (1992) Electrophoresis 13, 429-439.

A Comparison Between Low Background Silver Diammine and Silver Nitrate Protein Stains

SDS-PAGE was in 19 × 16 cm gels with 1.5 mm depth. A pH 8.5 330 mM TrisHCl resolving gel is used (compared to 375 mM pH 8.8 Laemmli). Stacking is a 250 mM BisTris pH 6.5, and electrode is 50 mM Tris, 385 mM glycine, 0.1% SDS. Stacking is 4.5% T (2.6% C), and resolving is 10% T (2.6% C). For each 60 ml gel a 0.5 ml 10% APS (0.83%) and 25 µl TEMED (0.04%) is used. Gels stained with diammine are prepared with PDA crosslinker using thiosulfate initiator (0.5 ml 10% thiosulfate pentahydrate), 0.5 mL 10% APS, and 50 µl TEMED.

Gel staining was 250 ml per gel except for the silver diammine (100 ml for gel), with plastic trays used.

Acidic silver methods tested are divided into fast and long (> 5 h) methods. Fast methods are those of Merrill et al. (in Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis of Proteins, Celis and Bravo, eds., Academic Press: Orlando FL, pp 93-109, 1984), Hempelmann et al (Electrophoresis '84, Neuhoff, ed., Verlag Chemie: Weinheim, pp 328-330, 1984), Johansson and Skoog (J. Biochem. Biophys. Methods 14 Suppl.: 33, 1987), Morissey (Anal. Biochem. 117: 307-310, 1981), Doucet and Trifaro (Anal. Biochem. 168: 265-271, 1988), Blum et al. (Electrophoresis 8: 93-99, 1987), and Rabilloud et al (Electrophoresis 9: 288-290, 1988). Long methods, usually requiring overnight fixation and extensive washing (to remove sensitizing agent typically), are those in the family of Heukeshoven and Dernick (Electrophoresis Forum '86, Radola, ed. Technische Universität: München, pp 22-27, 1986). Typical modifications use of double the amount of silver nitrate (0.2% instead of 0.1%) with doubled incubation times, and potassium carbonate instead of sodium carbonate with hypo included in the developer, and the use of Tris-acetate as a stop instead of disodium EDTA for extended times. The method of Sammons et al (Electrophoresis 2: 135-141, 1981) gave a consistently low level yellow background and was not tested further.

Silver diammine methods are based on that of Oakley et al (Anal. Biochem. 105: 361-363, 1980) and have been dramatically improved (see Hochstrasser, Patchornik, and Merril, Anal. Biochem. 173: 412-423, 1989; and Hochstrasser and Merril, Appl. Theor. Electrophoresis 1: 35-40, 1989). As a basis, Hochstrasser and Merril's method was used as a basis. Additional tested methods are Marshall and Latner (Electrophoresis 2: 228-235, 1981), Wray et al. (Anal. Biochem. 118: 197-203, 1981), and Mold et al. (Anal. Biochem. 135: 44-47, 1983). Fixation, the presence or absence of sensitizing steps (and the use of different agents such as glutaraldehyde), the use of methylamine or ammonium hydroxide as the amine complexing agent, and large variations on rinsing after fixation are the variations of these methods. Strictly consistent features of these methods are use of HCHO and citric acid in the developer and a high (0.8%) silver nitrate concentration and NaOH as the alkalinizer in the silvering step. The stop is usually 5% acetic acid in 20% EtOH, although one uses tris-acetate.

Note of the seven fast method protocols, the first three protocols listed were plagued by low sensitivity or high backgrounds or both (even with thiosulfate addition as a means to prevent high backgrounds), and so more extensive testing was limited to the latter four protocols.

In the initial stages, the sensitivity of silver staining methods were tested. The detection limiits of typical marker proteins were determined.

Detection limits bv silver staining for marker proteins†
Myosinβ-GalactosidasePhosphorylase Bovine Serum AlbuminOvalbuminCarbonic Anhydrase
All values in nanograms
Doucet and Trifaro 20 20 10 5-10* 20 10
Blum et ul. 5 5 10 10 10 10
Rabilloud et al. 2-5* 2-5* 5 5 10 10
Morrissey 20 20 20 10 20 10
Heukeshoven and Dernick 5 5 10 5 5 10
Tetrathionate method (H & D variant) 2 2 2 2 5 10
Wray et a1. 10 5 10 5 10 10
Modification of Mold et al. 2 1 1 2 2 50
Hochstrasser et al. 2 1-2* 1-2* 2 2 5
† The sensitivities ares expressed in ng detected in this gel system. The bands are ca. 8 × 2 mm; the sensitivities given here should therefore be divided by 16 to obtain the ng/mm2, so that 10 ng correspond to 625 pg/mm2. As the gels are 1.5 mm thick, a 10 ng detection corresponds to a 57 pg/mm2 (57 ng/mL).
* indicates when the results are highly variable from gel to gel. This variability seems greater in the high molecular weight region owing to a more intense background development. This background seems to be linked to several factors, including the cleanliness of the combs, whichs seems difficult to keep at a sufficient level owing to adsorption to the plastic. The detection limits for soybean trypsin inhibitor are not given since the protein migrates too close from the dye front to allow correct separation and estimation.

The least successful methods are those using DTT as a sensitizing agent. Yellow to red backgrounds appear (Doucet and Trifaro and the Morrissey methods). Adding thiosulfate to developer only partially relieves problem. Blum et al. and Rabilloud et al methods were best, although latter gives blacker bands.

Long silver nitrate methods give superior results although are prone to surface staining and formation of dark precipitates from silver carbonate. Hollow spots form which can be corrected by increasing the silver nitrate, decreasing the rinse between silver nitrate and developer, and adding 10 mg/L thiosulfate to developer.

The silver diammine methods gave the best results although original methods gave point streaks (rainy) gels. This is prevented by using alkylating the thiol reagent present in sample buffer (iodoacetamide is superior to iodoacetic acid). When sensitizers are not used, poorer sensitivity is seen. Use of naphthalene-2,7-disulfonicc acid instead of aldehyde works well (but one marker protein had its sensitivity reduced considerably, which means certain proteins may not be detected).

When small and/or basic peptides must be visualized formaldehyde, and not alcohol-acid, fixation is required, and a silver diammine method should be used.

2D electrophoresis of acidic, neutral, and basic proteins was also tested. Even the fast method performed as well as the longer. All did well for acidic and neutral proteins, with apparent higher sensitivity of silver diammine methods. Basic proteins were much better detected with silver diammine staining, giving darker spots and less hollow staining.

The hollowness of staining appears to be dependent on silver concentration, being high for 0.1% silver nitrate, moderate for 0.2% levels, and very low when diammine methods which typically use 0.4-0.8%, given a long development period (hollowness appears at first, then the spots darken as development continues).

protein identification, 2D gel electrophoresis, sequence databases

Henzel WJ et al. (1993) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 90, 5011-5015.

Identifying Proteins From Two-Dimensional Gels by Molecular Mass Searching of Peptide Fragments in Protein Sequence Databases

protein identification

Mann M, Hojrup P, Roepstorff P (1993) Biol. Mass Spectrom. 22, 338-345.

Use of Mass Spectrometric Molecular Weight Information To Identify Proteins in Sequence Databases

protein identification

Pappin DJC, Hojrup P, Bleasby AJ (1993) Curr. Biol. 3, 327-332.

Rapid Identification of Proteins by Peptide-Mass Fingerprinting

mass fingerprinting

James P, Quadroni M, Carafoli E, Gonnet G (1993) Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 195, 58-64.

Protein Identification by Mass Profile Fingerprinting

peptide mass maps, protein identification

Yates JR III, Speicher S, Griffin PR, Hunkapiller T (1993) Anal. Biochem. 214, 397-408.

Peptide Mass Maps: A Highly Informative Approach to Protein Identification

MALDI analysis, mass accuracy

Vorm O, Mann M (1994) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 5, 955-958.

Improved Mass Accuracy in Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry of Peptides

ABSTRACT. One problem of matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization coupled to time-of-flight mass spectrometry is the moderate mass accuracy that typically can be obtained in routine applications. Here we report improved mass accuracy for peptides, even when low amounts and complex peptide mixtures are used. A new procedure for preparing matrix surfaces is used, and there is no need to mix the matrix with the sample or to add internal standards. Examples are shown with a mass accuracy better than 50 ppm in a peptide mixture. Peptide mapping as well as sequencing by creating "ragged ends" or "ladder sequencing" should benefit especially from the improved mass accuracy.

zinc-peptide interaction, fragmentation, FD

Loo JA, Hu P-F, Smith RD (1994) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 5, 959-965.

Interaction of Angiotensin Peptides and Zinc Metal Ions Probed by Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry

1-10 mM ZnCl2 was added to a 50-100 pmol/µl (µM) solution of angiotensin II (FW = 1046, DRVYIHPF) at pH 6. The peptide bound one Zn2+ from the appearance of mass spectra. In some cases two Zn ions were bound. Angiotensin I (FW=1296, DRVYIHPFHL) has two His residues; it also has one Zn residue binding with some proportion having two bound Zn ions. Complex stoichiometry follows the formula [M + aZn2+ + (c − 2a)H+]c+ where c is the charge. At pH 6-7 the metal complex formation is at its highest, but falls off at the extremes (pH 3 or 10). Association with Zn can actually be identified since Zn has many isotopes with known natural abundance, and this can be used as a fingerprint.

Protonated and metal-bound peptides were subjected to collisionally activated dissociation. CAD of [M + 2H]2+ angiotensin II shows a series of an/bn singly charged products in both a low energy collision (triple quad) and higher energy collision (Finnigan MAT 900 double focusing forward geometryMS) CAD of the [M + Zn]2+ ion produces primarily [b6 + Zn]2+/[a6 + Zn]2+ pair also with ions formed by water loss.

Zn also influences the fragmentation. Protonated +2 and +3 angiotensin I produce +1 and +2 fragments along the entire backbone. The CAD spectra of [M + Zn]2+ at m/z 681 produces an ion at m/z 615 which is [b9 + Zn]2+, the most abundant product; ion [b6 + Zn]2+ is also observed. The fragmentation of His9-Leu10 is favored over that of His6-Pro7. This is probably related to a preferential binding of Zn to the His whose fragmentation is induced by the binding. When [Ala6]-angiotensin II is used instead, the Ala6-Pro bond is only one fragmentation site in the presence or absence of Zn ion. In contrast to [Ala6-angio II + Zn]2+, the acidified ion [Ala6-angio II + 2H]2+ produces abundant b6+ and b62+ ions. Substance P, lacking His (RPKPQQFFGLM-nh2), shows the same fragmentation pattern whether associated with Zn or protonated form for the 2+ ion. Protonated species produce singly and doubly charged a7, a8, b9, a10, and b10. Zn-assocation produces [b10 + Zn − H]+ ions of same type.

Some have said that the amide X—Pro bond is susceptible to fragmentation in multiply charged ions under CAD conditions. The process may not be favored if X is a positively charged residue such as Arg, Lys, His. Pro may not play a significant role in the [b6 + Zn]2+ ion formation: substitution of Pro7 for Ala7 produces a fragmentation pattern similar to the unsubstituted with Zn present.

One ion is a water-loss product, accounting for 30% of ions in the Zn-angio II complex. Water loss product is also significant in CAD spectra of angiotensin I and of [Ala6]-angiotensin II in Zn presence. Water loss comes from the N-terminal Asp residue. This does not happen with Substance P, which has no N-terminal Asp. Without Zn, a [M − H2O + Zn]2+ ion is not observed. The acidified/protonated form alone shows no water loss product. Note that with the Ala6 subsitution, Zn probably moves to another more preferable binding site (N-terminal Asp), and water loss ensues with metal presence. Tests of other N-terminal formations (acetylated-Asparate) did not yield water loss.

Consider the nature of peptides and proteins and the metals they bind. Histidine is a component of many metal-binding proteins, coordinating imidazole nitrogens around the metal. Consider the angiotensin structure. One of the imidazole nitrogens coordinates with Zn, and carbonyl oxygens from proline and from the preceding amino acid also coordinate with their nonbonding pairs on the oxygens. This folds the peptide in a way that entropy favors fragmentation to a b-type ion. A bidentate formation of the two His to Zn could occurs with angiotensin I (suggested by NMR). The pair a62+/b62+ forms very weakly compared to a92+/b92+ from angiontensin I [M + Zn]2+ resulting from the bidentate coordination, promoting formation of latter pair and inhibiting formation of former.

mobile proton theory, CID, peptide fragmentation, FD

Downward KM, Biemann K (1994) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 5, 966-975.

The Effect of Charge State and The Localization of Charge on The Collision-Induced Dissociation of Peptide Ions

ABSTRACT. The effect that charge state has on the collision-induced dissociation (CID) of peptide ions is examined in detail for several representative peptides under high-energy collision conditions. The CID spectra of singly and doubly charged precursor ions (generated by fast-atom bombardment and electrospray ionization, respectively) are compared for several peptides with similar primary structure. It is shown that for peptides that contain highly basic amino acids, the dissociation of doubly charged ions is strongly influenced by the position of these residues within the peptide and the general observations reported concerning the dissociation of singly charged ions can be extended to precursors with higher charge states. Based on the dissociation behavior of the doubly charged ions of these peptides, it is demonstrated that two charges can reside in close proximity in the precursor ions, overcoming possible repulsion effects, when favored by a high concentration of basic sites. In addition, this work illustrates that in the case of doubly charged ions, the charge state of some fragment ions can be determined directly from the mass-to-charge ratio assignments of the CID spectrum.

Eng JK, McCormack AL, Yates JR 3rd (1994) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 5, 976-989.

An Approach To Correlate Tandem Mass Spectral Data of Peptides With Amino Acid Sequences in A Protein Database

ABSTRACT. A method to correlate the uninterpreted tandem mass spectra of peptides produced under low energy (1050 eV) collision conditions with amino acid sequences in the Genpept database has been developed. In this method the protein database is searched to identify linear amino acid sequences within a mass tolerance of 1 u of the precursor ion molecular weight. A cross-correlation function is then used to provide a measurement of similarity between the mass-to-charge ratios for the fragment ions predicted from amino acid sequences obtained from the database and the fragment ions observed in the tandem mass spectrum. In general, a difference greater than 0.1 between the normalized cross-correlation functions of the first- and second-ranked search results indicates a successful match between sequence and spectrum. Searches of species-specific protein databases with tandem mass spectra acquired from peptides obtained from the enzymatically digested total proteins of E. coli and S. cerevisiae cells allowed matching of the spectra to amino acid sequences within proteins of these organisms. The approach described in this manuscript provides a convenient method to interpret tandem mass spectra with known sequences in a protein database.

Zhou HX, Lyu PC, Wemmer DE, Kallenbach NR (1994) J. Am. Chem. Soc. 116, 1139-1140.

Structure of A C-Terminal α-Helix Cap in A Synthetic Peptide

The end regions of an α-helix are critical since the amino acids are necessary to stabilize the helix. Amino acids within the center of the helix length would form H-bonds with NH and CO groups four residues away. It is therefore the case that the first and last four residues of a helix do not form the H-bonds required for helix formation. In globular proteins the mean length of alpha helices is 12 residues, meaning the majority of residues actually are end groups. To promote the helix stabilization, very flexible glycine residues interact with NH and CO groups and polar side chains.

This use of certain residues is known as helix capping. The capping stabilization has been demonstrated by sequence analysis and site-directed mutation of native proteins, and structual analysis of synthetic peptides. Perhaps the first evidence of capping was the observation of an unusual H-bond on the myoglobin C-terminal H-helix. Another report shows that one-third of helices end with residue in left-handed (αL) conformation. having φ and ψ angles > 0, promoted by Gly residues. Changing the C-cap from Gly to Ala destablizes the helix by 3.1 kcal/mol.

This report shows how the NH of the side chain of an Asn residue forms H-bond with helix main chain of CO four residues away. The 20-amino acid long synthetic peptide ac-YMSEDELKAAEAAFKRHxPT-nh2, where 'x' is a site for testing substitution of several amino acids, represents the consensus sequence of residues that make up the α-helix shown by Richardson and Richardson (Science 240: 1648, 1988). A local 310 helix at the C-terminus and the side chain H bonds in a loop. While it strengthens the helix, the formation of the loop also blocks helical continuation and more strongly than the Pro19 residue (shown by CD spectroscopy at 222 nm).

1H-NMR was used to examine how N18 significantly enhanced helicity compared to other substituted amino acids (Q, A, S, T, G). 2D TOCSY and NOESY experiments identify spin systems and sequential assignments. Each amide from residue 4 (Glu) links to the side chain NH of N18, and longer range bonding between CαH and amide NH from residue 5 to 14.

Three regions of the NOESY spectrum provide structure detail about the C-terminus. NOE cross peaks show C-cap structures involving N18 side chain. Two β protons of N18 have distinct chemical shifts, with one β′ proton closer to the peptide NH than the other β proton. The side chain amide proton is close to the CαH of F14. A ROESY experiment shows that weak peaks are not because of spin diffusion.. These NMR studies show H-bonding between CO of Lys 15 and NH of Asn 18, with possible bifurcation to CO of Phe 14 as well. Only Asn 18 side chain of NH bonds to CO of Phe 14. A weak NOE connect N18 backbone amide to β proton of His 17.

From the CD spectroscopy, order of helix stabilization for the X 18 site is N > Q > (A, S) > (T, G). Multiple interpretations are possible: Q H-bonding is less entropically favorable than N because of the extra methylene; Ala is still stabilizing at helix end, but not maximally; Ser and Thr can contribute a γ-proton to H-bond with CO of Phe 14, but there is no evidence; and Gly should be better than Ala at capping stabilization, although not shown for this peptide (it is possible that the presence of Pro affects the ability of Gly). The common feature in N- and C-caps seen so far is that H-bonds

tau protein, paired helical fragments (PHF), Alzheimer's disease

Schweers O, Schönbrunn-Hanebeck E, Marx A, Mandelkow E (1994) J. Biol. Chem. 269, 24290-24297.

Structural Studies of Tau Protein and Alzheimer Paired Helical Filaments Show No Evidence for β-Structure

Amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are features of the age-related dementia Alzheimer's disease. Both plaques and tangles arise from abnormally aggregated protein. Plaques contain Aβ peptide aggregated into fibers (Aβ peptide is membrane protein breakdown product) and tangles contain tau protein aggregated into PHFs. Abnormal protein formation and fibers are seen in other disease states as well, such as prion protein in scrapie or Creuztfeld-Jakob-Disease or fibers of systemic amyloidosis consisting of transthyretin. Aggregation might occur as a result of intermolecular β-sheet assembly. β-Amyloid and PHFs are very stable in interactions between interlocking β-strands. Moreover aggregation in vitro occurs where proteins adopt β-sheets in solution, as seen in CD and FTIR. β-Sheets also are seen in abnormal fibers by X-ray diffraction or FTIR. Alzheimer β-amyloid hve a cross β-structure where strands meander across fiber width such that a 4.7 Å reflection occurs on meridian of diffraction pattern corresponding to separation of strands. But not in all cases should it be assumed that fibrous aggregation is governed by similar mechanisms of formation. For example while transthyretin is composed mainly of β-sheet shown by x-ray crystallography, the interaction between subunits is mediated by thiols on the protein surface forming disulfides. Tau has only a negligible fraction of α- or β conformation, if any, similar to other microtubule-associated proteins (MAP2), a finding seen in tau isolated from brain or bacterial recombinant, and whether endogenously phosphorylated or free of it. Tau may acquire its β-stranding as a result of aggregation, which provides an interesting mechanism for PHF assembly. Amyloid fibers and PHFs co-exist in senile plaques, and so the cross-β pattern of tangle preparation could arise from the β-amyloid component, indicating that x-rays can pick out periodic structures even present only as contaminants.

Results. The domain structure of bovine brain tau is reviewed. CD shows little secondary structure, a finding also seen in E coli recombinant human tau. Boiled and dissolved in dilute acid, tau retains it microtubule assembly-promoting activity. All tau isoforms have large number of hydrophilic resides and prolines which are not usual for proteins compactly folded. Secondary structure prediction reports do not show significant structural features. Gel filtration analysis reveals that tau aggregates into dimers and higher order assemblies. Dimer association is anti-parallel, possible precursor to PHF formation. Electron microscopy is not informative on tau assemblies alone because of low contrast, but glycerol-spray rotary shadow technique shows elongated and flexible rod 35 nm long.

Small-angle X-ray scattering can determine overall molecular shape and internal structure. Scattering data were obtained for bovine tau isoform 4 (largest of isoforms) and a control lysozyme protein and plotted according to Gunnier (log I vs. s2 [nm−2]) and Kratky (I×s2 vs. s [nm−1]. The Gunnier plot shows for globular proteins like lysozyme a straight line from which a radius of gyration (RG) of 1.5 ± 0.05 nm is obtained. With tau there is a continuous curvature from which no RG value can be determined. This is also determined for tau domains (designated K0, K1, K2, and K12). The chain is this worm-like or described as Gaussian coil and not compacted to globular form. This approximates a denatured state. A Kratky plot of the scattering data shows three segments: a rise, a roughly horizontal region, and another rise. The segment 2-3 transition is a measure of persistence length of chain (1.97 nm).

Domain K12 contains two tyrosine residues (positions 310 and 394) and no tryptophan.
