Absorption of the phenol group depends on solution environment: changing the concentration of urea from 0 to 8 M shows no change in extinction coefficient, and spectrum between 240 and 310 is the same, indicating full exposure of Tyr residues to nonhydrophobic conditions in all cases.

Human tau isoform 23 and the K12 domains were observed in CD spectroscopy and the data show α-helical content of 0 and 10%, respectively, consistent with a previous report and of values so low as to be unreliable. Increasing temperature and ionic strength had no discernible effect on spectra. Increasing TFE, which is known to promote helix formation, to 50% increased K12 domain helix to 30% content. Spectra of monomers and cross-linked dimers

MALDI, analytical improvement techniques

Kallweit UK, Bönsen KO, Kresbach GM, Widmer HM (1996) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 10, 845-849.

Matrix Compatible Buffers for Analysis of Protein With Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Mass Spectrometry

The Linear Scientific (Hewlett-Packard) LDI-1700 mass spectrometer is used. Laser power is 2-3 µJ/pulse for the 337 nm laser, with 10 shots per spectrum in positive mode. DAHC is diammonium hydrogen citrate [NH4OOC-CH2-C(COOH)-CH2-COONH4], HIC is 1-hydroxyisoquinoline, DHAP is 2,6-dihydroxyacetophenone.

Formation of fine crystals with analyte embedded is ideal. 8 buffer with 5 different matrices were tested. Crystallization was characterized as excellent, good, difficult, or none using 5 different matrices (pure chemicals and combinations: 2,5-DHB, DHB/HIC, DHAP/DAHC, SA, SA/DAHC) in 50 mM of buffer salt (ACES, BES, HEPES, imidazole, MOPS, TES, Tris, phosphate). Phosphate made crystallization difficult with all matrices, and the DHAP/DAHC crystallized good only with MOPS, TES, and Tris. Sinapinic acid, DHB/HIC were good with all buffer salts not phosphate, and DHAC/SA was good with every one (except phosphate), and excellent with ACES, BES, and MOPS. 2,5-DHB was good or excellent with ACES, BES, imidazole and Tris, but not with MOPS or TES, and not at all with HEPES. The phosphate combination formed wet crystals. DAHC helps probably because it complex alkali ions or has a favorable lattice. Phosphate inclusion always resulted in bad signals.

BSA was dissolved to 10 µM in the buffers and 2 µl mixed with 2 µl of matrix, and 1 µl applied to probe tip and dried in vacuum for fast crystallization. For dealing with protein, sample is desalted by drop dialysis (5-20 µl drop on 25 nm pore Millipore MF for 30-60 min then removed and mix with matrix immediately). Or the following is done: Immobilon CD 4 mm dia. is soaked with MeOH and then water to make surface hydrophobic for aqueous substances; membrane immersed in 50 µl sample, shaken softly for 30-60 min; membrane rinsed 2 min with ultrapure water and then mixed with 30 µl sinapinic acid/DAHC solution.

With HEPES and MOPS, BSA gives good signal, even enhanced from pure water. BES, Tris, and TES give less homogeneous signals and broader peaks. Imidazole and ACES give noisy baselines and even broader, almost undetectable peaks.

Concentration dependence was checked with buffers at 50, 100, 250, and 500 mM using sinapinic/DAHC: in general buffer concentration should be < 100 mM so as not to affect crystallization. The best spectra always are found when crystallization is fast and homogenous. Excessive salt concentration causes a heterogeneous crystallization, and especially when buffer salts exceed matrix mole for mole. Low peak intensities and broad peaks are to be expected. At 500 mM several salts form wet films (Tris, MOPS, HEPES) while others form dry crystals (ACES, BES, TES, imidazole). Close look at MOPS shows that at 50 mM there is no signal interference, but at 100 mM the baseline is more noisy, with ion suppression. At 250 mM, the trimeric form of BSA [3M+H]+ is not seen and the matrix/analyte crystal is a heterogeneous layer. BSA in 500 mM MOPS is undetectable entirely since it is not a crystal but a wet film. Desalting using Immobilon membrane or drop dialysis restored the spectrum signal (best results with Immobilon CD membrane; note that Immobilon-PSQ, -N, and -S membranes gave smaller intensities). The best results with this desalting technique occur when the protein interacts with the membrane; the protein can be desorbed using the matrix solution, which disrupts the protein-membrane interaction. With drop dialysis, it helps to add DAHC to the reservoir solution.

ToF PD-MS

Zubarev RA, Håkannson P, Sundqvist B (1996) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 10, 1386-1392.

Accurate Monoisotopic Mass Measurements of Peptides: Possibilities and Limitations of High Resolution Time-of-Flight Particle Desorption Mass Spectrometry

With a ΔM / M = ±1 ppm, no more than 1% of all possible peptide combinations will fall within the interval M ± Δ M (99% confidence). Confidence is affected the tolerance set. A 90% confidence will allow a mass accuracy of 10 ppm. Average isotopic mass can not be used in this case since the natural distribution of isotopic abundances is wider than this tolerance. In the low and medium mass range, monoisotopic mass is better for comparison.

The DIPLOMA mass spectrometer was built for plasma desorption mass spectrometry (PDMS) and is also capable of SIMS mode. Its resolution is 5000 (with one reflectron) for organic ions. Clustered ions (CsBr) can be resoluted to 10000 FWHM. The TDC has a 0.5 ns time resolution. X- and Y-deflection plates and an Einzel lens are used in secondary ion beam focusing toward the reflectron. A beam of 72.3 MeV 127I13+ ions from a tandem accelerator were aimed in PDMS mode. A SIMS gun generates a 25 keV Ga+ ion beam with pulse of 5 ns width. Targets are prepared on 1 × 1 cm silicone slice (Biolon as makes commericial PDMS targets) with a 12 mm brass disc featuring a 2 µm thick alumninized mylar film. Matrix is 200 µg/cm2 layer of nitrocellulose deposited by electrospraying from acetone solution. Peptides are incubated in 1 M HCl at 100° at times from 2-10 min and dried on bare silicon slices. Bradykinins were partially acid hydrolyzed in this way for the mass accuracy test. TOF spectra had peak positions determined, mass scale calibration with low mass ion exact masses.

For peak position determination consider the low mass isobaric ions C 6+ and C4H8O, with only a mass difference of 0.058 u. First a peak location is determined: this can be a one peak, or with a better analysis, two more more overlapping peaks. Peak multiplicity m, or the number of peaks, is evaluated. Then m Gaussian curves are fit to the curves in the location. The width of the curves is constrained to 0.5-2.0 of the expected peak width, with 2.0 representing a value derived from the known resolution of the instrument. If broad metastable peaks are there, it can lead to too many Gaussians.

Of course, with ToF, the scale is t = A √m/z + B where A is the slope dependent on pathlength and voltages, and B represents the time delay in the electronics. This is fitted with a series of n equations as above solved for n known peaks.

194 peptides had their masses determined and compared to the theoretical. Deviations revealed both random (±22 ppm, or ±0.015 mDa, std dev) and systematic error (+16 ppm, or +0.010 mDa, std dev.). The systematic error reflects that peaks of petpide ions appear heavier than their theoretical masses. Why? One reason could be peak shape, with many peaks being asymmetric. The MH+ and MNa+ of Leu-enkephalin show tailing on the high mass side. Gaussian fits are symmetrical, but will shift the peak toward a skew when real peaks are not symmetrical.

Other sources of error are metastable decomposition: there is an appearance of a lower mass tailing that can affect mass accuracy. The Einzel lens, used to focus secondary ion beam and increase sensitivity has two modes of operation that depend on polarity, with one mode being same polarity as secondary ions. At certain value no more ions pass through (cut-off voltage). This mode delays the time of flight of ions. In another mode of operationthe polarity is reversed and causes acceleration with no cut-off effect, with a shorter t. Use of a higher potential is required to get good focusing. There is however better resolution of overlapping peaks, despite an equal amount of tailing.

Sample thickness also affects resolution, with thicker samples producing predictably broader peaks. Tailing is quite pronounced with thick (>3 µ m) targets. If inhomogeneity is ±1 µm in a field strength of 3 kV/mm, then the potential difference on the target surface varies ±3 V, which should be easily compensated in the reflectron. So peak broadening may be the result of another mechanism.

MCP detectors can limit resolution as well. The microchannels have a 7° angle to the normal of the plate surface. Illumination of ions penetrating the channel (bombardment to start a cascade) is a function of the penetration depth: it drops by 50% at a depth of d = 0.4 D/β, where D is the channel diameter and β is the angle to the normal. Where D is typically 10 µm, d = 40 µm, which is 17 ppm if the total flight path is 2.3 m as in the DIPLOMA. Since peak broadening by the MCP affects all ions similarly, the tailing effect cannot be explained by the MCP.

Reflectron imperfections (grids, fringing fields) could cause non-ideal initial energy compensation. Peak shapes were compared on machines with the same ToF components (reflectors, detectors, data acquisition systems) but with different ionization techniques. With PDMS and SIMS, both ion desorption techniques, peak tailing was clearly observed. But with ESI-MS there is no tailing. Thus ionization and not instrument system factors affect this.

Molecules in PDMS can acquire charge prior to desorption (preformed ions), or at the moment of desorption (desorption/ionization), or in the gas phase. In the latter case, one mechanism of gas phase ionization is a reaction between unionized and ionized molecules with a transfer of charge. In another mechanism large non-covalently bound aggregates of molecules desorb (chunk ejection) with chunks internally excited and undergoing metastable decomposition. A time delay occurs in these events and there is less kinetic energy than with desorption of pre-formed or co-formed ions. The kinetic energy is lower than the acceleration potential, and thus there is an energy deficit. For certain ions (H+, C+, CH+, even C60+) there is no real observed deficit. However about half of all molecular ions, specific fragments including immonium ions, there is a deficit in the tens of eV. This depended on the target surface: there was a greater deficit for fluffy samples typically produced by an electrospray than for smooth or crystalline target. Also protonated molecules showed the deficit more than sodiated (MNa+) molecules. With SIMS and PDMS, the ionization in the gas phase may be dominant, and so tailing is likely.

Consider that the flow of ions having the same m/z is expressed as a current I with an exponential time decay of formation: I(t) = I0 exp (−t/ α). In the absence of an energy deficit is a Gaussian with a dispersion σ0. The shape of the real ion peak is described by F(z) in the spectrum in the presence of a deficit is a convolution of the Gaussian with the exponent:

F(z) = ∫0∞ e−1/α e−(t − z)2/ 2σ dt [1]

The factor α represents the time of ion formation and the average energy deficit. α=0 when the ions are promptly ejected from the target surface. When α=σ0, the centroid C0 and the position Z0 of the peak is shifted toward later times. The centroid is actually C0 = α and the peak dispersion will be:

σα2 = σ02 + 2 α2 [2]

Since tailing occurs, C0 > Z0 for any α. If C0 = α = 1, then Z0 = 0.7 (units of σ0). In this event it is better to select the peak height rather than centroid in fixing the time (m/z), but the peak height also moves with α.

When peak position shift can be determined, mass accuracy is improved. Consider the algorithm:

  1. First determine the peak centroid on a TOF scale (CTOF) and the peak dispersion σα2.
  2. If σ02 is known, find α using eqn [1] above.
  3. Calculate C0 from C0 = α, and then subtract it from CTOF. This will give the true peak position on the TOF scale.

A problem occurs with overlapping peaks, finding centroids and dispersions. In simulating a number of peak shapes for different α (and therefore Z0), the FWHM was compared to an ideal peak with α=Z0=0. The width of the ideal peak is FWHM0=2.35σ0. In the region 0<Z0<1.5,

FWHM = FWHM0 (1 + 0.6 Z02) [3]

If the FWHM < FWHM0 the correction value Z0 is subtracted from the TOF of the peak to get the true position. FWHM0 and σ0 are determined from known resolving power of instrument.

An linear approximation to the

proline effect, CID, peptide fragmentation, FD

Vaisar T, Urban J (1996) J. Mass Spectrom. 31, 1185-1187.

Probing the Proline Effect in CID of Protonated Peptides

LETTER. Protonated peptides with Pro show interesting CID spectra. There are abundant y-type ions arising from cleavage of amide bond on the N-terminal side of proline. This has been reported in high energy collisions on sector instruments, low-energy collisions, and on hybrids. Seen in multiply charged protein ions. There is a high basicity of Pro relative other ions.

Using a peptide with structure AVxLG where x=N-alkylated amino acid, we looked at CID spectra. All peptides were synthetic and RP-HPLC purified. Spectra were obtained on triple quad (Fisons VG Quattro) with ESI. The argon pressure was set so there is 20% ion transmittance at 10 eV frame collision energy. With peptide [AVALG+H]+, a b4 ion is prominent, along with complements b2/y3 and b3/y2 in lower abundance. With [AVPLG+H]+, the y3 ion is dominant, reflecting V-P bond cleavage and the greater proton affinity for proline. For peptide [AV(NMe-Ala)LG+H]+, there is a dominant b3 ion (93% of TIC of fragments, similar to the Pro-containing peptide. [AV(Pip)LG+H]+ (peptide with pipecolinic acid, a homologue of Pro with 6-member ring) shows an abundant b3 ion similar to NMe-Ala peptide. [AV(Sar)LG+H]+ is the sarcosine-containing peptide, showing y3 (63% of TIC fragment current) and b3 (22%), with minor b2 and b4 ions. Alkylation of the amide N atom has a clear effect. It clearly produces b3 and y3 ions (as 3rd residue), while an alkyl side chain (off the α-carbon) promotes b3 ion formation. The sarcosine peptide b3/y3 ratio is 0.4, while NMe-Ala shows a 26.5 value (b3 dominates), Pip is 5.2, and Pro it is 0.03. When merely Ala, the ratio is 0.9. The dominance of a b or y ion will depend largely on the proton affinity of the N-terminal residue on the C-terminal fragment.

The formation of b ions will be a key to explaining the proline effect. It is proposed they form an oxazolone protonated ring rather than an linear acylium. Formation of a b ion with a ring product on C-terminal side of Pro would be highly strained, so the absence of such ions is not unexpected. It would be bicyclic. A b3 ion in the peptides used here would be unlike for Pro as 3rd residue.

Lui M, Tempst P, Erdjument-Bromage H (1996) Anal. Biochem. 241, 156-166.

Methodical Analysis of Protein-Nitrocellulose Interactions to Design A Refined Digestion Protocol

It is often the case that electroblotted proteins from 1-D and 2-D gels contain N-terminal blocking which must be overcome by the use of internal sequencing techniques that involve in situ micropreparative digestion. Unfortunately peptide recovery is a problem (70% for trypsin, 50% for endoproteinase Lys-C on average). Aebersold's group has reported that alkaline pH and organic solvents promote elution. Detergents were tried by others.

In the first experiments elution of intact proteins was tried with a variety of organic solvents and detergents. Standard marker proteins were electroblotted to NC membranes: lysozyme 14 kDa, Hb 16 kDa, ovalbumin 45 kDa, G6PD 55 kDa, β-galactoside 116 kDa. Proteins were radioiodinated and a few nanograms of labeled protein mixed with 1 µg unlabeled protein, run on gels, blotted to NC, then bands excised and counted, stored at −70°.

Several different organic solvents were tried (11, with up to 40% concentration). None of the proteins dissociated. pH extremes (20 mM KOH or 20% TFA in water) also did not help. In a 100 mM ammonium bicarbonate (pH 8.5) buffer, MeCN did not elute large proteins until reaching 40% concentration. Even more protein was released if the pH was increased to 10.5 and 12.0 (2- and 3-fold more, respectively, for a 40% and 60% release on average). EtOH, isopropanol, and DMSO do not promote elution from NC under mild alkaline conditions. With TFA, at 10% concentration at 37° and 40% MeCN provided a 25% elution. Use of higher temperature and higher TFA concentrations gave a false impression of improved elution of radioactivity, which actually was the result of protein degradation.

Several organic bases were then tried (since acid promotes degradation). Triethanolamine, triisopropanolamine, pyridine (PYRI), pyrimidine, morpholine, N-ethylmorpholine, piperazine, cyclen, pyrrolidine carbonitrile, and piperidine (PIP). PYRI at 40% (pH 8.5) and PIP at 20% (pH 13.10) were excellent at 37° and 65° in elution proteins. In combination with 40% MeCN and 1% PIP alone, near quantitative recovery was obtained (90%); even with 0.1% PIP/40% MeCN, a 65-70% recovery was better than any other combination. pH alone did not account for the effect since a 10 mM KOH with MeCN was less effective, despite the higher pH.

Different detergents were tested at three different alkaline pH (8.5 with 200 mM TrisHCl, 10.0 with 200 mM CAPS, and 11.5 with 10 mM KOH) at 37° and 65°. At pH 8.5, only 3% CTAB among ionic detergents (SDS, sarkosyl, sodium deoxycholate, all 3%) yielded the best recovery from NC; the zwitterionics (Zwit 3-16 at 0.3 and 3%, CHAPS at 3% did not do well, LDAO at 3% and 0.3%, Empigen at 0.3 and 3%) gave respectable recoveries. Among nonionics, only Tween and Triton were sufficiently good to warrant a further look (Genapol allowed 40-50% recovery, followed by Pluronic at 20-30%, while MEGA-10 and the glucoside detergents were poor). pH did not really promote greater elution except in the case of Triton and Zwittergent; with Triton it helped, but with Zwittergent elution was reduced.

Protein size may have been a factor. Hb, lysozyme, and ovalbumin eluted better with a lower 0.3% detergent than the larger β-galactosidase and G6PD proteins.

In general combinations of detergents and organic solvents promote dissociation of bound material, but in the case of NC membranes, recoveries were reduced by the combined use (as much as 15-30%). For NC membranes, it recommended that digestions be done in the absence of MeCN.

Zwittergent 3-16 is a sulfobetaine (N-hexadecyl-N,N-dimethyl-3-ammonia-1-propanesulfonate) composed of zwitterionic head and unbranched 16-carbon tail, the latter of which may be important. The N-dodecyl form resulted in 10% less recovery, and the N-octyl (Zwittergent 3-08) did not promote extraction at all. Use of the detergent is compatible with RP HPLC: it does not absorb at 214 nm and does not affect peak height or resolution. It elutes very late into a gradient.

For in situ digestion, the membrane area should be at a minimum. Prior to trypsin addition, membranes should be blocked with nonprotein material (0.5% PVP-40). But even without the blocking agent use of Zwittergent 3-16 helps to recovery considerably.

The large proteins at 55 and 116 kDa were used on electroblotted membranes and digested without prior blocking using different detergents. 80-90% of radioactivity was recovered after 2 h of 0.2 µg trypsin in 100 mM ammonium bicarbonate with 1% Zwittergent 3-16; lower recoveries (50-70%) were seen with Triton X or Tween80 at 1%. Endoproteinase Lys-C produces larger fragments, but the recovery with Zwittergent 3-16 was the same but much lower with nonionics.

CID, FD

Gonzalez J, Besada V, Garay H, Reyes O, Padront G, Tambara Y, Takaot T, Shimonishi Y (1996) J. Mass Spectrom. 31, 150-158.

Effect of the Position of a Basic Amino Acid on C-Terminal Rearrangement of Protonated Peptides Upon Collision-induced Dissociation

Peptides are fragmented into ions that are related to their sequence. N-terminal ions are classified as a, b, c, d, and C-terminal ions as x, y, z, v, w. The ions d, v, and w series specify side chain fragmentation seen with high energy CID. Interesting is that N-terminal ions are prominent when there is an N-terminal basic amino acid, and if at the C-terminus, C-terminus ions are more prominent. When basic residues in middle of peptide, the CID spectrum is more complex. In metal-cationized and protonated peptides, the C-terminal amino acid is lost by transfer of the C-terminal α-hydroxy moiety to the carbonyl carbon of the penultimate amino acid residue. The rearrangement is [bn-1 + H2O]. Labeling peptides by acid-catalyzed isotope exchange with 18O, the mechanism has been studied and is promoted by a basic amino acid (Arg) and depends on gas phase conformation.

A JEOL JMS-HX/HX110A four-sector tandem MS with FAB source, collision cell, and photodiode array detector was used. 0.5 nmol peptides in 50% MeCN are put on stainless steel probe tip, dried, mixed with glycerol and acidified with 0.1 M HCl. Positive ions are generated with Xe atoms at 4000 V, accelerated in 10,000 V field. Ions might be filtered by MS1 and accelerated at 8 kV into the collision cell before MS2. He atoms form the collision gas and are adjusted to reduce parent ion abundance in spectra by half. CID product ions are scanned by both E (electric) and B (magnetic) fields such that the B/E ratio is constant (B/E-linked scan mode).

Peptides were labeled with 18O. Product ion spectra of a partially 18O-labeled peptide Val148-Ala-Ile-Val-Glu-Arg-Tyr-Lys155 was obtained during API digest of outer membrane of N. meningitidis. Three groups of ions are seen:

  1. C-terminal ion show doublet peaks with similar abundances to that of parent [z3, y3, and wa4]
  2. N-terminal ions show peaks with natural isotopic distributions from loss of 18O at C-terminal COOH [a7 and b7]
  3. ion with isotopic enrichment to C-terminal ions and containing 18O, but with lower content, which is rearrangement ion [b7 + H2O]

A mechanism to explain the product spectra has been proposed. Precursor ions are [M+1]+ and [M+3]+ (16O and 18O isotopic forms, respectively). In acid-catalyzed labeling, the 18O isotope can become either the hydroxyl oxygen or carbonyl oxygen of the COOH moiety on the end terminal residue. In all cases, the hydroxyl oxygen creates an electrophilic bond with the carbonyl carbon of the previous residue to make 5-centered ring. This ring fragments (C-O and NH=CH-R are formed, the last an immonium) to create a [bn-1 + H2O] ion. Two rearrangement ions are seen, differing by 2 Da, the difference between the oxygen isotopes. Note that only one of three routes in the mechanism puts the 18O atom on the product ion: the population of 18O-labeled product ions should be lower in C-terminal and parent ions, but higher than for N-terminal derived ions.

Peptide [bn − 1 + H2O]/bn − 1
QGIEF 0.0a
HGIEF 0.4
KGIEF 0.9
RGIEF 5.6
RASVF 6.0
ARSVF 6.0
ASRVF 5.0
ASVRF 9.0
ASVFR —a
ASVKF 2.1
SVRF 9.8
EPQRF 6.8
VAIVERY 9.5
DGVVSRL 12.2
a These not detected

This cyclization and loss of the C-terminal residue happens significantly when Arg is the residue. When Lys is substituted, the rearrangement ion is present at less abundance; it is less basic than Arg. Four synthetic peptides with N-terminal residue being Gln, His, Lys, and Arg were analyzed for product ion spectra in the m/z 350-500 range. The abundance ratio [b 4 + H2O]/b4 increases when basicity is increased of the N-terminal amino acid (see table above). This ratio was significantly larger for Lys-peptide than Gln-peptide. Note that residual masses are identical since Lys and Gln are isobaric.

The effect of position was then assessed. All peptides had the same composition, but the position of Arg was altered. All peptides produce the rearrangement ion [b4 + H2O] except when Arg is the C-terminal residue, a reasonable finding since it usually produces C-terminal and not N-terminal ions. The peptide with Arg at n−1 was the most likely to show rearrangement. Intensity ratios [bn-1+H2O]/bn-1 for several chymotryptic peptides from recombinant proteins al with Arg at penultimate. A table of values shows clearly that basicity affects the ability to induce rearrangement.

It had been reported that metal-cationized peptides (but not protonated) that lack a basic amino acids show rearrangement products, suggesting that alkali metals interact with the COO anion at the C-terminus. Its presence facilitates nucleophilic attack of the -OH group on C-terminal -COOH to the carbonyl of the n−1 residue. But with Arg, the protonated guanidino might form a salt bridge with C-terminal -COO anion in vacuo letting it interact with the penultimate carbonyl as well. A mechanism is shown similar to the metal-cationized mechanism by which Arg side chain facilitates interaction between C-terminal -COO and the carbonyl carbon, with loss of the CO and immonium ions making up the C-terminal amino acid.

A previous paper suggested that low-energy collision produced these ions and that it resulted from metastable decomposition. To further verify the mechanism, two types of peptides were measured by B/E-linked scan with and w/o collision gase on MS1 and MS/MS. Spectrum without gas represents metastable ions and show rearrangement ions [b6+H2O] in highest abundance. When gas is added, rearrangement abundance is lower, and product ions da4 and db4 appear in spectrum. The latter occur from loss of larger and smaller substituents attached to β-arbon of 4th amino acid (Ile), resp., and characteristic of high energy collision. Rearrangement ion was nearly suppressed at 2 kV collision energy. High energy collision with a cell floated at several kilovolts excludes ions in front of and behind cell, because ions don't pass through analyzer. Thus rearrangement forms from metastable decomposition. In contrast, the rearrangement ion produced from a synthetic peptide of ASVRF is observed in the MS/MS while most abundant in B/E-linked scan spectrum. This is consistent with metastable decomposition in field-free region and with CID, but in sequence-dependent manner.

FD

Haller I, Mirza UA, Chait BT (1996) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 7, 677-681.

Collision Induced Decomposition of Peptides: Choice of Collision Parameters

In a triple quad MS with typical conditions (Ar collision gas, < 100 V ion acceleration) peptide bond scission usually dominates fragmentation pathways. 2+ peptides consist mostly of identifiable b and y-series ions. Complicating the interpretation of spectra are other possible fragmentation sites and neutral losses of water and ammonia.

The amino acid sequence, mass, and the obtained fitting parameters for the peptides used
Amino acid sequence Molecular mass Vopt (V) at (mtorr) Slope b (V−1) at (mtorr)
2.71.50.882.71.50.88
TSK334.46.87.2311.30.830.710.30
PFGK447.59.8210.313.90.740.690.48
VESSK548.610.010.715.20.760.710.31
SIGSLAK674.88.99.413.60.640.660.52
VHLTP VEK922.117.819.430.60.500.500.13
KRQHP GKR1006.227.330.545.70.400.490.23
PHPFH FFVYK1318.521.123.633.90.470.420.34
QATVG DVNTD RPGLL DLK1912.138.344.671.20.470.430.12
GGR288.35.175.988.00.550.750.42
GGYR451.56.907.9111.10.440.510.34
YIGSR594.78.278.9813.20.730.650.41
HLGLA R665.813.714.719.80.590.690.42
ASHLG LAR824.015.416.623.70.730.650.41
PPGFS PFR904.118.419.427.20.590.590.25
RPPGH SPFR1060.326.229.446.10.400.380.14
HSDAV FTDNY TR1425.527.631.547.50.560.510.13
EGVND NEEGH FSAR1570.627.930.453.50.300.390.11
ADSGE GDFLA EGGGV R1536.623.827.741.90.500.510.24

The peptide ASHLGLAR was set up in the 2+ state and tested at three different collision energies with a gas pressure of 1.5 mtorr. At 12 V collision cell offset, the parent ion is seen with highest relative intensity at m/z 412, but so is a y62+ at m/z 318 and a y5 at m/z 514. Note that Elab (energy at laboratory frame) is actually 24 eV, since the precursor ion is a +2 state. At Vc = 17.0 V (Elab = 34 eV), seven y ions (1, 4, 5, 6, 7, and the 2+ ions of 6 and 7) are identified, along with a b3 and a3 ion. The precursor ion still has the highest relative intensity. At Vc = 30.0 V (Elab = 60 eV), the precursor had been fully fragmented, but only three y ions could be seen and a low intensity b3 ion. The rest of the ions were low m/z peaks in the 100-300 range with no assignment, usually the result of secondary fragmentations of b and y ions. Of the three collision cell V offsets, Vc = 17.0 V provided the most (sequence) information, with 8 amino acids identified.

Plots of the abundance of product ions versus collision cell offset voltage can be done to assess optimal collision cell offsets. This was done for four product ions, m/z 109, y4, y5, and y42+, at collision offsets of Vc = 2, 6, 8, 10, 12, 13, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 23, 25, and 30 V. The [M+2H]2+ abundance of the precursor was also plotted in one of the plots to track the loss of parent. In the three y ion plots, a maximum is seen, and the maxima generally occur at the same voltage. The m/z 109 is representative of the histidine immonium ion and the result of multiple fragmentations. Its plot shows no maximum but rather a steadily increasing abundance curve up to 30 V.

To find the optimum collision offset, it is observed that the maxima in product ion peaks occur at a voltage where the sum of intensities of three strongest fragment ions is 1.5 times the precursor ion intensity. The conversion ratio R = sum of the abundances of the three strongest fragment ions in the CID spectrum divided by remaining precursor ion abundance. Vopt is the offset at which R = 1.5. Plot log R vs. Vc and a straight line is approximated. From R = 1.5 on the plot, find Vopt = Vc. Other plots make use of absolute intensity data, but the conversion ratio diminishes the effects that arise from fluctuations in the electrospray ionization yield. The observed exponential dependence indicates decomposition reaction is driven by a build-up (via multiple collisions) of internal energy that is approximately proportional to ion kinetic energy. Other factors contributing are collision cross section and time available for decomposition. Present experiments results do not allow evaluation of relative contributions of these other factors.

Peptide Mass Effects. Peptides from 3-18 residues listed in the table above had their CID spectra checked for 2+ state precursors with Vc = Vopt (or at least close to it). These peptides are representative of typical tryptic peptide sequences, having K and R residues on COOH terminus (see first eight entries of table for K and the rest for R residues). Spectra were obtained for three different Vc that bounded Vopt, and at three different pressures (0.88, 1.5, and 2.7 mtorr); thus 9 spectra for each peptide. In all cases, the conversion ratio R varied exponentially with Vc and the R = 1.5 criterion was in agreement with the goal of balancing peaks arising from single vs. multiple cleavage reactions. A plot of log conversion ratio R from 0.4 to 5.0 vs. Vc at the three different pressures is shown for one of the 18 peptides (HLGLAR) and shows how conversion ratio is also dependent upon gas pressure. Data for each pressure were fitted to R = 1.5 × exp[b(Vc − Vopt)]. The fitting parameters Vopt and b are shown in the table above.

Vopt shows a strong linear correlation with the peptide size, and this is indepedent of pressure: that is, Vope increases linearly with molecular mass for each of the pressures, and slope is inversely dependent upon pressure. Correlation coefficients of 0.87, 0.89, and 0.83 were found for the pressures of 2.7, 1.5, and 0.88 mtorr, respectively. Thus higher collision voltage offsets are required as the gas pressure goes down.

No dependence was found for the COOH terminal residue. Deviations that arise due to pressure differences are not random errors. Peptides that contain more than one R and/or K residue do require more energy for fragmentation than those with excess acidic residues, which is consistent with prior observations. Factors affecting fragmentation include center-of-mass energy available for excitation, excitation cross-section, and degrees of freedom in the excited peptide. Thus a observation of a simple linear dependence of Vopt on molecular mass was unexpected. These observations should be tested in triple quads of different design.

One implication for LC-MS/MS-based protein sequencing is the use of multiple collision energy profiles based on mass and charge of peptide ion. Once precursor mass and charge are assessed in MS mode, the switch to MS/MS mode will set the proper profile. The following three steps are proposed:

  1. use one or two scans in MS mode (Ar is in collision cell, and offset voltage set to 0) to get precursor mass and charge at onset of HPLC peak
  2. software monitoring sets collision voltage to Vopt after computation of the value
  3. CID spectra are averaged until the end of peak elution

The first two steps must be completed within seconds to get good MS/MS spectra.

selenocysteine

Stadtman TC (1996) Annu. Rev. Biochemistry 65, 83-100.

Selenocysteine

Selenocysteine is not recognized as the 21st amino acid. August Böck and colleagues have found that E coli mutants were defective in ability to synthesize Se-dependent formate dehydrogenases and these revealed four gene products that involved generation and insertion of SeCys into proteins. One product is of a unique tRNA and two others are new enzymes making SeCys- and Ser-tRNA. Another is a elongation factor recognizing SeCys-tRNA. Selenium-containing enzymes play an important role in survival.

  • Glutathione peroxidases scavenge deleterious peroxides.
  • Deiodinase enzymes synthesize and maintain optimum levels of thyroid hormones.

Genes in E coli selA, selB, selC, and selD have been identified. Seleno-Cys is actually formed on a tRNA: tRNASec, product of selC, is esterfied with amino acid Ser in the normal fashion. The selA product is a PLP-dependent enzyme that converts the Ser-tRNASec to produce aminoacrylyl-tRNASec. The selenocysteyl-tRNASec forms when selenophosphate reacts with the double bond in the aminoacrylyl derivative. Selenophosphate is produced by the reaction of hydrogen selenide (H2Se) with ATP, mediated by the selD product. It must be noted that the selenocysteine is built on the tRNA: while it may exist freely in the protoplasm (it does), it cannot be ligated to tRNA directly. The L-serine must be ligated to tRNA from which it is synthesized.

For eukaryotes, the mechanism has not been fully established. There is a tRNASec analogous to that in E coli, with esterification of Ser, and conversion to the selenocysteyl form. However, an O-phosphoseryl-tRNASec is also present, although there is no evidence of it having an intermediate role. A homolog for selD has been discovered, so the synthesis of selenophosphate is more likely.

It has been observed that in selD mutants, free selenocysteine is incorporated into proteins, but only because it is ligated to tRNACys and not tRNASec, its special anticodon.

The function of the remaining gene selB was determined when its mutants were found to accumulate selenocysteyl-tRNASec, indicating that they were not incorporated into protein. It is likely a translation factor required to transport the charged tRNA to the ribosome, and thus a functional homolog of EF-Tu. Both RNA protection studies and direct binding assays confirm this special affinity. SELB has little to no binding for Ser-tRNASec. SELB mediates in part the deacylation of the SeC-tRNASec, which decreases markedly under alkaline conditions; deacylation of Ser-tRNASeC is not affected.

salt clusters, ESI-MS, FD

Zhou S, Hamburger M (1996) Rapid Comm. Mass Spectrom. 10, 797-800.

Formation of Sodium Cluster Ions in Electrospray Mass Spectrometry

Two different models have been proposed for how solvent evaporation and formation of charged droplets which grow smaller and have higher charge to mass ratios. Iribarne and Thomson have proposed the direct ion evaporation (emission) theory, while Dole et al with support from Röllgen have proosed the charged residue model. Kebarle and coworkers have proposed a modified charge residue model called the single ion in droplet theory (SIDT). The SIDT can be subjected to experimental testing. When a nonvolatile ionic salt in the solvent is sufficiently concentrated, ion separation from counterion in the evaporative process is incomplete. Unseparated paired electrolyte ions would remain in the final droplet together with one excess ion, and this leads to a formation of a series of ion clusters. Sodium ion clusters from sodium salt solutions with concentrations higher than 0.25 mM under electrospray conditions occurs.

At low sodium ion salt concentrations (50 µM), the dominant ions species are clusters of Na+(CH3CN)n. At a cone voltage of 30-35 V, there are no naked Na+ ions. At cone voltages above 55 V the Na+(CH3CN)n clusters dissociate. As [sodium acetate] > 250 µM, ion clusters with the composition Na+(CH3COONa)n1(HCOONa)n2 appear. When sodium formate alone, the dominant cluster is Na+(HCOONa)n, where n ranges from 1 to 20. At low sodium salt concentration (< 250 µM), Na+ would be separated from their counter ions, and no or few unseparated ion pairs would be in the droplets. There is a critical concentration at which cluster ions appear, generally at around 100 µM. Kebarle et al have reported a plateau for total droplet current at electrolyte concentrations > 100 µM. Another group showed formation of ion-pairs between analyte and counterion responsible for changes in charge state distribution at analyte concentrations > 100 µM. Electrophoretic migration leads to ion separation at the ESI interface and ion migration to droplet surface. An ion monolayer at the surface might be complete at about 100 µM where sodium salts are dominant electrolyte. This halts or decelerates further ion separation either by shielding electric field or by repulsion via electrostatic interaction. In the droplet fission process unseparated ion pair are retained in the droplet together with excess ions, and this can explain formation of ion clusters.

An issue of the SIDT model considered by Kebarle and coworkers in selectivity of gas-phase ion formation among different ion species. Population of the different ions at droplet surface should be determined by electrophoretic mobility and their concentration in bulk solution according to

Ni = (Vs/Vi)KiCi/(1 + ∑KiCi)

where Ni is ion population at droplet surface, Vi is specific volume of ion particle, Vs is saturation volume of all ions at droplet surface, Ki is ion equilibrium constant or adsorption coefficient, and Ci is concentration of ions in bulk solution.

Fission of droplets is uneven and the offspring droplets are smaller than their parent ions, and carrying a much higher charge density. More uneven fission would produce droplets containing only a single ion, while ion pairs exist in original parent droplets. Non-volatile sodium salts show this: flow injection of NaCl into 80% MeCN produce Na+(NaCl)n where n > 4 and Na+(CH3CN)n clusters were formed. The isotopic distribution of chlorine made these findings easily identifiable.

Stability of Na+(CH3CN)n and Na+(CH3CN)n were assessed by increasing the OV settings: at OV = 55 V, the Na+(CH3CN)n clusters were dissociating, while with Na+(CH3CN)n clusters no dissociation was occurring significantly at OV = 135 V.

FD

Wang J, Ke F, Siu KW, Guevremont R (1996) J. Mass Spectrom. 31, 159-168.

Electrospray Tandem Mass Spectrometry of Alkali Metal-containing Anionic Complexes

Alkali metal adducts readily observable in FAB-MS of peptides. Fragmentation pathways are distinct from protonated peptides. Interaction of especially sodium and potassium with peptides may play important role. Gas-phase MS/MS might indicate how alkali metal ions associate with peptides intrinsically without effects of solvent molecules. Previous work with FAB-MS used matrix of glycerol/thioglycerol saturated with X-OH or X-Cl where X is alkali metal. ESI is better than FAB with respect to compatibility. Study of tripeptide in water/MeOH at pH 12 with X-OH produces several cationic X-peptide adducts. These were [M-H+2X]+ > [M-2H+3X]+ > [M-3H+4X]+ in order of decreasing abundance and M is tripeptide and X = Li, Na, or K. FAB-MS cannot even produce the [M-2H+3X]+ and [M-3H+4X]+ ions and the first ion is low in count. Metal ions usually coordinate with carbonyl O atom of peptide backbone. Also interactions with C-terminal carboxylate anion (-COO−) and peptide N atoms.

Experimental. Peptides were available from Sigma and dissolved to 1 mM in 1:1 water/MeOH adjusted to pH 12 in presence of XOH (alkali hydroxides). For deuterium labeling tripeptides aer dissolved in 1:1 CH3OD:D2O adjusted to pH 12 (only a few minutes for equilibration). Acylation of N-terminus done with 1% acetic anhydride in 1:1 MeOH:water for 1 h, then adjust to pH 12 with XOH. A TAGA 6000E SciEx triple quad (QqQ) is used with electrospray fashioned using 3 cm 33-guage (Hamilton 100 µm i.d.) stainless steel tube attached to other tube with epoxy glue and electropolished before use. Adjustments to argon gas pressure are done to determine the number of collisions a molecule undergoes. Collision energy is about 40 eV.

All tripeptides used in study have neutral side chains. Negative ion ESI-MS of LGG and GGV with KOH (at pH 12) shows ions [M-H]−, [M-2H+K]−, and [M-3H+K]− in order of decreasing abundance, indicating successive deprotonations of the peptide. Other tripeptides were similiar in these spectra, except that tripeptides APG and GPA where the [M-3H+2K]− was not detected. (The authors do not mention, but the spectra show other significant ions that are probably contaminants.)

CID spectra were obtained on the ion [M-2H+Na]− for the peptides AGG, GGA, LGG, GGL, VGG, and GGV. Conditions were adjusted for just one collision, and consequently this creates low product ion counts. Four major ions are evident: [x1 − 2H]−, [b2 − 2H]−,  [y2 − H + Na]−, [y2 − H + Na + CO2]−. Of these ions, the first three are found in all six tripeptides, and the last ion is found only in tripeptides of the sequence _GG. These same product ion were found in product ion spectra for [M-2H+X]− of GPA, APG, and PGG, and of product ions for this parent ion in other alkali metals.

CID spectra of selected ion [M-2H+X]− for M=GGL and X=Li, Na, K, and Cs shows greater fragmentation from Li to Cs (Li > Na ~ K > Cs) but same major product ions present for all metal ions.

Acylation of N-terminus alters fragmentation of [M-2H+X]− in multiple ways. For Ac-VGG and Ac-GGV, major product ions are [x1 − 2H]−, [b1 − 2H]−, [x2 − 3H + Na]−, [x2 − HCOOH]−, and [c1 − H + Na]− for both. In addition Ac-VGG shows [y2 − H + Na]−.

The parent ion [M - 3H + 2X]− was next fragmented for peptides AGG, LGG, VGG, and GGA, GGL, and GGV. There is only one major product: [y2 − 2H + 2Na]−. It is also a prominent product ion for PGG [M - 3H + 2X]−. With GPA and APG, this ion has much lower intensity.

These fragmentation patterns strongly indicate that the metal coordinates with the tripeptide wrapped around it. Major bonding is with carboxylate oxygen and to the amide N of the C-terminal amino acid, which is missing a proton. Other coordinations are likely with nonbonding electron pairs of the amide N atoms of the other residues. The same pattern occurs with the molecule missing 3 protons and having 2 metal atoms: one metal atom coordinates the background and the other forms a salt linkage to the C-terminal carboxylate O atom. Others have already proposed similar structures. Bonding to deprotonated carboxylate anion is required by MS/MS results and ab initio calculations. Yet another structure that is plausible is for the N atom on the 2nd residue instead of the C-terminal residue to be deprotonated. Fragmentation scheme to [y2 − H + Na]− is fairly predicable, with formation of R1CH=NH and loss of CO. Metal is coordinated to R3 N atom having no proton, and to R3 carboxylate O atom, with coordination to R2 N atom too. Formation of [y2 − H + Na − CO2]− involves either one or two steps, depending on starting structure. Another scheme is shown as to how [x1 − 2H]− is formed. Yet another scheme shows how [b1 − 2H]−. Formation of y ions requires transfer of proton from the neutral to ionic product. The β- (-CH-) and γ- (-NH-) hydrogen of preceding residue have been identified as the proton transferred. Using deuterated d4-[M - H + 2X]+ it was shown that [y1 + 2X]+ product is d1, and a mechanism involving the -CH- and not -NH- hydrogen from previous amino acid residue. In this case the [M - 2H + X]− anion, a d3 ion forms a d2 product ion and so the hydrogen must come from the N-terminus. When proline is part of the tripeptide, there are only 4 replaceable hydrogen atoms. Thus a fully deuterated [M-2H+X]− is d2, and fragmentation of M=GPA or APG produces a monodeuterated [y2 − H + X]−, but a di-deuterated ion when M = PGG. Deuterium labeling also proves the mechanism for parent ion where M contains or does not contain a proline, in which non-deuterated [x1 - 2H]− would be formed.

With N-acylated forms of ion [AcM-2H+X]−, there is a much richer fragmentation chemistry. Major product ions are [x1 - 2H]− and [y2 - H + X]−. The d2-[AcM-2H+X]− di-deuterated form shows a formation of d0-[b1 - 2H]−. Schemes are outlined in the paper for formation of other ions from this parent: [x2 - 3H + X]−, [x2 - HCOOH]−, and [c1 - H + X]−. To form [x2 - 3H + X]−, a proton movement from ionic to neutral product is required. If a di-deuterated parent produces a non-deuterated product, a hydrogen from -NH- and not -CH- must occur in the scheme. One sheme shows transfer of -NH- of R2 amino acid and elimination of R1CH2NHCOCH3. GPA and APG lack the -NH- on R2 so no product ion of this type is formed. With PGG however, this type is observed since the critical R2 -NH- is present. Product ion [x2 - HCOOH]− is formed from nonproline peptides and from PGG. Transfer of -NH- hydrogen on R1 to β-C on R1 with loss of R1CH=NCOCH3 will lead to [x2 - H + X]−, an intermediate, and this will lead to HCOOX elimination to form the [y2 - HCOOH]− product. For di-deuterated [AcM-2H+X]− parent, this should lead to d1-[x2 - HCOOH]− and it does. This product ion does not form from Ac-GPA or Ac-PGA, as expected. With PGG, the mechanism suggests a -CH- hydrogen from proline ring helps to form [x2 - H + X]− intermediate to β-C of R1 with loss of proline ring and this leads to formation of [x2 - HCOOH]− with no original exchangeable hydrogen. For formation of [c1 - H + X]− a cleavage of N-C bond on R2. This is not possible for APG and PGA peptides and so this product ion is not observed. CID of d2-[Ac-M − 2H + X]− of nonproline containing tripeptides produce d1-[c1 - H + X]− as expected.

The scheme to produce [y2 - 2H + 2Na]− from [M - 3H + 2Na]− is also given. One precursor involves a transfer of H from N-terminus to ionic fragment, while another involves transfer of centrally coordinated Na to the fragment. Deuterium labeling confirms the scheme.

Dikler S, Kelly JW, Russell DH (1997) J. Mass Spectrom. 32, 1337-1349.

Improving Mass Spectrometric Sequencing of Arginine-containing Peptides by Derivatization with Acetylacetone

ABSTRACT. Modifcation of arginine residues in bradykinin, [1-5]-bradykinin, splenopentin and two synthetic pentapeptides with acetylacetone (pentane-2,4-dione) signficantly increases the relative abundance of sequence-specic fragment ions produced by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI). The fragmentation efficiency as measured by post-source decay in a reflectron time-of-flight mass spectrometer increases by a factor of 2-3.5. Peptide bonds adjacent to modified residues are more susceptible to cleavage than in the non-derivatized peptide ions. The increased lability of these bonds gives rise to more complete sequence information. In addition, the relative abundances of sequence-specific fragment ions are enhanced. This strategy makes it possible to obtain valuable structural information from arginine-containing peptides that otherwise do not fragment well.

B. Küster B, Wheeler SF, Hunter AP, Dwek RA, Harvey DJ (1997) Anal. Biochem. 250, 82-101.

Sequencing of N-Linked Oligosaccharides Directly from Protein Gels: In-Gel Deglycosylation Followed by Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Mass Spectrometry and Normal-Phase High-Performance Liquid Chromatography

Glycoproteins are purified by SDS-PAGE and detected either with Coomassie or negative stains. Bands of interest are excised and deglycosylated in-gel with PNGase F. Several standard glycoproteins were looked at. The use of gels permits concentration of protein into a very small volume. 12.5 and 17.5% gel which are 0.75 mm thick permit analysis in the 10-200 kDa range. Bisacrylamide was reduced to 0.07% (as opposed to being 0.8%). The lower crosslink helps for in-gel deglycosylation.

Staining is by Coomassie or copper ions (Bio-Rad makes a kit for this). 1-15 µg (50-100 pmol) of protein is loaded to the gel. Note that the stain should not have a high amount of acetic acid so that sialic acid moieties are not affected. For the copper stain, the background and not the protein is stained, and this often lacks sufficient contrast; however the stain is rapid. Selected bands are excised and then proteins are reduced and alkylated.

A completely denatured rather than native protein is a better substrate for PNGase F. Water purity is especially critical. PEG and glucose molecules in starched gloves can ruin MALDI results. An in-gel buffer of 20 mM NaHCO3 pH 7.0 was used. Phosphate and citrate buffers are not compatible with anionic sugars. Ammonium buffers and cause formation of glycosamines, making reductive amination for labeling purposes impossible. PNGase F and sialidase were dialyzed against buffer prior to use. pH 7 was used when both enzymes were used together since it was between the pH optima of these enzymes. PNGase F was used at 100 U/ml; others have used in a range of 0.6-60 U/ml, but more was used because it was thought some loss would occur for an in-gel digest. Note that the total protein of enzyme was estimated to be 100 ng protein, not enough to interfere with

March RE (1997) J. Mass Spectrom. 32, 351-369.

An Introduction To Quadrupole Ion Trap Mass Spectrometry

REVIEW. The quadrupole ion trap can store gaseous ions and provide measurement of a wide range at high resolution using a pressure of 1 mTorr helium gas. The ion trap is essentially an electric field test tube. Since mass/charge ratios can be measured, the instrument thus becomes a mass spectrometer. The potential well (or basin) of the ion trap is tipped in a particular direction and ions tumble out of the well, leaving in order of ascending mass/charge ratio. Alternatively the perspective can be taken that ions are made to leave the basin when one side of the basin is lowered progressively. As ions are emitted, they strike a detector and are counted. Ejection is actually achieved by ramping up in linear fashion the amplitude of a radiofrequency potential applied to one of the ion trap electrodes. The initial amplitude and ramping rate are known and so the m/z is known. This method is known as the mass-selective axial instability mode.

The quadrupole consists of three differently shaped electrodes. Two are identical and have hyperboloidal geometry (small inverted saucers) and are called end-cap electrodes. One end-cap electrode has a single small central aperture through which electrons/ions are gated periodically and the other has several small apertures arranged centrally as well in which ions pass to the detector. Only a single hold is in end-cap electrodes having external ion sources. The 3rd electrode also has hyperboloidal geometry having two sheets rather than one and is called the ring electrode.

Corthals GL, Molloy MP, Herbert BR, Williams KL, Gooley AA (1997) Electrophoresis 18, 317-323.

Prefractionation of Protein Samples Prior to Two-Dimensional Electrophoresis

ABSTRACT. Thousands of proteins may be visualised on a two-dimensional (2-D) gel, but only hundreds are present at levels sufficient for chemical analysis. Therefore, prefractionation of protein samples prior to 2-D polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) will be important for the investigation of proteins that are present at sub-picogram levels in physiological samples. We describe an approach to prefractionate protein samples prior to 2-D PAGE using the Gradiflow, which is a new (preparative) electrokinetic membrane apparatus designed to fractionate proteins in a number of different ways. We have fractionated human serum under nonreducing conditions using the 'reflux' mode, in which proteins are fractionated according to their relative mobility under controlled electrophoretic conditions, where the current is periodically reversed. We describe how fractionation occurs and present examples of enrichment of specific proteins.

Vidal P, Morris MC, Chaloin L, Mery J, Heitz F, Divita G (1997) Lett. Peptide Sci. 4, 227-230.

Conformations of a synthetic peptide which facilitates the cellular delivery of nucleic acids

The peptide Ac-GALFLGFLGAAGSTMGAWSQPKSKRKV-Cya was synthesized. The first 17 N-terminal residues come from a hydrophobic region of HIV gp41 fragment and the final seven from a highly basic segment of a nuclear localization sequence (NLS) of SV40. The Trp residue provides intrinsic fluorescence, while a proline residue helps to break conformation. Synthesis was done using AEDI-Expansin resin on a Fmoc/tBu system and double couplings for Arg, Lys, Ser, and Thr. The peptide was purified on RP-HPLC with MeCN+0.1% TFA gradient and, with theoretical mass 2867.5, shows up on ESI-MS in positive mode at [M+H]+ m/z 2864. In addition an amino acid analysis was done.

The peptide was evaluated by circular dichroism, and the spectrum of peptide in pure water shows a single minimum at 198 nm, indicating unordered structure. When placed in 30% trifluoroethanol (TFE), the spectrum now shows two minima at 221 and 207 nm and a maximum at 193 nm, strongly indicating organization into α-helix. Increasing to 50% does not alter the spectrum from a plot of −Ellpticity vs. percent TFE in water at λ= 222 nm. The water-TFE titration is characterized by isodichroic point at 202 nm suggesting equilibrium between two conformational states. One state can be assigned to the α-helix, but the nature of the state in pure water is not known although it is not random coil. In a 20 mM potassium phosphate pH 7.2 buffer, the spectrum shows a single minimum centered at 212 nm, seen also at higher (100 mM) phosphate concentration. There is no peptide concentration dependence on spectrum. The minimum position is at a rather low wavelength compare to that typical for pure β-sheet (217 nm), and there is a suggestion of some β-sheet conformation. That there is a mix of structures is seen also in low ellipticity intensity and that no crossover occurs. Changes in peptide concentration also show changes in CD spectrum: increases in concentration appear to induce structural arrangements which appear to be β-sheet.

Moniatte M, Lesieur C, Vecsey-Semjen B, Buckley JT, Pattus F, van der Goot FG, Van Dorsselaer A (1997) Int. J. Mass Spectrom. Ion Proc. 169/170 179-199.

Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry in The Subunit Stoichiometry Study of High-Mass Non-Covalent Complexes

It is generally believed that multimeric proteins associated noncovalently cannot withstand sample preparation conditions for MALDI and that nonetheless ionization of the multimer cannot occur under MALDI conditions. Karas and Hillenkamp however reported in some case noncovalent complexes of catalase and strepavidin but that results were not always reproducible and that monomers were more often than not observed.

Proaerolysin was purified from pathogen Aeromonas hydrophila. It is a 335 kDa heptamer with UV concentration of 2.5 AU at 280 nm where 1 mg/ml is present. 4 mg/ml was dialyzed against 5 mM ammonium acetate pH 7.6 extensively at 4°. 20 µl of this is treated with 50 mg/ml trypsin (1:30 enzyme:substrate) which converts proaerolysin dimer to aerolysin. At different times 1 µl is removed and added to 4µl trypsin-chymotrypsin inhibitor (100 µg/ml) and immediately frozen in liq. nitrogen. 1 µl is used for MALDI-TOF and the balance 4 µl is used in SDS-PAGE. Alpha-hemolysin was purified from Wood 46 strain and 2 mg/ml dialyzed against 20 mM NaCl, 20 mM HEPES pH 7.0 at 4° overnight., then incubated 37° for 2 h with some vortexing. Oligomer monomer separation of the hemolysin was done on Sephadex G-75 1.5 × 70 cm column in a 5 mM ammonium acetate pH 6.7 buffer, concentrated to 1 mg/ml on vacuum centrifuge. Catalase from bovine liver, pyruvate kinase from rabbit muscle, yeast ADH, and concanavalin A were all from Sigma and prepared as fresh 20 pmol/µl stock in 10 to 50 mM ammonium acetate pH 7.0. Dilutions of stocks were done only just before MALDI spotting since dilutions over time may result in dissociation of multimers. Controls of stocks included preparation in 50% MeCN with 1% formic acid. Matrices used includ sinapinic acid, ferulic acid, 6-aza-2-thiothymine (ATT), and 2,6-dihydroxyacetophenone (2,6-DHAP).

Sample well spotting is two-step: 1 µl of sinapinic acid saturated in acetone is spotted to the well surface to form microcrystalline base coat. Then 0.5 µl sample dissolved in matrix at 13 mg/ml in pure water or 70:30 water:MeCN is applied. Drying is in air (takes 1 min) or vacuum (within 10 s). A finer crystalline surface is seen as opposed to larger needles. The base coat is believed to serve as nuclei for orienting crystallization. Other matrices are in classical preparatins: sinapinic as 13 mg in 70:30 water:MeCN; ferulic acid in neat tetrahydrofuran as 25 and 40 mg/ml solution; ATT and 2,6-DHAP as 2 and 10 mg/ml in 20 mM diammoniumhydrogen citrate (DAHC). 1 µl sample is mixed with 1 µl matrix and then 0.5 µl is applied and dried under vacuum.

The Bruker BIFLEX MALDI Tof with single stage source SCOUT with X-Y multisample probe including imaging and gridless reflector. A 337 nm 3 Hz pulsing nitrogen laser is used. Linear positive ion mode with 30 kV acceleration. A HIMAS detector with Venetian blind conversion dynode, MCP, and scintillator with multiplier was equipped; it can be operated in post-acceleration mode or not, but PAD is required for improving sensitivity of high mass ions. Ions are postaccelerated and then detected as secondary ions in a single MCP. PAD is set to 8-8.5 kV. Mass calibration involved use of ACTH 18-39, insulin (MW 5733.6), and cytochrome c equine (MW 12360). A Micromass VG Bio-Q triple quadrupole with Quattro (Q1) upgrade with m/z range to 4000 and Q2 with range to m/z 8000 was used so that detection of low charge states was possible. Mass analysis was set on Q1 when charge states with m/z 4000 or less were studied. Q1 and hexapole collision are set to high pass filters in rf only mode to transmit to Q2 for higher mass charge states. Solution is 25 mM ammonium acetate pH 7 using 10 pmol/µl sample. Sample cone is 20-120 V and source temp is 40 ° to minimize denaturation.

Proaerolysin is a 52 kDa dimer activated by 40 amino acid cleaved from C-terminus, this determined by ESI-MS. The 48 kDa dimer activated toxin binds to receptor on a target cell with oligomerization of the toxin to create transmembrane channel leading to cell death. Under SDS-PAGE this complex is stable, but in 70% formic acid for 30 min at RT it will dissociate; it has been shown to associate as a heptamer of 335 kDa using MALDI ToF, but the heptamer is not observed in ESI-MS. The time-dependent formation of the heptamer was studied with trypsin in a MALDI spotting-compatible buffer (5 mM ammonium acetate) with MALDI-ToF and SDS-PAGE monitoring.

Using standard dried droplet technique produced spectra with heptamer seen, but peaks were very broad and not reproducible. So a base coat to create crystallization nuclei upon which 1 µl of sample/matrix with 10 pmol sample in matrix in plain water or MeCN/water mix were tried. The better microcrystallization produced reproducible and narrower peaks. The dried droplet technique can be managed if the 10 pmol/µl sample is diluted 4 times; spectra will quickly decay however.

Spectra in range m/z50,000 to 400,000 are viewed over time course of t = 0, 3, 6, and 12 h. At time zero, a 2M+ peak at m/z 104,000 is barely seen above the more dominant m/z 52,000 monomer form. This continues to be barely detected at 3 and 6 h. At 12 h, several detectable peaks corresponding to heptamer in multiple charge states (7M+, 7M2+, 7M3+, and the 4+ form also). In addition the 48 kDa areolysin form is seen.

S aureus alpha-hemolysin is a 33.2 kDa hydrophilic monomer that also binds to cell membranes, whose monomers assemble to form a 232.4 kDa oligomer transmembrane pore, established also to be a heptamer. With sinapinic acid dried droplet, we could see only a monomer of aHL using MALDI-TOF. In ferulic acid both the monomer at m/z 33,800 and a broad peak centered at m/z 241000 were seen. In ATT in 20 mM ammonium citrate two broad peaks at 241 and 120.5 kDa are seen, being the +1 and +2 states of the heptamer. Peaks at 33.4 and 66.5 kDa were seen (+1 states of monomer and dimer). Some trimer, but no pentamers or hexamers were seen. Small peptide adducts caused peak broadening. Greater dilution improved signal to noise with improved resolution to eliminate pentamer, hexamer and octamer signals, and only heptamer at 234.9 kDa. Sample at 500 fmol/µl with low laser energy was best.

Four well known tetramers were characterized. They easily dissociate in SDS-PAGE. All were dialyzed in 20 mM ammonium acetate pH 7 and then mixed with matrix. The two-step sinapinic acid was tried as well as ferulic acid in THF and 2,6-DHAP in 20 mM aqueous DAHC. Bovine catalase is an assembly of a 60 kDa homotetramer. The sinapinic acid and 2,6-DHAP preps gave poor spectra, but ferulic acid showed tetramer and monomer as two series of broad peaks. Peak broadness is caused by matrix and salt adduct associations and possibly by loss of heme. Spectra with oligomer demonstrations decay quickly. The ESI-MS spectra showed a broad peak of tiny peaks with no multiple charge states, but desolvation is a problem because of the absence of organic components. Adjustments to cone voltage and gas flows were of little help.

With pyruvate kinase (57.2 kDa subunit forming homotetramer) ferulic acid spectra were not good, nor was 2,6-DHAP in DHAC. Sinapinic dried droplet worked if the sample-matrix second application was rapidly dried under vacuum, although spectra are observed with air drying. The rapid drying probably means that the tetramer is in contact with denaturing conditions for only a brief period and so most of the tetramer remains intact. In ESI-MS, multiply charged ions of the tetramer were seen in m/z range 6000-6700.

Yeast ADH could be observed only with 2,6-DAPH in DHAC. Monomer and dimer are seen with no trimer or pentamer. Rapid drying was necessary for maintaining tetramer. pH may play a role in dissociation since sinapinic acid has a pH 2.5 while the 2,6-DHAP has a pH of about 5. ESI-MS also revealed the tetramer quite easily.

Concanavalin A is predominantly a dimer at pH 5.8 and tetramer at pH 7.5 and above. Matrix and sample will not cocrystallize at pH 8.5 and so an ammonium buffer at pH 7.0 was used. Intense dimer and weaker tetramer peaks are seen in this case. With ferulic acid and sinapinic two-step, only monomer and dimer peaks are seen and fast evaporation was of no use. ESI-MS spectra showed presence of monomer, dimer and tetamer in ammonium acetate pH 7.0, as shown by others.

FD

Li H, Siu KWM, Guevremont R, Le Blanc JCY (1997) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 8, 781-792.

Complexes of Silver(I) With Peptides and Proteins as Produced in Electrospray Mass Spectrometry

Silver(I) cation is considered a soft cation in Pearson's classification preferring to bind to soft ligands that are polarizable. The soft functional groups in proteins include sulfur on Cys and Met. Metal binding to these groups can offer much information analytically. Fragmentation pathways of metal-bound peptides can be distinct from protonated peptides. The binding of transition metals diffes from other metals (alkali, alkaline earth). Peptides were cationized with protons or metals, deposited on silver, then bombarded with Cs ions to obtain spectra. Results suggested that Ag+ was likely chelated to N-termnal N atom and carbonyl O atom of 2nd residue whereas Na+ was chelated only to carbonyl O atom. Oligopeptides have been studied with Co(II), Mn(II), Ni(II), and Fe(II) and it was suggested that chelation occurs to N-terminal amino group, deprotonated amide N atoms, and C-terminal COO− anion. Interaction of metal with aromatic rings when present is seen. Cys-containing peptides interact with Fe(II). The His and carbonyl O atoms of angiotensin was found to interact with Zn(II). Cu(II) binds via N- and C-terminus.

Experimental. A SCIEX TAGA 6000E triple quad with home-made electrospray probe, and PE-SCIEX API 300 ESI-MS are used. Positive ion mode with scan speeds of 10-50 ms per m/z unit with ten summed scans is used to obtain spectra. Argon or nitrogen is used in collision cell at pressures designed to produce only a single collision, and collision energies of 40-80 eV are used. 59 oligopeptides having lengths of 2 to 11 residues, and a few proteins. About half had one or more Met residues, and one-third had residues with only neutral side chains. All are obtained from Sigma. Peptide concentrations were from 10 µM to 2 mM, and solutions of AgNO3 ranged from 1-10 mM in 50 mM acetic acid in 1:1 water:MeOH. In some cases acetic acid was not present. Flow rates were 1 µl/min. The semiempirical program ZINDO was used for molecular modeling. Geometry of complex formation is optimized by minimizing complex total energy.

Bovine insulin was mixed with Ag+ in 50 mM acetic acid and the spectrum showed four clusters of peaks with cationic charges ranging from 5+ to 8+ in which the ions had a [M + mH + nAg](m + n)+ pattern where, for example the 6+ cluster, m ranged from 1 to 6 and n also ranged from 1 to 6. Bovine insulin has two N- and C-termini, four basic residues, and six Cys residues all connected in three disulfide bonds. In just acid, it is fully protonated to 6+ for the possible protonations. In silver, charges higher than 6+ are possible indicating that silver does not merely displace the position held by protons.

Because of the presence of soft atoms like sulfur which could bind to silver, the peptide YGGFM (Met-enkephalin) and YGGFL (Leu-enkephalin) were tested as a sulfur- and nonsulfur-containing nearly identical molecule. The spectra in silver were quite different. Met-enkepalin had a [M+H+Ag]2+ form while Leu-enk was [M+H]+. While [M+Ag]+ and [M - H + 2Ag]+ were present in both spectra, they were less abundant relative to [M + H + Ag]2+ for Met-enk and to [M+H]+ for Leu-enk. Most important is that silver ion binds despite the absence of sulfur. Spectra for pH 7 solutions were quite similar to pH 3 solutions: increasing pH from 3 to 7 created a small increase of ratio of abundance of Ag-containing to non-Ag-containing peptide (from 12.1 to 14.6 for Met-enk and 0.33 to 0.49 for Leu-enk).

A longer oligopeptide, substance P (RPKPQQFFGLM-nh2) and its norleucine analogue (like Met, but a methylene -CH2- in place of the S atom), were tried. Both are C-terminal amides lacking a carboxylate, which could complex with silver. The ESI-MS spectra for pH 3 solution shows a prominent ion for [M+2H+Ag]3+ but the Nle11-Substance P major ion is [M + 2H]2+; while the [M+2H+Ag]3+ ion is present, it is far less of a presence in the spectrum. In pH 7 the major ions are the same as for pH 3.

A set of 24 di- and tripeptides with and without Met were tested in pH 3. For peptides with one Met, the [M+Ag]+:[M+H]+ ratio was 0.39; for peptides with no Met, the ratio is 0.05, and for Met-Met, the ratio is 5.9. For Met-enk, the ratio is 12.1, Leu-enk 0.33, substance P 13.4, and [Nle11]substance P 0.12. Thus the presence of sulfur strongly affects silver affinity.

In another special ESI-MS setup, the peptide solution (YGGFM) is infused into one spray system and silver nitrate infused from another side, the needle both charged at 3000 V. Both sprays traverse a copper tube charged at 1000 V, with compressed air blown in. The gas phase ions then mix at a T. Ag does not bind to Met-enk in this case, which means adducts do not form at 1 atm or in the lens region of the MS; they can only form in solution.

In the next phase, CID fragmentation is done on di- and tripeptides. A product ion spectrum of GlyAlaAla [M + 107Ag]+ shows that most product ions are Ag-associated. These product ions in general are the following species:

  1. [an - H + Ag]+
  2. [bn - H + Ag]+
  3. [yn + H + Ag]+
  4. [bn + OH + Ag]+

The first three species are seen in low energy fragmentation of singly substituted silver bound peptides. The last ion species is seen with fragmentation of alkali metal-containing peptides. In the product ion spectrum of [M+Ag]+ of GlyMet. If Ag binds to the Met S atom, then an N-terminal fragment ion shorter than and including b1 would be cleaved at amide bond and not contain sulfur. The [b1 + OH + Ag]+ is at the m/z 182 ion, which means that Ag+ must be bound to functional groups on N-terminal side of point of cleavage. ZINDO was used to determine the three lowest energy structures of the [M+Ag]+ ion. It is not so much important that they are really the lowest energy structures, but they all show Ag+ bound to the Met S atoms and to functional groups such as carbonyl O and amide N atoms, and to N-terminal amine N. Thus a chelation is shown. These models also are true when sulfur is not present. Peptides with three or more residues also show this chelation. The [M+Ag]+ ion of Met-enk shows a product ion spectrum populated with N-terminal fragment ions ([a4-H+Ag]+, b3-H+Ag]+, b3+OH+Ag]+) which do not have Met side chain but they are complexed to silver. The C-terminal side silver-containing ions ([y3+H+Ag]+, y4+H+Ag]+) contain the sulfur but have low abundance. If Met is replaced by Leu, then there are no y ions. These findings had been reported by Tang et al with Cs+ bombardment.

For the [M+H+Ag]2+ precursor instead of [M+Ag]+, the doubly charged will form a product with minimized coulombic repulsion, a short peptide with no basic residues and proton on the N-terminal amine N and silver ion on carboxylate anion. The more abundant y ions and less abundant b ions containing Ag support this expectation. For the triply charged precursor [M+2H+Ag]3+ of substance P and Nle analogue, there are strong intensities for b ions ([b10 + Ag]2+ for Met-containing and [b9 + Ag]2+ for Nle-containing). Additionally substance P produces [yn + H + Ag]+ where n is 5 and 6, but the Nle form does not produce these ions All product ion spectra were recorded several times to ensure reproducibility.

An interesting finding is what happens to as the peptide grows longer and whether it contains sulfur atoms. The hypothesis is that while silver is chelated by several groups it is anchored by the S atom of Met. The Ag-S bond is special in that it has strong σ bonds with readily polarizable S atom, but also π bond from electrons in metal dπ to ligand pπ orbitals. Sulfur has low electronegativity and high polarizability. Ag(I), Au(I) and Hg(II) readily bond to S atoms which is why they are used as heavy atom derivatives in crystallography. In acidic conditions, the carboxyl group is unionized and thus does not compete. Amide forms of peptides reveal the effect of carboxylate anion. In neutral and acidic solutions, the metal competes for protons to bind the amino terminal. There is evidence to suggest that solution and gas-phase structures are distinct and that rearrangement in the gas phase occurs within a few milliseconds. In solution silver ion is bound to S atom, but rearrangement suggests less of a role in interact with silver. Ion movements and structural rearrangements are more likely since the absence of solvation increases coulombic effects. In particular the loss of water may require the peptide to solvate the silver ion and wrap around it.

Rouse JC, Strang A-M, Yu W, Vath JE (1998) Anal. Biochem. 256, 33-46.

Isomeric Differentiation of Asparagine-Linked Oligosaccharides by Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption-Ionization Postsource Decay Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. Matrix-assisted laser desorption-ionization (MALDI) postsource decay (PSD) was used to differentiate glycoprotein- released N-linked oligosaccharide isomers directly from aliquots of glycosidase digests and peak fractions collected from high-pH anion exchange chromatography (HPAEC) with minimal sample handling and material. With the implementation of instrumental tuning and acquisition controls, MALDIPSD of NMR-characterized high-mannose, hybrid, and complex standards resulted in spectra with reproducible fragment ion peak intensity ratios which correlated well to the respective oligosaccharide branching patterns. A knowledge-based strategy was utilized to characterize unknown isomeric N-glycan structures in which specific fragment ion types and their distributions in the unknown PSD spectrum were compared to those in PSD spectra of standards possessing similar structural features. This PSD knowledge-based isomeric differentiation strategy was applied to distinguishing recombinant glycoprotein-derived Man7 D1 versus D2/D3 isomers directly from a PNGaseF digest aliquot of high-mannose N-glycans based on branching differences. A precursor ion selection device was employed to isolate the component of interest from the mass profile without additional chromatographic isolation steps. MALDIMS signal-tobackground was maximized for direct PSD with on-theprobe sample clean-up methods. The asialo complex Nglycan PSD knowledge base was used to differentiate HPAEC peak fractions containing the tri- and tri*-antennary branching isomers and two tetraantennary isomers with antennal versus core fucose locations. Although the particular asialo complex N-glycan isomers here were well separated by HPAEC, MALDIMS alerted us to their presence using m/z-derived monosaccharide compositions and PSD fragmentation allowed us to differentiate these structures using the HPAEC elution positions as guides.

Jai-nhuknan J, Cassady CJ (1998) J. Am Soc. Mass Spectrom. 9, 540-544.

Negative Ion Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Post-Source Decay Calibration By Using Fibrinopeptide B

ABSTRACT. Fibrinopeptide B (Mr 1552.58) was employed as a calibration compound for matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) post-source decay (PSD) fragment ion analysis in the negative mode. Experiments were performed by using both continuous and delayed extraction, with the maximum reflectron voltages being 30 and 21 kV, respectively. For comparison, a common positive ion PSD calibrant, ACTH(1839) (Mr 2466.7), was also employed with positive ion calibration constants being applied to negative ion spectra. Using fibrinopeptide B as the calibrant, the negative ion PSD results for angiotensin II (Mr 1046.2), renin substrate tetradecapeptide (horse) (Mr 1759.0), and the custom-synthesized peptide (K2G4)2 (Mr 987.1) showed a factor of 1.52 improvement in absolute mass accuracy. Typical absolute mass-to-charge ratio accuracies were within 61 Thomson and were achieved even when the peptide being analyzed was more massive than fibrinopeptide B. In addition, both calibrants showed increased accuracy when experiments were conducted in the delayed extraction mode. Other advantages of using fibrinopeptide B are its moderate cost and the ability to perform calibration and sample analysis for negative ion PSD under the same instrumental conditions.

Wannet WJB, Op den Camp HJM, Wisselink, van der Drift C, Van Griensven LJLD, Vogels GD (1998) Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1425, 177-188.

Purification and Characterization of Trehalose Phosphorylase from the Commercial Mushroom Agaricus bisporus

Fruit bodies of A. bisporus strain Horst U1 were obtained from mycelium cultivated on commercially prepared compost at growth stage 3. Mycelium was grown in static 200 ml liq. cultures in Fernbach flask on Dijkstra medium with 50 mM glucose, and harvested 21 days at 24°. Fruit bodies are frozen in liq. nitrogen and ground with glass beads (100 µm size) in mortar. Powdered frozen material is suspended in equal amount of KP buffer (50 mM potassium phosphate pH 7.0, 2 mM DTT, 0.5 mM PMSF, 20% glycerol). This is centrifuged at 40,000 g/30 min/4°. The supernatant (800 ml) was concentrated 5-10 fold in Minitan with MWCO 30 kDa. Alternatively fruit bodies were processed in Braun food-processing machine to yield similar activities. Solid ammonium sulfate (ground) was added to 30% saturation. This was then spun at 30,000 g for 30 min, 4°, and a 50% cut was then taken. The precipitate was resuspended in 50 mM KP buffer, dialyzed in the Minitan. Dialyzed enzyme was run in a Damon/IEC-B60 ultracentrifuge at 200,000 g for 1 h, 4° in a Beckman SB 283 swing out rotor to remove membrane fragments.

Supernatant was divided into several portions, each loaded on to Q-Sepharose Fast Flow (1.5 × 30 cm) equilibrated on 0.3 M KP buffer. After washing, elution was with 0.3-0.7 M KP linear gradient. Fractions pooled were concentrated on YM30 Diaflo (Amicon).

[continued: but the only thing interesting here was the tissue processing for the mushroom]

Cottrell JC, Green BN (1998) Micromass Application Note 212

MaxEnt: An Essential Maximum Entropy Based Tool for Interpreting Multiply-Charged Electrospray Data

A 20 kDa protein may generate a series of 10-20 peaks in an electrospray because of multiply charged states. In analyzing these peaks, each is transformed to a single peak on the scale to provide a zero-charge spectrum. An early method produced artefacts and a baseline increasing with mass. The Micromass Transform method produces artefact-free zero-charge spectrum. Ferrige et al. (Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 6: 707, 1992) described a method based on maximum entropy. The analysis is computationally intensive and processing over a wide range takes 5 minutes with a coarse mass scale of 3-5 Da per channel. This does not yield accurate masses, so a second analysis is repeated over the approximate masses in a narrower 0. 5-1 Da per channel scale.

Methane monooxygenase A is a non-heme iron protein composed of three subunits with masses of 20, 45, and 60 kDa (γ, β, and α subnits, respectively). Each chain is multiply charged in ESI, and these charge peaks overlap. Peaks are evaluated for the zero-charge form.

Vestal M, Juhasz P (1998) J. Am Soc. Mass Spectrom. 9, 892-911.

Resolution and Mass Accuracy in Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization Time-of-Flight

Early work with MALDI-ToF involved poor resolution and limited mass accuracy. The major limitations on resolution and accuracy is the broad distribution of intial velocities. Delayed extraction minimizes the effects on initial velocity.
