Although basic physics theory describes time of flight ion movement, for any combination of uniform electric fields the exact equation for TOF can be approximated by expression:

t = (Df0/vn)[1 + f1p/f0 + f2p2/f0 + f3p3/f0 + ... − (2day/f0D) (v0/vn)]   [1]

where D is the pathlength of the field-free region, da is length of first acceleration region, v0 is initial ion velocity, vn is ion velocity of particular m/z after acceleration from rest through total accelerating potential V, and y is ratio of V to the portion applied across first accelerating region. The analyzer geometry and relative operating voltages are contained in dimensionless coefficients f0 to f3; there are also expressions for common configurations include one- and two-field ion sources and mirrors. p is a dimensionless perturbation is the energy deficit of an ion produced at position x, with initial velocity v0 divided by normal kinetic energy after first stage of acceleration.

The m/z of ions is within the expressions for p and vn:

p = x/da − yT0/zV = x/da − y(v0/vn)2    [2]
vn = (2zV/m)½   [3]
T0 = mv02/2   [4]

Eq [1] accuracy is limited only by truncation of power series in p. If power series continues to infinity, eq [1] is exactly equivalent to equation from which it was derived. The last term of eq [1] which depends on first power of initial velocity is exact in all cases. p is on order of 1% or less for most applications considered, and error obtained by truncating after cubic term is < 1 ppm. For higher accuracy or if p is larger, more terms must be added to expansion.

Rewriting eq [1]:

t = tn[(1 + ε(x, v0)]    [5]

where

tn = Df0/vn    [6]
ε(x, v0) = f1pf0 + f2p2f0 + f3p3f0 + ... − (2day/f0D)(v0/vn)    [7]

Eq [5] rearranges to:

ε(x, v0) = (t − tn) / tn   [8]

Note that nominal flight time tn is given by effective flight distance Df0 divided by nominal velocity vn. The distribution of flight times relative to nominal is expressed in ε(x, v0).

Focusing in TOF MS means minimizing the dependence of flight time on initial conditions. The general condition for focusing to a particular order is that the derivative of the quantity in question with respect to variable in question (initial position or velocity) disappears at the mean of the distribution of the variable. First order focusing means the first derivative must be zero, and second order focusing means first and second order derivative vanish, and so on. The first derivative of flight time with respect velocity and position cannot vanish simultaneously, so if space focusing might be used when velocity distribution is narrow while velocity focusing might be used when spatial distribution is narrow. In cases where orthogonal injection or gas phase ionization in TOF ion source occurs, the ratio v0/vn is small and independent of m/z; the challenge is to reduce dependence on initial position x. While called space focusing, in reality it is energy focusing.

For space focusing, assume negligible initial velocity:

ε(x, v0 = 0) = f1(x/da)/f0 + f2(x/da)2f0 + f3(x/da)3f0 + ...    [9]

The particular coefficient in the power series in x/da should vanish for space focusing to a particular order. For first order space focusing, f1 should be zero, for second order f1 and f2 should be zero, and so on. Space focusing will not affect last term of Eq [1] or [7], propotional to first power of initial velocity.

Velocity focusing requires minimizing flight time dependence on initial velocity, including first power term. This can be obtained by delaying the accelerating field application. Ions are produced in a field-free region, and then the first acceleration field is delayed for some time Δt. Ion position is given by

x = v0Δt    [10]

Molloy MP, Herbert BR, Walsh BJ, Tyler MI, Traini M, Sanchez JC, Hochstrasser DF, Williams KL, Gooley AA (1998) Electrophoresis 18, 837-844.

Extraction of Membrane Proteins by Differential Solubilization for separation using two-dimensional gel electrophoresis

ABSTRACT. We describe the extraction and enrichment of membrane proteins for separation by two-dimensional polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (2-D PAGE) after differential solubilization of an Escherichia coli cell lysate. In a simple three-step sequential solubilization protocol applicable for whole cell lysates, membrane proteins are partitioned from other cellular proteins by their insolubility in solutions conventionally used for isoelectric focusing (IEF). As the first step, Tris-base was used to solubilize many cytosolic proteins. The resultant pellet was then subjected to conventional solubilizing solutions (urea, 3-[(3-cholamidopropyl)dimethylammonio]-1-propanesulfonate, dithiothreitol, Tris, carrier ampholytes). Following the completion of this step, 89% of the initial E. coli sample mass was solubilized. Finally, the membrane protein rich pellet was partially solubilized using a combination of urea, thiourea, tributyl phosphine and multiple zwitterionic surfactants. Using N-terminal sequence tagging and peptide mass fingerprinting we have identified 11 membrane proteins from this pellet. Two of these outer membrane proteins (Omp), OmpW and OmpX, have previously been known only as an open reading frame in E. coli, while OmpC, OmpT and OmpTOLC have not previously been identified on a 2-D gel. The prefractionation of an entire cell lysate into multiple fractions, based on solubility, results in simplified protein patterns following 2-D PAGE using broad-range pH 3.5-10 immobilized pH gradients (IPGs). Additional advantages of sample prefractionation are that protein identification and gel matching, for database construction, is a more manageable task, the procedure requires no specialized apparatus, and the sequential extraction is conducted in a single centrifuge tube, minimizing protein loss.

Herbert BR, Molloy MP, Gooley AA, Walsh BJ, Bryson WG, Williams KL (1998) Electrophoresis 19, 845-851.

Improved Protein Solubility in Two-Dimensional Electrophoresis Using Tributyl Phosphine As Reducing Agent

ABSTRACT. In this study, dithiothreitol was replaced by tributyl phosphine as the reducing agent in both the sample solution for the first-dimensional isoelectric focusing and during the immobilised pH gradient (IPG) equilibration procedure. Tributyl phosphine improves protein solubility during isoelectric focusing, which results in shorter run times and increased resolution. Tributyl phosphine is nonionic and thus does not migrate in the IPG, therefore maintaining reducing conditions during the course of the first-dimensional separation. The increased solubility provided by the maintenance of reducing conditions gives improved focusing and decreased horizontal streaking on the subsequent second-dimension gel. The use of tributyl phosphine in the equilibration step allows the procedure to be simplified, incorporating reduction and alkylation in a single step. This is possible because, in direct contrast to dithiothreitol (DTT), tributyl phosphine does not contain a free thiol and therefore does not react with thiol-specific alkylating reagents.

Papac DI, Briggs JB, Chin ET, Jones AJS (1998) Glycobiol. 8, 445-454.

A High-Throughput Microscale Method to Release N-Linked Oligosaccharides from Glycoproteins for Matrix-Assisted Laser Desportion/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometric Analysis

The MultiScreen-IP is a 96-well plate from Millipore (Cat #S2EM004M99, 10 plates) composed of PVDF membrane, 0.45 µm pore size. It was used to develop a high-throughput microscale method to remove sugars. The plate comes in a wide variety of membranes although Immobilon P (PVDF) is used here. The system has the ability to concentrate bound material from dilute solutions. An underside vacuum is created gently from a manifold; a rubber gasket with small aperture moves effluent from each well down. The vacuum was not used however: rather the bound material is recovered by pipet and transferred to conical tubes.

Plate wells are wetted with MeOH, washed repeatedly with water, then protein is added and reductively alkylated. Membrane is then blocked with PVP360 to prevent glycosidase adsorption. After washing away block, the glycosidase is added. Peptide N-glycosidase F (PNGaseF) is added in a pH 8.3 10 mM Tris acetate buffer (recommended buffer is 20 mM sodium phosphate pH 7.5 with 50 mM EDTA, not used because of lactone formation on SCX resin and decrease in S/N). Incubation time and concentration of PNGaseF must be determined for each substrate. This is done by comparing the mass spectral intensity during the release of the N-linked oligosaccharide. 20 µg of recombinant t-PA is added to each well and variable amounts of glycosidase are added from 3.1 to 50 U/ml in 50 µl volume. Best conditions were 18 h when 6.3 U/ml PNGaseF added. With 12.5 U/ml there was no changed in spectral intensity after 2, 4, or 24 h digestion time. Thus if a 25 U/ml treatment for 3 h, this ought to ensure thorough deglycosylation.

Reversed-phase HPLC @ 214 nm was used to monitor trypsin digestion of rt-PA either before or after PNGaseF treatment. 50 µg of rt-PA is applied to wells and then bound material subjected to digestion. 13 peptides could be seen. Two glycopeptides (of three expected) are seen as the first to elute. The T11 peptide when glycosylated comes off at 55 min, and when deglycosylated at 58.5 min; this is a high-mannose type. Unfortunately none of these peptides were ionizable in the MALDI-TOF.

Sialyated oligosaccharides are analyzed in negative ion mode. Neutral oligosaccharides of the high-mannose type are seen as sodium adducts [M + Na]+, acquired in positive ion mode. With citrate, negative ion mode can be used [M + 191]−. Only 1% of material was recovered, corresponding to ~850 fmol of rt-PA. The signal-to-noise was 10:1 even with a minor species, and the mass accuracy was better than 0.05%.

Campagna S, Vitoux B, Humbert G, Girardet JM, Linden G, Haertle T, Gaillard JL (1998) J. Dairy Sci. 81, 3139-3148.

Conformational Studies of a Synthetic Peptide from the Putative Lipid-binding Domain of Bovine Milk Component PP3

Component PP3 is a bovine milk glycosylated phosphoprotein from the proteose-peptone fraction with 28 kDa mass and 135 amino acids. It has 54% homology with camel whey protein. The gene itself has 56% homology with murine and rat glycosylation-dependent cell adhesion molecule (GlyCAM-1), indicating an immune defense function. The phosphorylated N-terminal domain has two Fe(III) binding sites. and there is a suggestion of PSer residues binding calcium ions too. The C-terminus is proposed to have an amphipathic α-helix and so it is a surfactant too, possibly binding lipids in function. PP3 has a strong affinity for an oil-water interface and it inhibits lipoprotein lipase prresent in milk. Nonetheless the PP3 function is not really known. PP3 119-135 was prepared on Perkin-Elmer Synergy 432 using 9-Fmoc chemistry. Secondary structure prediction was done by seven different published algorithms, and assignment to helix or sheet was made if four of the seven programs agreed; moreover, a stable β-sheet or α-helix required at least five consecutive residues. Hydrophobic cluster analysis (HCA) [Garboraud et al, FEBS Lett 224: 149, 1987) was also used, with HCA alignments done by a plot program from Doriane SA (Paris, FR).

In examining the secondary structure of the peptide, comparisons were made to camel whey protein and mouse/rat GlyCAM-1. The C-terminal region is residue 97-135 and predicted to have α-helix. Several methods were used to evaluate this and together they provide the highest confidence, while alone, the methods are less accurate than 65% for a single sequence input. Use of evolutionary information provided by multiple sequence alignments have been shown to improve prediction confidence to 70%. Other PP3 predicted helical regions are 8-13, 19-28, 43-48 and 68-79, all reduced length. Serines at 29, 34, 38, 40, and 46 are phosphorylated and Thr-17 and Asn-77 are glycosylated, and probably affect accuracy of prediction since models do not assume PTMs.

An HCA plot was developed to show the relationship between the four homologous proteins. In the 2D pattern nearly identical features are seen in the C-terminal region. Superimposable hydrophobic clusters display shapes typical of amphipathic α-helix. The segment 33-52 in PP3 show cluster shapes readily recognized within homologous parts of related proteins, and these two clusters may be critical for function and maintenance of the stability of the protein. Similarity between C-terminal domains of artiodactyl and rodent proteins is not observable in primary structure alignment of bovine PP3 and homologues. Use of HCA can however aid in detecting folding similarities despite nonconservation of fragments as detection is not sensitive to insertions or gaps in other sequence alignment methods. Sequence alignment and secondary structure prediction as combined analyses are more appropriate for identifying consserved domains of protein families s matrix choice in alignment gives less bias. Amphipathy in residues 99-135 can be assayed quantitatively with the Eisenberg et al helical hydrophobic moment. A helical hydrophobic moment reaches its maximum when each residue is offset 100 degrees from the preceding (usual for α-helix). The mean hydrophobic moment per residue is 0.49. Both isolation and synthesis of the peptide proved difficult because of its extremely high aggregation potential, so the peptide 119-135 was studied isntead.

CD spectra were recorded from 10-500 µM 119-135 peptide and spectral appearance was independent of changes in concentration; thus the peptide is a monomer in this concentration range. Spectra show random coiling. In 50% and 90% TFE, spectra show two bands with negative ellipticity centered at 222 and 208 nm, where n→π and π→π* transitions occur, respectively. A positive band at 190 nm indicates another π→π* transition, usually indicative of α-helix. In CD spectra of known 310 helices −[θ]208 > −[θ]222, although this is controversial since one report showed completely contrasting results and 310 and α-helices may not be distinguishable by CD. Ellipticity for a 17-residue peptide helix is [θ]222 = −32,000 deg-cm2dmol−1. Used as a measure of 100% helicity, the peptide show 23% helicity in 50% TFE and 29% helicity in 90% TFE. How TFE induces helicity is not completely understood, although Jasanoff and Fersht have proposed how it might work. In SDS-containing buffer, CD spectra were changed in and SDS concentration- and SDS-to-peptide-dependent way. 10 mM SDS is sufficient to form micelles and the CD spectrum shows 46% α-helical structure. Increasing SDS to 50 mM does not move the helicity at all (47%). At lower concentrations of SDS (1.75 mM), there are two clear minima at 208 and 222, strongly indicating α-helix. This probably discounts the idea that formation of micelles induces helix since 1.75 mM is below the critical micellar concentration. It may be the case that peptide molecules accumulate SDS molecules around themselves and create a microenvironment concentration that becomes micellar. At [SDS] < 1.75 mM CD spectrum show single minimum at 216 nm, similar to β-sheet and non-micellar SDS promotes β-structures while keeping molecule soluble. At very low [SDS] (< 1 mM), peptide 119-135 precipitates likely because β-sheet promotes aggregation.

Thus amphipathic α-helix is promoted in TFE and in SDS > 1.75 mM. The helix affinity for a lipid-aqueous interface is consistent with amphipathic structure. Dimyristoyl phosphatidylglycerol (DMPG) liposomes were prepared as lipid:peptide 10:1 and CD spectra show α-helix, and below the ratio it is β-sheet (a single negative minimum at 217 nm). When lipid:peptide exceeds 10:1 helicity decreases. At 90:1 molar ellipticity minima at 222 and 208 nm are nearly the same intensity, and [θ]222:[θ]208 is 1.01, thought to correspond to coiled-coil α-helices. Normally the ratio is lower than 1 in plane single-stranded α-helix.

In adequate concentrations of charged lipid peptide 119-135 folds into an α-helix. Anionic lipids (SDS) promote helical conformations and their interaction with the positively charged C-terminal might be important. Peptide was dissolved L-α-lysophosphatidylcholine (LPC) which are electrically neutral zwitterions. At 20:1 peptide:lipid CD spectra show peptide 119-135 with double minima characterstic of α-helix. At 203 nm is an isodichroic point with various peptide:LPC ratios and so there is a two-state α-helix and random coil equilibrium. For transition from random coil to helix the hydrophobicity. Anionic lipid heads do not have an absolutely required attraction to positively charged Lys residues.

Das C, Raghothama S, Balaram P (1998) J. Am. Chem. Soc. 120, 5812-5813

A Designed Three Stranded β-Sheet Peptide as a Multiple β-Hairpin Model

β-Hairpins likely nucleate β-sheets in protein folding. Multiple hairpin structures are successive strands connected by short loops of 2-5 residues and found in transmembrane β-barrels which are typical of bacterial porins. Isolated β-hairpins are stable in aqueous and organic solvents. Central nucleating segment can for either type I′ or type II′ β-turns, features widely seen in proteins. Peptides which can model/mimic will from first principles show rigorous test of understanding of factors affecting polypeptide stereochemistry. Purposeful design of peptides has mostly been on helical structures although the first one targeted β-sheets. β-sheets are complicated by limited solubility and tendency of strands to aggregate in solution. Strong residue pair correlations are not sen in β-hairpins. Many amino acids with β-branched side chains (Val, Ile, Thr) are seen in β-sheet structures and so designed peptides make use of these residues. Type II′ β-turn conformation is adopted by a central Pro-Xxx which stablizes the β-hairpin formation. The pyrrolidine ring restricts the φ angle in Pro to ~60°, and the key determinants in β-hairpin are β-turn nucleation and H-bonding between strands.

The peptide Boc-Leu-Phe-Val-dPro-Gly-Leu-Val-Leu-Ala-dPro-Gly-Phe-Val-Leu-OMe is a 14-residue (bold residues every fifth) with two D-Pro-Gly residues that provide the β-turn, giving three strands of a 3-4-3 residue hairpinning. It is highly soluble in organic solvents, including chloroform. 500 MHz proton NMR in CDCl3 showed sharp spectrum. As there was no concentration dependence seen with NH chemical shifts over range of 7.1 to 0.2 mM, this indicates that there was no aggregation effects. When there is a wide dispersion of NH and CαH shifts, this facilitates complete assignment and indicative of well-defined conformational species in solution. A combination of TOCSY and ROESY was used to assign all backbone proton resonance. A table presents all chemical shifts and coupling constants and their assignments. Vicinal JHNCαH values for potential strand residues are > 8.5 Hz, several > 9 Hz which indicate φ~120° throughout the strand segments. When the free radical 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) is added there are only two resonances, Gly5 and Gly11, which broaden significantly. Adding deuterated DMSO [(CD)3SO] to CDCl3 would perturb only exposed NH groups that create solute-solvent H-bonding. From the table of chemical shifts (Δδ values), only four NH groups on Phe2, Gly5, Gly11, and Val13 show large downfield shifts indicating their exposure. Eight remaining NH groups seem solvent-inaccessible and are probably involved in intramolecular H-bonding. The Gly5-Leu6 and Gly11-Phe12 show two critical NiH ↔ Ni+1H NOEs establish the backbone dihedral anlge for residues 11 and 12 (φ~−60° ± 30°; ψ~−40°±30°) consistent with residues in the i + 2 position of type II′ β-turns. There are an absence of interresidue NiH ↔ Ni+1H NOEs in the strand segments and there are intense interresidue CαiH ↔ Ni+1H NOEs Multiple hairpin conformation evidence is seen be observation of cross-strand NOEs between NH in Leu1/Leu8, Val3/Leu6, Val7/Leu14, and Ala9/Phe12. Interstrand CαiH ↔ CαiH between Phe2/Val7 establishes the N-terminal hairpin between residues 1 and 8. A ROESY spectrum is shown after addition of 16% (CD3)2SO to CDCl3. Thus Phe2/Val7 and Leu8/Val13 CαiH ↔ CαiH NOEs are observed, demonstrating presence of both the hairpin segments in the molecule. A long-range NOE is also seen between methyl group of C-terminal est and the Leu6 CαH, showing that antiparallel strands remain tight even at cap ends.

With eight solvent-shielded NH groups and four solvent-exposed NH groups and the high JHNCαH for strand residues and the finding of as many as seven critical interstrand long-range NOEs together provides evidence of 3-stranded β-sheet. With 35 NOE constraints and 8 interstrand H-bonding constraints we obtain a restrained molecular dynamic silution converged to family of 3-D structures with mean RMSD = 0.66Å for backbone atoms (see figure).

It is noted that aggregation did not occur even in a poorly solvating solvent like chloroform. β-Hairpin formation has been reported by us with octapeptide Boc-Leu-Val-Val-(d)Pro-Gly-Leu-Val-Val-OMe in both organic solvents and crystals. If only residues 1-8 are considered in one hairpin, two NH groups on the hairpin are exposed and four are internally H-bonded. With a two-hairpin three-stranded structure as many as 8 internally H-bonded NH groups while on NH groups on residues 2 and 13 are exposed; Gly NH groups in the turns do not contribute to extended 2-D sheet formation. With only one free NH group on the two outer strands, aggregation is limited, as aggregation is a process facilitated by cooperative formation of several H-bonds in sheets. In this peptide, any enthalpic gain by formation of limited intermolecular H bonds is offset by entropic losses due to desolvation and restriction of side chain flexibility and molecular motion. Scaling this peptide design to larger intramolecular β-sheets seems possible, and a demonstration of stable multiple hairpin formation in organic solvents is of relevance in mimicking porin-like structures. Note that β-sheets in proteins is largely buried in hydrophobic environments, which is consistent with importance of cross-strand H-bonding in maintaining structural integrity.

Yuan M, Namikoshi M, Otsuki A, Watanabe MF, Rinehart KL (1998) J. Am Soc. Mass Spectrom. 10, 1138-1151.

Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometric Analysis of Microcystins, Cyclic Heptapeptide Hepatotoxins: Modulation of Charge States and [M + H]+ and [M + Na]+ Ratio

Microcystins are cyclic 7-peptide toxins made by cyanobacteria, with up to 60 different structural variations. Structure is generally of the form cyclo(D-Ala-X-D--MeAsp-Z-Adda- . Identification for toxological analysis by ESI-MS is envisioned. Microcystins form doubly-protonated ions [M + 2H]2+ in a high ratio compared to single ions [M + H]+. Mechanism of ionization is debated: Wang et al found that pH, solvent composition, and sample concentration are factors, while Le Blanc et al found no pH dependence but that proton affinity depended on nitrogen bases added. Use of ammonium acetate is recommended especially with very acidic cyclic peptides since it improves ionization. The doubly charged forms are more likely to appear on peptides with Arg residues. Adduct forms ([M + Na]+ and [M + K]+) are typically found but fragmentation spectra are of no help with adducts (thus not helping with structural info).

Microcystins-RR, -LR, -YR, and LA were injected by flow method with a 47.5:47.5:5.0 MeOH:water:acetic acid mobile phase and the m/z values are reported for both +1 and +2 ions. For the RR form the base peak is the [M + 2H]2+ ion while for the LR and YR forms it is the singly charged. The LA form has no Arg residue and the [M + Na]+ is the base peak. In general presence of basic residues like Arg results in ionization appearing in the spectrum.

Protonation sites in cyclic peptides include amide nitrogens with evidence seen in MS/MS spectra. Arg and Adda (a complex phenyldecadienoic acid) can also be protonated to provide ions with very favorable free energies of formation (calculated by Winmopac 97).

Protonation of Arg probably means a electrostatic interaction with a Glu or MeAsp residue. In an acidic mobile phase, any carboxylate accepts either a proton or Na+ to form [M + H]+ or [M + Na]+. Generally positive ESI-MS gives greater sensitivity than does negative ion ESI-MS. Microcystin-RR in 1:1 MeOH:water shows no ions in negative mode, but those missing an Arg residue have very high sensitivity in negative ESI-MS. Isopropanol is found to be a good solvent, and increases in the pH clearly improve neg mode ESI-MS sensitivity. An isopropanol/water mobile phase (pH 9-11) was suitable for microcystin LR.

Ion current in ESI-MS is related to analyte concentration of species with singly charged nitrogen bases and multiply charged proteins. The LR form was studied by direct infusion at 10 and 100 µg/ml. The base peak is the m/z 995 [M + H]+ form at both concentrations. A [M + Na + H]2+ and [M + K + H]2+ are present at m/z 509 and 517, respectively, at 25% and 10% abundance at the higher 100 µg/ml concentration. In the lower concentration, the m/z 517, 509 are present at 40% adn 33% (thus the K form predominates). The [M + 2H]2+ at m/z 498 is seen at 25% abundance, and this is not present at all in the higher concentration. Plots of detected ion sum the singly and doubly protonated forms against the infused LR concentration were studied using SIM mode; flow rate 200 µl/min and 5 µl injection. A very linear correlation was found with the m/z 995 ion between concentration and summed ion current in the 0.1 to 1 µM range. The 2+/1+ ion ratios were examined at 0.1, 1 and 10 µM. For the various ions these were 2H/1H = 0.12 and 1Na+1H/1H = 0.32 for 10 µM; 2H/1H = 0.48 and 1Na+1H/1H = 0.58 at 1 µM, and 2H/1H = 0.48 and 1Na+1H/1H = 3.27 at 0.1 µM. The trend is that doubly charged ions of any kind increase inversely with concentration. With higher concentrations the lower abundance of multiple charge state ions is reduced because of coulombic repulsion which destabilizes their formation. Mobile phase pH was also checked from pH 3-12 using acetic acid (3-6), NaOH (9-11) and NH4OH (11-12). The 2H/1H ratio for LR did not change significnantly between pH 3-11, and the 1H intensity of the RR form increased signficantly between pH 3-6. These results can be explained by noting that Arg-containing microcystins form an ionic bond with COO− in Glu or MeAsp and so the response was connected with buffer pK constant.

Figeys D, Gygi SP, Zhang Y, Watts J, Gu M, Aebersold R (1998) Electrophoresis 19, 1811-1818.

Electrophoresis Combined With Novel Mass Spectrometry Techniques: Powerful Tools for The Analysis of Proteins and Proteomes

ABSTRACT. Analytical and preparative electrophoresis separation techniques have been essential tools in protein biochemistry and the biological sciences in general. The combination of high resolution electrophoresis techniques with high performance analytical procedures has dramatically enhanced analytical protein biochemistry. In this report we describe the combination of electrophoretic separation techniques with electrospray ionization (ESI) tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS). A series of different techniques, consisting of automated high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)-MS/MS, capillary-HPLC-MS/MS, and solid phase extraction (SPE)-capillary zone electrophoresis (CZE)-MS/MS, are described in the context of the identification of high pmol to the low fmol amounts of proteins. Application of these powerful new tools for the analysis of proteins on a large proteome-wide scale is presented. Furthermore, the combination of orthogonal separation techniques, such as immobilized metal affinity chromatography (IMAC) with SPE-CZE-MS/MS, and IMAC followed by HPLC, and by SPE-CZE-MS/MS, are presented for the detailed investigation of post-translational modifications of specific proteins.

Haynes PA, Gygi SP, Figeys D, Aebersold R (1998) Electrophoresis 19, 1862-1871.

Proteome Analysis: Biological Assay or Data Archive?

REVIEW

ABSTRACT. In this review we examine the current state of proteome analysis. There are three main issues discussed: why it is necessary to study proteomes; how proteomes can be analyzed with current technology; and how proteome analysis can be used to enhance biological research. We conclude that proteome analysis is an essential tool in the understanding of regulated biological systems. Current technology, while still mostly limited to the more abundant proteins, enables the use of proteome analysis both to establish databases of proteins present, and to perform biological assays involving measurement of multiple variables. We believe that the utility of proteome analysis in future biological research will continue to be enhanced by further improvements in analytical technology.

Chevallet M, Santoni V, Poinas A, Rouquie D, Fuchs A, Kieffer S, Rossignol M, Lunardi J, Garin J, Rabilloud T. (1998) Electrophoresis 19, 1901-1909.

New Zwitterionic Detergents Improve The Analysis of Membrane Proteins by Two-Dimensional Electrophoresis

ABSTRACT. Severe quantitative loss of protein is often observed in high-resolution two-dimensional electrophoresis of membrane proteins, while the resolution is usually not affected. To improve the solubility of proteins in this technique, we tested denaturing cocktails containing various detergents and chaotropes. Best results were obtained with a denaturing solution containing urea, thiourea, and zwitterionic detergents, synthesized for this purpose. Among the dozen detergents synthesized and tested, amidosulfobetaines with an alkyl tail containing 14-16 carbons proved most efficient, solubilizing previously undetected membrane proteins.

FD

Wenschuh H, Halada P, Lamer S, Jungblut P, Krause E (1998) Rapid Comm. Mass Spectrom. 12, 115-119.

The Ease Of Peptide Detection By Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Mass Spectrometry: The Effect Of Secondary Structure On Signal Intensity

Since Karas and Hillenkamp introduced MALDI-MS, it has proven quite useful for peptide mass fingerprinting and able to tolerate contaminants like salts. There are linear relationships between ion signal intensities and petpide/protein substrate concentration. Other factors include use of different matrices and altering sample prep method.

This study makes use of model peptides shown the table below:

Synthetic model peptides used in this study
Peptide Sequence Mass (av) Secondary structure Charge Hydrophobicitya
KLAL Ac-KLALKLALKALKLALKLA-amide 1960.6 large α-helical propensity +5 64.3
D-K, A-KLAL Ac-KLALKLALkaLKLALKLA-amide 1960.6 diminished α-helical propensity +5 64.3
VT5 DPKGDPKGVTVTVTVTVTGKGDPKPD-amide 2607.9 concentration dependent β-sheet formation +5, −4 20.7
D-V, T-VT5 DPKGDPKGVTVTvtVTVTGKGDPKPD-amide 2607.9 no secondary structure +5, −4 20.7
VT6 DPKGDPKGVTVTVTVTVTVTGKGDPKPD-amide 2808.2 β-sheet +5, −4 26.3
D-T, V-VT6 DPKGDPKGVTVTVtvTVTVTGKGDPKPD-amide 2808.2 diminished β-sheet propensity +5, −4 26.3
Reference peptide Ac-Ile-His-MeAla-Lys-Ile-His-MeAla-His-Ile-amide 1108.3 no secondary structure +4 17.8
a Rc denotes retention coefficients calculated by summing the Guo values of the amino acids.

The peptide KLAL is 80% α-helix in TFE/water while VT5 and VT6 are β-sheet. Analog peptides were constructed in the D-amino acid form to disrupt secondary structure (they are show as lowercase letters). MALDI analysis of 0.5 pmol of VT6 peptide gave no signal intenssity, the KLAL and VT5 were weak. With 1.0 and 1.5 pmolpeaks were sufficiently high enough to detect peptide.

Marshall AG, Hendrickson CL, Jackson GS (1998) Mass Spectrom. Rev. 17, 1-35.

Fourier Transform Ion Cyclotron Resonance Mass Spectrometry: A Primer

FT-ICR can be understood from idealized models:

  1. ion cyclotron frequency, radius, velocity, and energy as a function of ion mass, ion charge, and magnetic field strength follow directly from the motion of an ion in a spatially uniform static magnetic field
  2. ion cyclotron motion may be rendered spatially coherent (and thus observable) by the application of a spatially uniform rf electric field (excitation) at the same frequency as (i.e., resonant with) the ion cycltron frequency; the ICR (time domain) signal result from induction (detection) of an oscillating image charge on two conductive infinitely extended opposed parallel electrodes; a frequence domain is obtained by Fourier transformaion of digitized time domain ICR signal and this converts to mass domain spectrum
  3. ions are confined by a 3D axial quadrupolar dc electric field and this shifts ion cyclotron frequency whereas excitation and detection remain linear
  4. collisions broaden the ICR signal in a simple way: make it possible to cool and compress ion packet for improved detection and even multiple remeasurement
  5. although FT-ICR MS has been coupled to nearly every ion source, most ion sources work best outside the magnet and so several methods are developed to guide externally generated ions into the trap
  6. all above features may be combined in various experimental event sequences (much like pulse sequences in FT-NMR spectroscopy) to perform tandem-in-time mass spectrometery (MS/MS or MSn)

A spatially uniform magnetic field is established B = −B0k and the z-axis proceeds in direction opposite B. An ion moves in the presence and experiences the force:

F = ma = m (dv / dt) = qv × B   [1]

and m, q and v are the mass, charge, and velocity of the ion. Note the cross product of the velocity and magnetic field vectors (charge is scalar). This describes the ion cyclotron motion. If the ion is negative, it will move in a clockwise motion if B is directed perpendicular in the direction of the reader's view (not direction of the reader). If the ion is positively charged, the movement is counterclockwise in the field. Alternatively, if the thumb points in the direction of B, for positive ions, the curl of the left hand describes their motion while for negative ions, it is the curl of the right hand.

Because velocity is circular and not linear, it is described by an x and y (planar or 2D) components. The angular acceleration will be |dv/dt| = vxy2 / r, and so eqn [1] is substituted as follows:

mvxy2 / r = qvxy × B   [2]

The angular velocity ω (rad/s) about the z axis is ω = vxy / r and

mω2r = qωrB0
ω = qB0/m   [3]

Eqn [3] is the simplification. Dividing ω (rad/s) by 2π rad(ians) gives a value in s−, which is the frequency of motion νc. Moreover charge q = ze, where z is an integer multiple of the universal unit of charge e = 1.602 × 10−19 C, true for all protons and electrons that confer charge. With all the substitutions, it can be shown that:

νc = ω/2π = k {B0 / (m/z)}   [4]

where k = (1.602 × 10−19 C) / {(2π) 1.660 × 10−27 kg/u)} = 1.535611 × 107 Hz • amu / T, if B is in tesla (T, 1 T = 1 kg / C s), and m is in mass units (u). Eqn [4] is the cyclotron equation. All ions with the same m/z have the same frequency and this is independent of their velocity: focusing on translational energy is not essential to determine precisely m/z. At a typical static magnetic field of 7.0 T, ICR frequencies should range from a few kHz to a few MHz for the usual range of molecules (plot log νc from 1.0 to 109 Hz against log m/z from 1 to 107 at different magnetic field strengths from 1.0 to 9.4 T to see straight lines with negative slopes).

Rearranging Eq [2]:

r = mvxy / qB0 = mvxy / zeB0   [5]
r = (1.036427 × 10−8 T s / m amu) (m/z)(vxy / B0)

if r is in meters, B0 is in tesla, m is in u, and vxy is in m/s. This is the ion cyclotron radius for ion with velocity vxy (plot r in mm from 0 to 2.5 against m/z from 0 to 10,000 at different B0 from 1.0 to 9.4 T to see hyperbolic lines). The average x-y translational energy of an ion in equilibrium with surroundings at temperature T is

½ m⟨vxy2⟩ ≈ kT   [6]

where k is the Boltzmann constant. Rearranging Eqn [6] for vxy and then substituting for Eqn [5]:

r = (2mkT)½ / zeB0
r = 1.336510 × 10−6 (mT)½ / zB0    [7]

if all variables are in the units previously mentioned. At room temperature (T = 298 K) a z = 1 ion of mass m = 100 u in a magnetic field of B0= 3 T (30,000 Gausss) will have an orbital radius ~ 0.08 mm. If m = 10,000, the radius is 10-fold greater. If Eqn [5] is rearranged:

vxy = qrB0/m = zerB0/m
vxy = (9.64853 × 107 u/T s)(rB0)/(m/z)   [8]

A 100 u z=1 ion with an orbital radius of 1 cm in a 3.0 T field will have a translational velocity of vxy = 2.97 × 104 and its kinetic energy is:

Kinetic energy = ½ mvxy2 = (zerB0)2 / 2m
K.E. = (4.824265 × 107 eV u / T2 m2) (zrB0)2 / m   [9]

computes to 434 eV. Plots of E ranging from 0 to 10 keV vs r ranging from 0 to 1.5 cm under different B0 ranging from 1.0 to 9.4 T show plots of a parabola. It should be noted that the ion will travel nearly 30 km in one second and this offers higher mass resolution compared to a several meter long magnetic sector beam instrument.

Azimuthal Dipolar Frequency Excitation. The cyclotron motion is not itself useful. What is useful is the excitation of the ion using a spatially uniform electric field that oscillates (or rotates) at or near the frequency of the cyclotron frequency of ion of a particular m/z. The excitation occurs in three ways:

  1. accelerating ions coherently to a larger detectable orbital radius
  2. increasing ion kinetic energy above threshold for ion dissocation or ion-molecule reaction
  3. accelerating ions to cyclotron radius for greater than the trap radius so they are ejected

Applying an azimuthal (perpendicular to plane of B) spatially uniform electric field which oscillates sinusoidally with time along the ± y axis

E(t) = E0 cos ωctj   [10]

Note that i and j are unit vectors along the x- and y-axes; the y axis passes through the two plates perpendicularly, whereas the xz plane is parallel to the plates. E0 is generated by two opposed infinitely extended flat parallel conductive flat plates oscillating at +V0 and −V0 separated by d meters, so that

E0 = 2 V0/d = Vp-p/d   [11]

The linearly polarized electric field may be analyzed into two counter-rotating components EL(t) and ER(t)

E(t) = EL(t) + ER(t)   [11a]

where

ER(t) = E0/2 (cos ωtj + sin ωti)   [11b]
EL(t) = E0/2 (cos ωtj − sin ωti)   [11c]

The rf electric field component, ER(t), rotates in the same sense (viz. counterclockwise in xy plane) and at same frequency (i.e. in resonance with) the ion of interest pushes that ion continuously forward in its orbit. The electric field component, EL(t), which rotates in the opposite sense of the ion, is off-resonance by 2ω and has virtually no significant net effect after several cycles of the excitation frequency.

Ions absorb power according to the dot product of the electric field force and the velocity vector

A(t) = Force • velocity = qE(t) • vxy    [12]

For positive or negative ions at rest initially and subjected to oscillating resonant excitation (Eqs 10 and 11) for a period Texcite from Eq 12 it can be shown that the post-excitation ion cyclotron radius r is

r = E0Texcite/2B0   [13a]
r = Vp-pTexcite/2dB0   [13b]

The excitation radius is independent of m/z. All ions of given m/z range can be excited to same orbital radius with rf electric field whose magnitude is constant with frequency. Ion kinetic energy following azimuthal dipolar resonant excitation for period Texcite is related to ωc = qB0/m:

KEpost-excitation = mω2r2 / 2 = (qE0Texcite)2/8m = (qVp-pTexcite)2/8md2    [14a]
KEpost-excitation = (1.20607 × 107 eV u m2/ V2 s2)(zVp-pTexcite)2/md2    [14b]

A 100 u z=1 ion excited by ± 1 V applied for 1 ms to infinitely extended parallel flat electrodes 2 cm apart should have post-excitation energy of 1.2 keV. High collision energies are easy to generate. Post-excitation energy is not dependent on magnetic field strength B0, but the radius does vary inversely with B0, meaning that with a given post-excitation radius, and the energy increases with square of the magnetic field. Plots of log energy E (in eV, ranging from 10−3 to 107) vs. log m/z (from 10−1 to 106) produce several straight plots with negative slopes when B0 is varied from 1.0 to 9.4 T, all lines with a constant r = 1 cm. In another log E vs. log m/z plot, Vp-p = 1 V and d = 2 cm for the plate separation and applied peak-to-peak voltage, and Texcite is varied from 100 µs to 1 s logarithmically. For a 1000 u z=1 ion, a 1 s excitation can impart as much as 107 eV. Thus the FT-ICR might be equipped with ability to change energy in the ion by varying the magnetic field, or by altering Vp-p or Texcite.

Azimuthal Dipolar Single-Frequency Detection. ICR motion does not generate an observable signal, namely the net difference between charge induced in two opposed parallel electrodes. When ions are injected into the trap and the cyclotron motion forms, orbital motion phase is random. For an ion ensemble, charge induced in either of two opposed detector plates is balanced on average by equal charge induced by an ion with 180° out of phase, meaning on far side of orbit, and net difference is zero between two plates. Even if all ions with same m/z were in phase in the orbit, the radius is too small to induce detection signals without the excitation. But with resonant excitation, a spatial coherence occurs and detection enabled; orbits are actually centered on the z-axis, and with the increase in orbital radius the ion packet is moved significantly off axis.

The difference in image charge, ΔQ induced by an ion of charge q and the time variation of that signal are shown:

ΔQ = −2qy/d   [15]
dΔQ/dt = −2q(dy/dt)/d

There is no dependency on magnetic field strength. As the y-axis is perpendicular to the two detection plates (passes through them), induction is clearly a function of the position of the ions in along y in the orbit, which many factors affect. From Eq 5, increases in the y component of velocity (dy/dt > 0) should cause linear increases in orbital radius. In addition detected signal in more sensitive to multiply charged (z > 1) ions (eg. from ESI). Linearity is important because (i) ICR signal varies with ion cyclotron post-excitation radius and this depends linearly on excitation voltage amplitude-duration product, and the ICR response at any frequency is proportional to excitation spectral magnitude at that frequency; (ii) a Fourier transform of time-domain ICR response produces same absorption spectrum that would have been obtained by measuring power absorption while sweeping across the m/z range. The superposition principle implies that signals from any number of ions of arbitrary m/z values just add at the detector, and ions of a wide m/z range can be detected simultaneously. Thus a multichannel advantage exists in pulsed excitation followed by Fourier transformation yields a spectrum of N data points in 1/N the time it takes to scan the spectrum one channel at a time.

Broadband excitation. Having looked at response of an ion in a static homogeneous magnetic field B = −B0k to a oscillating electric field with single frequency resonant (E(t) = E0cos ωctj it can be seen (in a Fourier transform of f(t) vs.  t → M(ω) vs. ω) that other frequencies are excited as well, the peak width being m/Δm50% The frequency domain spectrum, E(ν) of a single frequency excitation at ωc = 2πνc when applied steadily for Texcite seconds is given by

E(ν) = [E0 sin(2πνcTexcite) ] / 2πνc   [16]

While the applied excitation may be precisely centered at frequency ω which differs from ωc, turning excitation voltage on at time zero and off at Texcite broadens the spectral range of excitation to bandwidth of ~1/Texcite rad/s. Thus the longer the time domain signal duration, the narrower the frequency domain spectral width. If an off-resonsance excitation at frequency ν is sufficiently brief such that (1/Texcite ≥ 2π |ν−νc|, it will still excite ions at cyclotron frequency ωc. This defines the precision by which ions can be mass-selected. Ion cyclotron frequencies are so high that as little as once second can be very mass-selective: ~10 ppm for m/z 1000 at 7.0 T. Eq 16 shows single freq exictation of duration Texcite will excite ions with frequencies whose range span ~0.1/Texcite

If a single frequency resonant excitation voltage of ± 1 V is applied to electrodes 2 cm apart to excite to a radius of 1 cm in 1.4 ms, excitation of ions anywhere within bandwidth of ~1 MHz will require excitation of ~0.1 µs corresponding to a ± 10,000 V rf excitation voltage, inconviently large. Thus a broadband ICR excitation is done by a frequency-sweep (chirp) excitation, achieving a relatively flat magnitude of excitation over broad frequency rang using relatively low excitation voltage. Disadvantages of the chirp excitation: a nonuniform excitation amplitude leading to variations in ion relative abundances, and limited mass selectivity at the start and end of the sweep. To solve this problem, one instead defines the excitation in the mass profile which is then converted to the frequency-domain excitation spectrum, followed by an inverse Fourier transform to get the time-domain excitation waveform. One waveform may just contain excitation that keep the ions in the trap; another may select which ions get ejected to enrich for low abundance ions. Mass spectral windows within which none or all ions are excited or ejected provide for mass selectivity for MS/MS or enhanced dynamic range by selective ejection of highly abundant ions. The use of the stored waveform inverse Fourier transform (SWIFT) (described above) achieves the flattest and most frequency-selected excitation magnitude spectrum theoretically possible for a given time-domain excitation period. See Guan and Marshall for how SWIFT excitation is used for the Penning ICR and Paul quadrupole ion traps.

Broadband Detection and Limits. Coherently orbiting ion packets induce differential currents between two opposed detection plates and modeled as a current source. The receiver plates and wiring connecting the ion trap to the detection preamplifier have an inherent resistance and capacitance in parallel. At typical ICR frequencies (> 10 kHz) the signal-to-noise is independent of cyclotron frequency. But at lower ICR frequencies (< 10 kHz), signal varies directly with frequency. Detected S/N ratio reflects the relative current differential induced on detection plates throughout most of frequency range excited by broadband chirp or SWIFT waveform. Detection limit is calculated from:

N = [CVd(p-p)]/[qA1(r)]    [17]

where C is capacitance in detection circuit, Vd(p-p) is peak-to-peak amplitude of detected voltage (calibrated for given spectrometer) and A1(r) is coefficient approx. proportional to r and is determined graphically. N is the minimum number of ions which can be detected from an undamped signal in a single 1 s acquisition period to produce S/N=3:1. For a typical operating circuit, C = 50 pF, Vd(p-p) = 3 × 10−7 V, and A1(r) = 0.5 (meaning the ion is excited to about half of its maximal cyclotron radius), the S/N=3:1 means that 187 ions is the detection limit.

Ion-Neutral Collisions. Eq 16 describe what happens to ions with a single value m/z in the absence of collision, obtained by Fourier transformat of a digitized time-domain signal to give a sinc function spectrum looking like Eq. 9, except Texcitation is Tacquisition. Ion-neutral collisions are model as an effect of a frictional damping force:

Force = m (dv/dt) = qE + qv × B − fv   [18]

The model leads to an exponential damping of the time-domain ICR signal for Ni ions of ICR frequency νi:

si(t) ∝ Ni exp(−t/τi) cos(2πνit)   [19]

where the Fourier transform produces a Lorentzian frequency-domain magnitude-mode spectrum:

M(ω) ∝ τ/[1 + (ω − 2πνi]½

FT-ICR spectral line shape approaches the sinc shape in the limit of zero pressure (τ >> Tacq'n, with essentially no ion-neutral collisions during data acquisition).

Blom N, Gammeltoft S, Brunak S (1999) J. Mol. Biol. 294, 1351-1362.

Sequence and Structure-Based Prediction of Eukaryotic Protein Phosphorylation Sites

Protein phosphorylation at serine, threonine or tyrosine residues affects a multitude of cellular signaling processes. How is specicity in substrate recognition and phosphorylation by protein kinases achieved? Here, we present an articial neural network method that predicts phosphorylation sites in independent sequences with a sensitivity in the range from 69% to 96 %. As an example, we predict novel phosphorylation sites in the p300/CBP protein that may regulate interaction with transcription factors and histone acetyltransferase activity. In addition, serine and threonine residues in p300/CBP that can be modified by O-linked glycosylation with N-acetylglucosamine are identied. Glycosylation may prevent phosphorylation at these sites, a mechanism named yin-yang regulation. The prediction server is available on the Internet at http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/NetPhos/ or via e-mail to NetPhos@cbs.dtu.dk.

Gygi SP, Han DK, Gingras AC, Sonenberg N, Aebersold R (1999) Electrophoresis 20, 310-319.

Protein Analysis by Mass Spectrometry and Sequence Database Searching: Tools for Cancer Research in The Post-Genomic Era

ABSTRACT. The post-genomic era is characterized by the deposition of sequence information for entire genomes in databases. Currently, besides the protein sequences for known human proteins, there are partial sequences from thousands more human proteins for which no biological function has been assigned. A powerful new tool for the unambiguous identification and characterization of gel-separated proteins is accomplished by the combination of mass spectrometry and sequence database searching. This combination provides the cancer biologist with the ability to (i) identify the potential protein:protein associations and (ii) fully characterize function-critical post-translational modifications, both directly from silver-stained polyacrylamide gels. In this report we describe the application of tandem mass spectrometry and database searching to two problems which are prototypical for cancer research and indeed for biomedical research in general. The first is the identification of gel-separated, low abundance proteins based on amino acid sequence composition following coimmunoprecipitation with the human apoptosis inhibitor protein BclX(L). The second is the determination of the precise sites of phosphorylation of the human regulatory protein 4E-BP1, which controls mRNA translation.

Molloy MP, Herbert BR, Williams KL, Gooley AA (1999) Electrophoresis 20, 701-704.

Extraction of Escherichia coli proteins with organic solvents prior to two-dimensional electrophoresis

ABSTRACT. Compared to soluble proteins, hydrophobic proteins, in particular membrane proteins, are an underrepresented protein species on two-dimensional (2-D) gels. One possibility is that many hydrophobic proteins are simply not extracted from the sample prior to 2-D gel separation. We attempted to isolate hydrophobic proteins from Escherichia coli by extracting with organic solvents, then reconstituting the extracted proteins in highly solubilising sample solution amenable to 2-D electrophoresis using immobilized pH gradients (IPGs). This was conducted by an extraction with a mixture of chloroform and methanol, followed by solubilisation using a combination of urea, thiourea, sulfobetaine detergents and tributyl phosphine. Peptide mass fingerprinting assisted in the identification of 13 proteins, 8 of which have not previously been reported on 2-D gels. Five of these new proteins possess a positive hydropathy plot. These results suggest that organic solvent extractions may be useful for selectively isolating some proteins that have previously been missing from proteome maps.

Santoni V, Rabilloud T, Doumas P, Rouquie D, Mansion M, Kieffer S, Garin J, Rossignol M (1999) Electrophoresis 20, 705-711.

Towards the recovery of hydrophobic proteins on two-dimensional electrophoresis gels

ABSTRACT. An extensive proteomic approach relies on the possibility to visualize and analyze various types of proteins, including hydrophobic proteins which are rarely detectable on two-dimensional electrophoresis (2-DE) gels. In this study, two methods were employed for the purification of hydrophobic proteins from Arabidopsis thaliana leaf plasma membrane (PM) model plants, prior to analysis on 2-DE immobilized pH gradient (IPG) gels. Solubilization efficiency of two detergents, (3-[(3-cholomidopropyl)-1-propanesulfonic acid (CHAPS) and C8phi, were tested for the recovery of hydrophobic proteins. An immunological approach was used to determine the efficiency of the above methods. Fractionation of proteins by Triton X-114 combined with solubilization with CHAPS resulted in the inability to detect hydrophobic proteins on 2-DE gels. The use of C8phi for protein solubilization did not improve this result. On the contrary, after treatment of membranes with alkaline buffer, the solubilization of PM proteins with detergent C8phi permitted the recovery of such proteins on 2-DE gels. The combination of membrane washing and the use of zwitterionic detergent resulted in the resolution of several integral proteins and the disappearance of peripheral proteins. In the resolution of expressed genome proteins, both large pH gradients in the first dimension and various acrylamide concentrations in the second dimension must be used. Notwithstanding, it is important to combine various sample treatments and different detergents in order to resolve soluble and hydrophobic proteins.

Görg A, Obermaier C, Boguth G, Weiss W (1999) Electrophoresis 20, 712-717.

Recent developments in two-dimensional gel electrophoresis with immobilized pH gradients: Wide pH gradients up to pH 12, longer separation distances and simplified procedures

ABSTRACT. Wide-range immobilized pH 312 and 612 gradients were generated. Depending on the extraction method of sample preparation, proteins with pIs up to pH 11.7 were resolved. Highly reproducible protein patterns, focused to the steady-state with round-shaped spots up to the basic end were obtained. Moreover, because a strong water transport from cathode to anode (reverse electroendosmotic flow) inherent to narrow immobilized pH gradients (IPGs) exceeding pH 11, such as IPG 1012, was negligible, the wide-range IPGs 312 and 612 could be run under standard conditions as originally described by Grg et al. (Electrophoresis 1988, 9, 531546). The wide-range immobilized pH gradient 312 proved to be perfectly suited for an overview separation of total cell extracts. Resolution could be increased by extending the separation distance from 18 to 24 cm. Furthermore, two-dimensional gel electrophoresis with IPGs (IPG-Dalt) was simplified by the use of an integrated system (IPGphor) where sample application by in-gel rehydration and isoelectric focusing (IEF) are performed automatically in a one-step procedure, overnight, without human assistance.

Fenyö D (1999) Bioinformatics 15, 339-340.

The Biopolymer Markup Language

ABSTRACT. SUMMARY: An XML derived from a data model designed to be a hierarchical representation of an organism has been specified and a browser to use this language has been developed. AVAILABILITY: The language definition is available in HTML form at Proteometrics. The BioML browser is available on request from the author.

Peleg L, Ries L, Getslev V, Lusky A, Chaki R, Lipitz S, Barkai G (1999) Prenat. Diag. 19, 224-228.

Heat Stable and Urea Resistant Alkaline Phosphatase in Maternal Neutrophils from Normal and Down Syndrome Pregnancies

Human alkaline phosphatase (ALP) has four isoenzymes. The placental and germ-line enzymes (placental ALP = pALP) can be used to assess intra-uterine growth retardation and low birth weight. pALP increases in maternal serum and it was thought it might be a biochemical indicator along with the triple test.

Blood was taken from mothers in 1st and 2nd trimester pregnancies who also went other screening (amniocentesis, chorionic villus sampling), and also from 3rd trimester followups. Fetuses with Downs were determined by prenatal karyotyping and blood from aborted fetuses. Sera were taken from 7 ml blood and stored deep freeze. PMN cells were from 7 ml heparin venous blood with neutrophil yield of 91%. Cells were sonicated (130 W) 30 s on-30 s off three times. Extracts were spun 16900 g 40 min at 4°; pellets were resonicated in Krebs-Ringers with 0.1% TX-100 for 30 s. ALP is extracted in cold butanol 30-45 min 4°, and supernatant dialyzed against 100 mM Tris pH 8 with 1 mM ZnCl2 and MgCl2. pALP activity is assayed with 4-methylumbelliferyl phosphate (according to Grozdea et al, 1984) and with p-nitrophenyl phosphate (according to Gainer and Stinton 1982); protein assay by Lowry. Half of samples are kept on ice and other are treated in 56° or 60° water bath for 10, 20, 40, and 60 min. Another part of enzyme is treated to 3.7 or 5 M urea for 5, 15, 25, 40 and 60 min at 37°.

All pregnancies showed significant elevations in pALP. A significant 2.2% and 5% increase in heat-stable and urea-resistant activity, respectively, was seen in 1st trimester. This became 64.5% and 49.3% respectively in 3rd trimester. Specific activity showed increases as well: 200 nmol/hr/mg protein from 1st trimester compared to nonpregnant controls having 95 nmol/hr/mg protein (p ≤ 0.5). Between trimesters howevever there is no significant difference in specific activity or in resistant neonatal ALP.

The 3.7 M urea incubation inactivation was studied. By 15 min, about 35% of activity is lost, and by 40 min, 60% is lost. After 1 hour, only 30% of activity is remaining, indicating a half-life of about 30 minutes under these conditions. There were no differences between samples of mothers carrying Downs and normal fetuses.

The ratio of pALP activities resistant to urea (3.7 M at 40 and 60 min) and heat-stabile (56° 20 min) from Downs and normal fetuses were plotted, with a range from 0.5 to 1.6 generally (Downs/normal). 13 Downs cases were studied, and normals matched for gestational age were done. No signficant differences for urea at 40 min were seen, but at 60 min a small different of 18% was seen. The difference was not significant by a t test but was significant using Wilcoxon sign ranks test of ratios (p < 0.05). 19 Downs with matched controls were test for heat stability but no signficant difference was seen. Other experiments included use of p-nitrophenyl phosphate, inactivation at 53° and 60°, addition of 0.01% BSA, or heat-treated male serum to neutrophil extracts to increase carrier proteins, 5 M urea, but in no case could significant differences be seen.

Oda Y, Huang K, Cross FR, Cowburn D, Chait BT (1999) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 96, 6591-6596.

Accurate Quantitation of Protein Expression and Site-Specific Phosphorylation

ABSTRACT. A mass spectrometry-based method is described for simultaneous identification and quantitation of individual proteins and for determining changes in the levels of modifications at specific sites on individual proteins. Accurate quantitation is achieved through the use of wholecell stable isotope labeling. This approach was applied to the detection of abundance differences of proteins present in wild-type versus mutant cell populations and to the identification of in vivo phosphorylation sites in the PAK-related yeast Ste20 protein kinase that depend specifically on the G1 cyclin Cln2. The present method is general and affords a quantitative description of cellular differences at the level of protein expression and modification, thus providing information that is critical to the understanding of complex biological phenomena.

Keough T, Youngquist RS, Lacey MP (1999) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci USA 96, 7131-7136.

A Method for High-Sensitivity Peptide Sequencing Using Postsource Decay Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. A method has been developed for de novo peptide sequencing using matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization mass spectrometry. This method will facilitate biological studies that require rapid determination of peptide or protein sequences, e.g., determination of posttranslational modifications, identification of active compounds isolated from combinatorial peptide libraries, and the selective identification of proteins as part of proteome studies. The method involves fast, one-step addition of a sulfonic acid group to the N terminus of tryptic peptides followed by acquisition of postsource decay (PSD) fragment ion spectra. The derivatives are designed to promote efficient charge site-initiated fragmentation of the backbone amide bonds and to selectively enhance the detection of a single fragment ion series that contains the C terminus of the molecule (y-ions). The overall method has been applied to pmol quantities of peptides. The resulting PSD fragment ion spectra often exhibit uninterrupted sequences of 20 or more amino acid residues. However, fragmentation efficiency decreases considerably at amide bonds on the C-terminal side of Pro. The spectra are simple enough that de novo sequence tagging is routine. The technique has been successfully applied to peptide mixtures, to high-mass peptides (up to 3,600 Da) and to the unambiguous identification of proteins isolated from two-dimensional gel electrophoresis. The PSD spectra of these derivatized peptides often allow far more selective protein sequence database searches than those obtained from the spectra of native peptides.

Osinga R, Tramper J, Wijffels RH (1999) Mar. Biotechnol. 1, 509-532.

Cultivation of Marine Sponges

REVIEW. The porifera are primitive, multicellular, sessile, filter-feeding animals that ingest organic particles between 0.1 to 50 µm, which include phytoplankton, heterotrophic bacteria, heterotrophic eukaryotes, and detritus. Their ability to inhabit nutrient-poor environments is likely due to their capacity to filter large amounts of water. About 10,000 species, mostly marine, are described.

Sponge anatomy shows that water is usually brought in through smaller pores, the ostia, on the surface of the outer body and ejected through a larger opening, the osculum, often at the top of the sponge in the filtration scheme. Special epithelial cells called pinacocytes line the outer surface and internal opening, channels and chambers. Choanocytes are flagellated cells that form the walls of the chambers and rhythmically beat to produce water currents directing flow toward the cavities and channels. Most of the mass of the sponge is a gelatinous matrix with free-floating undifferentiated cells called the mesohyl; this matrix also contains a skeleton of spicules, needle-like structures composed of silicon or calcium carbonate, and spongin, a collagen-like fiber. Archaeocytes are ameboid cells in the mesohyl moving through the matrix, phagocytizing larger particles. Choanocytes feature a collar around the flagellum that is composed of microvilli which trap very tiny particles (bacteria, prochlorophytes). Choanocytes digest some particles and transfer others to archaeocytes.

Secondary metabolites of sponges include cytotoxins, antifouling agents, anitbiotics, anti-inflammatory, and anti-viral agents. Some metabolites may not be produced by sponges but by endosymbiotic microorganisms. Halichondrin B is an anticancer drug isolated from Halichondria okadai and Lissodendorix sp. which successfully passed a preclinical test but is produced in such little amounts that the supply problem has not been overcome.

Sponge aquaculture has focused on natural bath sponge production. 13,000 tons were produced in the peak year 1938. Moore described in 1910 that cultivation could be done by cutting into pieces and attaching to aluminum wire embedded in concrete disks which were placed in the sea. Other fix sponge cuttings on nylon ropes; razor-sharp knives should be used in the cut and one side must contain skin cells (pinacoderm), and smaller cuttings should have proportionately higher pinacoderm. Moreover sponge cuttings must be done completely submerged, since introducing air into channels blocks water flow. Sponge farming should be removed from fresh water streams feeding the sea, as salinity changes are critical. Sponges that do not grow a great deal of biomass (grow the least well) produce higher concentrations of metabolites.

Short-term cultivation has been used mainly to study sponge biology than to harvest commercial mass. Studies by Wilson a century ago showed that cells of Microcionia prolifera could be dissociated using a thin mesh, which can reaggregate and differentiate into small sponges with functioning aquiferous system in a week. Cell dissociation can be achieved by mechanical or chemical means; cell adhesion is significantly dependent upon Ca2+ and Mg2+, which can be removed from seawater. Cell types within the sponge body can also be separated using standard cell type (usually density gradients) techniques, particularly to obtain stem cells.

The sandwich method refers to a technique from Ankel and Eigenbrodt in which young sponges obtained from gemmules (egg-like reduction bodies, usually a characteristic of freshwater sponges) a grown between glass slides or plates and a coverslip. Multicellular single cell layer forms (two-dimensional) are used for direct microscopic examination. Instead of gemmules, Langenbruch took approx. 1 mm3 explants of the marine H. panica into the sandwich but could still make morphogenetic studies (on a dissecting scope?). This method has also been used to study the effects of light on tropical sponges (Desmapsamma anchorata and Aplysina fistularis insularis).

Long-term in vitro cultivation methods have been reported by public and private aquaria. The consensus is that unfiltered seawater is the best. Some factors have been defined. Food is a limited resource in most closed systems, since they are usually trying to filter and keep water clean, and the natural environment of sponges is rarely that way; suitable organic particles must be supplied in any farming operation.

Desmospongia is the largest of classes in the phylum Porifera and their skeletons and that of the glass sponges (class Hexactinellida) are composed of many siliceous spicules. Sclerocytes secrete the structures which are formed from silicon they obtain via silicic acid and crystallizing it around a protein filament. Spicular silica can compose up to 62% of the dry weight of spp. in the order Haplosclerida, and 75% of of spp. in order Petrosiida. The calcareous sponges (class Calcarea) form spicules of CaCO3, usually present in seawater and not likely to be growth-limiting as silicic acid might.

Oxygen is another growth-limiting factor. Sponge respiration rates vary between 0.2 and 25 µmol O2 per hour per cm3 sponge volume. Such rates are comparable to other invertebrates such as crustaceans and molluscs, cultivatable at high densities. Certain sponges are sensitive to hypoxia.

Cyanobacteria are photosynthetic endosymbionts of tropical sponges and thus require light, similar to zooxanthellae in coral. They usually serve as food sources for the sponges. Indeed rather than supplementing culture systems directly with food, it might be preferable to provide light as an energy source.

Some factors inhibit growth when present, aside from those above that limit it when absent or insufficient. Clay particles and silt can reduce the pumping rate of the aquiferous channels; Spongia officinalis had a reduced growth rate. Air (bubbles) can also damage the flow system in sponges; air in the choanocyte chambers stops the pump, and sponges die after even only a brief exposure. Some sponges in intertidal areas adapt to air presence however: this may be due to chemicals on the surface that maintain wetness, or rapid closing of ostia. Light may also be growth inhibitory in certain spp. possibly due to sensitivity to UV.

The average seawater salinity is 35 g per kilogram. Species living in shallow or estuarine waters probably adapt to rapid changes, but marine species require a strict osmoregulation. Tropical bath sponges are intolerant to sudden downshocks. The wool sponge Hippospongia lachne could withstand salinity up to 46‰ but below 26‰ was lethal. As for temperature, sponges generally are not subjected to rapid changes in temperature except the seasonal variation; generally they can tolerate sudden decreases rather than increases.

Seawater is usually alkaline (between pH 7.8 and 8.4) and sudden drops in pH would indicate changes in salinity (low) or hypoxia leading to metabolic acidosis. The presence of ammonia in any form (NH3 or NH4+) can lead to growth inhibition; LC50 can be 60-100 µM. The ionic form is less toxic in that ammonia can permeate cell membranes and alter metabolism intracellularly. A role is also played by dissolved oxygen, which at lower concentrations enhances ammonia toxicity. A study of the effects of ammonia in high density cultures would be worthwhile.

In a bioreactor/aquarium farm for sponges, both natural and artificial (from the structure of the system) toxins, contaminants and poisons may accumulate and kill or affect growth. Usually, the natural toxins are used to stop predation or prevent fouling or settlement by competitive species; there may be inter- and intraspecific interactions that affect desired growth in a closed system however. Another problem is the death and decay of sponge species. Some release poisons (acetylene) while bacteria can cause ammonia accumulation during decay.

Sponges are also susceptible to host-specific pathogens (disease) that are extremely contagious. This is more so with high density populations. Generally higher temperatures appear to increase disease susceptibility. Many sponge die-offs recently have been in warmer waters, possibly a result of global warming.

Sponges have few predators. This is largely because they have spiculated skeletons, and they have endosymbionts that produce toxins. Nudibranches do eat sponges, and also use their toxins to prevent predation against themselves. Care must be taken not to introduce adult nudibranches, sea urchins, and parrotfish to cultures.

In vitro culture design. Adult individuals are harvested from the natural population and explants (cuttings) are set rather than the parents as the cuttings grow faster than intacts. Parents used should appear healthy and free of injury/lesions. Sponge or explants that start to decay or change to an unhealthy appearance should be removed from the culture immediately.

Alternatively, and probably essential for some species, is to raise sponges from early developmental stages such as eggs/larvae/reduction bodies. Such sponges may survive better in the long-term and adapt to growth in vitro. Sponges usually produce reproductive elements as the water warms, although continual production of these forms may occur too. Larval formation and release is triggered by temperature and light in some cases. In other cases, reduction bodies such as gemmules are obtained by adverse environments, such as diminishing food or energy sources. These can be harvested and used to trigger rapid growth under ideal conditions.

Transport of substrate energy to the sponge is controlled by both diffusion and the active pumping on the aquiferous system. Effectiveness of transport is determined by a factor η, which is defined as the conversion rate of substrate divided by the rate if there is no limitation in transport of substrate. η = 1 if there is no limitation regarding transport. η will be lower if transport is only by diffusion.

For some sponges, a diet may be restricted to the types of bacteria or other organisms. In some cases, sponges can obtain small molecules (amino acids, polyunsaturated fatty acids) directly from the seawater.

Sponge cell culture. No continuous cell lines have been developed to date. A methodology has been described by which to approach development.

  1. Cell dissociation of whole bodies or explants is done mechanically, chemically, or enzymatically, or a combination.
  2. Cell types are selected by unit gravity or density gradient centrifugation.
  3. Antibiotics are used to produce axenic cultures.

Cultures grown in calcium- and magnesium-free artificial seawater, pH 7 phosphate, and 5% BSA are ready. Mitogenic agents are needed to stimulate growth as well, and sometimes antibiotics are useless. One problem is that cells, when dissociated, rapidly lose their telomerase activity and thus their totipotency. Cell-cell contact was essential to maintain elevated telomerase.

Miranker AD (1999) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci USA 97, 14025-14027.

Mass Spectrometry of Proteins of Known Mass

COMMENTARY.

Wilkins MR, Gasteiger E, Gooley AA, Herbert BR, Molloy MP, Binz P-A, Ou K, Sanchez J-C, Bairoch A, Williams KL, Hochstrasser DF (1999) J. Mol. Biol. 289, 645-657.

High-Throughput Mass Spectrometric Discovery of Protein Post-Translational Modifications

Software tools such as MOWSE, MS-Fit, and PepIdent are available through the internet. Some of them can search a few common post-translational or artifactual modifications (phosphorylation in one, Met oxidation in the other) to account for unknown masses. To do this on a large scale rapidly to predict sequences that are modified is rather difficult. FindMod is added to these tools. The user generates the peptide mass fingerprint as usual to identify the protein. FindMod then searches for post-translation mods by comparing experimental peptide masses that did not match with the protein against those calculated from the assigned sequence, and looking for mass differences that might be due to modification.

For elucidating rules that FindMod might follow, 5153 incidences of modifications were analyzed. Modifications were all those known in the literature. N-linked glycosylation was not considered since the mass difference is difficult to predict. The program can predict 22 of the more common modifications listed in the table below.

Modification Δ mass Kingdom Amino acids Position in protein Rule
Monoisotopic Average
Acetylation 42.0106 42.0373 All K

Modications preceded by an asterisk (*) are generally artifactual and can also be searched for by FindMod.

a The regular expression [GN]-[DEQTR]-x-[LIVMFY]-x(2)-[LIVM]-x-[AIV]-M-K-[LMA]-x(3)-[LIVM]-x-[SAV] where K is the biotin attachment site.

b The regular expression {DERK}(6)-[LIVMFWSTAG](2)-[LIVMFYSTAGCQ]-[AGS]-C where C is the lipid attachment site. Additional rules are that: (1) The cysteine must be between positions 15 and 35 of the sequence in consideration (2) There must be at least one Lys or one Arg in the rst seven positions of the sequence.

c The regular expression [GN]-x(2)-[LIVF]-x(5)-[LIVFC]-x(2)-[LIVFA]-x(3)-K-[STAIV]-[STAVQDN]-x(2)-[LIVMFS]-x(5)-[GCN]-x-[LIVMFY] where K is the lipoyl-binding site.

d The regular expression [KRHEQSTAG]-G-[FYLIVM]-[ST]-[LT]-[LIVP]-E-[LIVMFWSTAG].

e The regular expression [DEQGSTALMKRH]-[LIVMFYSTAC]-[GNQ]-[LIVMFYAG]-[DNEKHS]-S-[LIVMST]-{PCFY}-[STAGCPQLIVMF]-[LIVMATN]-[DENQGTAKRHLM]-[LIVMWSTA]-[LIVGSTACR]-x(2)-[LIVMFA] where S is the pantetheine attachment site.

f See http://www.expasy.ch/sprot/prosite.html.

All modifications cause a mass change. Rules are simple. As an example formylation can happen to the N-terminal position in any species. Distinctions are made for some modifications, such as methylation, depending on cell classes (prokaryotes, eukaryotes). Other artifacts account for variable modifications (carbamylation, sulfoxide, cys-propionamide formation) occurring during sample preparation. The following four cases illustrate the use of FindMod in the discovery of modifications of peptides. PMF was done using a MALDI-ToF MS and fragmentation/sequencing spectra were obtained by MALDI-ToF MS/MS PSD.

Case 1: Lysine dimethylation in E. coli Elongation Factor Tu. The protein EFTu (P02990). One pepdtide of mass 1631.80 was not a theoretical match and after processing through FindMod, was reported to be AFDQIDNAPEEKAR with a Δm of +28.03 Da. This modification was reported to occur in one of three ways: (1) dimethylation of an amino acid (possibly K),

Harvey DJ (1999) Mass Spectrom. Rev. 18, 349-451.

Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Mass Spectrometry of Carbohydrates

REVIEW. Carbohydrates (CHOs) are the most abundant and diverse biomolecules. They form branched structures unlike the linear polymers of proteins and nucleic acids: for a hexasaccharide, there are more than 1012 possible isomers. Only a very few isomers are encountered since their biosynthesis is dependent on a limited number of glycosyltransferases.

Most monosaccharides have the formula CnH2nOn, where n = 3 (trioses) to 9 (nonoses), and n = 6 are the most abundant. Reducing sugars contain n − 1 hydroxy (OH) groups and either an aldehyde (CHO) or keto (-CHOH-C(=O)-CH2OH) group. Deoxysugars and those oxidized to form carboxylic (uronic) acid groups also occur. Some are reduced to alcohols, or there is an amination or acylamination. Some hydroxyls get methylated.

Sugars form rings typically. Ribose (ribofuranose) has a five-membered ring with fifth carbon out of the ring. Arabinose (arabinopyranose) is a 6-membered ring of a 5 carbon sugar. Xylose is an arabinose epimer at carbon 4; and xylose carbons 2-4 have the same stereo configuration as glucose. Mannose is a carbon 2 epimer of glucose, and galactose an carbon 4 epimer. Fucose is a 6-carbon 6-membered right with the 6th carbon fully methylated. N-acetylglucosamine is essentially the amination of carbon 2 of glucose, followed by acylation with acetate. Glucuronic acid is the fully oxidized 6th carbon carboxylate form of glucose. Rhamnose is an epimer of fucose at carbon 4. N-acetylneuraminic acid is also called sialic acid in which a 6-membered ring joins carbon 2 to 6 through the hydroxyl of carbon 6, and carbon 1 is in carboxyl form, carbon 4 is acylaminated, and carbon 6 is joined to a 3-carbon glycerol. Oligosaccharides are composed of 2-10 monosaccharides, and polysaccharides are considered to have > 10 units.

Proteins become glycosylated either as N- or O-linked glycans. N-linkage is achieved by glycosyltransferases that recognize the NX(S/T) (Asn-X-Ser/Thr) motif, where X is any amino acid but Pro. O-linked connect to Ser and Thr and also to glycosylphosphatidylinositol lipid anchors. N-linked glycans form a biantennary (sometimes more) trimannosyl chitobiose core.

[section here on glycolipids]

MALDI MS. Techniques for ionization of sugars are as numerous as the sugars themselves. Electron impact ionizaiton (EI) works only with smaller molecules which usually must be derivatized. MALDI can operate without sample conversion/derivatization. MALDI of sugars was investigated in the late 1980s mostly by Karas and Hillenkamp, while looking at matrices for ionizing proteins. Stachyose was one of the first looked at; this phytochemical tetrasaccharide will ionize without matrix, but when nicotinic acid or tryptophan were added for the Nd-YAG (266 nm) laser, signal improved; the major MALDI ion was a sodium form. 3-nitrobenzyl alcohol and 3-nitrophenyl octyl ether are liquid matrices and they produced instead a radical ion or [M-17]+, respectively. MALDI is 10-100 times more sensitive than FAB and 252Cf plasma desorption MS. It also worked for tryptic glycopeptides where PD failed. Ionization of MNa+ ions is not as sensitive as MH+, where the former is CHOs and latter are peptides. Generally high laser power is required and this reduces the number of spectra that can be obtained; laser aim must be in continuous movement to keep passable spectra collected in series.
