Lasers are typically nitrogen gas (337 nm). Infrared lasers such as Er-YAG (2.94 µm, 80-90 ns pulse) and Er-YSGG (2.79 µm, 80 ns) can be used for large glycoproteins, using glycerol or succinic acid matrices. Much more sample is consumed (by two orders) than for UV lasers. The first commercial MALDI-TOF was made in 1990 but had poor resolution as a linear type (200-300). Resolution of 2000 FWHM in magnetic sector instruments were used in CHO analysis, requiring array type detectors since they were pulsed. Eventually reflectron tubes were available, then delayed extraction or time-lag focusing ion sources were developed. Resolution of 10,000 or more with mass accuracies in low ppm range are available today.

Interesting is the use of magnetic sector MS with conventional point detector. The instrument is set to scan 0-2400 u over 1 min, and many spectra are recorded and averaged. This requires use of a matrix that can maintain a signal for several minutes. A liquid matrix of α-cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid (4-HCCA) and 3-aminoquinoline proved to be satisfactory. Resolution of 8000 FWHM and mass accuracy to 2 ppm were possible. MS/MS of maltodecaose also could be made with He gas in collision.

In another approach, 6-10 laser pulses are fired across each mass peak and the resulting spectra are smoothed for the peak profile. A single scan is sufficient to produce a high resolution (~20,000) spectrum. Ion trap and FT-ICR MS have been used successfully.

Matrices. These are optimized not just for the laser but the class of CHO. Substituted benzoic acids were used to look at free neutral CHO molecules. 3-amino-4-hydroxbenzoic acid was the first matrix used, producing MNa+ ions having good signals with as little as 1 pmol dextran hydrosylate and N-linked glycans from glycoproteins. 2,5-DHB was used (originally used for proteins) and is the most popular for CHO MALDI-MS; it also produces MNa+ ions. Inclusion of potassium and lithium also produces ions of this type. Alkali ion affinity appears to be Cs > K > Na; > Li > H. Cs will not ionize smaller CHOs as it will glycans.

2,5-DHB will crystallize from MeCN or EtOH/water as long needle-shaped crystals, orientied radially; re-dissolution in absolute EtOH will produce a more even film, increasing sensitivity roughly 10-fold. It has been understood that isomers of 2,5-DHB are not effective unless there is an ortho-hydroxy group. The reason is that an intramolecular proton transfer occurs between the phenol and carboxyl members, as shown by all ortho isomers being effective matrices and the rest not. 2,5-DHB was the most effective, although it is thought that photochemical decomposition occurs in which UV light induces elimination of CO2. Additional oxidation produces p-benzoquinone, relatively stable. Working from this assumption it has been possible to discover other matrices as 1,4-dihydroxy-2-naphthoic acid as it produces stable species of this type. 2,5-DHB matrix mixes also improve sensitivity and resolution. Mixes disorder crystal lattice and therefore provide a softer desorption. 10% 2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzoic acid with 2,5-DHB produces something called super 2,5-DHB.

Pfeifer T, Drewello M, Schierhorn A (1999) J. Mass Spectrom. 34, 644-650.

Using a Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer for Combined In-Source Decay/Post-Source Decay Experiments

ABSTRACT. Mass spectrometric experiments with fragment ions have not yet been possible with a matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectrometer because intense signals of fragment ions were rarely observed during continuous extraction and the mass resolution of in-source formed fragment ions has been low. This paper describes a combination of MALDI in-source decay and post-source decay experiments on a MALDI-TOF mass spectrometer equipped with delayed extraction. Fragment ions initially formed in the ion source were selected by the precursor ion gate and investigated by post-source decay. The in-source formed fragment ions were sufficiently excited to undergo further metastable decay. The new method was applied to linear peptides, the cyclic peptide gramicidin S and a pentasaccharide, leading to unambiguous structural information.

Link AJ, Eng J, Schieltz DM, Carmack E, Mize GJ, Morris DR, Garvik BM, Yates JR 3rd (1999) Nat. Biotechnol. 17, 676-682.

Direct Analysis of Protein Complexes Using Mass Spectrometry

Many important complexes of proteins exist in nature. RNA polymerase II transcription complex contains at least 50 different proteins, and eukaryotic ribosome consists of 78-80 unique proteins.

Vogel KG, Meyers AB (1999) Clin. Ortho. Rel. Res. 367S, S344-S355.

Proteins in the Tensile Region of Adult Bovine Deep Flexor Tendon

Type I collagen is the major protein of tendon. This study is undertaken to find ECM molecules in tendon also known to be present in cartilage, using gel electrophoresis and Westerns. Deep flexor tendon was obtained from font feet of 1-2 year old cows, and the tensile region (proximal to point of tendon bifurcation) was cut into small pieces with razor blade, powdered in liquid nitrogen with stainless steel ball or grinding mill. Storage was at −20°. 200 mg wet weight frozen tissue powder is put in screw cap tube with 4 ml extraction buffer and rotated vigorously end over end 24 h in cold room or at RT. This is centrifuged 30 min at 10 krpm (Beckman JA-20) at 5°. Supernatant is recovered and pellet extracted in series. Extraction is in series as follows: (1) 24 h with 1° PBS (50 mM pH 7.4 sodium phosphate + 150 mM NaCl) containing 5 mM benzamidine HCl, 5 mM N-ethylmaleimide, 2 mM EDTA, 1 mM PMSF for protease inhibition; (2) 4 M guanidine HCl in 50 mM sodium acetate pH 6.0 repeated 3 times at 1°; (3) 4 M GuanHCl + acetate but at 18° and repeated 3 times; and (4) Guan buffer containing 10 mM DTT at 18°, also repeated 3 times. Protein assays are by BCA (Pierce) checking for Guan interference.

The use of DTT in the later extraction helps to remove proteins that might be attached by disulfide bonds. A pellet that is quite gel-like (gooey) remains after all extractions; this is composed mostly of cross-linked type I collagen. 11% of the total protein is removed in the first 24 h PBS extraction. 68% of the protein is extracted in 4 M guan either at cold or room temp, and an additional 21% is solubilized in the guan + DTT extraction. Experiments with N-ethylmaleimide demonstrated that denaturation of protein by 4 M guan HCl was not leading to disulfide bond formation of proteins with other parts of the matrix.

SDS-PAGE showed that most protein extracted in PBS had masses < 70 kDa. Higher MW proteins were in the first 4 M guan HCl extraction, but these were observed only in samples that had been reduced. Rinsing in 4 M guan HCl extracts Type I collagen α chains.

Western analysis was then done. Proteins in the supernatant samples were analyzed before and after digestion with chondroitinase ABC (this removes chondroitin sulfate and dermatan sulfate glycosaminoglycan chains) and with and without reduction by thiols. Some decorin was solubilized in PBS whereas all of it was removed in the 4 M guanidine. After chondroitinase ABC digestion, core protein of the proteoglycan was solubilized. A 45 kDa band is found in undigested core protein lacking a glycosaminoglycan chain. Fibromodulin is extracted in both PBS and guanidine, seen as a broad immunoreactivity band at 60 kDa; a higher MW band reactive to anti-fibromodulin was not altered under reducing conditions or by digestion with chondroitinase ABC and could be fibromodulin carrying variable amounts of keratan sulfate or other type of glycosylation. Aggregcan was seen on the immunoblot only with chondroitinase ABC-digested guanidine extracts: intact aggregcan monomer would not have exited from the stacking gel and this protein does not carry keratan sulfate chains. Type IV collagen chains were found in the guanidine extract

Chaurand P, Leutzenkirchen F, Spengler B (1999) J. Am Soc. Mass Spectrom. 10, 91-103.

Peptide and Protein Identification by Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization (MALDI) and MALDI-Post-Source Decay Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. The potential of matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization (MALDI) and MALDI-post-source decay (PSD) time-of-flight mass spectrometry for the characterization of peptides and proteins is discussed. Recent instrumental developments provide for levels of sensitivity and accuracy that make these techniques major analytical tools for proteome analysis. New software developments employing protein database searches have greatly enhanced the fields of application of MALDI-PSD. Peptides and proteins can be easily identified even if only a partial sequence information is determined. Derivatization procedures have been optimized for MALDI-PSD to increase the structural information and to obtain a complete peptide sequence even in critical cases. They are fast, simple and can be performed on target. MALDI-PSD is also a very powerful tool to characterize or elucidate post-translational or chemically induced modifications. In association with database searches, proteins issued from electrophoretic gels can be identified after specific enzymatic cleavages and peptide mapping.

Gygi SP, Rist B, Gerber SA, Turecek F, Gelb MH, Aebersold R (1999) Nat. Biotechnol. 17, 994-999.

Quantitative Analysis of Complex Protein Mixtures Using Isotope-Coded Affinity Tags

ABSTRACT. We describe an approach for the accurate quantification and concurrent sequence identification of the individual proteins within complex mixtures. The method is based on a class of new chemical reagents termed isotope-coded affinity tags (ICATs) and tandem mass spectrometry. Using this strategy, we compared protein expression in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, using either ethanol or galactose as a carbon source. The measured differences in protein expression correlated with known yeast metabolic function under glucose-repressed conditions. The method is redundant if multiple cysteinyl residues are present, and the relative quantification is highly accurate because it is based on stable isotope dilution techniques. The ICAT approach should provide a widely applicable means to compare quantitatively global protein expression in cells and tissues.

Easterling ML, Mize TH, Amster IJ (1999) Anal. Chem. 71, 624-632.

Routine Parts-Per-Million Mass Accuracy for High-Mass Ions: Space-Charge Effects in MALDI FT-ICR

The elemental composition of low MW samples can often be determined by an accurate mass measurement. The count of peptides needed to identify a protein is inversely proportional to mass accuracy of data. FT-ICR has a very high precision but there is no guarantee of accuracy. ICR signals arise from measurement of image charge created by coherent motion of ions between a set of opposed electrodes in a strong magnetic field. Ions in a magnetic field show a frequency of motion that is ω = zB/m where ω is cyclotron frequency and is proportional to applied magnetic field B and inversely proportional to m/z. In order to get a narrow spectral line width, a static electric trapping potential is applied to confine ions within the magnetic field. Electric field influences ion motion and observed cyclotron frequency. Perturbation to trapping electric field are caused by collective electric potential of ions within trapping volume. Effect is called space charge and affects cyclotron frequency measurement. In describing the omegatron, the first ICR MS, this space charge effect was addressed.

The scanning ICR works by ejecting ions one mass at a time from the trapped ion cloud. In FT-ICR ions are excited into coherent cyclotron motion with substantial radius of gyration then detected simultaneously. To account for perturbations, an observed cyclotron frequency included new factors:

ωobs = zB − 2aV − zρGi
m a2B ε0B

The first term is the unperturbed cyclotron frequency, the second term describes the magnetron frequency for an ion in perfectly quadrupolar static trapping field. The last term is the space-charge component of the mass shift, where z is elementary charge magnitude, ρ is ion density, Gi

Shen T-L, Huang Z-H, Laivenieks M, Zeikus JG, Gage DA, Allison J (1999) J. Mass Spectrom. 34, 1154-1165.

Evaluation of Charge Derivatization of A Proteolytic Protein Digest for Improved Mass Spectrometric Analysis: de Novo Sequencing By Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Post-Source Decay Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. A simple mass spectrometric method to sequence a recombinant phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase of known structure and a novel variant of unknown structure isolated from Anaerobiospirillum succiniciproducens and Actinobacillus succinogenes 130Z, respectively, was evaluated. The proteolytic digests of the proteins were each chemically derivatized at the N-terminus by addition of a tris(trimethoxyphenyl)phosphoniumacetyl (TMPPYAc) group to produce peptides with a fixed positive charge. The derivatized digests were then partially separated by reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography. The fractions collected were subjected to matrixassisted laser desorption/ionization post-source decay (MALDI/PSD) mass spectrometric analysis. The resulting spectra are sufficiently simple to allow the sequence to be read directly without extensive interpretation. This is in contrast to spectra of underivatized peptides obtained by MALDI/PSD or conventional tandem mass spectrometry, where full sequence interpretation can be challenging. Aided with a set of very simple established rules, it was shown that the sequence of TMPPY-Ac derivatives can be derived strictly from predictable fragment ion series. In most cases, this is sufficient to determine extensive, unambiguous, peptide sequences de novo. The partial sequence (35%) of the unknown phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase from Actinobacillus succinogenes 130Z was obtained entirely by the mass spectrometric method evaluated here, which provided the basis for evaluating homology and for the design of oligonucleotide probes for cloning the corresponding gene.

Hoffmann R, Metzger S, Spengler B, Otvos L Jr (1999) J. Mass Spectrom. 34, 1195-1204.

Sequencing of Peptides Phosphorylated on Serines and Threonines by Post-source Decay in Matrix-assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-flight Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. In the era of complete genome sequences, biochemical and medical research will focus more on the dynamic proteome of a cell. Regulation of proteins by post-translational modifications, which are not determined by the gene sequence, are already intensively studied. One example is phosphorylation of serines and threonines, probably the single most common cellular regulatory mechanism. In this paper we describe the sequencing of mono- and bisphosphorylated peptides, including identification of the phosphorylation sites, by post-source decay (PSD) in matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry. In addition to dephosphorylation of the parent ions, we studied the influence of the phosphate group on the fragmentation of peptides. Generally, peptides phosphorylated on serine and threonine residues displayed no difference in their fragmentation patterns. The intensities of the resulting fragment ion signals depend only on the peptide sequence and not on either the phosphorylated amino acid or its position in the peptide chain. Phosphorylation increased the bond cleavage C-terminal to the phosphorylation site more than 10-fold, resulting in abundant signals, which typically dominated the PSD spectra. The produced C-terminally phosphorylated b-type fragment ions showed characteristic dephosphorylated fragment ions bn H3PO4 (98 Da) and bn HPO3 (80 Da) of higher abundances than the phosphorylated fragment ion. As a second layer to identify the phosphorylation site, all internally phosphorylated fragment ions were accompanied by minor, but always detectable, signals of the dephosphorylated fragment ions. Interpretation of PSD spectra of phosphopeptides was not more complicated than for unphosphorylated peptides, despite the increased number of obtained fragment ion signals.

Cotter RJ, Fancher C, Cornish TJ (1999) J. Mass Spectrom. 34, 1368-1372.

Miniaturized Time-of-flight Mass Spectrometer for Peptide and Oligonucleotide Analysis

As part of the process of miniaturizing mass spectrometers in which they would have multiple applications, particularly in the field, we recently introduced an endcap reflectron to provide nearly quadratic reflectron potential to obtain high mass resolution: these provide kinetic energy focusing to infinite order (flight times are independent of kinetic energy). The endcap ToF MS assembly is composed of a piston-like cylinder with an adjustable drift region and reflectron detph. A rod-like probe assembly is inserted on one end and concentrically surrounding is a detector anode (so the source and detector are within the same region. On the other end is a reflectron assembly in which the reflectron electron mounted on an adjustable plug whose depth is controlled by an adjustment rod, and the plug inserts into a grounded cylinder that forms the flight tube. Concentric to the reflectron assembly at the center is an opening from which the laser light enters opposite the source to illuminate it directly and begin the reflected flight. The entire drift region length is 2.00 inches usually, and the diameter of the assembly is 2.20 inches. The detector is dual channelplate. A 3.3 mm stainless steel probe moves through the vacuum wall via a ball valve in the center hole and behind the grid located at the front of the detector. Probe tip is electrically insulated from probe body and shielded from the detector using a 4.0 mm dia grounded sleeve. The source region is 0.5 mm to reduce effects of source length on mass resolution, and a 4500 V potential can be applied. A fine nickel mesh grid terminates the high source field, either 333 lines per inch for 70% transmission or 1000 lines per inch for 50% transmission. Arcing from the probe tip is reduced by polishing it with 12,000-grit abrasive. Reflectron is ground 1.75 inch (44.5 mm) i.d. stainless stell cylinder 2.125 in (54 mm) long, and capped with 1.6 mm thick stainless stell electrode plate mounted on movable polycarbonate plug, and terminated on other end with grounded nickel mesh (333 lines per inch). Four ceramic rods extending from detector through holes running through the reflectron plug provide alignment. Reflectron depth can be adjusted from 0.63 to 1.34 in or the drift region from 0.16 to 1.18 in. The entire assembly is mounted within a vacuum chamber. The laser is a pulsed Laser Photonic Model LN-1000 nitrogen laser, focused through fused silica window and through a CVI Laser 250 mm focal length lens. The probe is kept at +4.4 kV, ions reflected back to detector which is biased at -3.3 kV and using reflectron voltages of +6.0 kV. Detector is Galileo MCP, modified with addition of shielded and offset conical anode, coupled to 2 Gsample per second adaptor on a Lecroy Model 9374M 1 GHz digital oscilloscope, and data acquisition and processing was done using TOFWARE from ILYS software. Peptides at 1 µM are put on the probe at 0.5 µl followed by 0.5 µl of satd CHCA in 50% EtOH. In some cases, 0.5 µl sample, then 0.5 µl 5% ammonium citrate, then 0.5 µl of matrix. For oligonucleotides, 0.5 µl of 1 µM solution then 0.5 µl matrix, which is satd 6-aza-2-thiothymine (AAT) in 50% MeCN, from which 90 micro;l supernatant is mixed with 10 µl 50 mM ammonium citrate. Spectra are the average of 50 scans.

Pleissner K-P, Hoffman F, Kriegel K, Wenk C, Wegner S, Sahlström A, Oswald H, Alt H, Fleck E (1999) Electrophoresis 20, 755-765.

New Algorithmic Approaches to Protein Spot Detection and Pattern Matching in Two-Dimensional Electrophoresis Gel Databases

Before pattern matching can occur, spots must be detected for which there are several algorithms. Current spot detection mthods fall into two classes: Gaussian fitting and Laplacian of Gaussian (LoG) spot detectors (current commercial systems are Kepler, Gellab-II, PDQuest, Melanie, Phoretix. A new hierarchical watershed transformation (WST) combined with feature extraction was used. Gel images are downloaded from internet, followed by calculating a gradient image, performing the WST, localizing spot regions, merging partial spot regions, then calculating spot list.

Watersheds correspond to regions above a topographic or contoured plane and which fall below a waterline. Each watershed forms from a computation of local/global maxima and minima in the image signal, creating image segmentation. Regions are obtained using the WST on the gradient image (first derivative). A mosaic image is achieved. Well-located closed contours are a result of WST, although strong over-segmentation can also result from image noise amplifed in the gradient image calculation. Prior to WST, a Gaussian smoothing prefilter can alleviate noise effects.

Ideally all regions should correspond to a spot in the mosaic image, but oversegmentation a spot may be divided into several subregions (partial spot regions). Algorithms must be used that merge several regions together to form a single spot. A preprocessing step which is gray-value thresholding: a number of spot regions is reduced using a simple signal threshold on the assumption that spots have a significantly lower gray value than the background where black = 0 and white = 255 (in an 8-bit set of levels). After WST to obtain regions, the average gray value is determined. Then the gray value distribution for the gel image is constructed, and applied thresholds evaluated. Spots and partial spot regin in the mosaic will border on background regions. Regions with a neighboring region having a significantly higher average could be spot or partial spot regions. Suppose there are R set of regions and N= |R| total count of regions in the mosaic image. Neighbor (r) is the set of neighboring regins of r ∈ R.

Criterion 1. Neighbor difference D(r) of a region is given by: D(r) = inf{|μ(r) - μ(r′)| |r′ ∈ Neighbor(r)}

A candidate for a spot or partial spot region is a region r such that D(r) > t1 where t1 is a threshold given by 40% of the gray-value variation within the image. The assumption is not true for all partial spot regions, and especially partial spot regions in middle of spots not bordering on a background region. These regions will have low gray values and can be found using a second threshold value t2.

Criterion 2. A spot or partial spot region candidate region r ∈ R is such that μ(r) < t2 where t2 is a threshold give by 20% of the total gray variation within the gel image. The 40% and 20% threshold values were determined empirically.

The preprocessing step uses two specific gray-value thresholds to reduce the count of candidate regions significantly, but it is not specific to find exactly the correct spot candidates or remove all nonspecific regions. Convex curvatures are obvious features found on a topographic surface representing the gel image signal; it is also true for partial spot regions. WST is performed on the gradient image (1st derivative) and thus the watersheds separate regions of convex and concave curvature. Only regions with convexities are to be found as spot candidates. The curvature C(r) of a region r ∈ R is defined as:

C(r) = ∑f ′′(p)    p∈r

where the sum is taken over all pixels (p) in region r and f ′′ is the second derivative of the image. A candidate for a spot or partial spot region is a region r that satisfied C(r). With the two gray-value criteria and the curvature thresholding, remaining regions correspond to regions of spots or partial spots.

Spots have two characteristics: approximately elliptical shapes; and for neighboring partial spot regions within a spot, the local curvature CL is convex in a small neighborhood along their common border (watershed line). These are used in the merging of partial spot regions but the two properties are not sufficient to characterize the regions, and so a combination is used. To examine similarity of a region r to an ellipse, and ellipse Er is made within the circumscribed rectangle of a region. A χ2 test is used to look at the difference or similarity between the constructed ellipse Er and the region r. A region is merged with neighboring regions if the similarity of the merged region to an ellipse is higher than the similarity of each separate region to an ellipse. The local curvature CL for the neighboring regions r and r′ is found through the 2nd derivative in a 3 × 3 pixel neighborhood along the common border. The 2nd derivative is computed in the direction of the line connecting the centers of area/gravity of r and r′. Partial spot regions, together representing one spot, are expected to have a positive curvature along their watershed line, and in this case, regions can be merged. It the local curvature is negative (concave), then regions should not be merged. Using both criteria the algorithm would not lead to merging two or more neighboring circular spots, even if they overlap. Spots consisting of separate spot regions resulting from a segmentation process should nonetheless be merged. At the end, each identifed spot s is assocated with coordinate x(s), y(s) of its center of gravity with intensity i(s) being the sum of all gray-values in the region. Vectors x(s), y(s), i(s) of all spots are assembled into a list.

With spot detection complete, between-gel spot matching is the next phase with several algorithms described. Matching proficiency can be can be improved using pre-assigned corresponding spot pairs (landmarks), and some algorithms only work with landmarking. The Melanie II gel analysis system will work without manual landmarking. This paper reports a geometric method of spot patterns and associated intensities and is independent of geometric and densitometric (gray-value) image resolution. It is robust in the presence of noise (additional/missing spots). Matching makes use of the spot detection data (2D coordinates + intensity) only; the intensity is used only to obtain an intensity order relationship while the actual intensity value i(s) itself is not important.

For geometric point pattern matching, let P denote a point pattern which in this implementation is a set of intensive points from a small window in a source image. Compute all occurrences in P with another point set, T, spots in a target image. The pattern search can be likened to looking for a given star constellation in a celestial chart. There is an admissible space A representing transformations (translations, rigid motions and/or scalings, rotations) which can be used to map the pattern as close as possible to point set T. In addition there is a distance measure d between patterns. Also the Hausdorff distance H is often considered. In general a search for an f ∈ A and a pattern Q in T for which d(f(P),Q) ≤ ε, where ε is an error tolerance. For exact matching ε = 0.

Two approaches have proved useful in point matching, the alignment method and geometric hashing. The alignment method uses a similarity transformation based on a reflection through the mapping of a single line segment. Thus two points a and b in pattern P are chosen and the edge ab is mapped to all edges uv in target set T. In each mapping a check is made if it induces a matching (large partial approximate) of P. Even in partial matching it is not sufficient to consider only one edge ab. In a worst-case situation it would be necessary to map all pattern edges to edges in T. The use of scalings would make the process more complex, if they are allowed or not strongly restricted; for a given edge ab it it enough to search for a target edge of the same length with no scaling. If rotations are forbidden, all target edges with approximately same slope as ab are checked. The alignment method can be accelerated if points in the pattern and the target are labeled with positive values (intensities) and used such that valid matching requires that the intensity order of the pattern is consistent with order in the target. The quadratic size search space of all target edges can be reduced under certain cases to the set of all edges in the history of the incremental Delaunay triangulation of T which has an expected linear size. There is a considerable expenditure of time for doing the matching for each pair of edges ab in P and uv in T.

Avoiding the time spent can be helped by geometric hashing. A hash table is produced in preprocessing, then the number of pattern point matched by a transformation resulting from a legal edge pair can be counted efficiently. At the end the matches only for the best transformations are used in determination.

Local Matching Queries. Given a local spot pattern P in a 2D gel image, the task is to find all local spot patterns in target image T that resemble at least partially the geometric shap and spot intensities of P. Results of the local match are later used to form global match between source and target images. Algorithm to answer local matching queries starts from two assumptions: (i) the geometry of spot patterns is given by point patterns; (ii) the algorithm should not use relative position of the selected pattern within the source image or its location with respect to possibly given landmarks. The source and target images can be assumed to have the same bounding box whose size can be used to limit the search range and speed up matching. Linear scaling can be done to alter the bounding box.

  1. A small rectangular window in source S is chosen because a pattern P is identified within it. The pattern of the most intense spots are chosen first (it is not important if the spot counts differ between gels). Pattern size default is eight (8).
  2. In target T a matching pattern P′ can be found composed of local intense spots. Solutions are accepted in which P′ resembles only a large portion of P. This can help correct errors made by the spot detection algorithms which have problems resolving spots close to each other or which partially overlap.
  3. A simple rule incorporating two tolerance parameters λ and α are used to model the pure geometric resemblance between P and P′. Two line segments st and s′t′ are said to be similar for λ and α if the differences in their slopes is < α and the length meets the condition: 1 − λ ≤ |st| / |s′t′| ≤ 1 + λ. Two point patterns P and P′ are similar for (λ, α) if there is bijection f between points sets such that st and f(s)f(t) are (λ, α)-similar for all s,t ∈ P. In total the search is for (λ, α)-matchings between as large as possible subpatterns P′′ ⊂ P and target patterns P′.
  4. The absolute intensity i(s) values are not used directly in modeling intensity resemblance between spots, but a robust heuristic ranking rule is used assigning to each spot a discrete integer from 1 to 10. The 500 most intense spots in the image are distributed equallly according to cardinality between 10 and 6. Spots that remain are given integer values ≤ 5 so that the total intensity sum in each class is the same. In matching the criterion that a pattern spot s can only be matched to a spot in P′ can be done if the discrete intensity differs by at most 2-fold.
  5. The edge similarity constants λ and α are usually small (default values are 0.2 for both), and it is known that each (λ,α)-matching between P′′ ⊂ P and P′ is close to a translation t; more exactly it is the Hausdorff distance H˜(t)(P′′,P) between a translated P′′ and P′ representing the worst case bound from above by maxs,t∈P2ε|st|. Other that size of P′′, an evaluation of the match could be the Euclidean distance of the center of P′ from an expected center position of transformed P within the target image, given its source position is known.

The key idea, first used in a cited reference in finding a star constellation in a star atlas, is as follows. Call a triplet of spots in a gel image the most intense if its circumcircle does not contain a spot that is more intense than any of the triplet. An edge which connects spots s,t is intensive if there exists a third spot forming an intensive triplet together with s and t. Intensive edges described here are related to Delaunay triangualtion construction understood in computational geometry. Triangulation of point set S in the plane is called Delaunay triangulation if for each triangle in the triangulation its circumcircle contains only the triangle points. The triangulation is done in steps (incrementally) by adding one point after another. Assume that the Delaunay triangulation of a gel image is computed incrementally but inserting spots in order of decreasing intensity. Then the set of all Delaunay triangles and edges occurring during the history of that process is exactly the set of intensive triangles and intensive edges.

Hist* (T) is a data structure representing all intensive edges together with their lengths and slopes and so-called flipped diagonals. With a new line segment creating a bisection of the triangle, any segment that crosses it is deleted from the current triangulation. Four Delaunay edges (outer segments of the bisected triangle) and two flipped diagonals are added to Hist*(T). The edge set Hist*(T)is then used instead of the set of all edges in the target for the following reasons: (i) While the count of all edges is quadratic wrt to n count of spots, the expected count of edges in Hist*(T) is bounded by 12n. (ii) If a pattern P of locally intensive spots occurs in T, then one expects that despite the possible noise that cause changes in intensity order, many of the edges connecting spots in P will be (λ,α)-similar to edges in Hist*(T). Up to this point our technique is like Weber et al.

For Weber et al., each occurrence of a target edge that is of equal length is extended with a source pattern edge to a matching of the complete source pattern. A different strategy is called for because a small but nevertheless considerable length and slope tolerance that imply an edge search range in Hist*(T) which is too large although already linear in size. The alternative to the alignment technique is the two-step variant of geometric hashing. First compute all locations in a target image where good matching with the pattern is likely to occur, and then compute actual patterns that answer the local matching query.

For each pattern edge e target edges e′ in Hist*(T) meeting tolerance bounds wrt to length, slope, and discrete spot intensities are found and the vector t(e,e′) translating the midpoint of e to that of e′ is computed. A scoring table is kept storing translation vectors indirectly and yielding clusters of such vectors. Such clusters may correspond to possible matching locations: the bounding box of T is interpreted as the possible space for translation vectors t(e,e′), and then a regularly spaced grid is overlaid on the translation space with an integer scores data structure, initially zero, all maintained and defined for each grid node. Each translation vector increases the score among the four grid nodes defining the grid cell into which the vector occurs. Cell is divided into four rectangles by t(e,e′). Each of the four grid nodes adds it current score an amount proportional to area of the opposite rectangle given by the total area by 100. Score(i,j) is the total score accumulated in grid node (i,j) after probing all |P|C2 pattern edges. All local maixma that are greater than a threshold value depending on the cardinality of P are considered to correspond to potential matching locations.

After scoring, a list of putative locations of matching pattern centers (c) in the target is generated with each point c corresponding to a translation tc for which tc (P) is computed, mapping the pattern into the target. for each source spot s ∈ P, neighbors of tc(s) in the Delaunay triangulation of T are sought, constituting a list of matching candidates for pattern spot s. A maximal subste that defines (λ,α)-matching with subpattern of P is selected using an exhaustive search.

A geometric distortion between pattern P and counterpart P′ in the target can be more severe, done by increasing tolerances in the values for slope and length, increasing time bounds for geometric hashing process. A standard heuristic trick is to distort the pattern P iteratively in a typical (application-dependent) way and search for the distorted pattern but keep similarity tolerances low.

silver, peptides, fragmentation, sequencing, FD

Chu IK, Guo X, Lau T-C, Siu KWM (1999) Anal. Chem. 71, 2364-2372.

Sequencing of Argentinated Peptides by Means of Electrospray Tandem Mass Spectrometry

Two PE SCIEX triple quad (API 365 and API 3000) mass spectrometers were used. Peptides were prepared at 2 pmol/µl in 50% MeOH with 10 µM AgNO3. Infusion is 2 µl/min using air as nebulizer. Nitrogen pressure in Q2 is 3 mTorr and collision energy at center-of-mass frame (Ecm) is 1-3 eV. 1 mg proteins (bov cyt c, ubiquitin) are dissolved in 0.1 ml 8 M urea, 40 µl 800 mM ammoninum carbonate, and then 22 µl 2 mg/ml trypsin added, left 24 h at 37°. Water added to 1 ml, then 10 µl glacial acetic acid added. Digests are sampled, silver nitrate added to 10 µM.

The first figure shows product ion spectra of [M+107Ag]+. Note Ag has two stable isotopes, 107 and 109, which have about equal abundance. Three spectra with energies of Ecm = 1.5, 2.0 and 2.5 eV are shown. Ions are [an-H+Ag]+, [bn-H+Ag]+ and [bn+OH+Ag]+. Figure shows product ion yields increase with collisional energy. If spectra at each energy level are summed to produce a composite, it is a convenient way to present minimal number of search spectra to triplet/doublet identification algorithm. Alternatives include acquiring product-ion spectra where Ecm depends on m/z: a mass spectrum is shown in which Ecm is linear function of m/z: Ecm = (-0.0015798)(m/z) + 2.5474, in which Ecm = 2.5 eV at m/z 30 and 1.5 eV at m/z 663. Spectra are of quality that the masses are easily determined without computation. Triplet patterns of peaks can be found which are 18 and 28 units apart, and correspond to the three ion types (one a, and two b ions) above. For example, for Leu-enkephalin, the [M+Ag]+ ion is at m/z 662.2 and the first triplet m/z 548.9, 531.2, and 503.1 show differences of 17.7 and 28.1 units between the three, and representing [bn+OH+Ag]+ for the largest ion of the three. This latter ion is the truncated peptide after cleavage of the C-terminal residue. Difference between [LeuEnk+Ag]+ and [b4+OH+Ag]+ is 662.2 − 548.9 = 113.3, which identifies either Leu or Ile (theoretical is 113.1 for +1 ions). Continued mass difference determinations between [bn+OH+Ag]+ ions gives a proper sequence tag. The last triplet pattern has m/z 300, which indicates probably two amino acids from the N-terminus. The third peak in the triplet has m/z 299.1 and would be the [a2-H+Ag]+ ion. Cleavage between residue 1 and 2 would not produce a [b1-H+Ag]+ ion since most b ions are oxazolones and must be two residues in this state, and [b1+OH+Ag]+ is usually missing. The [a1-H+Ag]+ ion is present however at m/z 242.1, and the different with [a2-H+Ag]+ at m/z 299.1 is 57.0, identifying 4th residue from C terminus as glycine. The N-terminal residue can be found by substracting Ag isotope mass from proton (106.9 - 1.0 = 105.9) and then this from the mass of the m/z 242.1 ion, leaving 136.2, the immonium ion of Tyr. Thus a sequence of YGGF(L/I) is determined. The same kind of analyses are shown for other pure peptides and for tryptic peptides.

The [M+107Ag]+ product spectrum of GGEGG. The difference between [M+Ag]+ and [bn + OH + Ag]+ 482.1 − 425.1 = 57.0, making it Gly. The spectrum also shows that the next b ion is also Gly. These residues indicate fragmentation from the C-terminus. The next degradation indicates Glu. The [a1 − H + Ag]+ is weak and the small m/z 193.1 of [an − H + Ag]+ indicates it is [a2 − H + Ag]+, which for GG is a theoretical 193.0. Finally there is a peak m/z 136.0 to indicate an N-terminal G a1 ion.

Looking at bradykinin (RPPGFSPFR), the sequencing of the protonated [M+H]+ is difficult because of the proton is sequestered by guanidine of one or both of the two Arg residues, and so it does not affect amidic functional groups. In contrast silver ion binds to different sites on peptide. The spectrum reveals for each residue broken down a pattern of triplet peaks ([bn + OH + Ag]+, [bn − H + Ag]+, and [an − H + Ag]+) to reveal the tag FSPFR. For peptides longer than 6 residues in fact, it is not possible to sequence beyond 5 or 6 residues. An advantage to sequencing with silver ion is that it provides the signature triplet pattern as opposed to protonated peptides, and the pattern helps to identify fragment ions for sequencing. It was observed that Ag+ bound peptides with C-terminal Arg, Met, and Lys residues show strong [yn + H + Ag]+ product ions, and this confirms the cleaved residue. Bradykinin shows these [yn + H + Ag]+ ions for n = 3 to 5, and this too is matched by a triplet peak search. For the Pro residue the triplet signal is weak, which itself confirms such a residue. An oxazolone [bn − H + Ag]+ cannot be formed from the Pro and the weak [bn − H + Ag]+ is probably a ketene. Pro residues can also be identified by [yn + H + Ag]+ ions or identification of next triplet. The difference between [bn + OH + Ag]+ for n = and n = 3 for the spectrum computes to 243.8, which sums to Phe + Pro.

The dynorphin A fragment 1-7 YGGFLRR product spectrum for [M + 107Ag]+ is another highly basic peptide. A partial sequence of FLRR was determined by the [yn + H + Ag]+ product series.

To determine whether an unknown (not known a priori) could have its sequence determined by the search algorithm, a blinded scientist was given the task of sequencing. The partial sequences determined were correctly.

The greatest potential of sequencing argentiated peptides involves identifying

  • [bn + OH + Ag]+
  • [bn − H + Ag]+
  • [an − H + Ag]+
  • [yn + H + Ag]+

where the first three are the triplet particularly observed.

Cole RB (2000) J. Mass Spectrom. 35, 763-772.

Some Tenets Pertaining To Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. The field of electrospray ionization mass spectrometry is reviewed with emphasis placed upon advances in the elucidation of fundamental mechanistic aspects of the ionization process that have been reported over the past 10 years. The analytical consequences of these findings are also examined. Eight central conclusions or tenets are presented, as deduced from the body of work contained in 80 references.

Kebarle P (2000) J. Mass Spectrom. 35, 804-817.

A brief overview of the present status of the mechanisms involved in electrospray mass spectrometry identification technology

Two models have been proposed for the mechanism by which electrospray ionization occurs. The ion evaporation model (IEM) proposes that ions move into the gas phase from droplets whose radii has decreased to ≤ 10 nm because of charge repulsion. The charged residue model (CRM) proposes instead that analyte ions themselves never transit from the liquid phase to the gas phase, but that droplet fission proceeds rapidly to leave nothing but a charged single ion (i.e., the evaporation is of the solvent molecules, not the analyte ion). The steps in both models require the production of charged droplets at the ES capillary tip; the evolution of the charged droplets and the formation of gas phase ions. Sensitivity in ESMS depends on the analyte's chemical properties and concentration used, and on the presence of other analytes.

An electric field in the ES capillary causes a partial separation of positive and negative ions in solution. In positive ion mode, positive ions are driven to the surface of the liquid and negative ions toward the center. As fluid emerges from the tip of the capillary, the positive ions at the surface and the pull of the electric field at the tip is greater than the surface tension of the liquid. These forces cause the liquid to expand into a cone called the Taylor cone. The tip of the cone is the least stable point elongates into a liquid filament.

To enable onset of electrospray requires an electric field E0 expressed as:

E0 = ( 2γ cos 49° )½
ε0rc

where γ is the surface tension of the liquid, cos 49° is the half-angle of the Taylor cone, ε0 is the permittivity of vacuum, and rc is the capillary radius. Note the dependence on the surface tension of the liquid. Water has a higher surface tension, and a flow with a higher aqueous component will require higher voltage. The field is often higher than that which will cause corona discharge, and so special arrangements are needed to suppress discharges (arcing) with a water solvent. This is particularly true in negative ion mode, as there is a lower voltage threshold for electric discharge.

Successful formation of the Taylor cone in ES requires a certain ionic strength, with a minimum electrolyte concentration of 10 µM. Total droplet current (TDC) increases rapidly with change in the electrolyte concentration up to 10 µM, but the rate of increase falls off above that concentration. TDC or I can be defined as follows:

I ≅ constant × (γKVfε/ε0)½

(note ≅ means approximately equal to) where K = solution conductivity, Vf = solution flow rate, ε = permittivity of solution, and γ and ε0 have been defined above. The constant is usually 18 for liquids such as water, methanol, acetonitrile and formamide, which have a high dielectric constant (ε/ε0). This current equation and radius and charge equations below are valid when a cone-jet electrospray is attained: this is the cone from the capillary tip becoming a liquid filament (jet) where flow rates are few µl/min and electrolyte concentrations are < 10−3, typical electrospray MS conditions.

Electrospray devices using metal capillaries deliver continuous current, and so an electrochemical oxidation reaction must occur (the negative electrode must be the spectrometer ground wherever positive ions hit). Use of a Zn electrode showed the production of Zn2+ ions at the capillary tip. The [Zn2+] was found to be equal to [Q], which is the concentration of charge in moles charge per liter of charged droplets. [Q] is defined as:

[Q] = I / (FVf)

where F is Faraday's constant and I and Vf have been defined. That this equation applies indicates that the electrospray works as an electrochemical cell. It has been shown that some compounds not ionized normally in solution are ionized by oxidation in positive ion mode, or by reduction in negative ion mode. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are quite susceptible to free radical formation, and one-electron oxidations of PAHs such as perylene ([C20H12]+•) and rubrene ([C42H28]+•) are possible with ES MS. β-Carotenes and other carotenoids are as efficient. Electrochemical oxidation-reduction is unwanted in some cases, such as metal analyte quantitation of Ag+, Cu2+, and Hg2+.

The radius R and charge q of the initial droplets formed at the capillary tip have been deduced:

R ≅ (Vfε / K)1/3
q ≅ 0.7[8π(ε0γR3)½]

where all symbols and variables have been previously defined (≅ is approximately equal to). It is useful to note that smaller droplets (lower radii) can be achieved by higher electrolyte concentrations (higher K). Applying the equation for changing concentrations of NaCl, the following table is produced:

[NaCl] 0.5 mM 5 mM 20 mM
R (µm) 0.96 0.40 0.28
NP 83,000 26,000 13,000

NP is the number of elementary charges, which indicates the charge of the parent droplets.

Evaporation of solvent (from use of hot nitrogen desolvation gas) causes decreased droplet radius. With 100 µs, the radii are close the Rayleigh limit:

q = 8π(ε0γR3)½

This defines the point where Coulombic repulsion overcomes surface tension and droplet fission occurs. Solvents of low volatility and radii > 1 µm show such fission. Budding from the droplet occurs, with offspring radius about 0.1 of the parent radius (RP). Offspring droplets represent 2% of the mass and 15% of the charge of the parent droplet. Several nanometer-sized droplets with only a few elementary charges eventually make the gas phase.

CRM proposes production of gas phase ion in a scheme as that just mentioned until no further evaporation of solvent occurs. In single analyte solutions of species MX, offspring droplets will be composed of mostly M+ and some (M+)x(MX)n where x and n are low, but for the parent droplet, both are high.

IEM proposes that ions directly enter the gas phase after a combination of solvent evaporation and Coulombic-based droplet fission bring the size of charged droplets to a limit radius (about 10-20 nm). Droplet charge required for IEM is lower than that required for Coulombic-based fission. Ion evaporation replaces fission and M+ evaporation continues until the solid residue M+)x(MX)n forms. Ion evaporation rate was based on transition state theory:

kI = kBT e−ΔG‡/RT
h

Here kI is the ion evaporation rate from droplets, kB is Boltzmann's constant, h is Planck's constant, and ΔG‡ is an expression of the free energy of the factors that result in a late transition state (i.e., after the ion has left the droplet). The barrier is represented by attraction of the ion to the counterions in the polarizable droplet and the repulsive forces between ion and charges in droplet, ΔG‡(E). There is also a solvation free energy term, −ΔG°sol:

ΔG‡ = −ΔG°sol + ΔG‡(E)

ΔG‡(E) is a function of E, the electric field perpendicular to the charged drop surface. Because charges are distributed on the surface of a sphere, Coulomb's Law is thus:

E = q = Ne
4πε0R2 4πε0R2

R is the droplet radius, q the charge, and N is the number of elementary charges e. −ΔG°sol is effectively the free energy to desolvate ion (transfer it to gas phase if the droplet were uncharged (neutral). Li+, Na+, K+ and all alkali metals are strongly solvated. −ΔG°sol is lowest and better for IEM thusly when the ion takes (several) solvent molecules with it.

Rate constants kI for droplet radii R smaller than 10-20 nm were ≥ 106 s−1, meaning that ion evaporation is in the microsecond scale. Moreover charge qI required for ion evaporation is lower than Coulombic fission, meaning charge will be kept low and fission not taking place.

Experiments to validate models made use of NaCl as the MX and made reasonable assumptions about the distribution of gas phase ions and those trapped in solid residues. The distribution of spectra and ion counts matched IEM models and agreement was worse for CRM. Uncertainties that remained did not allow the IEM model to be proved unequivocally however.

In other experiments, there was a focus on the size and charges of solid residues formed after evaporation of solvent. These are fair approximations of the evolving charged droplet. Again the results were in agreement with IEM. Very small initial droplets were produced by low flow rate, high conductivity electrospray. The radius of these droplets falls close to the ion emission radius for IEM before Rayleigh disintegration occurs. Radius and charge could be determined from the mobility and mass of charged residues, using a hypersonic impactor apparatus measuring mass, and assuming density was same as solid salt.

Sensitivity. Different analytes will have different thresholds of detection, and this will be complicated by the presence of other ions not of interest (electrolytes, contaminants, interfering substances). Consider a two-component solution with analyte AX and electrolyte EX (for simplicity, in positive ion mode) and the dissociation is A+ and E+ in solution (there is no induced ionization electrochemically or otherwise). The counterion X− in AX and EX may not be the same. The ion current produced by A+ in the two-component system is:

IA+ = pf kACA I
kACA + kECE

For a three-component system of AX, BX, and EX:

IA+ = pf kACA I
kACA + kBCB + kECE

IA is the ion current registered by the MS, and CA, CB, CE are the concentrations in the electrosprayed solution. I is the total electrospray capillary current. p is the sampling efficiency of the ES MS, or ions detected relative to total ion in gas phase (a number that reaches 0.5, and rarely 0.8), and f is fraction of charge converted to gas phase ions, usually much smaller than p and dependent on sampling arrangements used. kA refers to the efficiency of species A to become a gas phase ion. ΔI/ΔC is higher when CE is < 10 µM, and much lower when CE is > 10 µM (a point stated earlier).

The relative sensitivities of any two analytes A and B can determined by applying the three component equation to derive:

IA = kACA
IB kBCB

It is convenient to set CA = CB for the determination of kA/kB. These concentrations are increased while CE is kept constant and IA and IB determined using the ES MS. Good fits were obtained generally, with exacts fits when CA and CB were high (> 10 µM). Only approximate fits were obtained with CA, CB < 10 µM. Plots show that below 10 µM where CA = CB, the ratio decreases to the limit kA/kB = 1. When CA and CB are both << 10 µM, the current I and the droplet charge Q are carried by the electrolyte E with its higher concentration. At low concentrations of A+ and B+, ions are quickly depleted from the droplet with high kA and kB, leading to an apparent kA/kB = 1. The ion signal intensities IA and IB depend only on the amount of A and B available, i.e. they are mass-dependent. and this provides maximum sensitivity.

The convention of expressing current I as a concentration of charge [Q] represents an advance in ES MS such that currents are really fractions of charges on droplets due to an ion species. Analyte AX is distributes within the interior with concentration [A+]i[X−]i and surface concentration of [A+]s. Equilibrium KA = [A+]s/[A+]i. Charge and mass balance equations become [Q] = [A+] + [B+] + ... and CA = [A+]i + [A+]s, respectively. Solutions for equations become apparent. Certain assumptions are made, such that [A+]s, [B+]s, etc. transfer to the gas phase proportional to the constant product pf.

A number of analytes were examined in methanol to determine the kA/kB working at high concentrations CA, CB. Singly charged inorganic ions Na+, K+, Rb+, Cs+, and NH4+ had nearly the same coefficients. However coefficients of analytes expected to concentrate mostly on the surface (i.e. surface active agents) have higher coefficients. Values for k are ≅ 1 for Na+, K+, Rb+, NH4+ and Cs+, Et4N+ = 3, Pr4N+ = 5, Bu4N+ = 9, Pen4N+ = 16, and heptNH3+ = 8. If KSA represents surface activity and is represents an equilibrium ratio of surface to bulk concentrations of A+X−, and kIA is a rate constant for ion evaporation, then the equation

kA = KSAkIA
kB KSBkIB

is an expression of the relative transition to the gas phase of two different species A and B in IEM. If instead CRM holds, then

kA = KSA
kB KSB

The rate constants kIA, kIB depend on the solvation free energies ΔG°sol for A+ and B+. Low −ΔG°sol mean high evaporation constants, and −ΔG°sol decreases when surface activity increases. If IEM is true, surface active ions have high kA because KSA is high (the surface concentration in the numerator is great) and kIA is high.

Berndt P, Hobohm U, Langen H (1999) Electrophoresis 20, 3521-3526.

Reliable Automatic Protein Identification from Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Mass Spectrometric Peptide Fingerprints

Correct identification of MS data depends on several factors. Size of database is a factor: SWISS-PROT has > 70,000 protein and the likelihood of false positive is greater with that number. Protein size is important since smaller proteins are less likely to generate more peptides and the increase in peptide count creates opportunities for mismatch. Mass measure to a precision of 0.05% (0.05 in 100 or 5 in 10000 or 500 ppm) or 0.0075% (or 0.0075 in 100 or 75 in 1000000 or 75 ppm) is critical.

The distribution of masses of queried peptides is important. Most fragments have masses in lower range (close to 800 Da) and few have higher mass at 4000 Da. Peptide number in matching is critical, with a protein matching more peptides giving a higher confidence result.

Suppose P(m, Δ) is the estimated probability for choosing a mass in the range [m − Δ m + Δ], perhaps computed as number of peptides in the mass range as a proportion of all peptides (N[m − Δ m + Δ]/ Npept). The database is queried with k masses. The probability of finding one protein with any masses in the k mass range = ∑ki=0 Pi(m,Δ). The probability of finding a single combination of two masses in k masses is the sum of the products of the probabilities:

∑ki=0 ∑kj=i PiPj.

So to find n masses out of k masses is the sum of all the products of the probability for all n-ary mass combinations: T1 = ∑PiPj...Pn.

For protein with p peptides, one can select T2 = p + n + 1Cn combination of peptides for any m < p.

So the probability of finding a single protein with a peptide list of p peptides from database of Nprot protein with only p-membered lists is T1T2. And finally the probability of finding the protein P in the database is sum of all probability for all single proteins: P = NprotT1T2.

Pfeifer T, Rücknagel P, Kuellertz G, Schierhorn A (1999) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 13, 362-369.

A Strategy for Rapid and Efficient Sequencing of Lys-C Peptides by Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry Post-Source Decay

ABSTRACT. A modification procedure for Lys-C peptides is described which simplifies the correct assignment of the amino acid sequence. Release of the C-terminal lysine from Lys-C peptides by carboxypeptidase B and subsequent N-terminal acetylation of the resulting peptides leads to predictable shifts of the C- and Nterminal fragment ions in Matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionisation time-of-flight post-source decay mass spectra and facilitates the correct assignment of mostly complete amino acid sequences for oligopeptides. The derived sequences of peptides from unknown proteins were used to search in databases for homologous protein sequences. Our method was applied to an unknown protein isolated from eggs of Drosophila melanogaster, resulting in the identification of a peptidyl prolyl cis-trans-isomerase.

Zissis KD, Brereton RG, Dunkerley S (1999) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 13, 1755-1761.

Principal Components Scores and Loading Plots for Visualization of the Electrospray Ionization Liquid Chromatography Mass Spectra of a Mixture of Chlorophyll Degradation Products at Different Cone Voltages

PCA is used in LC-MS and GC-MS for classifying/grouping peaks and compounds in complex chromatographic mixture. When MS/MS is not available, PCA can be used to assign ions belonging to resolved compounds with identical masses. Spinach leaf Chl a is extracted by a cited method, and Chl a standard dissolved in MeOH is degraded by 4000 lux light in 40 deg water bath with oxygen present for 60 min. Aliquot is dried down and resuspended in acetone and then injected on LC-MS. LC-MS C18 4.6 × 250 mm (5 µm) with gradient elution involving acetone, MeOH, and water, with a 20 ul full loop. ESI+ was done with MS m/z 500-1000 with 1.25 s scan. Cone V varied from 60, 65, and 70 V. A splitter was used to set LC flow @ 0.5 ml/min. Chlorophyll has many allomers which typically varies by the presence certain groups on C13 of the closed ring formed by one of the 4 rings in the porphyrin.

Mass spectral data are collected by MassLynx and the raw data decoded using a C++ program. A 5.5 min in chromatogram is scanned containing peak(s) of interest, with background subtraction. Mass spectral processing finds 70 m/z peaks attaining threshold, determined by a peak variance-to-mean ratio, with a threshold of 1 million ion counts. Data is then scaled by normalizing all selected masses to be equal in intensity despite the relative intensities in the raw data. After normalization, a standardization was done by subtracting the mean and dividing by standard deviation. This puts each of the selected m/z peaks (70) on same scale, and will give weight to low abundance ions (fragments?). For PCA, matrix X is the 70 selected masses and 360 time points (360 seconds), described by the equation X = T.P + E, where T is the scores matrix corresponding to elution profiles, P is loadings matrix corresponding to selected masses, and E is error term. Three components are determined. 3-D projections are generated by projecting Scores or Loadings values on to 2 dimensions using rotations in XY, XZ, and YZ planes.

Cone voltage increases from 60→70 V result in more ions in the spectrum (regarded as noise). In the chromatogram, 5 peaks are seen, very smooth at 60 V, very unsmooth at 70 V. Peak 4 is Chl a, and peak 5 is an isobaric epimer (mass 892). Peaks 1-3 are a hydroxy allomer, a methoxylacetone variant, and a ring E-opened variant (see previous papers for identification).

3-D plots of the Scores were generated on processed and scaled data. The locations of the five peaks are indicated on the plots. The 70 V 3-D plot clearly shows the effects of the noise, but the plot also shows a greater spatial separation of the 5 peaks, even for components have identical mass (such as peaks 4 and 5). At 60 V, peaks 2 and 3 are clustered in one group, peaks 4 and 5 in another. This separation increases with cone V. This is because of more information resulting from fragmentation of ions occurring at the higher voltage.

3-D plots of the Loadings show the 70 peaks, which are the protonated main mass, allomeric variants, and associated K and Na adducts. Three main clusters are found. One cluster contains m/z 962 and 978, two allomers. From the 60 to 70 V analyses, there is a better discrimination in ion clusters, in which some ions are regrouped (for example, m/z 595-597 to chlorophyll IV, while ions between m/z 600-603 and the ion at m/z 629 segregate to chlorophyll III. Ions at m/z 962 lie at the center, indicating the parent nature of this group.

Typical data analysis would involve looking at mass spectra for all four chlorophylls I-IV at the 3 different cone voltages in a conventional approach. The spectra show increased relative intensity for ions with a lower m/z. However, all these peaks may represent more than one compound in a co-eluting in the chromatogram. Chromatographic reproducibility and resolution is complicated by plumbing systems in which turbulent flow is more likely in capillary systems than in those of larger diameter. MS detects these mixing phenomena. PCA to produce the loadings plot visually clarifies the differences and confusion that might be caused by misassigments in the spectrum.

Knochenmuss R, Stortelder A, Breuker K, Zenobi R (2000) J. Mass Spectrom. 35, 1237-1245.

Secondary Ion-Molecule Reactions in Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization

ABSTRACT. Ion-molecule charge- and proton-transfer reactions in the desorption plume are considered for the case of matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI) with ultraviolet laser excitation, and it is proposed that they are major determinants of the observed mass spectrum. Specific MALDI phenomena which are discussed include the dominance of singly charged ions and analytematrix or analyteanalyte signal suppression. Should any be formed, highly charged products can be reduced by reaction with neutral matrix, yet singly charged ions cannot generally be neutralized in the same manner. Ion suppression effects can also be explained by similar reactions, which in some cases involve interconversion of dissimilar ion types. The plume is proposed often to be more under thermodynamic rather than kinetic control owing to these secondary reactions. UV/MALDI mass spectra should therefore be largely predictable, given sufficient thermodynamic information, and appropriate experimental conditions of sufficient analyte and plume density.

Görg A, Obermaier C, Boguth G, Harder A, Scheibe B, Wildgruber R, Weiss W (2000) Electrophoresis 21, 1037-1053.

The Current State of Two-Dimensional Electrophoresis with Immobilized pH Gradients

REVIEW. Sample preparation varies depending on species and tissue. The various techniques available include grinding in liquid nitrogen-cooled mortar, sonication, shearing-based methods, or homogenization. Solubilization can be in a lysis buffer containing 9 M urea, 1% DTT, 2-4% CHAPS, 2% 3-10 ampholytes, and 10 mM Pefabloc inhibitors, or in 2 M thiourea, 7 M urea, with CHAPS, ampholytes, DTT, and Pefabloc the same. Alternatively a hot SDS sample buffer (1% SDS in 0.1 M TrisHCl pH 7.0) might be used, and then diluted with 3-fold or more of the lysis buffer or thiourea lysis buffer. Mouse liver was ground in liq. N2-cooled mortar and the powder suspended in 20% TCA in acetone (−18°) containing 0.2% DTT and kept overnight at −18°. The pellet from centrifugation is resuspended in acetone with 0.2% DTT, and sample spun again. The pellet is dried under vacuum and solubilized in a lysis buffer. This is then centrifuged 40,000 g 60 min at 15° and can be stored at −80°. IEF is done on 3 mm strips either ready-made or prepared. Sample loading is by cup or in-gel rehydration.

IPG gel casting is with 4% polyacrylamide (3% C) in 0.5 mm thick sheets and lengths of 4, 11, 18, and 24 cm on GelBond PAGfilm. For the pH 9-12 and pH 10-12 range, acrylamide is substituted with DMAA with monomer increased to 6% T. Casting is with two glass plates with one sheeted with GelBond PAGfilm and the other with a 0.5 mm thick U-frame; the U-frame plate is treated with Repel Silane to prevent gel sticking to the plate. Immobiline acidic and basic starter solutions are used to prepare a gradient, and a gradient mixer is used to load monomer from the top. Since polymerization is pH-dependent, the starter solutions are adjusted to pH 7 (NaOH to the acidic, and acetic acid to the basic); the acid solution at a heavier density is placed in the mixing chamber, while basic solution (at a lighter density) is placed into the reservoir. The mold for the cast should be pre-cooled in the refrigerator and the gradient poured, then the mold is left 15 min at room temp to permit leveling of density gradient prior to polymerization, where mold is placed in 50° oven for 60 min. The IPG gel is removed from the mold was washed extensively (6 × 10 min each) in deionized water, then kept 30 min in 2% glycerol, and then dried at room temp in dust-free environment. Cover with plastic film and stored at −20°. Just before use, the IPG gel is cut into 3 mm strips with a paper cutter.

Rehydration of strips is done by mixing total cell/tissue lysates between 0.5-5 mg protein into 0.5 ml of 8 M urea (or 6 M urea + 2 M thiourea), 0.5-4% CHAPS, 0.4% DTT, and 0.5% 3-10 ampholytes.

After rehydration, strips might be dipped 1 second in distilled water and blotted between filter paper to remove excess swelling solution. This avoids urea crystallization on the gel surface, causing prolonged IEF and empty vertical lanes on the 2-D gel.

SDS-PAGE is described in a horizontal and vertical format, without the use of a stacking gel for the vertical format.

After the bromophenol blue dye is allowed to migrate out from the SDS gel, the gel is fixed in 40% ethanol with 10% acetic acid for at least 1 hour but usually overnight. Gels for analytical purposes are stained by silver whereas preparative gels are stained with CBB G-250 (0.1% in the ethanol/acetic acid mix for 1-3 h. If SYPRO Ruby staining is used fix is in 10% MeOH with 7% acetic acid for 30 min prior to staining.

O'Farrell proposed the first IEF sample buffer of 9 M urea, 4% NP-40, and 50-100 mM DTT, which has been modified to produce solubilizaition of different classes of proteins. Modifications include use of 2-4% CHAPS, 1% DTT, and 2% ampholytes, and thiourea in a reduced urea solution. In addition TCA precipitation before solubilization is possible. In some cases, SDS sample buffer gets at a wide variety of tough proteins.

In making an IPG gel, the thickness and width of the strip should be kept to a minimum since electroendosmotic effects from immobilized buffer groups appear, causing gel gluing and hindrance of protein transfer from 1st to 2nd dimension. Adding urea and glycerol are the only remedy for this.

As for IEF sample loading, when using cup loading, apply at either the anode or cathode, although anode end application appears to give better results (some exceptions, such as human cardiac proteins). When using basic end pH gradients (6-10, 7-10, 6-12) prefer the anodic end.

For analytical 2DGE using silver staining, 50-100 µg loads are best for 18 cm long strips that are 3-6 pH units wide. Either cup-loading or simple rehydration works, although for preparative work, prefer gel rehydration. Up to 1 mg protein in a 100 µl volume may be better for preparative work. Up to 10 mg protein might be loaded for even 1 pH unit narrow-range strips. Excessive protein loading causes problems in the 2nd dimension more than the 1st, but protein concentration should not exceed 10 mg/ml.

Note that when the sample has excessive salt, it is best to reduce the voltage to 50-100 V even for several hours before ramping up the voltage. When applying large sample volumes, voltage should be limited to 50 V overnight for improved sample entry.

The total number of volt-hours to do IEF depends on many factors: sample load, pH range interval, strip length. For pH 4-7, 4-9, and 3-10 strips used mostly for analytical purposes (50-100 µg) or micropreparative (up to 1 mg), the final focusing voltage is much lower (to 3500 V) and the times are fairly long the narrower the pH range (20-24 h for 1-1.5 pH units strips, 12 hours for 3 pH wide strips, 10 h for 4 pH wide strips, 8 h for 5-6 pH unit wide strips, 6 h for 7, 8, and 9 pH unit wide strips usually). If the strip is longer, the time is also increased (as for 24 cm strips). If there are greater protein loading, the time added may be 50% of that above for analytical separations.

Electrode wicks may need to be replaced for very long runs, and this is particularly true when the sample contains high amounts of salt.

When running narrow or medium-range pH strips in the alkaline range (typically for ribosomal and nuclear proteins), the acrylamide monomer should be DMAA and isopropanol may need to be added to the rehydration solution to avoid severe streaking.

Schilling B, Wang W, McMurray JS, Medzihradszky KF (1999) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 13, 2174-2179.

Fragmentation and Sequencing of Cyclic Peptides by Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Post-Source Decay Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. A series of synthetic cyclic decapeptides and other smaller cyclic peptides were analyzed using matrixassisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectrometry. The investigated compounds were cyclized in a head-to-tail manner and contained non-proteinaceous amino acids, such as Dphenylalanine, D,L-4-carboxyphenylalanine, e-aminocaproic acid, and g-aminobutyric acid, and were synthesized in a program to develop inhibitors of pp60c-src (Src), a tyrosine kinase that is involved in signal transduction and growth regulation. Post-source decay (PSD) spectra of the cyclic peptides featured abundant sequence ions. Two preferential ring opening reactions were detected resulting in linear fragment ions with an N-terminus of proline and a C-terminus of glutamic acid, respectively. MALDI-PSD spectra even permitted de novo sequencing of some cyclic peptides. Systematic studies on cyclic peptides using this method of fragmentation have not been reported to date. This work presents an easy mass spectrometric method, MALDI-PSD, for the characterization and identification of cyclic peptides.

Corthals GL, Wasinger VC, Hochstrasser DF, Sanchez J-C (2000) Electrophoresis 21, 1104-1115.

The Dynamic Range of Protein Expression: The Challenge for Proteomic Research

REVIEW. Genomic information provides good foundation for cross correlation between transcriptome and proteome-generated data. A powerful set of tools to study global and quantitative genome expression include differential display-PCR, cDNA microarrays, and serial analysis of gene expression (SAGE). The proteome itself is a dynamic, spatially and temporally expressed (nuclear proteins control transcription, and mitochondiral proteins regulate bioenergetics). Proteins are expressed in cluster or modules, usually because they have functional relatedness such as signal transduction. Proteins are also modified in dynamic (phosphorylation) and static (disulfide links) ways.

Proteomics methods are two-phased. The first phase is 2-DE separations with an intermediate analytical step to identify proteins of interest. The second phase is analytical at the MS. Raymond and Weintraub (1959) and Ornstein & Davis (1962) showed that polyacrylamide did better than starch. Margolis and Kenrick demonstrated a 2-D separation with a first dimension disc and then 2nd dimension gradient gel. O'Farrell and Klose independently demonstrated IEF combined with SDS-PAGE gave excellent multidimensional separations.

There was not much use for 2D gels as a useful tool until the sensitivity of instruments improved, making 2D gels a good semipreparative method. Edman sequencing could be done on high picomole amounts (this required a Western blotting first however. Other improvements include in-gel rehydration into the IPG strips, which avoided streaking caused by poorly soluble proteins.

Wide-range (> 3 pH units per 20 cm) IPGs present the problem of spot comigration (protein overcrowding when large loads are done). Multiple overlapping medium-range (1-3 pH units per 20 cm) IPGs have been considered as an answer to avoiding overcrowding. Unfortunately the number of proteins has not increased compared to wide range. Narrow-range (< 1 pH unit in a 20 cm distance) have been looked at. Tonella et al. have found thousands of proteins within a pH 5.1-5.6 narrow-range IPG in E. coli, based on a genomic analysis of 804 ORFs with calculated pI 5.09-5.59, predicted to produce 1029 polypeptides (based on a 1.28 peptides per ORF determination). 3.2 mg protein from lysate was placed and Ag-stained to show 949 spots. With 7% being fragments, that meant 878 proteins, or about 85% of predicted for the range. That is excellent coverage.

The yeast genome has 6139 ORFs. IPGs (25 cm) were poured ranging from pH 4.5-5.5 (1 cm = 0.04 pH units). These were cut to size (~18 cm) to feature a range of 4.8-5.5. Predicted ORFs with pI values in that range was 852; with 200 post-translational modifications possible for this subset, more spots are possible. 500 µg total yeast lysate was loaded on to the narrow-range IPG and visualized with Ag. The Melanie Bio-Rad package found 2700 spots (!) in which 852 were expected.

50 of the most intensely Ag-stained spots from a 4 × 4 cm section were selected and 39 identified as unique. 58 ORFs were predicted for the range, and 14 of the 39 predicted to fall within the pI range. Such failure to predict could be due to unanticipated posttranslational modifications. Additional gel loading does not help to illuminate proteins present in smaller amounts, as comigration and spot fusion occurs. In this case prefractionation or other purification might make additional loading possible.

Developments that advanced the used of ESI and MALDI-MS include use of microscale capillary RP-HPLC coupled to ESI; development of algorithms that correlated MS and MS/MS data to databases; better software and interfaces to instrument control; use of post-source decay (PSD) in MALDI-ToF permitting sequencing; cleanup of small 1-5 µl samples for ESI and MALDI; ability to use low ESI flow rates (10-25 nl/min) or nanoelectrospray; liquid extraction of peptides from in-gel proteolytic digestion; and simultaneous digestion and electrotransfer to PVDF for protein scanning.

For a comprehensive proteome analysis, at least 1 billion cells are necessary. This assumes 100% protein recovery and that 1000 copies of a protein are present per cell to produce 1.6 pmol protein. This is 4, 8, and 16 ng of 25, 50, and 100 kDa proteins, resp. Only a µLC-MS/MS or MALDI-ToF MS can analysis this low. If only 106 cells are present, only the most highly abundants are visualizable and amenable to MS. Staining is important too. The limits of Coomassie are at 1 µg, while for silver are 1 ng; radionuclides can visualize only smaller proteins present (for example at only 10 copies per cell with 1 billion cells, radioisotopes are necessary).

[The paper includes a most interesting Table 1 that shows the limits of detection and analysis and the amount of cells that must be used for predicted copies of proteins.]

2-DE prefractionantion is best done in solution to minimize loss of protein and minimize surface interaction. Liquid phase IEF is efficient and when done with carrier ampholytes and compatible compounds, transfer to IPGs is possible. Recycling IEF is where sample is re-introduced into a focusing cell. Screen elements prevent convective mixing. The Bio-Rad Rotofor and Dr. Weber Octopus can be used to prefractionate.

The multicompartment electrolyser is a form of IEF and descends from Bier's RIEF, and IEF in gel-layer approach. Here the protein is kept apart from the IPG matrix allowed to flow freely. Isoelectric membranes instead compartmentalize or stabilize a pI region. The membranes have IPG technology and proteins flow through. The Hoefer IsoPrime system works using this technology. The Gradipore Gradiflow system is a multifunctional electrokinetic membrane apparatus that processes and purifies in a number of ways: pI, mobility, size, and affinity. A thin polyacrylamide membrane on a support separates two fractions. It can prefractionate on a relatively large (3 ml to hundreds of mL).

Three different chromatographic techniques can be used to prepurify proteins: elution, frontal, and displacement. Step-gradient elution techniques are the most common. These include IEC, HIC, RP, and affinity. Size-exclusion has been replaced by membrane ultrafiltration.

Gygi SP, Corthals GL, Zhang Y, Rochon Y, Aebersold R (2000) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 97, 9390-9395.

Evaluation of Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis-Based Proteome Analysis Technology

A typical 2D gel with IEF in the pH 3-10 range and 50 µg load produced 1000 Ag-stained proteins. If the pH range is narrowed from 7 to 1 pH unit over a 20 cm rang and load increased to 500 µ, more than 1500 Ag-stained spots are seen. If seven 2D gels are run each with a 1 pH range, the expectation is that 10,000 proteins from a cell lysate can be seen by extrapolation. This surpasses the 6139 proteins predicted from the genome. An arbitrary 4 cm2 region was taken from the gel and 50 spots in the area identified by MS. MS/MS spectra were searched using SEQUEST against the yeast database.

Codon bias represents the preference of one codon among many in specifying an amino acid. The more highly expressed proteins have large codon biases (>0.2). Plots of the number of genes against the codon bias were made for the entire yeast genome, the genes predicted in the area that was cutout, those genes actually identified, and those both predicted and identified. For the entire genome, the largest number of genes have a bias values of 0.0 and 0.1. For the cutout area 58 genes are predicted and have a similar distribution.
