The codon bias distribution (CBD) was entirely different for the genes identified however, shifted well above 0.1 (no proteins had a bias value < 0.1, although more than half of genes fall into this range). The CBD of genes predicted and found (14 of the 58) also showed a similar distribution. Proteins of lesser abundance were not detected and there was a larger number of proteins migrating to the selected region than were predicted.

While the products of a single gene can be separated on a gel, the products of different genes can be found to comigrate to the same spot. This difference and identity in migration can complicated the comparative quantitative pattern in 2D gel databases.

In order to detect low abundance proteins (those with <0.1 codon bias values), 50 mg of protein was loaded on to 10% SDS-PAGE 15 × 12 × 1.5 cm gel run at 40 mA constant and stained with colloidal Coomassie Blue. A 3 × 100 mm in the 68-85 kDa range was excised, the strip diced into 1 mm3 pieces and in-gel trypsin digestion done. Extracted peptides were lyophilized and resuspended in 5 mM potassium phosphate/25% MeCN pH 3.0, loaded on to polysulfoethyl A (2.1 × 250 mm) and eluted with buffer containing 0.25 M KCl over a 60 min gradient at 0.2 ml/min. Off the SCX column, selected fractions were run on RP-microcapillary LC-MS/MS. 193 proteins were detected in the 68-85 kDa range (more than 1/3 of proteins predicted in this range). The CBD was of this set was similar (not identical) to the CBD for the entire genome, although many more proteins with bias value < 0.1 were detected this time. Low abundance protein range from 10-103 copies per cell, whereas high abundance are 104-106 copies per cell. With standard 2DE gels with a 40 µg load of whole lysate, the average abundance is 51,200 copies per cell and no proteins with < 1000 copies/cell. At 500 µg, proteins at 1000 copies/cell can be seen by Ag staining, but less than that are not detected. Pre-fractionation in milligram amounts is required to enrich loads for 2DE is essential; this compromises any ability to quantify amounts accurately however.

Santoni V, Molloy M, Rabilloud T (2000) Electrophoresis 21, 1054-1070.

Membrane Proteins and Proteomics: Un Amour Impossible?

REVIEW. Membrane proteins serve functions in signal transduction, cell adhesion, metabolite and ion transport, endocytosis, etc. From the sequencing of several genomes it is estimated that transmembrane proteins represent 30% of the total proteins. Proteins can be associated with a membrane, but there is a great deal of argument about the word associated. Typically intrinsic or integral membrane proteins are those that span the lipid bilayer a number of times; this association is with doubt. The polypeptide chain must organize into an α-helix or β-sheet in order to span the membrane.

α-helical proteins typically have long sequences of mostly nonpolar amino acids, the 15-25 required to span the bilayer. Their hydropathy values are quite positive (making them hydrophobic). In E. coli the count of α-helical transmembrane segments ranges from 3 for NADH dehydrogenase component NuoA to up to 15 for cytochrome o ubiquinol oxidase subunit-1, CyoB. 380 open reading frames encode these types of proteins and the hydropathy is skewed toward hydrophobicity.

Gram-negative bacteria possess a bilayer membrane external to the cytoplasmic membrane. This membrane is rich in integral proteins, but these are not α-helical but are usually β-sheet. The tertiary structure is usually a β-barrel, forming a pore that allows certain molecules past the outer membrane. These transmembrane domains form by alternating polar and nonpolar amino acids. Their hydropathy profiles show much lower hydrophobicity.

Proteins also become associated with membranes through post-translational modifications that include myristylation or polyisoprenylation. The latter modification occurs for G proteins. Other associations are achieved with glycolipid anchors such as glycosylphosphatidyl inositol (eukaryotes) or N-acyl diglyceride to an N-terminal cysteine (typical for bacterial lipoproteins). Acylation can also occur to simple fatty acid chains a part of the membrane.

With integral membrane proteins, there is no option to be associated or not associated. These are embedded and removal from the membrane ends the function, because denaturation is usually required. Other associations are provided by these post-translational modifications that cause partitioning between membrane and membrane-free phase. Yet another is caused by protein-protein interaction: for instance, ubiquinol-cytochrome c oxidoreductase core proteins 1 and 2 do not interact with the mitochondrial inner membrane, but do with the proteins that are embedded (cytochrome b).

In order to separate membrane proteins from soluble proteins, techniques such as salt washing and differential centrifugation are used. Use of chaotropic salts (such as KBr) strip proteins clinging to membranes away from them if they are not truly embedded. Use of sodium carbonate makes of pH in order to achieve the removal.

Bordier made use of two-phase detergents to achieve membrane protein purifications. Oligooxyethylene detergents (Tritons) show two transition temperatures in aqueous solution: one is a lower transition temperature in which they separate into a pure phase out of water, and an upper transition temperature in which a phase separation occurs between a detergent-rich and -poor phase, and compositions are constant at a given temperature. Triton X-114 has an upper transition of 20° (which is 60° for Triton X-100). If the ionic strength is raised, the transition temperature is lowered the higher salt concentration promotes the detergent transition. For example, in 3 M NaCl, Triton X-100 critical temperature goes from 60° to 20°. The problem is that at higher ionic strength, proteins are driven into the detergent phase; 50% of total cell proteins move into the detergent phase at 1.2 M ammonium sulfate.

Animal cells/tissues. When 2DE was first used, there was difficulty in preparing membrane proteins. When trying to solubilize erythrocyte membranes, Band III is not amenable to classical urea-nonionic detergents. In a subsequent paper integral membranes were separated by 2DE. Histocompatibility antigens prepared from radiolabeled cultured cells were immunopptd and the ppt. analyzed by 2DE, with spots at the expected pI and Mr. Postion of the protein was important in establishing that the separated proteins are proteins co-immunoprecipitated with the true antigen.

In some cases in order to characterize membrane proteins on 2DE partial purification may be necessary. A glucose transporter could be separated on 2DE in purified but not total cell extracts. The fact that hydrophobic proteins are poorly represented in the 2DE protein sets could be due to their belonging to low abundance proteins, but it could also be due to poor extraction using classical urea-detergent measures.

Yeast/Plant Cells/Tissues.

Merchant M, Weinberger SR (2000) Electrophoresis 21, 1164-1167.

Recent Advancements in Surface-Enhanced Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. The overall history and recent advances in surface enhanced laser desorption/ionization-time of flight-mass spectrometry (SELDI-TOF-MS) technology is reviewed herein. Fundamentals of SELDI-TOF analysis are presented while drawing comparisons with other laser-based mass spectrometry techniques. The application of SELDI-TOF-MS to functional genomics and biomarker discovery is discussed and exemplified by elucidating a biomarker candidate for prostatic carcinoma. Finally, a short discussion regarding future SELDI requirements and developments is supplied.

Kinumi T, Niwa H, Matsumoto H (2000) Anal. Biochem. 277, 177-186.

Phosphopeptide Sequencing by In-Source Decay Spectrum in Delayed Extraction Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. Protein phosphorylation underlies numerous cellular signaling processes. Since a reliable prediction of phosphorylation site(s) based on a consensus amino acid sequence is rather difficult to date, determination of phosphorylation site(s) in phosphoproteins is a crucial step toward the understanding of their function at the molecular level. A conventional protocol for the determination of phosphorylation sites utilizes radioactive labeling of a phosphoprotein by 32P and purification of digested peptides carrying radioactivity, followed by Edman degradation. This method is not only tedious, but also indirect because the evidence will be based on disappearance of a phenylthiohydantoin signal from the degradation cycle where the 32P radioactivity is eluted. Several methodologies have been developed to determine the phosphorylation sites directly by using mass spectrometry. These include collision-induced dissociation (CID) and post-source decay (PSD), both of which tend to produce fragment ions less efficiently as the number of residues exceeds 20. Moreover, in both decay processes, there is a tendency for the phosphate group to be removed during the breakdown of the main peptide chain. We report a method that allows direct observation of phosphorylated peptide fragments of phosphopeptides exceeding 20 residues by using an in-source decay fragmentation by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry, yielding results which are difficult or impossible to obtain by existing methods using CID or PSD.

Wittmack K, Szymczak W, Hoheisel G, Tuszynski W (2000) J. Am Soc. Mass Spectrom. 11, 553-563.

Time-of-Flight Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry of Matrix-Diluted Oligo- and Polypeptides Bombarded with Slow and Fast Projectiles: Positive and Negative Matrix and Analyte Ion Yields, Background Signals, and Sample Aging

ABSTRACT. Human angiotensin II, chain B of bovine insulin, and porcine insulin were determined by time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry under impact of ;25 keV Xe1 and SF5 1 ion beams and ;100 MeV 252Cf fission fragments. Matrix-embedded samples, dissolved in a large surplus of a-cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid, were prepared by nebulizer spray deposition, neat samples by the droplet technique. It is shown that the status of the sample can be assessed by evaluating the matrix-specific features of the mass spectra. The beneficial effect of matrix isolation was small for angiotensin but large for the insulin samples, which did not show parent peaks from neat material. Negative ion yields under SF5 1 impact were up to a factor of 50 higher than with Xe1. For positive secondary ions, the enhancement was much smaller. The mass spectra produced by slow ion beams or fast fission fragments were qualitatively similar. Quantitative differences include the following: with fast projectiles the yields were about 1030 times higher than with slow ions, but similar for negative ion emission under SF5 1 bombardment; the analyte-to-matrix yield ratios were higher with slow ions and up to 250 times higher than the molar analyte concentration; for analyte ions the peak-to-background ratios were higher using slow projectiles; the fraction of carbon-rich collisionally formed molecular ions was much higher with fast projectiles. Sample aging in vacuum for up to five weeks strongly reduced the yield of protonated analyte molecules ejected by slow ion impact, but not of deprotonated species. Hence protonation seems to correlate with sample wetness or the presence of volatile proton-donating additives.

Gevaert K, Vandekerckhove J (2000) Electrophoresis 21, 1145-1154.

Protein Identification Methods in Proteomics

ABSTRACT. REVIEW. A combination of high-resolution two-dimensional (2-D) polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, highly sensitive biological mass spectrometry, and the rapidly growing protein and DNA databases has paved the way for high-throughput proteomics. This review concentrates on protein identification. We first discuss the use of protein electroblotting and Edman sequencing as tools for de novo sequencing and protein identification. In the second part, we highlight matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry (MALDI-MS) as one of the main contemporary analytical methods for linking gel-separated proteins to entries in sequence databases. In this context we describe the two main MALDI-MS-based identification methods: (i) peptide mass fingerprinting, and (ii) post-source decay (PSD) analysis. In the last part, we briefly emphasize the importance of sample preparation for obtaining highly sensitive and high-quality MALDI-MS spectra.

Breen EJ, Hopwood FG, Williams KL, Wilkins MR (2000) Electrophoresis 21, 2243-2251.

Automatic Poisson Peak Harvesting for High Throughput Protein Identifcation

ABSTRACT. High throughput identification of proteins by peptide mass fingerprinting requires an efficient means of picking peaks from mass spectra. Here, we report the development of a peak harvester to automatically pick monoisotopic peaks from spectra generated on matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionisation time of flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectrometers. The peak harvester uses advanced mathematical morphology and watershed algorithms to first process spectra to stick representations. Subsequently, Poisson modelling is applied to determine which peak in an isotopically resolved group represents the monoisotopic mass of a peptide. We illustrate the features of the peak harvester with mass spectra of standard peptides, digests of gel-separated bovine serum albumin, and with Escherictia coli proteins prepared by two-dimensional polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. In all cases, the peak harvester proved effective in its ability to pick similar monoisotopic peaks as an experienced human operator, and also proved effective in the identification of monoisotopic masses in cases where isotopic distributions of peptides were overlapping. The peak harvester can be operated in an interactive mode, or can be completely automated and linked through to peptide mass fingerprinting protein identification tools to achieve high throughput automated protein identification.

Keough T, Lacey MP, Fieno AM, Grant RA, Sun Y, Bauer MD, Begley KB (2000) Electrophoresis 21, 2252-2265.

Tandem Mass Spectrometry Methods for Definitive Protein Identification in Proteomics Research

ABSTRACT. Optimized procedures have been developed for the addition of sulfonic acid groups to the N-termini of low-level peptides. These procedures have been applied to peptides produced by tryptic digestion of proteins that have been separated by two-dimensional (2-D) gel electrophoresis. The derivatized peptides were sequenced using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI) post-source decay (PSD) and electrospray ionization-tandem mass spectrometry methods. Reliable PSD sequencing results have been obtained starting with sub-picomole quantities of protein. We estimate that the current PSD sequencing limit is about 300 fmol of protein in the gel. The PSD mass spectra of the derivatized peptides usually allow much more specific protein sequence database searches than those obtained without derivatization. We also report initial automated electrospray ionization-tandem mass spectrometry sequencing of these novel peptide derivatives. Both types of tandem mass spectra provide predictable fragmentation patterns for arginine-terminated peptides. The spectra are easily interpreted de novo, and they facilitate error-tolerant identification of proteins whose sequences have been entered into databases.

Karas M, Bahr U, Dülcks T (2000) Fresnius J. Anal. Chem. 366, 669-676.

Nano-electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry: Addressing Analytical Problems Beyond Routine

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. The advent of nano-electrospray ionization (nano-ESI) has considerably extended the usability of ESI in the analytical mass spectrometric laboratory. One of the remarkable features of nano-ESI is its extremely low sample consumption. Only a few microliters of analyte solution (105108 M) are sufficient for molecular weight determination and structural investigations by MS/MS. But nano-ESI is more than just a minimized-flow ESI; the low solvent flow rate also affects the mechanism of ion formation. As a consequence, the area of ESI-MS applications is significantly enhanced. Oligosaccharides, glycosides as well as glycoproteins can be analyzed more easily than with normal ion spray. The same holds for the analysis of non-covalent complexes sprayed directly from aqueous solutions.

Dalluge JJ (2000) Fresnius J. Anal. Chem. 366, 701-711.

Mass Spectrometry for Direct Determination of Proteins in Cells: Applications In Biotechnology and Microbiology

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. A number of different procedures have been developed in recent years that utilize mass spectrometry for the direct determination of proteins in complex mixtures of biological origin. Specific examples of these include the use of matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry (MALDI-MS) or directly combined liquid chromatography-electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (LC/ESI-MS) for rapid profiling of protein expression in bacterial and eucaryotic cells and cell-free extracts. Approaches to sample cleanup, contaminant removal, and initial separation of analytes on-line for the direct determination of proteins in cells using MALDI- and ESI-MS are discussed. Advantages of these techniques over traditional biochemical methods are highlighted, and a critical review of their utility and potential as standard tools in the biomolecular and microbiological research laboratory is presented.

Gygi SP, Rist B, Aebersold R (2000) Curr. Opin. Biotechnol. 11, 396-401.

Measuring Gene Expression by Quantitative Proteome Analysis

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Proteome analysis is most commonly accomplished by the combination of two-dimensional gel electrophoresis for protein separation, visualization, and quantification and mass spectrometry for protein identification. Over the past year, exceptional progress has been made towards developing a new technology base for the precise quantification and identification of proteins in complex mixtures, that is, quantitative proteomics.

The intention of 2DE-MS is to provide a global proteome analysis, but closer examination reveals it is not truly global. Many protein classes are excluded or underrepresented in the 2D gel patterns. Very acidic or basic proteins, extremely large or small, and membrane proteins are not typically represented. Pre-gel enrichment is usually necessary to look at low abundance proteins, for example, as shown in a study of codon bias values.

Codon bias values generally correlate with gene expression. Highly expressed proteins generally have a large codon bias value. 61 codons code for 20 amino acids. Low abundance proteins (transcription factors, protein kinases) typically have codon bias values < 0.1. Of the 6139 genes in the known yeast genome, one half of the gens have values < 0.2 and more than 2500 gene are in the range of 0.0 to 0.1. In 2D gel studies of 343 detected proteins, most of these have high codon bias values.

Alternative to classical 2DE have been sought. Andrews and co-workers used a technique first to separate proteins by IEF then analyze to create virtual 2D gels. In one method prep HPLC is used to fractionate whole yeast lysate prior to SDS-PAGE.

In another method protein mixtures are digested into even more complex peptide mixtures and analyzed by LC-MS/MS. Co-eluting peptides can be filtered in the MS one at a time and fragmented and their fragmentation patterns studied for sequence information. The count of proteins that can be identified is only constrained by the lengh of the analysis and the complexity of the mixtures. Others have increased the number of co-eluting peptides by doing something called peak parking in which the flow in the capillary or nano-colums is reduced from 200 nl/min to 20 nl/min which extends elution time for particular peaks. Up to 10,000 sequencing attempts can be made in a single run.

Link et al. have reported the use of DAPLC (direct analysis of protein complexes) in which they separate proteins by charge and then hydrophobicity before MS, a multidimensional chromatographic technique. The mixture is denatured and reduced and then digested to peptides. The peptides are acidified and passed over a SCX column, and then discrete fractions eluted to an RP column with a salt step gradient. Peptides are then analyzed by LC-MS/MS. This successfully identified all proteins in the 80S yeast ribosome. This 2D technique gets 4 times more proteins than a 1D technique.

Using a preparative SDS-PAGE technique, a strip of the gel containing proteins in the region 68-85 kDa were removed from the Coomassie-stained gel and digested with trypsin. Peptides were then separated and analyzed by gradient SCX and then by capillary RP-LC-MS/MS. 193 proteins were identified and 63 had a codon bias < 0.1.

One difficulty with directly LC-MS/MS analysis is a complete loss of the ability to quantify levels of protein. In 2DE-MS/MS quantification is at the level of the 2D gel. New methods make use of stable isotope dilution techniques. Stable heavy isotopes (2H, 13C, 15N, etc.) are used because the ionization efficiency is quite variable among the different peptides of a protein, and thus alone present a confusion of the expression.

Gygi SP, Aebersold R (2000) Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol. 4, 489-494.

Mass Spectrometry and Proteomics

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Proteomics is the systematic analysis of the proteins expressed by a cell or tissue, and mass spectrometry is its essential analytical tool. In the past two years, incremental advances in standard proteome technology have increased the speed of protein identification with higher levels of automation and sensitivity. Furthermore, new approaches have provided landmark advances in determining functionally relevant properties of proteins, including their quantity and involvement within protein complexes.

Gygi SP, Aebersold R (2000) Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 919, 33-47.

Quantitative Proteome Analysis: Methods and Applications

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. With the completion of a rapidly increasing number of complete genomic sequences, much attention is currently focused on how the information contained in sequence databases might be interpreted in terms of the structure, function, and control of biological systems. Quantitative proteome analysis, the global analysis of protein expression, has been proposed as a method to study steady-state gene expression and perturbation-induced changes. Here, we discuss the rationale for quantitative proteome analysis, highlight the limitations in the current standard technology, and introduce a new experimental approach to quantitative proteome analysis.

Airs RL, Keely BJ (2000) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 14, 125-128.

A Novel Approach for Sensitivity Enhancement in Atmospheric Pressure Chemical Ionization Liquid Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry of Chlorophylls

Pure chlorophyll a was used to prepare pheophytin a by shaking a 1 µM solution in Et-O-Et (30 ml) with 2 M HCl (15 ml). The organic layer is washed 5 times in water, then dried in rotovap. Spectrophotometric scans are obtained with 1 cm cell using 2 nm slit a 300 nm/min, and concentration determined using ε662 = 81300 for chl a and ε662 = 46000 for pheo a. Spinach leaves (20 g) are blanched in boiling salted water for 20-30 s. These are then macerated in 50 ml HPLC acetone. The acetone is centrifuged at 2000 g for 5 min. Supernatant is passed twice through solvent-pretreated cotton wool, then dried by rotovap. HPLC was done on two 3 µm 4.6 × 150 mm Waters Spherisorb ODS2 column in series. The gradient elution is published. For LC-MS, a Thermo Finnigan system is used with AS3000 autosampler, ScM degasser, P4000 gradient pump, UV2000 detector. The Finnigan MAT LCQ ion trap with APcI source is used. Capillary temp is 150°, APCI vaporizer temp 450°, discharge current is 5 µA.

In the method, 5 µl of a 11 µM chl a solution is injected to the spray at 300 µl/min, using solvent composition expected in the gradient program, in order to optimize spectral data. The major ion is the [M-H]+ form. Peak area measurements show that chl a had the weaker ionization at 15% of that of pheo a. The weaker chl a response might be due to Mg2+ presence. APCI likely adds protons to the molecule. Protonation of porphyrin ring nitrogens would be disfavored since non-bonding electron pairs on a Mg-associated nitrogens contribute to the conjugated π electron system (16 members with 18 electrons). The lone pairs do not contribute to this in pheo a and so more readily protonate. Conversion of chlorophylls to pheophytins would achieve better ionization, except when analyses involve determination of mixtures. The latter problem is circumvented with on-line demetallation systems: use of formic acid introduced into solvent flow at 5 µl/min would remove Mg, showing a m/z 893 shift to m/z 871 and increase in relative intensity.

Airs RL, Jie C, Keely BJ (2000) Org. Geochem. 31, 1253-1256.

A Novel Sedimentary Chlorin: Structural Evidence for A Chlorophyll Origin for Aetioporphyrins

NOTE.

Wildgruber R, Harder A, Obermaier C, Boguth G, Weiss W, Fey SJ, Larsen PM, Görg A (2000) Electrophoresis 21, 2610-2616.

Towards Higher Resolution: Two-Dimensional Electrophoresis of Saccharomyces cerevisiae Proteins Using Overlapping Narrow Immobilized pH Gradients

The following conditions were used for both broad and narrow range IEF IPG strips:

IPG Strips Broad range: pH 3-10L, 4-7, 6-9
Narrow range: pH 3.5-4.5, 4-5, 4.5-5.5, 5-6, 5.5-6.7
Gel length 18 cm
Temperature 20°
Current 50 µA per strip
Power 5 W max.
Sample Volume 20-140 µl by cup loading
Focusing Broad range: 1 h @ 150 V, 1 h @ 300 V, 1 h @ 600 V, to 3500 V
Narrow range: 12 h @ 50 V, 1 h @ 300 V, 1 h @ 600 V, to 3500 V
pH 3-10: 18,000 Vh
pH 4-7: 45,000 Vh
pH 6-9: 45,000 Vh
Narrow range: 70,000 Vh

A Multiphor II chamber with dry strip kit and gradient mixer was used with GelBond PAGfilm. Haploid yeast wild-type FY1679 of S. cerevisiae were grown 30° in synthetic YNB medium (6.7 g/L) with 20 g/L glucose and buffered with NaOH/succinic acid (6 g/L, 10 g/L) to pH 5.8. When cells reached OD 1.0, they were washed in ice-cold deionized water and spun down at 5000 g in 5 min. Pellets were put in 1.5 ml conical tubes and stored at −80° unless used immediately. 200 µl hot (95°) SDS sample buffer (1% SDS in 100 mM Tris HCl pH 8.5) was added to pellet and sonicated 15 × 1 sec. Sample then boiled 5 min, cooled in ice-bath. 500 µl 2 M thiourea, 7 M urea, 4% CHAPS, 1% DTT, and 2% ampholytes 3-10 was added. This is re-spun at 16,000 g for 5 min.

IPG gels with many pH ranges narrow and broad were cast (listed in table). These were 250 × 180 × 0.5 mm in size. Strips were cut and rehydration was in 6 M urea, 2 M thiourea, 0.5% CHAPS, 0.4% DTT and 0.5% pH 3-10 Pharmalytes. Samples were loaded by cups on the anode side with total 40 (broad range) or 140 (narrow-range) µl volumes, all concentrations at 1 µg/µl. Except for 4-7 and 3-10 strips, all IEF was under silicone oil. Strips are soaked in 10 ml, 15 min each, of equlibration buffer: 50 mM Tris pH 8.8, 6 M urea, 30% (w/v) glycerol, 2% SDS, with 1% DTT in the first solution and 4% iodoacetamide in the 2nd. 13% polyacrylamide gels were cast (210 × 185 × 1 mm). These were silver-stained by an older method.

The study shows that the narrow-range gels produced many more resolvable proteins than the broad range gels. With the pH 3-10 strips only 755 spots were detectable in the pH 4-7 range. In the pH 4-7 gel, this became 1071 using identical spot detection parameters. When the narrow 4-5, 5-6, and 5.5-6.7 strips are combined, a total of 1754 proteins are resolved. This increase is from 1.6 to 2.3 times from the pH 3-10 strip.

Santoni V, Kieffer S, Desclaux D, Masson F, Rabilloud T (2000) Electrophoresis 21, 3329-3344.

Membrane Proteomics: Use of Additive Main Effects with Multiplicative Interaction Model to Classify Plasma Membrane Proteins According to Their Solubility and Electrophoretic Properties

ABSTRACT. Recent efforts at the proteomic level were employed to describe the protein equipment of the plasma membrane of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. These studies had revealed that the plasma membrane is rich in extrinsic proteins but came up against two major problems: (i) few hydrophobic proteins were recovered in two-dimensional electrophoresis gels, and (ii) many plasma membrane proteins had no known function or were unknown in the database despite extensive sequencing of the Arabidopsis genome. In this paper, several methods expected to enrich a membrane sample in hydrophobic proteins were compared. The optimization of solubilization procedures revealed that the detergent to be used depends on the lipid content of the sample. The corresponding proteomes were compared with the statistical model AMMI (additive main effects with multiplicative interaction) that aimed at regrouping proteins according to their solubility and electrophoretic properties. Distinct groups emerged from this analysis and the identification of proteins in each group allowed us to assign specific features to several of them. For instance, two of these groups regrouped very hydrophobic proteins, one group contained V-ATPase subunits, another group contained proteins with one transmembrane domain as well as proteins known to interact with membrane proteins. This study provides methodological tools to study particular classes of plasma membrane proteins and should be applicable to other cellular membranes.

Kaufman E, Lamster IB (2000) J. Clin. Periodontol. 27, 453-465.

Analysis of Saliva for Periodontal Diagnossis

REVIEW. Probing depth, attachment level, bleeding on probing (BOP), plaque index (PI) and radiographic loss of alveolar bone are used to assess clinical periodontal disease. Microbial infection and environment in the gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) is used to assess risk of potential disease or evaluate current disease.

Analysis of saliva provides great opportunities. It contains proteins of all classes (transporters, buffering agents, growth factors, matrix beds, antimicrobial enzymes and immunoglobulins), small organic molecules that include all classes of metabolites, and virtually every major eleectrolyte and trace element.

Enzymes present in saliva are likely produced by many differetnt sources besides saliva glands; microorganisms and polymorphonuclear leukocytes, epithelial cells and from GCF. Saliva from adult patients with periodontitis shows higher levels of alkaline phosphatase, esterase, β-glucuronidase, β-glucosidase, other aminopeptidases. These levels are higher than for healthy patient saliva; juveniles with periodontitis show the same high levels. Enzyme levels are reduced with treatment (root planing & scaling plus tetracycline); the belief is that microbes contribute to this enzyme pool. Effective nof treatment might be determined by monitoring bacterial enzymes or protein levels in saliva. Whole saliva in juvenile periodontitis shows higher Ig-degrading enzyme levels, and presence of these enzymes may provide bacteria an ecological advantage.

The matrix glycoprotein fibronectin offers an advantage to some bacteria while inhbiting others. Degrading enzymes made by bacteria might help them adhere and colonize. Whole saliva collected immediately after awakening and after toothbrushing shows a higher level of proteolytic activity in the saliva collected before brushing.

In a long term study of 24 adults with advanced periodontitis and 25 healthy subjects, the diseased group was treated and evaluated over 20 months. Salivary elastase levels correlated with deep pocket count and percentage of bleeding sites. Proteolytic activity (trypsin-like, collagenase, elastase-like) was higher in adults with periodontitis. Studies show collagenase of host source is found in whole, but not parotid, sublingual, or submandibular saliva. With treatment collagenase level falls. The authors conclusion that this collagenase originated from PMNs entering oral cavity through gingival sulcus; fibroblasts were ruled out. In particular Downs syndrome children show elevated collagenase levels: the activation of matrix metalloproteinases from PMNs and/or cytokine-activated fibroblasts may account for this early onset destruction.

Reduced levels of tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinases I (TIMP-1) was lower in patients with periodontal disease. Collagenase and gelatinase levels in saliva of 23 adult periodontitis patients and 7 juveniles were higher than controls in one study, and reduced after treatment, although there were no significant correlations of enzyme activity and clinical parameters ( gingival indices, plaque index, pocket depth). Patients with periodontitis have shown decreased lysozyme levels compared to healthy patients; however another study of 7 juveniles and 7 healthy children shows lysozyme, myeloperoxidase, and lactoferrin as significantly elevated in peripheral blood PMNs and in GCF. Thiocyanate levels show an inverse relationship to presence of plaque and of gingival inflammation when measured in both resting and stimulated saliva. Lactoferrin levels in stimulated saliva are directly correlated to gingival disease severity and plaque. Lysozyme was correlated to plaque index, and free lysozyme related to gingivitis severity. Other proteins studied include kallikrein and kininogen.

Plasma cells in the salivary glands are responsible for the presence of secretory IgA (sIga). The majority of sIgA comes from the parotid. sIgA probably works by interfering with the ability of bacteria to adhere and colonize. IgA is composed of two classes: IgA1 predominates in serum while IgA2 generally is found in secretions (tears, milk, saliva. Presence of IgG is derived directly from serum via the GCF, is in low levels in healthy gums, higher levels with periodontitis. Correlations have been shown between IgA levels and inflammation severity. IgA, IgG, and IgM levels in another study were correlated with juvenile periodontitis, although another study reveals lower IgA concentrations in mixed unstimulated saliva.

Regula JT, Ueberle B, Boguth G, Göl A, Schnöer, Herrmann R, Frank R (2000) Electrophoresis 21, 3765-3780.

Towards A Two-Dimensional Proteome Map of Mycoplasma pneumoniae

ABSTRACT. A Proteome map of the bacterium Mycoplasma pneumoniae was constructed using two-dimensional (2-D) gel electrophoresis in combination with mass spectrometry (MS). M. pneumoniae is a human pathogen with a known genome sequence of 816 kbp coding for only 688 open reading frames, and is therefore an ideal model system to explore the scope and limits of the current technology. The soluble protein content of this bacterium grown under standard laboratory conditions was separated by 1-D or 2-D gel electrophoresis applying various pH gradients, different acrylamide concentrations and buffer systems. Proteins were identified using liquid chromatography-electrospray ionization ion trap and matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization-MS. Mass spectrometric protein identification was supported and controlled using N-terminal sequencing and immunological methods. So far, proteins from about 350 spots were characterized with MS by determining the molecular weights and partial sequences of their tryptic peptides. Comparing these experimental data with the DNA sequence-derived predictions it was possible to assign these 350 proteins to 224 genes. The importance of proteomics for genome analysis was shown by the identification of four proteins, not annotated in the original publication. Although the proteome map is still incomplete, it is already a useful reference for comparative analyses of M. pneumoniae cells grown under modified conditions.

Lehmann WD, Schlosser A, Erben G, Pipkorn R, Bossemeyer D, Kinzel V (2000) Prot. Sci. 9, 2260-2268.

Analysis of Isoaspartate in Peptides by Electrospray Tandem Mass Spectrometry

IsoAsp (β-Asp) is found naturally and its occurrence impairs protein function. For example, in tau protein accumulation of isoAsp is associated with aggregation seen as paired helical filaments. Moreover knockouts of the known repair enzyme for isoAsp. protein L-isoapartate (D-aspartate) O- methyltransferase (PIMT) results in severe seizures and reduced life span in mice, and isoAsp accumulation is seen. IsoAsp forms by spontaneous deamidation via β-aspartyl shift in which a cyclic succinimide intermedate forms, and the ring is hydrolyze with a 3:1 IspAsp:Asp product ratio; racemization occurs when the ring intermediate is formed. PIMT methylates L-isoAsp and D-Asp residues. The isoAsp methyl esters then become the succinimide structure and re-enter the β-aspartyl shift. With repeated cycling, a portion is converted back to Asp. Some methods assay the level of L-isoAsp (not D-form). PIMT is utilized with radiolabeled S-adenosylMet in the methylation reaction and the quantity of radiolabeled MeOH reports the L-isoAsp present. An alternative is an HPLC-based measure of S-adenosylHomoCys product released (no radiolabel necessary). Using radiolabeling and then protein digestion, the site of isoAsp can be determined. Edman sequencing can be used since it stops at the isopeptide bond.

Using low energy CID, fragment ions can be produced that are b- and y-ions generated by cleavage at N-terminal side (X-Asp/IsoAsp bond), corresponding b- and y-ions from cleavage at C-terminal side (Asp/isoAsp-X), and the Asp/isoAsp immonium at m/z 88.

The myristoylated N-terminal petpide (1-7) of protein kinase A catalytic subunit was the model. Asn-2 will see partial deamidation/isomerization and the product ion spectra of synthetic myrG-D-AAAK and myrG-isoD-AAAAK were recorded and collision energy changed from −10 to −110 V (spectrum shows accumulation of scans at a change of 1 V per scan). Fragment ions specific for Asp or IsoAsp are absent; relative abundances rather than absolute intensities are measured, which are reproducible for product ion spectra under same conditions of gas pressures and collision energies. in the spectra (1) the b2 (m/z 383) over y5 (m/z 431) decreases for the isoAsp petpide, (2) b1 (m/z 268) over y6 (m/z 546) is changed in same way, and (3) Asp immonium at m/z 88.

With collision offset set to −80V, there was in intention to obtain immonium ions. Three forms of T1 were studied. The D2 (Asp in 2nd position), isoD2, and the succinymidyl (dehydrated) forms of the heptapeptide were evaluated. The m/z 80-90 fine mass range is shown. In D2, the immonium-D peak at m/z 88 is relatively intense compared to the base peak immK-NH3 at m/z 84 (Lys is the C-term residue). A signal of imm-D is still observed with the iso-D2 peptide, but no m/z 88 signal is seen with succ-D form. Thus immonium forms only original from noncyclic forms. Skimmer CID was used to purify the ion stream of D and isoD isomers. The fragment ion spectra were identical, and so immonium ions form equally from Asp or isoAsp peptides.

Additional peptides with Asn sites known to form isoAsp were studied. To understand mechanisms, it is important to examine relative intensity ratios with reference ions: immonium ion of C-term Lys −17 Da at m/z 84, immonium ion of Pro and immonium ion of Arg − 59 Da at m/z 70, immonium of Leu/Ile at m/z 86, and immonium of Val at m/z 72. IsoAsp peptides consistently show a lower m/z 88 relative intensity than the Asp-containing peptides. Complementary b and y ions were also examined. All peptide paris showed a higher b/y ratio in Asp form compared to isoAsp form. 15 Asp/IsoAsp peptides pairs showed big differences in m/z 88 abundances and b/y intensity ratios.

IsoAsp formation results in a consistently reduced b ion formation (see the b/y intensity ratio) and reduction of the Asp immmonium at m/z 88. This relationship shows that immonium ions result from b ions. The currently accepted theory is that C-N peptide bond cleavage involves protonation of amide nitrogen in the first step, weakening the C-N bond and increasing electrophilic character of carbonyl atom. The C-N bond is broken directly or by nucleophilic attack on the carbonyl oxygen at N-terminal side of carbonyl carbon of the protonated amide Oxygen-to-carbon attack leads to five-centered oxazolone, with b-ion formation favored. Direct bond cleavage favors y-ion formation.

When Asp is replaced with isoAsp in the structure, the reaction mechanism of oxazolone intermediate to b-ion formation is impeded. New interactions are created. With an extra methylene group inserted, a less-favored six-centered interaction is required and hampers b-ion formation.

The approach to examining Asp and IsoAsp isomers is first to examine product ion spectra of the pure isomers. The most pronounced quantitative differences are selected as the discriminatory parameter. Thus the immoniumm Asp at m/z 88 and the b/y ion pairs to Asp/isoAsp show the pronounced quantitative differences.

To determine the optimal collision energy for distinguishing peptide pairs, a plot of the ratio of ratios of intensities is done. Calculate the m/z 88 / m/z 84 of the D peptide, and the m/z 88 / m/z 84 of the iso-D peptide, and then plot the ratio of D to isoD ratios. This is for the K-terminated peptides. For the R-termininated peptides, instead of the m/z 84 peak, use the m/z 70 peak. When these are plotted against collision energies (from −40 to −150 V, in roughly 10-15 V steps), A broad maximum between −60 and −120 V is found for the pairs myrG-X-AAAAR, myrG-X-AAAAK, and GA-X-TAAK. For pairs GA-X-GAAK and VSI-X-QK, increasing collision energy was proportional to increasing discriminatory power. As an additional indicator absolute (not relative) intensity at m/z 88 at 80 V is useful.

A series of test mixtures with varying amounts of Asp- and isoAsp-isomer of the PKA fragment myrG-X-AAAAK were done on volumetric basis and analyzed by ESI-MS/MS with m/z 88 normalized to m/z 84. Then a plot of mole percent of Asp-peptide in a mixture based on the m/z 88/84 ratio against the volume percenter of Asp-peptide solution done. This shows a line of increasing slope which indicates a correlation between volumetric data and the 88/84 ratio. Using the VQ-X-GLR peptide (N-terminal region being residues 41-46 of human procollagen, which quickly forms isoAsp, Table 2 shows the b2/y4 intensity ratio decreases by factor of 40 for isoAsp compared to Asp. Plots of the ratio of intensity of m/z 228 / m/z 460 were done against the volume percent of the isoAsp peptide: a parabolic curve upward is found, indicating that there is a relationship, not always linear, between these intensity ratios and the mix of peptides. These peptides had a concentration of 5 pmol/µl, such that each scan was < 1 pmol peptide consumed.

ESI-MS/MS can thus be used to track deamidation and isomerization, and several components at the same time, so long as peptide mass differs for the components.

M & M. A Finnigan MAT TSQ 7000 triple quad with nanoESI (EMBL, Germany) was used. Spray capillaries were made in house with Sutter Instruments (Novato, CA) micropipette puller and surface-coated semitransparent gold film using sputter unit. Voltage on spray was +400 to +700 V; argon was used at 2e-3 millitorr. Solvent was 2:1 MeOH:water with 2% formic acid and sprayed at 5 pmol/µl. 50 consecutive scans with 4 s duration were acquired and averaged to get single data point. Data are the means of 3 data points. Peptides are synthesized on solid phase using Fmoc (9-fluorenylmethyloxycarbonyl) principles using Abimed AMS 422.

Berggren K, Chemokalskaya E, Steinberg T, Kemper C, Lopez M, Diwu Z, Haugland R, Patton W (2000) Electrophoresis 21, 2509-2521.

peptides, sodium and potassium adducts, FD

Rodriquez CF, Guo X, Shoeib T, Hopkinson AC, Siu KWM (2000) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 11, 967-975.

Formation of [M − nH + mNa](m−n)+ and [M − nH + mK](m−n)+ Ions in Electrospray Mass Spectrometry of Peptides and Proteins

The formation of adduct cations to peptides and proteins particularly include those interactions with alkali metals (sodium, potassium) especially when present as impurities or additives. These ions replace protons. Cu2+ and Ni2+ will induce abstraction of amide protons from oligopeptides in solution, after ligation to N-terminal nitrogen atom. Complex ions of the type [M−nH+mX](m−n)+ could be formed in the lens of the MS after collisional activation, as well as from collisions between peptide and neutral alkali metal compounds. Using lithium hydroxide, chloride and hydrate as examples, enthalpies were calculated for reactionswith N-methylacetamine, acetic acid, acetate ion, 1-propanamine (these all models of functionl groups found on peptides) and the majority of reactions are exothermic or slightly endothermic. In a model of reaction between HCONH2 and LiOH, reactions are dominated by relatively deep well from formation of binary complex and are devoid of barriers. Reaction rates are thus determined by reaction enthalpies. Using typical electrospray sampling condtions with endothermicities < 20 kcal/mol, peptide-lithium salt reactions which are exothermic or endothermic by less than 20 kcal/mol proceed to form [M−nH+mLi](m−n)+. The study of lithiated products was based on computational economy. (see Rodriquez et al, Int J. Mass Spectrom. 192: 303, 1999).

Experiments done here are with PE-SCIEX API 3000 prototype triple quad MS using ubiquitin at 10 pmol/µl + 1 mM (1000 pmol/µl) in 50% MeOH. Infusion was at 2 µl/min into pneumatically assisted electrospray probe. Mass spectra were acquired in range m/z 600-3000, with step size of 0.2 u, dwell of 10 ms, and 10 scans summed to produce mass spectrum. Density functional theory (DFT) was done using the B3LYP method, with Becke's 3-parameter exchange function (see Becke, J. Chem. Phys. 98: 5648, 1993) and the correlation functional of Lee et al (Phys Rev B: 37: 785, 1988). with the 6-311++G(d,p) basis set (Krishan et al J. Chem Phys 72: 650, 1980; McLean and Chandler, J Chem Phys 72: 5639, 1980; Chandresekhar et al, JACS 103: 5609, 1981; Chandresekhar et al J. Comput Chem. 4: 294, 1983; Curtiss et al, J Chem Phys 103: 6104, 1995) in Gaussian 98, (Gaussian Inc.) and used to calculate optimized geometries and vibrational frequencies. First-order saddle points were found using Berny transition state algorithm and the CALCALL method.

The ESI spectrum of Ubq with KCl and KOH show several charge states, and at each charge state are several ions forming an envelope that fits the patterns of [M−(m−z)H+mK]z+ where z represents the charge state. More K+ was incorporated with its hydroxide compared to its chloride. Ubq is a 76 residue protein with avg mass of 8564.9 Da. The solution to the count of K+ is given by

m = (5 × (m/z) − 5 − 8564.9) / (39.1 - 1.0)

where m/z is the ion in the charge state of +5 cluster. With chloride salt, m ranges from 0 to 20 where m=5 is the most abundant ion, but with the hydroxide, m ranges from 9 to 21 with m = 14 being the most abundant. There is less K+ incorporation with the chloride with increasing cluster charge. This is because of differences in reaction enthalpies with model functional groups of Ubq. KOH is able to react with more different functional groups than KCl; there are also strong resemblances between NaCl and NaOH as with the potassium counterpart. The resolution between the potassium adducts compared to sodium adducts are because of the higher mass of potassium.

The reaction enthalpies of KOH, KCl, K(H2O)+, NaOH, NaCl, and Na(H2O)+ with compounds which model function groups on the peptide are done. These are N-methylacetamide [CH3-NH2-(C=O)-CH3] (a peptide bond mimic), acetic acid and acetate ion (mimics of Asp and Glu side chains and the C-terminus), propanamine [CH3-CH2-CH2-NH2] (mimics amino terminus and side chain of various basic residues). For each alkali methods, the following 12 reactions are considered:

  1. CH3CONHCH3 + KOH → CH3CON(K)CH3 + H2O
  2. CH3CONHCH3 + KCl → CH3CON(K)CH3 + HCl
  3. CH3CONHCH3 + K(H2O)+ → CH3CON(K)CH3 + H3O+
  4. CH3COOH + KOH → CH3COOK + H2O
  5. CH3COOH + KCl → CH3COOK + HCl
  6. CH3COOH + K(H2O)+ → CH3COOK + H3O+
  7. CH3COO− + KOH → CH3COOK + OH−
  8. CH3COO− + KCl → CH3COOK + Cl−
  9. CH3COO− + K(H2O)+ → CH3COOK + H2O
  10. CH3CH2CH2NH2 + KOH → CH3CH2CH2NHK + H2O
  11. CH3CH2CH2NH2 + KCl → CH3CH2CH2NHK + HCl
  12. CH3CH2CH2NH2 + K(H2O)+ → CH3CH2CH2NHK + H3O+

Standard enthalpies can be calculated from thermochemical data, if the potassium ion affinities (KA values) of the anions of N-methylacetamide, acetate, and propanamine are independently known.

  • ΔH02 = ΔH0acid (N-methylacetamide) + KA (OH−) − ΔH0acid (H2O) − KA (1)
  • ΔH08 = ΔH0acid (acetic acid) + KA (Cl−) − ΔH0acid (HCl) − KA (2)
  • ΔH012 = ΔH0acid (propanamine) + KA (H2O) − PA (H2O) − KA (3)

where PA is proton affinity. Calculations included both KA and SA (sodium affinity) values of NMAA (N-methylacetamide), acetate, and PA, and also affinities for hydroxide, chloride, and hydrate using MO calculations. The latter are included as references to permit gauging accuracy of DFT method at B3LYP/6-311++G(d,p) level of theory. Electronic energies, zero-point vibrational energies, and thermal corrections (adjusted to 298 K) are shown in Table 1 of the potassiated forms of these three molecules, and also of the sodiated forms, in addition to the hydroxides, chlorides, and hydrates.

The attachment of Na and K to NMAA anion will produce conformational change which is same as when Li attaches, in which two methyl groups are cis to one another (compare structures 4, 7, and 10). In 10 there is a minor difference in which C-methyl group is staggered about O-Li bond, and in Na- and K-containing analogs 4 and 7, C-methyl group eclipses the O-metal bond. Replacing Li with Na or K leadst to lenghtening of X-O (X= alkali metal) bond and the X-N bonds, and widening of X-O-C, O-C-N, and C-N-X bond angles. otherwise salt structures of 10, 7 and 4 are identical. Increases in metal-ligand bond lengths and metal-related bond angles in accordance with increase in atomic radii from Li to Na and K. Similar effects with acetate ion (2) and 1-propanamide ion (3).

Calculated Li, Na, and K ion affinities of anions (kcal/mol) using DFT at the B3LYP/6-311++G(d,p) level of theory. Experimental values (Expt.) are also shown for comparison
Anion Lithiuma Sodium Potassium
theory Expt. theory Expt. theory Expt
1 170.4 170.4 124.0
2 170.5 170.5 127.0
3 175.6 175.6 128.7
OH− 187.9 185.7a 158.0 158.7b 141.5 144.7a
Cl− 131.8 132.7c 119.8 118.3f
H2O 35.5 33.9a 25.0 24.1d 18.0 17.2g
a Rodriguez et al Int. J. Mass Spectrom. 192, 303-317.
bΔfH 0 (Na+) + ΔfH 0 (OH−) − ΔfH 0 (NaOH) = 144.1 − 32.7 + 47.3 = 158.7
cΔfH 0 (Na+) + ΔfH 0 (Cl−) − ΔfH 0 (NaCl) = 144.1 − 54.4 + 43.0 = 132.7
dΔfH 0 (Na+) + ΔfH 0(H2O) − ΔfH 0 (NaOH2+) = 144.1 257.8 − 62.2 = 24.1
   ΔfH 0 (NaOH2+) = ΔfH 0 (H+) + ΔfH 0 (NaOH) − PA (NaOH) = 365.7 − 47.3 − 256.2 = 62.2
eΔfH 0 (K+) + ΔfH 0 (OH−) − ΔfH 0 (KOH) = 121.4 − 32.7 + 56.0 = 144.7
fΔfH 0 (K+) + ΔfH 0 (Cl−) − ΔfH 0 (KCl) = 121.4 − 54.4 + 51.3 = 118.3
gΔfH 0 (K+) + ΔfH 0(H2O) − ΔfH 0 (KOH2+) = 121.4 − 57.8 − 46.4 = 17.2
ΔfH 0 (KOH2+) = ΔfH 0 (H+) + ΔfH 0 (KOH) − PA (KOH) = 365.7 − 56.0 − 263.3 = 46.4
All reference thermochemical data from:
  • Lias, SG et al (1988) J. Phys. Chem. Ref. Data 17, Suppl. 1.
  • Lias SG et al (1994) NIST Standard Reference Database 25, Version 2.02
  • Bartmess, J. E. (1993) NIST Standard Reference Database 19B, Version 3.01.
  • Hunter EP, Lias SG In NIST Chemistry WebBook; Hunter EP, Lias SG (1998) J. Phys. Chem. Ref. Data 27, 413-656.

The degree of agreement between calculated and experimental affinities from the table shows that the DFT B3LYP/6-311++G(d,p) method is adequate. Another table shows reaction enthalpies for XOH, XCl, and X(H2O)+ where X = Li, Na, and K, with N-methylacetamide, acetic acid, and acetate anion, and 1-propanamine. Reaction enthalpies which are exothermic less than 20 kcal/mol can be sufficiently fast to be observable because of multiple collision activation in the lens region, if barriers to reaction are not significant. The 20 kcal/mol limit is not arbitrary: in a recent study with Ag(NH3)+n, very few Ag(NH3)+3 ions and no Ag(NH3)+4 ions were observed when a solution of AgNO3 was electrosprayed with 5% ammonia; the sampling conditions were mild. With regular lens conditions, no Ag(NH3)+3 ions are observed, and abundances for Ag(NH3)+2 and Ag(NH3)+ are very high. DFT at B3LYP/DZVP level of theory show reaction enthalpies (ΔH0n,n+1) for reaction Ag(NH3)+n + NH3 → Ag(NH3)+n+1 which are ΔH00,1 = −40.1, ΔH01,2 = −36.1, ΔH02,3 = −15.1, ΔH03,4 = −11.0 kcal/mol. Last three values are in agreement with experimental values. The absence of Ag(NH3)+3 and Ag(NH3)+4 is because of CID in lens region, which indicates energies of between 15 and 36 kcal/mol are available in collisional activation. Ag(H2O)+ and Na(CH3OH)+ complexes have bond enthalpies of 28.4 and 22.3 kcal/mol, respectively, and show intense signals. The abundance ratio of Na(CH3OH)+:Na+ is 1.2 to 1.5, and all these observations support a collisional activation of about 20 kcal/mol in lens region.

Count of functional groups whose reactions with alkali metal-containing reagents are either exo- or endothermic by <20 kcal/mol decreases from reagent being XOH to XCl to X(H2O). Most abundant functional group in peptide is amide bond, and reactions of CH3NH-C(=O)-CH3 with all three alkali hydroxides are exothermic, while with alkali chlorides are endothermic but accessible for LiCl and maybe NaCl.

In the previous study the potential energy hypersurface of LiOH + HCONH2 (formamide) was the prototypical example for formation of [M−nH + mLi](m−n)+. Reaction profile shows deep well of ~35 kcal/mol, and this is because of formation of formamide-lithium hydroxide complex with Li-O-C (lithiation of carbonyl oxygen) then transfer of proton from amide to oxygen of LiOH, di-coordiation of Li by amide O and N atoms, then elongation of Li-OH2 bond to yield HCON(Li)H and H2O complete reaction profile. None of reactions have large barriers and are driven by exothermicity.

HCONH2 + NaOH → HCON(Na)H + H2O
HCONH2 + NaCl → HCON(Na)H + HCl

The structures of these molecules and their transition states as well as many aspects of the energetics of the reaction are given.

collision-induced dissociation (CID), alkali metal ions, bond energies, guided ion beams, noncovalent interactions, thermochemistry, transtion metal ions, FD

Rodgers MT, Armentrout PB (2000) Mass Spectrom. Rev. 19, 215-247.

Noncovalent Metal-Ligand Bond Energies As Studied By Threshold Collision-Induced Dissociation

REVIEW. Noncovalent interactions account for most molecular chemistry such as condensation and solvation or conformation. Metal ion-ligand binding is a major type of noncovalent bonding. Multiple metals are involved in many types of noncovalent interactions: dipole and polarizability effects, chelation, conformers, tautomers. Metal-ligand bond dissociation energies (BDEs) are determined according to the following reaction:

M+(L)x + Xe → (L)x−1M+ + L + Xe

This endothermic reaction shows a Xe atom knocking off a ligand from the metal. A plot of the cross section of the reaction (from 0 to 30 × 10−16 cm2) vs. kinetic energy (from 0.0 to 5.0 eV for center-of-mass frame, 0.0 to 8.0 eV for laboratory frame)

effective temperature, computational chemistry, microcanonical analysis

Ervin KE (2000) Int. J. Mass Spectrom. 195/196, 271-284.

Microcanonical analysis of the kinetic method. The meaning of the effective temperature

Cooke's kinetic method is an MS technique used widely to obtain thermochemical information about ion-molecule systems. The metastable or CID of mass-selected cluster ion having two product channels is followed by MS/MS such as proton-bound anion A1HA2−:

A1HA2− → A1− + HA2   (k1)   [1]
   →HA1 + A2−    (k2)   [2]

These two reactions compete for the anion. The correlation between ratio of intensities of two product ions and the enthalpy or Gibbs free energy difference between to product channels is expressed as:

ln I2/I1 ≈ ΔΔH/RTeff ≈ −ΔΔG/RTeff   [3]

where Ij is the intensity of ion Aj−, ΔΔH = Δ2H − Δ1H ΔΔG = Δ2G − Δ1H Effective temperature (Teff) is a correlation parameter which is determined from the slope of ln I2/I1 vs. either ΔΔH or −ΔΔG. In measuring the product intensity ratios for proton-bound dimers composed of partners of known acidity, slope of the correlation is found and the acidity of the unknown can be assessed against a reference acid. Besides proton bound dimers, other types of clusters have been studed by the kinetic method to determine other thermochemical quantities, including electron affinities for electron-bound dimers (see references). This paper reports a microcanonical kinetics analysis of the kinetic method using classical RRK (Rice-Ramsperger-Kassel) theory of statistical unimolecular dissociation. A simple analytical expression for effective temperature for case of metastable ion dissociation is derived. The ratio of ion intensities observed for two pathways to products is equal to the ratio of macroscopic rate coefficients:

I2 / I1 = k2(T) / k1(T)   [4]

Rates for competing decomposition channels j = 1 and 2 are calculated using canonical transition state theory:

kj(T) = { [ kBT / h] [Qj‡(T) / Q0(T) ] } e−ΔjE0K‡ / RT   [5]

where T is temperature, h is Planck's constant, kB is Boltzmann's constant, Qj‡(T) is partition function for transition state leading to channel j, Q0(T) is partition function for cluster ion, and ΔjE0K‡ is the energy difference between the cluster and transition state at zero temperature. The rate coefficient, k(T), applies strictly to canonical ensemble of reactant molecules (that is system in thermal equlibrium at temp T). The logarithm of the ratio of the rates will evaluate to:

ln k2(T) / k1(T) = ln [ Q2‡(T) / Q1‡(T) ] − { Δ2E0K‡ − Δ1E0K‡ } / RT   [6]

Assumptions are made

  1. no reverse activation energies: ΔjE0K‡ = ΔjE0K
  2. entropy differences between two channles are zero: ΔΔS = R ln(Q2 / Q1) = 0, or else same for all dimer pairs: ΔΔS = Δ2S − Δ1S
  3. integrated heat capacity and entropy differences between internal energ, enthalpy, and Gibbs energy at various temperatures are equal for the two channels and they cancel: ΔΔE0K = Δ2E0K − Δ1E0K ≈ ΔΔHT ≈ ΔΔGT

With the approximations, the following expression is obtained:

ln k2(T) / k1(T) ∝ − ΔΔH / RT ≈ − ΔΔG / RT   [7]

The temperature in the expression is the effective temperature because clusters in the ion beam are isolated species and not in thermodynamic equilibrium at any temperature. Combining Eqs [4] and [7] thus show how Eqn [3] is derived.

When an ion leaves the source of the MS or undergoes its last collision, it is finally isolated and its total internal energy (E) conserved. Decomposition is described by the microcanonical rate coefficient, k(E), than the canonical rate coefficient, k(T). Products are detected in MS/MS if cluster ion lifetime falls within narrow time window corresponding to field-free region between two mass-selection regions. With sector instruments a typical time window is defined by the time of flight travel from the source of 20-40 µs, and ions with shorter liftimes will have higher internal energies and dissociate in first mass-selection region and are ejected. Ions with longer lifetimes (lower internal energies) do not dissociate in second mass-selected region. If ions dissociate within the time window of a MS/MS have one internal energy of E = Ed, the ion intensity ratio is:

I2 / I1 = k2(Ed) / k1(Ed)   [8]

and this is the microcanonical equivalent of Eqn [4].

Classical RRK theory (also called classical quasiequilibrium theory, QET) provides a useful approximation for calculating microcanonical unimolecular dissociation rate. The RRK model is not adequate for quantitative calculation of absolute rates, but provides function that reproduces the behavior of the unimolecular dissociation rate as function of internal energy. RRK rate constant kj(E) for channel j = 1 or 2 is:

kj(E) = ν × [ (E − ΔjE0K‡) / E ]s−1

where s identical classical harmonic oscillators of frequency ν make up the dissociating molecule. There are no reverse activation energies ΔjE‡ = ΔjE. Frequency factor and oscillator count is same for both channels, which is same assuming ΔΔS = 0. As RRK model tends to underestimate rates, number of oscillators s is reduced empirically by factor of 2-5.

metal cationization, CID, ESI-MS/MS, FD

Madhusudanan KP, Raj K, Bhaduri AP (2000) J. Mass Spectrom. 35, 901-911.

Effect of metal cationization on the low-energy collision-induced dissociation of loganin, epi-loganin and ketologanin studied by electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry

Loganin and its epimer are glycosides with therapeutic activity in liver disorders. They form strong [M+Na]+ ions and weak [M+H]+ ions in methanolic ESI-MS. CID MS/MS was done to obtain [M+H]+ by inducing formation of protonated molecules using cone voltage fragmentation of [M+NH4]+ ions. With a cone voltage of < 20 V in 5 mM ammonium acetate, just [M+NH4]+ are observed. Cone V was raised to > 25 V to enhance the analysis of [M+H]+, observed at m/z 391. The protonated aglycone [Agly + H]+ of the two forms has intensities of 100 and 22% respectively. For the ion [Agly + H − H2O]+, the epi-loganin has a 100% intensity and the loganin form is 3%. The epimers differ in that loganin has the C-7 OH above the plane as for the C-1 substituent. This difference may involve H-bonding involving the C-4 substituent and the C-3/C-4 bond stabilizing [Agly + H]+. This stabilization does not occur with the epi-loganin with C-7 OH below plane.

With deuterium-exchanged structures the [Agly+D]+ and [Agly+D−D2O]+ structures show at m/z 232 and 212, respectively. Most likely an exchangeable hydrogen from C-2 OH of the glucose moves to the aglycone moiety during formation of [Algy + H]+ ion at m/z 229 which eliminates anhydroglucose, presented with scheme including deuterated spectrum analysis.

The keto-loganin form (keto on C-8 of aglycone with m/z 389 in [M+H]+ shows two fragmentation pathways. Two ions are m/z 227 and 195 for [Agly + H]+ and [Agly + H - MeOH]+, respectively. Fragmentation pathways generally involve detection only of the aglycone.

Low energy CID spectra were taken of [M+Li]+ and [M+2Li−H]+ forms. Both 6Li+ and D-exchanged forms of molecule with methanolic LiCl show lithiated aglycone, [Agly + Li]+ at m/z 235. Elimination of MeOH is favored equally by both epimers. The [Agly + Li]+ ion at m/z 235 becomes m/z 237 with D exchange, and in cleavege there is transfer of D to the aglycone. With Li and not protonated molecule, there is also [Glc+Li]+ ion at m/z 187, the intensity higher for epi-loganin than loganin. Presumably chelating of Li ion is by C-1 and C-7 oxygens, a C3-C4 double bound and also C-4 substituent. In epi-loganin, C-7 OH falls below plane and cannot perform chelating. This means more Li+ is available to the sugar for bindding, and so [Glc+Li]+ has stronger signal. For D-exchanged, the [Glc+Li]+ is at m/z 191 instead of 187, and an exchangable hydrogen from C-9 of aglycone likely transfers to glycone moiety. The D-exchanged lithiated molecule normall at [Glc+Li−H2O]+ moves up to m/z 172 from 169. Thus [Glc+Li−H2O is [anhydroglucose + Li]+. [More studies of Li+ ion interaction explained here.]

Compared to [M+Li]+, intensity of [M+Na]+ ions for the three glycones is weak while fragmentation pathways are similar. Na+ appears to have equal affinity for aglycone and glucose. The ketologanin form readily loses MeOH compared to loganin. As the alkali metal size increases with K+, Rb+, and Cs+, but the fragmentation pattern involves only the loss of the association of metal ions. No fragments associated with K+, Rb+, and Cs+ are seen in spectra. Weaker bond energies are likely the cause.

The Ag+ ion configuration is of a d10 with empty s orbitnals. Configuration is similar to Cu+. Silver-bound methyl glycosides fragment with elimiantion of AgH similar to abstracting α-hydrogen from organic amine complexes of Ag+ and Cu+. In high enegy CID, Ag+ bound causes specific carbohydrate fragmentations. Methanolic solutions of the three molecules in AgNO3 or with MeOD for deuterated exchanges were done. The d3 was made in LiOH in D2O and spiked with AgNO3 to see the [M+Ag]+ ion at m/z 502. Fragmentation involves silver associated with the aglycone after which the silver dissociates as AgH. Some fragment sizes differ between loganin and the epiform.

In summary protonation leads to fragmentation with the proton transferring to aglycone. Alkali metal and silver cationization cause cleavage at the glycosidic bond. With lithiated species, ring cleavages are more probable.

guanidination, MALDI MS

Brancia FL, Oliver SG, Gaskell SJ (2000) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 14, 2070-2073.

Improved matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometric analysis of tryptic hydrolysates of proteins following guanidination of lysine-containing peptides

Ions accelerated in linear mode may show in-flight instability and decompose (fragment). They will be detected whether ionized or neutral. In refletron mode, neutral products should not be detected. Thus a comparison of linear and reflectron mode intensities should show the difference. The yeast ADH tryptic digest shows signed derived from Lys- or Arg-containing peptides. Lys-containing peptide intensities are greater in linear than in reflectron mode. The m/z 2701 ion is the 13th tryptic peptide and is not observed in reflectron mode. Since

structure prediction, membranes

Möller S, Croning MDR, Apweiler R (2001) Bioinformatics 17, 646-653.

Evaluation of Methods for the Prediction of Membrane-Spanning Regions

Several well known methods for prediction of MSRs were evaluated:

  • TMHMM 1.0, 2.0, and retrained 2.0 (Sonnhammer et al. 1998 and Krogh et al. 2001)
  • MEMSAT 1.5 (Jones et al 1994)
  • Eisenberg (Eisenberg et al. 1982)
  • Kyte & Doolittle (1982)
  • TMAP (Persson and Argos, 1997)
  • DAS (Cszero et al 1997)
  • HMMTOP (Tusnady and Simon 1998)
  • SOSUI (Hirokawa et al 1998)
  • PHD (Rost et al 1996)
  • TMpred (Hoffman and Stoffel 1993)
  • KKD (Klein et al 1985)
  • ALOM2 (Nakai and Kaneisha, 1992)
  • Toppred 2 (Claros and Heijne, 1994)

Alom2, Eisenberg, Kyte/Doolittle, TMpred and DAS typically look at properties of amino acids to find sub-sequences most likely to span a membrane, with a sliding window analysis. PHD uses a neural network (a nonetheless local approach like the others). Global approaches include HMMTOP and TMHMM usuing circular Hidden Markov models. TMAP, Toppred2 and MEMSAT combine features for both local and global heuristics. TMAP can make use of sequence alignments, but this data was withheld so that the data was reproducible.

The test set was 188 proteins with 883 MSRs determined from elucidated structures or by fusion experiments. Correct predictions were judged to be those in which at least 9 of the amino acids belonged to the MSR in the reference annotation; an MSR is expected to contain at least 20 residues. Ratings included three values:

  1. True positive predictions: that is the percentage of predicated transmembrane regions assignable to a reference MSR
  2. False negatives: percentage of reference MSRs not predicted
  3. False positives: percentage of predicted MSRs not existent in the reference protein set.

The sidedness of the membrane protein was also tested for reliability, but is not evaluated by all methods. Both mitochondrial inner membrane and plasma membrane proteins were tested. Kyte/Doolittle was evaluated on a 5- and 9-residue window system (KD5 and KD9).

A table is presented to show the TP, FP, and FN, and the methods are ranked from lowest to highest with respect to errors detected (FP + FN). By this ranking, all three versions of TMHMM were better than any other evaluation method. MEMSAT was second, but had twice as many errors. ALOM had a low false positive rate, and its FP/TP ratio is lower than the one of the TMHMM.

The average correct prediction of MSRs within a protein was evaluated, and again TMHMM versions were the best (with 2 in 3 correct predictions). In 7-8 of 10 predictions, the sidedness was also correctly determined (the retrained TMHMM did better in sidedness). Toppred, TMAP, and TMpred did worse in prediction than in mere random guessing.

A table of MSRs not presented to the program for training and analysis shows that the programs identified before did best in predictions. TMHMM has 80-85% correct prediction, with MEMSAT following at 76%. Eisenberg and Kyte/Doolittle were runners-up.

Many programs also interpret the signal/transit peptide sequences as part of the hydrophobic spanning core. These are hydrophobic, but are also removed from the mature protein. A test set of 34 proteins containing cleavable signals, and 8 proteins with transit peptides were included. Only the ALOM2 program correctly predicted that not a single signal sequence was part of the transmembrane spanning of the mature protein. This was followed by PHD with one error, and Toppred2 with 3 errors. TMHMM 2.0 had 7 errors, responsible for 1 in 6 of the false positives this program made. Kyte/Doolittle predicted 8 mitochondrial transit peptides as transmembranous.

The tendency of the software to overpredict proteins with MSRs was tested by submitting known soluble proteins. While globular proteins have hydrophobic sequences that form inner folds, these must not be predicted to be MSRs. A total of 634 cytoplasmic or periplasmic soluble proteins from SWISSPROT release 38 were tested. TMHMM had the lowest errors (8, or 1% false annotations), followed by SOSUI (19, or 3%). ALOM2, which has the lowest false positives on real MSRs, found 61 soluble proteins with MSRs (a poor 10% rate).

principal components analysis (PCA), mass spectrometry

Bryant DK, Monté S, Man WJ, Kramer K, Bugelski P, Neville W, White IR, Camilleri P (2001) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 15, 418-427.

Principal Component Analysis of Mass Spectra of Peptides Generated from The Tryptic Digestion of Protein Mixtures

ABSTRACT. Principal component analysis (PCA) has been used to analyse mass spectral peptide profiles obtained from the enzymatic digestion of standard protein mixtures. Scores and loadings plots clearly revealed peptide fragments that differentiated one protein mixture from another. Peptide map search results identified with a high degree of certainty any additional proteins in these mixtures. As a proof-of-concept this methodology was applied to hepatic protein mixtures obtained from rats treated with two hepatotoxic compounds: methapyriline and SB-219994. Liver proteins were extracted, pre-separated by one-dimensional polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, subjected to tryptic digestion and analysed by mass spectrometry. Two up-regulated proteins, glutathione S-transferase with methapyrilene and peroxisomal bifunctional enzyme with SB-219994, were identified in this manner.

salt cluster ions, FD

Hao C, March RE, Croley TR, Smith JC, Rafferty SP (2001) J. Mass Spectrom. 36, 79-96.

Electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometric study of salt cluster ions. Part 1—Investigations of alkali metal chloride and sodium

Electrospray ionization was reported by Dole et al in 1968 although used for biomolecules much later. Anacleto et al (1992) investigated protonated water clusters and salt clusters of NaF, KF, NaI, KI, RbI, CsI, CsNO3 and CsCO3 and found they could make calibration standards in positive and negative ion mode. Moini et al reported NaOOCCF3 could be a calibration standard from 100-4000 Th. ESI may work from either the ion evaporation model or by the charge residue model. Kebarle and Peschke found that hydrates of metal [M(H2O)x]+ and salt clusters [M(MX)n]+ in low m/z region. In one case, the study of alkali metal halides were given as support for charge residue. Additional studies with sodium ions clustered with their chlorides, formates, and combination formates and acetates although they were in low m/z region. Cases of [Nax(NaCl)n]x+ for x = 1 or 2 have been shown under nanospray. MS/MS spectra revealing 2+ ions of NaCl were recently reported, with magic numbers of molecules, and collision fragmentation channels. In this study are alkali metal chlorides and sodium fsalt with >2± charge and studied as CID with triple quad and QToF instruments.

In general the total ion current (TIC) increases with flow rate, temperature, and capillary voltage. The distribution of ions however are affected by cone voltage. The spectrum of a 50 mM NaCl in 50% MeOH is shown with cone V = 10 and 75 V. Note that a normal cone voltage (NCV) is thought to be in range of 45-80 V, while a low cone voltage (LCV) is any setting < 30 V. Two tables are shwonw for positive and negative ion mode. The data show that for NaCl and KCl as singly charged [Me(MeCl)n]+, the magic numbers are n = 1, 4, 9, 13, 22, 28, 37, and 47, although the n = 9 cluster for NaCl is not apparent in full-scan mass spectra. Very, very low intensities (barely detectable) can be observed for n = 14, 15, 24, and 32 and seen under NCV conditions. The magic and absent numbers are thought to correspond to stable and unstable clusters, respectively, and may relate to geometry of salt cluster ions. Doye and Wales have suggested [(NaCl)nCl]− for n = 1-35 with n = 13 and 22 having regular compact structures with greater stability. A cluster of 13 NaCl plus an ion (total 27 ions) has a 3 × 3 × 3 cubic-like structure. For n = 22, the structure shows a 3 × 3 × 5. It is not clear why n = 4 and 9 cluster ions are quite stable according to Doye and Wales. Clusters having n = 14, 15, 24 and 32 had particles protruding from regular clusters and might be lower stability.

Under NCV conditions, clusters ranged up to m/z 4000, but under LCV conditions, clusters in the low m/z region predominated, usually < m/z 1700. At LCV, clusters having magic numbers are no longer dominant.

For ions in the low m/z region subjected to CID, these ions are actually multiply charged clusters. Dications have been reported but multiply charged cluster ions have not been obesrved before although they have been reported for arginine solutions.

In a plot of intensity vs cluster number n for the formula Na+(NaCl)n, where the cone voltages are 10 (LCV) and 75 (NCV) volts, and n ranges from 1 to 29. Because (Na+)2(NaCl)n dications overlapped the monocation clusters, their intensities had to be subtracted. The chart shows that the magic numbers are n = 4, 13, 22, 28 with signficant intensities at NCV than at LCV. Sums of the cluster ion intensities are 138 × 106 counts for LCV, and 220 × 106 counts for NCV.

The count of energetic collisions (those with vibrational energy increases in ionic species) that occurs in the space/volume is dependent on cone voltage; total number of collisions is not dependent on cone voltage however, only on energy. With LCV, where sample and extraction cone voltage is ~10 V, energetic collisions are sharply reduced. This allows multiply charged cluster ions that are somewhat labile to survive which are collisionally cool. With higher cone voltage, only the really stable clusters (with magic numbers) are detected, so their intensities are maintained. Kebarle and Peschke have favored the CRM for salt concentrstions > 10 mM although the IEM is not ruled out. Thus charged droplets are formed first, with salt molecules and solvent molecules with excess cations in positive mode and anions in negative mode. Charged droplets then undergo evaporation and uneven fission until salt cluster ions form. The nascent cluster ions collide with gas molecules in the volume between sample and extraction cone, and collision energies determine distribution of cluster ions detected. When cone V is reduced in steps down to 0 V, cluster ions detected represent distribution of droplets in vicinity of sample cone although the distribution might be modified slightly because of non-uniform ion transmission. Few if any energetic collisions occur between ions in the volume between sample and extraction cones. For positively charged clusters of NaCl, the nascent ion ensemble is composed principally of numerous doubly, triply, and quadruply charged species and two additional species with n = 52 and 53, carrying six charges each.

The preponderance of ions with low m/z is because nascent ions having high number of charges (z) rather than low mass and single charge. Under LCV conditions there are very few +1 charged clusters. At LCV the intensity of the cluster ions at magic number n = 13 indicates that few collisions if any are energetic to induce dissociation. The data indicate that ESI itself does not produce the clustering conditions, but are conducive to formation of cluser ions that are thermodynamically less stable.

With sample cone V increases, ion-neutral collision fraction of total collisions being energetic or energy-rich is increased. Ions in nascent ensemble formed in ESI soruce under partial charge-transfer reactions and fragmentation. Secondary ion ensemble is now of higher average m/z because lower number of charges are associated with molecular clusters. The sample cone voltage controls the types of cluster ions that enter the MS. Cone voltage magnitude determines size (mass) and charge state of detected cluster ions. Plot of variations in signal intensity of Na+(NaCl)13 (a magic number) vs. cone voltage shows that signal intensity increases with increasing cone V until 55 V, then it decreases due to collisional dissociation and scattering.

CID helps to give information on structure through fragmentation pathways and thermodynamic behavior of gas-phase ions. With MS/MS analysis, ions are selected or isolated which fall within a 1-2 Da narrow band of m/z ratios in the analysis of the product ions formed. Product ion spectra were obtained for both positive and negative ions: (NaCl)nNaxx+ for x = 1-4, 6 and (NaCl)nClxx− for x = 1-3. Product ion spectra were also checked for potassium chloride with x = 1-3 for both the cations and anions. The base peaks were clusters having magic numbers in both ±1 or ±2 ions.

The ±1 ions entering the filter produce ±1 fragment ions naturally, losing MCl paired salt molecules in CID. For +2 ions with n < 28, only +1 are seen (never +2 ions). Thus the internal energy in collision + the energy of charge repulsion enable cluster fragmentation. When n ≥ 28, both +1 and +2 product ions are seen. Considering the n = 28 +2 ion is stable, what would be its structure? Most likely +2 ions and other multiply charged ions have a regular flat structure with thickness equal to size of single molecule being preferred. The two faces would have a relatively large area and look like a rectangular wafer. For the NaCl +2 ion with n = 28, it might look like a 2 × 4 × 7, with 56 positive and negative ions and lengths where the sides are approximately equal. The two excess sodium ions are connected to chloride ions on opposite corners, diagonally opposed for maximum charge separation. This would be 24.8 Å intercharge separation. The coulombic energy T is related to the intercharge distance R such that TR = 14.39 eV Å. Thus the coulombic repulsion energy for this dication is T = 0.58 eV.

CID spectra are collected for the following cluster ions: (NaCl)4Na+, (NaCl)21Na22+, (NaCl)45Na22+, (NaCl)50Na33+, and (NaCl)53Na66+.
