Domimant product ions for parent (NaCl)4Na+ (m/z 257) are (NaCl)Na+ (m/z 81), (NaCl)2Na+ (m/z 139, and (NaCl)3Na+ (m/z 197). Note that the m/z 257 value is a [M + 2]+ value, because it represents the greatest abundance of the molecular ion cluster, largely due to the dual isotopes of chlorine. With +1 ions, the only possible energy change is that resulting from loss of paired ions. With (NaCl)21Na22+ m/z 637, all +1 ions with n 1-20 are observed except for n = 14, which is reported to be unstable and seen only in low abundance under NCV conditions. In contrast (NaCl)13Na+ is quite dominant and corresponds to a magic number. It should also be noted that several product ions have m/z larger than the precursor. (NaCl)45Na22+ (m/z 1339) has a spectrum of both +1 and +2 fragment ions, where +1 ions have n = 1-4 and 28-44, with n = 37 having highest intensity and being a magic number. Why are fragment ions with magic number n = 13 not observed? Answer is addressed later. Ions of 2+ charge and n = 33-44 are also part of fragment spectrum. Four of these 2+ ions with greatest signal intensities have a loss of 1-4 NaCl molecules from the parent 2+ ion.

(NaCl)50Na33+ (m/z 998) undergoes CID to produce +1 ions with 1-4 NaCl molecules and complementary 2+ ions with 46-49 NaCl clusters. One fragment is the loss of a single Na+ to form (NaCl)50Na22+. There are no 3+ fragments.

There is a 6+ ion of (NaCl)53Na66+ (m/z 539) is simpler: there are three paths to dissociation. One is a loss of three Na+ ions (NaCl)53Na33+ (m/z 1051), another is a loss of two Na+ (m/z 795), and then a loss of six NaCl and two Na+ for an ion m/z 707. Low m/z fragment ions complementary to these are not seen. As charge states are determined by isotopic peak cluster difference, so long as resolution allows. In one particular cluster there are 45 peaks spread out over 29.333 Th.

Solution conditions such as solvent, concentration, and pH also affect ion clustering in ESI-MS. Earlier attempts to observe cluster ions in alkali metal halides may have been due to concentrations. NaCl at 0.10, 0.05, and 0.01 M aqueous in MeOH or MeCN at 25, 50, and 75% levels were studied. The distribution of ions was found to change in going from 10 to 100 mM. It was also affected by a changes in solvent. Total ion current was affected by both a change in concentration and in solvent combined are necessary. TIC increases with concentration and when MeOH or MeCN increases. A 75% MeOH solution gives best ion intensities in positive ion mode, and 25% MeOH gives best intensities in negative ion mode. Addition of HCl to pH 3 and NaOH to pH 11 in 50 mM NaCl was done: at pH 3 positively charged NaCl clusters show the presence of one or two HCl molecules. (NaCl)17(HCl)2Na+ and (NaCl)18(HCl)Na+. There is large reduction of ions seen in the high m/z region compared to pH neutral. This could be due to unresolvable combinations of (NaCl)n(HCl)mNa+. Negatively charged clusters were observed at pH 3 and similar to the spectrum of neutral molecules. At pH 11 the spectrum of positively and negatively charged culster is different from the neutral. There is a significant absence of large cluster ions in the high m/z range. Peaks are observed in low m/z range with ions having mixed clusters of NaCl and NaOH. Clusters of (NaCl)3-5(NaOH)1-2 with either Na+ or Cl− are prominent in the spectra. Differences in stability of the cluster are clearly related to size of the chloride and hydroxyl anions.

Ionic Radius. Salt cluster stability is a function of ionic radii and how it affects solvation energy. This is more significant when cluster size is n < 10. In a solvent of 50% MeOH at 50 mM concentration, with NCV (cone= 75 V) conditions, alkali metal chlorides (LiCl, RbCl, CsCl) are analyzed. LiCl for different values of n (zero charge cluster component) and x for different values of Li+ or Cl− are similar to NaCl behavior. In the previous work NaCl and KCl show a wide distribution of ions up to a limit of m/z 4000, depending on spectrometer. For heavier Rb and Cs, both positive and negative ions are seen as +1 or −1 ions ranging form n = 13. Ions at n = 16, 17, 22 and 23 are also seen. For 2+ ions of Rb and Cs clusters, ions for n ≥ 26 are only observed. The count of RbCl and CsCl clusters in absolute intensity are far lower than for NaCl and KCl cluster ions however. There is a minor series of cluster ions containing other cations (Na+ and K+) and may arise from impurities in the CsCl and RbCl.

An anionic series was also test against sodium (NaX), where X is iodide (I−), formate (HCOO−), acetate (CH3COO−), nitrite (NO2−, or nitrate (NO3−) was test with cone V = 75. NaI produced cluster ions up to m/z 6000, and now NaI is used for calibration for these reasons. Both sodium formate and sodium acetate shows clusters quite similar to each other. The largest ion has a n = 31 for formate and n = 32 for acetate. Under NCV conditions cluster ions having the normal magic number of molecules do not dominate the mass spectrum. 2+ ions are obaserved with n in region of 25 and one identified in positive ion spectra of NaNO2 and NaNO3. Also a (NaX)61Na33+ ion is found in all systems. The nitrite and nitrate spectra are remarkably similar to each other and to sodium formate and sodium acetate.

Mixes of clusters also occurs. For example, (CH3COONa)n(HCOONa)CH3COO− where n = 8-14 is unique; the presence of a single formate. Observations for NaCl and LiCl stand out among all others. LiCl produces no fewer than 246 different cluster ions in all, with 167 positively charged, and 79 negatively charged. It also produces the cluster ion with the greatest number of molecules (n = 152). NaI produces a series of 4+ ions counting 40 total (n = 65-104, x = 4) unlike no others. Note this is true only in positive ion mode, with 4 Na+ ions. What is the structure of a (NaI)65Na44+ cluster? Likely a wafer of 2 × 5 × 13 atoms (sodium and iodide), and the four Na+ should be located at corner of one of the two 5 × 13 faces. This provides maximum separation. What about the upper limit (NaI)104Na44+? This might be a wafer of 2 × 8 × 13 atoms. The sodium cations would be given the widest possible separation. These structures of 4+ ions cann be regular and compact as proposed for (NaCl)47Na44+. The four sodium ions in the n = 47 are part of regular rectangular structure than being attached to corners of wafer-like crystal. (NaCl)47Na44+ is quite stable as it is a CID product of the precursor (NaCl)53Na44+, As for negative cluster ions, those with charge > 2 are relatively rare. While the 4+ ion (NaI)65Na44+ was observed, not 3+ ion was.

Three principles can be stated about the formation of cluster ions:

  1. 10 of the 12 types of sodium salt cluster ions are 1± have a maximum in range of 25-37 molecules of NaX, depending on X.
  2. 9 of the 12 types have 2± have a minimum of 21-27 molecules, again depending on X.
  3. 5 of the 12 types of cluster ions with 3± ions have a minimum of 61-67 molecules, depending on X.

It can be asserted that when a Na+ must leave a cluster, it is forced by cluster instability, when the number of molecules in the cluster falls below a threshold (critical value). Suppose n = 70 and x = 3+. When n falls below a critical value, x will decrease by 1, where n will be somewhere between 61 and 67 depending on the anion. Then dications are observed.

Even more interesting observations for LiCl, NaCl, and KCl. It can be observed that the maximum value n for x = 1 is half that of the nmax for x = 2, and a third of that for nmax for x = 3, so that the m/z value is the same. It might be a property of the mass transmission function of the spectrometer or a property of the cluster ions.

salt cluster ions, FD

Hao C, March RE (2001) J. Mass Spectrom. 36, 500-521.

Electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometric study of salt cluster ions. Part 2—Salts of polyatomic acid groups and of multivalent metals

A Micromass Quattro LC triple-stage quadrupole (TSQ) equipped with Z-spray interface is used. Salt solutions are pumped with Harvard Model 11 syringe pump at 5 µl/min. Source block is 90° and desolvation 150°C. Capillary voltage is 3000 V and cone = 60 V. Argon @ 10 psi is the collision gas for MS/MS work. Beam of mass-selected ions is attenuated by about half. A 5 Th m/z range was isolated for MS/MS work. Collision voltage is adjusted to an optimum.

Results. A 50 mM CaCl2 solution is scanned in positive and negative ion mode in range m/z 0-2500. The ions present show positive clusters of the form (CaCl2)n(CaCl)xx+, where x = 1-3. In negative ion mode, the form is (CaCl2)n(Cl)yy− where y = 1-3. All cluster ions are identifed based on m/z ratio and intuition based on chemistry of material. Fragmentation studies by MS/MS also give clues about the structure. Five precursor ions were selected for CID fragmentation: (CaCl2)3(CaCl)+, (CaCl2)5(CaCl)+, (CaCl2)10(CaCl)22+ (isobar to previous), (CaCl2)13(CaCl)22+, and (CaCl2)25(CaCl)33+. The fragmentation was optimized to retain some of the precursor in the spectrum. Product ions appearing for the n = 3/x = 1+ ion include n = 1 and 2/x = 1+, thus losing CaCl2 molecules successively. For n = 5/x = 1+ and isobaric n = 10/x = 2+, the products are n = 1-8/x = 1+; no dications. For n = 13/x = 2+, again only 1+ cations with n = 1-12, indicating the energy to knock off CaCl2 one at a time. It thus appears that there is a critical value / threshold of n = 13 for the dication form to be possible. For n = 25/x = 3+, 1+ cations with n = 1-4 are observed and 2+ ions with n = 10-24 are observed. In addition, 3+ ions with n = 22-24 are observed, indicating a critical threshold for 22 ions before a CaCl+ is discharged. All this is similar to the results for MX, where M is alkali metals. The table below summmarizes the 50 mM CaCl2 data:

Charge number
x or y 		Observed n
Positive ions
(CaCl2)n(CaCl)xx+ 		Positive ions
(CaCl2)n(Cl)yy−
1 1-17 1-22
2 9-33 9-39
3 25-50 49-65

For 50 mM CuCl2 the ion pattern in MS mode is more complex. Formations of ions fitting the following five patterns were observed:

  • (CuCl2)n(CuCl)Cu+
  • (CuCl2)n(CuCl)+
  • (CuCl2)nCu+
  • (CuCl)n(CuCl)+ / (CuCl2)(CuCl)n − 1Cu+
  • (CuCl)nCu+

Thus in positive mode, there is are losses of chloride anions to form CuCl+ of Cu+. The table below summarizes the cluster formula and observed n:

Mode Cluster formula Observed n
Positive (CuCl)nCu+ 1-6
(CuCl)n(CuCl)+ / (CuCl2)(CuCl)n − 1Cu+ 1-4
(CuCl2)nCu+ 1-17
(CuCl2)n(CuCl)+1-17
(CuCl2)n(CuCl)Cu+ 1-17
Negative (CuCl)nCl− 1-3
(CuCl2)nCl− 1-16
(CuCl2)n(CuCl)Cl− 1-12
(CuCl2)n(CuCl)2Cl− 1-14

Note that both positive and negative mode clusters featured CuCl, indicating that Cu has been reduced from Cu(II) to Cu(I).

Product ion spectra were collected on the following precursors:

  1. (CuCl2)(CuCl)3Cu+
  2. (CuCl2)5(CuCl)Cu+
  3. (CuCl2)11(CuCl)+

For precursor 1, there are losses of one, two, and three CuCl molecules, and also losses of (CuCl)1-2(CuCl2). In addition ions appear that represent single Cl atom loss and the formation of three Cu+ ions (Cu+ appears at m/z 63.4). A particular problem is a distinction between empirical (ion) formula and molecular formula. The distinction might need to be resolved by understanding energy states. A particular ion that can be shown to be (CuCl)4(CuCl)+ might also be represented as (CuCl2)(CuCl)3Cu+.

Precursor 2 was determined based on a loss of five CuCl2 and one CuCl moiety. It loses two Cl atoms and produces no free Cu+ ions.

The species determined to be precursor 3 was determined in the same way, observing successive CuCl2 losses.

How does the reduction occur? Perhaps at the expense of chloride ion in the gas phase, which forms a radical Cl• or produces ½ Cl2 for a thorough oxidation. It was observed with CuCl2 sprays that there was a discharge between the ESI capillary and sampling cone, visible to naked eye, and 8 mm long, intensely blue in region of sample cone. The discharge was most intense at 3000 V, and loses intensity as the potential is decreased (at 2500 V it is no longer visible to dark-adapted eye). This discharge is likely attributable to the first negative system of nitrogen, N2+ (B2 ∑u+ → X2 ∑g+). This is a common component of aurorae. Ground state nitrogen forms the first state as follows:

N2 + e− ↔ N2+ (B2 ∑u+) + 2 e−

Thus gaseous electrons ionize dinitrogen. A blue emission occurs when there is a transition from excited to ground state ion:

N2+ (B2 ∑u+) ↔ N2+ (X2 ∑g+) + hν

The (0,0) transition at 3916 Å accounts for the blue flame. Differences between CaCl2 and CuCl2 are attributable to d orbital chemistry. Valence shell configuration is 4s2 for Ca and 3d104s1 for Cu. When ionized to 2+ ions, Ca2+ is 3s23p6, which is quite stable. In contrast Cu2+ is 3d9, less stable than 3d10, which would be Cu+. However, Cu+ is not stable in aqueous solution (2 Cu+ ↔ Cu2+ (aq) + Cu(s)). But in electrospray in the gas phase, it will form the more energetically favorable state CuCl.

ESI-MS of NaxY, where x = 1 or 2 and Y = CO32−, HCO3−, H2PO4−, and HPO4−. A 50 mM NaCO3 solution showed a spectrum of cluster ions quite similar to CaCl2 with a pattern shown in the table, with +1 and +2 ions in positive mode and −1, −2 and −3 ions in negative mode.

Charge number
x or y 		Observed n
Positive ions
(Na2CO3)n(Na)xx+ 		Negative ions
(Na2CO3)n(NaCO3)yy−
1 1-28 1-25
2 15-51 9-43
3 — 19-63

When 50 mM NaHCO3 was tested in positive and negative ion mode, peaks in respective positive and negative ion modes appeared similarly to those in NaCO3 indicating the common nature of the chemistry. More peaks were apparent in the hydrogencarbonate though. Selection for MS/MS by CID shows that the additional minor peaks were because of +1 and more charge state cluster ions with several NaHCO3 molecules. Note that there is a 22 Da difference between the lower mass hydrogencarbonate compared to the disodium form.

What the bicarbonate solution behavior shows is that there is a change of pH during electrospray. The quadrupole filter was set for parent ions around m/z 1083, 1048, 1028, and 1013, and product ion spectra recorded. For parent m/z 1083 fragments fit the patterns (Na2CO3)1-37Na+, (Na2CO3)29Na22+, and (Na2CO3)39Na33+. The precursor must have been composed of what amounted to four isobaric species: (Na2CO3)10Na+, (Na2CO3)20Na2+, (Na2CO3)30Na3+, and (Na2CO3)40Na4+. The products then represent a common loss of (Na2CO3)Na+ from all the precursors (n = 20, 30, 40 for x = 2, 3, 4) in order to produce n = 19, 29, 39 for x = 1, 2, 3, respectively. With bicarbonate the ion cluster may be (Na2CO3)16(NaHCO3)3Na22+ and the product will be (Na2CO3)15(NaHCO3)3Na+ with the loss of (Na2CO3)Na+.

Filtering at m/z 1013 ± 5 Th, this takes as precursor both (Na2CO3)28Na33+ (m/z 1012) and (Na2CO3)35(NaHCO3)3Na44+ (m/z 1014). Product spetra show +1 ions (Na2CO3)5-9,12-14,21-27Na+ and (Na2CO3)27Na22+. From (Na2CO3)35(NaHCO3)3Na44+ the ions (Na2CO3)34(NaHCO3)3Na33+, (Na2CO3)33(NaHCO3)3Na22+, (Na2CO3)35Na22+, and (Na2CO3)33-35Na+ are formed from a combination of molecules and atoms lost: these combinations include sodium carbonate, sodium bicarbonate, and an attached sodium ion. The main series of ions are composed of sodium carbonate molecules whether the solution is carbonate or bicarbonate.

So why does bicarbonate form mostly carbonate? The pH of 50 mM NaHCO3 is 8.42 and that of 50 mM Na2CO3 is 11.21. Bicarbonate forms carbonate by the abstraction of the proton with hydroxide. Thus a pH increase will favor carbonate formation. Clearly in electrospray, there is an increase in pH causing this conversion.

If this is true, then what about another polyprotic acid, for example sodium phosphate. The full spectrum of 50 mM NaH2PO4 in both positive and negative mode was obtained. Nearly two dozen ions were evaluated as clusters in positive ion mode of NaPO3, NaH2PO4, Na2HPO4, Na3PO4, and Na+; and in negative ion mode of NaPO3, NaH2PO4, Na2HPO4, Na3PO4, PO3− and H2PO4. Included in the spectrum was (H3PO4)Na+ and (H3PO4)2Na+. In the negative ion mode, (HPO3)PO3−, (H3PO4)PO3−, (H3PO4)H2PO4−, and (H3PO4)2H2PO4− The formation of H3PO4 indicates that pH is falling within the electrospray medium. Product ion spectra were obtained for the following precursors:

  • (NaPO3)(Na2HPO4)Na+
  • (NaPO3)(NaH2PO4)2(Na3PO4)Na+
  • (NaPO3)2(Na2HPO4)(Na3PO4)Na+ and its isobar (NaPO3)4(Na2HPO4)2(Na3PO4)2Na22+

(NaPO3)(Na2HPO4)Na+ (m/z 266.8) show fragmentations involving neutral losses of Na2HPO4 and one or two NaPO3 moieties. The loss of two NaPO3 moieties leaves an ion looking like (NaOH)Na+. For precursor (NaPO3)(NaH2PO4)2(Na3PO4)Na+ (m/z 529.1) were losses of H2O, H3PO4, NaPO3 and NaH2PO4. The precursor (NaPO3)2(Na2HPO4)(Na3PO4)Na+ (m/z 532.7) involved neutral losses of NaPO3, Na2HPO4, and Na3PO4. For fragmentation in negative ion mode, the precursor (NaPO3)3(Na2HPO4)PO3− there were losses of Na2HPO4 and NaPO3. (NaPO3)2(NaH2PO4)2(Na2HPO4)PO3− fragmentation involved H2, NaPO3, NaH2PO4, and the disodium phosphate too. Noticeably there is a reduction of PO3− (m/z 78.9) to PO2− (m/z 63.1). The negative ion MS/MS spectrum of (H3PO4)H2PO4− (m/z 194.6) shows a very strong intensity at H2PO4− (96.8) with much smaller intensities for ions PO3− (79.0), (HPO3)H2PO4− (176.9), and (HPO3)PO3− (158.0).

Certain patterns emerge. NaPO3 molecules were more prominent in cluster ions when NaH2PO4 solutions were sprayed, while Na3PO4 moieities were prominent in ions in which Na2HPO4 were sprayed. In ions where NaOH was also part of the cluster, it is clear that pH increased during electrospray. What is clear is that if monosodium phosphate is used, the pH goes down in ESI, while in disodium phosphate, the pH goes up. pH change may result from two mechanisms. One is by the electrochemical process accompanying ESI. Solvent composition affects the potential and type of electrolytic events. It also depends on if there is positive mode, when oxidation is likely to occur, and possible reactions lowering pH. With negative ion mode, reduction is likely to occur and cause increases to pH.

In positive ion mode, where electrons are pulled from solution, water electrolysis occurs to produce protons: 2 H2O → O2 + 4 H+ + 4 e− where E0 = 1.229 V. The concentration of electrons can be computed with Faraday's law: [H+] = ielectrospray / nFvf, where the factors of electrospray current, molar equivalent of electrons to produce 1 mol H+ (n = 1 in this case), and F = 96,480 C mol−1. The factor vf is the solution flow rate. At 5 µl/min and current estimated to be 0.1 µA, the [H+] = 12.4 µM, producing a final pH 4.9, a decrease of 2.1 units. What about pH as solvent evaporates? If monosodium phosphate is 1 mM, and the ratio of undissociated salt molecules to solvent is ~1:55000, then the bulk pH solution wil be 5.1 if Kh = 1.3 × 10−12 and K2 = 6.3 × 10−8. As droplet evaporation occurs in hot gas, the solubiliity limit of 372 g per 100 ml at 100° would be reached at 30.9 M, and the calculated pH would decrease to ~2.86 (neglecting activity coefficients). The ratio would of undissociated salt to solvent molecules is ~1:2. For disodium phosphate, the solubility is 117 g / 100 ml at 80° and would be a concentration of 6.5 M, with undissociated salt to solvent molecues being ~1:8.

In computing the proton and hydroxide forming constants in the equilibrium reactions for phosphoric acid, dihydrogen phospate, monohydrogen phosphate, the dissociation of NaH2PO4 while hydrolysis is the dominant process for Na2HPO4. Thus a 50 mM NaH2PO4 will be acidic and a 0.05 M Na2HPO4 will be basic: their pH is 4.71 and 9.30, respectively. What happens as the solvent evaporates is that pH < 7 will decrease more, pH > 7 will increase more, and when pH = 7, there is no change. Relative proportions of the four phosphate species (H3PO4, H2PO4−, HPO42−, and PO43−) as a function of pH can be computed based on the equilibrium constants. When pH < 7, clearly the more acidic forms dominate (0, −1); at pH > 7, then the more alkaline forms (2−, 3−). When 50 mM monosodium is present, NaPO3, NaH2PO4, and H3PO4 dominate the clusters by 53 to 31 for positive ions and 43 to 18 for negative ions.

salt cluster ions, FD

Charles L, Pépin D, Gonnet F, Tabet J-C (2001) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 12, 1077-1084.

Effects of Liquid Phase Composition on Salt Cluster Formation in Positive Ion Mode Electrospray Mass Spectrometry: Implications for Clustering Mechanism in Electrospray

Another article on ion cluster formation, this time with potassium bromate. Positive ion mode was assessed, and from one to four cations (K+) were associated with the cluster. Effect of seven solvents differing in dielectric constant and viscosity were tested: lower dielectric and higher viscosity favored clustering, but limited the charge state. Reduction in cluster charge state during desolvation does not correlate with solvent cation affinity. Ion distribution observations show that with increasing cluster size comes increasing charge state.

principal components analysis (PCA), clustering, gene expression analysis

Yeung KY, Ruzzo WL (2001) Bioinformatics 17, 763-774.

Principal Component Analysis for Clustering Gene Expression Data

ABSTRACT. MOTIVATION: There is a great need to develop analytical methodology to analyze and to exploit the information contained in gene expression data. Because of the large number of genes and the complexity of biological networks, clustering is a useful exploratory technique for analysis of gene expression data. Other classical techniques, such as principal component analysis (PCA), have also been applied to analyze gene expression data. Using different data analysis techniques and different clustering algorithms to analyze the same data set can lead to very different conclusions. Our goal is to study the effectiveness of principal components (PCs) in capturing cluster structure. Specifically, using both real and synthetic gene expression data sets, we compared the quality of clusters obtained from the original data to the quality of clusters obtained after projecting onto subsets of the principal component axes. RESULTS: Our empirical study showed that clustering with the PCs instead of the original variables does not necessarily improve, and often degrades, cluster quality. In particular, the first few PCs (which contain most of the variation in the data) do not necessarily capture most of the cluster structure. We also showed that clustering with PCs has different impact on different algorithms and different similarity metrics. Overall, we would not recommend PCA before clustering except in special circumstances.

mass spectrometry, carbohydrates

Harvey DJ (2001) Proteomics 1, 311-328.

Identification of Protein-Bound Carbohydrates by Mass Spectrometry

REVIEW. The higher eukaryotes have three types of glycans. N-linked glycans modify Asn using N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) on the motif NX(S/T), where X is any residue but Pro. It also modifies proteins via Ser or Thr in an O-linked glycan. There are also oligosaccharides that modify glycosylphosphatidylinositol: GPI anchors. In Gram-positive and archaea bacteria, glucose attaches to Asn, galactose to Thr, GlcNAc to Asn, rhamnose to Asn, and Glc or Gal to Tyr. The N-linked sugars typically form a tri-mannosyl chitobiose core with antennae attaching to each of the two outer mannoses. Antennae extend with N-acetyllactosamine (1 or more) and then terminate with sialic acid or α-linked Gal. Three general types of N-linked glycans are usual. A high-mannose in which only mannose form the antenna. Hybrid glycans are those in which one antenna is processed to remove the mannose. Complex glycans represent processing of both antenna. O-linked glycans are more diverse, from monosaccharides to large sulfated polysaccharides, and no common core or consensus.

As for structural analysis techniques, NMR does an almost complete job although it is less sensitive than MS and chromatographic analysis. Proteomic scale samples are insufficient for NMR workup. The steps usually involved are determining the sites of glycosylation on the polypeptide, determining the extent of occupation (occupancy) at each site, determining structures and amounts of each glycan at each site, and determing total count of individual species (glycoforms). Trypsin and other polypeptide digestion techniques are used in the first two determinations. The third determination is done on glycopeptides or released glycans. The last determination is difficult because of the complexity of mixtures.

MS can do pretty much anything but separate isomers. However it can be combined with HPLC to an ESI source to get glycan profiles. More sensitive than MS on an HPLC system is fluorescence detection of tagged glycans. Before 1988, MS work made use of electron ionization, typically with GC-based separations. Intact glycans are too large to be examined directly. In-beam EI has been used for large glycolipids. FAB was popular for intact glycans, but sensitivity is reduced by high matrix background.

Neutral sugars can be analyzed in MALDI MS as [M + Na]+ ions in the 1 pmole range. Glycans with masses less than 1 kDa will show less intensity than the larger glycans. In both positive and negative ion modes, acidic glycans show a lower signal than do neutral sugars. Other peaks in the spectra may result from sodium or potassium salts as well as adducts of the free acidic sugar. With negative ion spectra a proton is lost from anionic groups. Sialic acid groups are unstable and decompose in flight. Linear mode analysis may be better than reflectron mode since post-source decay is more significant in the latter.

DHB is the more common matrix producing strong [M + Na]+ ions. Super DHB is 9:1 mix of DHB:2-OH-5-methoxyDHB. 1-hydroxyquinolone also is an additive that has some effect. Recrystallization of sample from EtOH has worked as well. The idea is to reduce crystal size, and EtOH may promote mixing of glycan with matrix. Spermine addition may improve negative ion spectra of anionic glycans by binding salt. Other matrices: 5-chloro-2-mercaptobenzithiazole, various β-carbolines, 3-aminoquinoline, arabinosazone, and 2-(4′-hydroxyphenylazo)benzoic acid. 3-AQ supposedly gives lower background, increased resolution and is better for sialylated sugars than DHB. HABA gives good fragment ions but also produces many matrix ions up to m/z 1000, making it impossible for small glycan analysis. 6-aza-2-thiothymine increases sensitivity for anionic glycans.

Human urinary EPO analysis shows that the glycoprotein has fucosylated tetra-antennary glycans on Asn-38 and -83 but mixtures of fucosylated bi-, tri-, and tetra-antennary glycans on Asn-24. CD59 shows significant heterogeneity with 130 N-linked glycans having up to 25 monosaccharides.

ESI-MS is less sensitive than MALDI to glycans, particularly larger ones. Often permethylation (with diazomethane) is useful. Capillaries are charged at 3000 v in 1:1 MeOH/MeCN:water. Underivated glycans show [M + Na]+ ions.

To determine site occupancy, glycopeptides need to be generated, usually trypsinizing reductively alkylated protein. LC-ESI-MS is then applied on the digest. Oxonium ions such as HexNAc (m/z 204), hexose (m/z 163), sialic acid (m/z 292), or Hex-HexNAc (m/z 366) can be used to identify sugars.

To release glycans from N- and O-linked glycoproteins, hydrazine is effective, either manually or with automated equipment. O-linked are more sensitive at 60°, and N-linked require 95°. The peptide bond is destroyed in the process. Partial cleavage of acyl groups (N-acetylamino sugars, sialic acids) occurs as well.

Use of alkali releases O-linked glycans through beta-elimination. The presence of sodium borohydride can be used to reduce them to alditols as the reducing sugars are unstable at high pH. Disadvantages are that borohydride releases some N-linked glycans, the reducing sugar terminus is reduced to prevent tagging with chromophores, and O-acetyl groups are lost. Hydrazine at 65° under anhydrous conditions overcomes these problems, and O-linked glycans can be released by heating at 45° for 18 h in 50% aqueous hydrazine with 0.2 M triethylamine. The hydrazones are acetylatd and incubated in aqueous acetone 24 h at 55° to release glycan.

Thin (0.75 mm) 12.5% and 17% SDS-PAGE gels were used in a system that employed glycosidase PNGase F to remove N-linked sugars. Glycan is extracted in water and passed through AG-3/AG-50 mixed bed resin and C18 packed into gel loader tips. MALDI-MS or HPLC is then used to analyze. Removal of anions (by AG-3) was helpful for MALDI although it removes acidic glycans. Methylation prior to ion-exchanges is helpful to keep sialic and uronic acid sugars. Graphitized carbon can be used to clean up sulfated sugars.

For looking at the structure of glycans, a number of chemical methods are essential. Methanolysis produces methyl glycosides which can be analyzed by GC/MS as trimethylsilyl or acetyl derivatives. Alternatively hydrolysis to monosaccharides followed by high pH anion-exchange chromatography (HPAEC) coupled with pulsed amperometric detection (PAD) is also possible. For branch analysis, free hydroxyls must be permethylated after reducing end reduction. Hydrolysis to monosaccharides and reduction to alditols is done. These are then analyzed by GC/MS.

Additional structural analysis is by specific glycosidases. Digestion is probably best done in a matrix or sequentially. Mass spectrometry prior to digestion might help in glycosidase selection.

Periodate oxidation can provide information about linkage, as it is specific for cis-diols. Dialdehydes are created that are reduced with sodium borodeuteride and then methylated. Product mass then differs in a way that reflects linkage. If an interal monosaccharide has link at C1 and C4, there will be cleavage at C2 and C3. Linkage at C6 will result in peroxidation at C2, C3, and C4, with loss of C3.

Polysaccharides treated with acetic anhydride, acetic acid, and sulfuric acid in a (10:10:1) mixture results in peracetylation and cleavage of glycosidic bonds. 1−>6 branches are most susceptible, while 1−>2 and 1−>3 are more resistant. α anomers are also more susceptible than β anomers.

Fragmentation spectra may be useful in determining structure. The particular type of ion formed ([M + H]+, [M + Na]+), the charge state, collision energy, and time for fragmentation are all factors determining the type of dissociation. Mass changes may result from loss of adduct. Typical cleavages will be intermonosaccharidal, but not always. A nomenclature has been developed by Domon and Costello similar to peptide ions (see table)

Fragment Ion Nomenclature for Glycan Monosaccharides
Ion Bonds Cleaved Reducing/Nonreducing End?
s,tAn any two cross ring bonds Non-reducing end ion
Bn glycosidic bond, non-reducing side monosaccharide Non-reducing end ion
Cn glycosidic bond, reducing side monosaccharide Non-reducing end ion
s,tXn any two cross ring bonds Reducing end ion
Yn glycosidic bond, non-reducing side monosaccharide Reducing end ion
Zn glycosidic bond, reducing side monosaccharide Reducing end ion

The subscript n indicates the numbering of the rings from the non-reducing end if they are A, B, or C, ions, and from the reducing end if they are X, Y, or Z ions. The s,t superscript on the cross-ring ion indicates the two bonds of the ring that are broken in forming the ion. When fragments are from branched chains, Greek letters are used to designate ions, with α being that of the largest chain. Fragmentation is more easily achieved in protonated than in metal cationized species, and in metal cationized species the order of easier-to-harder decomposition is Li+ > Na+ > K+ > Cs+. Metal-cationized sugars produce more cross-ring fragments (particularly Li+). PSD spectra reveal that CHCA matrix protonates the nitrogen atom of 2-AP efficiently, and the [M+H]+ ion fragments only into a Y series of ions because of charge localization on the reducing terminus. DHB produces a [M+Na]+ with no localized charge, and this gives a mixture of B and Y ions with some cross-ring fragments.

PSD. Matrix selection is quite important. Some matrices are hot in that readily produce extensive fragmentation, but are less efficient with respect to ionization efficiency. CHCA is better at causing PSD but does not ionize carbohydrates as well as DHB. Typical tens of pmoles are necessary to see PSD spectra in neutral glycans. Acidic glycans more readily fragment, giving strong signals when sialic acid or 2-keto-3-deoxyoctonate are lost. Some even use linear mode to record spectra so that uncharged fragments can be seen. With reflectron spectra, the data must be collected in segments (different mass ranges) to produce a complete spectrum, and this is inefficient in terms of time and sample consumed.

ISD. In-source decay (ISD) is the prompt fragmentation or rapid decay occurring in the source which gives fragments focused with their parent ions. These are typically seen in FAB but not so much in MALDI spectra. They would be present in MALDI where acidic carbohydrates are rich in the sample or if there is a time-lag focusing feature (delayed extraction) used to increase resolution. ISD on an ESI-MS is controlled by adjustments to the sample cone voltage.

CID. This is essentially a directed fragmentation, and as such is much more reproducible. Today more work is done with an ESI-QToF using a high cone voltage where [M+Na]+ are the major species with complex spectra involving glycosidic and cross-ring fragment ions. Only 5 pmol are necessary. At lower cone voltages, the spectra are dominated by z = 2 ions, with hydrogen as adduct, and the fragments are largely glycosidic cleavage ions in CID. When tertiary amines are present there is an intense z = 2 as a result of amine protonation, and only 500 fmol sample is required. Sialylated glycans might benefit from permethylation or methyl ester formation to achieve sensitivity. When ESI in the high mass range is not useful, consider using high energy CID spectra from glycans in a MALDI-MS/MS system.

Generally carbohydrate fragmentation spectra are heavily represented by B and Y ions, indicating fragmentation on the glycosidic bond. This is more intense when the sugar is adjacent to sialic acid, and cleavages adjacent to HexNAc residues are favored over losses of hexose. N-linked glycans show prominent B-type fragments when the GlcNAc reducing termnal residue is lost, or when ever reducing terminal derivative or fucose is lost.

Küster B, Krogh TN, Mortz E, Harvey DJ (2001) Proteomics 1, 350-361.

Glycosylation Analysis of Gel-Separated Proteins

REVIEW.
ABSTRACT Beyond the identification of proteins involved in a particular physiological situation, many aspects of proteomics require more detailed characterization of the proteins involved. Post-translational modifications (PTMs) of proteins are a common means to target proteins, regulate their activities and to mediate communication between proteins and cells. Owing to the much higher analytical complexity of glycan analysis compared to e.g. protein identification, PTM analysis in general and glycosylation analysis in particular is largely neglected in proteomics. In this review, the current technological status of global and site-specific glycosylation analysis of gel-separated proteins is described and the way in which the available technology can be employed in proteomics is critically discussed.

Advances in delayed extraction MALDI-MS, nano-ESI-MS and HPLC with fluorescence detection have improved analysis. Glycosylation analysis typically requires very pure protein, typically several chromatographic steps if the protein is in solution. Recombinants do not require as much purification, but the problem is that biologically relevant glycosylation is not really achieved in recombinants, so the protein in its natural state is required. For large membrane glycoproteins, 1-D SDS-PAGE is the one way of trying to purify. Attempts to use 2-D gels often generate smears, making handling more difficult.

Bakhtiar R, Nelson RW (2001) Molec. Pharmacol. 60, 405-415.

Mass Spectrometry of the Proteome

MINIREVIEW.

MudPIT, 2DLC-MS/MS, LC-MS/MS

Washburn MP, Wolters D, Yates 3rd JR (2001) Nat. Biotechnol. 19, 242-247.

Large-scale analysis of the yeast proteome by multidimensional protein identification technology

Multidimensional protein identification technology (MudPIT) is reproducible chromatographically and in the final protein list. MS/MS data was generated from three different samples and assigned to 5540 peptides to identify 1484 proteins in the S. cerevisiae genome. 3 fractions represented soluble fraction, lightly washed insoluble, and heavily washed insoluble. Lysis was in 0.31 M sodium fluoride, 3.45 mM sodium vanadate, 250 mM sodium chloride, 12 mM EDTA, 50 mM Tris, and 0.14 M sodium phosphate dibasic, pH 7.6. Glass beads were added and extraction in BioSpec Mini-BeadBeater (see method in text). The pellet was washed in PBS (1.4 mM NaCl, 0.27 mM KCl, 1 mM disodium phosphate, and 0.18 mM dibasic potassium phosphate, pH 7.4) by vortexing 2 min. After spinning 14000 rpm 10 min in Eppendorf microfuge, one of these pellets (lightly washed insoluble) was then dried in SpeedVac SC110 (Savant). Another pellet was then washed three more times in this way, and was called heavily washed insolube. Soluble samples are adjusted to pH 8.5 with 1 M ammonium bicarbonate and then protein assayed according to Bradford. Samples are treated to urea (to 8 M), reduced with DTT (to 1 mM), and carboxyamidomethylated with 10 mM iodoacetamide. Endoproteinase Lys-C is used for the digestion of the soluble fraction.

Whole cell lysates (from yeast) are loaded separately on to biphasic microcapillary column and the column inserted into the instrumental setup. Elution from the experimental setup is with salt gradient on to the RP phase, and then from a RP into an ESI-IonTrap MS. A 4-way union permits HPLC gradient in opposite the fitting of the SCX/RP column, and a voltage wire opposite a waste/splitter port. The voltage behind the column supplies the ESI.

The yeast proteome was searched against the MIPS database which provides data on proteins according to cell localization. The two insoluble fractions identified may organellar proteins. Heavily washed insoluble represented nuclear, mitochondrial, ER, PM, and Golgi membrane proteins. The majority of proteins found for the vacuole were seen in the lightly washed insoluble fraction, including H+-ATPase domains VMA4 (CAI=0.27) and VMA5 (CAI=0.24). The analysis showed that every major functional category and protein class was represented in the data. 32 protein kinases, rarely seen in 2D-PAGE, including MAP kinase signal pathway kinases STE7, STE11, STE20, and FUS3 were identified. Low abundance proteins such as 45 transcription factors including SW1-SNF complex SNF5, SWI4, and SWI6. With 6216 open reading frames in the yeast genome, 83% have CAI values between 0-0.20. Most proteins found by 2D-PAGE could identify few proteins with CAI<0.20, indicating that it is likely incapable of detecting low abundance proteins. MudPIT found a proteome in which 791 or 53.3% of proteins had CAI<0.20. 1347 peptides from the 791 proteins were identified that had a CAI<0.20., an average of 1.7 peptides per protein. The peptides per protein increases with increasing CAI. CAI is considered a predictor of protein abundance, and it is not difficult to find the most abundant of proteins.

This study found 72 of 231 possible peripheral membrane proteins predicted in the Yeast Proteome Database. 23 from the heavily washed insoluble fraction and 14 from the lightly washed were uniquely identified. MIPS database has searched entire yeast genome for predicted transmembrane domains numbering from 1 to 20 using criteria of Klein et al. and Goffeau et al. 697 proteins in S. cerevisiae genome have ≥3 predicted Tm domains, and this analysis found 131 or 19%. Of the 131, 44 were in the heavily washed insoluble, and 33 in the lightly washed insoluble. Several had low abundance based on CAI.

Puig O, Caspary F, Rigaut G, Rutz B, Bouveret E, Bragado-Nilsson E, Wilm M, Séraphin B (2001) Methods 24, 218-229.

The Tandem Affinity Purification (TAP) Method: A General Procedure of Protein Complex Purification

TAP method involves fusion of the TAP tag to the target protein and then placing in the host cell or organism. Expression should be controlled to natural levels or the protein associates with nonnatural partners (heat shock proteins, proteasome).

The TAP tag consists of two IgG binding domains of S. aureus protein A and a calmodulin binding peptide (CBP) separated by a TEV protease cleavage site. A C-terminal TAP tag had been described previously and this report describes an N-terminal tag. The ProtA binding domain must be located at the extreme terminus, whether at the C- or N-end.

The material is passed over an IgG affinity column, washed thoroughly. The TEV protease is required to elute the material. The eluate is then incubated with calmodulin-coated beads in the presence of calcium. Washing removes the TEV protease and other contaminants. The bound material is released by adding EGTA.

In deciding how to make the fusion protein with TAP tag, consider that there may be a need to put the tag on the N- and C-terminus to see which one works.

Tonge R, Shaw J, Middleton B, Rowlinson R, Rayner S, Young J, Pognan F, Hawkins E, Currie I, Davison M (2001) Proteomics 1, 377-396.

Validation and Development of Fluorescence Two-Dimensional Differential Gel Electrophoresis Proteomics Technology

ABSTRACT Fluorescence two-dimensional differential gel electrophoresis (2-D DIGE *) is a new development in protein detection for two-dimensional gels. Using mouse liver homogenates (control and paracetamol (N-acetyl-p-aminophenol, APAP)-treated), we have determined the quantitative variation in the 2-D DIGE process and established statistically valid thresholds for assigning quantitative changes between samples. Thresholds were dependent on normalised spot volume, ranged from approximately 1.2 fold for large volume spots to 3.5 fold for small volume spots and were not markedly affected by the particular cyanine dye combination or by multiple operators carrying out the dye labelling reaction. To minimise the thresholds, substantial user editing was required when using ImageMaster 2D-Elite software. The difference thresholds were applied to the test system and quantitative protein differences were determined using replicate gels of pool samples and single gels from multiple individual animals (control vs treated in each gel). Throughout, the differences revealed with a particular cyanine dye combination were mirrored almost without exception when the dye combination was reversed. Both pool and individual sample analyses provided unique data to the study. The inter-animal response variability in inbred mice was approximately nine times that contributed by the 2-D DIGE process. A number of the most frequently observed protein changes resulting from APAP-treatment were identified by mass spectrometry. Several of these can be rationalised based on available data on the mechanism of APAP hepatotoxicity but others cannot, indicating that proteomics can provide further insights into the biochemical basis of APAP toxicity.

Mice were treated with 500 mg/kg APAP for 4 h and liver sections examined under light microscopy.

Gobom J, Schuerenberg M, Mueller M, Theiss D, Lehrach H, Nordhoff E (2001) Anal. Chem. 73, 434-438.

α-Cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic Acid Affinity Sample Preparation. A Protocol for MALDI-MS Peptide Analysis in Proteomics

High throughput sample analysis by MALDI MS requires some adaptations. Spectral reproducibility is enhanced when sample diameter falls below 250 µm. Pre-structured sample supports have been previously prepared with a strongly lyophobic (solvent-repelling) Teflon coating and an array of gold spots as hydrophilic sample anchors. Each sample spot drops onto one anchor. In this study, the sample supports are coated with ~5 µm thick layer of Teflon-like composite and an array of 384 circular interruptons having 400 µm diameter. The underlying stainless steel surface is the anchor.

The CHCA surface affinity sample prep method resembles the fast evaporation method such than an acidified, aqueous sample is deposited on a microcrystalline surface of CHCA. But in this method, sample deposited is not allowed to dry, but is removed after a short contact time on the sample surface. The following steps are done:

  1. Dispense 100 µl of 100 mg/ml CHCA in 90% acetone/0.005% TFA near one of the short edges of the support.
  2. Place a Teflon (PTFE) rod horizontally across the sample plate surface in contact with the matrix solution in order to spread it across the length of the rod to create a liquid film between rod and sample support.
  3. Draw the rod across the sample support, dragging the matrix solution along, to let each anchor absorb a small volume of matrix.

If only a small number of samples is desired

  1. Take a narrow pipet tip (GELoader, Eppendor) and immerse in a 1 mg/ml CHCA in 99% acetone / 0.2% TFA) and let capillary force aspirate it.
  2. Let the pipet tip touch an anchor, to deposit a small amount of matrix.

To deposit the peptides on the surface, acidify peptides in minimum 0.2% TFA

Beck JL, Colgrave ML, Ralph SF, Sheil MM (2001) Mass Spec. Rev. 20, 61-87.

Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry of Oligonucleotide Complexes with Drugs, Metals, and Proteins

REVIEW. Others have reviewed the use of ESI and MALDI for nucleic acid analysis (see McCloskey & Crain, 1992; Limbach, Crain, McCloskey, 1995; Nordhoff, Kirpekar, Roepstorff, 1996; Crain and McCloskey, 1998). Noncovalent interactions using ESI-MS have also been done: protein-protein, DNA-protein, DNA-drug, and Ab-Ag complexes. Particularly DNA-metal ion interactions since they are criticla in transcription and replication.

Antitumor drugs are useful and bind directly to DNA. Some drugs are designed using ADEPT or GDEPT to promote binding action. Drug design for DNA binders starts with sequence specificity, while also considering major or minor groove binding, determining mono- vs. bifunctional binding, and compare intrastrand vs. interstrand crosslinking for bifunctionals.

Alkylation is a natural event affecting carcinogenesis, mutagenesis. It occurs preferentially on N and O atoms in purines (N7 of guanine, the most nucleophilic). Reports have come out of the use of electron capture negative chemical ionization, thermospray, FAB, and API to characterize adducts with bases or nucleosides. ESI has been used to characterize addutts formed from malondialdeyde reaction with deoxynucleosides. Tamoxifen activation was studied in in rats, mice, and humand with 32P-postlabeled material and LC-MS.

Information about sequence is important because detailed information on ligand-DNA complexes by NMR and XRD requires shorter target sequences. Variations in local structure, (frayed ends in short sequences, higher order structure in longer ones) and the requirements for large amounts of sample (NMR) or difficulties in crystallization (XRD) make these techniques difficult.

Preliminary studies reveal that MS/MS spectra of alkylated oligos show a highly specific fragmentation. Hedamcyin (covalent) adducts were made with two different 6-mers. G akylation makes glycosidic bond labile, with depurination and then cleavage of 3'-C-O bond next to akylated residue. This compares much better than the unmodfified oligo MS/MS spectra. Electron-withdrawing groups on the base enhance fragmentation of the 3'-C-O to give w ions.

A number of potential binding sites exist on DNA. Electrostatic interaction between cationic ligands and polyanionic backbone. Intercalation in the planar rings between bases. Hydrogen bonding with bases through the minor groove. Many drugs have combinations: safranine T binds by intercalation and electrostatic interaction. In fact the general feature of intercalators is planarity like the bases and cationicity. Ethidium bromide, daunomycin are simple intercalators. Nogalamycin is a threading intercalator. Ditercalinium are bis-intercalators.

The minor groove is a preferred association because they have torsional freedom permitting twist complemetary to minor groove. Minor groove ligands interact with 3-4 bases in sequence-dependent manner, usually with A and/or T combinations, as alignment of hydrogen bond donors and acceptors on the ligand with those on the bases in the minor groove. AT-rich regions have larger electrostatic potential, strengthening the interaction, and the ligand has a positive charge on one or both ends.

The stability of DNA duplexes is improved by the presence of monocations in relatively high concentrations to minimize the repulsion between anionic backbones. But high salt concentrations cause ion suppression and to dispersion of the ion current among multiple adduct peaks for each species. Oliog length and sequence are important. Short oligos (≤ 10-mer) have been used to simplify data interpretation and control cost. But this is often shorter than a turn of the helix (requires 10 bp).

Drug studies have been done with ss DNA as well. Distamycin A binds to 14-mer self-complementary ds DNA in 1:1 or 2:1 ratios. This was followed by other minor groove binders (pentamidine and Hoechst 33258) and showed that non self-complementary oligos provide advantages.

Few studies have shown noncovalent interactions because of harsh ESI conditions do not promote them. Generally low capillary and cone voltages and lower source and probe temperatures. In one case DNA (5'-d[GGCTAGCC]2-3') was annealed in the presence of intercalator (nogalamycin) in 100 mM ammonium acetate. Just before analysis, it is diluted 10-100 fold to get away from signal suppression. Recent studies done with minor-groove binders and intercalators using non-self-complementary 12-mers: minor-groove binders showed sequence-specific binding but the intercalators did not. Studies with UV-vis specttroscopy and ESI showed that melting studies with minor-groove binders and intercalators was the same in solution and gas phase.

Metal ions complex with DNA in many ways. The antitumor agent cisplatin Pt(NH3)2Cl2 forms a covalent bond between the platinum metal and the N7 of purines.

Toby GG, Golemis EA (2001) Methods 24, 201-217.

Using the Yeast Interaction Trap and Other Two-Hybrid-Based Approaches To Study Protein-Protein Interactions

REVIEW. The popularity of the yeast two-hybrid system in the decade since its first description is indicated by more than 3000 articles. The technique is rapid, inexpensive, simple to perform. Two observations in the 1980s led to the development of the yeast two-hybrid system. One was the generation of a hybrid protein that could serve to activate transcription. A hybrid of the E. coli LexA repressor DNA binding domain and the yeast Gal4p transcriptional activation domain was expressed in S. cerevisiae and the chimera could induce transcription when lexA operator sites were present. Another is that transcriptional activators do not have to bind to DNA to work: they can interact with other proteins that themselves bind to DNA. Suppose protein X is translationally fused to a DNA-binding domain (DB) of a transcription factor; this is the bait protein. A second hybrid, a fusion of known protein Y or a library of proteins, is made to the transcriptional activation domain (AD); this is the prey protein. The bait must interact with the prey in order to bring DB and AD together to activate transcription. Usually the transcribed gene is a reporter (lacZ on XGal), or auxotrophic genes (HIS3, LEU2) are used to permit growth in medium with no His or Leu. The original yeast two-hybrid system used the Gal4p transcriptional activator. The LexA DNA-binding domain and either viral VP16 or bacterial B42 sequences act as the activation domain.

The system has been used to look at regulation of telomere structure, identification of substrate-kinase interaction, homodimerization of gag proteins, heterodimerization of myogenin with E2A products. Analyses that were not suitable were strong transcriptional activators, extracellular proteins, and membrane-associated proteins.

Recent work has seen the development of a dual-bait system. Two independent baits are fused to different DNA-binding domains (e.g., LexA and cI).

Dell A, Morris HR (2001) Science 291, 2351-2356.

Glycoprotein Structure Determination by Mass Spectrometry

REVIEW. About 25 years earlier the first glycoprotein was determined by MS in which multiple Thr O-linked disaccharides were found in antifreeze proteins. Electron impact and chemical ionization were used on permethylated samples, allowing volatization and β-elimination release. Advanced soft ionization methods are used now (FAB, ESI, MALDI) although permethylation is a strategy.

O- and N-type glycosylation are the two main types. Mammalian N-type glycosylation feature a trimannosyl-chitobiose core derived from Glc3Man9GlcNAc2 add cotranslationally. ER-resident glucosidases then trim to produce Man9GlcNAc2 which is further processed.

Herbert BR, Harry JL, Packer NH, Gooley AA, Pedersen SK, Williams KL (2001) Trends Biotechnol. 19, S3-S10.

What place for polyacrylamide in proteomics?

ABSTRACT. Two-dimensional polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (2D-PAGE) continues to deliver high quality protein resolution and dynamic range for the proteomics researcher. To remain as the preferred method for protein separation and characterization, several key steps need to be implemented to ensure quality sample preparation and speed of analysis. Here, we describe the progress made towards establishing 2D-PAGE as the optimal separation tool for proteomics research.

Sinha P, Poland J, Schnölzer M, Rabilloud T (2001) Proteomics 1, 835-840.

A new silver staining apparatus and procedure for matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization-time of flight analysis of proteins after two-dimensional electrophoresis

Gels were placed in a special staining apparatus for staining constructed with plexiglas platforms with perforations or grids. The gels are clamped into the system to prevent movement during shaking. An orbital shaker shakes the entire body. There is a drain to allow removal of 8 liters of solution (enough for 10 gels) in about 1 min.

Proteins were randomly excised from silver-stained gels and cleaned on ZipTip C18 then analyzed on MALDI using Reflex II (db search is of NCBInr db with ProFound algorithm and MS-Fit. Coomassie gels were overloaded with same sample and excised proteins showed identical MS spectra.

Several silver stains have been attempted and compatibility with MS is a problem. Schevchenko et al method is often used. Fixation is in MeOH/acetic acid and then acid is removed with MeOH wash, sensitized in thiosulfate, treated with AgNO3 then reduction with HCHO in sodium carbonate. This is a rapid (1 h) stain especially with thin gels. Thiosulfate helps to produce a clear background and treatment with silver nitrate is at 4° to avoid oxidation reactions. There is 1.6 ng detection limit for BSA.

This stain is the most sensitive to date (100 times more sensitive than Coomassie). Fixation is done 1 h + overnight or 4 × 30 min in 30% EtOH/10% acetic acid. Gels are soaked 45 min in 3 g/L potassium tetrathionate, 0.5 M potassium acetate, 30% EtOH. Gels are rinsed in 6 × 10 min water. Impregnation is done with 0.2% silver nitrate for 1-2 h. Very brief (5-15 s) rinsing in water is done. Development is with 3% potassium carbonate with 300 µl formaldehyde and 125 µl 10% sodium thiosulfate pentahydrate (hypo) per liter for up to 45 min. Reaction is stopped with 30 min soaking in 40 g Tris and 20 ml acetic acid per liter. Gels are rinsed in water before excision for MS.

Rabilloud T, Strub J-M, Luche S, van Dorsselaer A, Lunardi J (2001) Proteomics 1, 699-704.

A comparison between Sypro Ruby and ruthenium II tris (bathophenanthroline disulfonate) as fluorescent stains for protein detection in gels

Steinberg TH, Pretty On Top K, Berggren KN, Kemper C, Jones L, Diwu Z, Haugland RP, Patton WF (2001) Proteomics 1, 841-855.

Rapid and Simple Single Nanogram Detection of Glycoproteins in Polyacrylamide Gels and On Electroblots

Glycans on glycoproteins vary in weight from 1% in cytokeratin-18 to as much as 80% in mucin. N-glycosidic bonds occur through Asn, but O-glycans bind to proteins through the -OH group of Ser, Thr, HO-Lys, and HO-Pro, and through the glycosyl phosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor found on the COOH terminus of some proteins with the right signal sequence (however, removed upon attachment). Glycosylation has a great many biological effects: immunogenicity, clearance rate from blood, solubility, stability, and protease resistance. In addition it is involved in cell adhesion.

Methods to detect glycoproteins in gels and electroblots have proved very insensitive. Chromogenic detection of periodic acid-treaed with a Schiff stain like acid fuchsin has been tried. Also digoxigenin hydrazide after oxidation, followed with anti-digoxigenin Ab conjugated to alkaline phosphatase. Also use of biotin hydrazide conjugated to HRP or AP-streptavidin has been used. Alcian Blue staining has been done for acidic glycoproteins.

A new fluorescent hydrazide is used on PAS-treated proteins; it does not require a reduction step (sodium metabisulfite or sodium borohydride). The Pro-Q Emerald 300 was developed to be compatiable with usual UV transillumination sources. The dye absorbs maximally at 288 nm (while Sypro Ruby absorbs with a major peak at 282 nm and a broader peak at 470 nm), and so it can be excited by mid-range UV (UV-B). It emits at 533 nm (Sypro Ruby emits at 613 nm). Green illumination can be visualized with fluorescein band-pass emission filter and the Sypro Ruby can be controlled with Texas Red band-pass emission. Any Polaroid or CCD camera can visualize either fluorescent dye.

Comparison to other hydrazide detections. As the chemistry of hydrazide-based analysis is the same, the question is of sensitivity. Serial 2-fold diltuions of Candy Cane MW markers (mix of glycosylated and unglycosylated proteins) were run on SDS-PAGE and EITHER stained directly with the gel stain kit or proteins stained with the blot kit after electroblotting. The flourescent stain for the gel kit proved to be 150-200 times more sensitive than colorimetric acid fuchsin sulfite-based method, which varied with the glycoprotein evaluated. Alexa Fluor 350 hydrazide had 5-15-fold poor sensitivity that Pro-Q Emerald 300, and also showed nonspecific staining of unglycosylated proteins. Other fluorescent dyes evaluated include hydrazides of Alexa Fluor 488, Cascade Blue, dapoxyl sulfonyl, and Marina Blue, which all had worse nonspecific staining. Dansyl hydrazine had good specificity but 4-16-fold less sensitivity, not to mention that it requies heating gels in acidified DMSO.

Run TWO gels at the same time with the sample. One sample will be treated with periodic acid and the other will NOT be. This must be done to control possible artifacts (non-specific staining). Perhaps some proteins also have inherent fluorescence.

On PVDF blots, the Pro-Q Emerald dye is 8-10 times more than sensitive than acid- fuchsin sulfite methods. Biotin-hydradize with ALP-conjugated strepavidin and digoxigenin hydrazide with anti-Dig-conjugated ALP had similar sensitivity as the Pro-Q Emerald 300 dye, but 6-18-fold less sensitivity than stains in gels. The biotin and digoxigenin-hydrazide methods resulted in nonspecific staining of carbonic anhydrase, which lacks carbohydrate chains.

Other methods require a following reduction step to stabilize or visualize the chromphoric molecule. Pro-Q Emerald does lose its fluorescence 20-40% after storage in 3% acetic acid for 18-48 h. This is not prevented by using reduction steps, indicating that this occurs because of an instability in the molecule itself rather than rehydrolysis.

Quantitation. Several glycoproteins were titrated: α-2 macroglobulin (9-10% CHO), glucose oxidase (12-13% CHO), α-1 acidic glycoprotein (38-42% CHO), avidin (7% CHO), fetuin (22% CHO), and ovalbumin (3-4% CHO). All glycoproteins except ovalbumin and α-2 macroglobulin could be quantified in a 500-1000 fold range, while the linear range of the other two was about 125.

Comparison to Lectin. Ovalbumin could be detected using ConA and WGA but many glycoproteins were not. Con A binds to unsubstitued and 2-O-substituted α-mannosyl residues, while WGA bind with high affinity to tri-N-acetylglucosamine and sialic acid residues. Horseradish peroxidase is illuminated with Con A but not WGA, while fetuin is observed by WGA but not Con A. WGA detects α-1 acid glycoprotein (42 kDa), but Con A does not. Ovomucoid and ovotransferrin (28 and 76 kDa) are also detected by WGA, but not Con A. Ovalbumin is a mix of oligomannose, hybrid and multi-antennary complex N-linked glycans, and so it is a good subtrate for both lectins. α-1 acid glycoprotein has N-linked complex type heteroglycans present as tri- and tetra-antennary structures, and fetuin is mostly sialylated tri-antennary N-linked glycans and also sialylated O-linked glycans, which explains why Con A does not detect these. HRP is generally small, neutral N-linked glycans, usually not bound well by WGA.

Comparing blotting to direct gel staining, the latter is more sensitive since blotting represents an extra step wherein yields are reduced. Moreover glycoproteins transfer poorly to membranes. But with blotting there is the additional advantage in that multiple immunochemical analyses are possible. Caution: any step that uses periodate oxidation effectively destroys the sugar and binds it to the Pro-Q E300 molecule, and so lectins lose their affinity as the structure is destroyed.

Endoglycosidase F, Endo-O-glycosidase, and sialidase A were used in a cocktail to enzymatically deglycosylate several pure glycoproteins. The untreated and treated glycoproteins are then run in SDS-PAGE. SYPRO Ruby staining shows that treated proteins had a faster mobility shift with loss of the green flourescence seen with Pro-Q staining. The exception was HRP, in that it did not show a mobility shift but still showed loss of green fluorecence. HRP has an α(1,3)-fucosylated Asn N-acetylglucosamine linkage resistant to these enyzmes.

In gel staining SYPRO Ruby quenches Pro-Q 300 Emerald fluorescence, and so simultaneous visualization is not possible. For this reason, Pro-Q staining should precede SYPRO Ruby staining. With electroblotting, simultaneous visualization of red and green signal is possible. Hardware/equipment that does well (1024 × 1024 pixel systems with 16-bit intensities) incude Roche Lumi-Imager, Bio-Rad Fluor-S Max Multi-Imager, Perkin-Elmer 1442 Multiwavelenght Fluorimager, Fuji FLA-3000G Fluorescent Image Analyzer, and Genomic Solutions BioImage Analyzer. Other post-Pro-Q 300 staining could include Coomassie Brilliant Blue and its colloidal form and Ag staining.

Other Pro-Q Emerald Uses: LPS. Besides glycoproteins, PQE-300 can be used to check any glycoconjugates. All that is necessary is that it be periodate oxidizable. This stain was compared to an alkaline silver diammine stain (superior to many other stains, including acidic AgNO3, zinc-imidazole, SYPRO Orange and Ruby staining). The sensitivity of the PQE300 stain was as little as 2-4 ng total, which 250-1000 ng was required for the silver stain.

Radiolabeling of cultured cells with 3H and 14C and also specific doubling labeling with [35S]Met (for all proteins) and [3H]fucose has been done, but hazards and expense are a big disadvantage, and not all systems can be labeled in vitro.

Premstaller A, Huber CG (2001) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 15, 1053-1060.

Factors Determining The Performance of Triple Quadrupole, Quadrupole Ion Trap and Sector Field Mass Spectrometer in Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry. 2. Suitability for De Novo Sequencing

Fragment spectra of a decameric oligonucleotide (ATGCTACGAG, mass 3052.08) were generated in a triple-stage quadrupole (TSQ, Finnigan MAT TSQ 7000), quadrupole ion trap (QIT, Finnigan MAT LCQ), and double-focusing sector field (DFSF, Finnigan MAT 95S) mass spectrometers. Electrospray was used from a 250 µl Unimetrics glass syringe on Harvard model 22 pump, with a 10 mM triethylamine in 50% MeCN solvent with flow 3-20 µl/min. Cations were removed inline with a 20 × 0.5 mm Dowex 50WX8 microcolumn (Bio-Rad), and plumbing was with 50 µm (150 µm o.d.) capillaries. Heat was 200-210° on the spray, and negative mode with capillary voltage of 3200-4000 V used. Nitrogen sheath gas pressure was 345 kPa (TSQ), 65-93 units (QIT), and 410 kPa (DFSF). Precursor ion was selected with a 5 mass unit isolation width, argon set to 400 Pa for collision, and the energy from 20-50 V for the TSQ. For QIT, isolation width=3.6 u and collision energy is 20% relative (0-100% corresponds to rf voltage for resonance excitation from 0-5 V); Helium gas used for collision at 0.1 Pa.

In the TSQ and QIT instruments, the -4 ion was selected as precursor since it gives better sequence info compared to lower charge precursors. 83 fragments were identified on the TSQ. The (a-B) and w series were complete starting from (a3-B3(G)) to (a9-B9(A)) fragment, and from (w1) to (w9). Fragments with different charge states help to make sequence identification quite complete. With the exception of (a5), a-type ions from (a2) to (a8) were detected, as well as b-, c-, and d-series ions. The b- and c-series often lose the nucleobase at the 5′-end, giving rise to three fragments of the (b-B)- and most prominently, as many as 9 fragments of the (c-B)-series. 3′ fragments were seen in a nearly complete y-series, with only (y5) missing; additionally ions in the x- and z-series were seen, with or without loss of base at 3′-end of fragment. In the low mass end nucleobases adenine, guanine, and thymine were represented at good intensity. The drawbacks of looking at a 10-mer on the TSQ include substantial spectral complexity (83 fragments) and reduced signal-to-noise.

On the QIT only 28 fragments were seen. The product ions involved neutral loss of a nucleobase to form [M-A]4−, [M-G]4−, and [M-C]4− species. Some double neutral loss species were observed as well: [M-A-G]4− (note no [M-A-G]3− was found). Complete series of w-fragments (w11−) to (w94−) allowed the unambiguous determination of the exact sequence of the decanucleotide. When walking up the fragment series, certain fragments will be key in mass determinations. For the 10-mer, eight (a-B) type fragments, namely (a3-B3(G))1−, (a4-B4(C))2−, and (a6-B6(A))2− to (a9-B9(A))3− corroborate other findings. Elimination of PO3 from w-fragments is indicated by (y4)1− and (y7)2−. Gaps in the (a-B) series resulted from missing ions for fragments (a2-B2(T)) and (a5-B5(T)), which are formed after elimination of the thymine base in a first step fragmentation. (M-T) base loss ions are not seen because of a low reactivity of thymine in gas-phase collisions. Backbone cleavage at the position of this base is a less-favored pathway.

Griffin TJ, Gygi SP, Rist B, Aebersold R, Loboda A, Jilkine A, Ens W, Standing KG (2001) Anal. Chem. 73, 978-986.

Quantitative Proteomic Analysis Using a MALDI Quadrupole Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer

ABSTRACT. We describe an approach to the quantitative analysis of complex protein mixtures using a MALDI quadrupole time-of-flight (MALDI QqTOF) mass spectrometer and isotope coded affinity tag reagents (Gygi, S. P.; et al. Nat. Biotechnol. 1999, 17, 994-9.). Proteins in mixtures are first labeled on cysteinyl residues using an isotope coded affinity tag reagent, the proteins are enzymatically digested, and the labeled peptides are purified using a multidimensional separation procedure, with the last step being the elution of the labeled peptides from a microcapillary reversed-phase liquid chromatography column directly onto a MALDI sample target. After addition of matrix, the sample spots are analyzed using a MALDI QqTOF mass spectrometer, by first obtaining a mass spectrum of the peptides in each sample spot in order to quantify the ratio of abundance of pairs of isotopically tagged peptides, followed by tandem mass spectrometric analysis to ascertain the sequence of selected peptides for protein identification. The effectiveness of this approach is demonstrated in the quantification and identification of peptides from a control mixture of proteins of known relative concentrations and also in the comparative analysis of protein expression in Saccharomyces cerevisiae grown on two different carbon sources.

Lilley KS, Razzaq A, Dupree P (2001) Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol. 6, 46-50.

Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis: Recent Advances in Sample Preparation, Detection, and Quantitation

Proteins predicted from genome sequence data have recently been placed into three classes: those with known function, those with recognizable motifs (a vague idea of function), and those with no recognizable sequence similarities and therefore having no known function. 30% of Arabidopsis predicted proteins fall into the latter category. Transcript level studies are not really a clue as to protein levels.

Approximately 90% of the total protein cell is coded by only 10% of the total protein species. Low-abundance proteins, such as transcription factors, are undetectable by 2D PAGE. A single 2D PAGE with standard visualization will maximally show 3000 spots, and many of those are proteins co-migrating to the same spot with others. Gygi et al. reported that one faint spot held the products of six genes on Ag-stained, narrow pH range gel in a yeast cell extract. It is estimated that at least 1000 copies of a protein should be present to reach the level of detection on 2D PAGE, but Hoving et al. reported detection of down to 300 copies per cell on 1 pH unit zoom strips. Tonella et al. estimated that 70% of the E. coli proteome was seen on six different pH range gels. Pre-focusing fractionation (on the Bio-Rad Rotofor) has been found to improve proteome visualization as well. Anion-exchange chromatography is also useful in enriching certain proteins, and can work with lower abundance proteins.

Membrane proteins are barely soluble in the buffers used in IEF. Prefractionation with Triton X-114, chloroform/MeOH, or washes with sodium carbonate, with sequential detergent extraction helps. Santioni et al. used zwtterionic detergents achieve this effect. ASB14 and TX-100 combinations have helped to solubilize bacterial outer membrane proteins. A study of detergents generally found that the stronger detergents helped more in the detection of certain classes of membrane proteins.

As far as staining techniques, silver is more sensitive but has a very limited linear range and is unusable for quantitation. Sypro dyes are even more sensitive. Sypro red and orange give best results although Sypro Ruby is used.

Quantitative studies of protein abundance indicate the more sensitive dyes would be best at looking at low levels of protein expression. Certain software is being used to provide accurate estimations of protein levels over a linear range of 3 orders of magnitude, but pitfalls have been described by others.

Difference gel electrophoresis (DIGE) involves labeling samples with one of three distinct fluorescent dyes: Cy2, Cy3, and Cy5. Labeled samples are then run in a single gel and the gel scanned at different wavelengths. Since labeling requires Lys residues, Lys-rich proteins will be over-represented. Detection limits are estimated to be 0.1-0.2 ng, and the linear range is estimated to be over 5 orders of magnitude. A study of the heart mitochondrial proteome in mice deficient in creatine kinase made use of a looped two-frame movie that showed the simplicity of the technique but did not represent the best method for doing quantitation. In another analysis of mouse liver before and after paracetamol admin., the use of Phoretix/ImageMaster software showed that significance thresholds for changes indicate thresholds are dependent on normalized spot volumes, and lower volumes have higher thresholds. Also variation in levels was found in the mice and not in error associated with DIGE.

Sonnhammer ELL, Wootton JC (2001) Proteins 45, 262-273.

Integrated Graphical Analysis of Protein Sequence Features Predicted from Sequence Composition

ABSTRACT. Several protein sequence analysis algorithms are based on properties of amino acid compositionandrepetitiveness. Theseincludemethods for prediction of secondary structure elements, coiled-coils, transmembrane segments or signal peptides, and for assignment of low-complexity, nonglobular, or intrinsically unstructured regions. The quality of such analyses can be greatly enhanced by graphical software tools that present predicted sequence features together in context and allowjudgment to be focused simultaneously onseveral different types of supporting information. For these purposes, we describe the SFINX package, which allows many different sets of segmental or continuous- curve sequence feature data, generated by individual external programs, to be viewed in combination alongside a sequence dot-plot or a multiple alignment of database matches. The implementation is currently based on extensions to the graphical viewers Dotter and Blixem and scripts that convert data from external programs to a simple generic data definition format called SFS. We describe applications in which dot-plots and flanking database matches provide valuable contextual information for analyses based on compositional and repetitive sequence features. The system is also useful for comparing results from algorithms run with a range of parameters to determine appropriate values for defaults or cutoffs for large-scale genomic analyses.

Belghazi M, Bathany K, Hountondji C, Grandier-Vazeille X, Manon S, Schmitter J-M (2001) Proteomics 1, 946-954.

Analysis of Protein Sequences and Protein Complexes by Matrix-Assisted Laser/Desorption Ionization Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT In the context of proteome analysis, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry (MALDI-MS) can fulfil the two tasks of primary structure verification and protein identification. As an illustration of the first of these tasks, the sequence of Eschericha coli isoleucyl-tRNA synthetase, a protein with 15 reported sequence conflicts, has been established by means of MALDI mass mapping. The identification of mitochondrial proteins participating in a yeast supramolecular complex exhibiting NADH dehydrogenase activity highlights the performances of MALDI-MS for the second task. The spectral suppression phenomenon occurring for complex peptide mixtures analysed by MALDI is discussed, as well as the role of post-source decay analysis for confident protein identification.

Hamdan M, Galvani M, Righetti PG (2001) Mass Spec. Rev. 20, 121-141.

Monitoring 2-D Gel-Induced Modifications of Proteins by MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometry

REVIEW. With 2D gel/MALDI MS analysis the intact protein mass and its pI are information used for protein identification. The accuracy of pI prediction and the matching of mass are crucial. Modifications of proteins affecting mass determination are frequent. High pH conditions can for example cause reactions between IEF and polyacrylamide gel chemicals with amino acids (Cys can form cysteinyl-S-β-propionamide in reaction with acrylamide, and can form an adduct with 2-mercaptoethanol. Methionine can be oxidized to form a sulfoxide adding a 16 Da mass; usually the reaction of ammonium persulfate remaining. Coomassie-stained proteins may have tightly bound and affect the mass. Formic acid presence can cause formylation of Ser and Thr residues.

With gel creation, acrylamide (FW=71, Partition Coefficient=0.2) is not the only monomer used. Many N-substituted monomers have interesting properties. N,N-Dimethylacrylamide (DMA, FW=99, PC=0.5), N-acryloyl-2-amino-hydroxymethyl-1,3-propane (TRISACRYL, FW=175, PC=0.01), N-acryloyl-aminoethoxyethanol (AAEE, FW=159, PC=0.13), and N-acryloyl aminopropanol (AAP, FW=129, PC=0.1).

Polymerization is not always 100%, but only about 90%, with about 30 mM free unreacted acrylamide in the gel. To see the effect this might have on proteins, a 50 pmol/µl bovine β-lactoglobulin B (BLGB) solution was prepared with different levels from 0.5 to 30 mM of the monomers named above. These were incubated at room temperate at approx. pH 9 and then examined on MALDI ToF for the intact protein. Spectra show a more extensive reaction with acrylamide than with AAP; this is based on changes to relative peak heights of the major peaks and appearances of new peaks. The new peaks are consistent with the addition of from 2-4 acrylamide adducts. Eventually all monomers were compared and the reactivity scale appears to be acrylamide > DMA > AAEE > trisacryl > AAP.

It is thought that Cys is the reactive center, but Tyr hydroxyl, Lys ε-amino, and the free N-terminus are also implicated. For this study, bovine and human hemoglobin α-chains were used since they have only a single Cys residue. 50 µM proteins in 30 mM monomer were incubated 1 h (human) and 6 h (bovine), then washed to remove excess acrylamide, digested with trypsin, and then checked on MALDI. Before and after spectra were compared for the bovine: two new peaks appear at m/z 2114.0 and 2707.31, indicating modification of the sequences 12-31 and 69-92 with the added mass of m/z 71. There is no Cys in either fragment. Lys16 is present in 12-31 and Lys90 in 69-92. Human tryptic peptide analysis also shows m/z 71 transition in peak m/z 2531.31 to 2602.23. A single Cys 104 is present and is supposed to be the modified site. The longer incubation time for bovine vs. human may indicate that Lys reactivity is slower. It is also noted that a free -SH group is not a precondition, but Cys residues in -S-S- bridges are just as reactive, perhaps more so.

The polymers that make up immobilized pH gradients also were investigated for the potential to modify proteins. Immobilines include a great many chemicals: 2-acrylamido-2-methylpropane sulfonic acid (MW 207, pK 1), N-acryloylglycine (MW 129, pK 3.6), 4-acrylamidobutyric acid (MW 157, pK 4.6), 2-morpholinoethyl acrylamide (MW 184, pK 6.2), 2-thiomorpholinoethylacrylamide (MW 200, pK 6.6), 3-morpholinopropylacrylamide (MW 198, pK 7.0), 3-thiomorpholinopropylacrylamide (MW 214, pK 7.4), N,N-dimethylaminoethylacrylamide (MW 142, pK 8.5), N,N-dimethylaminopropylacrylamide (MW 156, 9.3), N,N-diethylaminopropylacrylamide (MW 184, pK 10.3). 20 mM of these chemicals were incubated 1 h at alkaline pH (9-10) with 50 µM proteins, bovine α-lactalbumin (bLA) and chicken egg lysozyme. 1 µl was taken and mixed with eq vol sinapinic acid and spotted on MALDI. It should be noted that at the working pH bLA with a low pI has a very negative charge, while the lysozyme is neutral or slightly positive; hence at alkaline pH acidic Immobilines, themselves highly negative, are unlikely to react with bLA at least. This was shown by reaction of the pK 3.6 Immobiline more vigorously with lysozyme than bLA.

At the higher pH there is strong evidence to show that Cys-SH groups are targets of acrylamide alkylation. This was found true with incubation of Immobiline and the change in m/z associated with tryptic peptides known to contain one or more Cys residues. The reaction was fairly complete.

Following Unfolding By Cys Alkylation.
