Protein folding and unfolding can be monitored by UV difference spectroscopy (Gratzer 196), fluorescence (Cantor & Timasheff 1982), circular dichroism (Bayley 1980), optical rotatory dispersion (Pace et al 1989), NMR (Jennings & Wright 1993, Bai et al 1994) and also MS (Miranker et al 1993, Zhang & Smith 1993, Konermann et al 1997). The MS technique is done largely through ESI and using hydrogen/deuterium exchange techniques. Use of immobiline-type chemicals has been used to study changes in the alkylation of Cys kinetically and with different levels of denaturants present.

Gel Crosslinker Reactivity. To test the potential of crosslinkers to modify proteins, a 5 mM acrylamide monomer solution with a range of 1-10% PEGDA crosslinker was incubated 15 min in 50 µM β-lactoglobulin B (bLGB). MALDI spectra show a single new peak emerging: from m/z 18281 to 18353, indicating acrylamide addition when no crosslinker is present, but two additional peaks when 5% C is present, indicating crosslinker reaction. In fact relative to acrylamide present the peak height suggests that the crosslinker has a more efficient reaction. One result found was that the reactivity of the other end of the crosslinker was altered after bonding with the first end. Longer incubation times were necessary to achieve modification.

bLGB was separated in SDS-PAGE and then extracted with formic acid:MeCN:isopropanol:water after 10 min and 2 h in ultrasonic bath. MALDI spectra of intact protein shows a series of peaks on an envelope. Some resulted from acrylamide modification, others from formylation of Ser/Thr residues with the presence of formic acid. Coomassie blue interference may be seen with particularly hydrophobici proteins.

How does one avoid all these potential modifications from 2-D gel work? One is to make sure the protein is sufficiently denatured. Urea (7 M), thiourea (2 M), SDS or other detergent (2%), DTT (65 mM), and 30% glycerol are used in the IEF process, and they all stabilize the unfolding of proteins. With unfolding, alkylation of Cys residues in particular should occur. Use of iodoacetamide or acrylamide at pH 9 will efficiently alkylate protein. One problem is that thiourea is quite reactive with iodoacetamide. If thiourea is present, proteins should be alkylated at pH 9 with acrylamide. Another factor to consider is that SDS may have a negative influence (as opposed to other detergents), on alkylation efficiency.

Zaia J, Boynton R, Heinegåd D, Barry F (2001) Biochemistry 40, 12983-12991.

Posttranslational Modifications to Human Bone Sialoprotein Determined by Mass Spectrometry

Bone sialoprotein (BSP) was obtained from human bone with GuanHCl extraction and then purifying on anion IEX chromatography. Analytical gel filtration showed single peak with amino acid analysis showing homogeneity. Amino acid similarity search with SwissPROT db shows topscore for BSP. A series of treatments is applied before MALDI-ToF analysis. Untreated shows peak at m/z 52533; N-Glycanase (2.5 µg substrate with 75 mU enzyme, 100 mM Tris pH 8.5, ON @ 37°) produced m/z 46077 protein; with neuraminidase alone, m/z 45771; combination of N-glycase and neuraminidase, m/z 41456, and with an N- and O-glycanase and neuraminidase, m/z 34799. The untreated peak is quite broad, reflecting significant natural microheterogeneity in BSP. Significant peak narrowing occurred with single and combined deglycosylations. Loss of mass calculations show that an average of 7 sialic acid (NAcNeuram) residues per molecule BSP. Total BSP oligosaccharide was about 17,734 ± 423 Da.

Hydrolysis of BSP (2 M TFA for 3 h for neutral sugars, 4 M HCl for 5 h for hexosamines, 6 M HCl @ 105° for 24 h for amino acids) reduces it to monosaccharides and amino acids, which can be analyzed. The saccharides are dissolved in water after drying and then separated on CarboPac PA-1, eluted with 50 mM NaOH and sensed by pulsed amperometry. A molar CHO to core protein ratio is found. Calculated CHO is 12,020 ± 2300 (oligo less sialic acid), comparable to MS determination of 10972 ± 1138 Da. BSP has 4 potential N-glycosylation sites and the 6.1 mol mannose/mol protein suggests two are glycosylated. If they are complex type oligosaccharides with no mannose other than core. Some sialic acid residues could belong to O-linked sugars. O-linked saccharides that are desialylated have a mass of 6660 Da, with 16 sialic acid residues.

Sulfated tyrosines in a peptide will fragment in positive ion mode to produce ion mass consistent with unmodified peptide. In negative ion mode there is less fragmentation, and pair of ions separated by 80.06 Da are seen (sulfated and desulfated molecules). Phosphate ions do not decay and their presence is confirmed with alkaline phosphatase treatment. Use of positive and negative ion mode spectral acquisition is useful in

Doucette A, Li L (2001) Proteomics 1, 946-954.

Investigation of the Applicability of A Sequential Digestion Protocol Using Trypsin and Leucine Aminopeptidase M for Protein Identification by Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time of Flight Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT An investigation of the applicability of a sequential digestion procedure involving endoand exoprotease digestion of proteins is reported. The procedure involves the digestion of a protein sample with trypsin, yielding peptide fragments characteristic of the protein. The resulting mixture of peptide fragments is then subjected to N-terminal sequencing with leucine aminopeptidase M (LAP), with matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time of flight mass spectrometric analysis of the various digestion products. Several proteins in solution, as well as gel extracted proteins were subjected to this sequential enzyme digestion procedure. The results of these experiments reveal that LAP will preferentially cleave specific peptides of the trypsin digested sample with high efficiency, while leaving other peptides undigested. Also, the length of the amino acid sequence tags that can be generated with this method is limited; the longest sequence tag generated from a single tryptic peptide was four amino acids, even though the digestion was allowed to proceed for long times. In the experiments, N-terminal digestion products were detected as early as two minutes, or as late as 90 minutes, following the addition of LAP to the sample. The method was shown to be effective for subpicomole starting quantities of protein, although with some loss in digestion efficiency at lower concentrations of starting material. This method is useful in providing additional sequence information to increase the level of confidence in protein identification, as illustrated in the identification of bacterial proteins fractionated by high-performance liquid chromatography. In some instances, this method can provide additional sequence information where post source decay and nanospray mass spectrometry failed to generate fragment ion spectra. This is illustrated in an example where the procedure was applied to a membrane protein, CD9, that had been isolated by sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Although the sequential digestion procedure requires more human intervention, it is a straightforward method and can be readily implemented.

shotgun proteomics, MudPIT

Wolters D, Washburn MP, Yates 3rd JR (2001) Anal. Chem. 73, 5683-5690.

An Automated Multidimensional Protein Identification Technology for Shotgun Proteomics

Peptide separation and protein identfication methods were compared using previously described buffer conditions: in that study solvent A was 5% MeCN + 0.5% acetic acid, solvent B was 80% MeCN + 0.5% AA, solvent C was 5% MeCN + 0.5% AA + 0.25 M KCl, and solvent D the same as solvent C but containing 1 M KCl. However, KCl is incomptable with ESI-MS. Ammonium acetate was substituted as a volatile alternative.

Soluble S. cerevisiae protein (420 µg) was digested and loaded to 100 × 365 µm fused silica capillary with tip pulled with P-2000 laser (Sutter Instruments) in which the fritless capillary had been packed with 10 cm of 5 µm Zorbax Eclipse XDB C18 (Hewlett-Packard) and then with 4 cm of 5 µm Partisphere SCX (Whatman). The column was connected to PEEK microcross to split flow of pump so that flow was 150-250 nl/min and spray set at 1800 V to a Finnigan LCQ ion trap mass spectrometer. Desolvation temperature was set to 180°. SEQUEST was used to interpret MS/MS data: all accepted results had a ΔCn of 0.1 or more, which leads to high confidence in SEQUEST result. After equilibrating column for 5 min with solvent A, a 2 min step each for 10, 15, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90, 90, 100, 100% solvent C was done to move SCX proteins to the RP phase. A 3 min flush then removes the ammonium acetate. The peptides on the RP resin are eluted by linear gradient of 0-10% B in 10 min, then to 45% B over 80 min. A new cycle starts with 100% solvent A and another fraction is eluted with a higher salt concentration from the SCX. In the last two cycles, the column is washed with 100% solvent C and 100% solvent D for 20 min to remove all peptides from the SCX. The entire analysis takes 15 cycles. Data for 666 peptides was obtained by MS/MS and searched against the database using SEQUEST, with identification of 288 proteins.

An offline prefractionation of peptides on 4.6 × 30 mm Zorbax Eclipse XDB C18 before loading on to the LC/LC columns. 2.1 mg protein from the soluble protein was loaded on to the column, the peptides eluted in 3.5 ml steps of 20, 30, 50, 70, 100% solvent B. Fractions were centrifugally evaporated then suspended in 20 µl solvent A, which was then run on the biphasic capillary column. A 15-cycle MudPIT was then done on each of the five fractions, and more than twice the number of unique peptides (1625) were found, with 607 proteins characterized. Although not orthogonal, it avoids signal overload, indicating chromatographic performance limiting analysis.

If peak resolution was the problem, a suitable ion-pairing agent was necessary. Alkanesulfonic acids make decent ion-pairing agents, but perfluorinated carboxylic acids up to 4 carbons are volatile and best for ESI-MS. A downside is suppression of ionization, which can be nonetheless minimized if concentrations are kept low. Substitution of acetic acid with 0.02% heptafluorobutyric acid (HFBA) was used with a 400 µg sample with MudPIT and 630 proteins were identified by 1665 peptides, nearly 3 times more than with acetic acid.

In other work, a larger set of proteins in the yeast proteome were analyzed by attempting to recover more than soluble extracts. These included lightly and heavily washed insoluble fractions. After drying them in centrifugal evaporator, these are resolubilized in 90% formic acid, then digested with CNBr. This likely presents a substrate amenable to tryptic digestion. Combining all results and doing LC using HFBA, a total of 974 protein based on 2169 peptides were identified in the lightly washed insoluble and 1036 proteins detected from 2114 peptides identified from heavily washed insoluble fraction. For each of the 15 cycles in a fraction analysis, the number of peptides identified was fairly constant, averaging 383 proteins, with a range of 218 (cycle 14) to 505 (cycle 2) peptides. Moreover each cycle provided unique peptide hits added to the final count, from a low of 38 unique hits in cycle 14 to 342 hits in cycle 2.

Thus MudPIT works by separating by charge in the 1st dimension and hydrophobicity in the 2nd. The effectiveness of this approach was tried on test proteins. Phosphorylase B was digested and run. A plot of peptide pI value vs. salt step cycle showed that peptides with lower pI values elute early from the SCX column, those with higher pI values in later cycles (solvent pH is about 3 in all washes). The peptides K.DFYELEPHK.F and K.DFYELEPHKFQNK.T differ by four amino acids at the C-terminal end. The former has a pI 4.65 and elutes in cycle 3 and the latter has a pI 5.45 and elutes in cycle 6. In addition, the count of singly charged peptides eluting in the first cycle is much higher than in subsequent cycles; 19% of peptides in the 1st cycle are singly charged, whereas in any subsequent cycle, at most 5% are singly charged.

Reproducibility in mapping is largely a function of chromatographic performance (less about MS performance). Two runs were done on consecutive days to evaluate reproducibility, and peptides usually eluted within a time window of less than 1 min. Where variation is seen, it is due to the difficulties in producing a consistent flow rate with a microcross split (used to make nanoliter/min flow rates). That all peaks were shifted in time was an indication of this. Even with a particular retention time shift, the SEQUEST algorithm correctly identifies the peptide from the spectrum.

An important aspect of LC/LC is the ability to improve the detection of components present in low quantities of analyses of complex peptide mixtures or the dynamic range. A theoretical measure of the performance of multidimensional separations is peak capacity. Peak capacity of the reversed phase is determined by:

nc = L / (4σ)

where L is the total time over which the peptide elutes, σ is the average standard deviation of the peaks. Peak width, represented by 4σ for a peptide eluting from reversed phase is ~25 s and the gradient time is 90 min, providing an nc of 216. Giddings has said that a peak capacity for a 2-D LC system is the sum of the capacity in each cycle if a column is used repetitively on successive cuts from a feeder column. Given 15 fractions came off the SCX column, the peak capacity is thus 3240. The mass spectrometer also represents a dimension with a peak capacity of at least 7 (the number of MS/MS spectra which can be acquired while a peak with width 25 s is eluting). Hence an LC/LC/MS/MS system has ~23,000 peaks it can analyze.

The dynamic range of a system is its ability to analyze both low and high abundance substances, and is the ratio of a protein of high abundance over a protein of low abundance. 9.8 fmol of G6P dehydrogenase from Leuconostoc mesenteroides and 94.9 pmol of α-casein were spiked into soluble S. cerevisiae cell lysate. Three peptides from the G6PDH were found, giving the system a dynamic range of 10,000:1. TDH2 from S. cerevisiae is one of the most abundant, present at 106 copies per cell. If the dynamic range is such, then the system can sense as little as 100 copies per cell, although this applies only to the method. If a sample were applied where proteins expressed at 100 copies per cell and the mass was at the attomole level, this is below the ability of the system to detect.

ICAT, quantitative proteomics

Smolka MB, Zhou H, Purkayastha S, Aebersold R (2001) Anal. Biochem. 297, 25-31.

Optimization of the Isotope-Coded Affinity Tag-Labeling Procedure for Quantitative Proteome Analysis

A set of standard proteins (BSA, ovalbumin, bovine β-lactoglobulin, and bovine α-lactalbumin) were labeled using 20 µg protein dissolved in 0.05% w/v SDS, 5 mM EDTA and 50 mM TrisHCl pH 8.3. 5 mM TBP for 10 min, then the ICAT (ABi) is added for 2 h at room temperature (the reaction is done in the dark). The reaction is halted with DTT to 10 mM. 12.5% SDS-PAGE gels are run and stained to look for a mobility shift caused by the added 442.2 Da of the ICAT reagent to each Cys. Several different concentrations of ICAT reagent were used to observe the partial labeling reaction: these were 0, 50, 150, 300, 600, and 1200 µM. The reaction was complete with 1200 µM (1.2 mM) under these conditions. To verify that the migration shift was due to complete labeling, the band was digested in gel and extracted peptides examined on MS. All peptides predicted to have Cys showed a mass shift of 442.2 Da, thus indicating that all residues were labeled. α-Lactalbumin has 9 theoretical peptides, of which 7 are detected, in the MS set at its range (600-2800). One Cys containing peptide was not detected in the QSTAR Pulsar Q-TOF using a MALDI source. This was because its mass was beyond the measured range (m/z 5096.35). Another peptide (pentapeptide) was also not detected, although it has no Cys.

In looking at other proteins, the concentration range was extended from 0 to 3 mM ICAT, and the proteins show variable reactivity. At 3 mM the ratio is more than 20-fold molar excess with the free thiol. A 50:1 reagent concentration was also tried in a 1 ml volume, the ICAT being 0.4 mM, but the labeling is incomplete. Thus a minimal ICAT concentration rather than an optimized ICAT:target ratio is more important.

The effect of denaturants was assessed in their ability to open up the protein to reaction. Different concentrations of ICAT (0-3 mM) in 0.5% SDS or 6 M urea were tried on the four proteins and the gels run. In the end generally both urea and SDS at these concentrations were effective, but urea did a better job of improving the reactivity of the ICAT at lower concentrations. For example, urea could effectively allow complete reaction as 1.2 mM, but SDS use resulted in a less than complete action. A reaction of 0.5% was compared to 0.05% and there was better partial labeling at a lower ICAT concentration: this indicates that SDS at high concentration interferes with the reaction, aside from opening up the protein to make the Cys accessible. It is advised that any preliminary extraction or denaturation with high SDS be diluted or dialyzed to remove possibly interfering concentrations. With ovalbumin it was observed that neither urea nor SDS at any concentration helped it to attain complete labeling.

A time course was also done using 1 mM ICAT with a solution containing 0.05% SDS, 6 M urea, 5 mM EDTA, 50 mM TrisHCl pH 8.3, and 5 mM TBP. Reaction times were 10, 30, 60 min, 2 h, 6 h, and 24 h. Results show that the reaction is nearly complete in 10 min, and complete by 60 min.

Since high ICAT concentrations are required for labeling, minimal volumes are thus necessary since ICAT costs can be come high. With lower volumes in the face of constant protein mass, the protein concentration increases as well. β-Lactoglobulin was dissolved between 0.1 and 3.6 µg/µl in SDS, urea, EDTA, Tris as before, reduced with TBP, and then treated with 1 mM ICAT for 2 h. Results show that even at 3.6 µg/µl, which is a 1:1 molar ratio of ICAT:sulfhydryls, all the protein is labeled, and none of it remains unlabeled or partially labeled.

A yeast total protein extract was then treated. 300 µg of yeast protein precipitate was dissovled in 50 µl of the ICAT reaction buffer and then reduced with TBP. The ICAT was 3 mM for 2 h. Yeast proteins have an average mass of 40 kDa and contain 7 Cys residues, and so the ICAT (175 nmol) was in 3-fold excess of predicted sulfhydryls. 2DGE with Ag staining was done. The image showed no evidence of partial labeling. Unlabeled and labeled 2-D maps were compared to look for shifts; the shifts that were seen were strictly 2nd dimensional, and not in the isoelectric points. Thus the ICAT does not affect charged groups, nor does urea cause carbamylation.

Beck JL, Colgrave ML, Ralph SF, Sheil MM (2001) Mass Spec. Rev. 20, 362-387.

Practical Implications of Some Recent Studies in Electrospray Ionization Fundamentals

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. In accomplishing successful electrospray ionization analyses, it is imperative to have an understanding of the effects of variables such as analyte structure, instrumental parameters, and solution composition. Here, we review some fundamental studies of the ESI process that are relevant to these issues. We discuss how analyte chargeability and surface activity are related to ESI response, and how accessible parameters such as nonpolar surface area and reversed phase HPLC retention time can be used to predict relative ESI response. Also presented is a description of how derivitizing agents can be used to maximize or enable ESI response by improving the chargeability or hydrophobicity of ESI analytes. Limiting factors in the ESI calibration curve are discussed. At high concentrations, these factors include droplet surface area and excess charge concentration, whereas at low concentrations ion transmission becomes an issue, and chemical interference can also be limiting. Stable and reproducible non-pneumatic ESI operation depends on the ability to balance a number of parameters, including applied voltage and solution surface tension, flow rate, and conductivity. We discuss how changing these parameters can shift the mode of ESI operation from stable to unstable, and how currentvoltage curves can be used to characterize the mode of ESI operation. Finally, the characteristics of the ideal ESI solvent, including surface tension and conductivity requirements, are discussed. Analysis in the positive ion mode can be accomplished with acidified methanol/water solutions, but negative ion mode analysis necessitates special constituents that suppress corona discharge and facilitate the production of stable negative ions.

von Brocke A, Nicholson G, Bayer E (2001) Electrophoresis 22, 1251-1266.

Recent Advances in Capillary Electrophoresis/Electrospray Mass Specrometry

ABSTRACT. In this review, the progress in hyphenation of capillary electrophoresis (CE) with electrospray ionization-mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) since the article of Banks (Banks, J. F., Electrophoresis 1997, 18, 22552266) is reported. In all capillary-based electromigration techniques, such as capillary gel electrophoresis (CGE), capillary isotachophoresis (CITP), capillary isoelectric focussing (CIEF), micellar electrokinetic chromatography (MEKC), affinity capillary electrophoresis (ACE), as well as in the hybrid techniques capillary electrochromatography (CEC), and pressurized capillary electrochromatography (pCEC) progress has been made in experimental setups, and for many groups of analytes, such as peptides, proteins, nucleotides, saccharides, drugs and their metabolites, CE/ESI-MS has been successfully applied. Electromigration is further miniaturized. New preconcentration methods allow the investigation of compounds, which are not sensitively detected with ESI-MS. Coordination ion spray (CIS) MS is another method for sensitivity enhancement by on-line formation of charged coordination compounds.

Wehofsky M, Hoffmann R, Hubert M, Spengler B (2001) Eur. J. Mass Spectrom. 7, 39-46.

Isotopic Deconvolution of Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Mass Spectra for Substance-Class Specific Analysis of Complex Samples

With the increasing mass of the observed molecule, the mass signal patterns become more complex. Up to 1800 u the monoisotopic mass is usually the most intense. Beyond that the monoisotopic signal becomes less intense to the other isotopic variants, and even becomes lost in the noise. With FTICR-MS mass accuracy of large proteins is about 1 ppm but the monoisotopic mass approaches 1 u of error. Some methods make use of determining monoisotopic mass from the average mass. Analysis of the isotopic cluster can also lead to monoisotopic mass determination. Horn et al. use a least squares fitting approach to derive the monoisotopic mass from ESI spectra of larger proteins. Zhang et al. use maximum entropy-based deconvolution of high mass molecules in ESI-FTICR-MS spectra.

Materials and Methods. If the atomic composition of a molecule is known, the natural isotopic distributions of atoms can be calculated using probabilistic calculations. For the average isotopic distribution of peptides and variance for a given molecular mass, the distributions are calculated for any possible amino acid in a given mass interval. The count of compositions increases exponentially with mass. Thus if N is the count of residues in a peptide and A is the count of possible components (20, for proteogenic peptides), the count of potential peptides is:

ν = AN

For position-insensitive counts (count of different amino acid sum formulae), this is the number of combinations c:

c = ( A + N − 1 ) = (A + N − 1)!
N N! (A − 1)!

These are the count of masses that can be formed from a set of amino acids. A plot from 600 to 1100 u with a mass interval of ΔM = 0.05 u shows local maxima every 14 u. This oscillation at every 14 u is logical as this represents the mass of CH2, a very common structural repeat in organics. Below 400 u the periodicity disappears as there are lower number of possible combinations. Zoom in closer to a very narrow mass range and it is clear that some masses drop to zero with respect to possible combinations. As mass increases, there are fewer zero population intervals. At 800 u, peaks are 0.3 u wide at base (0.14 u at half height), with a 0.7 u non-populated area, but at 1500 u, the nonpopulated clusters vanish. Note that sequence permutations only show up as increasing the peak height, not in a wider variation of masses. Each cluster can be reduced to a nominal mass, an integer value, and the average mass of the cluster can approximated as the nominal mass × 1.00043.

Generally proteins will be considered to consist of C, H, N, O, and S. The first 3 have only two isotopes, with the lightest having abundances of >98%. The lightest isotopes or O and S are also the most abundant, but three isotopes are to be considered for each. The heaviest stable isotope of S has a relatively high abundance of 4.22%. The probability of certain isotope combinations can be calculated from binomial distributions. The isotopic with the lowest mass, the monoisotopic mass, has mass M (to be considered the mass of the molecule). Masses of 1 u more represent a mix of molecules with atoms with the next heavier isotope. There is only one isotopic set of atoms for the monoisotopic mass M, but others represent a heterogeneity of the atoms with different isotopes. The exchange of a 12C for 13C, a 14N for a 15N, or a 1H for a 2H will be a factor in determining the intensity of the heavier isotopes. For the elements with three or more significant representations of stable isotopes, a polynomial distribution is used in the calculation. A plot of the ratio (as a percent) of the predicted intensity of the 2nd isotopic peak relative to the predicted intensity of the 1st isotopic peak against the monoisotopic mass (u) illustrates the pattern for all possible amino acid combinations (not sequence permutations). A cross in the plot represents one such mass. One then can plot the count of the crosses as a function of the calculated intensity ratios. For example one can show the distribution of amino acid combinations with a 0.1% intensity interval plotted for the cluster at mass 1000.4 u. The average of the distribution can then be calculated at 54 ± 3% (range 45-70%). The presence of a particular atom can be determined from the isotopic pattern.

Chernuschevich IV, Loboda AV, Thomson BA (2001) J. Mass Spectrom. 36, 849-865.

An Introduction to Quadrupole-Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry

TUTORIAL. Q-ToF hybrid MSes were first commercially introduced 6 years ago, combining ToF in MS and MS/MS modes with ESI and APCI. QqTOF will be used to refer to the technique and instrument where Q is the mass-resolving quadrupole, q is the r.f.-only quadrupole or hexapole collision cell, and TOF is the time-of-flight spectrometer. ESI-TOF was first used to demonstrate orthogonal injection from a high-pressure ion source, leading to QqTOF. The configuration can be seen as adding a mass-resolving quadruople to an ESI-TOF or as replacing the third quadrupole in a triple quad by a TOF MS. Sensitivity, mass resolution, and mass accuracy all increase for both precursor and product ions. More specialized modes of the precursor such as neutral loss and multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) scans in triple quads are not replaceable. In general the QTOF was generally seen as a qualitative analyzer, but can be used quantitatively once dynamic range issues are resolved. While the triple quad still has the better sensitivity, the QqTOF provides better specificity through its better resolution. MALDI ion sources have also been developed for QqTOF. The explanation of how the QqToF works is fairly much the same as the triple quad; the triple quad has been described by Yost and Boyd.

The usual QqTOF has a r.f. Q0 quadrupole for collisional damping, and so typically has a triple quad with TOF. A vacuum in the extraction cone of the ion source is set up at 0.5 torr. At Q0 the vacuumm is set at 1e-2 torr. The resolving Q1 quadrupole is set up at 4e-5 torr, while the Q2 collision quad has argon gas contributing to 1e-2 torr. The TOF tube is set up at 5e-7 torr. In the case of one system, Q0 and Q2 are hexapoles. For MS mode only instruments Q1 is operated in r.f. mode as a mass filter. Spectra from the TOF have the power of its resolution and mass accuracy; all ions are measured in a pulse rather than continuous (scanning) mode. Q1 scans can still be done using th TOF as ion current detector only; generally this mode is used for Q1 calibration and tuning only.

Q0 is used for collisional cooling of ions from the ESI source and for focusing. Q0 and Q2 are operated in r.f.-only mode, creating a potential well with radial confinement of precursor and/or fragment ions. These r.f. quadrupoles or hexapoles are operated at several millitorr and both radial and axial collisional damping of ion motion is obtained. Thermalization of ions by collision reduces energy spread and beam diameter. Re-acceleration of ions axially upon r.f. quad exit provides necessary energies and near-thermal energy spreads. In MS/MS mode Q1 is set to transmit the parent ion only with mass window of 1-3 thomson (Th) depending on whether isotope cluster transmission is desired. Acceleration of 20-200 eV into the Q2 collision cell containing argon or nitrogen produces fragments that are cooled and focused. Since TOF is more sensitive to incoming ion beam quality than a Q3 triple quad, fine tuning in this step is essential.

Collision cells are still pressurized with non-reactive gas to provide the collisional cooling that also helps focusing. After leaving the collision cell the ion is focused. Initially it is a field-free entry. Then a pulsed electric field is applied (several kHz) to push ions orthogonally where ions acquire several keV per unit charge. Ions travel through a field-free drift space where TOF separation occurs. Detectors are composed of aligned microchannel plates configured as a chevron. The electrostatic mirror and detector are similar to those used with pulsed ionization sources (MALDI). Note that positive ions (in that mode) are accelerated from ground to high negative voltages in the TOF of a QqTOF instrument while high positive to ground voltages are used in the MALDI-TOF. This inverted configuration requires and extra shield in the TOF chamber to create field-free drift region floated at high potential. All spectra in the TOF are recorded using time-to-digital (TDC) converter.

In mass analyzer mode with both r.f. and d.c. components applied to rods, and the reduced Mathieu parameters are used to characterize amplitudes of both components:

qM = 4eV   aM = 8eU
(m/z)ω2r02 (m/z)ω2r02

Here e is the electron charge constant in coulombs, V and ω are amplitude and frequency of the r.f. voltage, respectively, U is value of d.c. voltage, and r0 is inscribed radius of quadrupole. Typically with qM = 0.706 and aM = 0.237, a narrow m/z window is obtained. In r.f. mode only, aM = 0 and the quadrupoles are high-mass filters: ions with m/z values below cut-off value corresponding to qM = 0.908 are rejected. Transmission of ions with high m/z values suffers from poor focusing: the depth of the effective potential well is inversely proportional to m/z. Thus ions can be lost in any of the three multipoles on their way to the TOF section. In single MS mode set for r.f.-only mode for Q0, Q1 and Q2, ions covering an order of magnitude in m/z are transmitted simultaneously into the TOF. For a wider m/z range, the r.f. voltage is modulated (stepped or ramped) between two or more r.f. levels during acquisition, providing larger transmission window over time.

With scanning mass analyzers, only one ion type with particular m/z is recorded at any given time; the duty cycle is brought to below 0.1% with full spectrum recording, and is inversely proportional to mass resolution since narrow transmission window and smaller step size are required for higher resolution in a quadrupole.

Cramer R, Corless S (2001) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 15, 2058-2066.

The Nature of Collision-Induced Dissociation Processes of Doubly Protonated Peptides: Comparative Study for the Future Use of Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization On a Hybrid Quadrupole Time-Of-Flight Mass Spectrometer in Proteomics

MALDI-QTOF was done with Pulsar (MDS Sciex) mass spectrometer with prototype UV-MALDI source. ESI-MS/MS was on MDS Protana A/S with nanospray source. Sample introduction with syringe at 0.2 µl/min was done. MALDI-TOF was on PerSeptive Biosystems Voyager Elite XL. Analytes were purchased except for phosphorglycerate mutase 1 from 2Dgel.

Matrices were first examined for optimal selection. Tryptic α-casein digests were measured in linear (axial) mode in UV-MALDI-TOF MS because there is metastable decay in reflectron (lower resolution). There is a lower sensitivity in high mass range for MALDI QTOF MS based on the comparison of instrument modes. S/N dynamic range was better than for linear MALDI-TOF-MS. DHB-matrix peptides had better intensities than from CHCA or caffeic acid, possibly because of a lower background. This is because cold matrices probably have less decomposition. The decoupling of the desorption event from mass analysis in the QTOF but not linear TOF, converting MALDI pulse into quasi-continuous ion beam allows for much higher laser desorption. DHB was also better at yielding +2 ion and thus used for ESI and MALDI-MS/MS.

+1 charge Glu-Fib B was recorded on UV-MALDI-PSD-TOFMS, UV-MALDI-QTOF-MS/MS, and ESI-QTOFMS/MS, and +2 ion on UV-MALDI-QTOF-MS/MS and ESI-QTOF-MS/MS. The fragmentation spectra for +1 ion precursor look almost identical and independent of instrument or fragmentation method. Increasing collision energy decreases absolute signal intensities of precursor and high mass range fragments, shifting to higher yields of low mass fragments, without really causing new ions to form. With the +2 precursor the fragmentation pattern changes significantly, with 8 or 9 of 10 fragments being y ions (only 5 for +1 precursor).

The tryptic peptide of horse myoglobin (V17-R31) was examined with +1 and +2 precursors. In the +1 ion, all fragmentation spectra (including PSD) show high intensities for b10 and b11 along with y11 above m/z 900. Only y-type ions are seen with the +2 ion. The database search showed a significantly higher probability for horse myoglobin match from fragmentation data of the +2 precursor. In contrast +1 ion data showed typically very low confidences (probabilities), even though twice as many fragment ions are observed for +1 ion MS/MS spectra. Matching for the +2 ion data was to y-type ions, twice as many compared to a and b type ions combined.

Ag-stained protein was in-gel digested (known to be phosphoglycerate mutase), and analyzed by linear MALDI TOF and MALDI-QTOF. Both gave good PMF spectra. The calibration on the instrument was even 2 days old, and more than 80% of the matched peptides were within 5 ppm. Those peptides matched above the calibration range (> m/z 1700) were still matched within 15 ppm.

CID-MS/MS spectra of the tryptic peptide H11-R21 +1 and +2 precursor were more complex. More than twice as many a and b type ions were identified and only half as many y type for the +1 compared to the +2 precursor, although both spectra were good enough for unambiguous identification. For all UV-MALDI-QTOF the rel. abund. of +2 ion did not exceed 20% of +1 ion, and when laser intensity was raised to improve ion count, the rel. abund. fell to 10%. Production of +2 ions in MALDI is a function of both the peptide sequence and the matrix. The cold type matrix DHB does better at producing +2 ions.

UV- and IR-MALDI were compared including their special matrices. For Glu-Fib, the +2 ion was about 20-25% of that of the +1 in IR-MALDI using succinic acid matrix. No +2 ions were seen with DHB in UV-MALDI.

Macmillan D, Bill RM, Sage KA, Fern D, Flitsch SL (2001) Chem. Biol. 8, 133-145.

Selective In Vitro Glycosylation of Recombinant Proteins: Semi-Synthesis of Novel Homogeneous Glycoforms of Human Erythropoietin

EPO is a glycoprotein product of fetal liver and adult kidney. Elevated serum oxygen results in reduced EPO expression and low oxygen results in increased EPO. When the kidney fail chronically EPO is lowered and anemia can result. I.V. admin of recombinant human EPO eliminates the need for transfusions. As many as 58 glycosylation variants have been identified. Glycosylation does improve biological activity. It has been shown that O-linked glycosylation at Ser-138 is not essential, but it may serve in folding stabilization. N-linked glycans at Asn-24, -38, and -83 are essential. Sialylation increases circulatory half-life. One group has made it possible to insert Cys in the sequence by site-directed mutagenesis, and these can be glycosylated using iodoacetamide derivatives in a chemical synthesis. rhEPO with Asn−>Cys mutations (N24C, N38C, N83C). One problem in the use of rhEPO is that it normally contains Cys for disulfide bond formation.

His10-WT EPO with mutations N24C, N38C, and N83C were overexpressed from E coli B834(DE3) using pET16b expression system. The EPO was highly aggregated due to disulfide formation, sometimes with itself, sometimes to glutathione. The N-terminal His tag allows for one-step cleaning by metal chelation (Ni2+) affinity chromatography. Isoforms having similar MW were obtained with the overexpression. These were detected using mAbs at the N-terminus of rhEPO. The lower band had a mass of 21097 Da by MALDI-ToF and is most likely His10-C38hEPO (calcd mass 20906 Da). The upper band carries an extended sequence, which results from a failure of an inefficient stop (TGA) sequence that has been see with pET vectors. 26 bp downstream from 3′-end is an StuI site into which is inserted a stop sequence (TAA). Protein yields were 13 µg/ml.

Mass accuracy of the MALDI ToF is about 50-150 Da within the calcd masses. A better resolution was obtained with LC-ESI-MS on reduced protein samples. These are eluted from Ni2+ affinity as aggregates, then reduced in 10-50 mM DTT or TCEP before LC-MS to provide monomers in highly charged states. The mass was within 5-20 Da of the calculated.

Affinity-purified rhEPO Cys mutants were dialyzed against 6 M guanidine HCl in 50 mM Tris HCl pH 8.0 in a nitrogen atmosphere. The protein then was diluted 1:50 (to about 1 µM), then refolded in 2% N-lauroyl sarcosine in 50 mM Tris HCl pH 8.0 with 40 µM copper sulfate. A syringe filter with a 1.5 ml Ni2+-charged affinity resin was then used for concentrating the dilute protein as it was passed over. Another pulsed refolding strategy was used prior to concentration (see Lilie et al. Curr. Opin. Biotechnol. 9: 497-501, 1998). Elution from the nickel affinity columns is using 200 mM imidazole in 6 M guanidine HCl. The glycosyl iodoacetamide is then added to 10 mM. The reaction is monitored by sampling aliquots over time and then checking reaction extent on LC-ESI-MS. Even as high as 50 mM the reactions did not go to stoichiometric completion, but at least one glycosyl (GlcNAc, in this case) was added.

Note that the presence of imidazole assisted the glycosylation. In reactions where protein was concentrated by precipitation instead affinity resin, with resuspension in buffer having no imidazole, glycosylation could be seen on the N-terminal and possibly on the His10 tag. This was verified by use of 2-nitro-5-thiocyanaot-benzoic acid (NTCBA) cleavage of the peptide backbond and then ESI-MS. There were differences in the way the mutants glycosylated: the N38C mutant was >60%, while the other two were 30%. And glycosylation was better under denaturing conditions; samples eluted from affinity resin and refolded before glycosylation did not modify as much.

The neoglycoproteins were separated from non-modified using a lectin column (T. avesticum wheat germ agglutinin immobilized to 4% agarose beads). After glycosylation, products are dialyzed against 3 M guanidine HCl in 50 mM Tris HCl pH 7.5 with 1 M NaCl, 1 mM MnCl2, and 1 mM CaCl2 and then applied to column. Unbound material is washed out, and then the glycoprotein is eluted with 0.5 M GlcNAc. Fractions of elution are monitored by LC-MS.

The MS work established that only one residue had been glycosylated, so it became necessary to determine which site was modified. Unglycosylated protein is also employed since it is useful in comparison as an internal calibrant. Material was prepared at 60 µM in a 3 M guanidine HCl solution and digested with trypsin or chymotrypsin for 1-16 h. Unfortunately the generated peptides produced regions of interest that did not bind to reversed phase (N24C and N38C mutants).

Proteins bound to the affinity column were directly digested on-column. The material coming off the column was collected, and then bound material removed with imidazole. Chymotrypsin was effective at creating fragments of 4300 and 8000 Da. These were further treated with trypsin or V8 protease in 50 mM ammonium bicarbonate pH 8. MS analysis showed that glycosylation occurred between residues 21 and 45 according to the trypsin digest, and residues 24 and 43 on the V8 digest. The fragments not hold C24 and C38 mutants, but also the C29-C33 disulfide bond. The peptide resists V8 treatment (targets Glu). The ion is a +3 ion whose mass is two units smaller than the calculated, indicating that a disulfide bond is present. Glycosylation does not occur at C7 and C161, which form disulfides linking N- and C-termini in the native EPO.

Also tried was NTCBA treatment: this chemical cleaves peptide bonds adjacent to free cysteine thiols. In reduced EPO, NTCBA is effective in producing peptides cleaved at 7, 29, 33, and 161 in wild-type EPO; for the mutants, it cleaved at their sites as well. It was not possible to determine if C38 glycosylation occurred with this chemical because its use resulted in deglycosylation and cleavage. One glycosylated fragment appeared in the N-terminus (before Ile-6), and since there is no Cys here, it indicates another nucleophile.

The aggregation of recombinant EPO expressed in E coli has been subjected to structural analysis. Crystal structures of EPO/EPO-R complex and NMR analysis of recombinant EPO with hydrophilic subsitutions and additions was done. Dynamic light scattering (DLS) reveals the effect of glycosylation since it is insensitive to high ionic strength buffers necessary to solubilize EPO. Light scattered to a right (90°) angle can be assayed as it passes through an avalanche photodiode into autocorrelator. Changes in light scattering over time allow the determination of the translational diffusion coefficient (DT) and then the hydrodynamic radius (RH) with the Stokes-Einstein equation:

RH = kBT/6πηDT

kB is Boltzmann constant, T is absolute temperature, η is the solvent viscosity.

Non-reducing SDS-PAGE already indicated that the refolded proteins were monomeric and not aggregated. DLS was used to get DT when was used to calculate RH, from which an estimated MW was made. DLS was done with increased concentration of guanidine HCl (from 0 to 6 M guanidine HCl in 0.2 M steps). At about 2 M precisely, there was a sharp transition from a monomer weight of 25-30 kDa to about 250 kDa. Circular dichroism spectroscopy had shown such a transition at 1.75 M guanidine HCl for unfolding in EPO derived from CHO cells, and at 1.2 M GuanHCl for E coli-derived EPO.

Schwarz-Selinger T, Preuss R, Dose V, von der Linden W (2001) J. Mass Spectrom. 36, 866-874.

Analysis of Multicomponent Mass Spectra Applying Bayesian Probability Theory

ABSTRACT. In this paper we develop a method for the decomposition of mass spectra of gas mixtures, together with the relevant calibration measurements. The method is based on Bayesian probability theory. Given a set of spectra, the algorithm returns the relative concentrations and the associated margin of confidence for each component of the mixture. In addition to the concentrations, such a data set enables the derivation of improved values of the cracking coefficients of all contributing species, even for those components for which the set does not contain a calibration measurement. This latter feature also allows one to analyze mixtures that contain radicals in addition to stable molecules. As an example, we analyze and discuss the mass spectra obtained from the pyrolysis of azomethane, which contain the radical CH3 apart from nitrogen and C1- and C2-hydrocarbons.

Griffiths WJ, Jonsson AP, Liu S, Rai DK, Wang Y (2001) Biochem J. 355, 545-561.

Electospray and Tandem Mass Spectrometry in Biochemistry

REVIEW. Proteins can be identified at the sub-picomole level with MS (neuropeptides have been identified at the zeptomole—10−21 mol—level). Tandem MS (MS/MS) takes a precursor ion and selects it for fragmentation to provide product ions with structural information. Ionization was usually done by electron impact (EI) or chemical ionization (CI) methods, but these methods require that the molecule to be ionized already be in the gas phase. Polar thermally labile samples are not amenable to these ionization methods without prior derivatization.

Barber and others (1981) introduced fast atom bombardment (FAB) which permitted the ionization of polar thermally labile molecules up to a few thousand daltons. This worked well for already preformed ions (protonated, deprotonated, sodiated) in solution. Generally a 1 µl sample with perhaps [M+H]+ ion and their negatively charged counter ions are dissolved in 2 µl FAB matrix, typically glycerol, and then put into the vacuum. These are then bombarded with Xe atoms accelerated to 8 keV or Cs+ ions energized to 20 keV. The [M+H]+ ions are put into gas phase with protonated matrix clusters. This soft ionization method worked for species below about 1000 Da. Chemical noise can be significant with FAB however, although a continuous flow system helps to minimize the problem.

Karas and Hillenkamp in 1988 at an international conference described MALDI of proteins with masses greater than 10 kDa. Typically MALDI is used with TOF analyzers since they are both work using pulsed streams of ions rather than a continuous stream. Sample is co-crystallized with matrix (like FAB, a matrix is the mediator), and a laser supplies the energy. Ionized (protonated and deprotonated) sample and matrix molecules then are vaporized and mass-analyzed in the TOF which has a theoretically unlimited mass range measurement ability. Peptide mass fingerprinting (also called peptide mass mapping) is the typical use of MALDI-TOF of peptides. The masses are searched against a protein or DNA sequence database and the protein identified by this means. Like FAB, chemical noise from matrix makes the low mass range impossible to use to get data. But peptides tend to have m/z greater than the region.

Electrospray ionization is more versatile than MALDI in ionizing a wider range of polar molecules. Sample is ionized to [M+H]+ and/or [M-H]− ions

Bafna V, Edwards N (2001) Bioinformatics 17, S13-S21.

SCOPE: A Probabilistic Model for Scoring Tandem Mass Spectra Against A Peptide Database

MS/MS spectra generated from CID show fragmentation of peptides in a stochastic process whose factors include the physicochemical properties of the peptide and the collision energy. N-terminal ions form an a, b, c ion series while C-terminal fragments form an x, y, z ion series. The series a, b and y ions are the most common.

The core of most MS/MS spectrum analysis software involves three modules:

  • interpretation: the input is an MS/MS spectrum and output interpreted MS/MS data, which include sequence tags, parent peptide mass, combinations of tags, and any molecular masses
  • filtering: the input is the interpreted MS/MS data and a peptide sequence database, and the output is a list of candidate peptides which accounts for the MS/MS spectra
  • scoring: input is the candidate peptide list and the MS/MS spectrum, and the output is a score (possibly including p value) of the correlation; candidate peptides are sorted/ranked by score.

The filter would do more to eliminate peptides that could not have generated the spectra rather than looking for those that would.

Some de novo sequencing algorithms rely entirely on the MS/MS spectrum as data. They depend on very clean spectra, with the greater intensities corresponding to peptide bond breaks and also on little noise. Database searching algorithms rely more on scoring such that the peptide with the highest score or lowest p value explains the spectrum; it depends on database completeness and a good scoring mechanism. This paper focuses on scoring.

First some terms should be defined. A MS/MS spectrum S ∈ Rk+ is a vector of real positive numbers specifying k observed m/z values of the spectral peaks. A peptide p ∈ ξn is a sequence of n amino acid residues from the alphabet of amino acid symbols. Fragment space φ(p) is an enumeration of all fragment m/z values produced by peptide p. All possible m/z values are generated and each element of φ(p) is a fragment-charge state pair:

φ(p) = {(a1, i), (b1, i), (y1, i),..., (an, i), (bn, i), (yn, i), i = 1, 2, 3}

Where higher energy ionization occurs, double cleavage and no cleavage events and more ion types are variables. A mass-to-charge ratio of fragment f ∈ φ(p) is shown as m/z(f).

Fragmentation Pattern F ⊆ φ(p) is a subset of the fragment space respresenting observed fragments generated from peptide p. Fragmentation Space ξ(p) of peptide p is the set of all fragmentation patterns of p, or ξ(p) = {F : F ⊆ φ(p)}. Noise is considered to be any peak of S for which φ(p) provides no explanation of the peak other than it is noise.

A peptide p is scored by the probability that the observed spectrum S was generated by p. ψ(S|p) is the probability density function for a random vector S representing the MS/MS spectrum given p. A database is searched for petpide p* which satisfies: 

                       p* = arg max ψ (S|p)
                                       p

The formal description of the two-step model of fragmentation is:

ψ (S|p) = ∑F⊆φ(p) ψ(S |F, p) Pr(F |p)

Pr(F |p) is the probability of a particular fragmentation pattern of a peptide, the complex process of fragmentation is modeled in this value. ψ(S |F, p) is the probability that spectrum S was generated by fragmentation pattern F of peptide p. The equation for ψ (S|p) shows that it is computed as the summation over fragmentation space, which is an exponentially sized set. It cannot be computed as part of a database search since the cost is too high.

For getting Pr(F |p), we generate the list of observed fragments. Estimate likelihood of a peptide bond cleavage by counting the number of times it is observed. Some peptides will favor one cleavage or another. Clustering and data mining on the dataset will yield properties causing changes in the likelihood. Acidic amino acids in peptide make the neutral water loss ion type cleavages more likely. A database of expertly curated spectra of peptides does not exist, so probabilities are estimated by other means.

For the probability density ψ(S |F, p), one must resolve the issue of peaks as noise rather than signal. In general a unique m/z value in fragment space generates one spectral peak. Each spectral peak is the observed m/z of at most one of the unique m/z values in fragment space. Assignment of peaks to fragments must be non-crossing. Thus for all fragments f1, f2 and spectral peaks S1, S2, if m/z(f1) < m/z(f2) and S1 < S2. Zero probability is assigned to fragmentation patterns violating the assumptions. Peaks in the spectrum are then assigned either to noise fragments or to a unique from the fragment space φ(p). Only fragmentation patterns F ⊆ φ(p) with |F | = k have non-zero probability mass.

A stronger statement is that peak Si is equal to fragment f such that it is generated by it, and S = (S1, S2,...,Sk) is tandem MS spectrum ordered with respect to m/z. The fragmentation pattern F ⊆ φ(p), |F | = k is an arbitrary pattern with observed fragments f1,...,fk ∈ F ordered by m/z values.

The non-crossing and uniqueness assumptions means only one assignment of spectral peaks to fragments. With a Bayesian notion of valid assignments, then

ψ(S |F, p) = ψ(S | ∩ki=1 [Si =M fi], F, p)

Han DK, Eng J, Zhou H, Aebersold R (2001) Nat. Biotechnol. 19, 946-951.

Quantitative Profiling of Differentiation-Induced Microsomal Proteins Using Isotope-Coded Affinity Tags and Mass Spectrometry

Cell line HL-60 is used an in vitro model for cell differentation and there is much data with this cell line. Treatment with 12-phorbol-13-myristate (PMA) will cause change from a nonadherent state to monocyte-like, adherent, spreading and morphologically altered cell. One would assume with the transition from nonadherence to adherence, the cell surface protein profile would be extensive. The microsome fraction was isolated from untreated and treated HL-60 cell as follows. Lysates from 100 million cells of control or treated were differentially ultracentrifuged. Pellets were resuspended in 0.5% SDS in buffer, and 100 µg protein was reduced and labeled with either a light d0 (control) or heavy d8 (PMA) form of a sulfhydryl-specific ICAT reagent. Samples are combined, trypsinized, and then resolved on multidimensional chromatography: cation-exchange chromatography is used to separate into 30 fractions and remove remaining proteases, ICAT, and SDS. Then each of these fractions is passed through avidin affinity column. Biotinylated peptides are recovered and run on microcapillary LC-ESI-MS/MS. If fractions were taken directly from the cation column, the mass spectrum would be too messy with multiple contaminants.

The mass spectrum is full of paired signals, differing by 8 u from one another for each Cys present on a peptide. Automated precursor ion selection with an exclusion list of peptides already sequenced in a user-defined time window (dynamic exclusion) permitted analysis by CID of 12 of the peptides in a 30 s time window. Two peptides from the RP column separated by 4 s show CID spectra which identifies them as the transmembrane tyrosine phosphatase CD45 and the calcium pump ATC2. Their d0:d8 ratios are 1:0.72 and 1:1.2, resp., indicating that differentiation reduces the amount of CD45 while increasing the calcium pump. Analysis of all 30 cation-exchange fractions produced 25,891 CID spectra. Each fraction consumes 100 min of automated sequencing time, and thus about 50 h to complete. The NCI human sequence database of 73,656 proteins was searched with SEQUEST and identified more than 5000 Cys-containing peptides. These corresponded to 491 absolutely identified proteins. Because of so much data generated, software had to be created to manipulate this: XPRESS and INTERACT, which quantify and organize the peptides identified by SEQUEST.

The d0:d8 ratios were reproducible. CD45 has 23 theoretical Cys-containing peptides and 13 were found, some detected multiple times (between once and 10 times was the range of the 13, for a total of 65 analyses). Variability in quantification was <20%. Consistent variability is found when two additional small-scale experiments were done in a single LC-MS/MS analysis for each experiment. Such precision is the highest obtainable when different samples from different experiments are compared.

This technique does not or cannot quantify proteins without Cys residues, very low abundance proteins, and very hydrophobic proteins. The database searching of the CID spectra found ~5000 Cys-containing peptides matching to 1025 proteins. 491 proteins were conclusively identified and quantified from the d0:d8 ratios. Broad classes of proteins were identified, including moderate and low abundance, regulatory proteins (protein kinases and phosphatases, GTPases), membrane receptors, channels. Changes in abundance of most microsomal fraction proteins are not significant between control and treated cells. For example, proteins of ribosome, cytoskeleton, metabolism and a majority of cell surface receptors and channel proteins are not altered. Many signal transduction-associated proteins and enzymes showed significant changes, particularly those in the downstream pathway of PMA stimulation. Farnesyl-diphosphate farnesyl transferase (squalene sythetase, SQS) shows PMA-induced downregulation by 20-fold; in addition membrane-associated protein connected by a lipid anchor involving protein prenylation requiring farnesylpyrophosphate (FPP), a metabolite whose presence is regulated by SQS, are altered with respect to their subcellular location. SQS is a branchpoint of the mevalonate pathway playing a role in regulating the level of FPP pool either for cholesterol/sterol biosynthesis or nonsteroidal protein prenylation. SQS is activated coincident with a proteolysis-induced release from the membrane, consuming FPP for producing squalene, precursor to cholesterols and sterols. Such activation depletes FPP available for protein prenylation, and thus the PMA-induced downregulation of such prenylated proteins as RhoG and Rac1 in the microsome fraction is explained coincidental with loss of microsomal SQS. Downregulating SQS in response to cytokines and endotoxin, and the coordinated increase in HMG-CoA reductase activity is thought to increase isoprenoid intermediates for an acute inflammatory response.

PMA also downregulates Src family kinases, PKC isoforms, small GTPases, and phosphatases in microsomal fraction of treated HL-60 cells. Increased expression was exceptional: PKC-θ, Yes, and the PTN-1 and -3 phosphatases. PKC-α, -β1, Lck, Src, and phosphatases PP1A and PTN-2 were found in decreased amount after PMA treatment. Together these results indicate that there are unidentified mechanisms for the regulation of specific proteins that likely regulate cellular attachment and differentiation in HL-60 cells. This proteome profiling data now reveals study of the PKC isoforms to determine why these differences occur with PMA treatment.

Badock V, Steinhusen U, Bommer K, Otto A (2001) Electrophoresis 22, 2856-2864.

Prefractionation of Protein Samples for Proteome Analysis Using Reversed-Phase High Performance Liquid Chromatography

ABSTRACT. We describe an approach for fractionating complex protein samples prior to twodimensional gel electrophoresis using reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography. Whole lysates of cells and tissue were prefractionated by reversed-phase chromatography and elution with a five-step gradient of increasing acetonitrile concentrations. The proteins obtained at each step were subsequently separated by high-resolution two-dimensional gel electrophoresis (2-DE). The reproducibility of this prefractionation technique proved to be optimal for comparing 2-DE gels from two different cell states. In addition, this method is suitable for enriching low-abundance proteins barely detectable by silver staining to amounts that can be detected by Coomassie blue and further analyzed by mass spectrometry.

silver staining

Mörtz E, Krogh TN, Vorum H, Gög A (2???) Poster (unknown presentation)

Improved Silver Staining Protocols Compatible with Large-Scale Protein Identification

Proteins were stained and the digested in automated manner using Protana A/S workstation (can process eight 96-well plates in parallel). This workstation has high throughput, sensivitity and reproducibility. Samples are concentrated on ZipTips. 10% of sample applied to tip and eluted to 400 µm Bruker Anchorchip target with 2,5-DHB in MeOH:0.1% TFA (1:1). A modified fuzzy logic algorithm was run on Bruker REFLEX III MALDI with 384 sample Scout source. Software for queries and db managment is in-house, part of Protana Proteomics Software Suite (PPSS 2.2).

Three stadnard proteins were diluted in a series from 1 pmol to 5 fmol. They had been run on 1D gels, stained using Coomassie, and by silver using Schevchenko et al, Bio-Rad's kit, Blum and Vorum. Destaining of silver was also evaluated. Peptide digests were either used directly (2% of sample) or purified on ZipTips (10% of sample). Staining protcols were modified based on intermediate results to optimize sensitivity and recovery of peptides.

The following silver stain protocols were done:

  • EMBL Silver stain
    1. 20 min in 50% MeOH, 5% acetic acid
    2. 10 min in 50% MeOH
    3. 2 h in water (overnight washing reduces background even more)
    4. 1 min in 0.02% (20 mg/100 ml) sodium thiosulfate (Na2S2O3)
    5. 1 min two times in water
    6. 20 min in cold 0.1% silver nitrate
    7. 1 min in water
    8. Transfer to new container
    9. 1 min in water
    10. 0.04% (40 ul per 100 ml) formaldehyde in 2% sodium carbonate: monitor the development: if developer turns yellow, remove it and put in fresh developer.
    11. Stop: 5% acetic acid: change it a couple of times
    12. Keep gel in 1% acetic acid at 4°
  • Blum silver stain
    1. at least 1 h in 40% EtOH, 10% acetic acid fix
    2. 20 min twice in 30% EtOH
    3. 20 min in water
    4. 1 min in 0.02% sodium thiosulfate
    5. 20 s three times in water
    6. 20 min in cold 0.1% silver nitrate
    7. 20 s three times in water
    8. Move to new gel chamber
    9. 1 min in water
    10. Develop in 0.05% formaldehyde and 3% sodium carbonate; change developer if it turns yellow
    11. wash gel in water for 20 s
    12. Add 5% acetic acid to stop
    13. Wash in water three times for 10 min
    14. Keep gel in 1% at 4°
  • Vorum silver stain
    1. Fix gel in 50% MeOH, 12% acetic acid, 0.05% formalin for 2 h or overnight
    2. Wash gel three times in 35% EtOH for 20 min each
    3. Sensitizer: 0.02% sodium thiosulfate for 2 min
    4. Wash three times in water, 5 min each
    5. 20 min in 0.2% silver nitrate contain 0.076% formaldehyde
    6. Twice for 1 min each in water
    7. Develop in 0.05% formaldehyde, 6% sodiumm carbonate, 0.0004% sodium thiosulfate.
    8. Stop. 50% MeOH, 12% acetic acid at least 5 min
    9. Keep gel 4° in 1% acetic acid

The most significant changes were:

  • After acetic acid fixation, the washing was improved, which reduces background and increases sensitivity.
  • Limits to sodium thiosulfate were done: it increases recovery of peptides but it also increases background.
  • Alterations to the stop solution were done to make it MS-compatible

The three proteins were BSA, transferrin and carbonic anhydrase. With the EMBL silver stain, transferrin was detectable down to 25 fmol, with BSA just barely detectable. Carbonic anhydrase could be detected to 50 fmol. The modified Blum had best sensitivity and less background than EMBL. Vorum protocol was less sensitive, but provided black bands and a very clear background (advantage in image analysis). The Bio-Rad kit was comparable to Coomassie staining.

Recovery of peptides with EMBL and Blum was quite good for faint bands. Of interest, the recovery from Coomassie-stained gel or destained silver-stained gels is not better than from silver-stained gels. The best spectra were obtained with micropurified (ZipTip) aliquots and using the Anchorchip, which concentrates the target better. Sequence coverage was better in these cases, which enables identification.

2D gel maps were made with different stains. The background was much better with Vorum than other protocols.

Mörtz E, Krogh TN, Vorum H, Gög A (2001) Proteomics 1, 1359-1363.

Improved Silver Staining Protocols for High Sensitivity Protein Identification Using Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization-Time of Flight Analysis

ABSTRACT In proteomics it is essential to be able to detect proteins separated by gel electrophoresis at high sensitivity. Silver staining is currently the most popular method. Here we present silver staining protocols that are optimized for staining sensitivity, peptide recovery and compatibility with digestion and mass spectrometry.

Smilansky Z (2001) Biochemistry 22, 1616-1626.

Automatic Registration for Images of Two-Dimensional Protein Gels

Between-image registration (alignment of similar or identical patterns) is a complex matter. In 2D gel analysis programs it is one step in the process. In customary applications, spot detection, quantitation, editing and landmarking are done, and the registration is done as part of the matching process, followed by spot comparison. In the Z3 algorithm discussed here image registration precedes spot detection or it goes directly to computing differential expression in raw images rather than creating a synthetic spot image distinct from the raw image. The basis of Z3 is region-based comparison algorithm within the raw image rather than use of spot-cluster matching algorithms.

Image registration can be done using a number of gel features. Spots themselves have shapes, streaks, smears, spot tails, and other special background elements can be used for alignment. Theory of registration recognizes two broad approaches: feature-based and direct methods. Feature-based approaches start with a preliminary stage of feature extraction and then register using the feature list. Spot centers are the usual high-priority features. Direct approaches use intensity data from the raw image rather than working through feature detection. Transformations between gels are generally heuristic and not amenable to analytic modeling. Where a gel has suffered a crack the transformation must be robust. Small regions are expected to correspond and must be locally smooth. A region's small size allows compuation of a transformation as a simple shift vector, and geometric uniqueness enables high-confidence determination. The entire set of shift vectors is combined wtih global transformation using the obvious choice of Delaunay triangulation transformation.

The new method works by comparing regions of gels as opposed to doing registration spot-by-spot. Confidence of matching improves by comparing spot lists region by region rather than spot by spot. Current system implement a graph algorithm where vertex clusters are matched, but the new approach uses a rectangular region of the raw image contain several spots making a unique geometric signature (like a constellation). Direct registration techniques are applied to the subimage defined by this rectangular region and the correct transformation at the center of the region determined. This approach works better for detecting isoelectric shifts.

In the system to compare gel images, the reference is green and the comparative gel is magenta. Overlapping of the green and magenta produce a gray, with weak spots light gray and strong spots being dark gray to black. Similar gels will look entirely black-and-white, although differential expression leads to coloring (greenish when proteins are overexpressed, and magenta for underexpressed). This system is done because of theories on visual perception related to attentive and pre-attentive tasks. Pre-attentive are instantaneous tasks and time of performance is unrelated to complexity. Finding a red letter among a large field-of-view of green letters or a diagonal among vertical line segments is a task of this type. Detection of a difference between two adjacent similar configuration of letters or spots is an attentive task.

The basic step is an optimal shift computation in a small rectangular subimage. Output is a shift vector (x,y)→(u,v), this being a quadruple (x,y,u,v). The list of all shift vectors creates a global transformation; the more vectors, the more complex the transformation. The algorithm starts with the identity transformation, progresses to shift/translation, semi-affine, affine, and then to Delaunay type transformations.

If the size of the basic rectangle is too large, it might not correctly register the entire region. Geometric warping can result from uneven polymerization, uneven coolant flow, voltage leaks, even cuts or tears in the gel. Rectangles too small may not have a sufficiently unique geometric signature; they may have only one spot. Establishing a sequence of covering rectangles (SCR) thus should be such that there are at least 2 and ideally 3 or 4 spots contained. Too many spots runs the risk of having multiple solutions and a nonunique pattern. For the rectangle sequence, apply first a simple spot detection fast and robust without a need to be precise. A local threshold on the 2nd derivative would be an example of a mechanism. A segmentation algorithm then produces a list of spot segments with 3 params: area, bounding rectangle, and contrast value. The area S would contain 4 spots and then constructed. A score for the triangle is computed based on spot count, contrast, and area. If overlap occurs between triangles, the higher scoring one is kept and the other removed. Rectangles for the entire image are sequenced, with number 1 being the rectangle closest to the center of the image, and will be seed for the registration loop. Sorting occurs by determining the distance of all rectangles from the seed rectangle.

Shift Vector List. This represents the first step in the loop of the algorithm. The shift vector of the first rectangle is computed with the global transformation being identity. A discrepancy is a fixed parameter (maximum positional uncertainty) which indicates the maximal expected global shift between two images. If it fails in the 1st rectangle, then the next rectangle is regarded as the first. If it fails for the initial 10 rectangles, the algorithm stops and reports an error. If the solution in the seed rectangle is restricted to a simple shift/translation, then there is a tradeoff between the magnitude of global scaling and rotation and the size of the seed rectangle. Experience shows that the running and scanning and gel image result in relative scaling not larger than 10% and rotations not larger than 5°.

Using the global transformatin T determined by the previous step in the loop, the expected shift vector (x,y,u0,v0) is calcuated by (u0,v0) = T(x,y). The local shift is dx = u0 − x, dy = v0 − y. The expected Idst corresponding to Ri in the source image is Ridst = Ri + (dx, dy).

The allowed maximal horizontal and vertical discrepancy (Du) between the exact solution and the expected shift vector is estimated and for the first few points it is fixed, but with accumulation of several points, it is computed from previous values using principles of statistical error.

A set of rectangles is defined {Rkl = Ridst + s(k, l): k,l = 0, ±1, ±2,..., |sk|1≤ Du + 2s, |sl| ≤ Dv + 2s}. These defined in the destination image and together form the complete set of candidate matches to the original rectangle in source image Ri. The series of rectangles covers a region with sides 2(Du + 2s), 2(Dv + 2s) in jump of size s pixels. The step size s is set to radius of smallest expected spot on the gel and its purpose is to decrease computational load by s2 where typically s=3. The enlargement two by regions on each side helps verify that the solution that was obtained is a real one and not an artifact. If the best solution turns out to have a discrepancy larger than (Du, Dv), it is discarded.

For each rectangle Rkl, a comparison to Ri is done and similarity score is computed. This score function F is the sum of a pixel score function GP over all pixel pairs p ∈ Ri and the correponding pixel q = p + s(k, l) ∈ Rkl. Function Gp is specific to gel image registration and has 3 factors: (i) a fixed coontribution to the score when both pixels have some minimal contrast, allowing spots representing differentially expressed proteins to match, (ii) in cases where both spots have high constrast a bonus is given to give a match between strong spots, (iii) A contribution also occurs from a scalar product of two gradient vectors, increasing the score for spots having same size and shape, and decreases socre for spots whose boundaries overlap incorrectly. The edge pixels provide the contribution: where edges overlap and are similarly oriented, score is increased and where there is negative correlation, score is diminshed. Transformations are preferred where spot matches have similar contrast, size and shape compared to spot matches vastly different. Proteomes comparing different types of tissues or even organisms are inconceivable. In a typical case, at least 70-80% of the spots to match in position, if not size.

With a score assigned to all Rkl the best rectangle is chosen, considering both the score and discrepancy (although the initial rectangle has only a score). Discrepancy is implemented as a central preference factor in a parabolic shape and used in factoring scores. In case of two high scores, one central and one peripheral, the central one wins.

When the chosen solution fails the discrepancy limit, then the test fails. The test at this point is supposed to eliminate problematic areas (random matches) and one happens to be maximal. Scores are sorted by decreasing the distance from the position having the highest score. Sorted scores must form a distribution which has a minimal slope and with a winning score corresponding to a real peak.

A solution is now fine-tuned using optical flow techniques which assume that two images of distinct 2D gels are the same physical data observed twice; standard optical flow equations, the choice solution is fine-tuned to sub-pixal accuracy. Let ∇gi denote a gradient vector at pixel i and dgi be the gray level difference between source pixel Pisrc and the corresponding destination pixel Pidst. w denotes the required shift. The brightness constancy equation explains the gray level difference dgi resulting from an image shift. This is estimated using gradient ∇gi, thereby enabling the determination of w through minimizing ∑(∇giw − dgi)2, the summation being over all pixels in the region of interest. Least squares fitting is used in solution, iterating 2-3 times to gain robustness and precision. If convergence occurs, the analysis is a success; otherwise an error is generated and "failure" reported. If the shift vector was computed successfully and passed all test, the vector is added to SVL and transformation (discussed below) is applied/updated.

With all shift vectors computed, it is possible to analyze for an irregular vector as a new way of detecting errors. In some cases however large deviations (large 2nd derivatives) should be allowed (cuts/tears). A singleton is not allowed: this is a shift vector not supported by even one other vector in its neighborhood. Even with a tear or crack several vectors should be similar. This particular test is done at the end of the main loop. If there is no change in the shift vector list (SVL), then the main loop is exited; otherwise there is a chance to add more anchors.

silver-associated peptides, CID, FD

Chu IK, Shoeib T, Guo X, Rodriquez CF, Lau T-C, Hopkinson AC, Siu KWM (2001) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 12, 163-175.

Characterization of the Product Ions from the Collision-Induced Dissociation of Argentinated Peptides

Low (<100 eV) energy CID spectra of protonated peptides produce a series of ions that are typically a, b, and y type fragments. In solution the more basic sites are N atoms on the N-terminal amino, and side chains of Arg, Lys, and His. In gas phase however, the energy barriers are altered, particularly with collision so that the proton bonds to amide N atoms, which is the first step in promoting fragmentation. Charge retained on the N-terminal peptide becomes a b ion, and on the C-terminal side a y ion. A b ion can typically undergo neutral loss of CO and become an a ion. The type b ion was thought to be an acylium ion, but several groups (Harrison's, Wesdemiotis', and Hunt's) have shown evidence it is an oxazolone ring, which fragments under CID to produce immonium via acylium activated complex. Silver ion has been used for heavy atom derivatization in crystallography and metallothioneins have a high affinity for Ag ion. In solution Ag(I) has a high affinity for Met thioether, but in gas phase, it formed a complex with the amidic carbonyl groups probably as a result of an attempt to solvate with ion. Fragmentation showed four ion types: [bn-H+Ag]+, [an-H+Ag]+, [yn-H+Ag]+ and [bn+OH+Ag]+

The model peptide AAA shows a product ion spectrum of the ion [b2+OH+107Ag]+, filtered in the triple quad (the 109Ag form of peptide ion was filtered out). Another spectrum is of the product ions of [M+107Ag]+ of dipeptide AA. These two spectra are almost identical. The most intense peak at m/z 196 would correspond to two isobaric fragments, [b1+OH+Ag]+ and [y1-H+Ag]+. This spectral similiarity for [bn+OH+Ag]+ product ion and [M+Ag]+ with identical residues

GGG peptides, mobile proton theory, FD

Rodriquez CF, Cunje A, Shoeib T, Chu IK, Hopkinson AC, Siu KWM (2001) J. Am. Chem. Soc. 123, 3006-3012.

Proton Migration and Tautomerism in Protonated Triglycine

Different computed structures of GGG are presented using computational chemistry. Relative (1) electronic energies, (2) enthalpies, and (3) free energies are given at 298 K in tabular format. Initial structures computed using HF/6-31G(d) by Zhang et al were the basis for geometric optimization of neutral and protonated GGG calculated at B3LYP/6-31++G-(d,p). These results were then modified to produce isomers of GGG-H+ found on an energy hypersurface, which would generate a b2 ion Of the many isomers that could be structured, only the lowest energy structures are shown. Three neutral GGG are presented, two folded, and one linear. One of the folded structures (N2) is an optimization of the lowest energy HF/6-31G(d) minimum of Zhang et al; the only significant difference between the Zhang et al structure and N2 is the distance between N-terminal amino H atom and the C-terminal carbonyl O atoms. For Zhang et al, the distance is 2.654 Å but in N2 it is 3.683 Å. The use of B3LYP/6-31++G(d,p) higher level of theory is a more accurate description of long-range interaction. where electron correlation and diffuse functions are incorproated. N2 is also closed to the Strittmatter and Williams neutral GGG structure via molecular mechanics, with the major difference between the orientation of COOH group. Both folded structures (N1 and N2) are lower in energy than the folded (N3) by 2.9 kcal/mol. The results are not different for enthalpy changes at 298 K. Introduciing entropy terms, there is only a 0.2 kcal/mod difference in free energies among isomers (meaning differences are negligible).

Proton transfer from N-terminal amine N atom to C-terminal peptide bond amide N atom, followed by cleavage to form b2 ion is a long sequence involving 8 structures and 6 described transition states, all of which are computed. The free energy profile is shown computed in B3LYP/6-31++G(d,p), with a final two product yield of 2-aminomethyl-5-oxazolone (ring form GG) and glycine. Protonated GGG has sufficient flexibility to form long-range H-bonds. Four H-bond types are considered: N-H┉N, O-H┉N, N-H┉O, O-H┉O. H-bonding distances < 2.0 Å. Two low-energy N-terminal nitrogen-protonated structures designated P1 and 1 were computed: structure 1 is lower than P1 by 0.4 kcal/mol in energy and similar to lowest energy structure found by Zhang et al. while P1 is similar to the optimized structure of Strittematter and Williams.
