Hydrogen bond of type N1-H┉O2 (subscripts are residue number) of length 1.840 Å in structure P1, while it is shorter in structure 1 at 1.777 Å for N1-H┉O3. With hydrogen bonding, proton transfer to carbonyl O atom on 2nd peptide bond proceeds. The proton must then undergo a 1,3-shift to place itself on amide N3 atom for fragmentation to occur to produce b2 ion, but this takes 40 kcal/mol. From 1 to structure 2, the amino nitrogen proton moved to O1 atom is a 1,4-transfer requiring 4.3 kcal/mol; this structure is a global minimum and lower than structure 1 by 1.3 kcal/mol. 2 is more linear than 1 and thus has a greater entropy contribution; the O1-H┉N1 H bond is 1.748 Å, the shorter bond giving more stability. The 5-membered ring in 2 has a more compact (shorter bond lengths) than the ring in 1. The final structure is the 2-aminomethyl-5-oxazolone which requires rotation of the N-termainal amino so it is trans to carbonyl O atom (∠N1CCO1 ≈ 180°) [The text of this article goes into detail describing the transition and energy in the reaction which involves b2 ion formation. There are alternative structures considered, such as the transition from 4→6 going through 9 instead of 5.]

In collisionally activated decomposition, enough energy will cause progress from structures 1→4. From 4 (where protonation is on carbonyl O atom), there is a 32.5 kcal/mole barrier representing TS(6→7). Threshold energy experiments found an estimate of 54.5 kcal/mol, which is the upper limit as the kinetic shift, large for an ion with as many bonds as protonated GGG, was ignored; incorporating kinetic shift reduces the estimate drastically.

Many studies have looked at the probable protonation site of a petpide. Structure 1 suggests the N-terminal amino N atom, 1 kcal/mol higher than structure 2 which is amide O1 atom (with solvation by amino N atom). Structure 4 shows protonation on same O atom but H-bonding to carbonyl O atom of 2nd residue. Structure 2 has relative stability because it has larger entropy. Gas phase basicity of base B is the free energy change ΔG0r,298 while proton affinity is the enthalpy change, ΔH0r,298 of the reaction

BH+ → B + H+

and they are related by the simple equation

ΔG0r,298 = ΔH0r,298 − TΔS0r,298

ΔH0r,298 is arrived by molecular orbital calculations:

ΔH0r,298 = ΔEelec + ΔEZVPE(0) + ΔEint(298) + 5RT/2

First three terms oare electronic energy, zero-point vibrational energy, and thermal energy needed for reaction 1 at 298.15 K. The 5RT/2 constant is estimation of three translational degrees of freedome (3RT/2) for the proton plus RT which is the PV work term for the proton. Substituting the free-energy and enthalpy equations above along with

TΔS0r,298 = [298.15][S(BH+ − S(B)] − 7.8 kcal/mol

where the 7.8 kcal/mol is the entry of the proton at 298.15 K. With structures N1 and 2, the basicity of GGG is 216.3 kcal/mol, while for N1 and structure 1, basicity is 215.0 kcal/mol. Zhang et al determined basicity for the amino N atom and found 219.6 kcal/mol. Several different theoretical methods are used, and a couple agree with our own calcuations.

alpha2-macroglobulin, 2DGE

Kondo T, Sakaguchi M, Namba M (2001) Exp. Gerontol. 36, 487-495..

Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis Studies on The Cellular Aging: Accumulation of Alpha-2-Macroglobulin in Human Fibroblasts with Aging

KMS-6 and OUMS24 are normal human fibroblast cell lines from 9- and 6-week old female human embryos, respectively. KMST-6 was produced from KMS-6 by 60Co irradiation and OUMS24F from OUMS24 by 4-nitroquinoline 1-oxide treatment. Cells are maintained in EMEM with 10% hi-FBS and subcultured at confluence. 15th passage cells are young while 53rd passage KMS-6 and 74th passage OUMS24 cells are senescent. Aged cells were confirmed by incubating fixed cells (2% HCHO/2% glutaraldehyde 5 min RT) at 37° with 1 mg/ml BCI-galactose in pH 6.0 (40 mM citrate acid/sodium phosphate) buffer containing 5 mM K3Fe(CN)6, 5 mM K4Fe(CN)6, 150 mM NaCl, 2 mM MgCl2.

Proteins were obtained from thrice PBS-washed cells, treated with 10% TCA ice-cold 30 min on ice and pellets washed with PBS. Pelleted cells were solubilized in 5 M urea, 2% Triton X-100, 70 mM DTT, 2% ampholytes and 1 mM PMSF for 30 min on ice at 4°. 2DGE was on pH 4-7 Immobiline and run on a Multiphor. Second dimension was a 12% gel, with silver staining as done by Hochstrasser et al. Duplicate gels were run.

Stern DF (2001) Exp. Molec. Pathol. 70, 327-331.

Phosphoproteomics

REVIEW. In pathology there is an effort to distinguish disease into subtypes and to make prognostic predictions. Tumor analysis has two approaches: (1) develop a taxonomy for tumors involving tissue of origin and look at common biology, and (2) try to find biomarkers (individuals or groups) with strong prognostic or predictive significance. Transcriptomics and RNA profiling may hold promise, but these don't predict post-translational modifications that may originate a disease course.

Prototypic phosphoproteomic analysis. HER2/NEU/ERB2 is a gene for the receptor tyrosine kinase in the EGF receptor family. In 1 in 5 to 1 in 4 breast and ovarian (and other) cancers, this gene is amplified. Its presence is associated with a poor prognosis and chemotherapeutic resistance. Herceptin (Tratuzamab) is a humanized monoclonal approved for use in patients that overexpress Her2. Oncogene models in animals with Her2 overexpression show aggressive cancer. Her2 is weakly activated when overexpressed, but strongly activated by EGF family growth factors and maybe by splice alterations and proteolytic processing.

RTKs are phosphorylated on specific Tyr residues when activated. The phosphopeptides produced are docking sites for downstream signaling processes. The antibody PN2A is a mAb directed against phospho-Her2. It detects a heterogeneous signal in breast carcinomas, indicating a signal heterogeneity of Her2. With overexpression of Her2, there was only a weakly predicted poor prognosis. With a small subset of patients with high Her2 phosphorylation there was a shorter disease-free and disease-significant survival. Thus antiphosphate specific antibodies have strong predictive value.

A major function of Her2 is to stimulate Ras in cancer. Looking at downstream components such as MAP kinase could prove useful. Because it is an endpoint in the signaling system, it might be a superior marker to examine effects. But is MAP kinase a good indicator of Her2 activity? Hardly, since Her2 has other many downstream effects.

The hallmark of cancer is that there is a disruption of the growth factor (mitogen) requirement for cell proliferation. This can be achieved by mutations in Ras or by constitutive growth factor receptor activation by autocrine factors, receptor overxpression, and receptor mutation.

SPR, DNA-protein complexes

Buckle M (2001) Methods in Molecular Biology 148, 535-546.

Surface Plasmon Resonance Applied to DNA-Protein Complexes

Surface plasmon resonance (SPR) measures the refractive index changes (δn) at or near a surface and relates those changes to changes in the mass at the surface. The relationship is described through the Mossotti form [Eq 2] of the Debye equation [Eq 1]:

ε − 1 = N ( α + μ )   [1]
ε + 2 3ε0 kT
ε − 1 = Nα [2]
ε + 2 3ε0

where ε is the real part of the dielectric or permittivity constant related to the refractive index by ε = n2, N is the number density given by NAρ/Ma (NA is Avogadro's number, ρ is density, and Ma is molecular mass). The value Δn/ΔC is assumed to be constant.

The BIACORE instrument is an SPR device made with a monochromatic, plane-polarized light source with photodetector, these connected optically through a glass prism. A 50 nm thin gold film is deposited on one side of the prism, and this is covered with long-chain hydroxyalkanethiol forming a monolayer 100 nm thick. The layer is an attachment point for carboxymethylated dextran chains creating a hydrophilic surface to which ligands can couple. Light incident to the back side of the metal film is internally reflected on the diode array detector. An evanescent wave that is nonpropagative penetrates to the solution side of the prism away from light source. In the gold layer free electrons resonate with the evanescent wave. The amplitude vector of the transversal wave propagating along the gold surface (ksp) is equal to the component of the evanescent wave (kx). Since ε = n2, if ω is the wave frequency and c speed of light, then:

|ksp| = (ω/c)[(ε1 − ε2) / (ε1 + ε2)]1/2

The evanescent wave is described by:

|kx| = (ω/c) sinθ (εg)1/2

When resonance occurs, |ksp| = |kx|, and the intensity of reflected light decreases at a sharply defined angle of incidence, the SPR angle, given by the expression:

sinθ0 = (ε1ε2) / [εg(ε1 + ε2)]

The SPR angle θ0 is where there is a decrease in intensity of reflected light, measuring the refractive index of the solution in contact with the gold surface and depends on the wavelength of the light source and the metal used in the film. When those parameters are kept constant the angle shift in SPR depends only on refractive index changes in the thin layer on the metal surface. Increases of surface material should result in increases in the SPR angle, detected as a shift of the position of the light intensity minimum on the diode array. Changes in surface concentration over time have been correlated with radiolabeling methods and linearity is shown over a wide range of concentration. Instrument output is given in resonance units (RU) with a 1000 RU corresponding to a 0.1° shift in SPR angle, which for the average protein is a change in concentration of 1 ng/mm2. The Biacore 2000 can measure a deviation of 0.001°, thus being a variation in refractive index of 0.00001.

computational chemistry, 2+ NaCl cluster ions, FD

Aguado A (2001) J. Phys. Chem. B 105, 2761-2765.

An ab Initio Study of the Structures and Relative Stabilities of Doubly Charged [(NaCl)m(Na)2]2+ Cluster Ions

Alkali halide clusters have many useful properties and have been investigated in multiple ways. Much about singly charged clusters (AX)nA+ has been analyzed, as well as neutral clusters. Small clusters of sodium iodide and lithium halide would adopt ground state structures which are stacks of hexagonal rings while others adopt rock salt-like ground state structures. Theoretical calculations on the +1 charged clusters verify experimental records of bulk rocksalt symmetry even for elements crystallizng in CsCl-type structure: namely CsCl, CsBr, CsI. Doubly charged clusters present the problem of excess charges adding to instability. With NaI clusters a critical size was deduced for stability in which m = 18 for [(AX)m(A2)]2+. Pair potential calcuations on structures of 2+ NaCl clusters were used to explain experimental findings; cluster sizes had at least one metastable bound state, even though m < 8 caused removal of Na+ cation leading to exothermic reaction.

The model used is the ab initio perturbed ion (aiPI) model which is good computational framework for ionic systems in both crystals and clusters. aiPI has theoretical foundation in theory of electronic separability. The Hartree-Fock (HF) equations are solved stepwise, breaking the cluster wave function into local group functions (ionic characteristics). With each iteration total energy is minimized with respect to variations of the electron density localized in given ion, and densities of other ions are not varied (kept frozen). The self-consistent process finishes, and outputs are total cluster energy and set of localized wave functions, one for each geometrically nonequivalent ion of the cluster. Localized cluster-consistent ionic wave functions are used to estimate intraatomic correlation energy correction through Clementi's Coulomb-Hartree-Fock method. Large multizeta basis sets of Clementi and Roetti are used to describe the ions. In ths respect optimizations are performed using basis sets (5s4p) for Na+ and (7s6p) for Cl−. Use of diffuse basis functions was found unnecessary. Use of localized functions makes it possible to scale linearly the computational effort with number of atoms in cluster. Full structural relaxations of clusters have been done with as many as 58 ions with reasonable computational cost. Isomers (about 10-15) have been investgated for each cluster size. Generation of initial cluster geometries done using pair potential. Optimization of geometries was achieved using downhill simplex algorithm.

Optimized aiPI structures for ground state and the lowest lying isomers of [(NaCl)mNa2]2+ where m = 8-28 were determined. Structures for m = 6 and 7 were calculated just to show the special stability of m = 8 size. The low-lying isomers with m = 8 have a 3 × 2 × 2 structure with a a (NaCl)6 neutral cluster (notation indicates number of ions along each of three perpendicular Cartesian axes), and they differ in the way six extra ions are added. Most favorable addition of extra ions is along two opposite edges of the neutral. The two triatomic NaClNa+ units minimize mutual repulsion without distorting too much of the neutral cluster. Zhang and Cooks visualized structure as combination of two 3 × 3 × 1 planar sheets. Since sheets bend in the ab initio calculations, the notation 3 × 2 × 2 + 3 + 3 is preferable to describe the cluster; although calculations agree with their suggestion. Ground state structures of m = 9 and 10 are more visually difficult, resulting in addition of one and two NaCl atom pairs. The GS isomer of m = 11 constructs a GS isomer as 3 × 3 × 2 + 3 + 3; these added triatoms are on same face as neutral structure. With m = 12, a compact structure of different kind appears: the GS structure can be formed from singly charged (NaCl)13Na+ cluster and removing the inner chloride anion coordinated to six atoms. Pair potential calculations by Martin

radical cations, collision-induced dissociation, copper(II)

Chu IK, Rodriquez CF, Hopkinson AC, Siu KWM, Lau T-C (2001) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 12, 1114-1119.

Formation of Molecular Radical Cations of Enkephalin Derivatives via Collision-Induced Dissociation of Electrospray-Generated Copper (II) Complex Ions of Amines and Peptides

PE-SCIEX mass spectrometers were used: API III, and prototypes of API 3000 and Q/STAR; first two are triple quads, and latter is Q-ToF. 600 µM Cu(II)-amine perchlorate and 50 µM are in 50% MeOH, infused at 2 µl/min with air nebulization. Product ions are generated by nitrogen or argon with center-of-mass energies (Ecm) at 1-3 eV. Cu(II)-amine perchlorate is synthesized according to published procedures (perchlorate intead of nitrate). Amines tested are dien, Me5dien (N,N,N',N',N"-pentamethyldiethylenetriamine), terpy (2,2':6',2"-terpyridine), and 4-Cl-terpy (4-Cl 2,2':6',2"-terpyridine).

Peptide YAGFLR (= M) is mixed with [CuII(dien)](ClO4)2 in solution and submitted to ESI. The ion [63CuII(dien)M]2+ is most prominent at m/z 445.73 Th, with minor ions of [M+H]+ at 726.40 Th, M•+ at 725.38 Th, [CuI(dien)]+ at 166.04 Th, and [CuII(dien-H)]+ at 165.03 Th. CID of [63CuII(dien)M]•2+ shows that radical cations of the peptide M•+ are formed along with [CuI(dien)]+ when [63CuII(dien)M]•2+ fragments. Ion [M-106]•+ is a 2nd generation product ion as well. Note that the radical cation of M is formed from YAGFLR, not YAGFL. With the latter peptide, there are two reaction pathways: (1) dissociation into [CuII(M-H)]+ and [dien+H]+, and (2) dissociation into [M+H]+ and [CuII(dien-H)+]. Latter is intra-ionic proton transfer in complex ions.

Radical formation of the cation is not dependent on complexing amine of the metal (only peptide sequence). [63Cu(Me5dien)M]•2+ product ion for M=YGGFLR shows prominent M•+ and [M-106]•+. Also terpy and 4-Cl-terpy ligands were as effective. Comparing spectra shows that Arg and Tyr residues are important. Product ion spectra filtering on [63Cu(Me5dien)M]•2+ for M = MGGFLR (M=Met in peptide) produces [CuII(M-H)]+ and [dien+H]+, as well as [M+H]+ and [CuII(dien-H)]+, but no M•+ or [M-106]•+. 30 peptides were surveyed at the N-terminal, and either Tyr or Trp are necessary for radical cation production. Ionization energies for these two amino acids are the lowest among the amino acids. For the Trp-peptide complexed to Cu(II)(dien) as a radical 2+ ion, CID leads to formation of three different types of channels: (1) [CuII(M-H)]+ and [dien+H]+, (2) [M+H]+ and [CuII(dien-H)]+, and (3) some M•+ plus a prominent [M-129]•+ ion. Quinmethides form from oxidatin of phenolic compounds in biological reactions. Coenzyme PQQ (pyroloquiolinequinone) oxidation of Tyr and Trp can lead to Cα-Cβ bond cleavage producing p-quinmethide and 3-methylene indolenine respectively. The loss of 106 in YGGFLR and 129 Th from WGGFLR is because of the elimination of these side chains. With the product spectra of YGGFLR and WGGFLR looking virtually identical with relative abundance differences, it is likely the precursor ions have the same structure. Previous reports indicate that both Tyr and Trip and a basic residue like Arg in order to show radical cations, with radical cations showing loss of Tyr or Trp. These experiments show radical cations are produced in Tyr- and Trp-containing peptides without Arg, Lys, or His; moreover side chain cleavage of Tyr and Trp is not always seen. The way in which fragmentation occurs in copper-liganded peptides is only residue- and sequence-dependent.

Radical ion production for organics occurs through electron impact resulting in fragmentation. Dissociation mechanisms track the radical and charge sites (electronic hole) as mobile. Using resonant UV two-photon ionization plus resonant visible photon absorption to follow dissocation of small peptides with one Tyr or Trp residue, the charge is seen to migrate over several residues to effect fragmentation distant from chromophore. Charge is initially localized to chromophore as a ground state cation. Photoexcitation promotes unpairing of an electron to charge transfer state and the new hole hopes between sites that relatively stabilize it. Charge transfer between residues is dependent on conformation; favorable conformations enable sufficiently strong coupling strength and high probability of charge transfer. Two precursor radical cations containing peptide M = YGGFLK, the Lys containing peptide, are checked for product ions: [CuII(terpy)M]•2+ and [M-106]•+. For the [M-106]•+ ion and that for M=YGGFLR, similar ion types are observed, particularly yn* and zn, not commonly seen in protonated peptides. The YGGFLR y2* ion is believed to be cyclic, while z5 is thought to be a ketene. Ions of type an and bn are notably missing from protonated peptide spectra. N-terminal fragments like (b4*-H), (a4*-H), and (b3*-H).

Shorter peptides are also being investigated, particularly as they produce fewer ions and reduce the complexity of interpretation. Peptides YSK and YTK generated [M-106]•+ and this ion was filtered for its product ions. The two spectra are quite similar. They differ only in that the β-C of residue 2 has a methyl group vs. a hydrogen. Ions from m/z 234.18 and 248.17 in the spectra of YSK and YTK, respectively, differ by 14 Da and are y2 ions; corresponding ions at m/z 144.08 and 158.08 also differ by 14 Da, the different between -CH3 and -H atoms and are (b2*-H) ions. The latter ions lose the Tyr residue side chain, and this seems to be the characteristic of radical peptide cations.

Gygi SP, Rist B, Griffin TJ, Eng J, Aebersold R (2002) J. Proteome Res. 1, 47-54.

Proteome Analysis of Low-Abundance Proteins Using Multidimensional Chromatography and Isotope-Coded Affinity Tags

ABSTRACT. The effectiveness of proteome-wide protein identification and quantitative expression profiling is dependent on the ability of the analytical methodologies employed to routinely obtain information on low-abundance proteins, as these are frequently of great biological importance. Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis, the traditional method for proteome analysis, has proven to be biased toward highly expressed proteins. Recently, two-dimensional chromatography of the complex peptide mixtures generated by the digestion of unseparated protein samples has been introduced for the identification of their components, and isotope-coded affinity tags (ICAT) have been introduced to allow for accurate quantification of the components of protein mixtures by mass spectrometry. Here, we demonstrate that the combination of isotope coded affinity protein tags and multidimensional chromatography/mass spectrometry of tryptic peptide mixtures is capable of detecting and quantifying proteins of low abundance in complex samples.

Petricoin 3rd EF, Ardekani AM, Hitt BA, Levine PJ, Fusaro VA, Steinberg SM, Mills GB, Simone C, Fishman DA, Kohn EC, Liotta LA (2002) Lancet 359, 572-577.

Use of Proteomics Patterns in Serum to Identify Ovarian Cancer

In more than 80% of patients ovarian cancer is presented at late clinical stage with a 35% 5-year survival. Those presenting in stage I have a 90% 5-year survival with cure from surgery alone. CA125 antigen is most widely used, abnormally high in 80% of advanced stage disease, but has a 10% positive predictive value as a single marker; this improves to 20% with ultrasound added to the screening. Use of MALDI-TOF and SELDI-TOF might help with low MW serum protein profiling.

In this study 100 controls (50 preliminary and 50 masked) were available from an ovarian cancer program. 17 controls showing other problems were also avaiable: endometriosis (7), uterine fibroids (3), sinusitis (4), rheumatoid arthritis (2), ulcerative colitis (1) and included in masked validation. Cases from program were self-referred with at least one of following criteria: first-degree relative diagnosed, familial breast or ovarian cancer syndrome, positivity for BRCA1 or BRCA2, personal history of breast cancer. All women received annual 3-D color doppler flow ultrasound and CA125 measurements. Simple ovarian cysts were found by ultrasound in 38% of unaffected women (those having a min. 5 year follow-up without ovarian cancer). All epithelial subtypes of cancer were represented; stage I cancers were representative as they are in the community. The median age in the healthy controls was 49 (range 21-75) in the preliminary set and 48 (25-73) in the masked validation set. Median age in affected preliminary of 58 y (range 29-82) and masked validation of 59 (30-80) was not significantly different. Serum was obtained before exam, diagnosis or treatment and flash frozen in liq. nitrogen. Samples were thawed divided into 10 µl portions and re-frozen.

Analyzed serum was thawed and added to C16 hydrophobic interaction chip and analyzed on the Protein Biology System 2 SELDI-TOF (Ciphergen). The mass resolution is about 400 or less, and mass accuracy calibrated with angiotensin peptide (about 1000 ppm or 0.1%). Data were analyzed according to Holland's genetic algorithms and Kohonen cluster analysis. ASCII format spectral m/z and intensities from SELDI-TOF (about 15,200 values) are run through the algorithm whose output is the best fit of intensities which segregates data. Spectra from 50 healthy and 50 affected with biopsy-proven cancer were compared where the algorithm identifies the m/z values of signficance through iterative search. Once key subset of the m/z values are identified in the first phase analysis, a second phase to classify unknowns is done. Patterns of the relative intensities is matched to an optimum pattern from the first phase analysis. Unknowns fall into three categories: cancer, unaffected, or new cluster. New cluster indicates a point in N-space outside the defined likeness boundaries of the cancer and unaffected clusters. A more detailed description of results and analysis is available online.

Results show high reproducibility (<10% CV) with selected m/z peaks of the higher intensities. The analysis software took random samples and could reliably assign 100% of samples into the proper cluster. Two healthy and two affected samples were analyzed and intensities at m/z 534, 989, 2111, 2251, and 2465 discriminatory between healthy and diseased. There was a 100% sensitivity and 95% specificity for this set, with positive predictive value of 94%, compared with 35% for CA125.

Griffin TJ, Han DK, Gygi SP, Rist B, Lee H, Aebersold R, Parker KC (2001) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 12, 1238-1246.

Toward A High-Throughput Approach To Quantitative Proteomic Analysis: Expression-Dependent Protein Identification by Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. The isotope-coded affinity tag (ICAT) technology enables the concurrent identification and comparative quantitative analysis of proteins present in biological samples such as cell and tissue extracts and biological fluids by mass spectrometry. The initial implementation of this technology was based on microcapillary chromatography coupled on-line with electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry. This implementation lacked the ability to select proteins for identification based on their relative abundance and therefore to focus on differentially expressed proteins. In order to improve the sample throughput of this technology, we have developed a two-step approach that is focused on those proteins for which the abundance changes between samples: First, a new software program for the automated quantification of ICAT reagent labeled peptides analyzed by microcapillary electrospray ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry determines those peptides that differ in their abundance and second, these peptides are identified by tandem mass spectrometry using an electrospray quadrupole time-of flight mass spectrometer and sequence database searching. Results from the application of this approach to the analysis of differentially expressed proteins secreted from nontumorigenic human prostate epithelial cells and metastatic cancerous human prostate epithelial cells are shown.

Barth A, Zscherp C (2002) Quart. Rev. Biophys. 35, 369-430.

What Vibrations Tell Us About Proteins

REVIEW. Avg yeast proteins has 20,000 vibrational degrees of freedom, the normal modes of vibration. A normal mode couples movements of several internal coordinates (bond lengths and angles). The estimate is based on 500 amino acids in a protein with an avg 15 atoms per amino acid for a total 7500 atoms, assuming each has 3 degrees of freedom. 6 degrees of freedom correspond to translation and rotational movements, with the balance vibrational. Dominant vibrations include the C=O stretch and atoms belonging to functional groups.

Vibrational spectra can be acquired using Raman scattering and IR light absorption. Spectral recordings plot intensity or absorbance against wavenumbers (inverse wavelength). This spectroscopy is very sensitive to bond strength changes as 0.02% can be detected (based on spectral resolution of 5 cm−1. Bond length and energy are directly related so distortions during catalysis or binding can be monitored with significant accuracy.

The frequency of oscillation of two atoms is given by the equation

ν = (k/mr)0.5/2π

where k is force constant between two atoms and mr is a reduced mass (1/mr = 1/m1 + 1/m2). An increase in k clearly increases frequency, and this means electron density in bond increases. Alterations in density are caused by inter- and intramolecular factors. A larger the atomic mass, the slower the vibration. Indeed, isotopic labeling causes frequency shifts that are used in structural determinations.

Chemical structure of the molecule dominates spectral features and alterations in structure are sensitive to spectral interpretation. Protonation of catalytically active residues can be seen in IR. Changes in redox state cause changes in electron density and affect vibrations.

Stretching vibrational frequencies are a direct indicator of bond force constants. Relationships between vibrational frequency and bond strength (ΔH) were studied for serine proteases and proteins. Proteins form acyl-enzyme intermediates which breakdown based on interaction with acyl-enzyme ester carbonyl. For a dhydrocinnamoyl-chymotrypsin acyl-enzyme intermediate a nonbonded conformation and a productive conformation were identified, and carbonyl stretching wavenumbers shift by 39 cm−1, and this indicates a carbonyl bond strength of 26.9 kJ/mol. Shifts in frequency can correlated with reaction rates which are affected by changes in bond length.

Vibrations are coupled typically which depends on molecular geometry and geometry and frequency are correlated for many chemical groups. Thus coupling provides 3D structure information. The two C-O vibrations in COO− are coupled with stretching seen at 1400 and 1570 cm−1 but changing with electron density and the O-C-O angle. A hypothetical extreme of 90° and 180° gives no coupling at 90° and the strongest coupling at 180°. When the bonds oscillate at the same frequency coupling is its strongest. Chelation to a cation would cause changes in bond lengths and angles and therefore frequency shifts. Symmetric and asymmetric stretches will report the angle between P-O and V-O in phosphate and vanadate, used in myosin studies. Finally the amide groups in the protein backbone will couple with amide oscillators, the coupling dependent upon 3D structure.

Hydrogen bonds stabilize structures and are vital to catalysis, and vibrational spectroscopy directly indicates their bond strength. Bonding lowers the frequency of stretch vibrations because it lowers restoring force; in contrast it increases bending vibration frequencies since it produces additional restoring force. C=O groups that downshift 1 cm−1 correspond to favorable binding enthalpy of 1600-2600 J/mol for several aliphatics. In substrate binding to enzyme favorable enthalpies with respect to water are as large as 60 kJ/mol when C=O groups are bound between enzyme and substrate. For example pyruvate binding to LDH causes downshift of substrate C=O band by 35 cm−1, and the bond length only changes 0.02 Å! H-bonding to phosphate (PO2−) lowers the band position in symmetric stretching by 3-20 cm−1 and antisymmetric stretching by 20-34 cm−1. This is because electron density is reduced in P-O bonds and there is a relaxation in phosphate geometry toward the ideal tetrahedral as Coulombic repulsion is decreased.

Electric fields induce alterations in electron density distribution. These fields are natural within large molecules, such as the active site of a dehalogenase which strongly polarizes the product of the catalysis.

Bandwidth in addition to band position and intensity is a third spectral parameter useful in interpretation. A particular conformer of the molecule exists for 10−18 seconds, and the band position for a given vibration is slightly different for every conformer. This heterogeneity gives rise to the band broadening. The more flexibility in structure, the broader the band compared to more rigid structures; hence bandwidth is a measure of conformational freedom. Others have related bandwidth to entropy and the effects of entropy are quantified in catalysis. Phosphate bands of GTP will narrow (or become sharper) when the nucleotide binds Ras protein. Bandwidth studies have allowed determinations of whether a functional group or amino acid side chain is exposed to solvent or confined to an inner part of a protein.

With infrared spectroscopy, the electric field vector E(t) of the electromagnetic wave couples with the oscillating (vibrating) dipole moment μ(t) of the molecule. When the light and vibrational frequencies are the same, the electric field amplifies the movement of the oscillating charges. An additional point is that the larger the point charges +q and −q, the stronger the interaction with the electric field. Harmonic oscillation assumes discrete energy levels separated by hν where ν is vibrational frequency. Fermi's golden rule states that the transitional probability between two vibrational levels is proportional to the square of the transition dipole moment (TDM). For transition from vibrational level n to m of the electronic ground state ψ0 the Born-Oppenheimer approximation that separates the nuclear wavefunctions φn and φm from the electronic wavefunction ψ0 and using U = μ(t)E(t) for operator of interaction potential U:

TDM = ⟨ψ0φm|μ|ψ0φn⟩

TDM has a electronic and nuclear component in the equation with two selection rules: the nuclear term is zero except when m = n ± 1 and indicates that a jump can only be made to the next level: Δn = ±1. Most oscillators are in the ground state so it is the first excited state that represents the transition. For a diatomic oscillator the TDM to this first excited state is:

TDM = ⟨∂μ/∂R(R0)⟩(h/8π2mrν)0.5

The right term is the nuclear contribution, and the left term electronic, being the expectation value for change of dipole moment at equilibrium position R0 calculated with electronic wavefunctions. The second selection rule is revealed here in which IR wave absorption occurs when dipole moment of molecule changes with vibration. The larger the change the stronger the absorption; a large change is correlated with a large bond polarity. Consider a dipole moment with partial charges +q and −q with a distance R separating them and the moment μ = qR. The change in dipole moment with any change in R (effectively bond length) is ∂μ/∂R = q. Hence the larger the partial charge, the larger the bond polarity and the stronger the absorption. More intense (absorbed) bands are seen with C=O than for C=C in molecules like HFC=CH2, as H2C=CH2 does not absorb at all. Intermolecular actions (solvent actions) that contribute to polarization will be indicated in absorption magnitude.

A huge table is included in this article to list the IR absorption of amino acid side chains in the presence of water (H2O) and deuterated water (D2O).

Amino acid side chain IR bands
from Barth, 2000
Assignment Band position in cm−1
(and extinction ε in M−1 cm−1)
in 1H2O 		Band position in cm−1
(and extinction ε in M−1 cm−1)
in 2H2O 		Remarks
Cys, ν(SH) 2551 1849  
Asp, ν(C=O) 1716 (280) 1713 (290) if no H-bond 1762 cm−1 in proteins; shift 25 cm−1 down if H-bond; above 1740 cm−1 there is inverse correlation of ν(C=O) with dielectric constant ε
Glu, ν(C=O) 1712 (220) 1706 (280) Expected to be up to 50 cm−1 higher without H-bond
Asn, ν(C=O) 1677-1678 (310-330) 1648 (570) Up to 1704 cm−1 in proteins
Arg, νas(-NH-C[=NH2+]-NH2) 1652-1695 (420-490) 1605-1608 (460) Postion dependent upon salt bridges between Arg and other residues in 1H2O, not for 2H2. In 1H2O without a salt bridge, it is near 1672 cm−1. In proteins in water it is up to 1695 cm−1 and is down to 1595 cm−1 in D2O.
Gln, ν(C=O) 1668-1687 (360-380) 1635-1654 (550) Between 1659 and 1696 cm−1 in proteins
Arg, νs(-NH-C[=NH2+]-NH2) 1614-1663 (300-340) 1581-1586 (500) Postion dependent upon salt bridges between Arg and other residues in 1H2O, not for 2H2. In 1H2O without a salt bridge, it is near 1635 cm−1. In deuterated proteins there is shift down to 1595 cm−1.
HisH2+, ν(C=C) 1631 (250) 1600 (35), 1623 (16) Only one strong band seen for 4-methylimidazole at 1633 (H2O) and 1605 cm−1 (2H2O).
Lys, δas(NH3+) 1626-1629 (60-130) 1201 2H2O band position based on shift observed for CH3NH3Cl and CH3N2H3Cl
Tyr-OH, ν(C-C) δ(C-H) 1614-1621 (85-150) 1612-1618 (160) ε estimated relatve to 1517 cm−1 band, Tyr or p-cresol
Asn, δ(NH3) 1612-1622 (140-160)
Trp, ν(C-C), ν(C=C) 1622 1618
Tyr-O−, ν(C-C) 1599-1602 (160) 1603 (350) Tyr or p-cresol
Tyr-OH, ν(C-C) 1594-1602 (70-100) 1590-1591 (<50) ε estimated realtive to 1517 cm−1 band, Tyr or p-cresol
Gln, δ(NH2) 1586-1610 (220-240) 1163
HisH, ν(C=C) 1575, 1594 (70) 1569, 1575 Doublet is because of two protonated tautomers of His
Asp, νas(COO−) 1574-1579 (290-380) 1584 (820) Shift might be +60 or −40 cm−1 when cation chelation occurs, and in extreme cases the band position is as for ν(C=O)
Glu, νas(COO−) 1556-1560 (450-470) 1567 (830) See Asp νas(COO−)
Lys, δs(NH3+) 1526-1527 (70-100) 1170 2H2O band position is based on the shift observed for CH3NH3Cl and CH3N2H3Cl
Tyr-OH, ν(C-C), δ(C-H) 1516-1518 (340-430) 1513-1517 (500) Tyr or p-cresol
Trp, ν(C-N), δ(C-H), δ(N-H) 1509 indole IR spectrum
Tyr-O−, ν(C-C), δ(C-H) 1498-1500 (700) 1498-1500 (650) Tyr or p-cresol
Trp, ν(C-C), δ(C-H) 1496 Trp Raman spectrum, observed in the indole IR spectrum at 1487 cm−1
Phe, ν(C-C ring) 1494 (80)
Phe, δ(CH3) 1445-1480
Trp, δ(C-H), ν(C-C), ν(C-N) 1462 1455 (200) ε estimated from comparison with 1571 cm−1
His−, δ(CH3), ν(C-N) 1439 1439 Observed for 4-methylimidazole with strong contribution from δ(CH3). Thus, position for His may differ
Pro, ν(C-N) 1400-1465 Sensitive to backbone conformation
Pro, δ(CH3) 1425-1475 Good group frequency, normally at 1463, near 1425 cm−1, and more intense when next to a C=O group
Trp, δ(N-H), ν(C-C), δ(C-H) 1412-1435 1382 1H2O: higher number for Raman spectrum of Trp, lower number for IR imidazole spectrum. 2H2O: Raman spectrum of Trp.
Gln, ν(C-N) 1410 1409
Glu, νs (COO−) 1404 (316) 1407 see Asp νs(COO−)
Asp, νs(COO−) 1402 (256) 1404 could shift +60/−90 cm−1 with cation chelation, and in extreme cases the band position is as for ν(C-O) of COOH group. Band position of Asp in D2 is estimated from shift observed for CH3COO−
Asp, δs(CH3) 1375 or (1368, 1385) 1 band for one CH3 group, 2 bands for two adjacent groups (Val, Leu), narrower than δ(CH3) but same intensity. Insensitive to hydrocarbon chain conformation.
Trp 1352-1361 Higher number for Raman spectrum of Trp, lower value for IR imidazole
Trp 1334-1342 1334 (100)

Rabilloud T (2002) Proteomics 2, 3-10.

Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis in Proteomics: Old, Old-Fashioned, But It Still Climbs Up the Mountains

REVIEW. 2DGE became a more useful tool when microanalytical techniques (such as Edman sequencing at picomole level) became available to make use of it as a preparative tool in protein identification. With the use of MS as a more sensitive and effective tool, particularly with identifying post-translational modifications, the usefulness of 2DGE increased measurably.

Disadvantages in 2DGE include inability to automate and get high throughput. Although resolution in 2DGE is still impressive, it is insufficient for looking at all cellular proteins. Zoom/narrow range pH gels have helped a great deal. Other problems have to do with preventing abundant proteins (such as actin, present at 108 molecules per cell) from overwhelming detection of low abundance proteins (such as receptors or transcription factors, present at 100-1000 molecules per cell). In serum, albumin, at 40 mg/ml, can make it impossible to find cytokines, at pg/ml levels. Enrichment or prefractionation strategies must be considered. Other problems occur because of protein insolubility during 2DGE or with protein extraction failing to get some proteins.

Consider trying to do work without using 2DGE. SDS-PAGE coupled with MS/MS is one. The problems in focusing are eliminated, and one band on the gel theoretically represents a single protein. This approach worked on characterizing spliceosomes and highly enriched chloroplast envelope preparations. The problem is, most preparations have greater complexity, and it is rare that an isolated band contains a single species. SDS-PAGE has no other role than in deconvoluting the protein mixture, to prevent overcrowding of the MS/MS spectra. One problem with gel use and extraction of peptides is that yields are quite low (usu. ≤ 1%).

Because of this, others have decided to use gel-free methods. Yates and coworkers have introduced MudPIT, in which extracts are digested first into peptides (often with different enzymes), and the total digest separated multidimensionally by chromatography and then sequenced. Complexity reduction is in the chromatography step, but the MS/MS system also handles several peptides at a time. One small limitation is to be able to automate the system such that a nanoflow ESI runs without clogging for an extended period of time. MudPIT also has no ability to quantitatively assess the proteome.

Quantitative analysis of proteins using a non-gel approach would require use of ICAT labeling, although 1 in 7 proteins has no cysteines. Also such agents require a reactive cysteine for proteins not too hydrophobic.

Array-based approaches like that of DNA microarrays would involve use of a ligand bound to array substrate to bind to a labeled protein, in something quite similar to an ELISA (antibodies to antigens). Indeed use of antigens or antibodies to capture materials of interest is the focus. The best approach may be phage display, which can possibly generate several thousand specific binding sequences. Other issues arise however that mean doing several thousand immunoassays on a microscale while retaining specificity.

One of the great advantages of 2DGE is the ability to analyze modified proteins. Phosphoproteins are a good example. The complex mixture of proteins is digested with protease(s) after reductive alkylation. All amino groups are protected with tert-butyl oxycarbonyl (tBOC) first, then all acid functional groups (carboxyl and phoshoryl groups) are activated with EDC and then reacted with ethanolamine to form ethanolamide derivatives. The ethanolamide derivative from phosphoryl groups are selectively removed by mild acid treatment (the phosphoramide is more reactive than the amide of carboxyl groups) to yield the free phosphate group on peptides. The phosphate is then activated with EDC again and cystamine added to derivatize it. The disulfide in the cystamine is then reduced (with phosphine) and an SH-reactive biotin probe (namely an ICAT probe) is added. The phosphopeptide has now in these multiple reactions has been biotinylated and can be selectively retained on an avidin column. A strong acid can be added to deblock all derivative groups (the phosphoramide, the carboxylamide, and the tBOC-amine). The peptide is then subjected to MS/MS analysis.

Array-based methods for modified proteins is not yet ready. Consider the use of anti-phospho amino acid antibodies which work well for phosphotyrosine but weakly bind for phosphoserine and phosphothreonine. There is no concept for array-based methods involving other, usually very small derivative modifications such as acylation.

The ability of 2DGE small modifications will not come in the 2nd dimension since mass is hardly changed. Rather many such modifications alter charged residues and thus the pI.

FD

Sonsmann G, Römer A, Schomburg D (2002) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 13, 45-78.

Investigation of the Influence of Charge Derivatization on the Fragmentation of Multiply Protonated Peptides

Tryptic peptides subjected to ESI-MS conditions tend to be doubly charged in positive mode (doubly protonated). When fragmented, they yield singly-charged b and y ions. In cases of missed tryptic cleavage, these peptides (partials) contain more than one basic amino acid and the protonation can reach 4 or 5. Fragmentation is more intense in this charge state, and the product ions also have higher charge states to complicate spectrum interpretation. Chemical derivatization of peptides to increase charge state also improves fragmentation. Several mechanisms have been proposed to explain fragmentation, including charge site-induced and charge site-initiated, with the idea that a mobile proton is randomly distributed over the peptide backbone. Many studies have limited themselves to one and two basic residue peptides, but multiple basic residues would be of interest since a maximum count of charges is expected with increased Coulombic repulsion. This increased protonation would also limit the movement of a mobile proton. Because the C-terminus is a localization of negative charge and attracts the proton, greater fragmentation is expected near this site. To see the influence of negative charges, peptides with Cys were oxidized to cysteic acid. A negative charge brings in another proton for a net single positive charge on the molecular ion, and y ions (N-terminal charges) predominate.

Native glucagon (HSQGTFTSDYSKYLDSRRAQDFVWLMNT, every 10th residue in bold) was sequenced by ESI-MS/MS on a Thermoquest LCQ with flow 1-5 µl/min and capV=4500 V, temp=200° and sheath gas set to 60 (instrument value). Range was m/z 250-2000, isolation width was 3 Da. Increasing charge states of precursor were set with 25-50% lower collision energies, but adjusted to maximum fragmenation efficiency. Final spectra were acquired over 1 min (20-25 scans). The MS/MS spectra of charge states +2, +3 and +4 showed significant differences in fragmentation behavior. A +5 ion was not observed in glucagon although there are five titratable sites (bovine insulin B-peptide is reported to have +5 ion). Likely because Arg-17 and -18 are too close, one of them is not protonatable.

The +2 ion of glucagon is poorly fragmented. Ions are mainly products from cleavage at the COOH side of Asp; fragmentation at D residues is observed and may be because of nucleophilic attack on the deprotonated carboxyl group. What likely happens is that Asp lends its COOH proton to the amine nitrogen of the C-terminal residue, then the oxyanion binds to the carbonyl carbon of the own residue of Asp, forming an acid anhydride 5-membered ring, and cleaving the peptide.

Selection of the +3 precursor glucagon shows more thorough fragmentation with b and y ions present, these product ions also doubly charged. This might indicate a mobile proton on both ends is involved in fragmentation, where fragmentation involves a charge separation mechanism. Smaller singly charged peptide products are not detectable in the ion trap, and the double charged fragments are of detectable intensity.

The +4 precursor shows only intense fragmentation of the C-terminus. +3-charged b ions are explained by a mobile proton on the C-terminus whereas basic residues (His, Lys, Arg) are protonated by an immobile proton. In addition an immobile proton occupies the N-terminal His, withdrawn from peptide backbone.

The N-terminus was derivatized with chlorosulfonylacetyl chloride (CSAC, Cl-SO2-CH2-C(=O)-Cl) in a previously described method: 1 nmol peptide is dissolved in 2 µl 20 mM sulfonic acid (2 µl CSAC in 500 µl water), which is evaporated, then re-dissolved in 20 µl THF/ethyl-diisopropylamien (4:1) and 2 µl 0.1 M CSAC n dry THF added, vortexed for 30 s after 1-2 min reaction time, vacuum dried then dissolved in 50% MeCN with 0.1% formic acid. For acetylation, 10% acetic anhydride in acetic acid is used for 2 h, evaporated, then suspended in 1 M ammonium hydroxide for 20 min to remove O-acetylations, then evaporated and stored in freezer. It is dissolved in same solvent just before ESI-MS. In addition a triphenylphosphine (Br-TPP, bromoethyl-triphenylphosphine) was prepared and used with peptide (0.5-2 nmol) in a pH 9 Tris buffer, with a 10 nmol Br-TPP/µl MeCN solution added in 20-fold molar excess, and reacted for 3 h at 37°; derivatized peptide is collected on SepPak or BondElut CS to remove organic products.

The +2, +3, and +4 precursor ions of derivatized glucagon were then analyzed. The +2 precursor showed improved fragmentation with N-terminus y ions of +2 charge evident. Asp-induced fragmentation was less of a factor based on lower intensities of these ions. +3 charged precursor showed additional y ions and a significant increase in b ions with fragmentations at the C-terminus. Hence adding a negative charge at the N-terminus improved y ion appearance as expected. As for the C-terminus fragmentation, the second proton may locate at basic sites in the middle of the peptide and 3rd proton must be distributed along the C-terminus. A plot of the +2, +3, and +4 b and y ions of native and sulfonylated glucagon shows that sequence information (MS/MS spectra) improved considerably with derivatization.

The bovine insulin B chain (FVNQHLCCAMGSHLVEALYLVCCAMGERGFFYTPKA) resembles a tryptic peptide with a Lys at position 28 near C-terminus, and the Arg-22 represents a missed cleavage. Charge states from +2 to +5 were examined. The +2 ion MS/MS spectrum reveals poor fragmentation, with a main b29+2 product. The N-terminal side of Pro-27 fragmented easily with neutral loss of water (b272+ − H2O). There is very low abundance fragmentation of N- and C-terminus. Thus with two protons at Arg and Lys in the C-terminus, fragmentation along the backbone is unfavorable.

The +3 ion shows greater distribution of fragment ions. Doubly charged b ions (from b142+ to b272+) series and a y ion series from y282+ to y172+, and so a mobile third proton is explained. Only the Pro-Lys C-terminal bond resisted cleavage. The greater intensities were at both ends of the peptide.

The +4 ion MS/MS spectrum was more difficult to interpret, because of fragments in different charge states overlapping. The greater intensities are for cleavage in the middle of the peptide. In the +5 ion precursor spectrum only a few highly charged fragments can be seen. The more intense fragments are doubly charged with sequence of the center of the peptide being given. If the mobile proton theory is true, then a restricted mobility of the proton would account for the dissociation distribution. If His at 4 and 9 are protonated in the +5 ion, and the next basic residue is Arg-22, the fragmenation pattern shows a mobile proton trapped between His-9 and Arg-22.

Derivatized insulin peptide at the N-terminus puts a fixed positive charge on it (Br-TPP), with a +6 precursor now selectable. However, this derivative is not stable. The +2 ion selection yielded a high intensity fragment showing a 289 Da loss, corresponding to cleavage of TPP off the peptide, and the same was seen for +3 and +4 precursors. The loss is described with plasma desorption MS as a reversed Michael-type reaction. The MS/MS of +4 ion is quite different: the N-terminus now has a fixed charge and so Lys dissociation is not seen at N-terminus; y ion series at the N-terminus has been suppressed and now a b ion series at the C-terminus is favored, with some +2 y product ions from the C-terminus also observed.

Acetylation of the primary amines (N-terminus, ε-NH2 of Lys) should lower basicity. Only a +2 and +3 precursor ion can be seen. There is better fragmentation along the middle of the peptide for the +2 ion, and the +3 ion produces only a b series (b122+ to b272+). A small y series (y3+ to y6+) derived from charge separation reactions confirm the C-terminal sequence. With suppression of y fragmenting in the middle, a more easily intepretable spectrum is obtained. Bromo-nicotinic acid acylation produced similar results (note the isotope distribution of bromine for modification of the N-terminus can be used to help distinguish b and y ions).

When derivatized with CASC a mixture of mono- and bis-derivatives were found. Only +2 and +3 ion precursors were observed, indicating how the negative charge decreases overall charge state of precursors. Only a mono adduct (modified N-terminus) was seen. One intense ion showed a loss of the adduct, providing a marker for stepwise searching from N-terminal amino acid; the y292+ ion had a mass difference of 78.5 amu, which is exactly the correct mass difference for a +2 ion indicating Phe. The next seven (y292+ to y222+) fragments were determinable. The series y17+ to y7+ with charge localized to C-terminus were readable also. Thus derivatization improved fragmentation at the N-terminus and the abundance of y ions. Fragmentation of the +3 precursor also showed the same dissociation pattern, with mostly y series ions sequencing the N-terminus, with diminished b ion series intensities. Putting a negative charge on the N-terminus directs fragmentation to the N-terminus, and is independent of precursor ion charge state. There is additional help when the adduct is lost in some ions to help identify N-terminus ions.

Yarmush ML, Jayaraman A (2002) Annu. Rev. Biomed. Eng. 4, 349-373.

Advances in Proteomic Technologies

Advances in functional genomics do not obviate the need to study the structure, function, and interaction of proteins that come into the realm of proteomics. Proteomics is essential microarrays and PCR-based methods do not provide information about the proteome nor regulation at the transcriptional, translational, and posttranslational levels. Studies of yeast and liver show no direct relationship between transcriptome and proteome. Transcripts can be processed to different final messages that produce different protein isoforms.

The classical description of proteomics is (1) protein profiling (2) protein identification and (3) elucidation of protein-protein interaction. Proteome maps or fingerprints are obtained from two-dimensional gel electrophoresis, in which an orthogonal separation according to isoelectric point (pI) and molecular mass (MW) of subunit polypeptides. Fingerprints of different cellular or tissue states can be compared to identify relevant proteins particular to that state or phenotype. Major limitations of 2DE as a protein profiling method is its ability to represent the entire proteome. Proteins have widely varying solubilities and much of the protein is not seen with 2DE. Solubility in IEF is particularly a problem. Membrane proteins cannot really be analyzed by IEF and are lost in sample preparation. Hydrophobic proteins, basic proteins (pI > 8), and high MW (~200 kDa) proteins typically precipitate during IEF and are poorly resolved. Zwitterionic detergents (e.g., ASB) has improved solubilization of hydrophobic detergents, but affect resolution of other protein classes.

Fryksdale BG, Jedrzejewski PT, Wong DL, Gaertner AL, Miller BS (2002) Electrophoresis 23, 2184-2193.

Impact of Deglycosylation Methods On Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis and Matrix Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization-Time of Flight-Mass Spectrometry for Proteomic Analysis

A great deal of papers indicate LC-MS/MS is about to replace 2DE although 2DE still has high resolving power. Many studies today focus on comparative expression of proteins and few focus on PTMs in proteins.

LAMINEX cellulase mix was desalted with PD-10 using either a water or pH 7.5 sodium phosphate eluent. Desalted samples were then concentrated on Ultrafree-15 centrifugal concentrators. Digestion was done with PNGase F and Endo H using manufacturer's instructions (see text for details). O-Glycanase and sialidase II, with β-galactosidase and β-N-acetylhexosamindiase were used in a cocktail. After all digestions, proteins are precipitated with 10% TCA/20 mM DTT in acetone, leaving for 1 h at −20° collecting precipitate and washing twice with 20 mM DTT in acetone then air-drying. The Glyko-Free kit is TFMS + toluene, neutralized with pyridine. 63 mM ammonium bicarbonate is used to form a precipitate that contains the protein. GC-MS is used to measure mole percent of mannose, galactose, glucose, N-AG.

PNGase F and Endo H digests were examined on 1D gels with a 62 kDa standard (HRP?) PNGase F at 36 kDa was stained as was Endo H at 29 kDa; band shifting to a lower MW region was clear. Samples digested with O-glycanases showed no band shifting. The total carbohydrate and mole percent of the glycan removed was determined using GC-MS. Untreated protein has a 21% carbohydrate by weight and enzyme treated had 12% by mass. In stark contrast, TFMS-treated had very little (~2%) and each of the carbohydrate peaks present was found only in trace amounts, indicating that the glycoprotein gel stain was quite informative about the glycan content of treated protein. A table shows the mole percent: untreated shows 66.4% mannose, 8.8% galactose, 22.9% glucose, 1.9% N-acetylglucosamine, with no xylose detected. Enzyme treated protein showed 73.0% mannose, 8.8% galactose, 15.9% glucose, 2.3% NAGamine, and no detected xylose. TFMS-treated protein had no specific sugar at all detectable.

The cellulase samples were enzymatically treated (PNGase F, O-glycanses, and Endo H) and separated on 2D gels. Generally few if any difference were seen between the pre-treated and treated samples. Note that while all three pre-treated gels should theoretically look the same, the "pre-treatments" included additions of reagents or of denaturing conditions, not to discount the usual gel-to-gel variation that notoriously occurs in 2D gels. Isoform trains or spot patterns were seen in both pre-treated and treated. Molecular weight changes were not particularly noticeable. Two small spot trains at the extreme alkaline region disappeared with PNGase F, Endo H, and more faintly with O-glycanases. A new spot train at a lower MW appeared: this train probably represents endoxylanase II as seen on the TFMS-treated control.

Contrasting enzyme and TFMS treatments, TFMS treatments resulted in visible decreases in MW and tight charge trains. Eight trains were visible and also can be related to bands in the 1D Coomassie-stained gels. 2D gel pattern complexity was reduced. Spots were "most likely" consisting of same polypeptide or simple mixtures. Lower MW spots are single spots or smaller trains. Results show less effectiveness for enzyme treatments (probably steric hindrance); it is reported that glycan removal is more effective if the polypeptide is digested into peptides. Another report shows that a cellobiohydrolase I (CBH I) cellulase is reduced by 10 kDa when digested with Endo H and PNGase F, but there was no such loss of mass in these experiements. It is possible that an inhibition occurred since our preparation was not purified.

Curiously charge trains were still evident with TFMS treatment. Another group showed that TFMS treatment of CBH I result in loss of isoforms and formation of a compact spot. Do the charge effects result from acid treatment, or are they do to modifications not affected by TFMS degradation?

Cellulase control was run in 1D gels and stained with a phosphoprotein-specific dye but no banding was evident (absence of sensitivity). Sample was then analyzed using direct inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry and there was 327 µg phosphorus per gram protein, or 0.033% phosphorus by weight. If the avg MW of a protein is 50 kDa, this is 0.5 mole P per mole protein. This would likely make a protein insensitive to a phosphoprotein stain If phosphorylations alone accounted for the isoform train, there should be enough phosphorylations present to be detectable by the stain. For example a protein with 4.39 mol P per mol protein present at 160 ng would be detected. It thus seems unlikely that the isoform charge separation results from phosphate.

Proteins were identified using peptide mass fingerprinting with MALDI-TOF MS. Since the protein identity was already established, this amounts to a verification of the system. Two proteins in the spot train are unknown, whereas 5 are identified (β-glucosidase I, CBH I, CBH II, endoxylanase II, and endoglucanase III. Several plugs were taken from larger protein spots (five per protein). A table is shown of the avg number of total peptide seen in spectra using the three enzymes (and also three pre-treated). Enzyme treatment increased the number of peptides seen. Where a protein is heavily glycosylated there is little to no enhancement of ionization. As for increased peptide in mass spectra it is possible that a small amount of deglycosylation by enzymes results in better trypsin digestion.

An interesting finding was that spot plug excision location dependence was found for protein spots. 20 plugs were excised from random locations from the CBH I spot, and masses compared to theoretical digets of CBH I. The finding was that the avg number of total peptides matched to CBH I did no vary significantly between matching pre-treated and treated samples. It shows that spot samples for some proteins involves finding sweet spots and especially those in a charge train. Enzyme treatment generally did not improve the ability to identify proteins (except in case of PNGase F).

With respect to TFMS-treated, identifications were more problematic. Gel spots yielded a lack of peptides specific to protein using the normal search system. When spectra were processed through Proteometics m/z software and searched using ProFound with a public fungal database.

Methods. Excised gels spots are washed in three alternate cycles of 25 mM ammonium bicarbonate and 100% MeCN, then reductively akylated with DTT and iodoacetamide. Digestion is with trypsin in 25 mM ammonium bicarb for 4 h at 37°. Peptides are extractd in 3% formic acid. 0.5 µl sample (from 20 µl extract) is mixed with 0.5 µl of CHCA satd in 50% MeCN. The ABi Voyager DE-STR MALDI ToF MS in + ion mode with 20 kV, a 67% grid voltage, 185 ns delay, and 100 scans per spectrum in the m/z 700-3000. Calibration was internal using trypsin autolytic peaks. The ABi PMF system uses Protein Prospector MS-Fit at http://prospector.ucsf.edu/ and some data during comparison are processed using Proteometric, Inc. m/z Knexus Edition software and searched with ProFound.

Glycan analysis. Free glycan can be precipitated with 10% TCA in acetone if 100 ug protein used. Pellets are hydroylyzed with 1 M methanolic HCl, then dried, N-acetylated with MeOH and acetic anhydride, then trimethyl-sialylated wtih Tril-Sil. Samples are resolved on a 30 m DB-1 column with 0.25 mm i.d. using GC-MS.

Wehofsky M, Hoffmann R (2002) J. Mass Spectrom. 37, 223-229.

Automated Deconvolution and Deisotoping of Electrospray Mass Spectra

Experiments were done on quadrupole ToF with peptides in 50% MeOH with 1% formic acid at low picomole level. The Isoconv algorithm uses the theoretical isotopic cluster and variance of peptides to deisotope MALDI- and MALDI-PSD spectra. Monoisotopic masses are determined to simply interpretation of PSD spectra. The program is modified to deisotope multiply charged clusters in ESI-MS and ESI-MS/MS spectra, and is called ESI-Isoconv.

Analyzing lower charge states (singly and doubly, for example) might result in incorrectly calculated signals in the deconvoluted spectrum. In contrast deconvoluting spectra from high to low charge states gets past incorrect processing because intensities calculated for higher charge states fall between the intensities of the recorded signals. Only the maximum charge state zh is required for deconvolution and must be estimated or calculated from the spectrum. For MS/MS spectra zh is identical with charge of selected precursor ion. The basic algorithm loads the spectrum, subtracts background, and analyzes peak form. From low to high, the Z = zh is found. The spectrum is then deconvoluted and deisotoped with charge Z and stored. Z is then decremented by 1. The deconvolution and deisotoping and saving of the spectrum continues for all charge states down to Z = 1. Finally the individual charge spectra are deconvoluted and deisotoped for a combined spectrum.

For each data point in a signal , the mass is calculated based on Z as m/z × Z − (Z − 1), assuming ion [M + zH]z+. The mean isotopic pattern is then determined (see Wehofsky et al. Eur. Mass Spectrom 7: 30, 2001). Assuming a monoisotopic peak, the mean pattern is normalized to the intensity of the current data point and resulting intensities of the isotopic signals of the cluster at distances 1/Z are subtracted from processed spectrum (i.e. original spectrum for Z = zh). If assumption is that detected signal is monoistopic is correct, processed channels contain positive (other peptide signal present at this mass) or zero (no signal present at mass) signal intensity. The sum of signal intensities of detected cluster is written as monoisotopic singly charged signal [M + H]+ at mass m/z × Z − (Z − 1) to a new spectrum SZ containing only signals of currently processed charge state Z. Intensities of all signals corresponding to the cluster are substracted from the processed spectrum Sp. Negative intensities indicate one or more processed channels are not part of the cluster for that charge state. Intensities of these data points are not altered in processed spectrum and the data point in spectrum SZ would be set at zero. The final deconvoluted and deisotoped spectrum is calculated as the sum of the zh spectra at each mass

Sd(m) = S1(m) + ... + Szh(m)

If signals in a cluster are not baseline-separated, any charge state zh selected would produce a false signal at m/z × zh − (zh − 1). Subtraction of intensities in processed spectrum could affect deconvolution of incorrectly processed signals at lower charge state resulting in more background noise in deconvoluted spectrum. The program scans signals from low to high and always assumes a threshold signal represents a monoisotopic peak. Shape and width of a monoisotopic peak should resemble the other signals at higher m/z in the cluster. The form of the peak is decided based on the following exclusion criteria in the table below:

Exclusion Criteria for Checking Peak Form
Monoisotopic Peak
/ \ ^ v
Higher Isotopic Peaks / + − + +
\ − + + +
^ + + + −
v + + − +

In this table, a ‘+’ means that the peak form of an isotope cluster, while ‘−’ indicates the signal is not part of the cluster and no longer considered for processed charge state. ‘/’ and ‘\’ indicate ascending and descending intensity signals, and ‘^’ indicates the top of the peak while ‘v’ is the minimum between two peaks. If processed signals are not excluded in peak form analysis, the sum of the signal intensities are stored in the spectrum.

In testing the algorithm on insulin, limitations were found for higher peptides masses as higher charge states result in incorrectly assigned signals at higher masses than the exactly assigned dominant [M + H]+ ion at 5804.7 u. Examination of processed spectra Szh to S1 showed that misinterpretations occurred usually in only one charge state (Sn) but not in the next lower or higher charge state (Sn−1 or Sn+1). In contrast correctly assigned signals of higher charged species were always present in several spectra Sn resembling the ion seris of ESI spectra. Thus intensities of all corresponding data points (same masses) in both spectra Sn and Sn−1 were multiplied:

P(n,n−1)(m) = Sn(m) × Sn−1(m)

The P(n,n−1) for the zh−1 spectra had signal present only from the charge-dependent spectra Sn and Sn−1. Removed are the singly charged impurities from solvents and buffers as well as typical background noise. The final deconvoluted and deisotoped spectrum is calculated as the sum of all intensities of all data points of spectra P(zh,zh − 1) to P(2,1):

Sd(m) = P(2,1)(m) + P(3,2)(m) + ... + P(zh,zh − 1)(m)

Mass accuracy to assign two data points in different spectra to the same mass must be known before adding spectra. If md is the mass difference in the data points, then the mass accurayc has to be at least md × zh because data points in Szh are going to be very far apart.

The modified Isoconv worked well for small peptides so long as isotope clusters of ion species were baseline resolved and signal intensity between the isotopic peaks was zero. Deconvolution of higher charge state signals of mellitin and insulin [M + H]+ was 2845.76 u and 5804.75 u for initial charge states of zh = 5 and 7, resp. Thus additional parameters were added that included peak form analysis to deconvolute higher charge states with overlapping isotopic signals to suppress misinterpretations for higher charge states. A second parameter added was to

Yuan X, Desiderio DM (2002) J. Mass Spectrom. 37, 512-524.

Protein identification with Teflon as matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization sample support

ABSTRACT. Protein identification is a critical step in proteomics, and matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOFMS) plays an important role in that identification. Polytetrafluoroethylene (Teflon) was tested as a new MALDI sample support to improve protein identification. The tryptic peptides obtained from a model protein were bound to the surface of a modified MALDI sample holder via the hydrophobic interactions that occur between the Teflon surface and the peptide ion-pairs, and the affinity of a-cyano-4-hydroxycinnamic acid for the peptides. During that surface-binding step, the peptidemixture was also desalted and concentrated.Agreater number ofmatched peptides and a larger sequence coverage were obtained for the proteins when Teflon was used as the sample support compared with conventional sample preparation methods and a stainless-steel surface. In addition, the characterization of a small amount of protein was improved with Teflon. Nine silver-stained protein spots obtained from 2-D gel of a human cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) proteome were identified by this method. Among the nine protein spots, peptide 6 : c3c fragment and procollagen c-proteinase enhancer were not annotated in any published 2-D map of human CSF. A Teflon MALDI sample support is a low-cost, simple, and effective method that can be used to improve the quality of the MALDI mass spectrum of a complex tryptic peptide mixture, and to achieve a higher level of reliability and success in protein identification.

Nijtmans LGJ, Henderson NS, Holt IJ (2002) Methods 26, 327-334.

Blue Native Electrophoresis To Study Mitochondrial and Other Protein Complexes

ABSTRACT. The biogenesis and maintenance of mitochondria relies on a sizable number of proteins. Many of these proteins are organized into complexes, which are located in the mitochondrial inner membrane. Blue Native polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (BNPAGE) is a method for the isolation of intact protein complexes. Although it was initially used to study mitochondrial respiratory chain enzymes, it can also be applied to other protein complexes. The use of BN-PAGE has increased exponentially over the past few years and new applications have been developed. Here we review how to set up the basic system and outline modications that can be applied to address specic research questions. Increasing the upper mass limit of complexes that can be separated by BNPAGE can be achieved by using agarose instead of acrylamide. BN-PAGE can also be used to study assembly of mitochondrial protein complexes. Other applications include in-gel measurements of enzyme activity by histochemical staining and preparative native electrophoresis to isolate a protein complex. Finally, new ways of identifying protein spots in Blue Native gels using mass spectrometry are briefly discussed.

Oh-Ishi M, Maeda T (2002) J. Chromatog. B 771, 49-66.

Separation Techniques for High-Molecular-Mass Proteins

Abstract. Many high-molecular-mass (HMM) proteins (MW.100 kDa) are known to be involved in cytoskeleton, defence and immunity, transcription and translation in higher eukaryotic organisms. Even in the post-genomic era, purification of HMM protein is the first important step to analyze protein composition in a tissue or a cell (proteomics), to determine protein tertiary structure (structural biology), and to investigate protein function (functional genomics). To separate a HMM protein from a protein mixture, ions, chaotropes (urea and thiourea), detergents and protease inhibitors in extraction media and buffer solutions either for liquid chromatography or for gel electrophoresis should be carefully chosen, since HMM proteins tend to be aggregates under denatured condition and their long polypeptide chains are easily attacked by intrinsic proteases during separation procedure. Among many liquid chromatography techniques, affinity chromatography either with sequence-specific DNA for transcription factor, or with monoclonal antibody specific for myosin heavy chain has been used for preparative isolation of the respective HMM proteins. Though SDSPAGE could analyze the size and the quantity of megadalton proteins, the resolution of HMM proteins is relatively poor. A newly developed pulse SDSPAGE would be able to raise the resolution of HMM proteins compared with the conventional SDSPAGE. The 2-DE method is not particularly suitable in analyzing HMM proteins larger than 200 kDa. However, a 2-DE method that uses an agarose IEF gel in the first dimension (agarose 2-DE) has been shown to produce significant improvements in 2-DE separation of HMM proteins larger than 150 kDa and up to 500 kDa.

Zhou H, Ranish JA, Watts JD, Aebersold R (2002) Nat. Biotechnol. 19, 512-515.

Quantitative Proteome Analysis by Solid-Phase Isotope Tagging and Mass Spectrometery

A solid-phase isotope tagging technique is described. Beads covalently bonded to, in this order, a photocleavable linker, the isotope tag, and a protein thiol-reactive group are produced by attaching a o-nitrobenzyl-based photocleavable linker to aminopropyl-coated glass beads using solid-phase peptide synthesis (see Holmes and Jones, J. Org. Chem. 60: 2318-2319, 1995). 0.5 g of aminopropyl-coated controlled-pore glass beads with amin content of ~400 µmol/g (Sigma) are washed with anhydrous DMF. 600 µmol each of 1-hydroxybenzotriazole (HOBt, NovaBiochem), Fmoc-aminoethyl photolinker (NovaBiochem), and diisopropylcarbodiimide (DIC) were mixed 30 at room temperature, then added to beads for 90 min. Beads are washed sequentially with DMF and dichloromethane, then capped with 2 ml 40% acetic anhydride/60^% pyridine in dichloromethane for 30 min. Beads again washed with DMF and treated with 20% piperidine in DMF for 30 min, which removes Fmoc protection. The process is repeated to add Fmoc-Leu as the isotope tag (either the light or heavy form). The iodoacetyl group is attached to the beads using the method of Zhou et al. (Nat. Biotechnol. 19: 375-378, 2001): 3 equivalents of iodoacetic anhydride are added to 1 equivalent of amino-derivatized beads (Sigma G4643) with the presence of 3.3 equivalents of diisopropylethylamine in dimethylformamide (DMF). Beads are then washed successively in DMF, water, and methanol, dried under slight vacuum, and stored at room temperature in the dark. The heavy form of derivatized Leu is prepared using d7-Leu (Isotec) and Fmoc-N-hydroxysuccinimide (NovaBiochem) according the method of Lapatsanis et al (Synthesis 1983: 675-677, 1983) with the exception that the recrystallization step was omitted for purifying the product.

A 1 nmol Cys-containing laminin B peptide (CDPGYIGSR) and 500 pmol of phosphoangiotensin (DRVY*IHPF) were treated first with TCEP (5 mM in 100 µl 0.2 M Tris pH 8.0, 10 mM EDTA) for 30 min, then 5 mg beads (2 µmol binding capacity) were used in a 100 µl volume with constant agitation. 1 µl aliquots of a supernatant were analyzed both before and after addition of beads using µLC-MS. After 15 min 2 µl of 2-mercaptoethanol is added for 5 min, then beads washed with 2 M NaCl, methanol, and water. Beads are suspended in 100 µl of 0.2 M Tris pH 8, 10 mM EDTA, 2% β-mercaptoethanol. 500 pmol phosphoangiotensin is added as internal standard. A 100 watt Blak-Ray long-wave UV lamp filtered with a 1 cm deep 10% copper (II) sulfate solution is then used to illuminate the beads from 10 cm distance, using different times. 1 µl aliquots are analyzed on µLC-MS. Addition of β-mercaptoethanol prevents Met oxidation during photocleavage.

Note that the 360 nm light used in cleavage is chosen to minimize other photocatalyzable side reactions.

Shimizu A, Nakanishi T, Kishikawa M, Miyazaki A (2002) J. Chromatog. B 776, 15-30.

Detection and Identification of Protein Variants and Adducts in Blood and Tissues: An Application of Soft Ionization Mass Spectrometry to Clinical Diagnosis

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. The detection and identification of protein variants and abnormally increased modified proteins are important for clinical diagnosis.We applied soft ionization mass spectrometry (MS) to analyze proteins in blood and tissues from various patients. Over the past 8 years, we diagnosed 132 cases (55 kinds) of variant proteins including hemoglobin (Hb), transthyretin (TTR), and Cu/Zn-superoxide dismutase (SOD-1), using MS as the leading technology. Of these variants, eight were new, and nine were the first cases in Japan. Some abnormal Hb cause diseases, and most of them cause erroneous levels of glycated Hb, HbA1c, i.e., a popular index of diabetes. Most of the variant TTR causes amyloidotic polyneuropathy.Variant SOD-1 causes amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. We first showed that immunoprecipitation by a specific antiserum is a reliable and simple method to prepare protein from sera and tissues for analysis by matrix-assisted laser desorption time-of-flight MS, and liquid chromatographyelectrospray ionization MS (LCESI-MS). The use of this technology has become widespread. Using an immunoprecipitated target protein and LCESI-MS, we showed that the ratios of tetra-, di- and a-sialo-transferrin from two cases of congenital glycoprotein deficient syndrome were clearly distinguishable from those of control samples.We first reported a unique modified form of TTR, that is, S-sulfonated TTR, which increased markedly and specifically in three cases with molibdenum cofactor deficiency.We proposed that S-sulfonated TTR is a useful marker for screening this disease. ESI-MS was successfully used for the accurate determination of HbA1c, and we clarified the extent of discrepancies between the HbA1c value measured by conventional methods and the accurate values for samples containing various Hb variants determined by the MS method.

Krutchinsky AN, Chait BT (2002) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 13, 129-134.

On The Nature Of The Chemical Noise in MALDI Mass Spectra

Sensitivity in the mass spectrum is usually limited by background ions rather than inherent limits in the detection system. Previous work in MALDI/ESI-QqTOF and MALDI/ESI-ion trap show background ion peaks at every m/z value. Techniques to improve signal-to-noise include accumulation of longer-time spectra (or multiple spectra), but the improvement is only ∝ t0.5. Linked scan modes can also overcome these limitations but there is a low duty cycle because of the need to scan the spectrometer.

A Thermo Finnigan LCQ Classic commercial ion trap MS was installed with a new ion interface. The standard LCQ has a set of octapoles leading to ion trap that leads to the detector. The ion optics for the MALDI were fit with a quadrupole (0.635 cm dia × 20 cm long) between octapoles and skimmer. An aperture plate (~0.3 cm dia aperature) separates the quadrupole and octapole. The added quadrupole is a high pressure ion guide. A 500 kHz crystal oscillator controlled sine wave generator and power amplifier sets an RF voltage: amplitude on sine wave is +300-500 V. An accelerator is placed in the ion guide to drag ions toward the exit: these are four ~18 cm rods 0.32 cm dia inserted between quadrupole rod. These are closer to the axis of the ion guide at the entrance, and further from it at the exit. A constant +100 V in all four rods creates a small electrical field along the ion guide which improves transport. An atmosphere of 70 ± 10 mTorr is introduced by a small orifice, and a mechanical pump of 8 l/s drives the turbomolecular pump of the system pushing the pressure down to ~2 × 10−5.

The MALDI target plate surface is the polycarbonate surface of a CD. The CD is screwed to a metal plate and placed in the vacuum lock. A potential is applied by contact of the metal support plate with a spring electrode. The distance between the CD and ion guide entrace is ~1 mm. A special shaft-wheel assembly allows rotation of the CD to align the spot with guide entrance. The light of a 337 nm nitrogen laser (Laser Science, Inc.) with 10-20 Hz strobe is reflected towards a collimating lens (f = 15 cm) and then through sapphire window with angle of incidence ~60° on the CD. Light spot diameter is about 300-500 µm, with power density ranging from 2-5 × 107 W/cm2 and controlled by a variable attenuator (Newport Corp. Model 935-5).
