A video cam allows visualization of laser light and sample position.

Ion injection time (Maximum Inject Time) is 0.5 s, automatic gain control (AGC) is set on, maximum count of ions allowed to fill trap (Full MS Target) is 5 × 109. MS/MS spectra were obtained with these settings: m/z window (Isolation Width) was 3-4; activation energy (Normalized Collision Energy) was 25%, q of activation (Activation q) was 0.25, and activation time (Activation Time) was 0.3 s.

A mixture of 6 peptides; bradykinin 2-9 [PPGFSPFR], substance P [RPKPQQFFGLM], neurotensin [pyroELYENKPRRPYIL], amyloid β-protein 12-28 [VHHQKLVFFAEDVGSNK, CAS 107015-83-8], ACTH 1-24 [SYSMEHFRWGKPVGKKRRPVKVYP], oxidized bovine insulin B chain [FVNQHLC(ox)GSHLVEALYLVC(ox)GERGFFYTPKA] were made at 200 fmol/µl each win 35% MeOH + 5% acetic acid; dilutions were made just prior to analysis. Fresh saturated matrix solutions of 2,5-DHB, CHCA, and sinapinic acid (Sigma) were made up in solvent just before measurement. An equal volume of satd DHB and diluted peptide mix is prepared and 1 µl is spotted to CD target.

This system not only produces high quality spectra from low femtomole amounts of sample peptides; its principal feature is high speed analytical performance. A decent spectrum can be obtained after a 2 s acquisition, with 5 of 6 peptides showing sufficient signals above the noise. An MS/MS spectrum of the m/z 1673 peak (neurotensin) indicated that a 5 s acquisition gave sufficient S/N. Sample was diluted 1/10 (to 100 attomole spotting) permitted no discernible peaks even with 60 s acquisition. Background ions interfere with peptide ion signals. Their presence is largely the result of sample handling and preparation, but the resolution and type of ion detection of the MS is also a factor. Although no peak signals in the 60 s 0.1 fmol MS spectrum were seen, a 60 s MS/MS acquisition of the m/z 1673 peak produced fragments from the ion trap whose signals were sufficient. Certain characteristic fragmentations occur: N-terminal side of proline (b9, y7) and C-terminal side of Glu (y9). Starting from the parent ion are also a fragment series whose mass differences are 154 and 136 Da. DHB has a mass of 154.1 Da, while loss of water from DHB would be 136.1 Da. Similar losses were seen in MS/MS spectra of every m/z tested. These cluster ions have a composition of (DHB)nXC+ where X is an unknown species and C+ is a cation. The exact composition of the cluster species was not determined through MSn experiments because dissociation channels increase as a function of the order of MSn experiments. Other matrices were used but were inferior to DHB with respect to less intense signals, with lower shot-to-shot reproducibility, and higher noise level. This is probably due to the hotter nature of CHCA and sinapinic acid. Even so MS/MS spectra from these matrices showed characteristic mass losses indicating the clustering nature.

Broadband collisional activation of part of the spectrum was done at m/z 1673. Ions isolated in a window of ± 50 m/z units were activated. In unactivated controls the same chemical noise background is observed. A distribution outside the window forms whose center is shifted by ~150 m/z units, probably representing the loss of a single matrix molecule. If the activation energy is increased to the threshold for peptide ion fragmentation. This actually reveals the peptide more clearly at its parent mass, since the cluster is more effectively dispersed. Further increases do not increase relative intensity of the parent, since fragmentation ensues. In an MS2 stage the "normalized collision energy" of 20% is applied for 0.3 s which disperses/cleans the background ion cluster from the peptide, and in an MS3 stage, the energy is increased to 25% which results in peptide ion fragmentation, as shown in spectra. Degradation of the cluster is not complete, showing a stable component even at peptide fragmentation energies. About half of the noise caused by background is removed, resulting in a final ~3:1 signal-to-noise.

Papantonakis MR, Kim J, Hess WP, Haglund Jr RF (2002) J. Mass Spectrom. 37, 639-647.

What Do Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Mass Spectra Reveal About Ionization Mechanisms?

The MALDI spectra of peptides and oligosaccharides was studied using the widest range of wavelengths and pulse durations tested to now. MALDI is more properly described as matrix-assisted laser ablation ionization since materials are actually removed with laser pulses. In general once pulse durations exceed ~10 ps, energy is thermalized and ablation takes place in thermal equilibrium. The mass spectra for erythromycin, β-cyclodextrin, and angiotensin II are obtained in DHB generated from 266 nm with pulse lengths of 120 fs and 2 ns. Below m/z 300 in the spectrum the alkali metals sodium and potassium, matrix, and matrix fragment peaks dominate. [DHB + H]+, [DHB]+• radical, [DHB + Na]+, [DHB-H + Na]+• radical cations are these matrix peaks. Matrix fragment peaks involve losses of hydroxyls, water, and carboxyl groups from 2,5-DHB parent (MW=154). Peak m/z 273 corresponds to [2DHB-OH-H2]+. The region above m/z 300 is protonated analyte peaks particularly for erythromycing and angiotensin II. The β-cyclodextrin is dominated by sodium and potassium adducts, rather than just plain protonated analyte which is absent. Absence of protonated forms of oligosaccharides is not unusual in MALDI, for sodium and potassium adduction is typical.

For erythromycin, the matrix-to-analyte intensities do not change with variation in pulse durations

Lee H, Griffin TJ, Gygi SP, Rist B, Aebersold R (2002) Anal. Chem. 74, 4353-4360.

Developement of a Multiplexed Microcapillary Liquid Chromatography System for High-Throughput Proteome Analysis

ABSTRACT. Comprehensive proteome analysis requires the identification (and quantification) of the proteins in samples consisting of thousands of proteins spanning a range of abundance of several orders of magnitude. The currency of proteome analysis by mass spectrometry is the peptides generated by protein proteolysis. The high sample complexity of such samples requires a large separation capacity, which is commonly achieved by fractionation of the mixture followed by further serial separations of each fraction. The sample throughput of proteome analysis is therefore limited by the need to sequentially process large numbers of samples. We have developed a novel four-plexed microcapillary liquid chromatography system for automated, high-throughput separation of complex peptide samples. The system supports the concurrent separation of four different samples by directing identically split solvent-gradient flows into four microcapillary C18 columns. The simple design of the system achieves multiplexed separation without the need for extra solvent pumps. Peak resolution, reproducibility, and parallel separating capacity of the system were investigated using standard peptides. The applicability of the system to high-throughput protein expression profiling was demonstrated in qualitative and quantitative analyses of protein expression in S. cerevisiae grown on two different carbon sources using the isotope-coded affinity tag (ICAT) reagent and matrix-assisted desorption/ionization quadrupole time-of-flight mass spectrometry.

Lubman DM, Kachman MT, Wang H, Gong S, Yan F, Hamler RL, O'Neil KA, Zhu K, Buchanan NS, Barder TJ (2002) J. Chromatog. B 782, 183-196.

Two-Dimensional Liquid Separations—Mass Mapping of Proteins from Human Cancer Cell Lysates

REVIEW. The ability to identify key protein biomarkers involved in cancer-transforming processes may serve as diagnostic tool in early detection; molecular profiling of the tumor. Standard format 2D-PAGE reveals about 1000 proteins detected with Ag staining to 1-10 ng level (about 500-1000 copies per cell). Staining protocols also attempt to quantify differences in expression. Drawbacks of the method include spot position and intensity reproducibility; interlab comparisons are difficult. The DIG method attempts to compensate: two lysates are labeled with different dyes and then run on the same gel, and a differential color display is evaluated. Other problems include labor-intensive methods, Mr accurate to only 5-10%. Mass-scale automated analysis is much preferred.

pI-based separations are useful but in gels, the standard analysis effectively separates only in the pI 4-9 range, and only the lower pH range is separated while the higher end shows cathodic drift, resulting in band smearing. IPG strip use has much better performance and a greater loadability (in milligrams), but precipitation of proteins is still a problem; reproducibility is also a problem. Liquid-based IEF (with the Bio-Rad Rotofor) may be a better alternative: stability zones are created in 20 compartments created by monofilament polyester membranes. Preparative scale uses a 55 ml volume, and the mini-scale is 16 ml. Constant power is applied. The continuous rotation of the device and a 4-10° is thought to maintain solubility as the isoelectric point. A separation takes 3-5 h. Liquid are drained/suctioned from each compartment at the end. A problem with the Rotofor is that separatiosns are not as good as with IPG, although liquid-based seps are readily adaptable to HPLC separations.

Chromatofocusing is an ion exchange technique where proteins bind to an anion-exchanger and then eluted by a continuous fall in pH. pH 4-11 ranges can be achieved. Fractions from IEF or CF methods separating whole cell lysates of human cell lines will have 50-150 proteins, particularly numerous in the pH 5.5-7.0 midrange of the method, less on the basic and acidic ends. To separate such large numbers a nonporous C18 column (1.5 µm) is necessary. Pore-based particle columns generate smeared peaks and loss of resolution, poor recovery. Particularly low MW proteins (<40 kDa) are recoverable up to 90%, but separations of over 200 kDa are good. Larger particle columns provide good separation of over 400 kDa proteins.

Use of SDS is incompatible with RP-HPLC and ESI-MS. Triton X-100 and Tween-20 are not compatible with either IEF or RP-HPLC (also may make polymers interfering with MS). The nonionic n-octyl-β-D-galactopyranoside or n-octyl-β-glucopyranoside detergents are particularly good at solubilizing large and hydrophobic membrane proteins for IEF (Rotofor) and RP-HPLC. Other possibilities include sulfobetaine series, although they interfere with protein quantitation. Denaturing agents and chaotropes prevent protein precipitation (mixes of urea/thiourea coupled with DTT or tris(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine (TCEP)

Hansen RK, Broadhurst RW, Skelton PC, Arkin IT (2002) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 13, 1376-1387.

Hydrogen/Deuterium Exchange of Hydrophobic Peptides in Model Membranes by Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. We demonstrate here that the hydrogen/deuterium solvent exchange (HDX) properties of the transmembrane fragment of the M2 protein of Influenza A (M2-TM) incorporated into lipid vesicles or detergent micelles can be studied with straightforward electrospray (ESI) and nanospray mass spectrometry (MS) configurations provided that key factors, including sample preparation techniques, are optimized. Small unilamellar vesicle preparations were obtained by solubilizing dimyristoyl phosphatidylcholine (DMPC) and the M2-TM peptide in aqueous solution with n--D-glycopyranoside, followed by dialysis to remove the detergent. Electron microscopy experiments revealed that subsequent concentration by centrifugation introduced large multilamellar aggregates that were not compatible with ESI-MS. By contrast, a lyophilization-based concentration procedure, followed by thawing above the liquid crystal transition temperature of the lipid component, maintained the liposome size profile and yielded excellent ion fluxes in both ESI-MS and nano-ESI-MS. Using these methods the global HDX profile of M2-TM in aqueous DMPC vesicles was compared with that in methanol, demonstrating that several amide sites were protected from exchange by the lipid membrane. We also show that hydrophobic peptides can be detected by ESI-MS in the presence of a large molar excess of the detergent Triton X-100. The rate of HDX of M2-TM in Triton X-100 micelles was faster than that in DMPC vesicles but slower than when the peptide had been denatured in methanol. These results indicate that the accessibility of backbone amide sites to the solvent can be profoundly affected by membrane protein structure and dynamics, as well as the properties of model bilayer systems.

Reid GE, McLuckey SC (2002) J. Mass Spectrom. 37, 663-675.

‘Top Down’ Protein Characterization Via Tandem Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. Technological and scientific advances over the past decade have enabled protein identification and characterization strategies to be developed that are based on subjecting intact protein ions and large protein fragments directly to tandemmass spectrometry. These approaches are referred to collectively as top down to contrast them with bottom up approaches whereby protein identification is based on mass spectrometric analysis of peptides derived from proteolytic digestion, usually with trypsin. A key step in enabling top down approaches has been the ability to assign tandem mass spectrometer product ion identities, which can be done either via high resolving power or through product ion charge state manipulation. The ability to determine product ion charge states has permitted studies of the reactions, including dissociation, ionmolecule reactions, ionelectron reactions and ionion reactions of high-mass, multiply charged protein ions. Electrospray ionization combined with high magnetic field strength Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance has proven to be particularly powerful for detailed protein characterization owing to its high mass resolution and mass accuracy and its ability to effect electron capture-induced dissociation. Other types of tandem mass spectrometers are also beginning to find increasing use in top down protein identification/characterization studies. Charge state manipulation via ionion reactions in electrodynamic ion traps, for example, enables top down strategies to be considered using instruments with relatively modest mass resolution capabilities. Precursor ion charge statemanipulation techniques have also recently been demonstrated to be capable of concentrating and charge-state purifying proteins in the gas phase. Advances in technologies applied to the structural analysis of whole protein ions and in understanding their reactions, such as those described here, are providing new options for the study of complex protein mixtures.

FD

Bowie JH, Brinksworth CS, Dua S (2002) Mass Spec. Rev. 21, 87-107.

Collision-Induced Fragmentations of The [M-H]− Parent Anions of Underivatized Peptides: An Aid to Structure Determination and Some Unusual Negative Ion Cleavages

REVIEW. Positive mode MS for the sequencing of peptides and proteins has been of great utility for this technique (Biemann & Martin). Negative mode MS for proteins and peptides has typically involved mass determinations of species with rare reports of fragmentation being done in this mode. A survey of fragmentation of deprotonated amino acids and peptides indicates use of FAB-MS using a glycerol matrix. In some reports peptide fragmentation produced breaks along the peptide backbone allowing generation of sequence information comparable to positive ion mode analysis. Negative ion mode can also produce more information than positive mode since amino acid side chains show a characteristic fragmentation pattern more consistent than positive mode. The tendency of Ser to lose CH2O and Thr to lose MeCHO even dominate peptide bond fragmentation.

A complex nomenclature is used to describe peptide cleavages along the backbone. For MH+ ions, the b and y + 2 are the most interesting. For negative ion spectra of deprotonated peptides, the α and β cleavages provide the corresponding equivalent. However certain processes occur with negative ion fragmentation that do not occur with positive ions, and mechanisms are completely different, so a distinct terminology is called for. The following scheme is considered:

  1. R1NH-−C(R2)CONHCH(R3)CO2
                ↓
    [R1NHC(R2)=C=O    −NHCH(R3)CO2H]    →α    −NHCH(R3)CO2H  +  R1NHC(R2)=C=O
                ↓ β
    [R1NHC(R2)=C=O • H]−  +  NH2CH(R3)CO2H
  2. −NHCH(R3)CO2H  →  NH2CH(R3)CO2−

The α and β fragmentation reaction mechanism is shown to proceed by enolate anions. Reaction 2 is just a rearrangement of charge/proton from the α product. Enolate anions form from deprotonation or by protein transfer to -COO− or to CONH−. These anions might also form with successive proton transfer when the peptide chain has flexible or random conformations.

Consider the dipeptide anion α-methylglycylglycinate [1 below]:

  1. CH3NHCH2C(=O)NHCH2CO2− (0)
  2. CH3NH-−CHC(=O)NHCH2CO2H (22)
  3. [CH3NHCH=C=O    −NHCH2CO2H] (75)
  4. CH3NHCH=C=O   +   −NHCH2CO2H (95)
  5. β:  CH3NHC=C=O−  +  NH2CH2CO2H (68)
  6. α: CH3NHCH=C=O   +   NH2CH2CO2− (32)

The geometries are determined at the AM1 theoretical level and relative energies in kcal/mol are calculated using HF/6-31G(d)//AM1 theoretical level (shown in parentheses at the end of the molecular forms). In the reaction, the carboxylate anion becomes an enolate anion via proton transfer. This moves to a more activated transition state molecule [3] which is fragmented and produces even more highly energetic products. It is true that the fragmentation might occur with charge in a position remote from the fragmentation site (a charge-remote process), but no model can be found to indicate an energetically process that is charge-remote. The supposition of enolate ion formation at the fragmentation is plausible given the energies involved. The final products can track in two paths. The β fragmentation means that the ion (β ion) is an enonide less energetically stable than formation of a carboxylate on the C-terminal fragmentation product. Experiments confirm that the α fragmentation is more likely (being energetically favorable), with more numerous α-ions and these ions being more intense.

The peptide pEPQVFV-nh2 proved the fragmentation pattern. The parent (M-H)− has m/z 697 peak. In the range m/z 54-700, the following spectrum is described:

m/z Rel. Int. Fragmentation N-terminal Product
697 40% none (parent ion)
586 10% α pE
489 20% α P
472 100% γQ3
451 25% δF5
434 5% β [FV-nh2]
361 15% α Q
262 5% α V
245 5% γF5
207 10% β (QV)

The peptide GLFAVIKKVAKVIKKL-nh2 is similarly analyzed.

The positive ion spectrum for the pyroglutamate peptide sequences the entire peptide from the b and y + 2 cleavages taken together. The negative ion spectrum identifies all residues, but does not indicate the orientation of the final two (FV-nh2). Taken together, both the negative and positive ion spectra sequence the longer peptide. The α fragmentation information provides all but the identity of the final two residues. No β ions (β fragmentation) can be observed however. From the positive ion spectrum, b fragmentation provides sequence for all but the first two residues, and there is no y + 2 peak information.

Other backbone cleavages occur in the longer peptide. The losses involve Leu (not Leu-nh2), Leu-Lys, Leu-Lys-Lys, etc. and they occur irrespective of the nature of the C-terminal group as an anion (CO2− or CONH−). This involves amide bond cleavage with migration of NH from the C-terminal CONH− group. A cyclic intermediate (or transition) is envisioned. A charge-initiated process indicates that nucleophilic addition occurs to the carbonyl group of any amide bond in the backbone. Fragmentation occurs on the C-terminal amino acid and the charge is left on the remaining larger peptide in a process that is a type of β process, called β′ (beta prime). This type of cleavage occurs in peptides lacking Ser, Thr, Asp, Asn, Glu, or Gln (functions that effect facile side chain fragmentation) and also those peptides show α-cleavage but minor or no β-backbone cleavage.

γ and δ cleavages with Asp and Asn (also Phe, Tyr, His, Trp). The most intense peaks in a spectrum (above the parent intensity) are the result of the presence of Asp and Asn residues. Side chain fragmentation occurs in these residues, with loss of H2O in the case of Asp and NH3 in the case of Asn. It is proposed that for Asp the mechanism starts with an enolate anion: —−CH-CO2H → [(—CH=C=O) HO−] → —C≡C-O− + H2O or perhaps cyclization between side chain and adjacent amide with release of water. Cleavage always occurs between the α-amino nitrogen and α-carbon of Asp (or Asn, Glu, or Gln, etc.): the γ fragmentation leaves the anion on the Asp side chain, whereas the δ fragmentation leaves it on the amino nitrogen (yielding an amide δ-ion). This mechanism involves a side chain with an enolate elimination (water loss) product which can also occur with amino acids such as Phe, Tyr, His, and Trp. Indeed this occurs with these amino acids when peptides are ≤ four residues. It also occurs with Phe residues in larger peptides. Molecular modeling with 6-31G(d)/AM1 was done to characterize the process energetically. The side chain carboxylate ion involving cyclization to form a four-membered ring lactone would rule out the γ cleavage and so is dismissed as a mechanism requiring too much activation. Rather enolate anion formation is considered more favorable (barrier of 69.4 kcal/mole compared to lactone ring barrier of 77.1 kcal/mole). Charge delocalization activates the amino-α-carbon bond with subsequent cleavage with elimination. The γ fragmentation is very much energetically favored. The γ ion likely cyclizes by nucleophilic substitution with the n + 1 amino and the side chain Asp carboxyl to form a succinimide and release of water and the anion on the α-carbon of the n + 1 amino acid (enolate anion). If the residue is Asn, the nucleophilic substitution proposes release of NH3 instead.

With the extra methylene carbon on Glu and Gln, the mechanism of γ and δ cleavage is different than for Asp and Asn. Molecular modeling proposes two mechanisms and the relative energetic favorability. Again, an enolate anion is proposed in which the side chain CO2− (for Glu) or CONH− (for Gln) draws a slightly acidic proton from the α-carbon, and in which the O or N atom (Glu or Gln) bonds to form a 5-membered ring (lactone or imide), followed by fragmentation with charge transfer to either the enolate carbon on the side chain or to the nitrogen on the leaving amide. An alternative mechanism (less favorable energetically) is formation of the enolate on the side chain making it the nucleophile and straining to form a three-membered ring in a very endothermic γ or δ fragmentation product.

Presence of Ser and Thr produce profound side chain-induced cleavages with a loss of CH2O from Ser and MeCHO from Thr. These do not identify the position of these residues however. Consider the peptide GLFAVIKKVASVIKGL-nh2. The base peak in the spectrum is m/z 1609 and not the parent (M-H)− at 1639. Only α ions are present and backbone fragmentation occurs from the 1609 peak. There are no β ions, but β′ ions can be observed from m/z 1609. A γ cleavage of Phe is seen with m/z 1422.

With the peptide GLLEGLLGTLGL-nh2, the parent ion at m/z 1152 is nearly the most intense. The m/z 1108 representing loss of CH3CHO is present but at only 15-20% intensity. The spectrum shows both α- and β-cleavages. The γ-cleavage of E however comes from the (M-H MeCHO)− ion and not the parent.

A proposed mechanism for Ser-mediated cleavage involves a charge-remote process in the molecular model. The side chain forms a methoxy anion (methoxide) which delocalizes on the methylene and alpha-carbon. Formaldehyde is released to form the enolate on the backbone and charge transfer occurs to the C-side amide, with fragmentation between the αnitrogen and carbon on the Ser + 1 amino acid, and charge retained on the Ser (now Gly) amide nitrogen. Explaining the backbone cleavage induced by side chain activation is more interesting when account is taken that they are more likely to occur as at the peptide is larger; indeed fragmentations did not occur for peptides fewer than 16 residues. If losses of CHOH and MeCHO are so easily obtained from Ser and Thr, then how can backbone cleavage compete energetically? Perhaps the more likely mechanism is that backbone cleavage actually facilitates alkoxide removal from Ser and Thr, and that alkoxide elimination does not occur independent of it. The mechanism proposes that a nucleophile is generated on the backbone, and in a charge-remote process, generates the alkoxide largely through hydrogen bonding to it with concomitant charge delocalization. This nucleophile could be a C-terminal anion (CO2− or CONH−).

Other cleavages are structure-dependent cleavages that depend on a particular 3-D conformation. Caerin-1.1 (GLLSVLGSVAKHVLPHVVPVIAEHL-nh2) is an example. Much of the fragmentation in the spectrum follows standard principles but two peaks in the spectrum at m/z 1957 is formed from a daughter product representing parent less two CHOH groups and one at m/z 2481, representing parent less Val. Curiously the relative intensity of these peaks falls when the internal energy of the decomposing parent is increased. The m/z 1957 ion is GLLGVLGGVAKHVLPHVVPV-nh−: it forms by cleavage of the N-C bond on Ile in the [M-H — 2CHOH]−. Using many synthetic variations of caerin 1.1, one can discern a unique fragmentation process. The evidence is as follows:

  • Changing the last two residues has no effect on the generation of m/z 1957.
  • Changing residue 23 Glu results in the absence of 1957, even if the substitution is to Asp.
  • Replacing His at 24 with Glu results in the absence of the m/z 2070 peak, which is GLLGVLGGVAKHVPHVVPVI-nh−

The only mechanism that might explain what happens is a particular conformation that juxtaposes Ile21 and Glu23. 3-D structure analysis of the peptide using 2-D NMR indicates that it is an amphipathic peptide with well defined hydrophobic and hydrophilic zones with two helical regions and a hinge near the center. I21 and E23 are in the same region of a helix and the E23 side chain would be positioned away from I21. E23 is flexible enough to bend toward I21, but a substituted D23 would not (explaining one result). So why does this not occur with E24 and A22? Because these would be too far apart. An increase in the internal energy of the molecule would unravel the helix and affect the special proximity of the carboxylate group on the hydrogen of the α-carbon on I21. As for the second unusual peak, the loss of the Val from the parent ion, the identification of the Val that is lost will be necessary to arrive at some sort of explanation. Again this may involve an understanding of the structure.

Witzmann FA, Li J (2000) Am. J. Physiol. Gastrointent. Liver Physiol. 282, G735-G741.

Phosphopeptide Sequencing by In-Source Decay Spectrum in Delayed Extraction Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT.

Steen H, Jensen ON (2002) Mass Spec. Rev. 21, 163-182.

Analysis of Protein-Nucleic Acid Interactions by Photochemical Cross-linking and Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. Photochemical cross-linking is a commonly used method for studying the molecular details of protein-nucleic acid interactions. Photochemical cross-linking aids in defining nucleic acid binding sites of proteins via subsequent identification of crosslinked protein domains and amino acid residues. Mass spectrometry (MS) has emerged as a sensitive and efficient analytical technique for determination of such cross-linking sites in proteins. The present review of the field describes a number of MS-based approaches for the characterization of cross-linked protein-nucleic acid complexes and for sequencing of peptidenucleic acid heteroconjugates. The combination of photochemical cross-linking and MS provides a fast screening method to gain insights into the overall structure and formation of proteinoligonucleotide complexes. Because the analytical methods are continuously refined and protein structural data are rapidly accumulating in databases, we envision that many proteinnucleic acid assemblies will be initially characterized by combinations of cross-linking methods, MS, and computational molecular modeling.

Gorman JJ, Wallis TP, Pitt JJ (2002) Mass Spec. Rev. 21, 183-216.

Protein Disulfide Bond Determination by Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. The determination of disulfide bonds is an important aspect of gaining a comprehensive understanding of the chemical structure of a protein. The basic strategy for obtaining this information involves the identification of disulfide-linked peptides in digests of proteins and the characterization of their half-cystinyl peptide constituents. Tools for disulfide bond analysis have improved dramatically in the past two decades, especially in terms of speed and sensitivity. This improvement is largely due to the development of matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI) and electrospray ionization (ESI), and complementary analyzers with high resolution and accuracy. The process of pairing half-cystinyl peptides is now generally achieved by comparing masses of non-reduced and reduced aliquots of a digest of a protein that was proteolyzed with intact disulfide bonds. Pepsin has favorable properties for generating disulfidelinked peptides, including its acidic pH optimum, at which disulfide bond rearrangement is precluded and protein conformations are likely to be unfolded and accessible to cleavage, and broad substrate specificity. These properties potentiate cleavage between all half-cystine residues of the substrate protein. However, pepsin produces complex digests that contain overlapping peptides due to ragged cleavage. This complexity can produce very complex spectra and/or hamper the ionization of some constituent peptides. It may also be more difficult to compute which half-cystinyl sequences of the protein of interest are disulfide-linked in non-reduced peptic digests. This ambiguity is offset to some extent by sequence tags that may arise from ragged cleavages and aid sequence assignments. Problems associated with pepsin cleavage can be minimized by digestion in solvents that contain 50% H218O. Resultant disulfide-linked peptides have distinct isotope profiles (combinations of isotope ratios and average mass increases) compared to the same peptides with only 16O in their terminal carboxylates. Thus, it is possible to identify disulfide-linked peptides in digests and chromatographic fractions, using these mass-specific markers, and to rationalize mass changes upon reduction in terms of half-cystinyl sequences of the protein of interest. Some peptides may require additional cleavages due to their multiple disulfide bond contents and/or tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) to determine linkages. Interpretation of the MS/MS spectra of peptides with multiple disulfides in supplementary digests is also facilitated by the presence of 18O in their terminal carboxylates.

Shimura K, Kamiya K, Matsumoto H, Kasai K (2002) Anal. Chem. 74, 1046-1053.

Fluorescence-Labeled Peptide pI Markers for Capillary Isoelectric Focusing

Isoelectric point markers should quickly focus to form sharp bands in a gradient. The focusing of small ampholytes is dependent on −dz/d(pH) at the pI value, that is [−dz/d(pH)]pH=pI, where z = net charge of the ampholyte. Assuming no interdependent effects on ionizable groups in molecule on each other, then:

z = ∑i (ni / (1 + Ki/[H+])) − ∑j (nj / (1 + [H+]/Kj))

where Ki is acid dissociation constant for conjugate acid of basic group and Kj is that constant for the acidic groups, ni and nj are number of ionizable groups in a peptide. The value z = 0 should obtain for pH = pI. pKa values assumed are C-term=3.6, Asp=3.95, Glu=4.45, His=6.45

Cooper JW, Gao J, Lee CS (2002) Anal. Chem. 74, 1182-1186.

Gel Protein Capillary Extraction Apparatus. Electronic Protein Transfer

A gel protein capillary extraction apparatus is described to remove proteins from polyacrylamide. Fused silica capillaries with 50 µm i.d./192 µm o.d. are internally coated with polyacrylamide and filled with a 20 mM Tris pH 6.8 buffer. Modified Teflon sleeve permits extraction end of capillary to contact the gel. 200 µl buffer is spotted to create electrical contact between capillary and gel, and the gel is connected to ground via Pt wire. A CZE 1000R HV power supply (Spellman HighVoltage Electronics) is used to supply positive 7.4 kV at the outlet through a Pt electrode, establishing a 200 V/cm field in the 37 cm capillary. After the extraction, the capillary is transferred to buffer which has the common ground. A Linear UVIS 200 detector is on the outlet end 7 cm from end of capillary to monitor 214 nm.

Cytochrome c was run on 4-20% SDS-PAGE gels from Bio-Rad at 200 V constant. Protein was stained in 0.1% CBB-R in 30% MeOH. Loads from 2.5-50 µg were done. Cytochrome c from gel was then extracted by capillary. In addition a CZE capillary was set up to analyze SDS-treated cytochrome c samples at 4 mg/ml loading. Migration to UV detector for gel-extracted material is about 8.1 min, slightly shorter than for CZE. For a 2 min extraction, the base width is 0.5 min, corresponding to solution plug of ~30 nl in the capillary. The current fell from 9 to 6 µA during extraction. After the 2 min, the extraction end of the capillary was moved to a reservoir with buffer, and the current was restored to 9 µA. A calibration curve of SDS-cyt c complexes indicated that a protein load of 25 µg could be concentrated to 3.5 µg/µl in a 30 nl solution plug.

Spots of cytochrome c were done at low protein loading and stained with modified Coomassie blue, the limit being 50-100 ng/spot and in agreement with a 100-200 ng/spot reported by others. At 2.5 µg load, the migration time and peak profile of the stained SDS-cyt c were identical to the non-stained. The dye permits visualization with little effect on mobility or UV absorbance.

Shevchenko A, Schaft D, Roguev A, Pijnappel WWMP, Stewart AF, Shevchenko A (2002) Molec. Cellular Proteomics 1, 204-212.

Deciphering Protein Complexes and Protein Interaction Networks by Tandem Affinity Purification and Mass Spectrometry

Homologous recombination in S. cerevisiae is the method to integrate fragments into the genome, permitting endogenous in-frame fusions between ORF of choice and PCR-generated epitope tag cassettes. There are some limitations. It is easier to fuse tag into the C-terminus rather than N terminus. The selectable marker gene can be placed beyond the 3′ part of the coding region, but for N-terminal fusions the marker is between the promoter and targeted ORF, and then has to be removed. Generally N-terminal tagging was done only when C-terminal tagging presented a problem.

TAP tagging has several important advantages. The tag has two high affinity modules, a calmodulin (CaM)-binding peptide and double protein A epitope, both separated by a TEV protease cleavage site. Protein complex analysis is done by loading extract supernatants on to a IgG Sepahrose column, which is then washed with one buffer, then equilibrated in a TEV protease cleavage buffer. A recombinant TEV protease solution is then added to the column, and this washed into a CaM-Sepharose column using calcium-containing buffer. This purification results in less background than standard immunoprecipitation.

53 genes were tagged with the TAP epitope, with 52 tagged successfully (98%), as shown by Western blotting. One case showed successful homologous recombination although this was not shown by Western; caused by either incorrect prediction of ORF or absence of protein expression. Tagging did not cause any lethality or severely abnormal phenotype. For the Set1 fusion, tagging did not affect complex formation, but did interfere with enzymatic activity; when tagged on the N-terminal, normal enzymatic activity was restored. Bait proteins were observed in 4 of 52 cases by Western blotting. Insufficient amounts of iPed made them undetectable by mass spectrometry. The codon bias index of these four proteins is <0.1 indicating they are low abundance. The tagged proteins ranged from 9-175 kDa and pI 4.5-10.0 with CBI from −0.064 to 0.16.

Protein complex analysis by MS is complicated by the fact that gel analysis means extracted peptides can vary. Immunoaffinity isolation also tends to recover non-specifically bound proteins and are tough to scale up. Use of large volumes of culture media cause loss of binding specificity and increased background. A ~20 kDa Coomassie-stained band isolated from tagged Set1 immunoprecipitate was found to contain 25 peptides on MALDI MS spectrum of the digest, with the search find the S24 protein, a 15 kDa subunit of the 40S ribosome. 8 peptides were matched with 100 ppm accuracy and > 50% coverage, but the most intense peaks were not matched. Analyzed by nanoES MS/MS another 6 ribosomal proteins were found from sequenced peptides which had low confidence from MALDI: none of these identified S24 protein however. A +2 ion with m/z 382.0 matched a 15 kDa YBR258c with low confidence (because sequence was short and degenerate). Large multiply charged peptides undergo partial fragmentation to produce single and double-charged y-ions, thus making it difficult to do searches based on tryptic digestion. Re-checking the MALDI MS data showed that four peptides of YBR258c had mass matches. Hence MALDI and ESI MS alone can leave some proteins unidentified, but together produce greater confidence. Tagging of YBR258c confirmed it to be a subunit of the protein complex.

Immunoprecipitates were run on SDS-PAGE with controls. All bands not present in controls were analyzed by MS, as well as analyzing all bands.

Mitaku S, Hirokawa T, Tsuji T (2002) Bioinformatics 18, 608-616.

Amphiphilicity Index of Polar Amino Acids As An Aid In The Characterization of Amino Acid Preference at Membrane-Water Interfaces

ABSTRACT. MOTIVATION: An amphiphilicity index of amino acid residues was developed for improving the method of transmembrane helix prediction. RESULTS: The transfer energy of a hydrocarbon stem group beyond the gamma-carbon was calculated from the accessible surface area, and used to index the amphiphilicity of the residue. Non-zero amphiphilicity index values were obtained for lysine, arginine, histidine, glutamic acid, glutamine, tyrosine and tryptophan. Those residues were found to be abundant in the end regions of transmembrane helices, indicating their preference for the membrane-water interface. The moving average of the amphiphilicity index actually showed significant peaks in the end regions of most transmembrane helices. A dispersion diagram of average amphiphilicity index versus average hydrophobicity index was devised to facilitate discrimination of transmembrane helices. AVAILABILITY: The amphiphilicity index has been incorporated into a system, SOSUI, for the discrimination of membrane proteins and the prediction of tranmembrane helical regions (http://sosui.proteome.bio.tuat.ac.jp/sosuiframe0.html).

Adam GC, Sorensen EJ, Cravatt BF (2002) Molec. Cell. Proteomics 1, 781-790.

Chemical Strategies for Functional Proteomics

REVIEW. Strategies in proteomics can be divided into two areas of complementary objectives: (1) the global characterization of protein expression, (2) global characterization of protein function. With respect to expression, 2DE and MS are used for separation, detection, and identification. Low abundance and membrane-associated proteins are not well characterized by 2DE approaches though.

Global, high throughput methods are being used to look at function. Large scale yeast two-hybrid screens show protein-protein interactions, and the development of protein chip microarrays look at recombinantly expressed proteins. Nonetheless, even these methods do not look at proteins in their native environment.

Additional methods include chemical tools to look at function and interaction. Changes in protein abundance are currently examined by staining which are cost-effective but Coomassie and silver staining response is nonlinear or insensitive or has a limited dynamic range. SYPRO Ruby offers new possibilities but there is still problems with resolution of membrane-associated and low abundance proteins.

ICAT. Isotope-coded affinity tags (ICATs) are chemical probes of proteins that aid in measuring abundance. Light- and heavy-isotope labeled iodoacetamide are used to tag two different proteomes. The tagged material is then combined, digested with protease (trypsin), and then passed through an avidin affinity column to trap tagged peptides only (the label contains a biotin). These are run on LC-MS and the ratio of signal intensities shows the relative level of expression.

Royle L, Mattu TS, Hart E, Langridge JI, Merry AH, Murphy N, Harvey DJ, Dwek RA, Rudd PM (2002) Anal. Biochem. 304, 70-90.

An Analytical and Structural Database Provides a Strategy for Sequencing O-Glycans from Microgram Quantities of Glycoproteins

O-glycans are released by hydrazinolysis using strict anhydrous conditions (GC shows water content < 0.8%) since water presence causes β-elimination (peeling). Peeling results in elimination of terminal (core) GalNAc from some susceptible oligosaccharides, and 2-aminobenzamide can be labeled on teh exposed galactose reducing terminal.

Forde CE, McCutchen-Maloney SL (2002) Mass Spec. Rev. 21, 419-439.

Characterization of Transcription Factors by Mass Spectrometry and the Role of SELDI-MS

ABSTRACT. Over the last decade, much progress has been made in the field of biological mass spectrometry, with numerous advances in technology, resolution, and affinity capture. The field of genomics has also been transformed by the sequencing and characterization of entire genomes. Some of the next challenges lie in understanding the relationship between the genome and the proteome, the protein complement of the genome, and in characterizing the regulatory processes involved in progressing from gene to functional protein. In this new age of proteomics, development of mass spectrometry methods to characterize transcription factors promises to add greatly to our understanding of regulatory networks that govern expression. However, at this time, regulatory networks of transcription factors are mostly uncharted territory. In this review, we summarize the latest advances in characterization of transcription factors by mass spectrometry including affinity capture, identification of complexes of DNA-binding proteins, structural characterization, determination of proteinDNA and proteinprotein interactions, assessment of modification sites and metal binding, studies of functional activity, and the latest chip technologies that use SELDI-MS that allow the rapid capture and identification of transcription factors.

Hancock WS, Wu S-L, Shieh P (2002) Proteomics 2, 352-359.

The Challenges of Developing A Sound Proteomics Strategy

REVIEW. Many aspects of proteomic studies are difficult than genomic analysis. For example sample preparation is more variable and typically difficult: proteins have much more complicated chemistry and a representative sample can be hard to come by. A typical protocol is a mixture of human plasma protein (20 µg/µl). Human growth hormone is present at 0.6 ng/µl and is reductively alkylated (DTT/iodoacetate). A 1 ml sample is run on Vydac C-4 column (2.1 × 150 mm) with TFA/acetonitrile and elutes in 2 ml, is dried down and then digested with trypsin (1:50 w/w in 1 ml total in 0.1 M ammonium bicarb for 12 h at RT, a 2nd aliq. added for another 12 h). A 1:100 splitter reduces flow from 150 µl/min to 1.5 µl/min. A 2% MeCN with 0.1% formic acid flow is done (3 min) then ramped to 60% MeCN in either 180 or 590 min, then ramped to 80% MeCN for 20 min. 5 µl is loaded into 10 µl loop on to LCQ Deca-XP Microtech C-18 capillary column (150 µm × 10 cm) connected orthogonally to ion source with sheath flow at 3 units and temp at 140°, capillary voltage 2800 V and collision energies being 35% of MS/MS mode setting. the integration of the two-dimensional (2-D) gel platform with mass spectrometry measurements. The use of both matrix-assisted laser/desorption ionization (on off-line coupling) and electrospray (on-line) ionization are complementary. While the use of onedimensional and 2-D gels are essential to many aspects of proteomics research (sample preparation, preliminary fractionation and quantitation, storage of protein components), the emergence of shotgun sequencing based on high performance liquid chromatography and tandem mass spectrometry offers a powerful new approach. The latter has particular utility in the characterization of low level samples and complex post-translational modifications. The development of capillary columns, such as 75 to 150 micron, that can be packed in a reproducible manner has been a key step in the development of high sensitivity liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry analysis.

Jonsson A, Hjelmqvist L, Jörnvall H, O'Malley R, Swainston N, Young P, Millar A, Uria D, Langridge J (2002) Presented at 5th Siena Meeting, Italy 2-5 September 2002

Automated LC-MS/MS Data Analysis of A Novel Alcohol Dehydrogenase Form Isolated from Pigeon Liver

POSTER. ESI LC-MS/MS at nanoscale level is important in the high throughput identification of proteins in a proteome whose complex mixture is full of tryptic peptides. Some peptides remain orphaned: that is, their masses and (partial) sequences were not matched to database proteins. Proteomes of many species are not well-represented in databases, and a single amino acid substitution (quite common with differences at the genera or class level) leaves the peptide orphaned. The number of spectra that pile up for manual handling becomes enormous. The use of an automated approach to MS/MS spectrum processing can be done using a tiered series of algorithms. Unannotate MS/MS spectra emerging from the initial database search are passed to a modification search workflow; this is set to consider amino acid substitutions and other modifications of proteins already identified by 1st pass matched peptides. Simultaneously a sequence analysis routine can be applied to all MS/MS spectra. Assembly of the overlaps of peptide sequences is then done.

The setup includes a CapLC HPLC system, a 320 µm × 5 mm PepMap C18 trap and a 75 µm × 100 mm analytical C18 column. Solvent A is 5% MeCN + 0.1% formic acid and solvent B is 95% MeCN + 0.1% formic acid and the program starts sample loading on to the trap at 30 µl/min followed by running at a 200 nl/min flow at 0% B, then applying a 40 min gradient to 60% B. 1 second MS scans on the QToF Ultima were obtained with DDA-switching to MS/MS, 3 channels of 5 seconds each. Spectra not representing peptides sufficiently are discarded by the query interface (ProteinLynx). MS/MS spectra passing filter are transposed to single charge state and centroided by MaxEnt 3. Data are represented in XML format and searched against SWISS-PROT. A post-search filter is applied to hits in which partial sequences from spectra are compared to database sequences, and any mismatch disqualifies the hit. Spectra disqualified are then run through a modifications search which includes amino acid substitutions and non-specific cleavage. In ProteinLynx, the Databank Search Query has the following parameters set aside different from defaults: peptide tolerance: 50 ppm; fragment tolerance: 0.5 Da; fixed modifications: carbamidomethyl C. The AutoMod Query is set for the same peptide and fragment tolerances; modifications and substitutions are set to be considered with maximum modifications or substitutions per peptide set at 2 and subsitution likelihood set at −4. A filter is also applied.

An alcohol dehydrogase was purified from pigeon liver proteome, tryptically digested and applied to system. 123 MS/MS spectra were obtained on peptides. ADH from Japanese quail was matched on only 1 peptide with no missed cleavages or modifications set (2% coverage, score 67.5, submitted m/z 450.29, charge state 2, mass 898.549, sequence IIAIDINK). When resubmitted with Cys modification considered and 1 missed cleavage, 6 forms of ADH from different species were offered. One 2+ peptide at m/z 465.2 identified to try substitutions (here at position 8 in D to E) was found. Double substitutions also yielded results for two 2+ peptides, m/z 538.8 and 592.3 which included cleavage at non-tryptic site. The coverage was increased to include ADH3 Cotja sequence. The Bayesian probabilistic sequencing algorithm MassSeq was used for all MS/MS spectra. 77 of 123 MS/MS spectra provided sequence information. 38 peptides were annotated after all passes. A novel ADH sequence is obtained from all overlapping peptide sequence information. In addition to trypsin, Lys C, chymotrypsin and thermolysin digests were done.

Belgacem O, Buchacher A, Pock K, Josic D, Sutton C, Rizzi A, Allmaier G (2002) J. Mass Spectrom. 37, 1118-1130.

Molecular Mass Determination of Plasma-Derived Glycoproteins by Ultraviolet Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry with Internal Calibration

Drews O, Weiss W, Reil G, Parlar H, Wait R, Görg A (2002) Proteomics 2, 765-774.

High pressure effects step-wise altered protein expression in Lactobacillus sanfranciscensis

High hydrostatic pressure treatments of the bacteria were optimized and standardized. Stress from 25 to 200 MPa were applied and proteomes of Cells were grown in numbers to the same optical density as that of cells that were grown after pressure treatment. Nonetheless there were no difference in proteome maps of bacteria grown under normal conditions and those grown to lower numbers in order to eliminate confounding variables. Proteome maps of Lactobacillus sanfranciscensis were made of bacterial culture that was split and one of the fractions subjected to high pressure. Proteome patterns from 0.1 to 200 MPa in 25 MPa steps permits a pressure-dependent analysis of expression changes also. Pressure ramping was randomized as well since there can be heating and cooling of the bacteria and no temperature effects can be discounted from occurring. In optimizting pressure treatment, the bacteria were assessed before and after under the microscope, pH was measured

Cohen AM, Rumpel K, Coombs GH, Wastling JM (2002) Int. J. Parasitol. 32, 39-51.

Characterisation of global protein expression by two-dimensional electrophoresis and mass spectrometry: proteomics of Toxoplasma gondii

Tachyzoites from cloned RH strain of T. gondii (obtained from Pfefferkorn) were maintained in African green monkey kidney cells. Culture medium is Iscove's MDM with 50 U/ml-50 µg/ml pen-strep in 5% FCS at 37° in 5% CO2 humidified incubator. Infection ratio is 4:1 parasite:host and tachyzoites are harvested at 3 d. Parasites are separated from host cells by filtering through 3 µm polycarbonate Nucleopore Track-Etch membranes (Whatman). Filtered tachyzoites are washed in PBS (pH 7.4) by spinning at 1500 g for 20 min at 4°. A final wash is done with centrifugation at 16,000 g for 3 min at 4° and stored in batches of 50 million @ −80°. Protein assays are done using BCA (Pierce); these are read @560 nm in Titertek Multiskan MCC/340 MTP reader.

Frozen tachyzoite pellets were disrupted in 40 µl 8 M urea, 4% CHAPS, 40 mM Tris, and frozen (in liq N2) and thawed in 3 cycles.

Hastings CA, Norton SM, Roy S (2003) Rapid Comm. Mass Spectrom. 16, 462-467.

New Algorthms for Processing and Peak Detection in Liquid Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry

LC/MS enables id and quantification of thousands of analytes in single injection. Present peak detection algorithms attempt to identify peaks in individual ion chromatograms, or ion chromatograms made by averaging all signals in a mass range. With smaller sample volumes and/or lower concentrations, noise generally increases against signal. Detection in MS involves numerous physical mechanisms before ion is detected. At each point there is noise with a particular distribution, and this accumulates to final measured ion current. Noise is basically chemical and electrical. Histograms (plots of # of occurrences vs. log intensity) of two samples, tryptic digests of high MW fraction of human serum and 5-protein mixtures are shown. The histogram is produced by treating LC/MS data as 2D matrix. Signal intensity of matrxi points is on x-axis, and frequency is in which intensity range occurred is on y-axis (histogram described). Figure shows only small fraction of matrix point have signal because of analytes of interest, and they do not significantly affect histogram. Spectra acquired on Finnegan LCQ Deca with or with nanoESI heads (Protana, Denmark; New Objective, USA). and data not normalized before making histogram. Serum had been ultrafiltered in 10 kDa cutoff. Separately a 5-protein mix (equine myoglobin, bovine RNase A, BSA, bov. cytochrome c, human Hb) prepared in DTT/iodoacetic acid+NaOH before trypsinization.

Histograms of serum and 5-protein mix quite similar, described by sum of two normal distributions in log scale. There is a separation of the peak by a few orders of magnitude in intensity. Major noise component is chemical, and the log-normal distribution at higher intensity is associated with this noise type. In the 5-protein mix there are lower ion current intensities and so the noise is likely to be electrical.

Processing. Generally noise and artifact removal focuses on peak sharpening or removing nose and artifacts in corrupted chromatograms. Backfolding methods are used to sharpen peaks and increase intensity of signal by concentrating them in single scan. Signals are located in 2D dataset since sharpened peaks are prominent in total ion chromatogram, but loss of lineshape info complicates peak verification when nose on par with intensity of sharpened signals. When noise is significantly stronger than intensity of sharpened analyte signals this method fails, since noise obscures analytes in TIC after backfolding. The latter algorithm, called CODA, depends on averaging filter to identify noisy runs and handles non-normally distributed noise since smoothed and unsmoothed chromatograms differ. But the entire ion chroamtogram and not just noise component is removed from filtered dataset. Nonlinear filters are proper for handlings data with noise not normally distributed in linear scale. A filtering scheme based on median filter in which a simple nonlinear filter replaces each point in a data vector with the median of the point and some number of surrounding points. Such a filter has not been reported on the retention time axis, although used in mass spectra and cyclic voltammetry data. It should completely remove spectral features narrower than half-width of filter, and those wider than the filter width pass unchanged, although intenisty of signal slightly attenudated at or near peak maximum. Since it is an averaging filter, performance results improve from increased sampling (assumes increased sampling does not result in degraded signal-to-noise in individual scans).

Relative performance of mean (boxcar averaging) and median filters studied by use of a protein mixture dataset with noise distriubitons described above. Analytes elute typically in a period where 20-25 scans are collected. Dataset were mean or median filtered along time axis with 9-scan filter width. A filter width of half analyte signal width in scans maximizes discrimination between analyte and noise, but small variations in this value do not impact results. The base peak intensity is normalized to 109 count and the spectrum converted to log scale, then noise distributions calculated. Both mean and median filtering shifted noise distribution peak to the left, decreasing noise level. Signal-to-noise is increased if signal remains unchanged. Filter effectiveness is judged by shift magnitude of noise distributions. Median filtering is more effective for both distributions. Using a bimodal Gaussian distribution with software Grace, an improvement of fitting the curves was obtained. The mean filter shifts high intensity noise distribution to left by 1.26 and shifts low intensity to left by factor of 1.32. Median filter shifts noise to left by factor of 1.78 and low intensity noise by 1.86. Generally higher intensity (chemical) noise distribution is responsible for obscuring analyte signals and in this case the median filter is 1.78/1.26 = 1.4 times more effective in reducing noise than the mean filter.

NMR software packages are quite developed in looking at variation and detecting local maxima in multidimensional data exceeding a signal-to-noise. Candidate peaks are then subjected to additional filtering routines. Noise level is assessed from signal-free part of spectrum. The program AUTOPSY determines noise value as a geometric mean of noise levels of all vectors intersecting that point. The noise threshold varies from point to point in response to noise concentrated in regions of the dataset. LC-MS spectral noise and signals is not always amenable to algorithms for NMR data. Artifacts from mobile phase clusters and column bleed occur at discrete m/z ratios. Chemical noise occurs in particular m/z ranges and particular compositions of mobile phase. Peak detection can be done on the ion chromatogram itself or by first averaging ion chromatograms in the m/z range of interest.

The peak detection algorithm developed here takes a point (represented by m/z and retention time) and for it to be a peak, there must be a peak at that m/z in the mass spectrum for that retention time, and there must be a peak at that retention time in the ion chromatogram containing that m/z ratio. Clustered points (m/z and time) passing the criteria applied along ion chromatogram vector intersecting that point and also applied along the mass spectrum vector intersecting that point comprise peaks. These are then further optimized and filtered. This vectorized peak detection has two advantages. One: it is more robust to variation in noise and artifact distribution. Unlike in AUTOPSY NMR data, points on ion chromatograms corrupted by solvent clusters or column bleed are identified as candidate peaks if they exceed a threshold defined by level of chemical noise in that ion chromatogram, regardless of how noise-free adjoining mass spectra may be at that m/z value.

Vectorized peak detection also permits existing algorithms for peak detection in ion chromatograms and mass spectra to be used. Estimating noise in LC-MS data is complicated by centroiding and thresholding done at data acquisition time. This method usese only simple estimate: third-median of all nonzero points in vector under consideration. Bayesian or other proprietary methods in commercial MS software packages identifies candidate peaks in either ion chromatogram or mass spectra. Line shape and isotope distribution can be included in peak detection.

Comparing vectorized and global threshold methods is shown in fig 4 of LC-MS of human serum. A trade-off between detecting spurious peaks and missing peaks due to analytes of interest. The contamination caused by chemical noise is apparent in upper right. With a global threshold some spurious peaks are detected. With vectorized method, the threshold is varied (not set at a global level) and adapts to noise, avoiding the detection of noise as peak. when chemical noise is greater in intensity than weak peaks in uncontaminated regions, using single global threshold cannot identify all peaks simultaneously in uncontaminated regions, avoid identifying spurious, and pick the intense peaks in contaminated regions

silver-associated peptides, MALDI, FD

Chu IK, Cox DM, Guo X, Kireeva I, Lau T-C, McDermott JC, Siu KWM (2003) Anal. Chem. 74, 2072-2082.

Sequencing of Argentinated Peptides by Means of Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Tandem Mass Spectrometry

In a previous work, we prepared oligopeptides (tryptic digests) and then added silver(I) nitrate before doing ESI-MS/MS using low energy CID. Unlike protonated peptides, the argentinated peptides produced predominantly N-terminal ions (one a type, two b types) into a recognizable triplet pattern such that [bn+OH+Ag]+ is 18 u higher than [bn-H+Ag]+, and [bn-H+Ag]+ is 28 u higher than [an-H+Ag]+, the differences being H2O and CO loss, respectively. An algorithm is used to identify the triplet and doublets of fragment ion peaks, computes mass differences between neighboring triplets, and then proposes the residue removed. Silver ion in ESI might reduce ion intensity and analytical sensitivity. Another problem in ESI is multiple charge formation that includes Ag+ and H+, which complicates use of a simple algorithm. In this study, a MALDI MS/MS is used (ABi/MDS SCIEX QSTAR Pulsar i QqTOF MS and a ABi/Perceptive Voyager DE-STR MALDI ToF). Peptides are prepared at 10 µmol/L in 50% MeOH with 2 mM AgNO3 or with 0.1% TFA when they are to be protonated. 1 µl petpide solution mixed with 9 µl satd CHCA or DHB, then dried-droplet spotted to target plate (1 µl).

MALDI-MS spectra are compared for protonated and argentinated peptides ranging from 50-1140 fmol peptide. Sensitivity is comparable for both cationizations: [M+Ag]+/[M+H]+ ratios are from 0.2 to 0.6, showing that a significant fraction of peptides are argentinated. Angiotensin I has the highest affinity for Ag ion, not only in the intensity ratio, but also producing [M-H+2Ag]+ and [M-2H+3Ag]+ ionic forms.

Bradykinin shows a typical spectrum in which the peak cluster of [M+Ag]+ shows the 107Ag and 109Ag isotopes of equal abundance (107/109 ratio is 1.076). A third peak is in that cluster is often the most abundant though, because it is the sum of the intensity of the [13C2-M+107Ag]+ with that of [M+109Ag]+

CID spectra were collected on peptide MGGFLR as [M+Ag]+. The quadrupole was set to filter at 788.25 Th to remove one of the Ag doublets. The classic triplet pattern of two b and one a type ions is present, and the tag -GFL/IR is readable from the spectrum.

Previous work shows that N-terminal ions corresponding to the C-terminal side fragment of a proline residue are low in intensity. This is beccause an argentinated oxazolone cannot be produced by cleavage of proline on C-terminal side: prolyl residue lacks an N-H hydrogen for oxazolone formation. Bovine casein 192-198 is a tryptic peptide AVPYPQR. The [b5-H+Ag]+ has very low intensity, while [b5+OH+Ag]+ and [a5-H+Ag]+ have better intensity, and enabled assignment of the other b5 ion. The complement of b5 is [y3-H-Ag]+ and this C-terminal ion was in greater abundance: its mass confirms the -PQR tag. It was unusually intense for an R-terminating peptide. There is also a rather abundant N-terminal prolyl peptide corresponding to [y5-H+Ag]+, not much apparently because the complement N-terminal triplet is missing. Note that intense [yn-H+Ag]+ ions with N-terminal proline parallels the finding in protonated peptides.

CID spectra also show that protonated and argentinated peptides coexist, with the abundance ratio of [M+Ag]+/[M+H]+ being from ~0.2 to 1.0. The bovine α-casein tryptic peptides were studied. Peptides 140-147, 106-115, 38-49, 121-134, 23-37, and 119-134 make up 28% of the residues. Abundance ratios were hard to determine in this mix. 37 fmol of BSA digest was analyzed and the spectrum shows the mix of protonated and argentinated peptides. 9 ions of tryptic peptides (18% of sequence) were seen in H+ and Ag+ forms. Four Ag+ peptide ions were fragmented and gave minimum of three residues from C-terminal ions. This combination of tags and tryptic masses run through MASCOT gave unambiguous identifcation (MOWSE=307, with >71 being significant).

MEF2A protein was digested and mixed with silver nitrate and both MS and MS/MS spectra were collected. Two MS/MS spectra focused on m/z 1545.59 and 1532.51 Th gave partial sequences of -GN(I/L)GMNSR and -PHESR, respectively. The MASCOT processing produced a score of 165 (>65 significant) for MEF2A. The protonated MS/MS spectra were less informative.

Candiano G, Musante L, Bruschi M, Ghiggeri GM, Herbert B, Antonucci F, Righetti PG (2002) Electrophoresis 23, 292-297.

Two-Dimensional Maps in Soft Immobilized pH Gradient Gels: A New Approach To The Proteome of The Third Millennium

ABSTRACT. Same major improvements in proteome analysis of cytosolic and membrane proteins by two-dimensional mapping are here reported. A much improved transfer of proteins from the first to the second dimensional sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS)-gel is obtained by simply diluting the gel matrix, normally composed of 4%T polyacrylamide in all commercially available Immobiline strips down to as low as 3%T. In the analysis of total lysates of platelets, this augmented transfer has been evaluated as being 23 times higher than in standard 4%T gels. A second major improvement, in the case of analysis of membrane protein preparations, has been demonstrated to consist in a delipidation step in a tertiary solvent mixture composed of tri-n-butyl phosphate:acetone:methanol in a 1:12:1 ratio. By adopting this protocol, large amounts of spectrins (240220 kDa, filamentous proteins of the red blood cell membranes) could be transferred vs. essentially none when delipidation was omitted. The present report also confirms the importance of a reduction and alkylation step of the protein sample prior to all electrophoretic steps, including focusing in the Immobiline gel, as recently reported by Herbert et al. (Electrophoresis 2001, 22, 20462057).

Langridge J, Wallace A, Millar A, Young P, O'Malley R, Swainston N, Skilling J, Hayes J, Richardson K (2002) Presented at EPS, Sorrento, Italy 1-7 September 2002

A Fully Automated Software Strategy for De Novo Sequencing of Whole LC-MS/MS Datasets

POSTER. A problem of MS/MS spectra is that matches are not made in searches of known protein sequences. Only peptides within the database are identified, and good quality spectra with single amino acid differences are unmatched. Sequences can be used for BLAST-based homology searches or for preparing degenerate primers. An automated, high-throughput sequence analysis system is provided. The Q-ToF Ultimate API hybrid quadrupole oa-ToF is used for data generation. Two proteins were digested with trypsin, mixed in equimolar amounts. 100 fmoles were injected. System is fitted with 10-port valve, stream select module. Trap (300 µm × 5 mm) and analytical (75 µm × 150 mm) containing PepMap C18 (LC Packings) were used. The nano-LC sprayer is set up at 3000 V with a 5 psi nebulizing gas. Flow to sprayer is 200 nl/min with pump set at 2 µl/min with 1:9 splitter. An internal reference is used to provide mass accuracy tolerance of 5 ppm in both MS and MS/MS mode. Workflow is such that a filter is applied to dataset to remove spectra insufficient to represent a peptide; remaining spectra are recalculated using MaxEnt3 to zero-charge spectra; XML submissions are made and post-search filter applied to returned hits for validation.

The two proteins produced 30 ions, and 25 of these were matched to either pyruvate kinase or FBP aldolase A, the proteins. 11 ions produced identical sequences. With 14 cases, a high degree of homology was found. 5 ions had not database entry: these were re-submitted to a BLAST-P search against nrDB, where a match was made against the two proteins. It was found that the sequence was non-tryptic, explaining why no match was made.

Gobom J, Mueller M, Egelhofer V, Theiss D, Lehrach H, Nordhoff E (2002) Anal. Chem. 74, 3915-3923.

A Calibration Method That Simplifies and Improves Accurate Determination of Peptide Molecular Masses by MALDI-TOF MS

ABSTRACT. The use of delayed ion extraction in MALDI time-of-flight mass spectrometry distorts the linear relationship between m/z and the square of the ion flight time (t2) with the consequence that, if a mass accuracy of 10 ppm or better is to be obtained, the calibrant signals have to fall close to the analyte signals. If this is not possible, systematic errors arise. To eliminate these, a higher-order calibration function and thus several calibrant signals are required. For internal calibration, however, this approach is limited by signal suppression effects and the increasing chance of the calibrant signals overlapping with analyte signals. If instead the calibrants are prepared separately, this problem is replaced by an other; i.e., the ion flight times are dependent on the sample plate position. For this reason, even if the calibrants are placed close to the sample, the mass accuracy is not improved when a higherorder calibration function is applied. We have studied this phenomenon and found that the relative errors, which result when moving from one sample to the next, are directly proportional to m/z. Based on this observation, we developed a two-step calibration method, that overcomes said limitations. The first step is an external calibration with a high-order polynomial function used for the determination of the relation betweenm/z and t2, and the second step is a first-order internal correction for sample position-dependent errors. Applying this method, for instance, to a mass spectrum of a mixture of 18 peptides from a tryptic digest of a recombinant protein resulted in an average mass error of 1.0 ppm with a standard deviation of 3.5 ppm. When instead using a conventional two-point internal calibration, the average relative error was 2.2 ppm with a standard deviation of 15 ppm. The new method is described and its performance is demonstrated with examples relevant to proteome research.

Carpenter KH, Wiley V (2002) Clin. Chim. Acta 322, 1-10.

Application of Tandem Mass Spectrometry to Biochemical Genetics and Newborn Screening

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) has become a key technology in the fields of biochemical genetics and newborn screening. The development of electrospray ionisation (ESI) and associated automation of sample handling and data manipulation have allowed the introduction of expanded newborn screening for disorders which feature accumulation of acylcarnitines and certain amino acids in a number of programs worldwide. In addition, the technique has proven valuable in several areas of biochemical genetics including quantification of carnitine and acylcarnitines, in vitro studies of metabolic pathways (in particular h-oxidation), and diagnosis of peroxisomal and lysosomal disorders. This review covers some of the basic theory of MS/MS and focuses on the practical application of the technique in these two interrelated areas.

Hack CA, WH Benner (2002) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 16, 1304-1312.

A Simple Algorithm Improves Mass Accuracy to 50-100 ppm for Delayed Extraction Linear Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry

A linear MALDI-ToF with delayed extraction was built in-house. Sample is placed on circular stainless steel probe 4 mm dia attached to end of long rod inserted into vacuum chamber. Rod is mounted so that probe center is 1.5 mm from centerline of vacuum chamber, allowing probe rotation to obtain fresh spots. Rotation is done after 50-100 pulses. A Voyager Biospectrometry Workstation (PerSeptive Biosystems) operated in linear mode with DE; it takes a 192-spot plate ea. with 1 mm dia spots surrounded by hydrophobic surface. Sample irradition is in 3 ns pulses with 337 nm nitrogen laser. Spots are made in sandwich method: base layer is satd matrix solution alone (in some cases, 1/20 dilution of CHCA in acetone). The second layer includes peptides or proteins mixed to 0.1-5 µM in a solution with 20-fold dilute satd CHCA with equal vols water and MeCN containing 0.1% TFA (v/v). In some cases samples are dried under a nitrogen stream.

A linear MALDI ToF has the following components. A sample plate and extraction grid with the distance between them called the extraction region (for the Voyager workstation, it is 2.5 mm). A grounded grid entry plate is located 17.2 mm further. After that is the free flight tube or acceleration region whose length is 1228.8 mm. The in-house built system values are 9.5, 27.9 and 1189.6 mm, resp. Acceleration voltage is 15,000 V, and after the delay time the extraction grid is reduced to 95% of the sample plate voltage. A guide wire is positioned on the beamline axis between grounded grid and the MCP, set to −3 V. Delayed extraction times are 200-500 ns. As the extraction and accleration regions are longer in the in-house built system, larger voltage drops and longer delayed extractions times are necessary.

The initial velocity of ions (v0) can be calculated by observing changes in the ion TOF resulting from changes in extraction delay times:

v0 ~ β/t (dt / dτ)

where t is time of flight, dt / dτ is change in time of flight with respect to delayed extraction time, and β is property of instrument geometry and ratio between voltages on sample electrode and extraction grid. With voltage ratio of 89% in in-house system, β=0.0356; for the Voyager with ratio of 95%, β=0.0709. The ion initial velocity must be known to use the Juhasz calibration equation. Nitrocellulose was included in a matrix and this might have an effect on ion initial velocity. Using Substance P[1-7] fragment, an initial velocity of 300 ± 10 m/s was obtained with CHCA alone and 310 ± 13 m/s (each n = 5) with CHCA + nitrocellulose. The difference is not significant by Student's t test. While initial velocities were not statistically significant, the flight times of ions with nitrocellulose were always longer than for samples without nitrocellulose. There was a 99% probability that these flight times differed with the Substance P fragment, and 82% with a dynophorin peptide (this peptide has a 1600 Da mass compared to the 900 Da mass of substance P frag). The difference in time is 1-2 ns, which is not much when the electronics digitize at 2 ns intervals. These differences might result in errors of up to 200 ppm in calibration equations however.

Five peptides with masses in the range 500-3000 Da were measured in the in-house instrument with CHCA matrix (no nitrocellulose). The calibration would be √m/z = At + B for a linear fit.

The mass error (Da) is then plotted against the peptide mass (Da) and reveals peptides at the extreme of the mass range with δm > 0 and those in the middle having δm < 0. The lowest absolute deviation is 0.9 Da. The mean absolute deviation is 1262 ppm. A parabola can be fit to the deviation; the quadratic equation then shows the deviation from expected values. The mass can then be corrected using the quadratic equation. The accuracy of each mass is then increased dramatically, with all corrected values within 0.12 Da of theoretical and an average error of 59 ppm, a 21-fold increase.

The same ToF data were then calibrated with the Juhasz et al equation which adds second and third order terms to linear calibration, but which do not depend on the ion ToF, but rather initial velocity and instrument geometry, and are essentially constants. With this third order calibrated mass, errors are calculated and still the average error is 1150 ppm, hardly any improvement. A plot of the error curve of the adjusted masses is not really different than the uncorrected plot. This plot was used to create a quadratic equation to correct the data just as with the data not corrected by third order equation. The correction had an average error of 60 ppm like the previous correction. The third order correction becomes unnecessary and removes the need to know the initial ion velocity, which is not known with a high degree of accuracy anyway.

The calibrants used were not exactly evenly spaced. The span was from 500-3000 Da but four were < 2000 Da and three were spaced 600 Da apart. The parabolic/quadratic fit then was weighted to the 1000-1600 Da region, and R2 for the correction was 0.9979. When calibrants were chosen with more evenly spaced masses, the weighting was more equal and R2 became 0.9992.

Tryptic peptides of myoglobin were mixed with the 5-peptide mix. ToF data for the 5 calibrants were generated for both first order (linear) and third order Juhasz equation calibration curve. The average error of the linear calibrated (fit) masses is 230 ppm. With the Juhasz calibration the average error is 150 ppm. When quadratic correction is applied, the error is reduced to 4 ppm, a 50-fold improvement over the linear, and 30-fold over the third order calibration. Applying the correction to the myoglobin peptide masses, the masses are submitted to MS-Fit in Protein Prospector with 100 ppm tolerance. If the masses had been calibrated linearly, the average error would be 204 ppm, requiring a tolerance of 300 ppm to make the identification. With quadratic correction, the average error is reduced to 28 ppm.

Cytochrome c from horse and cow were analyzed to distinguish digests from highly similar amino acid sequences. There is only a 3 amino acid difference in the 154 residues of the protein. Quadratic corrections applied in the four internal calibrants reduced differences to 10-30 ppm of theoretical. A db search with 100 ppm tolerance then 500 ppm was done. Only one hit was found for the 100 ppm search, which was the correct identification for horse cytochrome c. The other cytochrome c 100 ppm search found cow and dog cytochrome c, with identical sequences in the regions of digest fragments.

Langridge J, Wallace A, Millar A, Hughes C, Vissers H, Dourdeville T, Young P (2002) Presented at 19th Montreux Symposium, Montreux, Switzerland, 6-8 November 2002

High Sensitivity Phosphoprotein Analysis Using A Combination of Variable Flow Chromatography and Precursor Ion Discovery on a Q-ToF Mass Spectrometer

POSTER. Precursor ion scanning is the best approach for analyzing post-translational modifications. Typical applications will scan through a protein digest and search only for peptides that are potentially modified (phosphorylated). During an HPLC run the MS is switched at one-second intervals between low and high energy collision energy. The first data set is low (10 eV) energy and shows normal pseudo molecular ions. The second data set is at higher energy to look at fragments.

As the HPLC gradient develops the energy is switched at 1-second intervals between low and high energy, and the quadrupole (MS1) is set to operate in RF mode only: the full mass range is passed to the ToF analyzer. Product ions seen in the high energy dataset may cause a switch to MS/MS mode to select precursors to find true parent.

The following workflow shows what happens:

  1. HPLC run is started
  2. MS Survey (low energy) is done
  3. Initial precursor mass list created
  4. Selection criteria applied: charge state, etc.
  5. Short list of precursors and expected products from neutral loss created
  6. Acquire high energy MS survey
  7. If there is a product due to neutral loss present, switch to MS/MS
  8. If there no product due to neutral loss, then is prodct ion present??
  9. In MS/MS mode of neutral loss products, is there still neutral loss present? If yes, acquire MS/MS on identified precursor, then return to lower energy MS survey. If no, return to lower energy survey without doing MS/MS on any precursor.
  10. If a product ion without neutral loss is present, switch to MS/MS mode on first shortlist precursor: if no product ion present, switch to MS/MS mode on next shortlist precursor. If no product ion present, acquire MS/MS on identified precursor, then go back to lower energy MS scans.
