Variable flow LC-MS/MS was set up with two 10-port valves of the Stream Select module and CapLC. A preconcentration trap was set up with nano-analytical column. The trap was 300 µm × 5 mm C18 and the separation column 75 µm × 150 mm PepMap C18. The spray tip was a PicoTip™ capillary with 10 µm orifice diameter. A 5 psi nebulizing gas was used. To run 200 nL/min through the column, a splitter was required and pump set to 7 µl/min.

The first 10-port valve was put on a switch that was triggered when low mass product ions were detected and precursors were interrogated, and the valve was switched to divert flow to waste and stop flow to the column. Two restrictors are placed on the first 10-port which slow the dissipation of the system backpressure created by the two column and moving back through the splitter to the two lines on the valve. Hence flow in the system is dictated by the rate of pressure dissipation and also by the continuing potential at the spray tip.

Five proteins (8 fmol ADH, 140 fmol β-lactoglobulin, 110 fmol pyruvate kinase, 8 fmol phosphorylase b, and 18 fmol glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase/aldolase C) were analyzed along with 30 fmol of synthetic phosphopeptide TNLSEQ(Yp)ADVYR. The software was set to look for a phosphotyrosyl immonium ion of m/z 216.0430 (tolerance ± 0.020 Da) in the high energy data set since neutral loss of H3PO4. 5 possible precursors were then selected for MS/MS analysis, selected from low energy data set if ion intensity and charge state could produce the m/z 216 ion.

The m/z 216.0430 ion was seen at 17.4 min in the chromatogram. The low energy set was immediately to select candidates. Each of the 5 ions were selected for 12 sec MS/MS analysis, for 1 min in the cycle. Since the peak width is typically 20-30 s that is time for only interrogating 1 or 2 ions. Reducing flow enables time for interrogation for more. The MS/MS spectra reveal that an ion at m/z 769.83 is the true precursor. Voltage was alternated at 1 second intervals between 30 and 70 V, necessary to confirm the presence or absence of the m/z 216.0430 peak. The odd numbered spectra (1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11) are 70 V spectra and an isotope cluster at m/z 216.04 (monoisotopic) is the only evidence of the phosphtyrosylimmonium ion. The even-numbered spectra (2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12) are the 30 V spectra and report the b2 sequence ion. Finally the MS/MS spectrum of selected precursor m/z 769.83 reveals a series of sequenceable y′′ fragment ions. 10 of 12 mass differences can be determined and correspond to the sequence, including the phosphoTyr.

The important point is the use of variable flow to increase the analytical time in MS/MS mode.

Choi B-K, Bobrowicz P, Davidson RC, Hamilton SR, Kung DH, Li H, Miele RG, Nett JH, Wildt S, Gerngross TU (2002) Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 100, 5022-5027.

Use of Combinatorial Genetic Libraries to Humanize N-Linked Glycosylation in the Yeast Pichia pastoris

Recombinant gene expression in fungi have several advantages when the therapeutic product is a glycoprotein, particularly N-linked. One problem in yeast expression is that the N-glycans are of the high mannose (Man) type. These are immunogenic in humans and thus a problem. Mammals and fungi share the first steps of N-linked glycosylation, namely the transfer of (Glc)3-(Man)9-(GlcNAc)2 from the ER lumen to the nascent polypeptide via an oligosaccharyltransferase. These are trimmed by glucosidases I and II and a specific α-1,2-mannosidase to (Man)8-(GlcNAc)2 (isomer Man8B), and then exit the ER to the Golgi. In the human Golgi, α-1,2-mannosidases remove the mannose to produce (Man)5-(GlcNAc)2 for its core. These mannosidases are type II membrane proteins with N-terminal in cytosol and C-terminal catalytic domain, featuring transmembrane domain and stem region; sequences in all parts to the polypeptide but the amino terminus dictate the enzyme localization. In S. cerevisiae glycosylation in contrast involves addition of more Man monomers, the final product having > 100 Man monomers. The enzyme α-1,6-mannosyltrnasferase (Och1p) has a broad substrate except for the human (Man)5-(GlcNAc)2 core. Addition of the first Man monomer by Och1p, additional α-1,6 mannosidases add more Man in α-1,6 manner, then α-1,2 and α-1,3 mannosyltransferase in the yeast Golgi continue the hypermannosylation. In P. pastoris the process is similar though there is much less mannosylation (also it lacks the α-1,3 transferase; confirmed by absence of α-1,3 branching). The first steps of humanizing the glycosylation apparatus involve creating gene knockouts of the α-1,6 and α-1,3 transferases. Subsequent steps are to create fusion genes that do everything possible to create active enzymes that localize in their proper position.

In this study a combinatorial genetic library generating hundreds of fusion constructs, with a high-throughput screen to analyze large numbers of strains. The library is an array of different fusion constructs, each containing a fungal cellular targeting sequence fused in frame to a catalytic domain. Each of the 608 constructs was tested for the ability to trim high Man structures to (Man)5-(GlcNAc)2. Strains able to produce this core were then given a second confirmatory screen. They were then engineered to produce GlcNAc-(Man)5-(GlcNAc)2 in which a β-1,2-N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase I/(GnTI)/leader library was used.

P. pastoris GS115 (his4, Invitrogen) or JC308 (ura3, ade1, arg4, his4, gift of J.M. Cregg). Medium is 1% yeast extract, 2% peptone, 0.1 M potassium phospate pH 6.0, 1.34% yeast nitrogen base, 0.4 mg/L biotin, and 1% glycerol. Cells are grown at RT in 96-well plates. For induction, the glycerol is replaced with 1.5% methanol. The minimal medium is 1.4% yeast nitrogen base, 2% dextrose, 1.5% agar, 0.4 mg/L biotin and amino acids.

The 1215 bp orf of P. pastoris OCH1 codes for a α-1,6-mannosyltransferase. Primers based its sequence were used to amplify genomic DNA from strain X-33 (Invitrogen). Another library (gift from J. Folkman) was used to amplify segments 2685 upstream and 1175 bp downstream of the orf of OCH1 gene: internal oligos of the gene were used with T3 and T7 oligos in the backbone of the library bearing a plasmid λ ZAP II (Stratagene). This makes a 5075 bp fragment placed into pCR2.1-TOPO vector (Invitrogen), called pBK9. The plasmid pJN329 contains a och1::URA3 mutant allele, and 100 µg is digested with SfiI, transfected into P. pastoris JC308 by electroporation. Selection on a uracil-deficient medium is done for 10 d. 1000 colonies were re-streaked. URA+ clones unable to grow at 37° but growing at RT were checked by colony PCR. One clone YJN153 was selected.

DNA encoding the Kringle 3 domain of human plasminogen was amplified with Pfu turbo polymerase (Stratagene) and clonded into the EcoRI and XbaI sites of pPICZαA (Invitrogen), which creates a C-terminal 6-His tag. Pro-46 was replaced with a serine to improve N-linked glycosylation. The plasmid (pBK64) was transformed into P. pastoris strains as a means of monitoring changes in glycosylation engineering. In the wild-type P. pastoris with the och1 mutant gene, hyperglycosylation was eliminated on K3 protein, as seen by westerns: 4-20% SDS-PAGE separated proteins transferred to nitrocellulose were probed with anti-peptide antibody (Sigma-Genosys) raised against CQQLSSPKIDYDPLTL, part of P. pastoris Och1p.

The N-glycans from K3 were removed by reductively alkylating Cys of the protein and then blocking the membranes. washing wells three times with water. 30 µl of 10 mM ammonium bicarbonate pH 8.3 with 1 mU N-glycanase (Glyko) is added and after 16 h at 37° the solution containing glycans is removed by centrifugation and evaporated to dryness. Glycans were resuspended in 15 µl water and spotted 0.5 µl on target plates, mixed with 0.5 µl of super DHB in 50% MeCN containing 0.1% TFA. (Man)5-(GlcNAc)2 was used as external standard. MALDI-ToF spectra showed a molecular mass consistent with (Man)10-16-(GlcNAc)2 for K3 expressed in wild-type. In K3 in strains with och1 mutant, predominantly (Man)6-12(GlcNAc)2 was found, with associated loss of smearing in westerns.

A leader library consisting of N-terminal peptides of type II membrane proteins which localize in the ER or Golgi of yeast was constructed. The catalytic domains of α-1,2-mannosidases from several species (human to single-cell eukaryotes) formed a second library. A third library of the catalytic domains of GnTI genes from a wide variety of eukaryotes was also prepared. The combination of constructs was such that the leader was fused with a catalytic domain.

The leader itself was of three classes: (1) a short length being the cytoplasmic tail and transmembrane domain, (2) a long form which added the complete stem up to the catalytic domain, and (3) a medium form containing half the stem along with the short form. The catalytic domain was obtained from different species to find an active form that could exist at different pH and temperature. The best chimeric constructs were those that had a high degree of Man-trimming activity and UDP-GlcNAc transfer activity on the K3 reporter.

608 total chimera were thus screened. Homologs of C. elegans had a high degree of trimming activity down to (Man)5-(GlcNAc)2; its leader in the fusion was the MNS1 or MNN10 fragments from S. cerevisiae. More than half (56%) of fusions formed only very low (<10%) amounts of the desired Man core. The constructs that worked accounted for 70-80% trimming. The results show the importance of picking a good localization sequence and a catalytic domain of proper length.

Andon NL, Hollingsworth S, Koller A, Greenland AJ, Yates JR 3rd, Haynes PA (2002) Proteomics 2, 1156-1168.

Proteomic Characterization of Wheat Amyloplasts Using Identification of Proteins by Tandem Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. We describe the initial characterization of the wheat amyloplast proteome, consisting of the identification and classification of 171 proteins. Whole amyloplasts and purified amyloplast membranes were prepared from wheat (Triticum aestivum). Protein extracts were examined by one-dimensional and two-dimensional electrophoresis, followed by high performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry of separated proteins. Tandem mass spectrometry data of individual peptides was then searched by SEQUEST, using a database containing known protein sequences from both wheat and other homologous cereal crops. Using this approach we identified 108 proteins from whole amyloplasts and 63 proteins from purified amyloplast membranes. The majority of protein identifications were derived from protein sequences from cereal crops other than wheat, for which relatively little gene sequence data is available. The highest percentage of protein identifications obtained from any individual species was 46% of the total number of proteins identified, using sequence data found in our proprietary rice (Oryza sativa) genome database.

Keller A, Nesvizhskii AI, Kolker E, Aebersold R (2002) Anal. Chem. 74, 5383-5392.

Empirical Statistical Model To Estimate The Accuracy of Peptide Identifications Made By MS/MS and Database Search

ABSTRACT. We present a statistical model to estimate the accuracy of peptide assignments to tandem mass (MS/MS) spectra made by database search applications such as SEQUEST. Employing the expectation maximization algorithm, the analysis learns to distinguish correct from incorrect database search results, computing probabilities that peptide assignments to spectra are correct based upon database search scores and the number of tryptic termini of peptides. Using SEQUEST search results for spectra generated from a sample of known protein components, we demonstrate that the computed probabilities are accurate and have high power to discriminate between correctly and incorrectly assigned peptides. This analysis makes it possible to filter large volumes of MS/MS database search results with predictable false identification error rates and can serve as a common standard by which the results of different research groups are compared.

Dickinson DP (2002) Crit. Rev. Oral Biol. Med. 13, 485-508.

Salivary (SD-Type) Cystatins: Over One Billion Years In the Making—But To What Purpose?

REVIEW. Barrett et al (1986) reported a trypsin inhibitor in egg white which could inhibit plant proteases like papain and ficin. The inhibitor was about 12.7 kDa and potent (Ki = 10 nM). Binding is a 1:1 reversible complex, although in many cases affinity is so high it is essentially irreversible. A 13.3 kDa protein in normal CSF and in the urine of renal failure patients was identified as cystatin C. Cystatins are found all throughout eukaryotic species: orthologs are in many species, and within many species are paralogs (occur by duplication). The proteins has 3 distinct structural features: an N-terminal glycine (posn 11 in cystatin C), a QXVXG motif in a hairpin loop, and a PW motif in a second loop in the C-terminus. All of these come together to dock with the active site of cysteine proteinases.

The chicken egg white protein (ortholog is human cystatin C) is a family 2 protein also found in fish, other birds, and mammals. These are 120-125 residues long with two disulfide bonds. A secretory peptide leader is present. Both x-ray crystals and NMR in solution have revealed structure. It is five-straned β-sheet wrapped with a five-turn α-helix. N-terminal 10 residues are disordered and flexible. G11 is in the first short β-strand A, connected to a five-turn α-helix 1. QLVSG (the QxVxG match) is in a hairpin between β-strands B and C. A short second α-helix 2 connects strands C and D; this α-helix is not seen in solution by NMR, forming a loop lacking secondary structure. The α-helix 2/loop is anchored by disulfide #1. Conserved PW motif is in a 2nd hairpin loop between β strands D and E, linked by 2nd disulfide. All three conserved regions come together to form a wedge that docks to cysteine proteinase active site. The RLV (pos 8-10) sequence in human cystetin C interact with S4, S3, and S2 substrate-binding subpockets, respectively, on the target enzyme. G11A12 from wedge-shaped edge that binds to active site cleft of papain (G11 binds S1 site. The bond is too far away for cleavage by the active site. Both hairpins interact with residues in the vicinity of the reactive site cysteine. All three domains act rather independently. Binding occurs without induced conformational changes, but the binding of cathepsin B is a two-step mechanism. The proteinase has a loop occluding the active site: there is probably a weak interaction with the N-terminal region of the cystatin, then a conformational change to displace the occluding loop, followed by tight binding.

cDNAs of the three human salivary cystatins S, SA, and SN and a distantly related cystatin D have been cloned, each about 740 bp long. Comparing mature protein to preprotein shows a 20-residue long secretory signal peptide, then an 11-residue N-terminal extension to the conserved G11. Cystatins S, SA, and SN have an 88% identity. Cystatins SA and SN have a greater similarity to chicken cystatin than to cystatin S, which has poorer inhibitory properties.

Cystatins from saliva in other animals have been noted. Snake venom (its glands are modified salivary glands) contain family 2 cystatins. One different from cystatin C by a 6-residue insertion in the loop 2 helix. EST seqeuncing of human amniotic and fetal skin epithelial cDNA libraries revealed a novel human cystatin E, as well as a down-regulated gene in human breast metastatic tumor cells.

Genetic expression diversity is rare in these small, highly conserved family 2 proteins. Haplotypes A and B differ at three sites in gene CST3. Two differences are in promoter region and one in signal peptide (A→T base change). there is no difference in the amino acid sequence. The mutation L68Q causes an autosomal dominant disease: hereditary cerebral hemorrhage with amyloidosis, Icelandic type. CST2 (cystatin SA) has a G→A transition in exon 2 and A→T transversion in exon 3 to produce G59D and E120D in SA1 and SA2 proteins. Substitution at 59 is within the QxVxG sequence: SA1 QIVGG→ SA2 QIVDG. with clearly different inhibitory properties. A C25R change in CST5 exon 1 is within the α-helix 1 opposite the inhbitory binding region and the Ki values remain unchanged.

About 20% of rat cystatin C is N-glycosylated at a NLT consensus site in the α-helix 2/loop region. Other cystatins have glycosylation sites although they are though of as nonglycosylated. The effect of glycosylation is not understood.

Within chicken cystatin (not human cystatin C) is a S82 phosphorylation site in the helix 2/loop. Human S and SA are partially phosphorylated, but cystatin SN is not. Phosphorylation sites at S2, S98, S111, and S114 have been identified. The SN also has a S98 consensus site. The S111 is a casein kinase 2 site [(S/T)xx(D/E/Sp)]. The S2 and S98 sites have a Golgi kinase site [Sx(E/Sp)].

Other cystatin families include Family 1, the stefins, of which humans have two, stefins A and B. Structurally they differ from family 2 inhibitors in that they lack disulfide bonds and the α-helix 2/loop, have a kink in α-helix 1, and have a 9-residue added C-terminus. Gene structure differences include different intron positions and the absence of a secretory signal sequence. Although they are thought to be intracellular, evidence shows secretion in some conditions. The Family 3 cystatins are the kininogens: these are a low and high MW form and the T-kininogen and are made up of three tandem Family 2 cystatin domains followed by a kinin fragment, with different C termini; all of them are inhbitors. Family 4 cystatins are the fetuins, which are abundant mammalian fetal serum and bone glycoproteins. These are N- and O-glycosylated and phosphorylated.

Cutler P, Heald G, White IR, Ruan J (2003) Proteomics 3, 392-401.

A novel approach to spot detection for twodimensional gel electrophoresis images using pixel value collection

Lin D, Tabb DL, Yates JR 3rd (2003) Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1646, 1-10.

Large-Scale Protein Identification Using Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. Recent achievements in genomics have created an infrastructure of biological information. The enormous success of genomics promptly induced a subsequent explosion in proteomics technology, the emerging science for systematic study of proteins in complexes, organelles, and cells. Proteomics is developing powerful technologies to identify proteins, to map proteomes in cells, to quantify the differential expression of proteins under different states, and to study aspects of proteinprotein interaction. The dynamic nature of protein expression, protein interactions, and protein modifications requires measurement as a function of time and cellular state. These types of studies require many measurements and thus high throughput protein identification is essential. This review will discuss aspects of mass spectrometry with emphasis on methods and applications for large-scale protein identification, a fundamental tool for proteomics.

Hoofnagle AN, Resing KA, Ahn NG (2003) Annu. Rev. Biophys. Biomol. Struct. 32, 1-25.

Protein Analysis by Hydrogen Exchange Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. Mass spectrometry has provided a powerful method for monitoring hydrogen exchange of protein backbone amides with deuterium from solvent. In comparison to popular NMR approaches, mass spectrometry has the advantages of higher sensitivity, wider coverage of sequence, and the ability to analyze larger proteins. Proteolytic fragmentation of proteins following the exchange reaction provides moderate structural resolution, in some cases enabling measurements from single amides. The technique has provided new insight into protein-protein and protein-ligand interfaces, as well as conformational changes during protein folding or denaturation. In addition, recent studies illustrate the utility of hydrogen exchange mass spectrometry toward detecting protein motions relevant to allostery, covalent modifications, and enzyme function.

Dowsey AW, Dunn MJ, Yang G-Z (2003) Proteomics 3, 1567-1596.

The Role of Bioinformatics in Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis

REVIEW. A single gene might be able to encode as many as six different protein species, indicating that a study of genomics alone is insufficient to understand what the science of proteomics brings to knowledge. Proteomics begins with sample collection, after which samples must be solubilized, denatured, and the proteins reduced to eliminate structural features that inhibit further analysis. 2-DE is the only method able to separate and quantitate as many as 10,000 proteins. The use of stable isotope tagging in MS is making this part of proteomics able to quantify proteins but 2-DE remains the main method to study differential expression. Staining of 2-DE primarily involves use of silver to detect minor proteins ("gold standard"), but Coomassie Brilliant Blue and SYPRO Ruby have their uses. Imaging of gels is done using 12- to 16-bit grayscale scanners.

The most intense third of spots seen on a gel account for 75% of the total protein loaded on to a gel, and the least intense third of spots make up only about 6% of the mass. The range between the most and least intense spot is probably million-fold for cells and tissues, and 1012 for body fluids (e.g., plasma). The effective staining range is 10,000-fold, which means the least abundant proteins can scarcely be distinguished from noise.

FD

Anbalagan V, Patel JN, Niyakorn G, Van Stipdonk MJ (2003) Rapid Comm. Mass Spectrom. 17, 291-300.

McLafferty-type rearrangement in the collision-induced dissociation of Li+, Na+ and Ag+ cationized esters of N-acetylated peptides

N-acetylated GGG peptide (AcGGG) is esterified at the C-terminal end with ethyl, propyl, and butyl groups and studied in presence of cations (Li, Na, Ag). CID spectra for AcGGGOEt show predominantly is y2+ which occurs when the AcG residue is lost as a oxazolinone. Ions of type [y2-1+Me]+ where Me is Li, Na, or Ag metal appear but at lower intensities. The Na- and Ag-cationized peptides also fragment into product ions [b2-1+Me]+ and [a2-1+Me]+. All metal forms of the AcGGGOEt produced a water loss ion: [AcGGGOEt-H2O+Me]+ was the most abundant peak of Li and Ag cationized ions, and major peak in the Na CID spectrum. Product ions were also seen for the methyl esters. In the unesterified peptide, a water loss ion would be predicted, but not in esters. With free C-terminal -COOH, the mobile proton bonds to the carbonyl O atom on -COOH, making the carbonyl C nucleophilic to attack by the amide O of the n - 1 residue. Water is eliminated with the creation of the charged oxazoloninone ring in what is called the Retro-Koch reaction. Alternatively the mobile proton can bond to a more internal amide O atom, and the proton on the amide N shifts to the other nonbonding pair on the amide O atom. Water is eliminated and a charged triple bond C-N is formed with the charge on the electron-deficient N atom. This is known as a Retro-Ritter reaction. This reaction requires a proton however, not present in case of metal-cationized peptides.

Another mechanism is proposed for water loss, one similar to that proposed in formation of bn+ or [bn-1+Me]+ product ions with cyclization to form 5-member ring, with protein transfer and 1,2-elimination to remove H2O. Evidence for the mechanism: (a) D2O is lost from esters with exchangable protium replaced by deuterium indicating two amide H/D atoms in mechanism, (b) if Pro, which lacks amide nitrogen proton required for 1,2-elimination, is the following residue after the N-acetyl terminus, there is no H2O loss. In the mechanism, The acetyl group isomerizes with N-terminus nitrogen: CH3-C(=O)-NH- → CH3-C(-O−)=N+H-, followed by the oxyanion attacking the carbonyl C atom of the n+1 residue, which forms a 5-member ring. The proton on the ring N atom moves to the n+1 carbonyl O atom (oxyanion) to form the hyxdroxyl. The n+2 nitrogen gives a proton up as the -OH on the ring becomes a good leaving group (1,2-elimination).

To verify structure of the remaining ion, MS3 analysis was done on metal-cationized precursor, with a neutral loss consistent with alkene elimination of 28, 42, and 56 Th, depending on whether the ester was ethyl, n-propyl, and n-butyl (a McLafferty-type rearrangement). Additional CID in MS4 resulted in 46 Th loss consistent with H2O and CO loss of the C-terminus, or loss of residue of C-terminal acid from tri- and tetrapeptide esters by a reaction which generates [bn+17+Me]+ from peptides with unesterified COOH. The loss of H2O is neither the carbonyl nor the ester O atoms on the C-terminus; combined with Pro being the 2nd atom and the absence of H2O loss, then the N-terminal amide carbonyl O is eliminated as indicated. Additional experiments (isotope labeling) should verify this mechanism.

A 28 mass unit loss in peptide dissociation is usually CO from the bn+ or analogous [bn-1+Me]+ product ion representing substituted oxazolinones to produce an+ or [an-1+Me]+ ions. The reaction results in peptide bond cleavage in which the C-terminal side takes the neutral peptide. CO elimination from cationized oxazolinone is an exothermic process. Direct 28 amu elimination in the peptide ethyl ester without b ion (metal-ionized or not) can only be explained by the McLafferty-type rearrangement, used to explain odd-electron ions from electron impact, with cyclization to form 6-member ring, then transfer of γ-C hydrogen to carbonyl O atom, followed by alkene elimination of the ester. Ethylene is a 28 Da neutral species that could be eliminated. Methyl ester of AcGGG in Li+ and shows H2O elimination without any Mclafferty since no transferable H atom is on a γ-carbon. With isopropyl and tert-butyl esters, losses of 42 and 56 amu represent propylene and isobutylene, respectively, consistent with McLafferty; the ion products are both m/z 238. And the relative intensities of the branched esters were higher since the formation of their alkenes has a lower energy barrier. The nature of the metal did not matter, since Na+ and Ag+ gave the same result. Expecting the product ions to be acetylated metal-cationized having COOH C-terminals, MS3 spectra of rearrangement products were compared with MS/MS of the metal-cationized peptides. The spectra are similar with generation of sequence ions (e.g., [b2+17+Li]+ and [b2-1+Li]+) to support a mechanism where the free COOH is produced from the esters by McLafferty rearrangment.

This rearrangement requires H atom transfer from γ-position. To verify 2,2,2-d3-EtOH was used to esterify CH3CO-peptides. If McLafferty-type rearrangement is true, the product ion should be 1 amu higher as it takes up a D atom, and the neutral loss will be 30 amu (not 28) as it takes two D atoms in the alkene. This was found in the spectrum. Intensities of fragment ions in CID spectra are function of precursor ion internal energy and rate of dissociation reactions. The McLafferty depends on the 6-member ring and branched alkyl esters (isopropyl, tert-butyl) offer more H atoms in the γ-carbon. This is shown also.

Dissociation profiles, which are plots of the fraction of ion abundance against the corrected activation amplitude (in arbitrary units) in an ion trap, show the energy needed to produce the dissociation. Different metal-cationized (Li, Na, Ag) forms of the acetylated peptides APF and GGGG had their profiles determined. For ethyl esters there is a decrease in precursor ion intensity and an increase in McLafferty-type rearrangment ions and Li and Na require higher corrected activation amplitudes than did Ag. The Na cationzed peptides had slightly lower activation amplitides than did Li-cationized peptides.

Wang H, Hanash S (2003) J. Chromatog. B 787, 11-18.

Multi-Dimensional Liquid Phase Based Separations in Proteomics

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. This review covers recent developments towards the implementation of multi-dimensional (MuD) liquid phase based systems for proteome investigations. Although two-dimensional polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (2D-PAGE) has been used as a standard approach in proteomics, its drawbacks including the limited dynamic range and molecular mass range, together with lack of on-line integration with biological mass spectrometery (Bio-MS) have limited its widespread use and applications in proteomics. In the meantime, various liquid-phase based multi-dimensional separation techniques have been explored. Especially, with the emergence of the combination of nanoflow capillary high-performance liquid chromatography (cHPLC) and Bio-MS, attention is again refocused on utilizing multi-dimensional liquid-phase based separation of proteins. Some remarkable applications of on-line analysis of intact proteins and on-column digested proteins, and the emergence of approaches such as multiple HPLCelectrospray ionization tandem MS and capillary array electrophoresis-matrix assisted laser desorption ionization MS, have stimulated thinking towards developing a automated multi-dimensional system (MuDSy) that integrates liquid phase based separation, digestion and identification of proteins in complex biological mixtures.

Luche S, Santoni V, Rabilloud T (2003) Proteomics 3, 249-253.

Evaluation of Nonionic and Zwitterionic Detergents As Membrane Protein Solubilizers in Two-Dimensional Electrophoresis

Methods in the past that have done much to reveal membrane-embedded proteins including SDS-PAGE and strategies such as MudPIT (MDLC-MS/MS), but these methods have some disadvantages such as not being quantitative. Use of thiourea as a chaotrope and the development of zwitterionics to extract proteins has enabled better analysis. Electrically neutral detergents do not repel each other as SDS does, and this leads to poorer solubility. Many experimental detergents are not commercially available now. So several nonionic, commercially available detergents were evaluated for their efficiency in membrane protein solubilization.

Arabidopsis thaliana leaf membranes were incubated in Triton X-100 with mixing 1:1 such that detergent concentration was 0.2% w/v, at 4° for 10 min with gentle shaking. The preparation was centrifuged at 120,000 g for 15 min. The pellet was resuspended in the storage buffer and centrifuged again at the same speed and time. The final membrane pellets were then solubilized in an extraction medium of 7 M urea, 2 M thiourea, 20 mM DTT, 0.4-1% carrier ampholytes, and 2-4% detergent. Zwitterionics included tetradecanoyl propyl dimethyl ammonio propane sulfonate (ASB14), 3-(4-heptyl)phenyl-3-hydroxylpropyldimethyl ammoniopropanesulfonate (C7BzO) that were synthesized previously. Glucopon and Plantacare were from Fluka/Sigma-Aldrich. Glycolipid detergents include dodecyl and tetrdecyl mellbionamide. At least 98% pure alkyl maltosides both dodecyl and tetradecyl were also available.

Protein amounts in sample were kept constant. Membranes were solubilized and centrifuged 250,000 g 30 min and supernatant directly focused. IEF was by home-made gradients from pH 4-8 and commercial 3-10 strips. Strip rehydration was on 3%T overnight in 7 M urea, 2 M urea, 20 mM DTT, and 0.4% Pharmalytes 3-10. Detergents were 2% although CHAPS was 4%. Focusing was from 0-300 V in 1 min, kept at 3 hours, then ramped to 3500 V over 60 min, and then kept at that for 20 h. For the 2nd dimension strips are incubated 10 min RT in 6 M urea, 30% w/v glycerol, 2% w/v SDS 13 mM DTT, and 0.125 M Tris 0.1 M HCl. An alkylating solution leaves out DTT and uses 2.5% iodoacetamide. The 2nd dimension is 10% T without a stack.

Band III protein in RBC membranes is easily identifiable (by MS) and the effectiveness of its extraction was the basis of comparison. CHAPS alone was not effective as no band III was detectable. The band for this membrane is not normally sharp probably because of many modifications (glycosylation, palmitylation). Tween family detergents were thoroughly ineffective (no band III was seen with polyoxyethylene sorbitan monopalmitate (Tween 40) nor Tween 20 or 80. Maltoside detergents were good (α and β-dodecyl maltosides). Tetradecyl maltoside and 6-cyclohexyl-hexyl-β-maltoside (Cymal-6) also gave good results. However these detergents are expensive. Cheaper substitutes like Glucopon and Plantacare are mixtures of alkyl glucosides and maltosides but these were ineffective. The dodecyl and tetradecyl mellbionamides were also ineffective.

Some detergents have an oligoethylene glycol polar head and a linear alkyl tail. Triton X-100 has such a polar head but its hydrophobic portion is tert-octylphenyl. Tetraethylene glycol monododecyl ether (Brij 30) did not solublized Band III, and docosaethylene glycol monohexadecyl ether (Brij 58) and docosaethylene glycol octadecyl ether (Brij 78) did little to solubilze and gave poor focusing. Decaethylene glycol monooleylether (Brij 96) solubilized a limited amount of protein and gave better focusing results. Brij 56, TX-100, and decaethylene glycol monotridecyl ether (C13E10) were as good as the zwitterionics and glycosidic detergents.

As a control, A thaliana membranes, rich in aquaporins and H+-ATPase, were compared as well. ASB14 is superior for C7BzO for band III extraction, but the opposite was true for plant membrane preparation. With respect to the nonionic detergents, Brij 78 was ineffective (as for RBC membranes) while Brij 56 was intermediate between ASB14 and C7BzO. Dodecyl maltoside was the most efficient in this panel however. Thus efficency of membrane protein solubilization is a factor of the membrane protein structure itself, the lipid content of the membrane, and the method used to prepare the membrane before final solubilization. Triton X-100 can partially delipidate plant membranes but have no effect on RBC membranes.

It may be necessary to try a panel of nonionic and zwitterionics as part of the process of selecting the best tool. Saccharide-derivative detergents should also be considered despite their costs. However there is batch-to-batch variability, and the detergents of highest purity should be used in this case.

One factor to consider is the hydrophilic-lipophilic balance (HLB). Detergents at the extremes with a low HLB (Brij 30, HLB=9.7) or high HLB (Brij 58, HLB=15.7; Brij 78, HLB=15.3; Tween 40, HLB=15.6) are inefficient, whereas those with intermediate HLB (Brij 56, HLB=12.9; Triton X-100, HLB=13.5; C13E10, HLB=14.1) were better. Brij 96 (HLB=12.4) was an exception with its oleyl hydrophobic moiety. Usually these principles hold true for extraction in the presence of denaturing chaotropes (urea-thiourea mixtures). Brij 30 and Brij 96 were more efficient under non-denaturing conditions however. Triton X-100 is better than CHAPS at solubilizing membranes in urea-thiourea mixtures.

Bruschi M, Musante L, Candiano G, Ghiggeri GM, Herbert B, Antonucci F, Righetti PG (2003) Proteomics 3, 821-825.

Soft Immobilized pH Gradient Gels in Proteome Analysis: A Follow-Up

ABSTRACT. As a follow-up of a previous work on two-dimensional map analysis utilizing soft (< 4%T) immobilized pH gradient (IPG) matrices in the first dimension (Candiano et al., Electrophoresis 2002, 23, 292297), we have further optimized the preparation of such dilute IPG gels. One important step for obtaining an even reswelling of the entire IPG strip along the pH 3-10 interval is a washing step in 100 mM citric acid. It appears as though after rinsing off the excess acid in distilled water, a gradient of this tricarboxylic acid remains trapped into the IPG matrix, from almost nil at the acidic gel region to substantially higher amounts in its basic counterpart. This gradient helps in obtaining a uniform reswelling of the IPG strip, since carboxyl groups are more heavily hydrated than amino groups. The combined effects of uniform reswelling and of diluting the gel matrix favor penetration of large macromolecules (> 200 kDa) and allow for better spot resolution and for the display of a substantially higher number of spots also in the 3060 000 Da region. A delipidation step in tri-n-butylphosphate:acetone:methanol (1:12:1) appears to substantially improve spot focusing and greatly diminish streaking and smearing of spots in all regions of the pH gradient.

Herbert B, Hopwood F, Oxley D, McCarthy J, Laver M, Grinyer J, Goodall A, Williams K, Castagna A, Righetti PG (2003) Proteomics 3, 826-831.

β-Elimination: An Unexpected Artefact in Proteome Analysis

ABSTRACT. Two persistent myths, ingrained in the electrophoretic literature of the last thirty years, namely carbamylation and deamidation, have been recently dispelled (Herbert et al., J. Proteome Res. 2002, in press). We report here, for the first time, a noxious and unexpected artefact in proteome -elimination (or desulfuration), which results on the loss of an H2S group (34 Da) from cysteine (Cys) residues for protein focusing in the alkaline pH region. With such an elimination event, a dehydro alanine residue is generated at the Cys site. In turn, the presence of a double bond in this position elicits lysis of the peptide bond, generating a number of peptides of fairly large size from an intact protein. The first process seems to be favored by the electric field, probably due to the continuous harvesting of the anion produced. The only remedy found to this noxious degradation pathway is the reduction and alkylation of all Cys residues prior to their exposure to the electric field. Alkylation appears to substantially reduce both-elimination and the subsequent amido bond lysis.

Grant BD, Wilkinson HA (2003) Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 15, 206-212.

Functional Genomic Maps in Caenorhabditis elegans

The nematode C. elegans is the first metazoan whose genomic sequence is complete. Half of the genes have been characterized in a large-scale EST project. A high percentage of genes have counterparts in humans. Gene expression is being studied by DNA microarray, yeast two-hybrid, and RNA-mediated interference (RNAi).

Microarrays containing 1-2 kb genomic sequence covering coding regions from about 94% of known or predicted genes are used for profiling. Two RNA samples are then compared as a ratio of a cy3-to-cy5 labeled template. Hill has developed a microarray of ologo containing 98% of known or predicted ORFs. Parallel chips are hybridized with different RNA samples and absolute levels of gene exression.

Hamdan M, Righetti PG (2003) Mass Spec. Rev. 21, 287-302.

Modern Strategies for Protein Quantification in Proteome Analysis: Advantages and Limitations

REVIEW. Advances in MS and development of protein/DNA databases and their search algorithms has enabled global identification and quantification of proteins. Two strategies in global analysis are 2DGE combined with MS analysis. Gygi et al and Washburn et al. have recently reported the value of multidimensional chromatography of protein digest complex mixtures combined with MS analysis. Although both approaches have strong and weak points, there are common characteristics. Proteins should be soluble (dissolved), denatured, and alkylated...a very critical step. For quantification, either gel spot analysis (with a non-saturable stain) or use of ICATs is possible. Other tagging methods include esterification of Glu and Asp using deuterated forms of MeOH have been used (see Goodlett et al.). Derivatization of Lys to homoArg has been proposed by several particularly as it increases peak intensities for MALDI-MS. Cagney and Emili have taken the approach of modifying the C-terminal Lys of tryptic peptides by differential guanidination (a process they call mass-coded abundance tagging (MCAT). Acrylamide labeling of Cys has also been used with isotope labeling to make control-treated quantitative comparisons.

With respect to sample preparation, there are several steps to be considered. Complete alkylation is essential. There are many competing processes for the nucleophilic leaving group iodine atom in the alkylating reagent iodoacetamide (IAA). Thiourea can react as much as ionized sulfhydryls on Cys in proteins at alkaline pH. Hence IAA is rapidly depleted by thiourea with formation of an adduct that deamidates to form cyclic thiazolinidone monoimine:

ICH2C=ONH2 + S=C(NH2)2 → (NH2)2C-S-CH2C(=O)NH2 → [-NH-C(-NH2)-S-CH2-C(=O)-] cyclic + NH3

Depletion of IAA in a solubilization medium containing thiourea was complete in < 5 min. Acrylamide might be added as a scavenger, but then there was the problem of substantially increased alkylation time (> 6 h). Studies with the alkylation of lactalbumin (with 8 Cys residues and a mass of 14186 Da) show quite variable results using alkylators such as acrylamide and 2- and 4-vinylpyridine.

Surfactants (detergents) are usually present at 2% concentration which help to solubilize the protein and make it amenable to better alkylation as well. The influence of SDS and CHAPS in the alkylation of reduced α-lactalbumin (at 50 pmol/µl) was tested in a 1 h incubation of 260 mM IAA at pH 8.8 with 6 M urea present, and with either 2% SDS or CHAPS. SDS has a substantial negative influence. Small angle neutron scattering studies indicate that a protein-decorated micelle is formed with the polypeptide effectively buried in the micelle and short (4-5 residues) outside the micelle and reactive to an alkylator.

Quantifying protein expression involves several possible strategies. Gygi et al. used light and heavy isotopic reagents to modify Cys-containing proteins, then combined them and proteolyzed, and then used affinity chromatography followed by MS. The ICAT has a thiol-reactive group to alkylate Cys, with a polyether link permitting replacement of eight H atoms with D atoms, and a biotin function to permit enrichment on an avidin affinity column. The ICAT group is substantial in size however (570.5 Da) and can overwhelm short peptides with collision-induced dissociation within the ion source itself. Furthermore complete alkylation is a problem with ICATs since the function is of the iodoacetamide type, which rarely achieves 80% blocking within intact proteins. Other considerations of ICAT-labeled peptides is an isotope effect seen with RP chromatography: deuterated peptides elute earlier than non-deuterated species, which can lead to misleading isotope ratio results critical to quantitation. This effect is more pronounced with the smaller peptides. The separations are not just in chromatography: isotope effects are more pronounced with micellar electrokinetic capillary electrophoresis of small tagged organic molecules.

MALDI ionization is more efficient with Arg than Lys residues (as reported by Krause et al 1999). Arg-containing peptides in one study showed 4-18-fold greater intensity in positive ion mode than Lys-containing peptides. This knowledge has spurred the development of derivatization procedures to permit de novo sequencing of Lys-terminated peptides by guanidination of the ε-amine. Optimization of methods have focused on reaction time and pH. Too high a pH resulted in hydrolysis products, and slightly lower pH brought more desirable results. Cagney and Emili have attempted to derivatize the terminal Lys with an MCAT reagent that adds 42 Da rather than the 8 Da with ICAT, permitting better discrimination. The guanidination reaction reaches near completion in 1 h at pH 10/37° and is specific for Lys side chain. It can be of help in identifying y ions in MS/MS spectra: fragmentation of ions before and after modification would be seen in the y ion as a 42 Da shift.

Other means of quantifying proteins include stable isotope labeling for protein profiling. Groups have used 2H, 13C, 15N, 18O, etc. in growth medium, then pooled protein from labeled and unlabeled and enriched on RP HPLC and SDS-PAGE and analyzed by MS. Yao et al have used 18O-labeled H2O in tryptic digestion to label the peptides during hydrolysis. Others have permethylated carboxylic acid groups with either d0-methanol or d3-methanol; ratios are obtained by normalization of the areas under the curves for the same charge states associated with the d0- and d3-methanol.

Global internal standard strategy or GIST is the description for the labeling strategies above. The idea is to get all peptides labeled independent of some structural feature which may not be present on all of them, such as depending on Cys for ICAT labeling. In a first try at this two groups showed that acylation of primary amino groups would be tried with N-acetoxysuccinimide or N-acetoxy-[2H3]succinimide. Reagents are added to experimental or controls, respectively, after extensive tryptic digestion. If the peptide had a C-terminal Arg, its mass increases by 42 Da. Peptides with a free amino terminus and C-terminal Lys would be acetylated twice (increase by 84 amu).

These experiments in labeling and mixing the variably treated samples probably owes its origins to a study of mRNA expression in which mRNA was labeled by different fluorescent dyes and then mixed, and individual species isolated by hybridization, with the relative degree of the change in mRNA concentration determined by the fluorescence ratio. Differential in-gel electrophoresis (DIGE) is a direct extension of this technique used for proteins. Samples are labeled with mass- and charged-matched fluorophores Cy3 and Cy5, then mixed and run on a 2D gel. Because the dyes are charge- and mass-matched, proteins labeled with them should migrate to the same spot on the pI axis, but >95% of labeled protein is shifted from its unlabeled protein (particularly at lower masses). Matched spots expressed as a violet color generally are in a 1:1 ratio. Cy5-dominant spots produce redder hues, while Cy3-dominant spots show bluer hues. Unlike attempts to match spots between different gels, no spot matching is required since one gel allows complete quantitative analysis. A major disadvantage is the high cost of equipment, software, and reagents. In general, the process should be repeated 3-5 times to provide a proper statistical evaluation.

Shaw J, Rowlinson R, Nickson J, Stone T, Sweet A, Williams K, Tonge R (2003) Proteomics 3, 1181-1195.

Evaluation of Saturation Labelling Two-Dimensional Difference Gel Electrophoresis Fluorescent Dyes

ABSTRACT. Two-dimensional difference gel electrophoresis (2-D DIGE) enables an increased confidence in detection of protein differences. However, due to the nature of the minimal labelling where only approximately 5% of a given protein is labelled, spots cannot be directly excised for mass spectrometry (MS) analysis and detection sensitivity could be further enhanced. Amersham Biosciences have developed a second set of CyDye DIGE Cy3 and Cy5 dyes, which aim to overcome these limitations through saturation-labelling of cysteine residues. The dyes were evaluated in relation to their sensitivity and dynamic range, their useability as multiplexing reagents and the possibility of direct spot picking from saturation-labelled gels for MS analysis. The saturation-labelling dyes were superior in sensitivity to their minimal-labelling counterparts, silver stain and Sypro Ruby, however, the resulting 2-D spot pattern was significantly altered from that of unlabelled or minimal-labelled protein. The dyes were found to be useful as multiplexing reagents although preferential labelling of proteins with one dye over another was observed but was controlled for through experimental design. Protein identities were successfully obtained from material directly excised from saturationlabelled gels eliminating the need for post-stained preparative gels.

Rappsilber J, Ishihama Y, Mann M (2003) Anal. Chem. 75, 663-670.

Stop and Go Extraction Tips for Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization, Nanoelectrospray, and LC/MS Sample Pretreatment in Proteomics

ABSTRACT. Proteomics is critically dependent on optimal sample preparation. Particularly, the interface between protein digestion and mass spectrometric analysis has a large influence on the overall quality and sensitivity of the analysis. We here describe a novel procedure in which a very small disk of beads embedded in a Teflon meshwork is placed as a microcolumn into pipet tips. Termed Stage, for STop And Go Extraction, the procedure has been implemented with commercially available material (C18 Empore Disks (3M, Minneapolis, MN)) as frit and separation material. The disk is introduced in a simple and fast process yielding a convenient and completely reliable procedure for the production of self-packed microcolumns in pipet tips. It is held in place free of obstacles solely by the narrowing tip, ensuring optimized loading and elution of analytes. Five disks are conveniently placed in 1 min, adding <0.1 cent in material costs to the price of each tip. The system allows fast loading with low backpressure (>300 L/min for the packed column using manual force) while eliminating the possibility of blocking. The loading capacity of C18-StageTips (column bed: 0.4mmdiameter, 0.5 mm length) is 2-4 g of protein digest, which can be increased by using larger diameter or stacked disks. Five femtomole of tryptic BSA digest could be recovered quantitatively. We have found that the Stage system is wellsuited as a universal sample preparation system for proteomics.

Finehout EJ, Lee KH (2003) Electrophoresis 24, 3508-3516.

Comparison of Automated In-Gel Digest Methods for Femtomole Level Samples

ABSTRACT. A comparison of automated in-gel digestion methods for low picomolar to femtomolar levels of protein is presented. Gel spots with 4 pmol to 120 fmol of protein were stained with either Coomassie colloidal blue or SYPRO Ruby and digested using an automated platform. The sequence coverages and average peak intensities obtained from a matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization-mass spectrometry (MALDI-MS) analysis are compared. Results show that methods using an acetonitrile extraction or digest times greater than the standard 4 h give no significant increase in peptide sequence coverage for automated digestion of low protein level samples. It is also shown that digests from SYPRO Ruby-stained gels show a greater improvement upon ZipTip cleanup than digests from Coomassie colloidal blue-stained gels. The digests from SYPRO Ruby-stained gels are also shown to give a higher average peptide intensity if a method with minimal gel plug washing is used.

Bodnar WM, Blackburn RK, Krise JM, Moseley MA (2003) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 14, 971-979.

Exploiting the Complementary Nature of LC/MALDI/MS/MS and LC/ESI/MS/MS for Increased Proteome Coverage

Most significant figure of merit in proteome analysis is proteome coverage. A proteolytic digest of a cell lysate might have several hundred thousand different peptides. 1000 precursors per hour can be identified. For this work analytical grade reagents/chemicals were from Sigma, HPLC grade solvents from Burdick & Jackson, and Promega trypsin was used. Ribosomes from mitochondria were prepared from a method; a 1:10 protein:trypsin by weight was used in the digest, with DTT/iodoacetamide treatment before digestion. An UltiMate system featuring FAMOS micro- autosampler and SWITCHOS valves. A 1 mm precolumn cartridge was used for sample preconcentration and desalting, and a 180 µm id × 15 cm PepMap C18 column for separation was used. On the elution end a Probot system features a coaxially mix 7 mg/ml CHCA solution and deposited on MALDI target. Flow at 1.5 µl/min meant that each spot was a 1 min fraction over a 180 min RP gradient of 5-40% MeCN. The Q-ToF Ultima API from Micromass was used., and up to 8 precursors were examined from each MS scan. Selection of precurors was a function of ion intensity, charge state, and dynamic exclusion (was the precursor previously selected?). Collision energy setting was a function of charge state and m/z value. The mass range was 700-3500. Scan combinations were a rolling average, and scans considered complete when any peak inside the 1000-2500 range obtained an intensity greater than a user-defined threshold. Variable collision energies (up to 5) could be set to determine an optimum from a profile: MS/MS acquisitions were stopped when either the end of the precursor list was reached, or the sample depleted, or the time for acquisition expired.

The LC program involved a split flow to the MALDI spotting plate or to the online ESI-MS. 39S bovine mitochondrial ribosomes were digested and separated in 3 h gradient with 20% flow to ESI and 80% to the MALDI target. Better intensities were obtained from MALDI than ESI (base peak intensity ~5 × greater). Differences in abundance are attributable to ionization process and experimental method. MALDI MS keeps MS scans to a minimum so that more sample is available for MS/MS; e.g. 260 scans (22 min) were spent on 15 precursors selected from 2 scans (10 s). Matrix ion clusters adducts formed during ionization contribute to background and can lead to ion suppression in MALDI-MS. As for the ribsome analysis, a selected 3 min chromatogram section showed that 3 peptides were seen in ESI-MS not in the MALDI analysis, 6 peptides seen in MALDI not in ESI, and 16 peptides were seen in both methods.

MS/MS spectra for two precursors were selected for MALDI/ESI comparison. Peptide mass error was ≤ 0.03 Da for each case, and MASCOT scores were ≥ 95% confidence. z=2 ESI and z=1 MALDI peptides differed in fragmentation patterns and ion intensities. The z ≤ 2 peptides give cleaner spectra with fewer internal fragments, but less structural info in some cases. Degree of fragmentation is a factor of sequence, but collision energy profiling overcomes difficulty. With MALDI Q-ToF Ultima, increasing collision energy for some peptide ions reduces precursor signal without a concomitant increase in fragment ion signal.

An interesting finding in the MASCOT search shows that version 1.7 and 1.8 yielded improvements in the score in the later version which allowed instrument type settings (MALDI/TOF/TOF was set in 1.8). This indicates a higher degree of fragmentation for singly charged peptides than expected. A significant amount of internal fragments and neutral losses (a, y*, and b* type ions) are seen.

Laugesen S, Roepstorff P (2003) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 14, 992-1002.

Combination of Two Matrices Results in Improved Performance of MALDI MS for Peptide Mass Mapping and Protein Analysis

Karas and Hillenkamp embedded tryptophan and nicotinic acid in a UV-absorbing matrix while Tanaka et al. tried glycerol and finely divided powder in the first experiments to develop MALDI. This led to changes in the laser wavelength, discovery of new matrices and sample prep methods.

The use of TFA or FA has significant effects on the spectrum. The best results (S/N, reproducibility, and reduced ion suppression) are seen with CHCA is prepared with FA, and DHB with TFA. Inspection of the dried droplets shows that CHCA forms small but unevenly sized crystals with larger crystals and lower densities at the center. DHB forms large crystal needles pointing inward from the outer edge. Combinations of the matrices showed better crystal distribution, with needle-like crystals from the rim of shorter length and evenly distributed CHCA toward the center. Different ratios (CHCA:DBH 2:1) resulted in one crystal type favored over another. Despite surface heterogeneity analyte formation occurred although ion intensity varied depending upon target. DHB matrix use typically resulted in sweet spot searching along the rim. Matrix mixes typically provided intense signals over the entire well surface. Examination of the m/z 0-500 range was done to check for matrix-related ions. Laser fluence required to get ions from the rim was twice needed for that in the center.

BSA, ADH, and lactoglobulin were run on 1-D gel, Coomassie-stained, in-gel trypsin-digested, and extracted peptides set up in matrix and mixes. 150 fmol (in 0.5 µl) was mixed with 0.5 µl matrix and applied to target. For all peptides more peptides could be seen with matrix mixture than with matrixes alone. CHCA produced more chemical noise in the low mass region (500-1500), while DHB had fewer matrix peaks and better S/N but was more prone to sweet-spotting. With the matrix mix, peaks > m/z 1000 generally show a 2- to 3-fold increase in S/N while those lower show an ion suppression. The m/z 1907.9 showed a better resolution with matrix mix and CHCA (9200) than did DHB (5600); below m/z 1500 no clear tendency is seen.

Ten faintly silver stained spots from a 2-D gel of the barley grain proteome were selected, in-gel digested, and 10% of volume of extracted peptides used for MALDI. Sequence coverage was then compared for the dried droplet using CHCA, DHB, and matrix mix. In all cases, the matrix mix was equal to or greater than CHCA or DHB alone. In one high coverage protein, CHCA and DHB are missing peptides found in the other, but all present in the mix. S/N for DHB and mix are generally comparable, while for CHCA it is low. The presence of impurities was also assessed. Peptides from digestion supernatant were loaded directly on MALDI or desalted and concentrated using an R2 GELoader tip nano-column. S/N is better after purification but fewer peaks are seen. The lost signals correspond to small hydrophilic and large hydrophobic peptides, either because they are not retained or not eluted from the column, respectively. However, for faint spots, this purification was necessary to get a protein ID.

The effectiveness of matrix mix on intact proteins was also evaluated. Ribonuclease B was examined using different matrix preps. 50 fmol protein premixed with matrix and applied by dried droplet. 100 laser shots randomly over the surface were accumulated with CHCA/DHB and CHCA. DHB matrix alone formed sweet spots. Ribonuclease B is an Asn-60-linked glycoprotein with the GlcNAc2Man5-9 oligo (the variable mannose units produce up to five different glycosylated forms). All MS spectra revealed the different forms (mass difference of a mannose unit is 162 Da). The better resolution was with matrix mix than pure forms. CHCA provided poorer resolution, while DHB caused adducting with high mass tailing. With test of nonglycosylated proteins (insulin, myoglobin, trypsin, BSA) results were similar, with improved spectra. The improvement effect was more pronounced with ribonuclease B.

More extensive testing with 500 fmol of well-purified recombinant glycoproteins was done. A matrix mix produced more intense spectra than CHCA or DHB alone. It was believed that urea might have been responsible for the ineffectiveness of pure matrices. Thus urea was added to the preparation: while crystals were poorly formed in urea presence, spectra could still be obtained. With 300 fmol of riboB in the presence of 80 mM urea, the three matrices were tried. Only the matrix mix produced well resolved spectral peaks. DHB alone produced signals at 300 fmol, and only a broad peak was found at 600 fmol. Higher amounts of urea (up to 8 M) could be tolerated so long as the protein was increased (to 6 pmol).

Peptides/proteins are modified or fragmented and much depends on matrix conditions. Tryptically digested lactoglobulin has a peptide from A131-R137 with mass 837.06 Da and containing a methionine. Oxidized and non-oxidized forms are seen with m/z 853.48 and 837.49, respectively. The oxidized form fragments: there is a loss of methanesulfenic acid with resulting m/z 789.51 peak because of in-source decay (ISD), and then a broad peak at m/z 796.52 due to post-source decay (PSD). The latter is dependent on MALDI ToF parameters. ISD was more likely with matrix mix than with CHCA, and with DHB was not present. With intact proteins riboB, a narrow peak at m/z 13682 is seen, most likely because glycan is lost by ISD caused by matrix mixture. With CHCA, there is broad peak with loss of glycan.

The sensitivity of the matrix preparations is now evaluated using MALDI-quality standard peptides prepared by a successive dilution of 1 µM stock solution in 5% formic acid. This is a seven peptide mix spanning 1-7 kDa. For targets containing 100-500 fmol, signals for all peptides were observed with matrix mix and DHB. At or below 25 fmol, signals were weak or absent for peptides m/z 3159.4, 5803.6, and 6959.9 for the matrix mix and DHB. With CHCA alone, the signals for these three peptides was not even detected up to the 500 fmol range; the peptide at m/z 1007.4 was also not present with CHCA, and was of low intensity with matrix mix and DHB and undetectable below 50 fmol (ionization is probably suppressed because of the absence of basic amino acids). At the lowest level (6 fmol applied to target), only two of the most intense (m/z 1084.4 and 1281.7) could be seen, and with a very deteriorated signal-to-noise. As for the sensitivity of proteins, sinapinic acid was included because of its preference as a matrix for proteins. 100 fmol protein on the target and all five glycosylated forms are seen in spectra. Similar results are seen with matrix mix and with DHB alone at 50 fmol, and deterioration is seen with CHCA and SA alone. At 25 fmol, only a barely perceptible signal is seen with mix, and no signal with CHCA, DHB, and SA alone.

Glish GL, Vachet RW (2003) Nature Reviews | Drug Discovery 2, 141-150.

The Basics of Mass Spectrometry in The Twenty-First Century

REVIEW. A mass spectrometer does not measure mass directly. Rather is measures the mass-to-charge (m/z) of ions, or a property related to m/z. The spectrum is a plot of the abundance of ions against m/z. An important effect of MS is isotopes: chlorobenzene has a molecular weight of 112.56, but there are no ions of m/z 112.56. The formula weight is determined by the weight average of all isotopes of the atoms present in a molecule. Chlorine has two isotopes: 35Cl makes up 74.5% of one of the isotopes, and 37Cl makes up 24.6%. The ions in chlorobenzene will be seen in the MS as m/z 112.01 or 114.01, and the peak height of the m/z 112.01 ions will be 3 times higher than the m/z 114.01 ions, reflect the 74.5:24.6 or 3:1 ratio of abundance.

An MS instrument must achieve several things. First it can only detect gas phase ions. Thus its source must ionize and then put the ions of interest in the gas phase. Historically this was achieved by attempting to volatilize the sample and then ionize it, usually by beam bombardment (with electrons usually). This limited MS to compounds that were low molecular weight and that could be volatilized. Most biological substances are high MW and have high polarities which limit volatility. However recent work has enabled biological substances of all kinds to be manipulable. Electrospray ionization (ESI) and matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization (MALDI) now permit analysis (and their development led to a share of the 2002 Nobel in Chemistry). ESI has also led to the renaissance of the use of atmospheric pressure chemical ionization (APcI).

With ESI, ion generation is achieved by passing the sample in a solution through a small capillary (< 250 µm i.d.) that is electrically charged to +500 to +4500 V. Voltage settings will be a function of the actual capillary internal diameter and the solvent composition of the sample; capillaries with larger diameters and higher boiling points require higher voltages. In addition a concentric flow of a non-reactive hot gas (typically N2) facilitates the conversion of ions to the gas phase through nebulization. Droplets emerge from the tip of the capillary as flow is started containing the ions, the net charge depending on the polarity of the capillary. Ionization of analytes is typically achieved by either their protonation or deprotonation. With large biomolecules, typically polymers composed of ionizable functional groups with acid/base functionality, multiple ionization is likely. Multiple charging of single molecules actually enhances mass measurment. It allows several peaks of the same molecule to be seen in the spectrum, since there are several ions of different m/z and only z is different. Also, most mass spectrometers are built to resolve to the highest levels peaks in a particular range of m/z (usually 500 to 5000). Several ESI-generated m/z peaks of ions of the same molecule fall within that range, allowing accurate mass measurement. For example, cytochrome c has a molecular mass of 12,360 Da, but if it is ionized with 10-20 protons, the m/z is brought to below 2000, in which most MS instruments measure masses with extremely high accuracy. ESI is also a soft form of ionization, in which there is no destruction or fragmentation of the molecule, nor are multimeric complexes or associations destroyed. Thus protein-protein complexes, ds DNA, protein-drug binding are possible to measure. Indeed tobacco mosaic virus can be mass measured not only intact, but it even retains its viability. MS instruments had to be adapted to ESI since ESI continously generates ions from samples but MS instruments are not constructed to continuously analyze them; MS instruments have a high duty cycle and ESI sources must be pulsed. ESI also is susceptible to ion suppression in which salts in particular can interfere with ion generation into the gas phase; thus the final stage should have ions of interest is solvents with little to no salt and with a high nonionized organic component.

APcI is an option with ESI. APcI works by ionization using a corona discharge enabled by a fine needle. Voltages between −1000 and +5000 V and a corona with a current of 2-5 µA is obtained. Electrons ionize nitrogen, oxygen, and water and solvent molecules around the needle. Molecules in nebulized sample are also ionized in a series of complex reactions as they pass into the discharge region. Both positive and negative ions are formed (usually by protonation or deprotonation). A distinct advantage of APcI is that it is less susceptible to matrix interference from salts, and weakly polar analytes not ionizable by ESI are ionized by APcI. Disadvantages of APcI include thermal decompostion of labile compounds with nebulizing gas that is too hot, and the higher sensitivity of APcI requires exacting solvent purity: ionization is achieved thermodynamically in APcI, and some compounds can cause ion suppression. For example, amines are typically added to improve chromatography, but can compete with protonation of the analyte in APcI.

MALDI is used where samples are generated by pulsed laser irradition. It is most suitable to MS because MS, particularly time-of-flight, requires that ions be generated in a pulse and analyzed in that fashion. Sample is co-crystallized with a matrix that acts as an antenna for the laser light.

[continued]

Wang H, Hanash S (2003) J. Chromatog. B 793, 15-36.

Derivatization of Carbohydrates for Chromatographic, Electrophoretic and Mass Spectrometric Structure Analysis

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Carbohydrates, either alone or as constituents of glycoproteins, proteoglycans and glycolipids, are mediators of several cellular events and (patho)physiological processes. Progress in the glycome project is closely related to the analytical tools used to define carbohydrate structure and correlate structure with function. Chromatography, electrophoresis and mass spectrometry are the indispensable analytical tools of the on-going research. Carbohydrate derivatization is required for most of these analytical procedures. This review article gives an overview of derivatization methods of carbohydrates for their liquid chromatographic and electrophoretic separation, as well as the mass spectrometric characterization. Pre-column and on-capillary derivatization methods are presented with special emphasis on the derivatization of large carbohydrates.

Marvin LF, Roberts MA, Fay LB (2003) Clin. Chim. Acta 337, 11-21.

Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry in Clinical Chemistry

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-Tof-MS) has recently become a popular and versatile method to analyze macromolecules from biological origin. In this paper, we will review the application of MALDI-Tof-MS in clinical chemistry and biology. MALDI-Tof-MS is used in clinical chemistry, e.g. disease markers can be identified with MALDI-MS analysis in combination with 1-D and 2-D gel electrophoresis separations thanks to either peptide mass fingerprinting (PMF) or peptide sequence tag (PST) followed by data base searching. In microbiology, MALDI-Tof-MS is employed to analyze specific peptides or proteins directly desorbed from intact viruses, bacteria and spores. The capability to register biomarker ions in a broad m/z range, which are unique and representative for individual microorganisms, forms the basis of taxonomic identification of bacteria by MALDI-Tof-MS. Moreover, this technique can be applied to study either the resistance of bacteria to antibiotics or the antimicrobial compounds secreted by other bacterial species. More recently, the method was also successfully applied to DNA sequencing (genotyping) as well as screening for mutations. High-throughput genotyping of single-nucleotide polymorphisms has the potential to become a routine method for both laboratory and clinical applications. Moreover, posttranscriptional modifications of RNA can be analyzed by MALDI using nucleotide-specific RNAses combined with further fragmentation by post source decay (PSD).

Righetti PG, Castagna A, Herbert B, Reymond F, Rossier JS (2003) Proteomics 3, 1397-1407.

Prefractionation Techniques in Proteome Analysis

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. The present review deals with a number of prefractionation protocols in preparation for two-dimensional map analysis, both in the fields of chromatography and in the field of electrophoresis. In the first case, Fountoulakis groups has reported just about any chromatographic procedure useful as a prefractionation step, including affinity, ion-exchange, and reversed-phase resins. As a result of the various enrichment steps, several hundred new species, previously undetected in unfractionated samples, could be revealed for the first time. Electrophoretic prefractionation protocols include all those electrokinetic methodologies which are performed in free solution, essentially all relying on isoelectric focusing steps. The devices here reviewed include multichamber apparatus, such as the multicompartment electrolyzer with Immobiline membranes, Off-Gel electrophoresis in a multicup device and the Rotofor, an instrument also based on a multichamber system but exploiting the conventional technique of carrier-ampholytefocusing. Other instruments of interest are the Octopus, a continuous-flow device for isoelectric focusing in a upward flowing liquid curtain, and the Gradiflow,where different pI cuts are obtained by amultistep passage through two compartments buffered at differentpHvalues. It is felt that this panoply of methods could offer a strong step forward in mining below the tip of the iceberg for detecting the unseen proteome.

Molloy MP, Brzezinski EE, Hang J, McDowell MT, VanBogelen RA (2003) Proteomics 3, 1912-1919.

Overcoming technical variation and biological variation in quantitative proteomics

Quantitative proteomics requires the careful determination of technical variation between two test sets. Method comparisons involve pairwise of spot volumes on 2-D gels (two replicates per method) with correlation coefficients (r2) determined. A coefficient of variation (CV) was evaluated for repeat gels to examine reproducibility. Five different sample types (bacteria, cultured cells lines, primary cultured cells) were evaluated. r2 values were between 0.83-0.91, while CV values were between 18.7-26.4%. The technical variation had an average CV of 23% (average CV of replicate 2-D gels for all five sample types). Samples prepared with the IPG format IEF strips did not differ from a tube gel system used.

With the degree of technical variation assessed, biological variation can be evaluated. The between-experimental variation for bacterial proteomes showed a r2 = 0.74, CV = 31.2% and for mammalian cultured cells a r2 = 0.78, CV = 26.0%. Because the cells are essentially clonal, biological variation is expected to be minimal, and these values set a mark for making comparative assessments of biological variation.

Samples of mouse bone marrow cells and macrophages in primary culture, often used in drug toxicity studies, were examined for proteomic variation. Spot volumes from different experiments, representing cultures established from different animal pools, showed low reproducibility as shown by lower r2 and higher CV values (the latter averaging 40-50%). Deviation from the mean CV was also high, about 70%, thus representing the sum of the average CV and the average SD.

Human serum proteins were quantitated based on clinical drug test. The drug showed good preclinical efficacy, no Phase I toxicity, and it required a good serum biomarker to assist monitoring pharmacodynamic drug activity. A serum baseline was taken from 4 same-sex patients and then at 24 and 48 h post-treatment. 30 spots from 2-D gels were found to have changed greater than 2-fold in any of the patients, but 3 of the 30 (spots 14, 15, 16) were 2-fold changed in all patients at both 24 and 72 hours. These proteins were repressed in 6 of 8 samples and induced in the remaining two.

2-D gels represent the most robust high-throughput method in quantitative proteomics. Replicate gels show an r2 of ~0.85. The average CV for spot volumes in replicate gels is 18-27, consistent with previous reports.

Vollmer M, Nägele E, Hörth P (2003) J. Biomolec. Tech. 14, 128-135.

Differential Proteome Analysis: Two-Dimensional Nano-LC/MS of E. coli Proteome Grown on Different Carbon Sources

ABSTRACT. Different sugars provided to bacteria as single sources of carbon and energy require the induction of different metabolic enzymes, transporters, and uptake systems in order to support growth and cell survival. Using a nanohigh-performance liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry (nano- HPLC/MS) system we constructed comprehensive peptide maps for Escherichia coli grown with either lactose or glucose in minimal medium. Digested bacterial samples were separated in a two-dimensional manner by combining strong cation exchange (SCX) and reversed-phased (RP) chromatography. Peptides were eluted online to an iontrap MS instrument and further analyzed by tandem MS fragmentation. Bacterial proteins originating from the differing samples were analyzed by searching the Swiss Prot Database. Data are presented that show the ability to detect several hundred different proteins significantly expressed under both conditions. Several enzymes and binding proteins related to the lactose metabolism were only identified in the sample grown with this carbon source.

Patterson SD, Aebersold R (2003) Nat. Genet. Suppl. 33, 311-323

Proteomics: The First Decade and Beyond

REVIEW. Discovery science aim at assaying function and control of biological system based on less well-defined technologies. Proteomics at one point thought to identify all proteins in a cell or tissue, but currently serves more useful purposes including sequencing, quantifying, assessing modification states, interactions with other proteins, biological activity, subcellular distribution, and structure.

Forward genetics refers to the standard process of using protein chemistry as an expression of phenotype to get at the genes that were responsible for the phenotype. A glossary of terms is included that are useful in understanding proteomics, including 2DE, discovery science, DNA microarrays, ESI, ICAT, ion source, ionization, MALDI, mass analyzer, mass spectrometry, MS spectra, MS/MS (or CID) spectra, protein identification, and yeast two-hybrid.

ESTs represent large-scale efforts to sequence partially the cDNAs of cells and tissues. These and genomic libraries provide information about possible proteins. Then mass spectrometry of peptides and proteins provide mass information useful in identification of proteins, reported in 5 different pubs in 1993. MALDI-ToF has a greater ease of use and is the method of choice. ESI was used mostly with triple quad and ion trap systems.

Better algorithms can now match MS/MS spectra to sequence databases, and are especially suitable for partial sequence databases such as ESTs.

Gel proteomics is not as promising as thought. 2DE is technically complex and labor-intensive. The resolution of gels is not what was once thought, with MALDI-MS and ESI-MS/MS revealing a great many spots with comigrating proteins. This is especially so when protein sets are unfractionated and using conventional staining which is relatively selective in illumination as well as insensitive to low-abundance proteins.

With the demonstration of LC-MS/MS to show parts of the proteome not shown by gel-based methods, a gel-independent approach was realized. Hunt and coworkers uses immunoprecipitation to isolate peptide-MHC complexes and then subjected antigenic peptides to LC-MS/MS. They also used a cytotoxic T cell (Tc) bioassay to verify antigenic peptides in each fraction, correlating functional data with the mass spectrometric data. The use of LC-MS/MS is called shotgun proteomics and can catalog hundreds, even thousands, of peptides. Proteins identified by this process include subcellular fractions, including periplasmic space of bacteria, yeast ribosomal complexes, murine nuclear interchromatin granule clusters (nuclear speckles), murine mitochondrial soluble intermembrane proteins, and human urinary proteins, and many more. A limitation of this method is the ability to get MS/MS (CID) spectra for all peptides in a sample, of which tens of thousands can be generated in a single experiment. One protein digested by trypsin can generated 30-50 peptides (theoretically), and so a digest of the entire proteome generates hundreds of thousands of these.

Complexity reduction approaches are therefore considered. Typically the simplest is fractionation—selection of the sub-proteomic set. One method might be to target proteins with reactive cysteine sulfhydryls, or residues modified with phosphate (phosphoproteins) or carbohydrate (glycoproteins). Multidimensional chromatography has also helped reduce complexity with use of cation-exchange and capillary RP columns interfaced to ESI.

One problem with mass spectrometer is the difficulty of quantitating differences in expression. A problem is that the mass spectrometer will detect peptides with different signal intensities based on chemical composition, and signal intensity is also a function of the matrix and other variables not really understood. The intensity of a peptide signal is not quantitatively associated, and certainly there is no reasonable expection of a linear response. One means of making MS quantitative however is to use isotope dilution techniques. Isotope-coded affinity tags (ICAT) was the first approach tried. The ICAT reagent is composed of iodoacetamide group to allow reaction with the protein (by cysteine thiols), a polyether linker containing either eight 1H or 2H atoms, and a biotin affinity tag. The tags are labeled d0-ICAT or d8-ICAT, depending on whether they contain hydrogen or deuterium, respectively. Reagent is added to protein from the reference (control/untreated) set, and the other reagent is added to protein from the study (treated) set. These ICAT-labeled samples are now combined. This is possibly followed by enrichment, then digestion with protease. An avidin column is used to recover the labeled tags now bound to peptides, and the peptides analyzed by LC-MS/MS.
