The ratio of the abundance d0- to d8- peptides is the ratio of the relative abundance of proteins, and thus serves to quantitate differences. Identification is done by MS/MS spectra. Other methods include solid-phase isotope tag transfer, 16O and 18O incorporation from water containing enriched isotopes during trypsin digestion (which incorporates the isotopes into the carboxyl terminus), and stable-isotope metabolic protein labeling.

Systems biology takes the approach that as much data that can be obtained globally as possible should be done. Identification of interesting components or processes is then done by mathematical tools such as cluster analysis or singular value decomposition.

Another area of activity in proteomics is actually the evaluation of activity, biological activity. Activity-based reagents react with only the biologically active forms of protein. The tags are either fluorophores or biotinylated probes in cases where MS is not used, but isotope-tagged versions are being developed.

(Micro)array-based profiling is also being done for proteins as it is done for transcripts. Ordered arrays of specific protein-binding modules are being prepared, with modules including phage library-selected scFv antibodies, minibodies, cyclic peptides, atpamers, antibodies, etc. Problems with array-based profiling include the need to maintain the native (binding) state during imprinting (not a problem with cDNA), and to keep sensitivity since amplification of proteins is not possible unlike with DNA-based microarrays.

Lehner I, Niehof M, Borlak J (2003) Electrophoresis 24, 1795-1808

An Optimized Method for The Isolation and Identification of Membrane Proteins

Three methods were used to extract membrane proteins from A549 cultured cells. Each method was done three times. The sequential method was that of Molloy et al (1998 Electrophoresis). Thawed frozen cells are extracted in Tris (vortex 10 min, 40 interval sonications), then centrifuged at room temp for 10 min max speed in microfuge, and then the pellet is extracted in urea/thiourea/CHAPS/SB3-10/DTT/ampholytes with the same vortex and sonications, and centrifuged such that the supernatant is the membrane fraction. With detergent-based extraction, the cells are lysed in buffer with digitonin (10 mM PIPES pH 6.8, 0.015% digitonin, 0.3 M sucrose, 0.1 M NaCl, 3 mM MgCl2, 5 mM EDTA, 10 µl/ml Pefabloc SC, 10 µl/ml aprotinin). The supernatant is recovered as cytosolic extract after low speed spin (480 g, 5 min, 4°). Pellet is suspended in Triton buffer (10 mM PIPES pH 7.4, 0.5% v/v TX-100, sucrose, NaCl, MgCl2, EDTA, Pefabloc SC and aprotinin as before), shaken for 30 min at 4° then spun 5000 g 10 min 4 °. The supernatant is recovered as lyophilized. All fractions are stored at −80°. In a centrifugal extraction method, cells are suspended in 150 mM KCl (3 ml per gram cells) and homogenized in glass homogenizer (20 strokes). These are centrifuged in Optima LE-80K with Ti70 rotor at 15,000 rpm for 30 min (4°), equiv. to 11,000 g (the pellet is DNA-rich). The supernatant is recovered and spun 55,000 rpm (170,000 g) for 60 min (4°). The pellet is then resuspended in 2D loading buffer (5 M urea, 2 M thiourea, 2% CHAPS, 2% SB3-10, 40 mM Tris, 100 mM DTT, 0.5% 3-10 ampholytes). In a Whole-Cell extraction method, cells are thawed and given the 2-D loading buffer, vortexed 5 min vigorously at 4°, sonicated 20 times, and then microfuged 10 min at RT before storing frozen. For an SDS-based total protein extraction, cells are suspended in a lysis buffer (only Tris and SDS) and then boiled for 10 min. This is then followed by sonication on the cooled sample, spinning on microfuge 10 min and then collecting the supernatant. A small aliquot is taken for protein assay, and then sample buffer is added, boiled 3 min, then stored frozen. Protein assays consisted of the Bradford and BCA assays using microtiter plate format.

Results show that the best total yield was a detergent-based method (32.3 µg protein/million cells), followed by the sequential method with 16.2 µg protein/million cells, then centrifugal method at 9.0 µg protein/million cells. Another method (sucrose/percoll) produced yields too low to be seriously considered (0.17 µg/million cells).

A marker for testing membrane protein extraction was E-cadherin (120 kDa) for which anti-E-cadherin is available for Western blotting (1D). It was detectable in the SDS, sequential, detergent, and centrifugal extractions in the membrane fractions, and not detectable in the cytosolic fractions of the sequential and centrifugal, but present in the detergent-based cytosolic fraction. The sequential and detergent-based fractions did better at enriching E-cadherin compared to total protein. The centrifugal and sequential fractionation clearly put the protein in the membrane fraction.

IEF was done on 7 cm IPG 3-10 strips ranging from 8000, 20,000, and 35,000 Vh. The best time was 20,000 Vh based on analysis of the membrane fraction of the sequential method. Medium-range gels (pH 4-7, 5-8, 7-10) along with pH 3-10 were run on the same sample. In the pH 3-5 region there were few if any spots in all gels. The pH 5-8 region was very crowded. Streaking was evident at the gel edges, and half of the pH 7-10 gel showed nearly nothing but streaking.

A comparison was made of 2-D gels run with 17 cm pH 3-10 strips using different samples (whole cell extracts, cytosolic and membrane fractions) in which the sequential extract was used for the latter two. The whole cell extracts should contain both cytosolic and membrane fractions ideally and the 2-D gel images did show where proteins segregated according to their selective solubility. In a comparison of the extraction method, the sequential, detergent, and centifugal extractions all gave distinctive 2-D gels, and so it appears that not all proteins are obtained by one strict method.

Clearly the size of the gel mattered as well. Using narrower range pH IEF strips and larger strips (gel formats) always produces greater spots, as much as twice the amount.

Le Bihan T, Duewel HS, Figeys D (2003) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 14, 719-727.

On-Line Strong Cation Exchange µ-HPLC-ESI-MS/MS for Protein Identificatioin and Process Optimization

Sensitivity for discovery of low level proteins is a problem with gel-based proteomics methods. Membrane proteins are usually not detected by 2-D gel systems. Concentration levels among proteins can differ by as much as 105, with total number of protein species in the thousands.

New strategies including targeting specific classes of proteins, use of affinity purification, and multidimensional fractionation are being reported. Subsequent to enrichment, (usually trypic) proteolysis followed by separation of peptides and identification by MS is used. MudPIT is a strategy used that couples online SCX chromatography to RP columns; it is also done offline. Little optimization of the first dimension SCX is done because of time.

The system used here is Picotip capillary column (75 µm i.d./360 µm o.d. × 7 cm, with 15 µm tip opening, New Objective, Inc.) fitted with a precolumn (200 µm × 3 cm fused silica tubing, Polymicro Technologies), with frit created in precolumn according to Zhang & Huang. Connectors or fittings were from Upchurch or Valco. SCX buld resin was polysulfoethyl aspartamide (5 µm, 300 Å pore, PolyLC, Inc.) were conditioned with 0.2 M NaH2PO4, 0.3 sodium acetate (see Western Analytical web site for method). Zorbax SB-C18 (5 µm) bulk came from Agilent Technologies. Conditioned resin is suspended then in 1 M ammonium formate, 0.25 M formic acid and then slurry-packed in column and pre-column using home-built pressure vessel (pressure vessel connected to Perkin-Elmer series 200 Micropump), delivering 0.1% (v/v) formic acid with max press 400 bar. For the RP packing, slurry was in chloroform and the pump delivered acetonitrile.

A gradient elution for SCX was 0.25 M formic acid to 0.25 M formic acid + 1.0 M ammonium formate was designed for direct delivery to ESI-MS. The precolumn is 200 µm i.d. × 360 µm o.d. × 3 cm. The column is 75 µm i.d. × 360 µm o.d. × 5 cm with 15 µm tip opening. A 3-tee connects the HPLC pump to the pre-column, and the perpendicular goes to one port of a 6-port valve. A 4-tee (cross) connects to the other end of the pre-column straight through to the column; the other connections are to another port of the 6-port valve and straight through to a platinum wire. The other ports of the 6-port valve are connected to (1) waste, (2) a loop to two of the ports, and (3) a line to waste but one which features a restrictor capillary which is 20 µm i.d. × 360 µm × 15 cm fused silica. In the load position, sample comes through the restrictor line through the loop and into the pre-column via the 3-tee. In the inject position, flow through the loop goes out to waste from the 4-tee. (If port 1 is at the top, connect port 1 and 4 to the loop, port 2 to the line from the 4-tee, port 3 to waste, port 5 to the restrictor line that goes to waste, and port 6 to the line going to the 3-tee.)

Performance of the system was tested on a BSA tryptic digest. 950 fmol was injected on to the SCX precolumn + cap column setup. The gradient program was a wash for the first 4 min, then a 10 min increase to 0.2 M (amm formate), then a 3 min increase to 0.6 M, then 1 min to 1.0 M, which remained there for 4 min before a 1 min decrease back to zero salt. The total program was 30 min. This represented an optimized gradient with 30 peptides separated and identified for 41% sequence coverage. ESI was stable at 1.0 M amm formate. A MS/MS spectrum was done of the eluate. Retention time reproducibility between times 16-22.5 min was 2-10 seconds, peak to peak. Peak width at half height was 10-15 seconds for all peaks evaluated by MS.

Because tryptic digests are usually done in ammonium bicarbonate and this is incompatible with SCX without dilution. Samples were brought to 0.25 M formic acid after trypsin digestion containing various levels of Amm Bicarb. At 50 mM Amm Bicarb, sample loss and broadening was significant, and was noticeable at 25 mM as well. Better recovery was seen at 5-10 mM Amm Bicarb. Peak broadening in generally is seen in samples eluting early in the gradient, and is even not really observed with late eluters (even with 50 mM Amm Bicarb in the load).

Step-gradient elution from the SCX to RP columns makes it easier to optimize the ion-exchange elution profile. With 50 mM ammon. formate in 250 mM FA, only 6 major components are seen, but when ammon. formate is increased to 100 or 150 mM ammon. formate, 9-10 distinct components appear. Early eluting peptides elute no matter what the concentration of NH4OOCH. No peptide binds to the column indefinitely; if the duration is sufficiently long, the peptide elutes. Stronger interacting peptides will show peak broadening at lower concentration steps.

Tryptic peptides of BSA and phosphorylase b were examined by SCX-MS and the calculated pI plotted against retention time using the Bjellqvist algorithm. With peptides having pI < 6, an increasing pI was seen in an increasing retention time. Little or no dependency is seen with peptides > 6. No trend was observed between peptide time on RP vs. SCX column.

The limit of detection was determined to be the lowest amount of protein that can analyzed and identified from a database search. Different amounts of phosphylase b were loaded and the search results plotted against the mass loaded. A relationship was clear between score and load, and a relationship between score and number of peptides as well. As little as 17 fmol was sufficient to identify phosphorylase b.

Online SCX-MS/MS and RP-MS/MS were compared with respect to complex sample profiling. Human K562 cells were cultured in DMEM + 10% FBS until 100 million cells were grown; cells were spun (410 g) and washed in PBS twice. TRIzol was used on a cell pellet, and the final protein pellet solubilized in 1% SDS (1 ml). The BioRad DC protein assay was used to assess protein. 200 µl (about 1 mg) of solublized protein was diluted in 500 µl water and 75 µl of 1 g/ml TCA, and sample left at −20° for 5 min. Precipitate was pelleted 20,000 g for 10 min at 4°. Pellet was resuspended in 0.5 mM HCl, 50:50 acetone:MeOH (300 µl) and after 5 min spun 15,000 g 10 min at 4°. 200 µl cold acetone was added to the pellet and sample kept at −20° for 10-20 min. This was again spun 20,000 g 10 min at 4°. Thus the pellet was washed several times and dried on a centrifugal evaporator. Samples were digested with trypsin: pellet was suspended in 0.1 M ammonium bicarbonate containing 4 mM DTT and incubated 55° for 30 min, followed by alkylation with 12 mM iodoacetamide 60 min at 37° in the dark. Sample is then digested overnight at 37° using a trypsin:substrate 1:50 (w/w). About 2 µg of cell protein (the amount in 22,000 cells) was submitted to SCX-MS/MS and RP-MS/MS and the top 25 scoring proteins identified. Both SCX and RP identified the some of the same top 10 proteins, but in different order, and there were unique peptides. The dnaK-type chaperone ranked 5 on RP-MS but was not in the top 25 of SCX-MS as an example, and polypeptidyl-tRNA translocase and cyclophilin A were 9 and 10 on SCX-MS but not in top 25 of RP-MS. Few peptides per protein were obtained with SCX as opposed to RP.

Both SCX- and RP-MS tend to favor identification of peptides depending on their average molecular weight. A plot of relative distribution percent against the peptide length of peptides analyzed show an asymmetric distribution for both modes. The peak maximum falls in the range 8-12 residues for RP-MS, and 14-18 residues for SCX-MS. A plot of integrated (cumulative) distribution percent against peptide length allows one to find the peptide lengths at the 50% point, an averge: for RP-MS, it is about 13 residues, and for SCX-MS, about 15.4 residues. The higher the mass of the peptide, the more like SCX-MS is to identify it, but more importantly, how RP- and SCX-MS make complementary coverage.

Müller WEG, Müller IM in W.E.G. Müller, ed., Marine Molecular Biotechnology, Progress in Molecular and Subcellular Biology series, (Berlin: Springer-Verlag), 2003, pp 1-33.

Analysis of the Sponge [Porifera] Gene Repertoire: Implications for the Evolution of the Metazoan Body Plan

All metazoan phyla likely originate from a hypothetical common ancestor, the Urmetazoa. Gene analysis and cytological data now disprove the posited view that the Choanoflagellida are the closest to Urmetazoa. Some gene fine structure analyses of protein kinase C, hsp70 and others suggest Metazoa have a common ancestry with Fungi. Analysis of coding regions in sponges (primarily the marine Suberites domuncula and Geodia cyodonium) show an unexpected similarity to humans and more divergence from C. elegans and D. melanogaster. Additional divergence from protostomians is found in molecules of the immune system and the related apoptotic pathway. The genome of S. domuncula is being mapped in toto and can be tracked. Fungi and Urmetazoa diverged probably after establishment of signal transduction and adhesion molecules (galectins). The Urmetazoa benefitted from development of cell-cell/matrix adhesion molecules, immune molecules, and neuronal receptors and morphogens. The Porifera then emerged (Hexactinellida, Demospongiae, and later the Calcarea. Prior to the emergence of the Radiata, a nerve system, germ-somatic cell lines, and homeotic genes emerged. From these the Cnidaria and Ctenophora diverged from Radiata. With the development of a dorso-ventral axis, the Urbilateria then emerged, diverging into the Protostomia and Deuterostomia body plans.

Sponges are sedentary filter-feeders with well-constructed and complex network of water-conducting canals and choanocyte chambers. The chambers are lined with flagellated choanocytes. The entire system clears a water mass equal to the volume in the sponge every 5 seconds. Two cell layers envelope a ground substance, the pinacoderm on the external sponge surface, and the choanoderm (also called endopinacoderm) on the internal lining. The ground substance is the mesohyl. Analysis of the protein complement of sponges has indicated how they have a body plan. Proteins critical to cell-cell/matrix connections are found: integrin, collagen, FN3, SRCR- and SCR-domain- containing proteins. Signal transduction tyrosine kinases are present. Immune-related proteins: cytokines, variable Ig-like molecules, (2-5)A synthetase.

Sponge classification is not quite resolved. Demospongiae and Calcarea are cellular sponges, and Hexactinellida is a synctial group. Another is based on the fact that Demospongiae and Hexactinella are siliceous while the Calcarea are removed from this clade and linked to Cnidaria. Coding region gene analysis however suggests that the Calcarea are likely more related to other nonsponge metazoans. Thus Porifera are paraphyletic with Calcarea forming a clade with other Metazoa. Homeobox genes are indicators of anterior/posterior axis although no morphological evidence indicates such an axis; related genes appear to be transcription factors with a general function, and are also present in fungi and plants.

A mineral skeleton is created by the secretion of spicules from sclerocytes. In the Demospongiae, silica is crystallized around an organic nucleating filamentous element, but no such filament is the basis of nucleation in Calcarea. Demospongiae also form their spicules intracellularly, while Calcarea use a cluster of sclerocytes to form the spicule extracellularly. Demonspongiae and Hexactinellida are alone in using silica to form a skeleton, as the rest of the animal kingdom uses calcium. Calcium in seawater is orders of magnitude higher in concentration than silicon (10 mM vs. 5-20 µM). Demospongiae also have high amounts of polyphosphate (10 µg/g wet weight), which chelates calcium and prevents its precipitation. Demospongiae also harbor symbiotic bacteria and Calcarea do not, possibly indicating that polyphosphate is of bacterial origin

The many studies of Microciona prolifera and G. cydonium have been useful in studying cell-cell and cell-matrix adhesion. A special aggregation factor (AF) was isolated from these sponges. In M prolifera this had a relative molecular mass of 20 million daltons! AF mediates cell-cell aggregation and is calcium-dependent. Later the first cell-cell adhesion (galectin) was cloned as was a cell-matrix adhension integrin.

AF is composed of a proteoglycan core. Protein MAFp3 has been cloned as one member of the core. It is likely entrapped in a polysaccharide cover. The gene encoding MAFp3 is quite polymorphic. An 86 kDa polypeptide is thought to be associated with the core (peripherally) and its C-terminal has a significant hydrophobic stretch (residues 786-806 for a 807 aa long polypeptide); on the N-terminus are nine short consensus repeats (SCR), each separated by 4-aa long spacers (the spacers also have an interesting combination: NRVQ, QIVA, VRNQ, EIVM, IRNQ, EIVL, NRVQ, QAVE). Generally well conserved in the SCR are four Cys, two Gly, one Trp, one Phe, and two Pro residues, something typical in the mammalian complement-control protein family.

Antibodies to AF have been found to eliminate its aggregating function, and these antibodies were used to find a 1.7 kb cDNA whose N-terminus coding region has high similarity to amphiphysin/BIN1 of both Proto- and Deuterostomia, but which lacks a characteristic SH3 domain in the C-terminus. A 47 kDa protein is predicted, and a 36 kDa protein recombinant was expressed in E. coli. This protein competes for binding with the core, and is also associated with galectin. It is predicted to connect the AF core to galectin.

Galectin is a carbohydrate-binding protein that links the AF core, probably through a 36 kDa associated polypeptide, to AR, the aggregation receptor. It has three isoforms, from soluble to membrane-associated.

The aggregation factor receptor, AR, is a membrane-associated protein that links the cells of the pinacoderm to the AF complex. The protein is composed of 14 scavenger receptor cysteine-rich (SRCR) domains, 6 short consensus repeats (SCR), a transmembrane region in the C-terminus, and a C-tail that is intracytoplasmic. Several experiments have shown that AR binds to AF complex and that it is strengthened by galectin.

Cell Adhesion Matrix. The mesohyl is not really a homogeneous ground substance but is composed of galectin, collagen, fibronectin-like molecules, and minor component recently identified as dermatopontin. Collagen is present only in metazoa. At least 20 different types of collagen can be found in the higher metazoa, but only two types are in sponges: fibrillar and type IV-related collagen. EM studies show sponge collagen is made of 20-25 nm thin fibrils which have a regular banding pattern and period length of 60 nm that are three periods long; intraperiod bands dissect the period. Molecular analysis of both marine and freshwater sponges shows typical G-x-y triplets forming internally and terminally helixed strands. One species shares a feature with type IV collagen found in basement membranes, one associated with integrins.

Long ago sponge have a protein that cross-reacts with antibody to firbronectin. One cDNA from G. cydonium codes for an RGD domain, and another has a cDNA for the α-subunit of integrin. Three of the sponge's proteins cross-react with human anti-fibronectin antiserum.

Integrins are membrane proteins composed of αβ heterodimers. 16 different α and 8 different β subunits have been identified that yield more than 20 types of heterodimeric receptors. When integrins bind, they activate intracellular signalling pathways (kinases, SH2 and SH3 signaling and phospholipid mediators). With collagen in the ECM of sponge, cDNAs were found that encode α subunit of integrin. These subunits show presence of 7-8 repeating domains and putative divalent cation binding sites. The greatest sequence similarity is with D. melanogaster and C. elegans from invertebrates, and mouse integrin αV, chick integrin αVIII, and human fibronectin receptor α subunit.

A β integrin 878 aa long and 95,215 Da has three Cys-rich domain signatures. Also an EGF-like domain Cys-pattern signature, transmembrane segment, and Ca2+-binding site. Cytoplasmic domains interact with the cytoskeleton. 35% sequence identity and 55% sequence similarity with other β integrins in higher metazoa complete the description. Sponge integrins trigger signal transduction pathways. AF-mediated cell-cell adhesion is blocked by RGDS peptide, which interacts with β integrin. RGDS and AF stimulated DNA synthesis as well. RGDS or AF addition to isolated cells of S. domuncula induces increases in intracellular Ca+ within 1-2 min. There is also an activation of GTP-binding protein Ras. Prolonged incubation of the cells with RGDS and AF also upregulates Ras and calmodulin. Integrin is thus an adhesion molecule and signal mediator.

Proliferation is associated with differentiation in higher metazoans. Moreover, ageing and senesence is associated with reduction in telomerase activity.

Wei YQ, Feng R, Yi ZS, Liu QF (2003) Di Yi Jun Yi Da Xue Xue Bao 23, 1161-1164.

Establishment of two-dimensional gel electrophoresis profiles of proteome from CD34+ hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells

Abstract. Article in Chinese. OBJECTIVE: To investigate the differential expression of proteins in bone marrow (BM) and mobilized peripheral blood (MPB) CD34+ cells. METHODS: Immunomagnetic beads were used to separate and purify CD34+ cells from the BM and the MPB mononuclear cells (MNCs) mobilized by granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) of normal subjects. The whole cell proteins in CD34+ cells were extracted by freeze-thaw lysis, and applied for two-dimensional electrophoresis (2-DE), the results analyzed with image analysis software. RESULTS: The average purity of CD34+ cells was 92.33% ± 2.65% in output, with an average cell number of (1.12 ± 0.42) × 106. 2-DE techniques were optimized, which yielded satisfactory 2-DE profiles of the proteome, showing the different expressions of the proteins between different CD34+ cells. CONCLUSIONS: Immunomagnetic beads in combination with 2-DE is applicable for research of hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells proteome. There are differences in the protein expressions between BM- and MPB-derived CD34+ cells.

Shaw MM, Riederer BM (2003) Proteomics 3, 1408-1417.

Sample Preparation for Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis

REVIEW. Sample prep in 2DGE depends largely on the aim of the separation. If soluble aggregates are to be separated under IEF, the prep method should be nondenaturing, nonreducing. Thylakoid membrane proteins have been prepared in nonionic detergents (Triton X-100 and N-dodecyl-β-D-maltoside); these disrupt lipid-lipid and lipid-protein as opposed to protein-protein interactions. In most cases however, sample prep is denaturing and reducing to achieve the solubilization of the most proteins.

Urea disrupts hydrogen bonds and should be present between 5 and as high as 9.8 M. Urea breaks down by hydrolyzing to cyanate and ammonia. Left overnight, a 10 M urea solution at room temperature will produce 20 mM cyanate ion. Cyanate can also react with primary amine to form urea monosubsitutes (carbamylation); these amine groups are normally positively charged on proteins, but are lost and can affect IEF results. Reaction can also occur under slightly acidic conditions (at pH 6) with sulfhydryl groups to form substituted thioureas. Spermine is a cyanate scavenger that can be added during strip rehydration.

Thiorea was first used in 1996 in membrane solubilization. At pH 8.5-9 the sulfur on thiourea becomes as reactive as the cysteine sulfhydryl. This happens to be the pH of the 2nd dimension equilibration buffer (pH 8.8). Thus thiourea will scavenge iodoacetamide and result in poor alkylation. It has been recommended that reductive alkylation be done prior to IEF. DTT itself is a scavenger of cyanate, and alkylation will prevent carbamylation of the protein primary amines. Thiourea is used at 2 M along with urea at 5-7 M; Musante et al. report that protein resolution is seriously affected with high thiourea, so they limited it to 0.5 M. One problem with protein resolution may be that thiourea inhibits SDS-protein binding or that the lipid content is too high, which also reduces 2-D resolution.

The use of SDS in IEF appears illogical since it imparts a negative charge to proteins. However, SDS will not interfere with IEF if used together with an excess of nonionic or zwitterionic detegents such as NP-40, Triton X-100, CHAPS. SDS will form micelles with NP-40 and migrate to the anode; an NP-40:SDS ratio of 8:1 is necessary to avoid streaking. Moreover if SDS is used, it should be < 0.25%. Other problems with using SDS is that its electrophoretic removal during focusing might result in in-gel protein precipitation.

Nonionic detergents are used in nondenaturing IEF, such as Tween 80, NP-40, Triton X-100. These are used at 0.4-4%, but 10% NP-40 has been used. As for zwitterionics, CHAPS has proven the most effective, but SB3-10 and ASB-14 are useful as well. Compatibility of detergents with high urea concentrations is a factor. SB3-10 is compatible with only low concentrations of urea.

Reducing agents. 2-mercaptoethanol is little used because of its tendency to ionize at the alkaline end of the IEF gel, causing it to electrophorese to the cathode and to disturb carrier ampholytes in the region, resulting in streaking. This also happens with DTT, DTE, and TCEP (tris[2-carboxyethyl]phosphine). Often disulfide-rich prtoteins, incuding and especially keratins, form spurious spots in the alkaline region. Use of TBP apparently overcomes the problem.

Carrier ampholytes. Carrier ampholyte use appears to inhibit interactions between hydrophobic proteins and immobilines, often occurring at the basic end of the gel and leading the streaking. They also help to scavenge cyanates and to precipitate nucleic acids. Used at 0.5-2%, although 2% is recommended if proteins solubilize poorly.

Protease inhibitors. Denaturants will inhibit proteases but even in 1 mg/ml SDS, cathepsin C, several carboxypeptidases and endoproteinases, chymotrypsin, trypsin, plasmin, and proteinase K are among the examples. Inclusion of protease inhibitors is recommended (see table)

Protease Inhibitors and Their Targets
InhibitorTargetRecommended Concentration
APMSF Plasma serine proteases 10-20 µM
Aprotinin Serine proteases 0.01-0.3 µM
Bestatin Aminopeptidases 40 µg/ml
Dichloroisocoumarin Serine proteases 1-43 µg/ml
Disodium EDTA Metalloproteases 100 µM
E-64 Thiol proteases 1.4-2.8 µM
Leupeptin Serine and thiol proteases 1 µM
Pepstatin Acidic proteases 1 µM
PMSF Serine proteases 100-1000 µM
Phosphoramidon Thermolysin
Collagenase
Metalloendoproteinases		7-569 µM
TLCK-HCl Trypsin
Thiol proteases 		37-50 µg/ml
TPCK Chymotrypsin
Thiol proteases 		70-100 µg/ml

Sample Prefractionation. Prefractionation can be done not just chemically, but anatomically (careful dissection of tissues) or cellularly (such as cell sorting). The problem with such manipulations is that they may induce stress signalling pathways that alter the natural protein profile.

Subcellular fractionation from homogeneous cell types or from tissue are useful. Centrfiugation has been used to achieve physically based separations. Other techniques include the resistance of subcellular structures to extraction buffer components, such as actin and intermediate filaments and nuclei to nonionic detergents; and of the resistance of intermediate filament proteins, vimentin, and nuclear proteins to the weakly ionic detergent sodium deoxycholate (actin is susceptible to solubilization).

Removal of high abundance proteins (albumin in serum, fibrinogen in plasma) may be necessary in prefractionation. Also reduction of salts may be necessary. Dialysis, gel filtration, TCA precipitation or centrifugal ultrafiltration (Centricon). Excess lipid, particularly in lipid-rich tissues such as adipose and brain tissue, can be removed by acetone precipitation. Polysaccharides can obstruct gel pores; typically ultracentrifugation can remove the higher MW polysaccharides. Lower MW polysaccharides can be removed by TCA, ammonium sulfate, or phenol/ammonium acetate precipitation. As for polynucleotides they can be removed by nucleases, addition of carrier ampholytes followed by ultracentrifugation, or by a basic polyamine at high pH.

Preparative IEF systems such as Bio-Rad's Rotofor, Amersham Bioscience's Isoprime, and Gradipore's Gradiflow are useful for high capacity applications. The Rotofor rotates during its work but the isoelectric zones are not stable nor are proteins well-resolved. The Isoprime system is a multicompartment system with each compartment separated by gel membrane and possessing special immobilines at a certain pH; fractions are high quality, but the sample usually already partially purified for large scale applications, and does not work well with crude extracts. A smaller scale version of solution IEF is by Zou and Speicher, and a microscale solution or nusol IEF technique has been developed.

Elusive Proteins. Proteins may fail to enter the IEF gel because of several factors. Size may be the most significant. Spectrins are large filamentous proteins (280 kDa) which do not appear on the 2-D map unless active sample rehydration is done. Some proteins lose solubility and fail to enter the gel. The use of thiourea has made it possible to solubilize many proteins, particularly polymeric ones like tubulin and fibronectin.

Detergents also improve solubilization. CHAPS-containing solutions with urea and thiourea are effective at solubilizing high MW integral membrane protein than are SB3-10-containing solutions. The urea has to be reduced to 5 M when SB3-10 is included because of its incompatibility. Molloy et al. have used detergent combinations of 2% CHAPS, 2% SB3-10 with 1% ASB14. ASB14 with 7 M urea and 2 M thiourea produces larger spots on 2-D gels, indicating a greater extraction; this may have been due to the greater urea concentration. A buffer containing 2/7 thiourea/urea + 4% CHAPS, and one containing all those + NDSB256 (Calbiochem) yielded many more spots in one study involving 2-D maps. The alkylaryl aminosulfobetaine C80 failed to extract a number of membrane-associated proteins, although it was effective at extracting the water channel and H+-ATPase complexes in plant cell membranes. Washing with sodium carbonate at pH 11 removes peripheral membrane proteins.

Organic solvents can be used to extract proteins as well. E coli was lyophilized and then extracted in 1:1 (v/v) chloroform:methanol. The extract was evaporated and resuspended in ASB14 solubilizing buffer, and new hydrophobic proteins were observed. A lipid smear was present on 2-D gels and highly hydrophobic proteins could not be resolved. Without the solvent, these proteins were resolved.

Prelabeling of proteins. The first attempts to label proteins involved radiolabeling followed by autoradiography. Fluorescent dyes have now replaced radiolabels. The first was monobromobimane and 2-methoxy-2,4-diphenyl-3(2H)-furanone (MDPF). MPDF reacts with primary amines and can alter charge/pI, so cannot be used prior to IEF. Monobromobimane reacts with free sulfhydryls, which makes it better for IEF; a problem however is that not all proteins have cysteines and many proteins are variable in number, so it can not be used to quantitate proteins. PerkinElmer UK is currently developing Superbright as an alternative to monobromobimane, and Amersham Biosciences has produced a series of Cy dyes that bind to sulfhydryl groups

Burkitt WI, Derrick PJ, Lafitte D, Bronstein I (2003) Biochem. Soc. Trans. 31, 985-989.

Protein-Ligand and Protein-Protein Interactions Studied by Electrospray Ionization and Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. Electrospray ionization has made possible the transference of non-covalently bound complexes from solution phase to high vacuum. In the process, a complex acquires a net charge and becomes amenable to measurement by MS. FTICR (Fourier-transform ion cyclotron resonance) MS allows these ions to be measured with sufficiently high resolution for the isotopomers of complexes of small proteins to be resolved from each other (true for complexes up to about 100 kDa for the most powerful FTICR instruments), which is of crucial significance in the interpretation of spectra. Results are presented for members of the S100 family of proteins, demonstrating how non-covalently bound complexes can be distinguished unambiguously from covalently bound species. Consideration relevant both to determination of binding constants in solution from the gas-phase results and to the elucidation of protein folding and unfolding in solution are discussed. The caveats inherent to the basic approach of using electrospray and MS to characterize protein complexes are weighed and evaluated.

Standing KG (2003) Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 13, 595-601.

Peptide and Protein De Novo Sequencing by Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. Although the advent of large-scale genomic sequencing has greatly simplified the task of determining the primary structures of peptides and proteins, the genomic sequences of many organisms are still unknown. Even for those that are known, modifications such as post-translational events may prevent the identification of all or part of the protein sequence. Thus, complete characterization of the protein primary structure often requires determination of the protein sequence by mass spectrometry with minimal assistance from genomic data de novo protein sequencing. This task has been facilitated by technical developments during the past few years: soft ionization techniques, new forms of chemical modification (derivatization), new types of mass spectrometer and improved software.

Lill J (2003) Mass Spec. Rev. 22, 182-194.

Proteomic Tools for Quantitation by Mass Spectrometry

REVIEW. Protein identification and characterization are the initial steps in a proteomic strategy, but quantitation also becomes important. Ion current intensities do not always correlate. For one thing, not all peptides ionize equally, and so within a proteome, one protein cannot be said to be expressed relative to another protein. Moreover some differences are subtle or slight, sufficient to produce a biological effect, but not subject to analytical distinction if mass spectral intensities are the only data available.

Quantitation of protein expression has been done using Westerns, autoradiography of metabolically labeled samples, fluorography, and protein stains in gels. In addition to 2-D gel/MS, activity-based profiling helps in at least the detection activities.

Relative Quantitation. The relative abundance of proteins is of concern for drug discovery. Comparison of diseased and control cells or tissues is involved. 2DGE works well in this regard. Samples are loaded with equal amounts of protein that allow relative comparisons between proteomes and not just within them. 2DGE is relatively reproducible. Quantitatively the best stains provide differences of expression that are 3 orders of magnitude; low abundance proteins are undetectable. Other disadvantages are that protein spots may not be homogeneous, or some proteins are distributed in several bands. From run to run, and protein to protein there may be variable staining intensity. Post-translational modifications can often be the cause of streaking of spots.

Metabolic Labeling. Media containing 15N can be used in a treatment sample while normal media be used in the untreated control. This can compare treatments, or treated vs. untreated. The two sets are equalized either by cell number or cell weight, and then pooled. Sample pooling ensures than any processing that causes losses occurs equally, so relative expression information is not lost. 13C is another isotope for which different incorporation media can be used. Stocklin et al. have used a technique where one sample is grown in 99.98% 12C (13C-depleted); an internal standard is monitored as well. The two labeled peptides show a non-natural isotopic distribution in the MALDI-TOF. Several amino acids are available that have stable heavy isotopes. Generally for a total proteome analysis, the most abundant amino acid should be selected as the label since it will create significant mass difference between the compared proteomes. A specific amino acid might be chosen if a peptide of interest is targeted and a specific amino acid is present. SILAC (Stable Isotope Labeling by Amino Acids in Cell Culture) is basically the use of heavy stable isotopes for labeling, and use of these amino acids does not alter cell metabolism. Ong et al. have reported that 5 cell doublings are sufficient to completely (97% or 31/32) of molecules. The use of isotopic incorporation of 15N or amino acids is fairly simple to do. If collision-activated dissociation is done, the fragmentation is not distinct between 15N and 14N.

Chemical Labeling. Metabolic labeling is only possible with cell cultures.

Andersen H, Jensen ON, Moiseeva EP, Eriksen EF (2003) J. Bone Miner. Res. 18, 195-203.

A Proteome Study of Secreted Prostatic Factors Affecting Osteoblastic Activity: Galectin-1 Is Involved in Differentiation of Human Bone Marrow Stromal Cells

PC3 cells are a human prostate cancer cell line that can be grown in MEM with 10% FBS. Human bone marrow stromal cells were isolated by Lymphoprep and plated at 106/ml in MEM + 10% FBS. PC3-conditioned medium (48 h in MEM with 0.1% BSA in cells 80% confluent) was pooled, centrifuged to remove debris, and then precipitated with 25% (v/v) TCA on ice 30 min. Precipitated protein was centrifuged and the pellet washed with ice-cold 96% EtOH (to remove TCA) and then resuspended in 1 ml of 9 M urea, 2% (v/v) Triton X-100, 0.13 M DTT, 8 mM PMSF, traces of bromophenol blue, and 2% (v/v) immobilines pH 3-10. Samples are stored at −80° until analysis by 2D-PAGE.

First-dimensional IEF was using pH 3-10 linear immobiline strips: these are rehydrated 15-20 h at room temp in 0.4 ml protein sample, and then focusing done with 500 V for 3 h, 3500 V for 5 h, followed by 3500 for 20 h in a gradient mode (at 22°). Focused strips are rinsed twice 15 min each in 10 ml 0.1% Tris HCl, pH 6.8, 5.5 M urea, 0.3% glycerol, 35 mM SDS, and 65 mM DTT (in the 2nd rinse, DTT is replaced by 14 mM iodoacetamide and traces of bromophenol blue). These are transferred to ExcelGel XL SDS 12-14% gradient gels and electrophoresis done at 15° using the Excel SDS Buffer Strips for horizontal electrphoresis with maximum 1000 V (20 mA) for 45 min. The strips are removed and electrophoresis resumed for 2 h. Proteins are illuminiated by silver staining: fix in 45% MeOH + 5% acetic acid 30 min, then double distilled water overnight; sensitize with 0.02% sodium thiosulfate 2 min, incubate in 0.1% silver nitrate 30 min, develop with 0.04% formalin and 2% sodium carbonate 10 min; stop with 1% acetic acid.

Spots ranging from 5-30 kDa, 30 in all, were excised, destained with acetonitrile, then 100 mM ammonium bicarbonate, then dried. Pieces were re-swelled in 30 µl 100 mM amm. bicarb. with 10 mM DTT for 45 min at 56° (reduction), then 55 mM iodoacetamide in 100 mM amm. bicarb. for 30 min (alkylation), then washed 1:1 MeCN:100 mM amm. bicarb. 80 µl MeCN was added to shrink gel pieces before vacuum drying. Digestion of proteins with 15.5 ng/µl trypsin in 50 mM amm. bicarb. overnight at 37°. Peptide extraction was by 25 µl 5% formic acid (5FA) 10 min and 25 µl MeCN for another 10 min; this procedure was done twice and extracts pooled, dried under vacuum, and then resuspended in 20 µl 5FA. GelLoader tips were given a slurry of 100-200 µl Poros 50R2 resin in 1:1 5% formic acid:MeCN to make microcolumns, which were washed in MeCN followed by 5FA. 3 µl of peptide was mixed with 15 µl 5FA, followed by washing with 15 µl 5FA. CHCA matrix in MeCN was then used to elute the columns directly on to MALDI targets. A Bruker-Reflex MALDI-ToF was used to get spectra (200 laser shots with internal calibration of autolytic tryptic fragments at m/z 842.51 and 2211.10. The database search tool MASCOT and ProFound software were used for identification of peptides (see http://www.jbmr-online.com/fulltext/01802/01950/www.matrixscience.com and http://www.jbmr-online.com/fulltext/01802/01950/www.proteomics.com).

Three 2-D gels were analyzed independently to ensure reproducibility of the profiles. MALDI-ToF spectra were searched for all 30 spots excised. Spot #3 was identified as galectin-1, and #26 as cyclophilin A. Spots #1, 2, 4, 9, 13, 19, 20, 21, and 22 were identified as fragments of the BSA that had been in the culture medium. The remaining spots were not identified largely because of interference from the BSA and largely because the protein amounts were too low to be analyzable.

A human cDNA library was screened to obtained the full size of galectin-1. A Pfu polymerase was used in the PCR with primers featuring 5' NcoI and 3' BglII sites was used in the amplification. The amplified product was inserted into the NcoI-BglII site of pQE60 (Qiagen). A recombinant with modified COOH-terminus was obtained (ArgSerHis6 at the tail). E. coli was transformed with the plasmid and expression controlled by IPTG induction (2-3 h). The protein is purified with a HisTrap (AmershamPharmacia); in PBS it is refined on PD10 columns, concentrated on Centriprep-3, and frozen to prevent multimeric formation. Galectin-1 is a 14 kDa protein and found in many mammals. It will bind to matrix proteins laminin and fibronectin in a β-galactoside-dependent way in ELISA. The recombinant galectin-1 forms dimers similar to the native form.

10 and 1000 ng/ml alone or in combination with IGF-I (10 ng/ml) was used to treat hBMS cells (IGF-I is used because high plasma levels of this hormone are associated with increased risk of developing malignant prostate cancer). Proliferation of hBMS cells increased 3-fold in in PC3 cell-conditioned medium as shown by [3]H-thymidine. But recombinant galectin-1 alone or in combination with IGF-I had no effect on proliferation; in contrast, proliferation was inhibited by up to 70% compared to control cells with 1000 ng/ml alone, although this was blocked by the presence of IGF-I. When 100 mM lactose was added to the PC3-conditioned medium, proliferation was increased but to only 2.6-fold, not significantly different from untreated medium.

The conditioned medium and recombinant galectin-1 were then used in differentiation assays of hBMS cells. ALP activity is increased 1.7-fold in hBMS cells with CM, and increased 1.3-fold in medium with 10 and 1000 ng/ml recominbant galectin-1. These increases were inhibited by IGF-I up to 101 and 91%, resp. IGF-I alone increases ALP by 1.3-fold. When cells are treated with CM containing 0.1 M lactose, hBMS ALP activity goes up 1.6-fold, the same as for CM from untreated cells.

Osteocalcin secretion is reduced 81% by conditioned medium. Recombinant galectin-1 at 10 and 1000 ng/ml reduces secretion by 93% and 58%, resp. In contrast IGF-I alone increases osteocalcin up to 130%, and the combination with recomb. galectin-1 produces cells with 1.2-fold increase in secretion at 10 ng/ml, but a reduced secretion at 82% of control at 1000 ng/ml. Lactose in conditioned medum gave a secretion of 94% of control, effectively only slightly different. Other results show that the presence of lactose in medium prevents the adhesion of PC3 cells to laminin, fibronectin, and collagen type I.

Galectin-1 can modulate differentiation in a large number of cells, and has been shown to be involved in fibroblast-to-myocyte differentiation. Galectin-1 had a counteracting effect with IGF-I in the hBMS cells: IGF-I is known to induce tyrosine phosphorylation cascade leading to transcriptional activation. Galectin-1 binds to CD45 in Jurkat T cells and Burkitt lymphoma B cells; CD45 is a receptor-type protein tyrosine phosphatase, and galectin-1 binding inhibits the activity.

Galectin-1 stimulated ALP and inhibited osteocalcin secretion, consistent with its possible role in promoting mineralization around metastatic tissue. ALP produces hydroxyapatite while osteocalcin delays its nucleation and may be a chemoattractant for osteoclasts.

Westbrook J, Feng Z, Chen L, Yang H, Berman HM (2003) Nucl. Acids Res. 31, 489-491.

The Protein Data Bank and Structural Genomics

PDB (http://www.pdb.org/) has grown from an archive of 3D structural data having 7 files in 1971 to one with 18,800 in late 2002. Earlier work with target databases (http://www.genome3d.org/) has led to a centralized target registration database (TargetDB, http://targetdb.pdb.org/). Targets are loaded into a relational database with sequences from experimentally determined structures. All or subsets of sequences can be searched with FASTA sequence method. A simple search permits queries of target data including the contributing site, protein name, sequence, project tracking, last mod date. Search results are reported in HTML, FASTA file, or XML docs.

The International Task Force on Deposition, Archiving and Curation of Primary Information recommends all depositions in structural genomics include information normally found in Materials and Methods sections of any article reporting structure determination.

Millea K, Chakraborty AB, Wall DB, Cohen SA, Krull IS, Berger SJ Presented at ASMS, Montréal, Canada, 8th-12th June 2003

A Multidimensional LC/ESI-TOF MS Prefractionation Approach for The Analysis of Intact Proteins in Complex Proteomes

A Waters 2796 sample handling and pump system was configured to a 4.6 x 35 mm nonporous sulfopropyl column. A 1525µ binary pump was used to pump a gradient to RP columns (2.1 × 50 mm) Symmetry300 C4. A four-solvent AutoBlend system was set up to allow control of both pH and ionic strength. Solvent A was 0.1 M acetic acid, B was 0.1 M sodium acetate, C is 1.25 M NaCl in 12.5% MeCN, and solvent D is 12.5% MeCN. A and B are used to control pH and C and D used to control ionic strength. The first dimension program loads the SCX column and then elutes with salt steps at a constant pH 4. At the end the pH is raised to remove proteins not affected by salt but ionically held. The 2796 is fitted with a pH and conductivity meter to monitor changes. The period for each step is the sum of the salt divert time and the time for a gradient in the 2nd dimension of the step. At the end we have several plots: one a TIC of ions in the MS, another of the salt steps for the SCX colum, another for each RP gradient of the 2ndD, another of the pH change of the 1stD, another two of the valve changes for the 2ndD column select and of the salt diversion.

12 mg of E. coli cytosol was acidified with 20% acetic acid which precipitates nucleic acids and other debris, removed by centrifugation. The supernatant is usally richer in smaller polypeptides. This supernatant was then run on 2DLC with the SCX and RP column. Spectra were acquired at 2 seconds per scan over a m/z 500-3000 range. Fractions from the post-valve split were collected at ~3 min intervals.

Craig R, Beavis RC (2003) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 17, 2310-2316.

A Method for Reducing the Time Required to Match Protein Sequences with Tandem Mass Spectra

ABSTRACT. An algorithm for reducing the time necessary to match a large set of peptide tandem mass spectra with a list of protein sequences is described. This algorithm breaks the process into multiple steps. A rapid survey step identifies all protein sequences that are reasonable candidates for a match with a set of tandem mass spectra. These candidates are then used as models, which are refined by detailed analysis of the set of tandem mass spectra for evidence of incomplete enzymatic hydrolysis, non-specific hydrolysis and chemical modifications of amino acid residues resulting from either post-translational modifications or sample handling. Compared with current one-step methods for matching proteins to mass spectra, this multiple-step method can decrease the time required for the calculation by several orders of magnitude.

Suckau D, Resemann A, Schuerenberg M, Hufnagel P, Franzen J, Holle A (2003) Anal. Bioanal. Chem. 376, 952-965.

A novel MALDI LIFT-TOF/TOF mass spectrometer for proteomics

REVIEW. It is estimated that the number of expressed proteins is > 100,000 which by far exceeds number of estimated genes (ca. 30,000). Thus systems to determine sequence and expression level of mRNA and proteins are being sought. There is also a poor correlation between protein and mRNA levels, so quantitating mRNA is no clue about quantitating protein. Posttranslational modifications also mean that intensive study of the proteins themselves is necessary.

Most widely adopted strategy is 2D-gel electrophoresis combined with MS. Spots in gels are usually digested in situ (typically with trypsin), and peptides eluted/extracted and prepared on a MALDI plate because of its high throughput and good sensitivity in femtomole (sometimes subfemtomole) range. Peptide mass fingerprint (PMF) used to screen protein sequence database. Predicted masses of peptides from proteins in the database are matched to the actual masses obtained from the PMF. A scoring is done. Success of identification depends on the following variables:

  • database size and its intrinsic error rate
  • count of matching peptides and their predicted masses
  • accuracy of the peptide masses provided by MS
  • control of the digest chemistry

The best results come with a bigger count of peptides and a good MS calibration. Poorer results are seen if mass tolerance is increased and there is more chemical heterogeneity. More problems arise when:

  • proteolysis is incomplete
  • there are non-specific cleavages
  • side chains are modified that affect the mass (e.g. oxidation of Met, deamidation, acrylamidation of Cys)

When PMF data are insufficient, MS/MS fragment ion analysis will improve the chance of success. Problems with PMF alone can occur when:

  • There are a low number of digest peptides in the standard mass range of 800-3500 Da, probably because the protein itself is of low MW (< 15 kDa). When cleavage sites are not distributed to give good spectra, this is also a problem. Also suppression of peptides is seen in the matrix/contaminant range. Low amounts of protein and high levels of detergents and other preparation materials can lead to poor PMF spectra.
  • The EST or genomic databases being screened have high error rates, usually ≥0.3%, which for a protein of 400 amino acids can mean as much as 2 amino acids in error at 0.3%, or 4 amino acids at 1% error rates. Any sequence error can cause frame shifts as well. Moreover, peptides whose coding spans the splice between two exons are usually not matched.
  • Protein idents based on mass spectra representing a set of proteolytic petides from several proteins cannot be based only on PMFs. These include 1-D chromatography or multidimensional chromatography of complex protein mixtures. Sample complexity is too hight to be certain that peptides correspond to proteins. Isotope-coded affinity tags (ICAT) and diagonal chromatography are being used to make identification possible.

MALDI-MS/MS tends to generate poor fragment ions compared to ESI. Ions with z=1 are more common in MALDI whereas ESI generates z≥2 ions. Sequence-specific fragments are more easily generated from multiply protonated ions. Hot MALDI matrices are used in post-source decay (PSD) for metastable fragmentation of MALDI generated ions. It has sensitivity to the mid-attomole range and can characterize modifications such as phosphorylations.

MALDI-TOF/TOF are colinear arrangements of two TOF mass analyzers, each with ion source accelerating and focusing ions. TOF1 accelerates and precursors are selected and fragmented, and fragments move to source of TOF2 to be accelerated and mass analyzed. Two MS/MS modes are available: LID (laser-induced dissocation of metastable ions) for protein ident and CID (collision-induced dissocation) for de novo sequencing, and for resolving Leu/Ile ambiguity.

The MALDI LIFT TOF/TOF (Ultraflex TOF/TOF from Bruker) is a gridless MALDI source with delayed extraction electronics, high-resolution timed ion selector, lift to raise potential energy of ions, stage for focusing velocity and a post-acceleration (source 2), a post lift metastable suppressor (PLMS), gridless space-angle and energy focusing reflector, fast ion detector for linear and reflector mode.

Ion source takes target plates same size and shape of microtiter plates. Anchor chip plates of 384 and 1536 hydrophilic anchors enhance sensitivity 10-fold. Image recognition does plate positioning, and target to target movement time is 300 ms.

In MS mode source voltage can be up to 15 kV in linear, reflector, negative and positive. A gated MCP used in linear mode; gating prevents saturation from low-mass ions and neutrals. In reflector mode a fast dual MCP used with microchannels having 5 µm diameter and 12° bias angle (better subnanosecond pulse widths for single ions). Optimized for symmetrical peaks and minimal ringing, better for finding exact mass using software algorithms such as SNAP.

Pulse voltage modulation of delayed extraction permits best resolution over the 500-4000 Da range. At lower mass range resolution limited by detection system adding constant signal width to ion signal. By increasing laser fluence to provide larger count of precursor ions per shot, high fragment ion yields are increased. A low initial accelerating voltage of 8 kV permits longer flight times for fragmentation to occur. Note that fragments formed after acceleration have same velocity as precursor.

Wu CC, MacCoss MJ, Howell KE, Yates 3rd JR (2003) Nat. Biotechnol. 21, 532-538.

A Method for the Comprehensive Proteomic Analysis of Membrane Proteins

The objective of proteomics is a systematic identification of all proteins expressed in a cell or tissue, including posttranslational modifications. This includes membrane proteins. Integral membrane proteins are usually extracted apart from soluble proteins using alkaline pH conditions; electron micrographs show that high pH prevents resealing of membrane structures after mechanical agitation which favors presence of membrane sheets with free edges. To solubilize the membrane proteins, detergents, organic solvents, and organic acids can be used with loss of native structure. If instead protease are used to cleave extramembrane segments, native structure is preserved.

Rat brain was obtained from halothane-killed animals and regions separated (cortex, cerebellum, striatum/hypothalamus, hippocampus). These were homogenized in 10 volumes of ice-cold 100 mM potassium phosphate, pH 6.7 containing 5 mM MgCl2, 0.25 M sucrose with 30 strokes of tight Dounce homogenizer. A 15 min, 4° spin at 3000 g was done, and supernatant adjusted to 1 mg/ml with buffer (protein assay by Lowry H Protein from Bio-Rad). Golgi fraction were also prepared from livers of cycloheximide-treated rats (see Taylor et al., Mol. Biol. Cell 8: 1911, 1997). Homogenates with 500 µg protein were diluted with equal vol. of 0.1 M potassium phosphate pH 6.7 and spun 18000 g for 30 min at 4°. The pellet is resuspended to 1 mg/ml in 200 mM sodium carbonate pH 11 by five passes through an insulin syringe; it is left on ice for an hour. Urea is then added to 8 M, and then reduced and alkylated. 5 µg proteinase K is added and sample incubated 3 h at 37° in Thermomixer (Brinkmann). Another 5 µg proteinase K is added and incubated 37° for 90 min. The reaction is quenched with formic acid (to 5%) and microfuged at 18,000 g for 4° 15 min. Golgi membranes were worked up according the method described by Washburn et al.

MudPIT. Digests are pressure-loaded on to a 5 cm of a 250 µm id with 2 µm filtered union (Upchurch) and containing 5 µm Polaris C18-A (Metachem), serving as a desalting column. The loaded column is washed with 5% MeCN + 0.1% formic acid, and proteins eluted into the rear of a triphasic 100 µm id capillary with 5 µm pulled tip and packed from the tip as follows: 7 cm of 5 µm Aqua C18 (Phenomenex); 3 cm of 5 µm Partisphere SCX (Whatman), and 3 cm 5 µm hydrophilic interaction chromatography material (PolyLC). The column is then brought into line with quaternary system and eluted over 12 steps. Solvent A is 5% MeCN + 0.1% FA, solvent B is 80% MeCN + 0.1% FA, solvent C is 500 mM ammonium acetate + 5% MeCN + 0.1% FA. The program was:

  1. 100 min from 0 to 100% solvent B
  2. 3 min of solvent A at 100%
  3. 2 min each of 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50 and 60% solvent C
  4. 10 min of a gradient from 0-15% solvent B
  5. 97 min gradient from 15-45% solvent B
  6. For the final step the gradient contained 3 min of 100% solvent A, 20 min 100% solvent C, a 10 min gradient from 0-15% solvent B, and 107 min gradient from 15-70% solvent B.

Elution is directly to electrospray into a ThermoFinnigan LCQ-Deca MS with a 2400 V spray voltage. The mass range is m/z 400-1400 with three data-dependent MS/MS spectra at 35% normalized collision energy was done continuously.

1610 proteins were identified with >95% confidence with a two-peptide minimum. 28.2% of these (454 proteins) had predicted transmembrane domains (TMD) using the analyzer TMHMM 2.0. Many had only 1 TMD, but most known proteins have 2-23 TMD (54% of proteins). Reports on genome analysis predict that 20-30% of all ORFs encode integral membrane proteins. This range agrees with the 28.2% of proteins with TMDs.

The nonspecific protease approach is related to redundant sequence coverage. Most proteins had <20% sequence coverage. 79 modifications on 51 proteins (24 assigned to 18 membrane proteins) were identified. These included 22 phosphorylations (16 predicted by NetPhos 2.0), 14 monomethylations, 39 dimethylations, and 4 trimethylations or acetylations. Assignments were made based on mass shifts seen in MS/MS.

Membrane proteins (STX2, AQP4, GRID2, ATP2b2) and soluble proteins (NVP2, VSNL1, CALM1) were particularly selected to examine the effectiveness of proteomic analysis. STX2 (syntaxin 2) is a SNARE protein with central role in exocytosis of synaptic vesicles. It contains 1 TMD at the COOH end. Its sequence coverage was 54.2%. Three peptides show phosphorylation of Ser14 with 99.7% confidence. Tandem MS of nontryptic +2 phosphopeptide KDSDDEEEVVHVD (S is modified) shows a loss of [M-98]2+ from the precursor. Fragment ions of the b- and y-ion series are identifiable completely.

AQP4 (aquaporin 4) is the predominant water channel in brain expressed only on the basolateral surface of epithelial cells. It has 6 predicted TMDs. Coverage was 26.3%, and localized redundant coverage was 45.7% on COOH soluble domain. Five peptides overlap into the C-terminal-most predicted TMD (thus the domain is exposed and may not be embedded). Ser180 and Ser276 are thought to control the mechanism of action and cell surface localization when phosphorylated., but were not detected by this work because coverage was missing. Ser285 was not previously reported to be phosphorylated, but three peptides identified its modification with 98% confidence. The tandem MS of the +2 peptide DNRSQVETEDLILKPGVV showing a base peak that has a loss of -H2PO4.

Protease protection experiments help determine sidedness as long as membrane compartments remain sealed. Complete digestion with the high pH-proteinase K method was done in 3 steps. The protease is added at neutral pH first. Intact membrane structures are re-isolated in the 2nd step. In the 3rd, high pH-protease unseals membranes and digests luminal domains. Golgi membrane proteins are most usefully analyzed by protease protection.

SIAT1 (sialyltransferase 1) is a resident Golgi type II membrane protein involved in terminal sialylation of N-linked carbohydrate groups of glycoproteins and glycolipids. Identification was made with 47% coverage. With the use of high pH-protease all peptides over the COOH domain were found. A +2 HLNEGTDEDIY*LFGK peptide identifed Tyr388 phosphorylation with 90% confidence. Fragment ions b10, b11, and y5 identified the localized phosphorylated group. The majority of SIAT1 protein is located on the luminal side and so were protected against digestion from protease before high pH treatment.

Wright ME, Eng J, Sherman J, Hockenbery DM, Nelson PS, Galitski T, Aebersold R (2003) Genome Biol. 5, R4.

Identification of Androgen-Coregulated Protein Networks From The Microsomes of Human Prostate Cancer Cells

LNCaP cells are a continuous human prostate cancer cell line which were treated with 10 nM R1881 androgen (methyltrienolone) for 72 hours. Control (AS) and treated (AD) cells after growth in RPMI 1640 with 10% charcoal-treated FBS. Microsomes were prepared and treated with 5 mM TBP for 3 h, then with ICAT reagent for 3 h and then digested overnight with trypsin at 37°. The peptide digest is resolved on cation-exchange column with fractionation. 53 fractions are then avidin-purified and subjected to µLC-ESI-MS/MS. MS/MS spectra are searched against 73,600 human sequences of the NCBI nrDB. SEQUEST was used in the search. Fixed/static modifications include 503 Da for the Cys-light ICAT coupling and variable modification of +8 Da for the heavy ICAT coupling. SEQUEST output is passed through INTERACT which filters peptide identification as correct: Xcorr > 1.5, Δ correlation scores ≥ 0.1, Sp rank ≤ 8, singly tryptic, and at least one Cys. The list contained 5450 MS/MS spectra. When filtered through PeptideProphet, 93% of entries are ≥ 0.99 probability and 97% of entries had 0.90 or higher. The XPRESS quantification program was used to analyze, validate, correct quantification.

Lysates from the AD and AS 72 h-treated cells (16 µg) were also immunoblotted with 1 µg/ml mouse anti-PSA (Res. Diag Inc. RDI-PSA85abm/RDI-PSA85abm-1), 1:1500 rabbit anti-TMPRSS2, 1:200 rabbit anti-LDLR (all Res. Diag. Inc) and 1 µg/ml mouse anti-MST-3 (BD Transduction lab clone 47), 1 µg/ml mouse anti-FAS (BDTL clone 23), 2 µg/ml anti-β-catenin (BDTL clone 14), 1 µg/ml anti-FasL (BDTL clone 13), and 50 ng/ml mouse anti-Hsp60 (Stressgen clone LK1). All cells were then gorown as usual and labeled with Mitotracker Red CMXRos and Alexa Fluor 488 phalloidin and DAPI. Fluorescent images were obtained and deconvolved. LNCaP cells were also exposed to three growth conditions (androgen-depleted and -treated, as well as normal serum) then incubated with respiratory chain inhibitors for 24 h: 10 µM rotenone, 50 µM carbonyl cyanide m-chlorophenylhydrazone (CCCP), 10 µg/ml antimycin A, 5 µg/ml oligomycin. Controls were treated with EtOH 24 h (vehicle). At time of drug addition, cell densities were 1000/cm2 for the standard cells, and 3000/cm2 for the AS and AD cells, which are equivalent cell densities.

Proteins identified in SWISS-PROT were searched at Incyte Human Proteome Database and assigned to a class of functions. Proteins with a GenBank GenPept accession assignment were also searched.

Kawasaki N, Itoh S, Ohta M, Hayakawa T (2003) Anal. Biochem. 316, 15-22.

Microanalysis of N-Linked Oligosaccharides in A Glycoprotein by Capillary Liquid Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry and Liquid Chromatography/Tandem Mass Spectrometry

A Microchrom BioResources Magic 2002 LC system connected to ThermoFinnigan TSQ 7000 triple quad was set in positive ion mode with m/z 800-2000 equippd with AMR nanonelectrospray ion source. A graphitized carbon column (GCC) of Hypercarb 5µ (200 µm × 150 mm) from ThermoFinnigan was used with mobile phase of 5 mM ammonium acetate pH 9.6 with 2% MeCN. Sugars were reduced and eluted at 2 µl/min in 18-38% gradient 40 min (solvent B contains amm acetate with 80% MeCN). Capillary voltage is 2000 V with metal needle and capillary temperature is 175°. Detector is 1200 V. Argon gas is 2 mTorr. Collision energy is −25 eV and 3 second scans are collected.

EPO oligosaccharides are separated after PNGase F treatment and reduction with borohydride (so anomers are not separated). 50 ng EPO was injected to 200 µm column and 20 µg to 2.1 mm column, and were detectable in the mass chromatogram (> 10:1 S/N).

Recombinant hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) produced in NS0 cells were studied for carbohydrate. Reduced oligosaccharides from 200 ng HGF were run with 11 peaks identified (two major peaks 5 and 9). α-galactosidase treated HGF yield about six peaks, with barely resolved peaks c and d as major. Peak 5 was an m/z 1467 corresponding to [M+2H]2+ ion of [dHex]1[Hex]7[HexNAc]5[NeuGc]2, being a fucosyl triantennary complex-type with additional Hex and two N-glycoylneuraminic acids. Peak 9 was 2+ ion with m/z 1394 consistent with [dHex]1[Hex]8[HexNAc]5[NeuGc]1. Peaks 1-4, 6-8, and 10 and 11 were probably fucosyl bi-, tri-, and tetraantennary types with 0-3 Hex and 0-3 NeuGc. Thus the majority of N-linked glycan types on HGF appear to be triantennary complex-type with NeuGc and additional Hex.

α-Galactosidase will hydrolyze Galα1→3,4,6Gal/Glc bonds as an exoglycosidase. Peak c had m/z 1386 2+ ion, and was deduced to be fucosyl triantennary bearing two NeuGc, possibly produced from FucTri-Gal1NeuGc2 (peak 5) with loss of a Gal. Peak d was a 2+ ion with m/z 1232 and is triantennary with one NeuGc with loss of two Gal from peak 9. Thus α-linked galactosylation on the nonreducing ends of HGF oligosaccharides is likely.

LC-MS/MS was done on peaks 5 and 9. Fragment spectra show clean b ion series at m/z 528 (Hex2HexNAc+), 673 (NeuGc Hex HexNAc+), 690 (Hex3 HexNAc+), 836 (NeuGc Hex2 HexNAc+, 1362 (NeuGc Hex4 HexNAc2+), and 1209 (NeuGc Hex8 HexNAc4 2+).

Four isomers, peaks a to d, were seen at m/z 1467 (2+ ion). Fragmentation was able to distinguish peaks a and c

Osinga R, Belarbi EH, Grima EM, Tramper J, Wijffels RH (2003) J. Biotechnol. 100, 141-146.

Progress Towards A Controlled Culture of The Marine Sponge Pseudosuberites andrewsi in A Bioreactor

P. andrewsi sponge samples were obtained from a Rotterdam zoo, which originated from a single parent. Explants with known volume was tied to nylon fishing line on to a plastic carrier (healthy fragments attach). Special PVC bioreactors (880 ml) were constructed with overflow device and magnetic stirrers and thermostated bath set at 26°. The food source was the marine diatom P. tricorotum; it was cultured in 5 L Erlenmeyers using ~100 µmol m−2 s−1 at 22° for 1 week, and product stored at 4°. Food particle concentration was quite important. Food particle concentration in the water surrounding the sponge can be described as:

[P] = [Pin]φ(φ + FVsp)−1

where [P] represents food particle concentration in the bioreactor, [Pin represents the concencentration of particles in the inflowing stream, φ is the flow through the bioreactor, F is the filtration rate (in cm3 seawater per minute per cm3 sponge volume), and Vsp is volume of all sponge explants in the bioreactor. Explants were added to the reactor such that Vsp = 14.42 cm3 initially. A value F = 3.5 cm3 SW min−1 cm−3 sponge was assumed (this is the known average for P. andrewsi from other work). [P] was to be set at 2 × 105 diatoms cm−3 by varying both φ and [Pin], in this case φ = 0.34 cm3 min−1 and [Pin] = 3 × 107 diatoms cm−3.

All sponges in these experiments grew. Increases in explant weight averaged 255 ± 112%. Sponges fed on live diatoms and crude extracts showed no difference in growth (crude extracts of diatoms were prepared by sonicating the diatoms at 200 W (max power) for 10 min, and then filtering on Whatman GF/F). In about a month, explants fed crude extracts doubled their sizes. In public aquaria, P. andrewsi grow at about 160% in 50 days (n=4, SD=33%), and was surviving on adsorbed organic materials rather than living forms.

There is a question about the filtration activity of sponges relative to their size (volume). To avoid drastic changes, a tight control of [P] is necessary. Dissolved organics are likely taken up the outer surface layer of the sponge body, the exopinacoderm. Attempts to change the food source of the sponge from P. tricornotum to the chlorophycae Nannochloropsis sp. resulted in sponges losing weight rapidly, indicating a difference in the nutritive value of the two microalgal species. A search of the literature to compare the two algae for their composition indicates both produce amino acids and are rich in fatty acids. One component that Nannochloropsis was missing was the polyunsaturated fatty acid docosahexanoic acid (DHA). When DHA is supplemented to 4 mg per liter along with the Nannochloropsis feed, there was no growth in the sponges.

Lopez MF, Pluskal MG (2003) J. Chromatog. B 787, 19-27.

Protein Micro- and Macroarrays: Digitizing the Proteome

REVIEW. Arrays of cDNAs sequences and oligonucleotides are in routine use in large-scale analysis of gene expression and variations in gene sequence. Expression proteomics largely involves serial processing of 2DGE. The high throughput methods useful in nucleic acids are now being used for identifying useful functions in proteins.

Being able to amplify DNA in vitro by PCR is a great asset in an analytical approach. The closest equivalent is specific affinity selection or isolation of defined charge class by IEF from complex mixture. This is the best that can be done now for complexity reduction.

Proteins, like DNA, can also be labeled with fluorescent molecules to improve the sensitivity of detection, or to multiplex detection of several targets for easy interfacing with instrumentation and automation. The finding that MALDI-MS can be used on oligonucleotides to resolve single bases for sequencing shows its potential.

Antibody arrays/Phage Display/Antibody Mimics. Antibodies are relatively manipulable without loss of the ability to bind ligands. A problem is they cannot recognize all protein isoforms or post-translational modifications. Nonetheless one group printed 115 antibody/antigen pairs on derivatized glass slides with a robotic arrayer and could detect half of the arrayed antigens and one-fifth of the arrayed antibodies in complex mixtures at concentrations ranging from 1 to 340 ng/ml. Others have shown similar results, and some companies have formed to develop protein chips based on antibody arrays (Zyomyx, BioSite, Hypromatrix & Diversys). Rather than whole antibody molecules, which have large molecules and often lack specificity, others are using antibody fragments, Ab mimics and phage display.

Phage display creates antibody libraries with genetically modified phages that express the variable fragments of Ig molecules in the capsid surface. Companies such as Dyax, Cambridge Antbiody Technology, and Affitech are using this approach or its modifications. Phage display has problems with specificity as do conventional antibodies. These display libraries are not limited to antibodies and can consist of non-biological antibody mimics and diverse molecules. Aptamer (single-stranded oligonucleotides expressing high affinity for protein molecules) libraries are easily synthesized and less labile than antibodies but are subject to nucleases that might destroy them when present in complex mixtures from body fluids use to screen chips.

Ciphergen Biosystems pioneered a technique called SELDI in which a MALDI target surface is modified with affinity ligands in order to capture proteins. The target is directly inserted into a mass spectrometer for analysis. Another approach uses surface plasmon resonance (SPR) to quantify the target capture.

In other approaches, glass slides are activated with cross-linking agents that react with primary amines used to attach proteins. Protein-protein interactions, enzyme-substrate and protein-ligand reactions using fluorescent probes or radiolabeled ATP. In a single experiment one protein was identified within an array of 10,000 other proteins, which shows the utility of using protein microarrays for large-scale, high-throughput screening. Polyacrylamide gel pads fixed on to glass slides are being used to minimize changes in the 3-D integrity of proteins. Others have developed nanowell technology to assay 117 different yeast kinases with 17 different substrates. A novel Tyr kinase was found as a result. In another study, a library of about 15,000 nonredundant His-tagged protein from human fetal brain cDNA library; the fusion proteins are arrayed onto glass and membrane and then probed with Ig, with successful screening shown despite the likely high amount of denaturation.

Some companies are using microfluidic printing or arrayed chemistries to individual protein spots blotted on membranes. Thus each spot on a 2-D gel blot is a protein chips (a 2-D macroarray). Since the proteins are biologically genuine (from an extract separated by pI and MW), they include posttranslational modifications. Proteins are membranes are stable for indefinite periods of time. Using a piezo-electric chemical printing technique, several chemistries can be applied to a single spot, such as trypsin digesting and PMF, glycosidase digestion, glycopeptide analysis, etc.

[Fig 1 shows proteins in microarray format. α-1 acid glycoprotein (AAG), horseradish peroxidase, IgG, and soybean trypsin inhibitor are arrayed on PVDF adhered to glass slide from a 384-well source plate with range of concentration from 62.5 to 4000 µg/ml in PBS. Spotting was done with V&P Scientific manual glass slide arrayer fixed with four rows of eight pins (32 total), ~500 µm dia. spot size, 1125 µm horizontal pitch and 750 µm vertical pitch (where pitch is the center-to-center spacing of spots). Replicates of 6 are arrayed, with a total of 168 spots.]

Finehout EJ, Lee KH (2003) Electrophoresis 24, 3508-3516.

Comparison of Automated In-Gel Digest Methods for Femtomole Level Samples

ABSTRACT. A comparison of automated in-gel digestion methods for low picomolar to femtomolar levels of protein is presented. Gel spots with 4 pmol to 120 fmol of protein were stained with either Coomassie colloidal blue or SYPRO Ruby and digested using an automated platform. The sequence coverages and average peak intensities obtained from a matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization-mass spectrometry (MALDI-MS) analysis are compared. Results show that methods using an acetonitrile extraction or digest times greater than the standard 4 h give no significant increase in peptide sequence coverage for automated digestion of low protein level samples. It is also shown that digests from SYPRO Ruby-stained gels show a greater improvement upon ZipTip cleanup than digests from Coomassie colloidal blue-stained gels. The digests from SYPRO Ruby-stained gels are also shown to give a higher average peptide intensity if a method with minimal gel plug washing is used.

Raffaelli A, Saba A (2003) Mass Spec. Rev. 22, 318-331.

Atmospheric Pressure Photoionization Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. Atmospheric pressure photoionization (APPI) is the last arrival in the family of atmospheric pressure ionization (API) methods to couple mass spectrometry (MS) to liquid-phase separation techniques. The basic idea was to further extend the fields of application of liquid chromatography (LC)MS to those molecules that are not, or are poorly amenable, to electrospray (ESI) or APCI. The present review explores the literature. After a short introduction with an historical background and the premises for its development, we describe the technique, its physical principles, and the factors that affect its efficiency. The review also presents a survey of applications in different fields.

Rabilloud T (2003) Nat. Biotechnol. 21, 508-510.

Membrane Proteins Ride Shotgun: A New Mass Spectrometry-Based Approach Identifies and Characterizes Membrane Proteins On A Large Scale

NEWS.

Kuyama H, Toda C, Watanabe M, Tanaka K, Nishimura O (2003) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 17, 1493-1496.

An Efficient Chemical Method for Dephosphorylation of Phosphopeptides

Probably 1 in 3 eukaryotic proteins are modified by phosphate at any one time. While there are many enzymatic treatments described, a chemical method that is specific can be preferable and more complete.

The method described takes 100 µg of lyophilized peptide in 50 µl of 50% hydrofluoric acid (HF) or 70% HF in pyridine (Fluorochem Ltd., Derbyshire UK). Peptide is left standing on ice bath or at room temperature, and 7 µl aliquot is taken and dried under vacuum with a CaO and NaOH trap to capture the HF. The dried residue is resuspended in 20 µl water for MALDI-ToF MS.

HF is used in the final cleavage step of peptide synthesis since it removes a wide variety of protecting groups. It is also volatile and easily removed by vacuum. It is corrosive however and toxic to humans, so it must be trapped in alkali. At lower concentrations it is less toxic but is still effective at achieving nucleophilic attack. A 50% HF has been found to remove phosphate esters of saccharides without causing cleavage of the O-glycosidic bond, maintaining oligosaccharide structure.

The model peptides used in these experiments included WAGGDApSGE, Ac-IpYGEF-nh2, and GFETVPEpTG-nh2. Using 50% HF, cleavage of the single phosphates was completed within 3 h on an ice bath as shown with MALDI MS spectra. The first peptide produced an [M+H-80]+ peak (the mass of the removed phosphate ester is 80 Da). The second peptide produces before digestion both [M+Na]+ and [M+K]+ peaks in the Shimadzu AXIMA-CFR (20 kV acceleration in gridless electrode, with satd CHCA matrix in 50% MeCN + 0.05% TFA, mixing of peptide and matrix not on-plate).
