These Na and K adduct peptides are present at 80 Da less. For the third peptide, it is present as a [M+H]+, [M+Na]+, and [M+K]+ ions. With phosphothreonine residues, 3 h on ice bath is insufficient, with part of the starting peptide still present. At 1.5 h at room temperature, the reaction finishes well.

With 70% HF in pyridine, dephosphorylation was complete in 60 min on an ice bath for all three phosphopeptides according to spectra.

Other conditions tried includes 95% TFA for 3 h on ice, with no appearance of spectra peaks at 80 Da less. This shows that acid catalysis alone is not the factor by which cleavage occurs, and that it is related to a specific affinity of fluoride anion for the oxygen-phosphorus bond.

A more complex mixture of peptides was tried. α-casein was digested with trypsin and the resulting peptides treated 3 h on ice bath with 50% HF. The pre-digest MALDI spectra show m/z 1661.21 and 1952.35 corresponding to VPQLEIVPNpSAEER and YKVPQLEIVPNpSAEER, respectively. Post-digest spectra show these two peaks exactly at 80 Da less, with no peaks of the precursors.

Sulfation. For sulfated peptides/proteins, it must be considered that the mass loss of a phosphate versus sulfate ester are nearly identical: sulfate loss is 79.957 while phosphate loss is 79.966, a difference too small to resolve on MS reliably. However, the sulfate ester modification is much more acid labile, and so use of the 95% TFA treatment prior to HF treatment makes it possible to distinguish between modifications.

Zhang H, Li X-J, Martin DB, Aebersold R (2003) Nat. Biotechnol. 21, 660-666.

Identification and Quantification of N-linked Glycoproteins Using Hydrazide Chemistry, Stable Isotope Labeling and Mass Spectrometry

The top-down approach in global protein analysis in proteomics unfortunately typically catches on the most abundant proteins. Because of these limitations, strategies have been employed which focus more on enrichment of proteome subsets, such as isolation/purification of organelles or cellular substructures (ribosome, spliceosome, nuclear pore complex, mitochondria, peroxisomes, etc.), before doing the analysis. Chemical specificity has also been used to enrich proteomes selectively (such as phosphates or thiols on proteins) as they have affinity for particular ligands.

Glycosylated proteins are another chemically specific subproteome. Carbohydrates can be O-linked to Ser or Thr or N-linked to Asn. The usual motif for N-linked glycosylation is -N-X-S/T- where X is any amino acid except Pro. N-linked glycosylation is generally found on proteins with extracellular domains, there the oligosaccharide is likely to be located; it also includes secreted proteins. Many clinical biomarkers and therapeutic proteins are such glycoproteins: Her2/neu for breast cancer, β-human chorionic gonadotropin and α-fetoprotein in germ cell tumors, PSA in prostate cancer, CA125 in ovarian cancer.

A method for quantitative glycoprotein profiling is described. A vicinal (cis)-diol is oxidized by periodate to produce a dialdehyde. An unwanted side reaction might occur if a primary amine and secondary hydroxyl groups are on adjacent carbon atoms (such as the presence of an N-terminal Ser), but this would be rare in proteins. Different oligosaccharides have different reaction conditions (periodate concentration, reaction time). 15 mM sodium periodate for 60 min was used here, intended to assure reaction with all types.

The oxidized glycoprotiens are then passed over a solid support with hydrazide groups (Bio-Rad). The hydrazide forms a hydrazone with the sugar, coupling it to the support, and washing away nonglycosylated proteins. The coupled glycoproteins are then digested with a protease, and nonglycosylated peptides are washed away. The nonglycosylated peptides can be collected for further analysis. ε-amino groups on Lys are then converted to homoarginine. The α-amino groups of the glycosylated coupled peptides are then treated with one of two isotopic forms of succinic anhydride: either a d0 (light) or d4 (heavy) form, the latter with four deuterated atoms (C/D/N Isotopes). The N-linked glycopeptides are then released from the support with PNGase (specific for N-linked glycosylation sites, but those with fucose cores are unreactive, New Eng. Biolabs). Recovered peptides are passed through µLC-ESI MS/MS or offline µLC MALDI MS/MS.

Consider a model analysis with three glycoproteins α-1-antichymotrypsin, α-1-antitrypsin, and α-2-hs-glycoprotein. Four glycosylation sites were identified, although only three had been reported in the literature (one for each glycoprotein). An additional peptide FN#LTETSEAEIHQSFQH represents a glycosylation site in α-1-antichymotrypsin. Abundance ratios calculated from the isotopic ratios agreed with expected values.

For O-linked sugar analysis, there is no enzyme like PNGase F that can release O-linked sugars. It is thus necessary to sequentially remove monosaccharides with a panel of exoglycosidases until only the Galβ1,3GalNAc core is left on Ser/Thr, and then release it with an O-glycosidase. Since not all sugars have this core, it might be necessary to use β-elimination to release the peptide as well.

The human serum proteome was now tested. Oxidized serum proteins were coupled to hydrazide beads. Samples were then analyzed on 9% SDS-PAGE and silver-stained or glycoprotein-stained (Gel Code Blue, Pierce). Control lanes in which proteins are run without incubation with coupling beads show the glycoproteins to be coupled. The post-coupling solution was examined and the bands have disappeared, showing the effectiveness of the method in coupling. Bands appeared which were not coupled but were clearly not glycoproteins.

To compare conventional serum protein analysis with the selective subproteome method, the conventional approach used Cys-labeled ICAT reagents to select proteins. Both products were then subjected to µLC-ESI-MS/MS. ICAT-labeled peptides were also examined a 3-D chromatographic approach (cation exchange, biotin affinity, RPLC) with 17 cation-exchange fractions then analyzed by ESI-MS/MS. A single run of LC-ESI-MS/MS requires 2 h on the mass spectrometer; 145 unique peptides were found corresponding to 57 unique proteins with glycopeptide capture (2.5 peptides/protein). With ICAT, 72 unique peptides corresponding to 23 unique proteins, of which 15 were identifed also by glycopeptide capture. A more extensive separation protocol for ICAT-labeled proteins used 34 h mass spec time, identifying 356 unique peptides mapping to 97 serum proteins. Of 57 proteins identfied by glycopeptide capture, 23 of these were not identified using ICAT approach.

There are 4 major conclusions:

  1. ICAT-labeling approaches can be limited substantially by the presence of some high-abundance proteins (with serum there are five major plasma proteins, making up 80% of the total protein: albumin, α-1-antitrypsin, β-2-macroglobulin, transferrin, and γ-globulins). The MS spent one-third of its acquisition time on CID spectra of albumin (39% of peptides identified by Cys-tagging were from albumin); in contrast glycopeptide capture eliminates albumin, and only 1% of the time was spent identifying it.
  2. Proteins not identified by Cys-tagging were readily identified by glycopeptide capture.
  3. Glycopeptide capture reduces sample complexity and thus background and signal loss of low-abundance proteins. 2.5 peptides per protein were seen.
  4. Presence of N-glycosylation sequence motif in identified peptides is further validation of specific isolation and increased confidence in results.

Not all glycoproteins may be identified. The coupled peptide may be too short or too long for MS/MS analysis and is thus lost. In this case, perhaps alternate digestion schemes (aside from trypsin) might cover those proteins not identified.

Quantitative Analysis. Having established the principle, it now becomes important to assess its potential in reporting quantitative differences. Crude membrane fractions from LNCaP prostate cancer epithelial cell line were subjected to the protocol. 104 unique peptides mapped to 64 unique protein (1.6 peptides/protein), and all peptides featured the -N-X-S/T- motif. Identified proteins were assessed for subcellular location: of the 64, 45 (70%) were true or predicted transmembrane proteins. The nontransmembrane proteins were either secreted (7 proteins, 11%) or lysosomal (9 proteins, 14%); these are compartments known for being rich in glycoproteins. Only 3 (5%) proteins were considered cytoplasmic. These proteins also have high MW or extreme pI and would not likely be seen in a gel approach. For example, heparan sulfate proteoglycan core protein (a basement membrane-specific protein) with mass 470 kDa, and the acidic transmembrane signal sequence receptor α subunit (pI 4.39) were identified.

Methods. Isotopic labeling is done by washing coupled glycopeptides in a high pH (> 11) 15% ammonium hydroxide, then 1 M methylisourea in 15% ammonium hydroxide is added at 100-fold excess over amine groups and incubated 55° for 10 min. Beads are not washed twice in water, and then twice with DMF:pyridine:water at 5:1:4 (v/v/v), and then suspended in DMF:Pyr:water. Succinic anhydride is added to 2 mg/ml, left at RT for 60 min, washed 3 times with DMF, 3 times with water, and 6 times with 0.1 M ammonium bicarbonate. Peptides are released by adding 1 µl PNGase F for every 40 mg protein used and leaving overnight. Released peptides are recovered, dried and resuspended in 0.4% acetic acid for LC-MS/MS. For coupling the glycoproteins to hydrazide resin, the oxidation is first done in 15 mM sodium periodate in pH 5.5 0.15 M NaCl and 0.1 M sodium acetate (1 h, RT), which is washed away after. The oxidized protein is treated to hydrazide beads at 20° for 10-24 h.

Sipkema D, Heilig HGHJ, Akkermans ADL, Osinga R, Tramper J, Wijffels RH (2003) Mar. Biotechnol. 5, 443-449.

Sponge-Cell Culture? A Molecular Identification Method for Sponge Cells

Dysidea avara specimens were obtained from Gulf of Naples, dissociated into single cells and suspended in natural seawater filtered and containing an antibiotic cocktail. Cells were transported and washed in artificial seawater (33 g/l instant ocean reef crystals in demin. water); one fraction set aside for DNA isolation and the balance cultured. Artificial seawater (ASW) enriched in the same antibiotics (kanamycin, tetracycline, gentamycin, tylosin). ASW was replaced twice to ensure that only attached cells were in culture. Cells were then scraped and incubated in 50% DMEM w/ glucose, Gln, kanamycin, tylosin, Tet, gentamycin, but the osmolarity was adjusted to seawater with NaCl. Medium was replaced weekly, cultures maintained at 18°. After 4 weeks cells were harvested for genomic analysis.

The gene for 18S ribosomal RNA was amplified from genomic DNA by PCR using universal primers (see Collins 1998). Products were cloned into E. coli JM109 using Promega pGEM-T vector. Ten transformants were selected. White colonies were transferred using toothpick into 20 µl TE, and cells lysed at 95°/15 min. PCR was then done on lysates with pGEM-T-specific primers T7 and Sp6, confirming insert sizes. Only two of the 10 transformants contained an 1800 bp insert. Transformant #7 was selected for further workup, although #10 was also selected for partial sequencing for confirmation. RFLP analysis using CfoI was done to determine diversity; transformants #7 and #10 had identical patterns. Inserts with unique patterns were purified on spin minipreps (Qiagen) and the DNA sequenced by taking 1 µg pure pGEM-T plasmid and the T7 sequenase sequencing kit (Amersham Life Sci). The complete 18S rDNA was deposited into GenBank and assigned AF456236. BLAST analysis of the complete sequence came up with the highest similarity scores with 18S rRNA genes for the marine sponges Pleraplysilla spinifera and Hippospongia communis (98% and 97%, resp.).

Cells taken through the culture regime were generally pure after a single medium replacement despite doing two replacements. Cells grew in small aggregates loosely attached to petri dishes. Cells had a uniform appearance and a growth rate of 0.13 per day, corresponding to a doubling rate of 5-6 days. Restriction analysis of 18S rDNA of the growing organisms indicated that the proliferating cells were not D. avara, but that of another eukaryote although the similarity was 85%. Search analysis indicated the rDNA had 99.4% similarity to rRNA gene from Candida parapsilosis.

A difficulty of culturing sponge cells is that they seem to be as susceptible to antibiotics specific for yeasts and fungi. Use of 18S rRNA gene for identification is useful for verifying sponge cells.

Stark J, Callard R, Hubank M (2003) Trends Biotechnol. 21, 290-293.

From The Top Down: Towards A Predictive Biology of Signalling Networks

ABSTRACT. True quantitative and predictive biology requires the ability to interpret increasingly complex datasets in new ways to reveal underlying functional interactions. This has come a step closer with two recent articles that describe a top-down modelling approach to reconstructing functional networks from microarray data.

Rappsilber J, Ishihama Y, Mann M (2003) Anal. Chem. 75, 663-670.

Stop and Go Extraction Tips for Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization, Nanoelectrospray, and LC/MS Sample Pretreatment in Proteomics

StageTips are reversed-phase beads placed in Teflon matrix mesh with a small disk having a 60 nL volume; useful in MALDI and nano-ESI work. The disk is punched out with a needle using an Empore Disk C18 (3M). The disk is positioned in the tip, serving as packing material and frit simultaneously. The Teflon minimizes peptide absorption

Chamrad DC, Koerting G, Goborn J, Thiele H, Klose J, Meyer HE, Blueggel M (2003) Anal. Bioanal. Chem. 376, 1014-1022.

Interpretation of Mass Spectrometry Data for High-Throughput Proteomics

Mouse brain extracts were run on 2D gel and illuminated by CBB G250. 1336 spots were automatically cut using the Bruker Daltonics Proteineer and Protagen (Bochum). MALDI-ToF of tryptic peptides was collected in reflectron mode in the Bruker Daltonic Reflex III with Scout 384 ion source. The SNAP algorithm was used to detect peptide signal. Peak lists from spectra, 2DE images and gel spot data were put into ProteinScape database. ProteinScape is a relational database MS data interpretation is done with a module called ScoreBooster.

Prior to PMF identification, MS data are processed by a calibration, peak rejection, triggering of search engines, result evaluation, and then annotation and storage in PorteinScape. Three identification approaches are undertaken: one involves external calibration with no further data processing, with the search engine ProFound being used. Approach 2 involves automatic calibration and peak rejection. Approach 3 involves a meta search strategy making use of the three available PMF search engines: Mascot, ProFound, and MS-Fit.

Many signals in the spectra other than the peptides of the protein of interest, such as autolytic products of cleavage enzyme and the MALDI matrix and the 2D gel stain. Other contaminants include keratin from hair, nails, skin, PEG in hand creams and plastic softeners. The mass of some contaminants if known can be useful in a multipoint calibration. Alternatively the peaks can overlap important peptide signals or generate false matches in database searches.

Calibration constants of MALDI-TOF-MS are affected by instrument parameters, sample position and morphology, desorption laser anergy, and temp variations. Calibration is achieved in three common ways: through external calibrants, internal calibrants, and statistical calibration by the peptide mass distribution rule.

To prevent wrong calibrations and keep track of the rendered calibration, the quality of the calibration was assessed by these formula:

Osinga R (2003) J. Biotechnol. 100, 91-92.

Biotechnological Aspects of Marine Sponges

EDITORIAL. Porifera are the oldest of metazoans. Besides being natural sponges, their secondary metabolites are useful as natural products in medicine and other areas.

New cultivation (farming) techniques are sought. 40 scientists in 2001 attended international meeting dedicated to subject.

Culture Method Advantages Disadvantages
Sea-based aquaculture
  • low cost
  • easy
  • exposure to pathogens of sponges
  • lack of control of adverse growing conditions
Semi-enclosed unfiltered seawater culture
  • control of most growth conditions
  • natural food
  • higher cost
  • continued susceptibility to pathogens
Closed marine systems completely controlled growth ignorance of defined optimal conditions
culture expansion from totipotent cells better control against pathogens little data to date

Multicellular aggregates (primmorphs) are the best starters for culture than infinite cell lines.

Zenzmaier C, Kollroser M, Gesslbauer B, Jandrositz A, Preisegger K-H, Kungl AJ (2003) Biochem. Biophys. Res. Comm. 310, 483-490.

Preliminary 2-D Chromatographic Investigation of The Human Stem Cell Proteome

ABSTRACT. Stem cells represent a promising tool for the treatment of various hematopoietic diseases. In order to identify stem cell-specific proteins, the proteome of human stem cells from umbilical cord blood was explored for the first time. For this purpose, the crude lysate of 4 × 105 CD34+ cells was subjected to in solution trypsin digestion. The resulting peptides were then separated via cation exchange followed by reversed phase chromatography and analyzed by nanospray MS/MS. Database search revealed a total of 215 proteins which could be reliably identified. To obtain a more complete picture of the human stell cell proteome and to also access low abundant proteins, pooling of more than one CD34+ preparations seems necessary in order to increase the cell number and thus the protein content.

Schmitt-Kopplin P, Frommberger M (2003) Electrophoresis 24, 3837-3867.

Capillary Electrophoresis-Mass Spectrometry: 15 Years of Developments and Applications

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Since its introduction in 1987, capillary electrophoresis-mass spectrometry (CE-MS) has developed to a well accepted multidimensional analytical approach complementary and/or competitive to classical MS-hyphenated separation techniques. The threefold combination of rapid developments of an exceptional separation technique, of selective mass detection possibilities, and of very mild ionization modes first allowed these progresses. This article shows the CE specificities that need to be well controlled/ known, compared to classical and more routinely used liquid chromatography in the light of its coupling to MS. The major trends and developments over the last 15 years and most of the reviews and applications found in ISI Web of science and publisher databases are presented in a tabulated way. The reader can thus rapidly find existing CE-MS analysis techniques in his field of research and application (forensics, environment, bioanalytics, pharmaceutics, and metabolites).

Cornwall GA, Hsia N (2003) Molec. Cell. Endocrinol. 200, 1-8.

A New Subgroup of the Family 2 Cystatins

REVIEW. Cystatins are superfamily of reversible competitive inhibitors of C1 cysteine proteases; they inhibit proteases like plant papain and the mammalian cathepsins B, H, and L. The superfamily consists of stefins (family 1), cystatins (family 2) and kininogens (famiy 3). Family 1 cystatins have a size of about 11 kDa and no disulfides or oligosaccharide groups and include cystatins A and B. Family 2 include cystatins C, D, E/M, F, S, SN, SA and are 13 kDa secretory proteins with two disulfide bonds in the C-terminus and some family members being glycosylated. Faimly 3 are low MW (50-68 kDa) and high MW (88-115 kDa ) forms also secreted and glycosylated and contain three family 2 domains, two of which have protease inhibitory activity.

Both mutagenesis and X-ray crystallography show three conserved regions in cystatins forming a wedge-shaped structure blocking C1 cysteine protease active site. The three regions are (1) N-termainal glycine, (2) a Gln-Val-Gly loop (QXVXG), and (3) a C-terminal hairpin with Pro-Trp (PW) residues. Roles in tumor invasion, inflammation, and proprotein processing have been proposed, although there is not a great deal understood with respect to in vivo biological function. Gene knockout of murine cystatin B and loss-of-function mutations in human cystatin B result in neurological dysfunciton as a form of epilepsy. Mutations in cystatin C cause a neurological disease amyloid angiopathy.

The archetypal cystatin was probably a family 1 gene. Disulfide bonds were added with the emergence of family 2 genes, and two gene duplication events likely gave rise to the higher MW forms of family 3 genes. Fetuin and His-rich glycoprotein (HRG) contain two cystatin-like domains and conserved disulfide bonds but have no inhibitory activity indicates a 4th family with possibly new functions. HRG has no known function but fetuin will bind TGF-β1 and -β2 and might be a cytokine antagonist.

Witin family 2 cystatins are the cystatin-related epididymal spermatogenic (CRES) subgroup, identified by subtractive hybridization for genes preferentially expressed in the proximal portion of the murine epididymis. The CRES and cystatin group had a low total sequence similarity (< 30%), but had the greatest identity with family 2 cystatins. CRES is a N-glycosylated secretory protein with similar size to cystatin C and conserved Cys residues. Cres gene structure shows an additional exon with 5'-untranslated sequences and the 3 exons downstream have sizes similar to mouse cystatin C; intron/exon split sites are also conserved; finally it maps to chromosome 2 and co-segregates with cystatin C. CRES represents a subgroup also in that it contains the C-terminal PW site but lacks teh Q-V-G sequence required for Cys protease inhibition. The N-terminal region, required for high affinity binding to Cys proteases, is poorly conserved and thus specificity may be entirely different. Cystatin C is also ubiquitous whereas Northern blots show high levels of Cres mRNA in proximal caput epididymis and testes but not in 28 other tissues probed. ISH shows Cres expression in epithelial cells of epididymis and in stage-specific germ cells of the testes. CRES protein is found in tissue and luminal fluid of proximal epididymis and in the sperm acrosome, indicating importance in sperm maturation and fertilization. RT-PCR and immunohistochem work shows Cres mRNA and protein in the anterior pituitary gonadotroph cells and a colocalization of CRES with LHβ in the secretory pathway.

Two genes later emerged as members of the CRES subgroup. Testatin has been shown in differential display for a search of genes in mouse testicular development, and cystatin T emerged from a database search of cystatin-related genes. Testatin and cystatin T have a 23 and 38% protein sequence identity to CRES, and 21% to each other. While that percentage is low, what is interesting is the sharing of unique features: they encode secretory proteins of similiar MW and they possess conserved Cys residues. They contain PW at C-term but lacks the Q-V-G and have divergent N-terminal sequences. As for gene structure, testatin has two introns of similar alignment and cystatin T maps to chromosome 2 near cystatin C and Cres. More compelling is the expression seems focused in the reproductive tract. Testatin is expressed according to RT-PCR in mouse testis just after Sry (sex-determining region) gene is. Cystatin T is expressed in pachytene spermatocytes and round spematids.

A study of inhibition found that CRES does not inhibit cysteine proteases like papain or cathepsin B. However at nanomolar concentrations it inhibits the prohormone convertase, involved in proteolytic prohormone forms of maturation. Thus CRES is a new functional family of Ser protease (serpins) inhibitors. It lacks the Asn39 residue said found as important in cystatin C inhibition mechanism.

Database search of genomic sequences shows that CRES-like sequences even in the nematpode are found. Several orthologs are found in different species including catfish, zebrafish, and carp.

Mano N, Iijima S, Kasuga K, Goto J (2003) Analyt. Sci. 19, 1469-1472.

Exopeptidase Degradation for the Analysis of Phosphorylation Site in a Mono-phosphorylated Peptide with Matrix-assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Mass Spectrometry

Phosphopeptide detection in MALDI applications differs from that of other peptides. Every peptide fragment produced by enzymatic cleavage has different charge and physicochemical properties. HPLC with UV detection at 210-220 nm will detect P-peptides similiar to non-P-peptides. Tryptic peptides of β-casein were treated with alkaline phosphatase. HPLC runs show a peak with retentiom time of 10.0 min peak disappears in the ALP-treated while a peak at 10.4 min appears in the sample not treated with ALP. The 10.0-min peak in positive ion mode shows a [M+H]+ peak at m/z 2063, which would be a singly phosphorylated 33-48 fragment, which the 10.4-min peak shows a signal at m/z 1983, fully 80 amu different. In negative ion mode, a [M-H]− peak has an m/z 2061 with very high sensitivity. Together these confirm the fragment nature and its phosphorylation.

Carboxypeptidase W (CPW, Seikagaku, Tokyo) and aminopeptidase M (APM, Roche Diag) were used in ladder sequencing. For CPW, 10 pmol peptide in 15 µl 50 mM ammonium acetate pH 4.0 is mixed with 1.2 µg CPW (20:1 substrate:enzyme), and 3 µl aliquots are removed and mixed with 3 µl 0.2% TFA at 37° at various time intervals. For APM, 10 pmol substrate mixed with 12 µl 50 mM TrisHCl pH 7.5 with 1 mM MgCl2 and 64 µl APM (20 U/ml). This is incubated at 37° for various intervals, and 11 µl alquots taken and mixed with 8 µl 0.2% TFA. The various times were from 0-300 min. Peptides that included the Lys residue were strong in signal, while without it the signal was less intense because of phosphate negative charge. In negative ion mode the ladder peptides had predictably stronger signals.

With peptides FQpSEEQQQTEDE and FQpSEEQQQTEDELQ there are no positive ion signals, but the negative ion mode signals were barely detected. Two potentially phosphorylated residues, Ser-35 and Thr-41, are present. Spectra suggest no phosphate at Thr-41. APM digestion was unhelpful since it was blocked by the phosphorylated Ser. It has been found that phosphorylated residues resist amino- and carboxypeptidase action. After treating with ALP, APM and CPW digestion was done and peptides formed between Thr 41 and Lys 48 were easily detectable. The ladder formed by APM treatment easily clarified the phosphorylated residue from the dephosphorylated peptide. Good ladders from Phe 33 to Glu 37 were formed.

Storey JD (2003) Ann. Stat. 31, 2013-2035.

The Postive False Discovery Rate: A Bayesian Interpretation and The q-Value

Single hypothesis testing concerns the control of the false positive rate (FPR) while maximing probability of detection when there is a condtion. This is maximing the power conditional on Type I error being at or below some level. With multiple hypothesis testing (testing them simultaneously) a compound error measure is defined according th FPR one is willing to encounter. One sets the error rate at desired level and maintains power of each test as much as possible. The family-wise error rate (FWER) is most commonly controlled in multiple hypothesis testing, with Bonferroni test the typical. With m hypothesis test, each test is controlled so that the probability of FP ≤ α/m for a chosen value of α. Then overall FWER ≤ α.

In some cases we are concerned about FP rates among rejected hypotheses rather than probability of making one or more Type I errors. Today a dataset presents so much information that several hypotheses can apply to it simultaneously. The concern is over false positives: the rejection of the null hypothesis when it is true. There is less concern over the significance of all items.

Possible Outcomes from m Hypothesis Tests
Accept null Reject null Total
Null true U V m0
Alternative true T S m1
W R m

The table above gives various outcomes that occur when m hypothesis tests are done according to some significance rule, fixed or data-dependent. FWER can be stated to have probability Pr(V≥1). Benjamini and Hochberg introduced the multiple hypothesis testing error measure called the false discovery rate (FDR) defined as:

FDR = E [ V / (R ∨ 1) ]
= E[ (V / R | R > 0] Pr(R > 0)

Only effect of R ∨ 1 in denominator of first expectation is that ratio V / R is set to zero when R = 0.

The Benjamini and Hochberg procedure works thusly: suppose the p-values resulting from m tests are ordered so that p(1) ≤ p(2) ≤ ... ≤ p(m). If the following is calculated:

k = arg max{k:p(k) ≤α• k/m},

for 1≤k≤m for the arg max.

Edge ASB (2003) Biochem. J. 376, 339-350.

Deglycosylation of glycoproteins with trifluoromethanesulphonic acid: elucidation of molecular structure and function

REVIEW. An advantage of TFMS chemical deglycosylation over enzymatic removal is that all oligosaccharide groups can be removed in a single step with no requirement about the structure or type of glycan. TFMS has been show to work on O- and N-linked glycans as well as those collagen saccharides attached by hydroxyproline linkage. Gal→Ser, Ara→HO-Pro, Man→Ser, Glc→Tyr linkages in all manner of living species have been broken.

Amide bonds are stable under TFMS, which is why the polypeptide is not damaged. In fact, TMFS is unable to break the Asn and N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) bond.

The reaction is done in anhydrous conditons with a free radical scavenger (often anisole) to protect amino acids. Solvolytic cleavge of glycosidic bonds occurs, done in absence of water, or else this can induce protein cleavage. In the solid phase synthesis of peptides, TFMS is used to cleave the finished peptide from the resin. With anisole present damage to side chains of Tyr, Trp, Cys, Met, Ser, and Thr are kept to a minimum. Deprotection is also achieved by HF with same methods, but TFMS is less toxic and more powerful.

TFMS varies on how it takes apart the sugars. The GalNAc that is directly connected to Ser/Thr in O-linked sugars is rather resistant to TFMS, also observed with HF. All Gal and Man chains in fetuin were removed at 0° in less than an hour, while GalNAc at 25° was 75% removed after 3 h. TFMS has fully deglycosylated plant glycoproteins and proteoglycans, distinct from the more resistant mucins, whose resistant is more structure-based than the extent of glycosylation.

The scavenger provides a sink for reactive electrophiles. Severe side reactions are seen in the absence, with amino acids Ser, Thr, Asp, Cys, and Met, and the aromatics. Others have reported that phenol and toluene give superior results. TFMS reactivity is reduced if the scavenger concentration is too high. Generally the anisole is set at 10% of level of TFMS mole-for-mole. Reaction volumes are usually less than 100 µl and reaction temperature should be 0° unless O-linked GalNAc must be removed, in which case the temperature should be higher.

TFMS is an option when enzymic deglycosylation has proven difficult or useless. N-glycanase (PNGase F) and endo F and endo H (endo-β-N-acetylglucosaminidases F and H) are typically used enzymes. Often these enzymes will not work without using denaturing agents to open access to the cleavage site. Enzymes of O-linked sugars are much more limited. The commercially available O-glycanase is specific for the disaccharide Gal-GalNAc. Mucins generally are untouched because of their complexity.

Treatment of proteoglycans with heparanases, chondroitinases, hyaluronidases, and keratanases will remove the GAGs, but it is often necessary to know something about the sugar structure before using these enzymes. The core saccharide GlcA-Gal-Gal-Xyl is not removed by enzymes and remains.

Following deglycosylation, mass determinations using MS have been done and the predicted and measured masses corresponded quite well. The fungal glycoprotein hydrophobin S3 was TFMS-treated and MALDI-ToF MS measured a 10854 Da mass against the theoretical 10856 Da. The pre-TFMS mass is 14,400 Da.

Sequencing of glycoproteins. Glycoproteins are less susceptible to trypsin and other proteases used in sequencing or protein identification. In Edman degradation, the PTH-amino acid of the glycosylated residue is not determined. Fragmentation of MS ions is complicated and gives uninterpretable spectra. Mucin analysis was impossible since they are protease-resistant, whereas TFMS made it entirely analyzable. Glycsoylation sites are all determinable for O-linkages if TFMS treatment is limited or mild (1 h, 4°). If full removal of O-linked sugars is desirable, periodate treatment subsequent to TFMS treatment can be done.

It is ofen useful to use N-glycanase treatment and TFMS to look for mass differences between the products. TFMS removes all O- and N-linked, while N-glycanase removes only N-linked. A significant mass difference indicaes O-linked sugars. Combined with proteolysis, mass analysis of the peptides can suggest locations of where oligosaccharides are attached. Confirmation of O-linkage can be done with the use of lectins specific for many O-linked sugars.

The difference of glycosidic bond susceptibility to TFMS has been exploited to characterize the oligosaccharides structurally. Substituents at C-2 which include amido and acetyl groups alter TFMS reactivity at C-1. With the complete reaction, monosaccharides are obtained that can be analyzed quantitatively.

TFMS does not appear to affect other post-translational modificiations. Thus if the mass of a protein is reduced by TFMS, it is safe to say that the modification was a glycan. 32P-labeled proteins retain the radiolabel under TFMS, as shown after acid hydrolysis of phosphoamino acids. Sulfates on sugars are cleaved by TFMS, but not on tyrosine. Haem groups are not affected by TFMS, and Ca2+ ion is stably associated with their proteins. Glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors are expectedly removed by TFMS. Fatty acid acyl linkages are stable. Disulfide linkages are also unaffected.

Wang W, Zhou H, Lin H, Roy S, Shaler TA, Hill LR, Norton S, Kumar P, Anderle M, Becker CH (2003) Anal. Chem. 75, 4818-4826.

Quantification of Proteins and Metabolites by Mass Spectrometry without Isotopic Labeling or Spiked Standards

In this study human serum is pooled (from four anonymous healthy donors) and several metabolites and proteins will be spiked into it. A 5-protein mix (eq. myoglobin, BSA, bov RNase A, bov cytochrome c, human Hb) is also used, some proteins not varied, others varied. A binary HP 1100 Series HPLC is interfaced to ESI to ThermoFinnigan LCQ DECA with automatic gain or Micromass LCT ESI-ToF with New Objective nanospray. PicoFrit capillary columns (5 µm BioBasic C18, 75 µm × 10 cm) is run at 300 nl/min in a split flow. 20 µg of tryptic peptides are injected in 20 µl loop. Gradient is 0.1% formic acid to 40% B (= 0.1% formic acid in MeCN) over 100 min period. For metabolome work, a 20 µl injection is done: this is 10-25% solvent B in 40 min, then 25-90% solvent B in 30 min. With these programs, 50 samples/week can be analyzed.

5-protein mixtures were prepared so that eq myoglobin, RNase A, and BSA are constant in three preparation. Cytochrome c and Hb were however varied 5-fold in the two other preprations (in one prep 5× cytochome c and 1/5× Hb; in other 1/5× cytochrome c and 5× Hb). Proteins are alkylated after reduction, digested with trypsin, and then analyzed on ion trap. Each preparation is run in four replicates. Intensities of tryptic peptides of the proteins kept constant in all three mixes show that the signal intensities for the two proteins changed were close to linear in the known relative concentrations, within an acceptable coefficient of variance (CV).

With human serum, the proteome (high MW) and metabolome (low MW) are first separated and both fractions have significant complexity as shown by the ion chromatogram. With the ToF tracking and quantifying large counts of mass spectral peaks is advantageous. Software was customized for doing analysis. MS scans of 1 s period are taken during chromatography: noise reduction involves background subtract and signal smoothing. Peak detection is by vectorized method described in another publication (particular good in high intensity or chemical noise). De-isotoping is done (requires idealizing an isotope pattern for all peaks). Reference sample is arbitrarily chosen for adjusting retention times where small variations exist. Centroided intensities are normalized globally (one normalization constant for the sample). Where MS peaks are in multiple samples, these become components of the study, and final intensities are determined in each sample, and CV computed. Paired or group statistical tests (such as t test) are used to determine significant differences. In baseline subtraction, a low-order polynomial smoothing filters (based on Savitzky-Golay) is applied to remove baseline noise and spikes, without loss of signal frequency (see Chapt 14.8 of Numberical Recipes in C by Press et al). A smoothed baseline with well-defined starting and end points for all peaks results. Then sets of points belonging to baseline selected, and low-order polynomial interpolation results in new baseline approximation, which is subtracted from original spectrum. Methods described in Savitzky, Golay (Anal Chem 36: 1627, 1964), Steiner et al (Anal Chem 44: 1906, 1972), and Madden (Anal Chem 50: 1383, 1978) are used to process peak and baseline signal, with different filter parameters for baseline and signal, prove good for multifrequency sginals (multiple peaks with different peak width). With vectorized peak detection, local maxima are found in two dimensions. Ion counts must be greater than a varying threshold over a limited range of m/z and time values, and this phase is peak sensing. Points seen in both dimensions pass the criteria. there is a robust elimination of chemical noise while accepting weak analyte peaks. Chemical noise peaks can be elimianted or at least greatly reduced in that they show no local maxima in the chromatographic dimension.

The maximum intensity isotope in a spectral region is located and then a template matching tool is applied (often used in image processing for object recognition) and an isotope pattern is found. Templates derived from an isotopic table search for patterns of peaks in the original spectra. The template or pattern is mass-dependent and based on nominal peptide elemental composition associated with avg occurrence of various amino acids determined for large number of proteins (see Mathews & van Holde, Biochemistry, Chap 5, 1990). Measure of fit between original data and isotopic pattern template is cross-correlation (convolution) between the two, and is maximized by the isotopic template that matches the one found in the original data. A variety of patterns associated with different charge states (and different masses for m/z region) are examined systematically up to z = 5 or 6, and best fit chosen. Isotopes then are found to belong to single molecular ion and then removed from peak list and no longer considered.

Small variations also occur in the 100 min chromatographic run. Tracking ions can be difficult when many elute in a dense time period. Dynamic time warping (DTW) is an approach developed by us where a sample file is compared to the reference; for each comparison, a set of peaks in common between the two files are selected by software based on retention time windows (in the first stage ± 5 min) and on m/z (± 0.10 Da). All mass chromatograms spanning elution times at these masses are used in compututation rather than just peaks themselves. The number of mass chromatograms is limited to ~200 since computations are time-consuming. The 200 mass chromatograms are combined into a matrix: each element is difference in intensity at time point and m/z between two files, each matrix row originates from mass chromatogram. Using dynamic programming techniques (Rabiner & Juang, Fundamentals of Speech Recognition, 1993, Ch 4) a path is found through the matrix minimizing intensity differences. This path provides a warping function to apply to the nonreference file. Wang & Isenhour (Anal Chem 59: 649, 1987) applied a similar approach but only for TIC plots, which is not enough for this type of analysis. Peak intensities are next determined for quantification using smoothed data, by using eitehr peak area (summed over elution time of component which is mass chromatogram, or by max peak height in ion counts. Software can sum over all isotopes or use intensity of monoisotopic peak. In this report the TOF data took as the peak intensity the max valu of smoothed monoisotopic peak in ion counts.

Data is normalized to correct for instrument sensitivity drift over time and sample-to-sample concentration variations. One file is chosen as reference and then other files refactored (normalized) relative to it. There is no prior evaluation in choosing the reference file. Retention time and m/z values are matched by a window. Unlike size-constrained list used for DTW, no need to constrain count of ratios, thus 1000-3000 peak pairs used. The single normalization constant for each file is taken as median of the ratios of intensities for all componnents between file being examined and the reference. The software does not select peaks in making comparison, but the median value of intensity ratio of all spectral peaks between the sample and reference file is used as normalization for that file. In using the median instead of average, strongly changing peaks get a better representation. Component building now occurs by scanning de-isotoped peak maximums according to m/z and retention time values. If a peak in another sample is with user-settable m/z and time windows, the software calls it an identity. The ToF m/z window is 0.1 Da or less than for ion trap. As for intensity, a threshold is set by user (usually ~20 ion counts); if more conservative, more reliable and robust.

In the serum proteome analysis (20 µg trypsin-digested), about 2700 molecular ions were found in the file. In the metabolome fraction of 100 µl serum, there were 730 molecular ions detected and tracked.

Now to quantify, stability and reproducibility of analyte signal and linear (or near-linear) dependence on control is required. 105 proteome samples were were processed and analyzed consecutively on nano-LC-MS in 13 days, 80 on ion-trap and 25 on ToF. 115 samples were analyzed for metabolome analysis over 17 days. MassView software was used to quantify intensities relative to reference in order to measure CV for larger numbers of molecular components. A histogram of the CV values of normalized intensities are then plotted for about 3400 ions from 25 samples, and with about 85,000 ion measurements (each molecule de-isotoped). Median CV was 25.7% and mean CV was 29.0% for proteome and 23.8% and 28.5% for metabolome, respectively. This histogram distribution was divided into quartiles on the basis of average intensity for components in order to compare high and low-intensity ions. New histograms were prepared for lowest to highest intensity ions. Plots show that there is no real increase in CV values for the lowest intensity ions: some narrowing of CV distribution occurs in lowest quartile because of the influence of threshold eliminating small intensity data.

Two proteins (eq myoglobin and bov carbonic anydrase II) were spiked into 20 µg unprocessed human serum in amts ranging from 100 fmol → 100 pmol. Samples were denatured and digested with trypsin and analyzed on ion-trap and ToF MS instruments using nano-ESI-LC systems. Plots of intensity vs pmol spiked protein show that the signal is quite linear over the entire range. With the ESI-ToF, at 50 fmol protein, signal-to-noise was more than 60, showing that lower masses could be used.

Piraud M, Vianey-Saban C, Petritis K, Elfakir C, Steghens J-P, Morla A, Bouchu D (2003) Rapid Comm. Mass Spectrom. 17, 1297-1311.

ESI-MS/MS analysis of underivatised amino acids: a new tool for the diagnosis of inherited disorders of amino acid metabolism. Fragmentation study of 79 molecules of biological interest in positive and negative ionisation mode

Many amino acids and their catabolic products can be monitored for evidence of disorders of metabolism. All manner of fluids can be followed. Automated AA analyzers are ion-exchange chromatography-based after Spackman et al. This technique can monitor 50 AA and derived compounds, with post-column derivatizatin (ninhydrin). It is not high throughput (only 8-10 runs a day) with high operating costs on dedicated system. Most AA methods would always use pre- or post-analytical modification using UV-absorbing or fluorescent constituents; derivatization improves sensitivity but this introduces variation. Tandem MS is being used to analyze AA, organic acid, purines, pyrimidines, fatty acid oxidation to study inborn errors of metabolism. FAB ionization and then ESI methods were developed to look at inherited disorders. Butyl esters of AA improve detection, minimize ion suppression with complex biological matrices.

Attempts have been made to analyze AA without derivatization. CE-ESI-MS/MS of 20 proteinogenic and 31 physiological AA in standard mixture can be done. Different ion-paired RPLC methods for the 20 AA are also avialable using C18 and porous graphitic carbon with perflourinated carboxylic acids in the ion pair interfaced to ESI-MS/MS. Our lab detects and quantifies 80 molecules routinely using Beckman 6300 AA analyzer. This study hopes to use LC-ESI-MS/MS to replace it. This report looks at 79 molecules of interest using pos, and neg ion mode. Petritis et al had previously look at 42 in pos mode. The instrument is API 2000 triple quad MS with ESI. Nitrogen is collision and curtain gas.

10 µM solutions were prepared in MeOH/water and infused by syringe into ESI. It has an MRM to select most abundant or most specific transition. Gas flow and voltage parameters are similar for all ions. The declustering potential (DP) was specific for each precursor ion, and collision energy (CE) specific for each fragment ion. A table is produced which shows the results of negative ion mode, showing DP values, nominal mass [M-H]− and the produced fragment ions with at least 10% RI. Small-mass molecules usually show no [M-H]− ion in neutral solvents or detectable fragments. Basic AA do not ionize expectedly. All these results show AA are better studied in pos mode. A total of 41 of the 79 molecules produce [M-H]- ions and fragments. Leu, Ile, Val, Arg, Orn, Lys, and Tyr do not show in neg mode and these are typical AA in metabolic problems.

Another table shows the results of positive ion mode. Fully 67 of the 79 molecules show [M+H]+ ions in neutral conditions. Of the 12 not detected, they can be detected in neg mode. When solvent was acidified, 9 of the 12 were detectable. The 3 not detected are orotic acid, orotidine, and phosphoethanolamine (PEA). None of these are true AA and they are highly acidic, better seen in neg mode.

Fragment ion spectra are in agreement with previous reports for some molecules under specified conditions. Some fragments (not reported) were obtained at high CE (> 40 eV). Differences in relative intensities may be because of use of optimized CE values rather than presets. Optimization involved setting curtain/cone gas, ion source gas 1, ion spray voltage (IS), declustering potential (DP), focusing potential (FP), and entrance potential (EP). Mechanisms of fragmentation have been studied.

38 of the 79 molecules are detected in both pos and neg mode. Taurine, S-sulfo-L-cysteine, L-citrulline, γ-carboxyglutamic acid are a few that are better detected in neg mode. Sulfur-containing AA (Cys, homoCys) have low intensity signals but are better detected in oxidized form (Cys-S-S-Cys, HCys-S-S-CysH).

A next step was flow injection analysis (FIA). Molecules that are poorly or not detectable in ESI(+) mode have highly electronegative groups (-COOH, phosphate, sulfate). These are delivered as zwitterions and thus do not get drawn into MS path. Tridecafluoroheptanoic acid (TDFHA) is an extremely strong acid and volatile ion-pairing agent used for underivaized AA for separation and MS/MS. Both neg and pos ion mode show signals, although weaker in neg mode. Solvent was made alkaline in 0.25% ammonium hydroxide for some molecular analyses and there was a signal enhancement, indicating that mobile phase clearly has a significant effect on analysis. In assessing limits of detection (sensitivity), rough estimates of pos mode for a molecule is about 0.1-0.2 pmol (piperidine, Leu, Pro, Lys) to 30-40 pmol (Gly, Tau). In biological fluids under physiological conditions, plasma AA can range from 10-700 µM, which would be 5-350 pmol in 5 µ of a 1:10 diluted sample: detection would be possible in plasma or urine at even 1:10 dilution with 5 µl injection.

As the AA were not in matrix but merely solvents, it is important to study them in biofluids for ion (signal) suppression. MS/MS specificity is linked to a combined analysis of precursor and product ion. A problem arises if two molecules select on the same precursor and product ions. 20 µL of 50 µM solution of all analytes were injected by FIA under acidic conditions. Signal (peak area) obtained with each transition was measured. If signal was > 0.5% of signal obtained with molecule for which transition was selected, it is an interference. Results indicate negligible (<1%) to significant (>15%) interference, sometimes higher than the analyte signal. For example HCy(O3H) (m/z 184) and Met-sulfone (m/z 182) both produce a m/z 56 fragment (the transition) and this represents 136% of the signal.

Isobars include Gln and Lys and Leu, Ile, and (a)Ile, which are even isomers. At low CE, they have identical fragmentation patterns. There are 12 groups of isobars. 16 molecules have transitions (fragment in a way) that allows their distinction and identification. 8 pairs would need separating before analysis. 6 molecules in have a [M+H]+ at m/z 132. Most have transitions that allow distinction. The two diastereomers of Ile would not be distinguished unless a prior chromatographic step was done.

Some interference is the result of in-source CID fragmentation. These can interfere with (be mistaken for) other precusors and interfere with other transitions: for example, Orn gives 133 → 70 and 133 → 116, and these ions become precursors interfering with Pro (116 → 70).

Other interferences arise from the natural isotope distributions, mostly because of 13C (1.1%). In some cases where sulfur is present, its 34S is present at 4.5% abundance. When molecular masses differ by 1 or 2 u, the interference occurs. Met-sulfone (182) can interfere with Hcy(O3H) (184). Gln and Lys (147 → 84) will interfere with Glu (184 → 84) because of 13C. 8 other situations arise from isotope abundance.

Δ1-Pyrroline-5-carboxylic acid interferes with 132 → 68 and 132 → 69 and 132 → 114 transitions, but there is no ability to find the reason. Cross-talk effect as a result of slow ion flight times was ruled out. Interference might be due to impurity present in the chemical compound or a PC degradation product. If true, then it should not occur in biological samples.

cluster ion, FD

Charles L , Chiron J, Galy J-P (2003) Rapid Comm. Mass Spectrom. 17, 2471-2474.

Characterization of ammonium chloride derivatives by salt clustering in electrospray mass spectrometry

Cluster ions are of the form [CA]xCmm+ in positive ion mode and [CA]yAnn+ in negative ion mode where C is the cation and A is the anionic part of the salt. Both the charged residue and ion evaporation models can account for cluster ion formation. Factors affecting salt cluster ion formation include:

  • salt concentration
  • solution conductivity
  • viscosity
  • mole percent of organic solvent
  • solvent polarity
  • counterion characteristics

Chirality of molecules (e.g. amino acids) is also a factor is clusters showing homochirogenesis. Homochiral serine clusters formed a magic number protonated octamers.

All experiments are done on Sciex API III Plus TQ with pneumatically assisted electrospray. Interface temperature is 54°. A curtain gas of 600 ml/min nitrogen is used with 800 ml/min zero-grade air. Spray voltage is 5000 V positive and orifice voltage is 35 V. Negative spray is −4800 V and orifice is −35 V. Sample flow rate is 5 µl/min.

A spectrum of A 1 mmM 4-aminomethyl HCl in isopropanol with range starting at m/z 200 to 1600 produced numerous peaks. The use of isopropanol was expected to favor the formation of clusters. A base peak

Heck AJR, van den Heuvel RHH (2004) Mass Spec. Rev. 23, 368-389.

Investigation of Intact Protein Complexes By Mass Spectrometry

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Mass spectrometry has grown in recent years to a well-accepted and increasingly important complementary technique in structural biology. Especially electrospray ionization mass spectrometry is well suited for the detection of non-covalent protein complexes and their interactions with DNA, RNA, ligands, and cofactors. Over the last decade, significant advances have been made in the ionization and mass analysis techniques, which makes the investigation of even larger and more heterogeneous intact assemblies feasible. These technological developments have paved the way to study intact non-covalent proteinprotein interactions, assembly and disassembly in real time, subunit exchange, cooperativity effects, and effects of cofactors, allowing us a better understanding of proteins in cellular processes. In this review, we describe some of the latest developments and several highlights.

Zhang R, Barker L, Pinchev D, Marshall J, Rasamoelisolo M, Smith C, Kupchak P, Kireeva I, Ingratta L, Jackowski G (2004) Proteomics 4, 244-256.

Mining Biomarkers in Human Sera Using Proteomic Tools

ABSTRACT. One of the major difficulties in mining low abundance biomarkers from serum or plasma is due to the fact that a small number of proteins such as albumin, a2-macroglobulin, transferrin, and immunoglobulins, may represent as much as 80% of the total serum protein. The large quantity of these proteins makes it difficult to identify low abundance proteins in serum using traditional 2-dimensional electrophoresis. We recently used a combination of multidimensional liquid chromatography and gel electrophoresis coupled to matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization-quadrupole-time of flight and Ion Trap liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry to identify protein markers in sera of Alzheimers disease (AD), insulin resistance/type-2 diabetes (IR/ D2), and congestive heart failure (CHF) patients. We identified 8 proteins that exhibit higher levels in control sera and 36 proteins that exhibit higher levels in disease sera. For example, haptoglobin and hemoglobin are elevated in sera of AD, IR/D2, and CHF patients. The levels of several other proteins including fibrinogen and its fragments, alpha 2-macroglobulin, transthyretin, pro-platelet basic protein, protease inhibitors clade A and C, as well as proteins involved in the classical complement pathway such as complement C3, C4, and C1 inhibitor, were found to differ between IR/D2 and control sera. The sera levels of proteins, such as the 10 kDa subunit of vitronectin, alpha 1-acid glycoprotein, apolipoprotein B100, fragment of factor H, and histidine-rich glycoprotein were observed to be different between AD and controls. The differences observed in these biomarker candidates were confirmed by Western blot and the enzyme- linked immunosorbent assay. The biological meaning of the proteomic changes in the disease states and the potential use of these changes as diagnostic tools or for therapeutic intervention will be discussed.

Evans CA, Tonge R, Blinco D, Pierce A, Shaw J, Lu Y, Hamzah HG, Gray A, Downes CP, Gaskell SJ, Spooncer E, Whetton AD (2004) Blood 103, 3751-3759.

Comparative proteomics of primitive hematopoietic cell populations reveals differences in expression of proteins regulating motility

Hematopoietic cells from marrow of C57Bl/6 mice were isolated on Optiprep and enriched for Lin− cells with a linear marker antibody cocktail (Pharmingen) using magnetic sheep antirat beads. These cells were then labeled with FITC-anti-Sca-1 and PhycoE-anti-cKit and sorted to prepare Lin− Sca-1+ c-Kit+ (lSK) or Lin− Sca-1+ c-Kit− (lSk) cells. lSK cells show a reduced motility (chemokinetic) response to SDF-1 compared to lSk cells. SDF-1 attracts hematopoietic progenitors by activating the PI-3K/PIP3 signal cascade. Cells were treated with SDF-1 and then fixed and stained with a GFP-tagged form of the pleckstrin homology (PH) domain of GRP1 (the PH doman binds selectively to PIP3 ). A mutant PH GRP1 GFP-tagged form unable to bind PIP3 was used to determine background fluorescence. The data show that cells were identical in fluorescent response, and that both lSK and lSk cells produce PIP3. The use of PI-3K inhibitors completely blocked the motility and chemotaxis of both lSK and lSk cells.

Between 0.1-1 million cells were washed 3x in PBS and pellets stored frozen at −80°. Pellets were resuspended in 9 M urea, 2 M thiourea, 4% CHAPS, 0.5% TX-100 to a 2.75 mg/ml protein concentration. These are vortexed on platform for 2 min at room temp to complete lysis and spun 13,500 rpm on microfuge 10 min. Supernatants are transferred to fresh tube and samples treated with 1 mM Tris(tris2-carboxyethyl)phosphine for 60 min at 37°. For every 25 µg protein, 20 nmol of Cy3 or Cy5 labeling dye (Amersham Biosciences) in DMF is added, reaction done for 30 min at 37°. Lysis buffer with 4% (v/v) immobilized pH gradient (IPG) 3-10 nonlinear containing 20 mM DTT is added. Samples are iced before storage at −80°. 2D-separation is done using the IPG 3-10NL 24 cm strips of Amersham Biosci using Multiphor II (for 72 kVh) and then the 2nd dimension of the ISODALT SDS-PAGE system (Amersham Biosci). Visualization is by scanning gels on 532 nm (Cy3) and 633 (Cy5) Typhoon 8600 flourescent scanner in gel format.

2D-DIGE (2D-difference gel electrophoresis) can be done using maleimide CyDye labeling. This might pick up the difference in proteins responsible for the difference in motility between lSK and lSk. The first generation of Cy dyes are N-hydroxysuccinimidyl esters that label ε-amino groups on Lys residues which label 5% of proteins. The maleimide dyes label Cys sulfhydryl protein to saturation and they provide enhanced sensitivity. Cy3 and Cy5 maleimide dyes are mass- and charge-matched. A cell line was test labeled with Cy3 and Cy5 to see if there were any differences in labeling properties, and there were none.

25 µg protein samples representing about 250,000 cells from lSK and lSk cells labeled with Cy3 or Cy5, resp., and run on 2D gel. Both dyes were used on both cell types to control for dye-labeling artefacts. Five sets of cells were compared to establish significant differences in expression (four Cy5 and one Cy3). A mean value of 550 ± 32 protein spots was found, and the gel image analysis showed major differences between the two cell populations. 122 spots were unique in the lSK cells, and 41 spots in teh lSk cells. Difference maps were constructed to look at the relative fold differences.

One set of proteins has a mass of about 80 kDa and form 7 spots between pI 5-7. These proteins may be splice variants with minor changes in mass or might be posttranslationally modified. The database search of mass fingerprints identified adseverin, also known as scinderin or gelsolin-like protein. These mediate actin capping, nucleation, and filament splicing. Spot volumes were greater in lSk cells than lSK. And so were spots slightly higher above these in the 2D gel (slightly higher mass), corresponding to gelsolin. mRNA level expression also correlated with protein level expression: 1.3 fold in adseverin vs. 4-fold in gelsolin.

A variety of mass spectrophotometric techniques were used to determine the nature of the pI difference in spots. N-acetylation was observed for adseverin, and it is known that acetylation is used to modify cytoskeletal proteins. The acetylated peptide AQELQHPEFAR corresponds to amino acids 2-12 of adseverin: Met is cleaved from the amino terminus and the alanine residue is acetylated (uslly happens to 2nd amino acid when it is small and neutral). Actin filament regulation of this kind alone could account for differences in motility of the two cell types. The actin levels are equivalent.

Friedman DB, Hill S, Keller JW, Merchant NB, Levy SE, Coffey RJ, Caprioli RM (2004) Proteomics 4, 793-811.

Proteome Analysis of Human Colon Cancer by Two-Dimensional Difference Gel Electrophoresis and Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. Two-dimensional difference gel electrophoresis (2-D DIGE) coupled with mass spectrometry (MS) was used to investigate tumor-specific changes in the proteome of human colorectal cancers and adjacent normal mucosa. For each of six patients with different stages of colon cancer, Cy5-labeled proteins isolated from tumor tissue were combined with Cy3-labeled proteins isolated from neighboring normal mucosa and separated on the same 2-D gel along with a Cy2-labeled mixture of all 12 normal/tumor samples as an internal standard. Over 1500 protein spot-features were analyzed in each paired normal/tumor comparison, and using DIGE technology with the mixedsample internal standard, statistically significant quantitative comparisons of each protein abundance change could be made across multiple samples simultaneously without interference due to gel-to-gel variation. Matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization- time of flight (MALDI-TOF) and tandem (TOF/TOF) MS provided sensitive and accurate mass spectral data for database interrogation, resulting in the identification of 52 unique proteins (including redundancies due to proteolysis and post-translationally modified isoforms) that were changing in abundance across the cohort. Without the benefit of the Cy2-labeled 12 sample mixture internal standard, 42 of these proteins would have been overlooked due to the large degree of variation inherent between normal and tumor samples.

Hirabayashi J (2004) Glycoconj. J. 21, 35-40.

Lectin-Based Structural Glycomics: Glycoproteomics and Glycan Profiling

ABSTRACT. Structural glycomics (SG) plays a fundamental part of concurrent glycobiology aiming at comprehensive elucidation of glycan functions (i.e., functional glycomics) in the context of post-genome sciences. The SG project started in April 2003 and will continue for 3 years in the framework of NEDO (New Energy and Industrial Technology Organization) under the METI (the Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry), Japan. The main purpose of the project is the development of highthroughput and robust machines, which should greatly contribute to the structural analysis of complex glycans. In this chapter, 2 major research items, i.e., (1) glycoproteomics, which enables comprehensive analysis of glycoproteins, and (2) glycan profiling by means of lectins, are described. For the latter, frontal affinity chromatography has been adopted as a starting tool for comprehensive analysis of the interaction of 100 lectins and 100 oligosaccharides under the concept of hect-by-hect, which refers to 100 × 100.

Balogh MP (2004) LC GC Europe 17, 152-159.

MS In Practice: Debating Resolution and Mass Accuracy

With the use of an MS as a detector in LC systems, there are increased expectations regarding its performance. Its primary functions are to produce accurate mass signals at high resolution. But as a detector, sensitivity and dynamic range also become important. One important thing overlooked however in LC-MS work is the expectation that a single run provide all the needed work. Instead, runs should be in triplicate and they should have well-prepared samples, with accurate mass.

An anecdote from K. Biemann from the early 1960s is given. The drug reserpine was marketed by CIBA starting from the 1930s but not structurally determined until the 1940s. Techniques such as Zn dust distillation involved purification of alkyl indoles and pyridines through their crystallization in picrates, which are then identified by melting point and elemental analysis. Biemm used MS with something called mass spectrometic shift technique instead of mp determinations and IR. One reviewer asked Biemann if the appropriate level of characterization had been done. One journal (J Am Soc Mass Spectrom) requires consideration of acceptable uncertainty for any method used to support structural determinations. For example, when parent masses having C0-100, H3-74, O0-4, N0-4 show an m/z 118, no alternative formulae within 34 ppm can exist. If the mass becomes m/z 750 for C0-100, H25-110, O0-15, N0-15, there are now 626 alternatives and all within 5 ppm. For m/z 118, this now becomes 0.018 ppm to eliminate alternatives.

FTICR MS instruments provide both sensitivity and high resolution. Bruker and others have been market leaders in FTICR although Thermo recently introduced a model. AG Marshall at the National High Field Fourier Transform ICR Center in Florida plotted the logarithm of the spacing between resolved peaks in datltons (Y) against the ratio of instrument resolution to molecular weight (X). Bovine ubiquitin in an electrospray is the example. At a plot point up to (X = 10−4,, Y=10−3), the resolution is weakest but able to resolve charge states. Between the last X,Y and (10−9, 10−2), resolution of identically charged adducts ([M+nH)]n+ and [M+n−1H+Na]n+ is enough when n is large. Between the last (X,Y) and (1, 10−10), isotopic peaks of an ion are resolved as baseline resolution of highly charged ions (multiple peaks seen within an m/z 1 scale unit. And beyond the last (X,Y) one can resolve isomers to 0.005 m/z units.

The ion cyclotron was first reported by Hipple, Sommer and Thomas in the late 1940s and then Cooley and Tukey developed the fast FT algorithm. Bendix Corp. made the first ToF instrument, and later a more compact instrument with reflectron to correct for effects of kinetic energy distribution of ions was made based on Boris Mamyrin's work. In general ToF offers higher resolution than quadrupoles.

Mass accuracy is extremely critical. It is the ability to calibrate or measure the instrument response against a known entity. Tolerance is measured in ppm, or the deviation from a response to the known mass. To achieve the highest accuracy, continuous calibration with a lockmass is necessary.

LC-ToF and Q-ToF provide the best mass range. ToF is the best choice for broad or general applications, whereas FT-MS and magnetic sector are specialized.

Vitorino R, Lobo MJC, Ferrer-Correira AJ, Dubin JR, Tomer KB, Domingues PM, Amado FML (2004) Proteomics 4, 1109-1115.

Identification of Human Whole Saliva Protein Components Using Proteomics

Whole saliva contains mucins and other high MW glycoproteins which create problems for 1st dimension IEF. 1 ml whole saliva was obtained from healthy gums at 8 am after overnight fasting, immediately spun max speed in microfuge for 20 min at 4°, and Lowry assay done. 60 µg was loaded to 13 cm pH 3-10 IPG strip (Amersham Pharmacia) with 3-10 Immobilines, thiourea, CHAPS, and urea. This was run in a 12.5% gel and then silver-stained. For tryptic peptide preparation, 150 µg was loaded, stained with Coomassie.

With the analytical method, 200 spots could be detected. Good resolution was obtained with a preparative gel technique. 60% of total protein is α-amylase in the 50-70 kDa range with multiple isoenzymes. Keller et al. have reported that the amylase fractionates into two major groups, one at 59 and another at 63 kDa. The higher MW group is because of N-linked sugars. The resolution of the gel is sorely affected as a result. With optimized protein levels more proteins are visible on the acidic zone compared with earlier reports. About 100 spots were selected for trypsin digest and MALDI-ToF-ToF (ABi 4700 Proteomics Analyzer) in the m/z 800-4000 ranges. Resolution was 15000 with mass accuracy of 25 ppm. A switch to MS/MS mode (excluding known background or contaminant peaks) was of the two most intense peaks in the parent spectrum. The MS/MS range was 70 (to include immonium ions) to the parent mass; resolution was 8000 and mass accuracy 75 ppm. Fragmentation spectra saw peaks with y and b-series, immonium, amine, and water loss ions. 40% of spectra produced at least a partial sequence even for peptides with m/z values > 2000, and 15% of peptides were fully sequenced. Identification was accepted with a Mascot score of 90 with confirmation using MW/pI values. 43 spots were identified this way, with identical identifications for several spots. Glycosylation and phosphorylation account for PTMs.

Lipocalin-1 was seen as four spots, prolactin with 5 spots, carbonic anhydrase VI with five spots, lysozyme with 2, histatin 1 with one, PLUNC-palate lung nasal epithelial clone, lactotransferrin, secretory component, common cystatins (SN, three spots; SA, one; SA-III, -D, and -C, one), two uncommon cystatins, several fragments of α-amylase.

12 new proteins were identified. Statherin and histatin-3 found by others were not found. The same is true for interleukin-1, IgJ, and fatty-acid binding protein, which might be suppressed by peptide masses of co-migrating proteins or are subject to individual variation. Proline-rich proteins are more difficult to analyze since they produce few tryptic digest peptides (3 or 4). Four spots of carbonic anhydrase VI were seen.

Mitulović G, Stingl C, Smoluch M, Swart R, Chervet J-P, Steinmacher I, Gerner C, Mechtler K (2004) Proteomics 4, 2545-2557.

Automated, On-Line Two-Dimensional Nano Liquid Chromatrograph Tandem Mass Spectrometry for Rapid Analysis of Complex Protein Digests

2-D chromatography was done on a capillary HPLC from LC Packings featuring FAMOS autosampler, UltiMate micropump with UV detector and SWITCHOS column switcher. All MS data were acquired using a Finnigan LCQ classic ion trap MS that included a homemade nano-ionization source with a luminary strip and red diode to avoid reflection. MS/MS data were obtained in data-dependence setting with dynamic exclusion. Database searches of MS/MS were done using MASCOT (on a Compaq alpha cluster 8 processor running under Linux). UltiMate was in nanomode at 200 nl/min. SWITCHOS loading ran at 35 µl/min and its flow transported sample from the loop to SCX column. Its flow also washed the C18 trap column to prevent matrix and/or salt from reaching the nano sep column and MS. The FAMOS was operated in large inject volume mode with 250 µl loop. Columns were BioX-SCX 500 µm i.d. × 15 mm LC Packings; 300 µm i.d. × 5 mm cartridge with PepMap100 3 µm C18 LC Packings; a PepMap nano sep 75 µm i.d. × 15 cm PepMap100 3 µm C18 LC Packings. The system was tested with tryptic digests of bovine heart cytochrome c (Sigma C-2037), BSA Fraction V (Fluka 05480), horse liver alcohol dehydrogenase (Sigma 17233), β-galactosidase and serotransferrin (Sigma). Protein were reduced with DTT (Sigma D-9163) and alkylated with IAA (Sigma I-4386). These were dialyzed away with 0.1 M ammonium bicarbonate pH 8; and trypsinized overnight at 37° using Promega sequencing grade trypsin. A 1:10 dilution with 0.5% TFA was done and loaded to SCX equilibrated with 0.1% formic acid (Fluka 06440),

RP columns alone (1D chromatography), even with long gradient elutions yield poor results in MS/MS and database searching. Alternatively, tryptic peptides can be held on to SCX trap and then sep column, and then eluted to RP trap and sep. The peak capacity of a multidimensional chromatography system is effectively the product of peak capacities of each dimension in the system. Column switching permits use of loading columns with larger i.d.s in first dimension (the SCX had a 0.5 mm i.d.) and this leads to more data points in later dimensions. The plumbing config was setup with the FAMOS 6-port valve and the two 10-port valves on SWITCHOS. For the FAMOS, port 3 leads to the injection needle, ports 2-5 to holds a sample loop, port 1 to the SWITCHOS loading solvent (at 35 µl/min), port 6 to port 1 of valve B on SWITCHOS, (and port 4 to waste?). On SWITCHOS valve B, port 2 runs to top of SCX column, port 9 to the bottom of the column, and port 10 to port 9 of valve A of the SWITCHOS. SWITCHOS valve A features ports 4 and 8 to waste, port 3 to one end of an RP 300 µm i.d. trap column, port 10 to the other end of the trap column, port 2 to the gradient pump running at 200 nl/min, and port 1 leads to the RP 75 µm i.d. nano sep column on the UltiMate.

With inject mode, peptides in the FAMOS loop are loaded on to the SCX column where positively charged proteins are bound. Unbound proteins continue toward valve A of the SWITCHOS which holds an RP trap column. Peptides that continue to remain unbound goes out the waste line (port 4). In a wash mode, valve B is switched while valve A is not: the 35 µl/min wash line comes in at port 1 and goes out port 10 of valve B and directly to port 9 and to 10 of valve A, causing washing of the RP trap column to remove matrix and salts. In elute mode, valve A is now switched and the RP trap eluted via the gradient line on to the RP nanosep column, and peptides separated on to the detector (MS). For step 4, a conditioning mode switches both valves A and B and the columns are reconditioned.

500 fmol of each of 5 proteins was digested and run on to a nanosep RP column (1D sep) alone, and the base peak chromatogram shows a high number of peptides eluting within a short range of time (from 18-48 min in a 55 min run). 0.1% formic acid and 50 mM phosphate were then used as loading mobile phases for the SCX column set up in line at the top of the RP column: thus all peptides off the RP column represent unbound peptides to the SCX. A greater amount of peptides remained unbound to SCX with 0.1% FA, as the base peak had a higher intensity than in direct injection of the RP column. With phosphate as the loading mobile phase to SCX, more peptides bound to SCX. These were eluted from SCX to MS detection with increasing steps of 50, 100, 200, and 500 mM ammonium acetate salt plugs. A disadvantage of off-line loading is that it takes several hours and sample loading requires some experience to be successful. Multiphase single column use results in faster sample loading and less loss but does not allow removal of salts before the RP separation.

Loading buffer selection is not easy when coupling an SCX to an RP trap. Conditions that improve trapping on RP reduce the amounts of peptides that bind to SCX. 0.05% TFA resulted in low SCX peptide binding even though it helps create ion pairs for RP. Use of formic acid represented only a slight improvement in peptide binding to SCX. Phosphate represented a better compromise. It stabilizes pH over a large range and can promote RP trapping. The problem is that phosphate is not compatible with ESI-MS, and so the RP trap requires washing prior to elution. A switch to 0.1% FA is appropriate, but wash time needs to be optimized, since peptides will eventually elute from the RP trap if prolonged beyond removal of all phosphate. Each HPLC parameter depends on several factors. Flow rates are set according to column (SCX) dimensions, column capacity, and connecting tube types. Loading times will generally be affected by sample volume, but complexity and matrix of the sample is important, as is the loading column capacity. Matrix and salts can displace peptides on the columns if loading times are too long and there is competitve affinity. Note that in the plumbing configration that the RP trap column is bidirectional and eluted through a back flush onto the RP nanosep column: this reduces peak broadening.

Step elution (salt plugs) was not always clean. Some proteins eluted in more than one fraction (step elution). Very abundant proteins even eluted in several fractions if strongly bound to SCX. Low abundance proteins, the aim of this work, are often obscured in complex samples in which a large number of proteins predominate. Comparisons were made to a 1D separation and the sensitivity of the low abundance protein increased 2-fold with a 1D separation. Use of phosphate pH 3.0 resulted in higher MASCOT scores (sequence coverage), but at the expense of a higher MS/MS background compared to FA. It was clear that not all of the phosphate was or could be washed free. Optimization of the phosphate concentration and pH showed that as little as 2.5 mM phosphate at pH 2.5 could result in reduced effects of MS without affecting ion exchange.

Jurkat cell nuclear matrix protein was prepared and separated on 2-D gels run from pH 3-8 and separated between 20-250 kDa. 94 gel spots were analyzed by MS whereas in contrast 174 proteins could be identified in a single 10 µg run on LC. 108 of the 130 proteins found by LC-MS/MS were not found in the gels, largely because of high basic pI values and low Mr. 46 of the 68 proteins that could be theoretically resolved on 2-D gels were in fact resolved; this score is higher than others who have done comparisons of LC-MS/MS and 2DGE-MS.

Hopfgartner G, Varesio E, Tschaäppät V, Grivet C, Bourgogne E, Leuthold LA (2004) J. Mass Spectrom. 39, 845-855.

Triple Quadrupole Linear Ion Trap Mass Spectrometer For The Analysis of Small Molecules and Macromolecules

ABSTRACT. Recently, linear ion traps (LITs) have been combined with quadrupole (Q), time-of-flight (TOF) and Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance (FT-ICR) mass spectrometery (MS). LITs can be used either as ion accumulation devices or as commercially available, stand-alone mass spectrometers with MSn capabilities. The combination of triple quadrupole MS with LIT technology in the form of an instrument of configuration QqLIT, using axial ejection, is particularly interesting, because this instrument retains the classical triple quadrupole scan functions such as selected reaction monitoring (SRM), product ion (PI), neutral loss (NL) and precursor ion (PC) while also providing access to sensitive ion trap experiments. For small molecules, quantitative and qualitative analysis can be performed using the same instrument. In addition, for peptide analysis, the enhanced multiply charged (EMC) scan allows an increase in selectivity, while the time-delayed fragmentation (TDF) scan provides additional structural information. Various methods of operating the hybrid instrument are described for the case of the commercial Q TRAP (AB/MDS Sciex) and applications to drug metabolism analysis, quantitative confirmatory analysis, peptides analysis and automated nanoelectrospray (ESI-chip-MS) analysis are discussed.

Choi J-K, Chae H-Z, Hwang S-Y, Choi H-I, Jin L-T, Yoo G-S (2004) Electrophoresis 25, 1136-1141.

Fast Visible Dye Staining of Proteins in One- and Two-Dimensional Sodium Dodecyl Sulfate-Polyacrylamide Gels Compatible With Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization-Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. A fast and matrix assisted laser desorption/ionization-mass spectrometry (MALDI-MS) compatible protein staining method in one- and two-dimensional sodium dodecyl sulfate- polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (1- and 2-D SDS-PAGE) is described. It is based on the counterion dye staining method that employs oppositely charged two dyes, zincon (ZC) and ethyl violet (EV) to form an ion-pair complex.
