The protocol, including fixing, staining and quick washing steps, can be completed in 11.5 h depending upon gel thickness. It has a sensitivity of 48 ng, comparable to that of colloidal Coomassie Brilliant Blue G (CBBG) staining with phosphoric acid in the staining solution. The counterion dye stain does not induce protein modifications that complicate interpretation of peptide mapping data from MS. Considering the speed, sensitivity and compatibility with MS, the counterion dye stain may be more practical than any other dye-based protein stains for routine proteomic researches.

Tang N, Tornatore P, Weinberger SR (2004) Mass Spec. Rev. 24, 34-44.

Current Developments in SELDI Affinity Technology

ABSTRACT. The overall history and recent advancements in Surface- Enhanced Laser Desorption/Ionization (SELDI) affinity technology is reviewed. A detailed account of SELDI technology, utilizing Immobilized-Metal Affinity surfaces, pseudo-specific chromatographic surfaces, and biospecific interactive surfaces, is presented with particular emphasis placed upon examination of fundamental characteristics as well as specific applications for each. Finally, a detailed review of the specific use of such affinity surfaces in fundamental aspects of clinical, process, and research proteomics activity is presented.

Zaia J (2004) Mass Spec. Rev. 24, 161-227.

Mass Spectrometry of Oligosaccharides

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Glycosylation is a common post-translational modification to cell surface and extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins as well as to lipids. As a result, cells carry a dense coat of carbohydrates on their surfaces that mediates a wide variety of cellcell and cell matrix interactions that are crucial to development and function. Because of the historical difficulties with the analysis of complex carbohydrate structures, a detailed understanding of their roles in biology has been slow to develop. Just as mass spectrometry has proven to be the core technology behind proteomics, it stands to play a similar role in the study of the functional implications of carbohydrate expression, known as glycomics. This review summarizes the state of knowledge for the mass spectrometric analysis of oligosaccharides with regard to neutral, sialylated, and sulfated compound classes. Mass spectrometric techniques for the ionization and fragmentation of oligosaccharides are discussed so as to give the reader the background to make informed decisions to solve structure-activity relations in glycomics.

Li J, Liu S, Osterman T, Zhang Y, Coppage H, Pedrick N, Witzmann FA (2004) Anal. Biochem. 332, 187-190.

A Software Utility for Creating Interactive Maps for 2D Gel-Based Proteomics

Notes & Tips.

Bogdanov B, Smith RD (2004) Mass Spec. Rev. 24, 168-200.

Proteomics By FTICR Mass Spectrometry: Top Down and Bottom Up

REVIEW. FTICR provides the highest mass resolution, resolving power, mass accuracy, and sensitivity of all MS technologies. One field that has benefitted from FTICR is proteomics. Proteomics can be defined as the direct qualitative and quantitative analysis of the full complement or subset of proteins present in an organism, tissue, or cell under given set of physiological or environmental conditions. Analyses can be from the the bottom up (peptide to protein) or top down (protein to peptide).

Identification of peptides (the bottom up approach) describes the determination of the peptides masses from a parent protein and the other from MS/MS fragmentation of one or more of the peptides. The first approach is peptide mass fingerprinting. The second approach is based on information from dissociation (collisional activation) of one or more polypeptides isolated in the first stage of MS analysis. Bottom-up approaches do not provide info on the whole protein sequence.

Peptide fragmentation in the FTICR is achieved by sustained off-resonance irradiation (SORI) collision-induced dissocation (CID), infrared multi-photon dissociation (IRMPD), both with CO2 laser and blackbody radiation, and surface-induced dissociation. Peptides fragment primarily into b- and y-type ions for slower mutli-step activation processes; fragmentation efficiency and relative fragment ion abundances are dependent upon amino acid sequence. Peptide CID in Q-ToF or QIT (quadrupole ion-trap) is generally faster because FTICR requires re-establishment of high vacuum before excitation and detection. CID is also done outside the FTICR, in a rf-multipole device.

To achieve controlled, predictable fragmentation, Lee et al prepared single and double sodiated peptides on MALDI and ESI using SORI. Sodiated peptides showed highy selective cleavage at Asp residues. Peptides without acidic residues show sequential cleave from C-term. The mechanims was described as a salt-bridge chemistry, where Na ion stabilizes proton transfer from Asp residue to adjaent amide nitrogen.

SORI-CID has been used with negative mode FTICR to assess the expectation that negative ions would produce good spectra. Dominant fragments were c, y and internal fragments, with a, b, x, and z ions formed. Much of the fragments were cleavage next to acidic (Asp, Glu, and cysteic acid) residues on either side (N or C) of the residue. Acquiring a single spectrum takes >2 s and even with that long a scan, there are many problems that give low fragmentation efficiency; FTICR with in-cell SID was designed with a high acquisition rate (300 ms/spectrum) which traps fragment ions with a high efficiency, well controlled kinetic energy of the parent, and high fragmentation. A modified SORI-CID was used for a MALDI source.

In 1998 electron capture dissociation was pioneered using FTICR and remains unique to it. ECD was applied to larger multiply charged protein molecules, and was applied to peptides having at least two charges in order to induce fragmentation. Low-energy (<1 eV) electrons were captured by [M + nH]n+ ions to produce [M + nH](n−1)+•. These fragment rapidly and randomly (fast recombination of thermal electrons and protonated sites) than that by CID, with cleavage of N-αC to produce N-terimal c-type and C-terminal z-type ions. Post-translational modifications that are labile to other fragmentation processes are retained with ECD. ECD also cleaves disulfide bonds.

Accurate Mass and Time (AMT) Tag. Polypeptide AMT tags are a bottom-up approach in which proteins in large numbers (as in cell lysates) are digested

Candiano G, Bruschi M, Musante L, Santucci L, Ghiggeri GM, Carnemolla B, Orecchia P, Zardi L, Righetti PG (2004) Electrophoresis 25, 1327-1333.

Blue Silver: A Very Sensitive Colloidal Coomassie G-250 Staining for Proteomic Analysis

A study was done to see assess how quickly the various stains reached a certain staining intensity over time. Three staining preparations were tested: (1) the original recipe of Neuhoff et al., (2) the blue silver stain reported here, (3) a commercial Neuhoff-like recipe from Sigma. The fastest and most intense staining was with the blue-silver: 80% of the dye is taken up in the 1st hour vs. 40% with the Neuhoff staining, and virtually nil with the commercial dye. After 50 hours of staining, the Neuhoff stain is 2.5 times more intense and blue-silver is 3.3 times more intense. A dilution curve of BSA runs as bands on a 1-D gel shows that staining can be sensed with as little as 1 ng, possiby 0.75 ng.

2-D maps of human kidney tubular epithelial cells were run and stained with Neuhoff, silver, and blue silver. The blue-silver showed far more sensitivity than did the Neuhoff. To prepare gels, the cultured cells were lysed in a 5 mM phosphate pH 8 buffer with inhibitors of phosphatases and proteases. Protein content was adjusted to 5 mg/ml, adding 10% SDS, 3% DTT, 40 mM Tris, and 0.1 mM EDTA, heating for 5 min at 100°. Soluble sample was treated with a delipidating extraction solution of 1:12:1 tri-n-butylphosphate:acetone:methanol and cooled on ice. 14 ml of this was added to SDS-solubilized cytosolic epithelial cell with a final acetone concentration of 80% and left at 4° for 90 min. Centrifugation was at 2800 × g for 20 min at 4°. Pellet was re-washed with delipidizing solution and spun and then air-dried. Pellet was re-suspended in 7 M urea, 2 M thiourea, 4% CHAPS, 5 mM TBP, 20 mM iodoacetamide, 40 mM Tris, and 0.1 mM EDTA pH 8.8. The solution sat 3 h before focusing was started. DTT was added to neutralize iodoacetamide before focusing, and 100 µg was loaded on to an IPG strip.

Hirano H, Islam N, Kawasaki H (2004) Phytochem. 65, 1487-1498.

Technical Aspects of Functional Proteomics in Plants

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Since the completion of genome sequences of several organisms, attention has been focused to determine the function and functional network of proteins by proteome analysis. This analysis is achieved by separation and identification of proteins, determination of their function and functional network, and construction of an appropriate database. Many improvements in separation and identification of proteins, such as two-dimensional electrophoresis, nano-liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry, have rapidly been achieved. Some new techniques which include top-down mass spectrometry and tandem affinity purification have emerged. These techniques have provided the possibility of high-throughput analysis of function and functional network of proteins in plants. However, to cope with the huge information emerging from proteome analyses, more sophisticated techniques and software are essential. The development and adaptation of such techniques will ease analyses of protein profiling, identification of post-translational modifications and proteinprotein interaction, which are vital for elucidation of the protein functions.

Cortón M, Villuendas G, Botella JI, San Millán, Escobar-Morreale HF, Peral B (2004) Proteomics 4, 438-441.

Improved Resolution of The Human Adipose Tissue Proteome at Alkaline and Wide Range pH by Addition of Hydroxyethyl Disulfide

Samples from 10 morbidly obese women and 10 female controls were cut into small pieces and frozen at −75° until processed. A Polytron PT-1200C with a 8.4 M urea, 2.4 M thiourea, 5% CHAPS, 50 mM DTT and 1% 3-10 ampholyte was used for lysis (2 ml/g fat). Thiourea used in combination with urea helps to improved protein solubility. The suspension was shaken at room temp for 60 min, spun at 70,000 rpm for 1.5 h at 19° using Beckman TL-100. Solubilization of lipid-rich proteins is best done by taking the infranatant (part below the fat supernatant). A Bradford assay is used for protein. The original extract was solubilized in 8 M urea, 2 M thiourea, 2% CHAPS, 0.5% 3-10 ampholyte, 0.002% bromophenol blue, and 10 mM DTT (alternatively 50 mM DTT or 10 mM hydroxyethyl disulfide [HED] was sometimes used in place of DTT. IPG strips with pH 6-11 range were loaded with 100 µg protein in 100 µl rehydration solution using a cup-loading method positioned on the anode. For the IPG pH 3-10 80 µg protein was loaded using in-gel sample rehydration in 350 µl solution. The 18 cm strips were focused at 50 µA per strip with the following running conditions: for IPG 6-11, 0-300 V in 60 sec, then 300 V for 3 h, 300 to 600 V in 2 h, 600 to 1000 V in 2 h, and 1000 to 8000 V in 3 h, and then 5 h at 8000 V. The IPG 3-10 strips were run in conditions specified by Görg et al. with the modification that there was an additional step at 120 V for 60 min, and 90 min ramp from 1000-8000 V rather than 30 min. The 8000 V step was maintained until 35 kVh was reached. For the 2nd dimension, gels were run in a Protean II XL system with 12.5% gels in a 185 × 200 × × 1 mm and fixed overnight and then silver-stained.

In the alkaline range of 2-DE maps horizontal streaking is common. This is because the reducing agent is degraded and because protein thiols oxidize, and because there is water transport to the anode because of reverse electroendosmotic flow. Some use paper wicks immersed in DTT at the cathode during focusing, and it is thought that adding 10% or an isopropanol/glycerol mixture reduces water transport. Others compensate by reducing the total focusing time to a minimum (ramping the final voltage quickly in doing so).

Fig. 1 shows that the use of the Amersham-Biosciences DeStreak reagent in the pH 6-11 strips shows improved separation efficiency. This confirms work by others that HED eliminated horizontal streaking. The same was observed for pH 3-10 strips (Fig. 2) with much better maps when HED rather than 10 and 50 mM DTT being used. HED works by oxidizing protein thiol groups to disulfides and improving gel reproducibility. Different concentrations of HED (50, 100, 200 mM) were tried, and they all led to the same spot patterns. PDQuest software found 110 and 123 additional spots with pH 3-10 strips when HED was used rather than 10 and 50 mM DTT, respectively. For pH 6-11 strips, only the HED map was analyzed, finding a total of 488 spots.

The Shevchenko et al. method with minor variations was used for in-gel trypsin digestion. Extracts were spotted on 400 mm AnchorChip MALDI plate (Bruker) and analyzed on Bruker Reflex IV MALDI-ToF in positive reflectron mode. Two tryptic autolytic products were used to calibrate masses (m/z 842.510 and 2211.105). A mass accuracy of 30 ppm was found. The Bruker MS BioTools interface was used to search NCBInr database (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov) with Mascot, with no species restriction or variable modification, 1 missed cleavage, and a mass accuracy of 50 ppm set.

Cooper JW, Gao J, Lee CS (2004) Electrophoresis 25, 1379-1385.

Electronic Gel Protein Transfer and Identification Using Matrix-Assisted Laser Desportion/Ionization-Mass Spectrometry

Fused silica capillaries (50 µm id/192 µm od, 100 µm id/200 µm) were coated internally with linear polyacrylamide (Kilar & Hjertén, 1989). A gel protein capillary extraction apparatus has been described previously. The 50 or 100 µm coated capillaries are filled with 20 mM Tris pH 8.0 and a modified Teflon sleeve fit over and placed in contact with the gel. Tris buffer or deionized water is placed on gel-capillary interface to establish electrical contact. The gel itself is set to common ground with Pt wire, set to positive. Field strength is varied from 100 to 500 V/cm over a 37 cm capillary length. To study the effects a detection window is burned 7 cm from capillary outlet and 214 nm lamp and detector aligned. The outlet end of the capillary can be postioned in a drop of solution or placed on top of a MALDI target (a 20 cm instead of 37 cm capillary is used when a MALDI target is used; note that the entire solution volume of 20 cm long × 100 µm id has an est. vol of 1.5 µl). After extraction, the capillary is fit to a syringe pump and placed on the target at 1.5 µl/min (for 1 min). After drying, 1 µl matrix is pippeted to and allowed to crystallize. Matrix per spot is either 10 µg CHCA in (2:3:1 v/v/v) isopropanol:water:formic acid or in 40:60:0.1 MeOH:water:acetic acid or in 50:50:0.1 MeCN:water:TFA; also 20 µg DHB in 1:9 MeOH:water; or in 10 µg sinapinic acid in MeCN:water:TFA (30:70:0.1). An ABi Voyager DE Linear MALDI-ToF with 50 shots per spectrum was done.

Previous work showed that there is a continuous current drop observed at the capillary-gel interface during protein extraction, caused by a depletion of limited carrying electrolytes. There is also generation of low conductivity solution plug at the capillary extraction end. A higher voltage drop per capillary length occurs across small plug of low conductivity buffer than in the rest of the capillary. This higher electric field strength near extraction end promotes electroelution, but also promotes sample stacking because of the field amplification. Complexes (SDS-protein) move rapidly across the low conductivity drop and halt.

In the system, the gel containing the protein is stained, destained, and then equilibrated with 20 mM Tris before extraction. After 2 min of extraction set at 300 V/cm, the voltage is turned off and the extraction end moved from gel to reservoir with 20 mM Tris buffer. Positive voltage is re-applied and the complexed pushed to the UV detection end. Peak heights increased up to 4 min of extraction time; longer times resulted in tailing of non-stacked proteins.

Raising the field strength continuously from 100-500 V/cm reduced migration time. Peak heights increased with strength and reach a plateau with 300 V/cm. A constant 300 V/cm was used for further work to avoid Joule heating. Peak heights increased 3-fold by varying buffer strength from 20 mM Tris down to deionized water; the de-I water had the effect of causing great stacking and greater extraction.

[continued]

Lamanda A, Zahn A, Röder D, Langen H (2004) Proteomics 4, 599-608.

Improved Ruthenium II Tris (Bathophenanthroline Disulfonate) Staining and Destaining Protocol for A Better Signal-To-Background Ratio and Improved Baseline Resolution

Proteins labeled covalently with fluorescent dyes can be detected with high sensitivity. Noncovalent stains such SYPRO Ruby, along with other SYPRO dyes and ruthenium II tris-bathophenanthroline disulfonate (RuBP) are also effective. RuBP is cheaper and offers several possibilities for improvement compared to SYPRO Ruby.

RuBP was prepared according to Rabilloud et al and the UV/Vis spectral analysis was identical with published spectrum. SYPRO Ruby was from Bio-Rad with a new formulation. Marker proteins were run on 1D 17.5% gels in a serial double dilution in the lanes for sensitivity testing. For 2D gels, pH 3-10 strips are rehydrated 10 h with 300 µl sample in 8 M urea, 2% CHAPS, 18 mM DTE, 0.5% IPG buffer 3-10 and with some bromophenol blue dye in which 80 µg E. coli proteins are present. The focusing program is 200 µA per strip, 150 V for 60 min, 300 V for 1 h, 3500 V for 5 h. These are the analytical strips. The preparative strips have 10-fold more protein in the same volume which are loaded 30 V over 10 h (active rehydration). The 2nd dimension is 12% gel run at 2° for 5 h at 50 mA per gel with a 500 V.

Silver staining was done using the Swain and Ross method with some modifications. Gels are fixed in 40% EtOH/10% acetic acid for at least 2 h (overnight okay), then incubated in 40% EtOH + 10 µl of 37% HCHO for 5 min, washed in 40% EtOH for 20 min, then 20 min in water, then in 0.02% sodium thiosulfate for 1 min, then 0.1% silver nitrate for 20 min, then three times with water for 1 min each (very critical not to overwash!), developed with 2.5% sodium carbonate containing 40 µl formaldehyde per 100 ml) for 4.25 minutes. If the solution turns yellow after the first 1.25 minutes (when spots typically appear), change it quickly with fresh solution of the same volume. Stop with 10% acetic acid containing 0.6% Tris base (leave 5 min). Rinse water for at least 5 min and get an image right away. Store in 1% acetic acid at 4°.

The SYPRO Ruby protocol is typical: gels are fixed in 10% MeOH and 7% acetic acid for 30 min, and then incubated for at least 3 h (overnight might be better), then washed in solvent for 30 min and imaged immediately.

For RuBP, fix in 30% EtOH 10% acetic acid overnight, rinse gel in 20% EtOH for 30 min, repeating 3 times. The 20 mM stock is diluted to a working solution of 100 nM (5 µl in 1 liter 20% EtOH) just before use, and the gel left 6 hours. Wash twice in water for 10 min each, and image immediately. This method is that of Rabilloud et al.

The modified RuBP staining protocol performs the fixing, acid-removal, RuBP staining, and brief water washing steps, but also destains additionally in 40% EtOH + 10% acetic acid for 15 hours, and repeats the brief water washing steps before imaging.

Note that RuBP-stained gels can be stored in water for several days, and even silver-stained additionally.

The silver-stained gels produced uneven staining (not unexpected), whereas the fluorescently stained proteins were quantitative. Peak (cone) volumes over the background levels were calculated to assess quantitative results. The silver stain threshold detection was 2 ng (lactalbumin 14.1 kDa marker), 4 ng for SYPRO Ruby (trypsin inhibitor 20.1 kDa marker), 16 ng for RuBP (carbonic anhydrase 30 kDa marker), and 8 ng for the modified RuBP staining (trypsin inhibitor). Silver stain was the most sensitive, and although SYPRO Ruby was second best, better linearity and more intense signal were seen with RuBP modified protocol. Curiously additional silver staining of modified RuBP produced a 60 kDa artifact stain probably from traces of a detergent used clean glass plates.

Profiling and 2D densitometry were done to characterize signal-to-background. Areas at the upper and lower edge of lanes with no protein represented the background. A signal to background of 60/0.2 for the improved RuBP was found, 7/0.8 for SYPRO Ruby, and 23/3 for standard RuBP staining. Silver staining is impossible to quantitate because of peak saturation (flattened peaks along the lane). Fluorescent staining even with the highest load amounts in a lane never caused peak saturation.

The lesser sensitivity of the modified RuBP procedure compared to SYPRO Ruby is a result of improving contrast (resolution) by washing out the background of RuBP with the extra step. If low abundance proteins are to be detected, the modified staining procedure might fail to detect them. Either shorten or even eliminate the destaining step to improve their detectability.

For 2D gels intended to be compared quantitatively for expression, fluorescence staining should be considered in preference to silver staining. The development of the silver stain is time-dependent and makes gel comparison difficult to impossible. Fluorescent staining depends on equilibration and is independent of time. 2D gels were stained the four ways indicated. Spot number detection was compared: silver found the most at 1000, SYPRO Ruby revealed 650, RuBP found 430, and the modified RuBP found 750. Signal-to-background was determined although visual inspection shows that modified RuBP had the most obvious highest contrast.

Craig R, Beavis RC (2004) Bioinformatics 20, 1466-1467.

TANDEM: Matching Proteins with Tandem Mass Spectra

The fundamental idea of tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is that particular intact peptide parent ion is isolated with one MS and electronic or vibrational energy added to it (such as with collision with argon) and the mass of the resulting fragment ions measured with the 2nd MS. Hopefully most of the signal peaks break along the peptide backbone and the masses reveal the differences in residues, permitting sequencing (only Leu and Ile cannot be distinguished).

Because MS/MS spectrum are not entirely clear, an alternative was developed in which the same information could be compared to the spectra of every known peptide sequence generated from the known proteome of the organism being studied. This sort of analysis cannot be done manually, but software solutions, many commercial, are available although the algorithm is not.

TANDEM is an open source project running from the command line and takes an input XML file. The code is composed of classes that do the following:

  1. read XML input parameters
  2. read protein sequences from FASTA files
  3. read MS/MS spectra in DTA, PKL, and Matrix Science formats (all ASCII)
  4. process the MS/MS psectr to remove noise and artifacts
  5. manipulate peptide sequences with cleavage reagents, and posttranslational and chemical modifications
  6. score peptide sequences
  7. create XML output with the best scoring and statistics relevant to scoring process

Benkenstock K, Sundqvist G, Edlund P-O, Roeraade J (2004) J. Mass Spectrom. 39, 1059-1067.

Influence of Droplet Size, Capillary-Cone Distance and Selected Instrumental Parameters for The Analysis of Noncovalent Protein-Ligand Complexes by Nano-Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. It has been suggested in the literature that nano-electrospray ionization (nano-ESI) mass spectrometry better reflects the equilibrium between complex and free protein in solution than pneumatically assisted electrospray ionization (ESI) in noncovalent interaction studies. However, no systematic studies of the effects of ionization conditions have been performed to support this statement. In the present work, different instrumental and sample-derived parameters affecting the stability of noncovalent complexes during analysis by nano-ESI were investigated. In general, increased values of parameters such as drying gas flow-rate, ion-source temperature, capillary tip voltage and buffer concentration lead to a dissociation of ribonucleaseA(RNAse)cytidine 2-monophosphate (CMP) and cytidine 5-triphosphate (CTP) complexes. The size of the electrosprayed droplets was shown to be an important issue. Increasing the capillary to cone distance yielded an increased complex to free protein ratio when a hydrophilic ligand was present and the reverse effect was obtained with a hydrophobic ligand. Important in this regard is the degree of sampling of ions originating from late-generation residue droplets, that is, ions present in the droplet bulk. Sampling of these ions increases with longer capillarycone distance (flight time). Furthermore, when the sample flow-rate was increased by increasing the capillary internal tip i.d. from 4 to 30 m, a decreased complex to free protein ratio for the RNAseCTP system was observed. This behavior was consistent with the change in surface to volume ratio for flow-rates between 2 and 100 nl min1. Finally, polarity switching between positive and negative ion modes gave a higher complex to free protein ratio when the ligand and the protein had the same polarity.

Russell RB, Alber F, Aloy P, Davis FP, Korkin D, Pichaud M, Topf M, Sali A (2004) Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 14, 313-324.

A Structural Perspective on Protein-Protein Interactions

REVIEW. There are 12,000 known complexes of proteins involving two or more protein chains identified from a variety of organisms. Based on sequence similarity they can be organized into 3500 groups. The most comprehensive info comes from yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae consisting of 6200 proteins, provided by the yeast two-hybrid system and affinity purification followed by MS. It is believed that the yeast may have complexes of proteins with a lower limit of 30,000. The human proteome may have an order of magnitude more.

X-ray crystallography is the gold standard with respect to accuracy and resolution in providing structure of proteins and their complexes. A great many complexes (RNA polymerase, photosystem I and light-harvesting complex of photosystem II, the signal recognition particle complex in nascent protein targeting) have been determined. NMR has been used for larger subunits and can provide info on the residues involved in interactions.

Electron microscopy also provides information through several variants. Single-particle EM, electron tomography, and electron crystallography are ways of looking at two-dimensional arrays of sample. Single particle cryo-EM can look at assemblies of 250-500 kDa with resolutions as high as 5Å. Two-dimensional images are created in a stack or layer from which 3-D projections are computed, capable of showing the structure at any angle/perspective. And sample does not have to be prepared as a crystal or in large quantities. X-ray crystal structures require crystalline samples impossible to attain with macromolecular assemblies.

Protein interactions can be obtained using low resolution experimental techniques. Two-hybrid systems, tagged affinity chromatography, phage display, and synthesis of peptides on cellulose membranes. Biophysical, biochemical, and molecular biology methods include site-directed mutagenesis; forms of footprinting that include hydrogen-deuterium exchange, hydroxyl radical footprinting; chemical crosslinking; fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET); Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FTIR); small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS).

Methods to assess protein-protein docking have been developed. One method generates many possible orientations of two docked proteins using fast Fourier transforms, then ranks them with the hope that the highest ranked one is the native (Katchalski-Katzir et al., 1992 PNAS 89: 2195). Many docking programs are being combined with experimental techniques to assess their ability to predict interactions. Many docking programs include FTDock, 3D-Dock, GRAMM, DOT, ZDOCK, HEX, ICM, and CAPRI.

Often it is possible to predict interaction by using what is known about the structure of interacting domains. Homology searches can be used to determine whether proteins have potential interaction domains when compared to known structures. Specific interaction predicting programs based on homology templates include InterPReTS and ModBase.

Constantini M (2004) Gene 342, 321-325.

An Analyis of Sponge Genomes

S. domuncula (Porifera, Demospongiae, Tetractinomorpha, Hadromerida, Suberitidae) and G. cydonium (Porifera, Demospongiae, Astrophorida, Geodidae) were collected from Bay of Naples at 20 m, with specimens collected in individual bags and kept in seawater basins between 15-20°. DNA was extracted from internally in body (avoids epibionts). 5 g samples ground in liq. nitrogen and dispersed in 10 ml of 0.1 M NaCl, 50 mM EDTA, pH 8. SDS was brought to 2% with 20% stock, and this heated to 60° for 30 min and treated with proteinase K (3 h @ 50°) and then RNase at 37° for 3 h. Phenol/chloroform and chloroform/isoamyl alcohol extracted proteins. Sodium acetate pH 5.9 was added to 3 M and then ethanol pptn. DNA redissolved in 10:50 TE pH 8 and stored 4° EtBr-included 0.7% AGE was used to view DNA. DNA was also separated on a pulsed-field system to estimate weight distribution.

To identify sponge DNA, two sponges are cut into pieces with external layer not used. These are put into filtered seawater in the dark (prevents photosynthetic endobiont growth) for 4 days. Tissue is dissociated into cells and washed in artificial seawater (ASW: 7 mM Na2SO4, 2 mM NaHCO3, 50 mM MgCl2, 10 mM CaCl2, 540 mM NaCl, 10 mM KCl, 20 mM TrisHCl pH 8.2); cell dissociation on 5 g samples of S. domuncula is done in Ca/Mg-free ASW containing EDTA (CMFSW-E), which is just ASW without the calcium and magnesium chloride and supplemented with 20 mM EDTA, with gentle shaking at 20°. For the silicious sponge G. cydonium dissociation is done in 100 µg/ml trypsin, 100 IU/ml penicillin, and 100 µg/ml streptomycin; cells are filtered through a 20 µm nylon mesh. Cells are centrifuged 15 min at 800 g and dispersed in CMFASW-E. Lysis is 4 M GuanSCN, 25 mM sodium citrate pH 7, 0.5% sarcosyl, 0.1 M 2-mercaptoethanol.

Analytical ultracentrifugation of the DNA was done in CsCl gradients run to equilibrium. The speed was 44,000 rpm in the Beckman XL-A with wavelength set to 260 nm; equilibrium is reached in 24 h. GC content was assessed by the Schildkraut et al. relationship:

ρ = (GC × 0.098)/100 + 1.66

Results of ultracentrifugation of genomic DNA of G. cydonium show that it had a greater buoyant density with a peak of ρ = 1.7030 g/cm3, while S. domuncula was ρ = 1.6987. Two additional heavier peaks were observed (at 1.7173 and 1.7253 g/cm3) for G. cydonium, indicating a rather heterogeneous DNA. A previous report indicated that five different densities were apparent, although the profile showed them to be discrete, and the density profile in this study showed a broad range of heterogeneity. S. domuncula showed two additional minor peaks, one heavier and one lighter than the main peak.

The additional peaks have two possible explanations. One is that the DNA truly is heterogeneous. The other is that the DNA is of endosymbiotic organisms, and thus contaminant.

Genomic DNA from purified cells was then analyzed by CsCl ultracentrifugation. For S. domuncula a single peak was clear at 1.6987 g/cm3, corresponding to the second and main peak in DNA harvested from the interior of sponge body. For G. cydonium purified cells, the DNA re-analysis showed a single large peak at 1.7030 g/cm3, again for DNA having the highest peak; two additional but very small peaks relative to the main were also seen. In addition G. cydonium was analyzed on ethidium bromide-containing CsCl gradients, and the peak of 1.7030 g/cm3 was seen with no detection of the smaller peaks.

Baldwin MA (2004) Molec. Cell. Proteomics 3, 1-9.

Protein Identification by Mass Spectrometry

It is vital that there be a non-zero probability that a protein match from a database search. The data quality can not be ignored despite hits being returned from these searches.

Typically the analysis of peptides is the basis for producing data. Proteins are hydrolyzed by trypsin, but only a subset of these peptides are detectable above the noise. Sequence coverage is improved significantly by analysis peptides from more than one type of digest, such as adding chymotrypsin digests in parallel. Factors that affect where a large or small fraction of peptides are detected include the amount of protein in original sample, efficiency of extraction, digest, and peptide extraction, presence of other proteins and impurities, the sensitivity of the mass spectrometer and mode of ionization, mass separation and ion detection. Early implementation of MALDI-TOF provided mass accuracies of ±2 Da, no longer an acceptable standard since the reliability of database searching by limiting possible compositions of peptides for any given mass. Delayed extraction MALDI-ToF in reflectron mode should provide better than 50 ppm accuracy; with careful internal calibration the error is ~10 ppm. ESI-MS is used with single or triple quads or quad ion traps with modest resolution. With a quad mass selection and quad collision cell with orthogonal acceleration ToF (QqTOF) might produce resolution as high as 10,000 with 5 ppm accuracy. FT-MS provides a mass accuracy of about 1 ppm, the ultimate, but these are expensive, technically demanding, and usually only found in large MS facilities.

With the growth of the size of databases, the likelihood of finding an incorrect hit with a mass associated with a high error (100 ppm or greater). The NCBInr has grown by 50% in a year from 2002 to 2003 (having 1.5 million entries at that time). The need to have more peptides above background threshold and larger sequence coverage is important. Moreover, adding CID spectra from MS/MS mode analysis provides tags to narrow the possibilities.

MALDI-ToF with PSD is difficult to collect and the mass accuracy is low and so this is little used. MALDI configured QqTOF and TOF/TOF is a more desirable configuration. Also popular are low-resolution 3-D ion traps which work well with LC-MS/MS; these cannot determine charge states in full-scan mode. Libary searches on this data therefore cover the search range by do analyses assuming one, two, and three protons are attached.

One uncontrolled variable is the choice of database search engine. Searching with PMF and sequence tags, programs for calculating isotope patterns, and predicting digestion are routine.

CID spectra are too complicated to analyze without software scanning. Certain peak picking algorithms are propietary but others have developed mathematical approaches. Such algorithms produce lists of monoisotopic mass and intensity and reduce electronic and random noise. The m/z is defined by the centroid, determined above something like 50%

Chertov O, Biragyn A, Kwak LW, Simpson JT, Boronina T, Hoang VM, Prieto DA, Conrads TP, Veenstra TD, Fisher RJ (2004) Proteomics 4, 1195-1203.

Organic Solvent Extraction of Proteins and Peptides from Serum As An Effective Sample Preparation for Detection and Identification of Biomarkers by Mass Spectrometry

The effect of organic solvent extraction efficiency on the peptides and proteins from serum was analyzed. Acetonitrile was a natural choice since it is miscible and used as a solvent in analytical processes, particularly in mass measurement. Different volume ratios of 0.1% TFA in acetonitrile:serum (1:1, 2:1, 3:1) were investigated using 100 µl serum and 100, 200, 300 µl solvent. Precipitates were centrifuged, and additional volumes were added to collected supernatants. Because there was only one precipitate additionally formed after the initial extraction, it was decided that a 2:1 volume ratio was sufficient to generate all obtainable precipitate. Use of methanol produced a larger but less dense precipitate that was difficult to remove from the supernatant. SDS-PAGE on precipitate extractions of human and mouse serum. High MW proteins were effectively precipitated, but low MW proteins were clearly retained in the supernatant.

Acid hydrolysates of mouse serum proteins retained in the supernatant by doing the 2:1 TFA/MeCN:serum extraction and drying down the supernatant before acid hydrolysis. A control of free amino acids was obtained by analysis of resuspended supernatant which was not acid hydrolyzed, and then subtracting total (acid) from free (no acid) amino acids. The estimate was that there was 40 µg peptide per 100 µl serum, or about 0.6% of total protein, assuming 65 mg total protein per milliliter in mouse serum.

Aliquots of mouse sera and extracts of the sera were analyzed by SELDI-MS, effective at looking at peptides up to 10-15 kDa. The spectrum generated is an image of visual contrast that reveals difference quickly. In particular an extracted sample with mass 9348 Da went undetectable in analysis of whole serum samples. Hence this extraction technique improves detectability of some proteins/peptides as it removes large abundant proteins. Spectra were then generated of sera of tumor-bearing mice to see if markers could be revealed. BALB/c mice had been inoculated with different counts of syngeneic B lymphoma (A20) cells: 25; 2500; 250,000, with the minimal lethal dose being 100,000. Control mice were injected with vehicle (PBS). Sera were collected on day 0, 25, and 40, and 20 µl aliquots precipitated with TFA in MeCN. Spectral analysis revealed that peaks at 8760 and 9340 Da are absent at day 40 in the mice injected with 250,000 cells, and absence correlating with tumor development in the animals. Extracted and unextracted were compared in the sera of these animals both on days 0 and 40. The intensity of a peak at 8762-8768 is significantly reduced.

To identify the proteins of interest, 150 µl serum of control mice was extracted with TFA/MeCN, the extract dried and resuspended for RP-HPLC and fractions run on SDS-PAGE. Bands from the fraction 15 (with two major components) were analyzed by Edman sequencing. One was not sequenceable (N-terminal modification). An aliquot was then digested and and run on MALDI-ToF MS with five peaks indicate a high probability that the 8700 Da protein was apolipoprotein A-II, accounting for the fact that C-terminal Lys is often removed. Analysis by LC-MS/MS also indicated apo A-II. The murine Apo A-II apparently exists as a monomer, while human Apo A-II is a disulfide-linked dimer of two chains with 77 amino acids. If the N-terminal Gln is cyclized to pyroglutamate and the Lys is removed, the theoretical mass is exact to the 8718.81 Da mass in the MALDI.

Jiang L, He L, Fountoulakis M (2004) J. Chromatog. A 1023, 317-320.

Comparison of protein precipitation methods for sample preparation prior to proteomic analysis

ABSTRACT. Protein samples should be free of salt and other disturbing agents and have an appropriate concentration to be suitable for two-dimensional (2D) electrophoresis, the principal step of proteomics. To find the most efficient method for sample preparation, we used human plasma and compared four widely applied precipitation methods, using trichloroacetic acid (TCA), acetone, chloroform/methanol and ammonium sulfate, as well as ultrafiltration. Precipitation with TCA and acetone and ultrafiltration resulted in an efficient sample concentration and desalting. We also found that ammonium sulfate fractionation can efficiently remove albumin, which represents more than 50% of plasma proteins.

Colland F, Daviet L (2004) Biochimie 86, 625-632.

Integrating A Functional Proteomic Approach Into The Target Discovery Process

REVIEW. Protein-protein interactions are being described through tools such as yeast two-hybrid (Y2H) system, protein chips, phage display, or systematic analysis by tandem affinity purification (TAP) and mass spectrometry. But the study of these is a means to the end of discovery targets.

Y2H is a relatively easy way of identifying protein-protein interactions in a high throughput, low cost fashion. It identifies a large number, but not even a majority of interactions, as they must be seen in the yeast nucleus if they occur at all. A significant count of false negatives and positives are likely. Intrinsic limitations of Y2H is possible misfolding and instability of hybrid polypeptides, inappropriate subcellular localization, absence of posttranslational modifications (tyrosine phosphorylation, complex glycosylation). False positives occur when bait proteins are auto-activated such that they start reporter gene transcription without prey, and when prey proteins bind nonspecifically to baits.

Other kinds of screening include the matrix and library formats. The matrix approach takes a collection of predefined open-reading frame products (full-length proteins) and use these as bait and prey for interaction assays. The combination of bait and prey is either individual or in pools. A limitation is that it tests only full-length proteins. With the prey library format, randomly generated prey protein fragments are screened against given bait polypeptide. The interaction map quality is much better and minimizes false negatives. Use of truncated (domain length) rather than full-length proteins maximizes the chance of obtaining properly folded bait and prey and of looking at what really happens in interactions: the binding of domains rather than full-length proteins. With randomly generated prey fragments, the region of overlap helps to narrow down the actual interaction domain.

The library approach has its limitations too. One is the need to prepare highly complex prey fragment libraries for comprehensive coverage of the transcriptome of interest (for rare mRNAs in particular). Another is the technical difficulty and cost of interaction screens required to cover complex libraries exhaustively.

It is important to score each interaction with a certain level of confidence as well. A scoring system called PBS has been shown in several studies to correlate the biological significance of interactions. Other attempts at confidence scoring used only the redundancy of the prey fragments or identified the parameters used in PBS calculation as global predictors in a trained linear model.

PIMRider is a tool which is a web-based graphical interface that visualizes, explores, and analyzes interaction maps from raw interaction networks. It features a ProteinViewer component that annotates a given protein, its sequence, and list of interacting partners; the PIMViewer which shows dynamical graphical view of the interaction network; InteractionViewer, providing access to raw experimental data on prey, bait, and SID sequences; DomainViewer. which shows domains and motifs revealed from experimental (bait and SID) and calculated (transmembrane segments, signal peptides, and InterPro domains). GenoLink from the Genostar Consortium is a graph pattern query engine that builds up queries of protein interactions.

Challapalli KK, Zabel C, Schuchhardt J, Kaindl AM, Klose J, Herzel H (2004) Electrophoresis 25, 3040-3047.

High reproducibility of large-gel two-dimensional electrophoresis

ABSTRACT. Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis (2-DE) facilitates the separation of thousands of proteins from highly complex protein mixtures and has become a central method in proteomics in recent years. In the present study, we examined the technical variability of large 2-DE gels with respect to sample preparation, electrophoresis procedure, data acquisition, and biological variation by analyzing a disease (Huntingtons disease) and control state with a commercially available software package, PROTEOMWEAVER. Scatter plots and correlation coefficients were obtained to quantify both technical and biological variation. Even 2-DE gels run separately in both dimensions yielded correlation coefficients around 0.88 and deviations from the mean close to 20% for lowintensity spots. This indicates a high technical reproducibility of the 2-DE procedure developed in our laboratory. Variability within a biological condition was low and comparable to technical variation (at least 0.87). Two-dimensional (2-D) gels obtained from samples of different biological conditions (health vs. disease) achieved a variability similar to intracondition and technical variability. These findings highlight the importance of multiple gel and spot-by-spot comparisons to identify biological significant changes. Minor errors introduced by technical and biological variation allow a comparison of all gels within a study which facilitates the tackling of complex biological problems.

Digital images were made from silver-stained large format 2D gel. In the figure are the acidic pI 3.5-6 halves of brain extracts of a transgenic mouse that is a Huntington's disease model, and with extracts of a mouse control. Important to this study is how the image was acquired: Umax Mirage-II scanner saved at 16-bit, 200 dpi grayscal TIFF, images analyzed with Definiens PROTEOMWEAVER 1.3 software, with spot detection and gel/spot matching/warping set on automatic.

Gel-to-gel comparisons were done on about 3500 resolved spots. Scatter plots and correlation coefficients were determined by (Xmgrace (available online), data plotted on a log scale and a Perl program used for integration. Mean, SD, and nested t test (difference of means between two groups per standard error of difference) were used in plot analysis. The standard deviation of a pair of spots in gel comparisons was estimated as (|x−y|)/√2 where x and y are spot intensities. 73 comparisons were made of 32 different gel images. Extracts of three different C57Bl/6 mice were pooled and differences between three gels made from the same pooled sample analyzed. The influence of the 2nd dimension was also studied, in addition to repeated scanning to assess differences. 66 comparisons were done for all possible combinations of six control and six HD gels.

The software PROTEOMWEAVER also includes an averaged gel feature, with the standard setting being that when a matched spot is found in at least 50% of the gels, it will be present in the average gel. Spot matching itself was set to indicate matching when spot centers fall within a 250 pixel radius of each other.

Results. Pixelation is the assignment of the pixels to a spot during scanning; scanner cleanliness clearly contributes to variability in scanning procedures. Single pairs of gels contained about 3500 spots able to be matched. Plots of spot intensity data on a linear scan with regression analysis revealed an r = 0.988. Plotted on a log scale, greater variability was revealed in spots with lower intensities: below an intensity of 0.1, the scatter in the log plot was obvious. A plot of the coefficient of variation (CV = std dev/mean) against the mean spot intensities shows that CV is 20% at the lower intensities and 5% at the higher. For the log plot r = 0.952 to reveal the effect of variation in the lower intensities. Nonetheless the log plot showed reproducibility of scanning was adequate over 3 orders of magnitude. Another possibility with respect to spot intensity calculation is variability introduced by the software in how to include pixels in a spot during detection or variations in digitization of spots during image file creation. Redetection and matching by the software of the same gel raw image showed variation in the lower intensity spots. Nonetheless, the variation introduced here is insignificant to other technical and biological variation.

Several gels of the same sample were then run. Brain extracts of three male mice were pooled. A scatter plot of spot intensities (gel 2 vs gel 1) was made and the r = 0.926 found over three orders of magnitude. A plot of CV vs. mean spot intensity now reveals that the CV is raised at the higher intensities, but that the CV running average is only about 20%, 10% at the higher intensities. This variability is termed multiplicative and is seen with DNA chips as well.

Ways to limit the variables that can introduce significant variability in the production of 2D gel data include using the same technician or a standardized method, preparation of chemicals in large batches and/or from the same commercial lots.

Gels were then analyzed with respect to a grouping of homogeneous samples (health or disease). Six gels from male 8 week CBA × C57BI/6 controls and those with transgenic HD models (R6/2) were used. 12 gels allowed for 66 paired comparisons. In additions, 15 control-control and R6/2-R6/2 matches were done as this determines the biological background variation. Plot of CV vs. mean spot intensity show that the relative error was about 20% for all spot intensities. Estimations of standard deviations from just two measurements is not good. Running averages for 100 serial points were determined and the average correlation coefficients ranged from 0.87-0.89, somewhat smaller than those of pooled sample of with r = 0.93. Average correlation of all 15 control-control comparisons was 0.88, and that for the diseased-diseased was 0.87. r values were slightly better for 2nd dimension runs that were run in the same run (buffer + gel cast) than for those with different runs (buffer + gel cast). Thus most variability was biological rather than technical.

Matching spot intensities from a large 2D gels of HD vs. control were plotted and the r = 0.877 found. This is remarkable given that only a very few proteins are differentially expressed. Hence in diseased and healthy tissues, high abundance and/or housekeeping proteins do not alter their expression significantly.

To reduce group heterogeneity, gel averaging was done as a step toward automated analysis. In doing single gel pairing, 3500 spots were matched. With three gels used in creating an average gel, spot matching is 1700. With 6 gels used in the average, the reduction in spots is 460, with very low intensity spots missing entirely from the gel, since matching occurs in only a minority of cases. Since most spots are of low intensity, this means elimination of those spots from consideration.

Bashir S, Mutter R, Derrick PJ (2004) Eur. J. Mass Spectrom. 10, 487-493.

Parameterizing Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization: Effects of Solvents and Co-Additives on Analyte Peak Intensities

DHB spotting properties depend on solvent system used. In MeOH/water, small crystals form, and in DMF these crystals are slightly larger (viewed using optical microscope). The ratio of [DBH-OH + H]+/[DHB + Na]+ for plain laser desorption and matrix-assisted laser-desorption (NLDI and MALDI) was determined for various solvent systems. No clear pattern could be seen with respect to the solvent used except that the solvent used affected LDI but not MALDI. Use of DMF seemed to give higher peak intensities in work with MALDI of substance P and betacyclodextrin.

Besides use of particular solvents, co-additives also help. Adding 2-hydroxy-5-methoxybenzoic acid (HMBA) disrupts the DHB crystallization and improves matrix-analyte mixing. DHB may coordinate by hydrogen bonding to the analyte. Breaking of the H-bonds is useful and can be assisted by use of DMF.

Huang R-H, Wang D-C (2004) J. Chromatog. B 803, 167-172.

Mass spectrometric strategy for primary structure determination of N-terminally blocked peptides

EAFP1 and EAFP2 are antifungal peptides previously purified and blocked to Edman sequencing. Rather sequencing was attempted from the C-terminus end. Patterson et al previously presented the use of C-terminal ladder sequencing using MALDI-MS. This successfully found the sequence of 19 C-terminal residues. Only a few peaks are present at a short CPY digestion time; the low rate of CPY digestion is attributed largely to the high amount of glycyl residues in these peptides. Sequence determinations were for EAFP1 RCPRPCNAGLCCSIYG..gSGNAYcgAGNCRCQCRG and for EAFP2 nagLCCSIYGY..SgAAYC...NCRCQCRG. Lowercase letters represent residues identified in spectra of different CPY quenching time, and the dots are gaps unidentified in the mass spectra. Generally sequences can be read down to about 600 Da, where the matrix CHCA ions begin to interfere with reading. An advantage of CPY is its sensitivity (use of very small amounts of sample). A disadvantage is that it is quite sequence-dependent and additional methods to confirm results are often necessary.

This confirmation of C-terminal sequencing by CPY can come in the form of protease enzyme selection based on the sequencing results. EAFP1 and EAFP2 both contain sites amenable to trypsin cleavage. After trypsin treatment and HPLC separation, peptides were measured on MALDI-MS and then Edman sequencing. Results were used to build the final sequences (EAFP1: RCPRPCNAGLCCSIYGYCGSGNAYCGAGNCRCQCRG, EAFP2: RCPRPCNAGLCCSIYGYCGSGAAYCGAGNCRCQCRG). Indeed more peaks in the HPLC were observed than expected for trypsin cleavage, probably because of trypsin impurity. One peptide with MALDI-MS mass of 704 Da eluting at 12 min in the HPLC was resistant to Edman sequencing and is likely the N-terminal peptide. The tandem FTICR MS/MS was used to read the monoisotopic masses ([M + H+]). Parent ion mass was 705.2997 Da. Y-series ion masses could be read easily. A sequence of PyroGul-Thr-Cys-Ala-Ser-Arg was determined. There was a 10 Da difference observed between calculated and experimental average masses of the EAFP1 and EAFP2 peptides. The calculated mass is higher probably because of the 10 protons on Cys residues that would be removed if five disulfide bridges were formed.

Methods. Peptides are routinely reductively alkylated. Generally 100 µg peptide are dissolved in 100 µl of 0.1 M TrisHCl pH 8.3 buffer containing 6 M guanidine HCl. DTT is added to a 100:1 molar ratio under nitrogen gas at 37° for 30 min, and then iodoacetamide at 500:1 molar ration under nitrogen gas 37° for 4 h. The mixture is diluted to 1 ml and cleaned on reversed phase (Waters YWG-PAK C18, 3.9 × 250 mm) with 5-45% MeCN in 0.1% TFA linear gradient for 60 min.

CPY digestion is done as described by Patterson et al. 500 pmol peptide is suspended in 20 µl water and 160 mU CPY (Sigma) in 30 µl water. These are then mixed at 37° to produce a 10 pmol peptide and 3.2 mU CPY per microliter concentration. 1 µl aliquots are removed at 20 and 60 seconds, 2, 5, 10, and 30 minutes, and 2 and 16 hours for 8 time points. Each aliquot is mixed immediately with 9 µl CHCA saturated in 50% MeCN + 0.1% TFA, and 1 µl of these are placed on target wells.

A Bruker Proflex III MALDI-MS was used for MALDI-MS and a ABi 491 sequencer for Edman degradation. A Bruker APEX II FTICR mass spectrometer is used for mass measurement. 500 pmol peptide is dissolved in 25 µl 50% MeOH with 2% acetic acid and injected at 30 µl per hour. MS/MS fragment ions are generated with 3500 µs argon gas pulse at 1 mbar

Bafna V, Reinert K (2004)      

Mass Spectrometry and Computational Proteomics

The mass spectrometer has a source for producing molecular ions in the gas phase (MALDI, ESI) and then a mass analyzer for measuring mass: ion trap, ToF, quadrupole, fourier transform.

Fragmentation in CID MS is a stochastic process. Properties of the peptide and collision energy are important. Ions in the a, b, c refer to ionized N-terminal fragments while x, y, z ions are C-terminal fragments. The most common ions are a, b, and y.

Bayesian probabilistic models are used to assign a likelihood of a sequence based on peptide fragment masses. Data is analyzed in three modules: interpretation, filtering, and scoring. In interpretation, the MS/MS spectrum data are input and an interpreted spectrum is output. Parent peptide mass, partial or complete sequence tags, and combinations of tags are used. In filtering the interpreted spectrum and a peptide sequence database are brought together, and those peptides not in the database that match a mass closely are removed, and a small list of candidates remains that is most likely to represent the spectrum. A scoring module takes the candidate peptide list and then ranks and scores the peptides in the list. The highest scoring peptide is returned, possibly with a p value of significance.

Starting with the MS/MS spectrum, interpretation is any sequence information obtained from it. Interpretation is done without assistance from a peptide database comparison, as in filtering. A spectrum might be composed of b ions and their intensities used to locate them. One problem is that spectra are not just composed of the fragments of interest. There are internal fragments and ions with different charge states, and some peptide bonds do not fragment. The use of a prefix residue graph and creation of a list of prefix-suffix pairs that are possible and impossible is done.

In referring to a database of all combinations of peptides, the actual spectrum and a hypothetical spectrum are correlated, a technique used regularly in database searches of proteins. SEQUEST works by generating a hypothetical spectrum, then scores it against the actual spectrum. In scoring, a raw numerical score and a significance (p) value are given. SCOPE is a probabilistic model for scoring tandem mass spectra against a peptide database. Scoring improvements have been made given conditions such as neutral loss more likely when acidic or basic residues present, or when there is Pro-directed fragmentation.

Filtering scans a database of peptide candidates and removes the vast majority of those peptides not likely to account for the spectrum. Simple filters for parent mass, immonium ions, matching peaks are used. One useful approach is the use of suffix trees with respect to pre-indexing sequence databases. Sequence tags are often used as filters in the database search.

Peptides that elute from LC system to MS as a detector have their spectra collected as elution occurs (real time).

Henkin JA, Jennings ME, Matthews DE, Vigoreaux JO (2004) J. Biomolec. Tech. 15, 230-237.

Mass Processing—An Improved Technique for Protein Identification with Mass Spectrometry Data

ABSTRACT. Matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry analysis following tryptic digestion of polyacrylamide gel pieces is a common technique used to identify proteins. This approach is rapid, sensitive, and user friendly, and is becoming widely available to scientists in a variety of biological fields. Here we introduce a simple and effective strategy called mass processing where the list of masses generated from a mass spectrometer undergoes two stages of data reduction before identification. Mass processing improves the ability to identify in-gel tryptic-digested proteins by reducing the number of nonsample masses submitted to protein identification database search engines. Our results demonstrate that mass processing improves the statistical score and rank of putative protein identifications, especially with low-quantity samples, thus increasing the ability to confidently identify proteins with mass spectrometry data.

Vollmer M, Hörth P, Nägele E (2004) Anal. Chem. 76, 5180-5185.

Optimization of Two-Dimensional Off-Line LC/MS Separations To Improve Resolution of Complex Proteomic Samples

ABSTRACT. In off-line 2D-HPLC a continuous salt gradient is applied in the first separation dimension. This increases the number of identified proteins from complex samples significantly due to higher chromatographic resolution compared to stepwise elution. Achievement of optimal resolution requires the optimization of the two separation dimensions. The influence of LC elution gradients in the first and second dimensions, of analysis time, of stationary- phase material, and of column dimensions was systematically investigated in order to obtain information on the overall peak capacity of the separation system. Provided data indicate that for complex samples such as an E. coli cell extract, a shallow LC SCX gradient with a high number of collected fractions significantly increases the overal peak capacity while for lower complexity samples short gradients with few fractions were sufficient to obtain a maximum of identified peptides. In addition, column dimensions and materials exihibited a strong effect on the overall efficiency of the 2D HPLC separation. The outcome of these experiments could hence serve as a guideline for investigators to adapt their method for the separation of their specific proteome sample to achieve a maximum of peptide sequence information by 2D LC MS/MS analysis.

Samples of a digest of 10 bovine proteins and an E coli lysate were used to test the SCX gradient comparison in a 2DLC system. The SCX is a 0.3 × 35 mm with 3.5 µm particles. A 0-100 mM NaCl gradient programmed for 15, 30, 60, and 120 min were tried, with a steep short ramp to 500 mM in 2.5, 5, 10, and 20 min, respectively. The SCX column resolution is good even for a 120 min gradient. Runs were done in triplicate and the average relative std deviations of amount of identified peptides and proteins were 3 and 6%, respectively. For E coli lysate proteins, the peptide and protein rel std dev were 4.3 and 9.8% on peptide and protein level.

Column dimensions is important feature.

Benkestock K, Sundqvist G, Edlund P-O, Roeraade J (2004) J. Mass Spectrom. 39, 1059-1067.

Influence of droplet size, capillary-cone distance and selected instrumental parameters for the analysis of noncovalent proteinligand complexes by nano-electrospray ionization mass spectrometry

ABSTRACT. It has been suggested in the literature that nano-electrospray ionization (nano-ESI) mass spectrometry better reflects the equilibrium between complex and free protein in solution than pneumatically assisted electrospray ionization (ESI) in noncovalent interaction studies. However, no systematic studies of the effects of ionization conditions have been performed to support this statement. In the present work, different instrumental and sample-derived parameters affecting the stability of noncovalent complexes during analysis by nano-ESI were investigated. In general, increased values of parameters such as drying gas flow-rate, ion-source temperature, capillary tip voltage and buffer concentration lead to a dissociation of ribonucleaseA(RNAse)cytidine 2′-monophosphate (CMP) and cytidine 5′-triphosphate (CTP) complexes. The size of the electrosprayed droplets was shown to be an important issue. Increasing the capillary to cone distance yielded an increased complex to free protein ratio when a hydrophilic ligand was present and the reverse effect was obtained with a hydrophobic ligand. Important in this regard is the degree of sampling of ions originating from late-generation residue droplets, that is, ions present in the droplet bulk. Sampling of these ions increases with longer capillarycone distance (flight time). Furthermore, when the sample flow-rate was increased by increasing the capillary internal tip i.d. from 4 to 30 m, a decreased complex to free protein ratio for the RNAseCTP system was observed. This behavior was consistent with the change in surface to volume ratio for flow-rates between 2 and 100 nl min1. Finally, polarity switching between positive and negative ion modes gave a higher complex to free protein ratio when the ligand and the protein had the same polarity.

Zehl M, Allmaier G (2004) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 18, 1932-1938.

Ultraviolet Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry of Intact Hemoglobin Complex from Whole Human Blood

Fresh human blood from fingertip pricks were diluted in 20 mM ammonium acetate or in 0.1% TFA (latter for subunit and cluster ion formation) with dilution factors of 1:50, 1:100, 1:500, 1:1000 and 1:5000 for effective Hb concentrations of 46, 23, 4.6, 2.3, and 0.46 µM. Diluted blood was mixed with 0.17 M ferulic acid in EtOH in 7:3 ratio (Houston and Reilly), and 0.5 µl applied to steel target, dried under RT under air stream. For other spotting: 0.5, 1.0, or 1.5 µl sample is mixed with equal volume satd 2,6-DHAP in 25% MeCN in 20 mM ammonium acetate, and another was satd 2,6-DHAP in 25% MeCN in 0.1% TFA, using dried droplet.

Solution acidity leads to dissociation of noncovalent complexes. 2,6-DHAP is less acidic a matrix than cinnamic acid. When used with TFA, Hb subunits are fully dissociated. The α and β subunits could be resolved well (resolution is 1518 and 1785 for alpha and beta chains respectively). The theoretical mass of HbA is 15216.36 and HbB is 15867.22 Da (apoprotein) and the experimental is 15216.45 and 15867.22, mass differences of 6.4 and 0 ppm!

Cluster ions formed, with decreasing intensity as to size of cluster.

Freeman WM, Hemby SE (2004) Neurochem. Res. 29, 1065-1081.

Proteomics for Protein Expression Profiling in Neuroscience

ABSTRACT. As the technology of proteomics moves from a theoretical approach to a practical reality, neuroscientists will have to determine the most appropriate applications for this technology. Neuroscientists will have to surmount difculties particular to their research, such as limited sample amounts, heterogeneous cellular compositions in samples, and the fact that many proteins of interest are rare, hydrophobic proteins. This review examines protein isolation and protein fractionation and separation using two-dimensional electrophoresis (2-DE) and mass spectrometry proteomic methods. Methods for quantifying relative protein expression between samples (e.g., 2-DIGE, and ICAT) are also described. The coverage of the proteome, ability to detect membrane proteins, resource requirements, and quantitative reliability of different approaches is also discussed. Although there are many challenges in proteomic neuroscience, this eld promises many rewards in the future.

Kreil D, Karp NA, Lilley KS (2004) Bioinformatics 20, 2026-2034.

DNA microarray normalization methods can remove bias from differential protein expression analysis of 2D difference gel electrophoresis results

ABSTRACT Motivation: Two-dimensional Difference Gel Electrophoresis (DIGE) measures expression differences for thousands of proteins in parallel. In contrast to DNA microarray analysis, however, there have been few systematic studies on the validity of differential protein expression analysis, and the effects of normalization methods have not yet been investigated. To address this need, we assessed a series of samesame comparisons, evaluating how random experimental variance influenced differential expression analysis. Results: The strong fluctuations observed were reflected in large discrepancies between the distributions of the spot intensities for different gels. Correct normalization for pooling of multiple gels for analysis is, therefore, essential. We show that both dye-specific background levels and the differences in scale of the spot intensity distributions must be accounted for. A variance stabilizing transform that had been developed for DNA microarray analysis combined with a robust Z -score allowed the determination of gel-independent signal thresholds based on the empirical distributions from same same comparisons. In contrast, similar thresholds holding up to cross-validation could not be proposed for data normalized using methods established in the field of proteomics.

Yang Z, Hancock WS (2004) J. Chromatog. A 1053, 79-88.

Approach to The Comprehensive Analysis of Glycoproteins Isolated from Human Serum Using A Multi-Lectin Affinity Columnh

ABSTRACT. Glycosylation is one the most common post-translational modifications (PTM) and glycoproteins play fundamental roles in a diversity of biological processes. The development of an analytical approach to the study of variation of glycosylation patterns in serum samples has been hindered by the structural heterogeneity of this post-translational modification and the complexity of serum proteome.We have used the ability of different lectins to recognize specific glycosylation motifs to develop a specific affinity system that can achieve a comprehensive capture of serum glycoproteins. In a preliminary investigation, we evaluated the ability of five commonly used immobilized lectins to capture glycoproteins from human serum. SDS-PAGE analysis showed each lectinwas able to enrich a subset of the serum glycoproteome and overlaps in lectin specificity were indeed observed. Based on these results and with the goal of studying the extent of the human serum glycoproteome, we then developed a multi-lectin affinity column containing Concanavalin A (Con A), Wheat germ and Jacalin lectin. The selection of lectins was also based on the known N-linked and O-linked glycan structures that are considered representative of the serum proteome. We then demonstrated that the capture of glycoproteins was specific, efficient and reproducible with this multi-lectin column. The results obtained with this affinity step indicated that about 10% of human serum proteins are glycosylated (weight/weight) and, after removal of six high abundance proteins, including albumin, at least 50% of the remaining proteins were glycosylated. We then evaluated the use of this affinity column to monitor changes in the pattern of glycosylation in serum samples by a controlled, stepwise release of the captured proteins from the multi-lectin affinity column with specific displacers.

Cooper JW, Lee CS (2004) Anal. Chem. 76, 2196-2202.

Integrated and Ultrasensitive Gel Protein Identification

Milligram amounts of protein can be loaded and separated on 2D-PAGE. Gygi et al reported that current gel/MS identification identifies only the most abundant proteins despite 1500 Ag-stained spots in a narrow pH range. Regulatory proteins typically are undetectable because less than 100 copies are present in a cell.

A system that combines electronic protein transfer with in situ proteolysis was designed to permit ultrasensitive identification. A continuous current drop is monitored during the protein extraction period which indicates depletion of limited electrolytes at the capillary/gel interface and the generation of a low-conductivity solution plug at the extraction end of the capillary. Elution is promoted by the high voltage drop across the low conductivity buffer, and sample stacking is also achieved. Modified Coomassie Blue and SYPRO Red staining were developed to enhance visualization on low protein loadings. Electronic transfer was done for 2 min for 3 model protein (cytochrome c, 14 kDa; ovalbumin, 45 kDa; β-galactosidase, 116 kDa) with gel loadings from 5 µg down to 1 ng. The peak height and concentration decrease proportionally with decreases in protein loading. If deionized water is used at the capillary/gel interface both the protein concentration and recovery increase 4- to 10-fold, resp.

Use of the electronic capillary extraction technique with modified SYPRO Red staining enable visualization and extraction as low as 1 ng and with 90% recovery of proteins. PVDF membrane was placed inside a commonly used capillary fitting to serve as a miniaturized trypsin membrane reactor. Trypsin is immobilized on to the porous membrane. As protein substrate passes, it is digested, and fragments directly loaded to MALDI target plates. As little as 1 ng of ovalbumin (22 fmol) and β-galactosidase (8 fmol) could be evaluated. In an old paper by Gygi et al, 14 of 58 predicted yeast proteins were identified and were high abundance proteins, with CAI values > 0.2. Using this concentration/extraction technique, 11 additional, 8 of them low-abundance with CAI < 0.2 were identified. These include RNA polymerase I-specific transscription initiation factor. 10 low-abundance proteins were actually predicted for the cut-out region, and 4 of them were found using this sampling technology.

Canelle L, Pionneau C, Marie A, Bousquet J, Bigeard J, Lutomski D, Kadri T, Caron M, Joubert-Caron R (2004) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 18, 2785-2794.

Automating Proteome Analysis: Improvements in Throughput, Quality, and Accuracy of Protein Identification by Peptide Mass Fingerprinting

ABSTRACT. The use of robots has major effects on maximizing the proteomic workflow required in an increasing number of high-throughput projects and on increasing the quality of the data. In peptide mass finger printing (PMF), automation of steps downstream of two-dimensional gel electrophoresis is essential. To achieve this goal, the workflow must be fluid. We have developed tools using macros written in Microsoft Excel and Word to complete the automation of our platform. Additionally, because sample preparation is crucial for identification of proteins by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ ionization (MALDI) mass spectrometry, we optimized a sandwich method usable by any robot for spotting digests on a MALDI target. This procedure enables further efficient automated washing steps directly on the MALDI target. The success rate of PMF identification was evaluated for the automated sandwich method, and for the dried-droplet method implemented on the robot as recommended by the manufacturer. Of the two methods, the sandwich method achieved the highest identification success rate and sequence coverage of proteins.

Karp NA, Kreil DP, Lilley KS (2004) Proteomics 4, 1421-1432.

Determining a significant change in protein expression with DeCyder during a pair-wise comparison using two-dimensional difference gel electrophoresis

ABSTRACT. Two-dimensional difference gel electrophoresis (DIGE) is a tool for measuring changes in protein expression between samples involving pre-electrophoretic labeling with cyanine dyes. Here we assess a common method to analyze DIGE data using the DeCyder software system. Experimental error was studied by a series of same sample comparisons. Aliquots of sample were labeled with N-hydroxyl succinimidyl ester-derivatives of Cy2, Cy3, and Cy5 dyes and run together on one gel. This allowed assessment of how experimental error influenced differential expression analysis. Bias in the log volume ratios was observed, which could be explained by differences in dye background. Further complications are caused by significant gel-to-gel variation in the spot volume ratio distributions. Using DeCyder alone results in an inability to define ratio thresholds for 90 or 95% confidence. An alternative normalization method was thus applied which resulted in improved data distribution and allowed greater sensitivity in analysis. When combined with a standardizing function, this allowed gel-independent thresholds for 90% confidence. The new approach, detailed here, represents a method to greatly improve the success of DIGE data analysis.

Halligan BD, Ruotti V, Jin W, Laffoon S, Twigger SN, Dratz EA (2004) Nucl. Acids Res. 32, W638-W644.

ProMoST (Protein Modification Screening Tool): a web-based tool for mapping protein modifications on two-dimensional gels

ABSTRACT. ProMoST is a flexible web tool that calculates the effect of single or multiple posttranslational modifications (PTMs) on protein isoelectric point (pI) and molecular weightanddisplays the calculated patterns as two-dimensional (2D) gel images. PTMs of proteins control many biological regulatory and signaling mechanisms and 2D gel electrophoresis is able to resolve many PTM-induced isoforms, such as those due to phosphorylation, acetylation, deamination, alkylation, cysteine oxidation or tyrosine nitration. These modifications cause changes in the pI of the protein by adding, removing or changing titratable groups. Proteins differ widely in buffering capacity and pI and therefore the same PTMs may give rise to quite different patterns of pI shifts in different proteins. It is impossible by visual inspection of a pattern of spots on a gel to determine which modifications aremost likely tobepresent.ThepatternsofPTM shifts for different proteins can be calculated and are often quite distinctive. The theoretical gel images produced by ProMoST can be compared to the experimental 2D gel results to implicate probable PTMs and focus efforts on more detailed study of modified proteins. ProMoST has been implemented as cgi script in Perl available on a WWW server at http:// proteomics.mcw.edu/promost.

Wang D, Park JS, Chu JSF, Krakowsik A, Luo K, Chen DJ, Li S (2004) J. Biol. Chem. 279, 43725-43734.

Proteomic Profiling of Bone Marrow Mesenchymal Stem Cell upon Transforming Growth Factor β1 Stimulation

Bone marrow stem cells are nonhematopoietic pluripotent stromal cells which can expand in culture and differentiate to osteoblasts, chondrocytes, adipocytes, skeletal and smooth muscle cells in response to microenvironmental cues. TGF-β1 are multifunctional proteins regulating growth, differentiation, migration, ECM production. TGF-β increases smooth muscle α-actin in MSCs, but will induce chondrocyte differentiation in presence of dexamethasone or cell aggregates. Thus the effect depends on microenvironmental cues not understood.

Proteomics is a systematic approach for the quantiative and qualitative mapping of the whole proteome. 2D-PAGE is done because of its ease of use and rapidity.

Human bone marrow MSCs were purchased and characterized by the company: positive for CD105, CD166, CD29, CD44; negative for CD34, CD14, CD45. The company supplied the medium and FBS (MSCGM medium). Detached expansions of cells were washed with PBS with 1% BSA for 30 min, then FITC-conjugated antibodies to CD14, CD34, CD45, CD105, and CD166 incubated for 30 min before characterization on Beckman-Coulter EPICS XL flow cytometer. Antibodies to CD29 and CD44 were incubated for 30 min followed by 30 min with FITC-conjugated 2nd antibody and then flow cytometry; negative controls were cells incubated only with FITC-2nd Ab. Antibodies and FITC-antibodies came from many vendors (Santa Cruz Biotech, BD Biosci, Chemicon, Serotec, BIOSOURCE, and Molecular Probes). Sigma TGF-β1 at 10 ng/ml was used for treatment (5 and 20 ng/ml were tried with same effect). Medium was changed every 2-3 d for longer incubations. For immunostaining and confocal work, cells were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS 15 min, permeabilized with 0.5% TritonX-100 in PBS 10 min. Antibodies to gelsolin, α-actin, and FLAG tag were incubated 2 h and then FITC- or rhodamine-conj. 2nd for 1 h. F-actin was stained with rhodamine-phalloidin 30 min. The Leica TCL SL confocal with Ar and He/Ne laser, a scanner and the Leica DM IRB microscope were used. Projection planes were 0.3 µm thick. Immunoblots were prepared in cells lysed with 25 mM TrisHCl pH 7.4, 0.5 M NaCl, 1% TX-100, 0.1% SDS, 1 mM PMSF, 10 µg/ml leupeptin, and 1 mM sodium vanadate; with supernatants run on SDS-PAGE, transferred to NC membrane, blocked (3% nonfat milk), and primary Ab incubated in Tris-buffered saline with 0.05% Tween-20 and 0.1% BSA; goat anti-mouse or anti-rabbit IgG-HRP with ECL detection used.

Cells passaged and expanded up to 10 times were used. MSCs at passage 10 were positive for CD105, CD166, CD29, and CD44 but negative for CD14, CD45, and CD34, indicating no change in phenotype. Cells cultured 2 weeks in chondrogenic medium became rounded and synthesized large amounts of glycosaminoglycans, indicating chondrogenic potential. Cells in osteogenic medium for 2 weeks stained with Alizarin Red indicating matrix mineralization.
