Cells were treated long term with TGF-β. After 2 d, MSC show a more polygonal broad shape with myoblast-like morphology and which was maintained by 6 d. The fibrous-like appearance stained positive for actin filaments and thick fibers. Immunoblotting indicated a quantitative increase in α-actin while total actin was not changed; tubulin expression was seen to be constant (internal control). TGF-β was seen to affect SM α-actin and SM-22α at transcriptional level.

Proteome characterization involved 2D-PAGE and characterization of select silver-stained proteins, determined by treated and untreated cells. 1500 spots were resolved (confidence > 95%), and 60 showed up- or down-regulation by >2-fold in triplicate studies of 4-day treated cells. 30 of the spots were selected for identification using in-gel digestion and LC-MS/MS on Q-ToF API US from Waters. The LC system was a 20 µl/min with pre-concentration on 300 µm × 5 mm PepMap C18 (Dionex) with peptides eluted to 75 µm × 15 cm PepMap C18 analytical. Buffer A is 3% MeCN + 0.1% formic acid and Solvent B is 95% MeCN + 0.1% FA; the program is loading with Solvent A and elution with 3-40% gradient of Solvent B over 35 min at 0.25 µl/min, achieved by flow splitting pumps A and B running at 8 µl/min. A PicoTip emitter (New Objectives) was used to direct eluent to ESI source. The MS had source temp of 100° with 40 V on the cone; the PicoTip was set at 2000 V. The ToF was in V mode. Calibration was of Glu-fibrinopeptide B fragment ions obtained by CID. MS/MS were obtained by directed data acquisition mode in which peaks with z= +2, +3, +4 with highest intensity were selected for CID, collision energies set at 10 and 30V for MS and MS/MS scans. The NCBI nrdb (non-redundant database) with masses from 1000-500,000 Da and pI 3-10 were selected; modifications set for Cys (carbamidomethylation), N-terminus (acetylation), N-Gln (to pyro-Glu), Met (oxidation), and Ser/Thr/Tyr (phosphorylation). Predicted MW and pI of the 30 spots using Z3 program agreed with theoretical values (±10%). Proteins affected by TGF-β include cytoskeletal proteins gelsolin, T-plastin (and an isoform), γ-actin and α-cardiac actin. A series of annexin molecules (cell membrane bound). Matrix synthesis proteins: collagen-binding protein 2 precursors and isoforms. Metabolic enzymes change include GA3P DH, thioredoxin reductase, malate DH, Tyr-tRNA synthetase. TGF-β also modulates post-translational modifications, e.g. HSP27 phosphorylation at Ser-82. Both ProteinLynx and MASCOT agreed on protein spot identity and scoring; two peptides were sequenced with good MS/MS spectra. Some spots had more than one protein co-migrating.

Gelsolin expression was reduced by TGF-β according to the 2D gel. Gelsolin severs actin, disrupting the cytoskeleton, but having roles in cell motility and apotosis. Its role in differentiation is unknown. A time course study indicates expression falling off with 4-6 d growth factor treatment. qPCR was used to study transcriptional regulation. After 24 h, gene expression decreases by 50% for gelsolin, with α-actin up 4-fold. At 48 h, the trend continues, indicating TGF-β alters both proteins through transcription. Immunocytohistochemistry of 4 d treated and untreated cells shows gelsolin in untreated cells co-localized with actin (a weak background in cytoplasm).

Olsen JV, Ong S-E, Mann M (2004) Molec. Cell. Proteomics 3, 608-614.

Trypsin Cleaves Exclusively C-Terminal to Arginine and Lysine Residues

Proteins were extract from young mouse liver (3 wk old male). Tissue was crushed with mortar and pestle under liquid nitrogen and resolublized with 6 M urea (Invitrogen), 2 M thiourea (Fluka), 3-[(3-cholamidopropyl)dimethylammonio]-1-propanesulfonate (CHAPS, Invitrogen), and protease inhibitors (Complete Tablet, Roche). Benzonase (Roche) was added to degrade DNA and RNA, left on ice 30 min. Sample was spun 10,000 g to get a supernatant. 90 µg protein was run on a 4-12% Bis-Tris gel (Novex, Invitrogen), stained with colloidal Coomassie. The lane was cut to 10 equally sized pieces and in-gel tryptic digestion done: piece were destained, washed, reductively alkylated (DTT/iodoacetamide), and digested with Promega trypsin overnight/37°. Extraction was with 30% MeCN/0.3% TFA, followed by vacuum evaporation. Peptides are desalted and concentrated on C18 StageTips. Nanoflow LC-MS/MS is on a 7 T ThermoElectron Finnigan LTQ-FT MS, using Agilent 1100 nanoflow system (degasser, nanoflow pump, thermostated-microautosampler. A 75 µm × 20 cm capillary was packed with MeOH slurry of 3 µm Repro-Sil-Pur C18-AQ at 50 bar under helium. 6 µl of the tryptic mix was autosampled with 500 nl/min flow for 20 min, eluted with 90 min gradient from 4-40% MeCN in 0.5% acetic acid at 200 nl/min. The mass spec switches from MS to MS/MS mode in data-dependent way, with survey from m/z 300-1500 in FTICR with r=25,000 at m/z 400. Three most intense ion sequentially isolated by FTICR SIM scan consisting of 10-Da mass range, r=50,000 and target accum. value = 50,000. These are fragmented in linear ion trap using CID with normalized collision energy of 30% and target value = 2000. Former target ions selected for MS/MS were dynamically excluded for 30 s, and total cycle time was 3 s. 4755 MS/MS mass spectra were acquired. Identification involved searching the Mouse International Protein Index protein sequence database (v. 2.18 with 40k+ sequences, curated by European Bioinformatics Institute; http://www.ebi.ac.uk/IPI/) which includes SWISSPROT, TrEMBL, RefSeq, and Ensembl and the contaminants porcine trypsin and human keratins. Fixed modifs were carbamidomethyl Cys and variable modifs were oxid Met and N-acetylation. Tolerances were 3 ppm for MS and 0.8 Da for MS/MS peaks. MASCOT was set for "ESI-Trap".

Mouse liver proteins were run on SDS-PAGE (1D gel), and 10 equally spaced bands excised. Highest apparent molecular mass was selected for proteomic analysis. FTICR-MS can have very high mass accuracies in low or sub-ppm range if ion counts are strictly controlled. With the ion trap, precursors selected for MS/MS analysis can be accumulated within the linear trap, then fragmented and the fragments analyzed within the linear trap or in the FTICR-MS.

Maurer MH, Feldmann Jr RE, Fütterer CD, Butlin J, Kuschinsky W (2004) Neurochem. Res. 29, 1129-1144.

Comprehensive Proteome Expression Proling of Undifferentiated versus Differentiated Neural Stem Cells from Adult Rat Hippocampus

ABSTRACT. Adult neural stem cells can be isolated from various regions of the rat brain and seem to have multilineage differentiation potential. In this study, we investigated the hypothesis that global protein expression of adult neural stem cells isolated from rat hippocampus is changed during in vitro differentiation. After 2 days of differentiation, we separated total protein extracts by two-dimensional gel electrophoresis and used mass spectrometry and gel-matching for identication. We detected a differential expression in 367 regulated protein spots, of which 128 could be identied. Regulated proteins included participants in transcription and DNA metabolism; signal transduction and Ca2+-signaling; MAP kinase pathways; cytoskeletal rearrangement; regulation of cell cycle, proliferation, and survival; protein biosynthesis, folding, and degradation; and glycine and glutamate metabolic pathways. These results suggest a massive reorganization of the stem cell proteomic prole upon differentiation and indicate potential cellular targets mediating the differentiation of neural stem cells.

Ng TB (2004) Peptides 25, 1055-1073.

Peptides and Proteins from Fungi

Mushrooms are a class of fungi that are quite protein-rich and used in diets in all cultures around the world. Among proteins from fungi of interest are ribsome-inactivating proteins, antifungal proteins, ribonucleases, ubiquitin-like proteins and peptides, lectins, cellulases, xylanases, laccases, invertases, and trehalose phosphorylases.

Of the ribosome-inactivating proteins, many are found in flowering plants which are type 1 proteins with molecular masses of 25-32 kDa. These are immunosuppressive, antimitogenic, anti-tumor/anti-proliferative, and antiviral. Type 2 inactivating have an inactivating protein chain and lectin chain.

Rejtar T, Chen H-S, Andreev V, Moskovets E, Karger BL (2004) Anal. Chem. 76, 6017-6028.

Increased Identification of Peptides by Enhanced Data Processing of High-Resolution MALDI TOF/TOF Mass Spectra Prior to Database Searching

Mass spectra were obtained with a ABi 4700 Proteomics Analyzer using Nd:YAG laser at 200 Hz using ABi Explorer v1.1 (resolution 15,000 and 4000 in MS and MS/MS modes, resp). Accuracy is ± 10 ppm in MS (internal calib) and 0.2 Da in MS/MS. Agilent Tech Series II 1090 liquid chromatography on to 2.1 mm × 15 cm polysulfoethyl A (PolyLC) and separated with 60 min linear gradient at 200 µl/min. Sample is 2 mg/ml yeast lysate with 0.5 ml injection. Solvent A is 25% MeCN, 10 mM phosphate pH 3.0; solvent B is solvent A + 0.35 M KCl. From twenty 0.6 ml (3 min) fractions obtained, 10 with highest UV selected and diluted 10-fold and loaded to 75 µm × 15 cm column with 3 µm 100 Å. 10 µl sample is loaded manually, to precolumn of 1 mm × 300 µm (UltiMate). Sample was desalted and eluted to analytical column at 200 nl/min with solvent A of 0.1% (v/v) TFA in 2% MeCN, and solvent B of 0.1% TFA, 5% IPA, 85% MeCN with 60 min linear gradient. An Upchurch MicroTee mixed eluent with 7 mg/ml CHCA in 50% MeCN + 1 mM ammonium citrate + 0.1% TFA MALDI matrix at 1.3 µl/min which is streaked on plate with 20 cm × 40 µm (i.d)/150 µm (o.d.) capillary, with 250 µm wide streak.

A model sample of yeast soluble protein digest was run through an SCX column and 10 of 20 fractions run through a reversed-phase nano-LC deposited as narrow streaks on target plates under rough vacuum. Spectra were denoised with MEND and precursor ions for MS/MS selected using PRESEL. The MS/MS spectra were processed by generation of peak lists, which are centroided and then de-isotoped; intensity of deisotoped peaks is the sum of the area of the peaks in a particular isotope cluster. Peaks make the list only if a S/N > 5 threshold is reached and the cluster area > 100, and up to 20 of most intense peaks in a 200 Da region. Searches were done on Mascot with precursor mass tolerance of 50 ppm (external calibration mass accuracy, 6 calib targets per plate). 9504 spectra resulted in 1077 peptides identified.

Enhanced processing of MS/MS spectra involved generating three separate peak lists for each MS/MS spectrum based on increasing cluster area threshold. Peak lists are submitted to search with 10 ppm tolerance, involving closely placed external std streak over entire chromatographic run. Identified spectra are removed and search using semitryptic specificity conducted for all three cluster area thresholds. Spectra not identified yet are denoised with wavelet transformation. With peak detection, another search at 10 ppm mass tolerance.

The peak lists were intially generated by ABi 4700 software. Intensity and count of random peaks are factors used to optimize selection of fragment ions in the Mascot score. A model peptide FAHEGGYYIVPLSSK was used for calculating theoretical mass values of six consecutive y ions, and the intensities normalized to 1. Also added to the peak list were 1-19 peaks with random m/z values and intensities one-tenth (0.1) of those in the y-ion series. 20 peaks resulted and were submitted to Mascot. The Mascot score decreased systematically from its high of 59 when there are no random peaks, to 28 when 19 random peaks are present at the 10-fold lower intensities. Thus random, noisy peaks do have a negative effect on Mascot scoring, and an effort should be made to reduce their inclusion when possible.

One way of excluding random peptides is by excluding masses that cannot possibly ever be present as calculated by all potential combination of small peptides with the 20 amino acids. All theoretical tryptic peptides from the ORFs of yeast were generated and the masses of b- and y-ion fragments calculated. Intervals with the mass range 70-3000 Da were next determined which would have the theoretical fragment ions, which included the error of ±0.2 Da for the mass accuracy of the MS in MS/MS mode. About 70% of the mass range included potential masses, but at least 30% of the masses could be eliminated as forbidden.

Then the mass spectra were acquired. About 7% of the total masses were eliminated as forbidden. This indicates that the standard analysis software of the MS system is rather effective in identifying fragment ions. Database searching was done on the filtered set, and there was a 4% increase in identified peptides. In a reversed database search which catches false positives, the removal of random peaks from the search caused a negligible increase in the count of false positives (from 2.7 to 2.8%).

Multiple threshold values were set for fragment ion peaks in MS/MS spectra. This is because a single threshold often lets in too much background in some spectra while it might reduce it in other spectra. Spectra were centroided and deisotoped, and peaks with S/N > 3 chosen. A histogram was constructed of the dependence of the different cluster areas (peak intensities): it reveals a 2-fold increase in the number of peaks with cluster area of 100 relative to those with area of 200. Thus background noise peaks have a cluster area <200.

Three peak lists were then generated, with thresholds for peak inclusion being cluster areas of 100, 300, and 500. Peaks with S/N > 3 were preselected, then forbidden m/z values filtered out, then the 20 most intense peaks in a 200 Da mass interval selected. After this step, the cluster threshold was applied for the three variable thresholds. The search was then applied with a ± 50 ppm tolerance. 70% of all spectra obtained a significant score with 3 peak lists, 20% for two peak lists, and 10% for only one. The three-peak list approach provided 11.3% more identifications.

A low intensity MS/MS spectrum was submitted to this approach using a peak list with cluster area threshold 100. A Mascot score of 56 (highly significant) was obtained for this peptide (QLYSFDLEGFWMDVGQPK) but dropped to 6 with a threshold of 300, as far few fragment masses were available. The measured mass was only 2.2 ppm from the theoretical. Thus lowering threshold increases the Mascot score.

But suppose the lower threshold was used on all MS/MS spectra. Increased noise also results in lower Mascot scoring. For instance peptide EVSDGVIAPGYEPEALAILSK obtained a significant Mascot score (30) only when the cluster threshold was raised to 500 from 300, where its score was an insignificant 15.

Precursor ion mass accuracy is a factor in the improvement of identification. 1000 MS/MS spectra were taken on proteins from a single SCX fraction. The dependence of the Mascot score on a search against the MSDB for all organisms as opposed to only ORFs for the yeast genome. The significant score is calculated from the theoretical count of peptides with the mass tolerance. Generally it is a better idea to reduce the tolerance of the precursor ion to get high scoring hits. Good MS calibration becomes a factor in that case. Internal calibration is more desirable since the tolerance falls from ±50 to 10 ppm, but addition of mass standards can lead to ion suppression in MALDI samples. Placing external calibrants in close proximity (i.e. in the same well) to the sample such that they can be acquired in a single sequence allows a tolerance of 10 ppm without the associated ion suppression. Comparison of the theoretical with the measured precursor masses showed all masses within 10 ppm tolerance for peptides with highly significant identifications.

Thus after doing a three peak list searches based on cluster area thresholds, a filter was set for precursor mass to be within ± 10 ppm tolerance. 2101 peptides has a Mascot score > 17 (the significant level). 5% of precursors were outside the 10 ppm tolerance, so the search was repeated at 30 ppm level, and hits with only 99% (Mascot ≥ 26.5) significance were accepted to reduce false positives. 19 additional significant identifications were made.

The standard MS software and the enhanced processing system were compared, and the variable threshold plus precursor mass accuracy changes results in 377 more identifications with only a slight increased risk of false positives (from 2.7 to 3.6%, still below the 5% level of confidence).

Additional complicating factors are the presence of proteases that cleave nonspecifically. Additional peptides (96, or about 5%) were obtained with Mascot scores > 35 which were not produced strictly by tryptic expectations. With all these still ~75% of MS/MS spectra did not yield identifications. Wavelet denoising is known to be very effective for processing MS/MS spectra, although care must be taken not to produce false negatives, and so it should only be done after doing the other searches first, which is why it is part of the enhanced method at the final stage. Optimization of wavelet denoising is done on a subset of MS/MS spectra by setting the different variables that are the base functions, order, and decomposition level. For this study, the Sym8 function with decomposition level = 5 was used. The peak list was then generated after denoising with threshold of S/N 15. Database searching with 10 ppm tolerance and no missed cleavages was set, and 178 additional peptides. One example of an MS/MS spectrum before denoising had a Mascot of only 17, which improved to 47 after several y-ion fragments emerged.

Whitelegge JP (2004) Plant Physiol. Biochem. 42, 919-927.

Mass Spectrometry for High Throughput Quantitative Proteomics in Plant Research: Lessons from Thylakoid Membranes

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Proteomics seeks to monitor the flux of protein through cells under variable developmental and environmental influences as programmed by the genome. Consequently, it is necessary to measure changes in protein abundance and turnover rate as faithfully as possible. In the absence of non-invasive technologies, the majority of proteomics approaches involve destructive sampling at various time points to obtain snapshots that periodically report the genomess product. The work has fallen to separations technologies coupled to mass spectrometry, for high throughput protein identification. Quantitation has become the major challenge facing proteomics as the field matures. Because of the variability of day-to-day measurements of protein quantities by mass spectrometry, a common feature of quantitative proteomics is the use of stable isotope coding to distinguish control and experimental samples in a mixture that can be profiled in a single experiment. To address limitations with separation technologies such as 2D-gel electrophoresis, alternative systems are being introduced including multi-dimensional chromatography. Strategies that accelerate throughput for mass spectrometry are also emerging and the benefits of these shotgun protocols will be considered in the context of the thylakoid membrane and photosynthesis. High resolution Fourier-transform mass spectrometry is bringing increasingly accurate mass measurements to peptides and a variety of gas-phase dissociation mechanisms are permitting top-down sequencing of intact proteins. Finally, a versatile workflow for sub-cellular compartments including membranes is presented that allows for intact protein mass measurements, localization of post-translational modifications and relative quantitation or turnover measurement.

van Wijk, KJ (2004) Plant Physiol. Biochem. 42, 963-977.

Plasmid Proteomics

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Plastids are essential organelles present in virtually all cells in plants and in green algae. The proteomes of plastids, and in particular of chloroplasts, have received significant amounts of attention in recent years. Various fractionation and mass spectrometry (MS) techniques have been applied to catalogue the chloroplast proteome and its membrane compartments. Neural network and hidden Markov models, in combination with experimentally derived filters, were used to try to predict the chloroplast subproteomes. Some of the many proteinprotein interaction, as well as post-translational modifications have been characterized. Nevertheless, our understanding of the chloroplast proteome and its dynamics is very incomplete. Rapid improvements and wide-scale implementation of MS and new tools for comparative proteomics will undoubtedly accelerate this understanding in the near future. Proteomics studies often generate a large amount of data and these data are only meaningful if they can be easily accessed via the world-wide-web and connected to other types of biological information. The plastid proteome data base (PPDB at http://www.ppdb.tc.cornell.edu/) and other web resources are discussed. This review will briefly summarize recent experimental and theoretical efforts, attempt to translate these data into the functions of the chloroplast and outline expectations and possibilities for (comparative) chloroplast proteomics.

Lee S-J, Saravanan RS, Damasceno CMB, Yamane H, Kim B-D, Rose JKC (2004) Plant Physiol. Biochem. 42, 979-988.

Digging Deeper Into The Plant Cell Wall Proteome

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. The proteome of the plant cell wall/apoplast is less well characterized than those of other subcellular compartments. This largely reflects the many technical challenges involved in extracting and identifying extracellular proteins, many of which resist isolation and identification, and in capturing a population that is both comprehensive and relatively uncontaminated with intracellular proteins. However, a range of disruptive techniques, involving tissue homogenization and subsequent sequential extraction and non-disruptive approaches has been developed. These approaches have been complemented more recently by other genome-scale screens, such as secretion traps that reveal the genes encoding proteins with N-terminal signal peptides that are targeted to the secretory pathway, many of which are subsequently localized in the wall. While the size and complexity of the wall proteome is still unresolved, the combination of experimental tools and computational prediction is rapidly expanding the catalog of known wall-localized proteins, suggesting the unexpected extracellular localization of other polypeptides and providing the basis for further exploration of plant wall structure and function.

Stauber EJ, Hippler M (2004) Plant Physiol. Biochem. 42, 989-1001.

Chlamydomonas reinhardtii Proteomics

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Proteomics, based on the expanding genomic resources, has begun to reveal new details of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii biology. In particular, analyses focusing on subproteomes have already provided new insight into the dynamics and composition of the photosynthetic apparatus, the chloroplast ribosome, the oxidative phosphorylation machinery of the mitochondria, and the flagellum. It assisted to discovered putative new components of the circadian clockwork as well as shed a light on thioredoxin proteinprotein interactions. In the future, quantitative techniques may allow large scale comparison of protein expression levels. Advances in software algorithms will likely improve the use of genomic databases for mass spectrometry (MS) based protein identification and validation of gene models that have been predicted from the genomic DNA sequences. Although proteomics has only been recently applied for exploring C. reinhardtii biology, it will likely be utilized extensively in the near future due to the already existing genetic, genomic, and biochemical tools.

Riccardi F, Gazeau P, Jacquemot M-P, Vincent D, Zivy M (2004) Plant Physiol. Biochem. 42, 1003-1011.

Deciphering Genetic Variations of Proteome Responses To Water Deficit in Maize Leaves

ABSTRACT. The proteome of the basal part of growing Zea mays leaves was analyzed from 4 to 14 d after stopping watering and in well watered controls. The relative quantity of 46 proteins was found to increase in leaves of plants submitted to water deficit. Different types of responses were observed, some proteins showing a constant increase during water deficit, while others showed stabilization after a first increase or a transient increase. Isoforms encoded by the same gene showed different responses. The response to water deficit showed genetic variation. Some increased proteins were induced specifically in one of the two studied genotypes (e.g. ASR1) while others were significantly induced in both genotypes but to a different level or with different kinetics. Analyses of relations between protein quantities, relative water content (RWC) and abscisic acid (ABA) concentration allowed us to show that the quantitative variation of some proteins (e.g.ABA45 and OSR40 proteins) was linked to differences in ABA accumulation between the genotypes. Other proteins showed genetic variations that were not related to differences in water status or ABA concentration (e.g. a cystatin). Data obtained from these experiments, together with data from other experiments, contribute to the characterization of maize proteome response to drought in different conditions and in different genotypes. This characterization allows the search for candidate proteins, i.e. for protein whose genetic variation of expression could be partly responsible for the variability of plant responses to drought.

Schneider M, Tognolli M, Bairoch A (2004) Plant Physiol. Biochem. 42, 1013-1021.

The Swiss-Prot Protein Knowledgebase and ExPASy: Providing The Plant Community with High Quality Proteomic Data and Tools

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. The Swiss-Prot protein knowledgebase provides manually annotated entries for all species, but concentrates on the annotation of entries from model organisms to ensure the presence of high quality annotation of representative members of all protein families. A specific Plant Protein Annotation Program (PPAP) was started to cope with the increasing amount of data produced by the complete sequencing of plant genomes. Its main goal is the annotation of proteins from the model plant organism Arabidopsis thaliana. In addition to bibliographic references, experimental results, computed features and sometimes even contradictory conclusions, direct links to specialized databases connect amino acid sequences with the current knowledge in plant sciences. As protein families and groups of plant-specific proteins are regularly reviewed to keep up with current scientific findings, we hope that the wealth of information of Arabidopsis origin accumulated in our knowledgebase, and the numerous software tools provided on the Expert Protein Analysis System (ExPASy) web site might help to identify and reveal the function of proteins originating from other plants. Recently, a single, centralized, authoritative resource for protein sequences and functional information, UniProt, was created by joining the information contained in Swiss-Prot, Translation of the EMBL nucleotide sequence (TrEMBL), and the Protein Information ResourceProtein Sequence Database (PIRPSD). A rising problem is that an increasing number of nucleotide sequences are not being submitted to the public databases, and thus the proteins inferred from such sequences will have difficulties finding their way to the Swiss-Prot or TrEMBL databases.

Kim SI, Voshol H, van Oostrum J, Hastings TG, Cascio M, Glucksman MJ (2004) Neurochem. Res. 29, 1317-1331.

Neuroproteomics: Expression Profiling of the Brain's Proteomes in Health and Disease

ABSTRACT. The term proteome describes the protein complement of a genome. Proteomes of cells are dynamic and are directly affected by environmental factors, such as stress and/or drug treatment, or as a result of aging and disease. One of the distinct advantages of proteomic analysis, not attainable with RNA expression data, is the ability to fractionate the cells proteins into various subpopulations. In neuroscience, neuromics (proteomics in the central nervous system) is in its infancy, with a paucity of studies in the context of the brain. One of the objectives of this review is to illustrate the potential of neuromics to profile differences in the distribution of thousands of proteins as a function of disease markers. We have previously used this approach to determine the effects of varied postmortem interval in examining human brain tissue and to identify biomarkers. Here we review proteomic studies of schizophrenia, Alzheimers disease, and Parkinsons disease. Experimental results regarding Parkinsons disease are presented to illustrate the potential of neuromics to identify pathways of pathogenesis and novel therapeutic targets.

Saravanan RS, Rose JKC (2004) Proteomics 4, 2522-2532.

A critical evaluation of sample extraction techniques for enhanced proteomic analysis of recalcitrant plant tissues

ABSTRACT. Most published proteomics studies of bulk plant tissues use a procedure in which proteins are precipitated with trichloroacetic acid (TCA) and acetone (TCA-A), but few attempts have been made to contrast this approach in a systematic way with alternative methods against a spectrum of tissues. To address this, TCA-A was compared with another acetone-based protocol (TCA-B) or a phenol (Phe)-based method, targeting a range of tomato tissues and three species of fruits that contain high levels of contaminating compounds: banana, avocado and orange. The Phe method gave a higher protein yield and typically greater resolution and spot intensity, particularly with extracts from tissues containing high levels of soluble polysaccharides. The methods also generated remarkably different two-dimensional gel electrophoresis (2-DE) protein spot patterns. Peptide mass fingerprinting was used to identify polypeptides that were common to multiple extracts or uniquely present in one extract type. While no clear pattern emerged to explain the basis for the differential protein extraction, it was noted that the Phe method showed enhanced extraction of glycoproteins. These results suggest that the Phe protocol is highly effective with more recalcitrant tissues and that a combination of TCA-A and Phe methods provides enhanced 2-DE based proteomic analyses of most plant tissues.

Seike M, Kondo T, Fujii K, Yamada T, Gemma A, Kudoh S, Hirohasi S (2004) Proteomics 4, 2776-2788.

Proteomic Signature of Human Cancer Cells

ABSTRACT. We assessed proteomic profiles as biomarkers for monitoring cell phenotypes. Protein expression profiles were obtained by fluorescence two-dimensional difference gel electrophoresis (2-D-DIGE), in which quantitative ability is improved by labeling proteins with fluorescent dyes prior to electrophoresis. Integrated protein spot intensities were analyzed by a statistical approach. The proteomic data of two groups of cell lines: (1) adenocarcinoma (AC) cell lines derived from lung, pancreas and colon tissues and (2) lung cancer cell lines with different histological backgrounds, including AC, squamous cell carcinoma and small cell carcinoma, were assessed on the basis of prior biological information. Hierarchical clustering analysis and principal component analysis were used to divide the cell lines into subgroups on the basis of similarities between their protein expression profiles. The majority of cell lines were grouped according to their organ of origin or histological background. A machine-learning algorithm selected 32 protein spots that were responsible for the classification. The results indicate that proteomic data generated by 2-D-DIGE can provide a signature of essential cell phenotypes, suggesting that it might be possible to apply this technique to developing tumor markers that could identify the organ of origin of metastatic tumors and contribute to the differential diagnosis of lung cancer.

Causier B (2004) Mass Spec. Rev. 23, 350-367.

Studying The Interactome with The Yeast Two-Hybrid System and Mass Spectrometry

Protein function can often be determined through interaction with other proteins whose functions are known. One approach is to analyze purified protein complexes by MS. Another is the yeast two-hybrid in vivo assay. Yeast two-hybrid studies evolved from study of eukaryotic transcription factors. Transcription factors have two domains: a DNA-binding and activation domain (BD and AD, respectively). It was discovered that the domains were both functionally and physically separable. Ptashne and co-workers found that the BD of one protein could be fused to the AD of another, making a new transcription factor. Fields & Song (1989) found that two proteins that interacted, one linked to the BD and another to an AD, would elicit transcription. In a proof-of-principle study, SNF1 was bound to the BD C-terminus of GAL4 and called the bait, and SNF4 was constructed to the GAL4 AD, called the prey protein. Plasmids were transformed into yeast that had a lacZ reporter under the control of GAL4. This is now known as the GAL4 system. Other systems include LexA or interaction trap system, utilizing the BD of the bacterial repressor LexA and the AD of E. coli B42.

The nature of this allows the generation of many prey constructs in order to screen a library of prey proteins. In early work there were a large number of false positives, but methods have evolved which put a higher stringency on interactions. One means of producing higher stringency is to use yeast that carry several reporters (lacZ, HIS3, LEU2, URA3, ADE2, gusA, GFP, MEL1). GAL4 stringency is increased by adding 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole (3-AT) to millimolar concentrations, a competitive inhibitor of HIS3 gene product; this reduces background caused by basal HIS3 expression. Stringency in LexA is determined by the use of reporter genes that have different numbers of LexA operators. It was also an improvement in developing tow mating types, MATα and MATa as opposed to using the original co-transformation method, because expression in the haploids are already at a steady state level. Sensitivity of the system is such that it can determine differences of a single amino acid.

Among the difficulties with using yeast two-hybrid are the false positives, as well as the rare false negative. One problem is the ability of constructs to localize to the yeast nucleus, which they must if the system is to function. Proteins have nuclear localization signals (NLS), but the bait and prey themselves may have signals that cause localization to other compartments. An assay was developed to determine if the bait localizes to the nucleus.

Sos Recruitment The yeast strain cdc25H carries a temperature-sensitive mutation in the Ras guanyl nucleotide exchange factor (GEF). It can be rescued with human Ras GEFhSos, which is recruited to the plasma membrane, activates yRas, and reconstitutes signaling. hSos is fused to a test protein, and the second is fused to a v-Src myristilation signal that localizes to the yeast plasma membrane. At the restrictive temperature, cdc25 is no functional and cannot activate Ras. After mating hSos is recruited to the membrane and substitutes for cdc25 at the restrictive temp. Only interactions that occur permit yeast growth, and the advantage here is that nuclear localization is not required. In addition, post-translational modifications important for some interactions are more likely in the cytoplasm. A hybrid using mRas to rescue cdc25 has also been constructed. Problems with the cdc25H system include reversion of temperature sensitivity, in which case the untransformed control must be tested. Expression libraries used with the systems encode proteins fused with the signal, and Ras proteins are common false positives; procedure can be used to eliminate proteins encoding false positives.

Split-ubiquitin. Ubiquitin can tag proteins for destruction in the 26S proteosome, and ubiquitin is recycled by ubiquitin-specific proteases (UBPs) back into the cytoplasm. One group produced a split-ubiquitin construct by fusing protein X to the C-terminal half of ubiquitin (Cub) with a reporter attached. The second test protein Y was fused to the N-terminal half of ubiquitin (Nub). If X and Y interact, the split ubiquitin join to form an active ubiquitin recognized by UBPs, and the reporter protein is released. The first system made use of an immunochemically identifed reporter. Other systems have been constructed, such as an A-LexA-VP16 transcription factor which when released activates lacZ and HIS3. In another system Ura3 converts 5-fluoroorotic acid to 5-fluorouracil which is toxic: Cub alone is not recognized by UBPs, but Cub-Ura3 is toxic to cells grown on 5-FOA, and if Cub-Ura3 is a fusion of protein X, interacting with protein Y fused to Nub, Ura3 is released by UBPs and is degraded in the proteosome such that it can not be toxic.

Dual-Bait. In this system, lacZ and LEU2 are put under the control of LexA, and LYS2 and gusA are bound to λcI. Bait protein X1 is fused to LexA BD and second bait protein X2 is a fusion of λcI BD. The appropriate yeast strain is co-transformed, and interaction is done with prey protein fused to B42 AD.

Yeast One-Hybrid System. A variation which studies protein-DNA interactions. Here the bait is not a protein but known DNA sequence. Multiple copies of bait DNA are inserted upstream of a reporter (lacZ, HIS3).

Numerous in vitro methods are being used to study interactions including co-immunoprecipitation, pull-down assays, affinity chromatography, protein array chips, and surface plasmon resonance. Bait proteins can be modified with affinity tags (GST, His6, CaM-binding peptide, and common epitope tags such as HAgg, myc, FLAG). Some tags are used in combination on the same protein to permit extensive purification (tandem affinity purification).

Large-scale two-hybrid screens. A matrix-based approach clones full-length open reading frames into bait and prey two-hybrid vectors each transformed into MATa and MATα strains. Each bait strain is mated with an array of prey strains, diploids identified by reporter gene products. In the library-based approach, undefined prey libraries expressing either full-length ORFs or randomly generated cDNAs are screened with bait strains. Screen simplification occurs when pools of the library are screened against each bait. The first eukaryotic genome to be completely sequenced and annotated was S. cerevisiae in 1996. This led to the first comprehensive analysis of the interactome using matrix- and library-based approaches of proteins encoded by 6000 predicted ORFs. Using matrix-based 192 bait proteins were screened against array of 6000 prey proteins, and 281 interacting protein pairs identifed. In the library-based approach, 6000 prey proteins were pooled to generate a complex library. Using a partially automated system, the library was screened with individual bait representing 6000 ORFs; 692 interactions were found. Comparisons show that matrix-based approach showed 3.4 interactions per bait, while 1.8 interactions per bait were seen with library-based, making the former more sensitive.

Kakniashvili DG, Bulla LA Jr, Goodman SR (2004) Molec. Cell. Proteomics 3, 501-509.

The Human Erythrocyte Proteome

ABSTRACT. This report describes an analysis of the red blood cell proteome by ion trap tandem mass spectrometry in line with liquid chromatography. Mature red blood cells lack all internal cell structures and consist of cytoplasm within a plasma membrane envelope. To maximize outcome, total red blood cell protein was divided into two fractions of membrane-associated proteins and cytoplasmic proteins. Both fractions were divided into subfractions, and proteins were identified in each fraction separately through tryptic digestion. Membrane protein digests were collected from externally exposed proteins, internally exposed proteins, spectrin extract mainly consisting of membrane skeleton proteins, and membrane proteins minus spectrin extract. Cytoplasmic proteins were divided into 21 fractions based on molecular mass by size exclusion chromatography. The tryptic peptides were separated by reverse-phase high-performance liquid chromatography and identified by ion trap tandem mass spectrometry. A total of 181 unique protein sequences were identified: 91 in the membrane fractions and 91 in the cytoplasmic fractions. Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase was identified with high sequence coverage in both membrane and cytoplasmic fractions. Identified proteins include membrane skeletal proteins, metabolic enzymes, transporters and channel proteins, adhesion proteins, hemoglobins, cellular defense proteins, proteins of the ubiquitin-proteasome system, G-proteins of the Ras family, kinases, chaperone proteins, proteases, translation initiation factors, and others. In addition to the known proteins, there were 43 proteins whose identification was not determined.

Görg A, Weiss W, Dunn MJ (2004) Proteomics 4, 3665-3685.

Current two-dimensional electrophoresis technology for proteomics

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Two-dimensional gel electrophoresis (2-DE) with immobilized pH gradients (IPGs) combined with protein identification by mass spectrometry (MS) is currently the workhorse for proteomics. In spite of promising alternative or complementary technologies (e.g. multidimensional protein identification technology, stable isotope labelling, protein or antibody arrays) that have emerged recently, 2-DE is currently the only technique that can be routinely applied for parallel quantitative expression profiling of large sets of complex protein mixtures such as whole cell lysates. 2-DE enables the separaration of complex mixtures of proteins according to isoelectric point (pI), molecular mass (Mr), solubility, and relative abundance. Furthermore, it delivers a map of intact proteins, which reflects changes in protein expression level, isoforms or posttranslational modifications. This is in contrast to liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry based methods, which perform analysis on peptides, where Mr and pI information is lost, and where stable isotope labelling is required for quantitative analysis. Todays 2-DE technology with IPGs (Grg et al., Electrophoresis 2000, 21, 10371053), has overcome the former limitations of carrier ampholyte based 2-DE (OFarrell, J. Biol. Chem. 1975, 250, 4007 4021) with respect to reproducibility, handling, resolution, and separation of very acidic and/or basic proteins. The development of IPGs between pH 2.512 has enabled the analysis of very alkaline proteins and the construction of the corresponding databases. Narrow-overlapping IPGs provide increased resolution (DpI = 0.001) and, in combination with prefractionation methods, the detection of low abundance proteins. Depending on the gel size and pH gradient used, 2-DE can resolve more than 5000 proteins simultaneously (,2000 proteins routinely), and detect and quantify,1 ng of protein per spot. In this article we describe the current 2-DE/ MS workflow including the following topics: sample preparation, protein solubilization, and prefractionation; protein separation by 2-DE with IPGs; protein detection and quantitation; computer assisted analysis of 2-DE patterns; protein identification and characterization by MS; two-dimensional protein databases.

Meng Z, Simmons-Willis TA, Limbach PA (2004) Biomolec. Eng. 21, 1-13.

The Use of Mass Spectrometry in Genomics

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. Recent advances in the development of electrospray ionization (ESI) and matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI) now permit the near routine analysis of oligonucleotides and intact nucleic acids. These developments have led to the use of mass spectrometry (MS) as a detection platform for genomics studies. Among the various uses of mass spectrometry in genomics, applications focused on the characterization of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and short tandem repeats (STRs) are particularly well-suited to MALDI or ESI-based analysis. It is predicted that continued developments in methodology and instrumentation will further improve the capabilities of mass spectrometry for nucleic acid analysis.

Smith RD, Shen Y-F, Tang K (2004) Acc. Chem. Res. 37, 269-278.

Ultrasensitive and Quantitative Analyses from Combined Separations-Mass Spectrometry for the Characterization of Proteomes

ABSTRACT. This article describes developments in fundamental and applied aspects of separations, electrospray ionization phenomena, and mass spectrometric instrumentation that are interrelated and important for making more effective and quantitative measurements, particularly for proteomics applications. The basis for better quantitation and ultrahigh sensitivity is highlighted for highresolution capillary liquid chromatography separations that provide low nanoliter per minute flow rates to an electrospray ionization interface. The increased dynamic range of measurements and low zeptomole regime detection limits obtainable open new avenues for biological research.

Balmer Y, Koller A, del Val G, Schürmann P, Buchanan BB (2004) Anal. Chem. 79, 275-280.

Proteomics Uncovers Proteins Interacting Electrostatically with Thioredoxin in Chloroplasts

ABSTRACT.

Reinders J, Lewandrowski U, Moebius J, Wagner Y, Sickmann A (2004) Proteomics 4, 3686-3703.

Challenges in Mass Spectrometry-Based Proteomics

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. During the last decade, protein analysis and proteomics have been established as new tools for understanding various biological problems. As the identification of proteins after classical separation techniques, such as two-dimensional gel electrophoresis, have become standard methods, new challenges arise in the field of proteomics. The development of functional proteomics combines functional characterization, like regulation, localization and modification, with the identification of proteins for deeper insight into cellular functions. Therefore, different mass spectrometric techniques for the analysis of post-translational modifications, such as phosphorylation and glycosylation, have been established as well as isolation and separation methods for the analysis of highly complex samples, e.g. protein complexes or cell organelles. Furthermore, quantification of protein levels within cells is becoming a focus of interest as mass spectrometric methods for relative or even absolute quantification have currently not been available. Protein or genome databases have been an essential part of protein identification up to now. Thus, de novo sequencing offers new possibilities in protein analytical studies of organisms not yet completely sequenced. The intention of this review is to provide a short overview about the current capabilities of protein analysis when addressing various biological problems.

Stasyk T, Huber LA (2004) Proteomics 4, 3704-3716.

Zooming In: Fractionation Strategies in Proteomics

REVIEW. Fractionation strategies must be employed to attempt to recover low abundance proteins such as regulatory proteins (kinases, phosphatases, etc.). It is also necessary to enrich certain proteins corresponding to a particular subproteome of interest.

Organelle proteomics. Subcellular fractionation allows the separation of organelles based on physical and biological properties and involves first the disruption of the cell (homogenization), and then fractionation of the homogenate into its component organelles. Centrifugation is the typical approach. First the intact cells are collected by low speed spin. After disruption (mechanical usually), nuclei are removed with a low speed spin and then possibly purified to remove debris and unbroken cells. The postnuclear supernatant is cytosol and other organelles which can be separated in an equilibrium gradient medium, or possibly by rate zonal method. Sucrose is the typical gradient medium, but Ficoll, Percoll, Nycodenz or Metrizamide are also used. Free flow electrophoresis and immunoisolation are also used. Although the organelles can be relatively enriched, they cannot be completely pure. Enrichment is still valuable since it can bring low abundance proteins to signal levels. For example, p14 is a low Mr protein found in late endosomes, a fact obtained by enrichment. The protein is an adaptor protein for targeting MAPK signaling to the late endosomal compartment in an alternative EGFR pathway.

Enriched endosomal fractions were studied using 2D-DIGE and showed an enrichment of 305 (2- to 120-fold) and 292 (2- to 25-fold) protein spots in purifed late and early endosomal fractions in comparison to protein of the PNS serving as the starting fraction. Wu et al. took an organelle proteomics approach by first isolating the Golgi fraction from rat liver using sucrose step gradient centrifugation. Golgi samples were digested and then analyzed by MudPIT using triphasic chromatography (reverse phase, SCX, and HIC). In 421 identified proteins, 110 were known to be resident in Golgi, and 64% were predicted transmembrane proteins. In other studies Kikuchi et al. used Nycodenz density gradient centrifugation to isolate peroxisomes which were further purified with anti-PMP70 antibodies (70 kDa peroxisome membrane protein) immunomagnetically.

Drake SK, Bowen RAR, Remaley AT, Hortin GL (2004) Clin. Chem. 50, 2398-2401.

Potential Interferences from Blood Collection Tubes in Mass Spectrometric Analyses of Serum Polypeptides

Greatest sensitivity and resolution of MALDI-ToF is in the mass range 500-20,000 Da. Many blood collection tubes contain components that might interfere with these analyses. Silicones for lubricants for stoppers or coating on internal surfaces. Polyvinylpyrrolidones or polyethylene glycols are useful in surface wetting. Plus clot inhibitors or activators.

1 ml PBS (pH 7.2, KD Medical) was added to collection tubes and incubated at RT for ~4 h with gentle rocking with contact on all surfaces, simulating real conditions of blood handling. Tubes studied included BD, Greiner Bio-One Vacuette North America. These are mixed with 0.5 vol of 6 M guanidine HCl + 3 g/L TFA (0.3%). 30 µl of these were extracted to C18 ZipTips (0.6 µl). Tips are washed three times with 0.1% TFA, then eluted with 3 µl of 50% MeCN + 0.1% TFA. 1 µl of this and of 50 mM CHCA or sinapinic acid in 50% MeCN + 0.1% TFA are mixed on 384-well target. Analysis is with Bruker UltraFlex MALDI-ToF in positive linear mode; 300 shots on 10 positions done, on external calibrated system.

The serum tubes (except for no-additive glass) contributed much background in the m/z 1000-3000 range. A series of 5-6 peaks differing by 14 Da (assuming +1 state) and repeating every 111 Da were found. The 111 Da repeat is consistent with polyvinylpyrrolidone monomer, while the 14 Da difference represents a -CH2- group. CHCA was better than sinapinic for producing higher intensities in range < m/z 5000. BD plastic serum separator showed peaks in the m/z 1800-1900 range, while the Greiner Bio-One showed peaks at about m/z 1400.

Extracts of EDTA-containing plasma tubes and no-additive glass with glycerol as lubricant showed no significant background peaks that were obvious. An analysis program that looks for S/N > 20 found nothing.

One plasma tube for research use created to stabilize proteins for analysis had several contaminating peaks (m/z 1052, 1066, 6509, 6696, and 6880). These may correspond to protease inhibitor additives.

Conclusions include testing all containers with saline extraction technique to test for potential interferants in the analysis range. There is a general recommendation that plasma collection tubes contribute less potential interferents compared to serum tubes.

Giles K, Pringle SD, Worthington KR, Little D, Wildgoose JL, Bateman RH (2004) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 18, 2401-2414.

Application of A Travelling Wave-Based Radio-Frequency-Only Stacked Ring Ion Guide

Radiofrequency (RF) multipole ion guides are used for transportation of ions. Gerlich has detailed of these ion guides and says that at pressures low enough, collisions with background gas molecules are unimportant. In some cases these guides can be used to cool ions to permit thermal ion-molecule reaction studies. Quadrupole, hexapole and octapole guides are useful when the gas pressure is high 10−3 to 10−3 mbar. Electrostatic lens for focusing and transport is difficult because of scattering at moderate background pressures. By reducing the effective potential well using RF-only multipoles, these losses in ions are reduced. Bahr et al (1969) first discussed the stacked ring ion guide (SRIG) and Gerlich and coworkers developed it. Smith and coworkers have pursued the ion funnel concept, in which the apertures of the ring electrodes are consecutively reduced in diameter from entrance to exit.

Khoudoli GA, Porter IM, Blow JJ, Swedlow JR (2004) Proteome Sci. 2, 6-17.

Optimization of The Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis Protocol Using The Taguchi Approach

Rehydration buffers typically contain chaotropes, detergents, reducing agents, and carrier ampholytes. The combination 7 M urea/2 M thiourea reportedly produces better 2-D gels with IPG strips compared to 8 M urea. The reducing agents DTT, TBP, anc TCEP have all been used and were test as 20 mM DTT, 2 mM TBP, or 10 mM TCEP in our urea/thiourea/4% CHAPS/0.5% ampholyte preparation. 50 µg Xenopus egg protein was obtained by MeOH/chloroform precipitation and used in the rehydration. DTT showed the best results (TBP and TCEP) reduced focusing.

When carrier ampholytes were added at higher concentrations to determine optimal, the focusing time was lengthened. A one-step fast-ramping gradient from 250-5500 V after 30 min at 250 V works well for 7 cm strips at all pH ranges. A total 33000 Vh produced good results (with a restriction to 50 µA per strip); this was sufficient for the highest carrier ampholyte concentration.

It is thought that the presence of SDS in alkylation buffer prior to 2nd dimension separation reduces the completeness of the alkylation. It has been proposed that alkylation be done before IEF solubilization, but thiourea can also prevent alkylation by iodoacetamide. Acrylamide is an alternative, so it was used to 60 mM concentration in the rehydration buffer after precipitated protein was solubized for 2 h in DTT. Acrylamide was also added to the 2nd equilibration buffer before SDS-PAGE.

The Taguchi experimental optimization arranges variables in an orthogonal array. For 2DGE, each column in the array (table) is the individual buffer component of the IEF rehydration buffer, and each row represents the individual IEF rehydration buffer. Each component is defined at 3 possible concentrations (A, B, C) to cover the range of varying effects. Effectiveness is determined by a count of spots on the 2D gel, and Taguchi's signal-to-noise ratios (SNR) are calculated for all components:

SNR = −10 log [ 1 ∑i=1 n 1 ]
n Yi2

where n is number of trials with given concentration, and Yi is yield on corresponding trials. As an example to calculate SNR for 1% CHAPS, the total spot counts of gels 2, 5, 8 (n = 3) were used since they used 1% CHAPS. A 2nd order polynomial was used to determine the concentration corresponding to maximum SNR as if were plotted. The Taguchi method factors performance as a measure of mean and variability (SNR is ratio of mean to standard deviation in simplest form). SNR plots were determined for CHAPS and DTT, and determination of 1.32% CHAPS and 34 mM DTT was found as maximal SNR values. When using the lowest concentration of ampholytes and ASB14, the highest SNR values are seen. When experiments were repeated three time, optimal CHAPS is found to be 1.20%, DTT to be 43 mM, 0.25% ampholytes, and 0.4% ASB14.

While spot count was the measure of performance, spot circularity, streaking, spot intensity, and so on could have been factored in as well. When ASB14 was greater than 2.0% significant streaking and spot shape changes occurred (thus reducing spot number).

Lower concentrations of ampholytes and ASB14 may improved detected spot number. From 0.1% to 0.4% ASB14 and 0.05% to 0.25% ampholytes, there was little change in spot number. Was ASB14 even useful? A rehydration buffer of 8 M urea, 4% CHAPS, 0.5% ampholytes and 20 mM DTT (called sRB) produces 425 spots, while 7 M urea, 2 M thiourea, 1.2% CHAPS, 0.4% ASB14, and 0.25% ampholytes (called oRB) produces 659 spots, a 50% increase. Since our interest was in chromatin-associated proteins (Lys and Arg-rich), it was observed that there was a paucity of basic and high MW proteins on the gels with the 1st buffer, but a larger number were seen with the 2nd buffer.

The improved oRB buffer was able to reveal more about the chromatin proteins, eliminating ambiguities on immunoblots of high MW proteins. Condensin component XCAP-E (140 kDa)

Wilmarth PA, Riviere MA, Rustvold DL, Lauten JD, Madden TE, David LL (2004) J. Proteome Res. 3, 1017-1023.

Two-Dimensional Liquid Chromatography Study of the Human Whole Saliva Proteome

Unstimulated whole saliva from healthy 28 y o male nonsmoker was spun 20000 g for 15 min and supntnt dialyzed against 12 mM ammonium bicarbonate overnight with 10000 MWCO. BCA assay shows 1.1 mg/ml. Sample dried by vacuum centrifugation. Sample dissolved in 8 M urea, 0.4 M ammonium bicarb, 80 mM methylamine in 0.5 ml total. 125 µl of 0.9 M DTT for 15 min at 50° followed by 250 µl 1 M iodoacetamide at room temp in dark 15 min. Another 125 µl 0.9 M DTT, then 500 µl 1 M ammonium bicarb, then 100 µg seq.-grade trypsin (Promega V5113) in 500 µl water, left 18 h at 37° with shaking. 75 µl of 88% formic acid is added and peptides purified on SepPak Light cartridge, eluting with 0.5 ml 50% MeCN, then 0.5 ml 100% MeCN. Digest (vol=2.0 ml) injected on to 100 × 2.1 mm sulfoethyl column at 0.2 ml/mi with solvent A (10 mM NaPi pH 3.0 + 25% MeCN) for 10 min isocratic and gradient with solvent B (A + 0.35 M KCl) from 0-50% over 40 min, then 50-100% over 20 min. 2-min fractions collected and dried on vacuum, redissolved in 160 µl 5% formic acid, then run on 3.0 cm × 180 µm trap with 5 µm Zorbax SB-C18 using a 0.2% acetic acid mobile phase. Sample is loaded over 10 min, the flow rate slowed to 1.5 µl/min and then the trap switched inline to a 10 cm × 180 µm column with same packing. Peptides are eluted using mobile phase B with 75% MeCN and 0.2% acetic acid. Gradient consisted of 0-10% B over 5 min, 10-40% B over 60 min, and 40-100% B over 25 min. MS scans from m/z 400-2000 were followed by single data-dependent MS/MS scans with dynamic exclusion with repeat count of 1, repeat duration of 1.0 min, exclusion duration of 3 min, and exclusion mass width of 3.

37 SCX fractions were generated and 36,000 MS/MS spectra were analyzed by Sequest searches. Outputs were filtered with DTASelect, and 892 nonredundant peptides mapped to 268 proteins. Rather strict DTAselect filtering thresholds were placed and additional steps taken to ensure reliability of protein identifications. SwissProt entries were consulted before the nonredundant NCBI human entries, used as a second resort. 84 proteins were identified with three or more peptides using the DTASelect cutoffs, accepted without further validation. 28 protein identifications based only on two peptides were manually validated. 7 proteins were removed from a total of 105 valid database entries.

Tuteja R, Tuteja N (2004) BioEssays 26, 916-922.

Serial Analysis of Gene Expression (SAGE): Unraveling The Bioinformatics Tools

REVIEW. Many important cell biology events are associated with the expression of key genes: mitosis/division, differentiation, signal response to hormones and growth factors, apoptosis. In understanding disease etiology the comparison of different expression profiles under different conditions identifies individual and groups of genes. Methods for assaying expression fall into two classes: closed in which expression levels are measured by collected clones and sequences, and open where prior knowledge of genes to be measured is not required. Subtractive hybridization and differential display are methods used to screen transcript populations. They are however insensitive to low level transcription. Use of microarrays of oligonucleotides can catch these low level transcripts but limit themselves to previously identified transcripts (cDNA or EST libraries). Massively parallel signature sequencing (MPSS) is another global approach combining non-gel-based signature sequencing with the in vitro cloning of millions of templates on separate microbeads.

SAGE is a high throughput, high efficiency way to detect expression at any point in time and particularly of low level gene expression. SAGE works by generating tags that are 9-10 bases long. These are then concatenated serially into long DNA molecules before a final sequencing of the serialized tags. The frequency of the occurrence of tags is a direct function of its level of expression. Thus the gene belonging to the tag is both identified and quantitated for its expression level. With just one clone, 30-50 different mRNA can be identified. The development of LongSAGE was recently described in which 21 base-long tags are made and rapidly serialized to genomic sequence data. Results in SAGE are digital, making analysis and data management more amenable to bioinformatic manipulation.

A 10-11 base (pair) long tag is sufficient for unique identification of a transcript. This size of the tag is convenient for serializing into sequencable samples whose length allows sequencing of between 25-50 tags in the lane of a DNA sequencer. In the SAGE method a 9-10 base (pair) long tag is made by reverse transcription (first and second strand synthesis) of poly(A)+ RNA into a biotinylated ds cDNA. Fragments contain an anchoring enzyme NlaIII linker to generate fragments whose average length is 256 bp. Biotinylated fragments are isolated using strepavidin magnetic beads. The fragments are divided into two, and each half is ligated to two different linkers. Both linkers have sites for a tagging enzyme (BsmFI), an anchoring enzyme overhang, and priming site for PCR amplification. The tagging enzyme is then used to digest the bound linker-cDNA sequences to generate fragments composed of linker and bound cDNA tag, which is then released from the bead. The linker tages are then blunt-ended (ss nuclease). The two sets of linker-tags are ligated to form linker-ditag-linker constructs and then PCR-amplified with primers specific to the linkers. The anchoring enzyme is then used to release the ditags. Ditags are isolated, ligated to concatemers, cloned, and then sequenced. Many modifications have been made to the original SAGE method and these modifications are described by various names: SAGE-lite, micro-SAGE, mini-SAGE, SADE (an adaptation for downsized extracts), and GLGI (Generation of Longer cDNA fragments from SAGE tags for Gene Identification).

Sequence results from SAGE are first inspected to confirm tag content. Software first extracts and tabulates the sequences and then counts their occurrences. It then should compare tag abundance between projects/experiments. It should also match tags to reference sequences in other databases.

The company Genzyme has produced a propietary SAGE database as part of their therapeutic discovery process. It has over 4 million tags probably representing 100,000 genes from tissues both normal and cancerous. For a license fee it will make the library information available.

SAGEnet is a public database (http://www.sagenet.org/) with tags from tissues of colon and pancreatic cancers as well as control (healthy) tissues. It is maintained by the Vogelstein/Kinzler lab at Johns Hopkins.

SAGEmap is a public repository maintained by NIH NCBI in collaboration with the NIH Cancer Genome Anatomy Project (CGAP). The database is accessible through both WWW and FTP servers. Procedures to submit data, construct and characterize SAGE tags to gene assignments, the derivation and use of a special statistical test to analyze differential-type SAGE data are described. CGAP SAGE created SAGE Genie for analyzing and presenting SAGE data. One of the advantages of SAGEmap is that it can map SAGE tags to UniGene EST clusters. It can incorporate EST frequency location, and orientation info as well as correct sequencing error in refining mapping of tags to genes.

The mouse SAGE site is a database of all available SAGE libraries of mouse tissues and cell lines. This is maintained by the Institute of Molecular Genetics at the Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic. At Stanford, there is a Saccharomyces Genome Database the includes a SAGE resource.

The program SAGE300 was developed to compile a database of tags extracted from human sequences in Genbank. It provides a statistical analysis to report a p value in the event of differences between sequenced tags and expected tags. Man et al. compared three commonly used statistical tests that deal with pairwise sequence comparisons: the chi-square test (test for equality of two proportions), Fisher's exact test, and the Audic-Claverie Bayesian method (see site), and they found that the chi-square test has the greatest power and robustness, especially for lower expression levels.

discriminant function, peptide identification

Strittmatter EF, Kangas LJ, Petritis K, Mottaz HM, Anderson GA, Shen Y, Jacobs JM, Camp II DG, Smith RD (2004) J. Proteome Res. 3, 760-769.

Application of Peptide LC Retention Time Information in a Discriminant Function for Peptide Identification by Tandem Mass Spectrometry

Complete genomes done for more than 150 organisms. Much proteomic data coming in using peptide identfication from MS/MS using pattern matching algorithms such as SEQUEST and Mascot, where scores indicate confidence. In order to determine better thresholds between poor and good scores, Keller et al used a discriminant function based on several SEQUEST parameters and Bayesian statistics for creating probabilistic model for accepting or rejecting peptide identfiications.

A neural network-based model for determining peptide retention time was derived from large collection of data on peptides from digests of D radiourans and S oneidensis proteins. The model predicts retention time based on the amiono acid composition of a peptide: this is the normalized elution time (NETpred) using specific separation conditions. Difference between NETpred and NETobs are calculated for all tentative identifications, which includes those of 17 control proteins. Assignments for the control proteins showed a less broad (errant) histogram/distrbution than for D melanogaster proteins for which the training set was not developed. 90% of the control proteins had a deviation ≤ 0.10, and 50% of identifications of within 2.5%. Note that all NETobs results are the mean of several LC/MSMS experiments which were quite reproducible (median standard deviation for the peptides was 0.0034 NET units).

Nine LC-MS/MS datasets with 14,762 spectra were used to develop a NET-based discriminant. Of the spectra 3420 have top-scoring spectrum assigments (648 unique sequences) to one of the 17 control proteins. The ideal score criteria would make a distinction between correct and incorrect assignments. There is no perfect discrimination however because data quality and noise among other factors.

Washburn et al defined a cross-correlation (Xcorr) and ΔCn criteria, making 2241 nonunique peptide identifications to the control set, across all charge states. If the data of these experiments is applied using Washburn algorithms, the false positive rate is ~5%. The effect of applying a dNET (dNET = |NETpred − NETobs|), which for D melanogaster halves the number of incorrect identifications and reducing the false positive rate. Looking at peptide identifications grouped by charge state, there was improvement for +1 and +3 charge state peptides. The count of control proteins peptide identifications as a function if Xcorr grouped by raw number and as fraction of identifications of +1 protonated peptides was done by binning data in 0.2 Xcorr intervals. Results with and without the dNET criteria show that the dNET < 0.10 has a limited impact on number of control protein set identifications while the false positive reate is reduced by nearly half. Using a ΔCn > 0.1 restriction greatly reduces false positives above Xcorr = 2.0. Results indicate that many valid peptide identifications may have Xcorr < 1.9. Similar plots are produced for +2 and +3 peptides with similar trends to +1 peptides.

Parameters dM and ln(RankSp) can be used to judge match between peptide and mass spectrum. A discriminant function combining the factors Xcorr′, ΔCn, dM, and dNET was determined. This is

discrim score = sigmoid(Xcorr′) + sigmoid(ΔCn + sigmoid(ln(RankSp)) + sigmoid(dM + sigmoid(dNET) + tryptic parameter

where the sigmoid function is:

sigmoid(x) = β1 / {1 + exp[(β2 − x) / β3] }

and β1, β2, and β3 are coefficients optimized to produce maximum separation between confident identifications to control protein set and the supposed errant assignments. Note that the SEQUEST software produces the values Xcorr (cross-correlation score between actual and predicted spectrum), ΔCn (relative difference between correlation score for highest scoring peptide match and second hight peptide match, RankSp (rank based on preliminary Sp score for peptide; Sp score = preliminary score of peptide in search procedure) and dM (absolute difference between precursor ion mass and mass derived from assigned peptide). Xcorr and RankSp values are transformed also. Xcorr′ is a transformation of Xcorr and number of expected fragment ions in the assigned peptide:

Xcorr′ = ln(Xcorr) / ln(NL)

which reduces the length dependence of Xcorr (proposed first by Keller et al). RankSp is used as its natural log.

The discriminant function provide new value F which separates identifications of control proteins from false positives by combining scores of its five components. Discriminant scores were set for each MS/MS spectra, ranging from −3 to +7 (max). Spectra are placed in distibution with bin width of 0.2 and counting number of peptides that had F scores in a particular bin.

Baggerly KA, Morris JS, Coombes KR (2004) Bioinformatics 20, 777-785.

Reproducibility of SELDI-TOF protein patterns in serum: comparing datasets from different experiments

Petricoin et al (2002, Lancet) reported different patterns in SELDI-TOF MS spectra of women with and without ovarian cancer. Using 100 spectra from cancer patients, 100 from healthy and 16 with benign disease, they split them, using 50 cancer and 50 healthy spectra to train a classification algorithm. The algorithm was then used to classify remaining spectra. 50 of 50 cancer spectra were correctly classified, and 47 of 50 normals were classed, with 3 false positives. Of the 16 benign, it classed them as other than normal or cancer.

A question arises about whether differences can reflect biological variation or artifacts related to the technology. Artifacts include

  • handling or processing samples differently
  • changes in type of ProteinChip array
  • mechanical adjustments to the mass spectrometer
  • shift to the use of another instrument or lab

Three datasets of SELDI mass spectra to study ovarian conditions were obtained. Set 1 is from Petricoin et al 2002 with 216 spectra in five groups: training set for cancer and normal, test/validation for cancer and normal, and a set for benign disease. The H4 ProteinChip was used, and all data baseline-subtracted. Dataset 2 is the same groups but the WCX2 chip was used. Dataset 3 are new samples, 91 healthy and 162 cancer; these samples were processed robotically (the previous by hand), and run on WCX2 chip and data are not baseline-subtracted. File contains first column of m/z values and second column of relative intensities.

Data normalization involves altering the maximum and minimum intensities to be equal to 1 and 0, respectively, and recalculating the intensity by the normalization factor [= NVi = (Vi − Vmin) / (Vmax − Vmin) ] where Vi = raw intensity and NVi is the normalized intensity. The fitness of a feature set with N features is assessed using associated scaled intensities to define locations in the N-dimensional unit cube: start with sample 1; if the Euclidean distance between sample 2 and sample 1 < 0.1 × √N, the samples are placed in common cluster, and the means of the samples are the center. When sample 2 is farther is beyond the cluster test limit, a new cluster is started. Samples are processed until complete. After all clusters are formed, they are labeled cancer or normal by majority vote, and fitness defined as number of samples correctly classified.

Feature sets are then selected with a genetic algorithm. The algorithm run starts with 1500 logical chromosomes (feature sets), the size ranging from 5-20 index values. New populations are produced by preferential combination of pieces of the most fit members of the current generation. The process evolves for 250 generations, and a 0.02% mutation rate and random crossover locations. All 15,154 spectral featuers are available for inclusion in a feature set; with no initial peak finding step. For each of the experiments a single feature set that allows the cancers to be separated from the normals is reported.

In examining the ovarian datasets for features, dataset 1 was processed according to methods described above. In the original report were five m/z values, so they were put into a feature set, the distance between all pairs was computed for a distance matrix. The distance between cancer samples and normal samples was not different than between two cancer samples or between two normal samples. The pattern should be plaid: with small distances between samples of the same type and large distances between samples of different type. There were only four pairwise distances > 0.1 × √5, the cutoff distance for new cluster with five peaks. Clusters will not be formed at all. The problem here is baseline subtraction. The correction was noted by authors to create negative intensities. The correction is an irreversible nonlinear operation: the raw values cannot be reconstructed. In the three datasets supplied, only Dataset 3 was not baseline-subtracted.

In the original study, 16 samples were identified as being other than cancer or normal. When spectra are plotted side-by-side, a heat map is produced such that regions of higher intensity show as darker bands. This heat map for Dataset 1 shows the other group with a clearly distinct pattern, whereas the normal and cancer share significant similarity. Dataset 2 however showed no significant differences in the heat map: it differs in the chip used. In the original study, the analyses on both chips were concurrent and the technicians blinded. An analysis of data shows that Dataset 1 and Dataset 2 are not numerically identical.

Since Datasets 2 and 3 were done with the same chip. While Dataset 2 was baseline-subtracted, qualitative features were assessed for looking at similarity. In looking at indices such as major high intensity peaks, the spectra from the datasets appeared offset by 50-60 clock ticks. This corresponds to a 1% imprecision although the stated mass accuracy is 0.1%. A quadratic offset to the masses of dataset 3 were fitted using four peaks in calibration. These are m/z 6773, 7269, 9566, and 10,260 in dataset 2 and m/z 6823, 7321, 9632, and 10,337 in dataset 2. The peak matching produced and offset of 200 Da at the spectral low end.

In comparing datasets 2 and 3, which should be comparable if the chip type is the same, the distance matrix shows randomness and no distinct clustering. One feature at a time was checked, starting with the seven in Dataset 3, because Dataset 2 had been baseline corrected. The peak m/z 435.46 was the most useful in distinguising cancer and normal samples. Other problems became evident however, such as the presence of valleys in one dataset where there was a peak in other dataset. And some raw spectral signals were saturated (flat regions of high intensity). Several mathematical efforts were made to align and match signals and features.

The problem with much of the data was the presence of a maximum recorded raw intensity (signal saturation). Thus normalzing or correcting data can be a problem in looking for features. The raw data was searched uncorrected. A two-sample t-test was used to look for differences between cancer and normal samples at every m/z value in Dataset 3, with emphasis on seven m/z values reported on the author's website. The most extreme t values are huge, and the focus was at m/z 435.46, with t = 22.3463. 238 of 253 samples were correctly classified using this peak.

Severcan M, Haris PI, Severcan F (2004) Anal. Biochem. 332, 238-244.

Using Artificially Generated Spectral Data To Improve Protein Secondary Structure Prediction from Fourier Transform Infrared Spectra of Proteins

A data set prepared by Lee et al. (Biochemistry 29: 9185, 1990)

Morelle W, Michalski J-C (2005) Curr. Anal. Chem. 1, 29-57.

The Mass Spectrometric Analysis of Glycoproteins and Their Glycan Structures

REVIEW. Glycosylated molecules participate in many biological processes, including coordination of immune functions, pathogens targeting host tissues, protein regulation and interaction. Glycosylation occurs in all eukaryotes and is found in prokaryotes. Proteins are glycosylated at specific target sites. N-glycosylation occurs at Asn residues with a consensus of Asn-X-Ser/Thr, where X is any amino acid but Pro. O-linked modification is on Ser or Thr. Cys and Lys are glycosylated in rare instances. Glycosylation is not always structually identical even for the same protein. Human RBC CD59 shows 100 different oligosaccharide structures at a single glycosylation site, demonstrating an important feature of glycosylation which is microheterogeneity.

There are some common features. N-linked modification is usually by an amide bond of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) to Asn. A core is then built up to be Man5-9GlcNAc2. These glycans have a high mannose type cor oligomannose core, formed by trimming the larger core with α-glucosidase and -mannosidases. Glycans can also contain N-acetyllactosamine (Galβ1-3/4GlcNAc) in the antennal region, making them complex type. Mammals may add antenna composed of addtion of β-Gal and GlcNAc, with tandem repeats of LacNAc. The hybrid type has both mannose and N-acetyllactosamine attached to trimannosyl chitobiose core. Core and antenna can be capped with fucose or sialyl groups by α linking, in contrast to the use of β linking for the backbone sugars.

O-linked sugars show more diversity, from monosaccharides to large sulfated polysaccharides. The connecting sugar is GlcNAc as in N-linked, although other sugars have been reported. Cytosolic and nuclear glycoproteins show O-GlcNAc.

Ahnert N, Patton WF, Schulenberg B (2004) Presented at the Association of Biomolecular Resource Facilities Annual Meeting: Portland, Oregon, February 28-March 2, 2004

Optimizing Conditions for Diluting, and Reusing SYPRO Ruby Protein Gel Stain

Berggren et al (2000) introduced SYPRO Ruby which can detect as little as 1 ng protein and still permits Edman sequencing and MS (Finehout and Lee 2003). The formulation was later improved (Berggren et al 2002) for use with other stains like Pro-Q Emerald 300 glycoprotein and Pro-Q Diamond phosphoprotein stain. Unfortunately it is rather expensive.
