A more economical ruthenium-based fluorescent stain (Berggren et al 2002, Rabilloud et al 2001) and dilution of the stain (Krieg et al 2003). Figures are presented which show the following:

  • Gels should be prefixed rather than unfixed. 50:10% MeOH:MeCOOH consistently gives better results than unfixed gels.
  • In a plot of fluorescence intensity vs. ng BSA, any kind of fixation produced the same results: 50:3% EtOH:MeCOOH, 10:7% MeOH:MeCOOH, and 50:10% MeOH:MeCOOH, compared to no fixation. Thus 10:7% MeOH:MeCOOH is the most economical
  • A time course shows that fluorescence consistently improves with staining time. At 7 h, intensity is generally twice that of 3 h, and overnight is usually twice that of 7 h.
  • The stain was diluted 1/2, 1/3, 1/5, 1/10, and 1/20. There were clear reductions in fluorescence intensity at higher amounts of protein, but the reductions were less so with smaller amounts of protein.
  • In looking at re-used stains, there was a clear reduction of fluorescence intensity with each re-use, but when the volumes used were in greater volumes, more fluorescence intensity was retained (see table)
    ng BSA: 62.5 125 250 500 1000
    50 ml
    unused 1500 2500 3900 6600 11,000
    1X 800 1200 2200 3300 6100
    2X 700 1100 1800 2800 5000
    100 ml
    unused 1300 2200 3600 6000 9500
    1X 1000 1700 3000 5300 8500
    2X 800 1400 2500 4100 6700
    Note that gels were preincubated in two changes of 50:10% MeOH:MeCOOH, for 30 min each.

Maleknia SD, Downward KM (2005) Anal. Chem. 77, 111-119.

Charge Ratio Method: Approach for Deconvolution of Electrospray Mass Spectra

ESI-MS produces multiply charged ions, and so deconvolution algorithms are used to calculate charge states, then the mass. The following equation is fundamental to their determination:

Rz = (M ± zm)/z    [1]

From the m/z value for any two ions (Rz)a and (Rz)b within the spectrum and the corresponding charge difference (zb = za + integer) along with assumptions about the charge-carrying species m, the equations constructed can be used to solve M. In addition, entropy-based calculations are used first to predict a molecular weight range and then hypothetically multiply charged species are fit to the data.

The charge ratio analysis method (CRAM) is the ratio of two multiply charged ions, a and b, originating from the same compound derived from eq. 1

(Rz)a = zb(M ± zam)    [2]
(Rz)b za(M ± zbm)

When the mass of the species M is very large, as for proteins, that is when M >> zam or zbm, then eq 2 simplifies to

(Rz)a = zb    [3]
(Rz)b za

A comparison of the ratio of m/z values (Rz) to the unique ratio of any two integers identifies the charge state values for each of the ions. Once the charge states are identified, the Rz values for two ions are multiplied by their charge state values.

(Rz)a za = M ± zam    [4]
(Rz)b zb = M ± zbm    [5]
(Rz)az − (Rz)bz = ±m (za − zb)    [6]

When z and m are obtained, eq. 1 can be used to evaluate M.

An example of lysozyme is used. Its average mass is 14305.1438 Da. A table lists the theoretically generated (Rz)n) values for the lysozyme ions with 10-13 charges formed from addition of protons, and sodium and potassium ions. For a ratio of 1301.47542/1431.52218 = 0.90915, this is closest to 0.90909 obtained by dividing 10 by 11. Thus the calculation of these means that these species represent +10 and +11 ions.

Now eq. 6 is applied to find the difference in the mass:

(1301.47542 × 11) − (1431.52218 × 10) = 1.0078

This represents the difference for the mass of a proton, which this must be the charge-carrying species that accounts for the difference in the +10 and +11 species.

The errors associated with these determinations are calculated as:

| (Rz)n + 1/(Rz)n − zn / zn + 1 |

When the adducts are protons, the errors are 6 × 10−5 (60 ppm) of their theoretical values; when potassium, then 244 × 10−5 of the theoretical values. This follows from the assumption of M >> znm. As znm increases with the adduct size however, this value becomes more significant relative to M.

CRAM is not limited to calculations of adjacent/consecutive m/z species. It can calculate using any two m/z for which Δz > 1.

Correlating Isotopic Compositions of the Charged Species Using CRAM. Another feature of CRAM is its ability to find within isotope clusters of the charged species the match between those species representing identical isotopic compositions with but the exception of the addition of the charged species. The process requires acquisition of high resolution mass spectra to see accurate masses of the isotopes of the multiply charged species. A table is constructed with the m/z values of each isotope, its relative intensity, the isotope spacing (1/zn), and the calculation of the error. In addition the ratios of all isotopes in one cluster of a multiply charged species and the isotopes in another cluster are determined. Suppose that A and B represent one multiply charged species, and Am and Bn represent the mth and nth isotope in their clusters (it could represent only isotopes with m/z that meet a minimum threshold relative intensity). The ratio Am / Bn is determined for all m and n. If the ratio of A1 / B3 = 0.92857 (i.e., the 1st isotope in the cluster of species A and the 3rd isotope in cluster B is that ratio value), then that corresponds to quotient of the division of integers 13 / 14. Thus the isotopes A1 and B3 have identical isotopic composition. It can also be seen that A2 / B4 have the same ratio within experimental error, and are thus isotopically identical too, as would be expected.

Stübiger G, Marchetti M, Nagano M, Reichel C, Gmeiner G, Allmaier G (2005) Rapid Commun. Mass Spectrom. 19, 728-742.

Characterisation of Intact Recombinant Human Erythropoietins Applied in Doping By Means of Planar Gel Electrophoretic Techniques and Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Linear Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry

Human erythropoietin (EPO) is produced in human adult kidney and coded by the chromosome 7 into 193 amino acid long pre-protein with 27 aa signal peptide. The mature form is 165 aa (with Des-Arg, 166) long and has N-glycosylation at Asn-24, -38, and -83, and O-glycosylation at Ser-26, MW calculated to be 18240 Da. Hypoxia leads to transcriptional induction, as well as effects of hGH, ACTH, IL-3, angiotensin II, and catecholamines. First recombinants in mammalian cells were reported in 1985, and FDA approved drug in 1987. Natural and derivative hEPO (NESP, pegylated EPO, continuous erythropoiesis receptor activator [CERA]) are widely available on market (Erypo, ESPO, Epogin, Procrit, NeoRecormon, Aranesp).

For this study Janssen-Cilag Erypo (2000 IU EOP-α injection, in 500 µl), Roche NeoRecormon (500 IU EPO-β in 300 µl) and Amgen Aranesp (10 µg novel erythropoiesis stimulating protein in 400 µl) were studied. 1 IU is about 8.4 ng (~280 fmol). Most chemicals are Sigma. MALDI matrices are Fluka. See M&M for other suppliers.

The commercial products were de-salted on MicroSpin G-25 columns (Amersham Biosciences) and analyzed on 10% bis-Tris-SDS-PAGE. Detection limits were 400 and 80 ng on Coomassie- and silver-stained gels, respectively. MW of bands was estimated from log MW vs. Rm plot: EPO-β has a lower 36 kDa with than EPO-α at 37 kDa. These are 6-7 kDa higher than seen on MALDI-MS, probably because of non-ideal mobility by failure of SDS to bind to oligosaccharides. Slab gel (planar) IEF was done with electrotransfer to PVDF and immunostaining. NESP was far more highly acidic than EPO-α or -β, probably because it is highly sialyted. EPO-α shows 4-5 isoforms, and EPO-β about 7 to 8. Two EPO-β isoforms were quite basic. NESP resolved 4 bands. Detection limit for immunostaining is about 20 pg using chemiluminescent detection (strepavidin-biotin HRP + Covalight chemilum kit). With increases in loaded amount, other bands were detected.

The EPO products were de-sialyated (in 10 mU Roche neuraminidase per µg protein in 10 mM sodium bicarbonate pH 8.0, 18 h at 37° rocked at 350 rpm on thermomixer). Bands of identical mobility are seen on SDS-PAGE in enzyme-treated samples. Deglycosylation (Roche PNGase F 1-3 U/µg proteins 18 h at 37° in pH 8 product buffer) produces EPO-α running at 19 kDa, the O-glycosylated product. NESP deglycosylation (no prior reduction alkylation) showed incomplete reaction with two bands at 28 and 19 kDa; the 28 kDa band is still N-glycosylated at one point. With reductive-alkylation, the 28 kDa band disappears.

MALDI-MS at threshold energy shows an average MW of 30.2 ± 0.4 kDa for EPO-α and -β and 37.6 ± 0.9 kDa for NESP. Measurements (n = 12-17) done with an external calibration of [M]+ signals using sinapinic acid. Weight can fluctuate ± 1.3% for EPO-α and -β and ±2.4% for NESP if laser energy is beyond threshold. Internal calibrants trypsin and enolase provide a higher mass accuracy.

Purified proteins from the bottle were ZipTipped and spotted for MALDI-MS. Spectra of NESP showed an [M]+ of m/z 36807.1 corrected by use of 23.3 kDa trypsin and 46.7 kDa enolase internally. EPO-α [M]+ is m/z 29869.0.

Proteins were run on SDS-PAGE, extracted from gel slices cut with scalpel, destained with 40% MeCN/60% 50 mM ammonium bicarbonate, washed in water, crushed with glass rod, then extracted in 1:3:2 formic acid:water:isopropanol. Gel particles were spun down and supernatants evaporated. Proteins are resuspended in 1% formic acid and cleaned with ZipTips. MALDI-MS spectra show an [M]+ with m/z 36092.3 and [M]2+ of m/z 17984.8 for NESP, and [M]+ with m/z 28971.3 and [M]2+ of m/z 14498.7 for EPO-α. In some cases the weight differences are due to sodium and/or potassium adduct formation despite extensive desalting. The 6.7 kDa mass difference between NESP and EPO-α and -β is due to additional N-glycations.

Matrices such as sinapinic and ferulic acid, and the benzoic acids (DHB, and super-DHB) did well in ionizing EPO products. The trans-cinnamic acids crystallized well: sinapinic acid shows disperse distributed rhombic crystal, while ferulic is more needle-like (from 0.5-1 mm long) around rim. Laser aims at crystals produce sustained spectra. With respect to S/N and peak resolution, no one matrix stood out from the others. Metastable fragmentation is seen when there is an asymmetric peak tailing that results from raising the laser energy especially on DHB matrices. 3-5 mg/ml matrix concentrations were good, and higher (≥ 10 mg/ml) may contribute to noise, drowning out sample signals in the fmol range. At ≤ 1 mg/ml, crystal formation is impaired with signal loss. A DHB/CHCA combination in 5% formic acid/0.1% TFA has been used: less laser energy is required but there are multiple charged forms. Calculation of the 1+ ion from multiple charged states shows a difference from the direct measurement of a [M]+ ion, but may be more accurate. Other matrices caffeic acid, 2,6-DHAP, 3-HPA and β-carbolines (harmaline, nor-harmane) failed because there were too many laser aims to find a sweet spot. In negative ion mode THAP with ammonium citrate produced ionization; shown to work with sialyated glycoproteins and glycopeptides; it worked in positive ion mode too, but the other matrices were far better.

C18 ZipTip binding capacity for rhEPO was shown to be ≤ 1 µg, and similar to findings for C4 ZipTips. MALDI-MS (on Shimadzu Biotech Kratos Analytical AXIMA-LNR, 10 Hz firing, 3 ns pulse with 1.2 m linear tube with delayed extraction, 20 kV acceleration, externally calibrated with +1 and +2 ions of BSA) was done on stainless steel with different target surface types. CS4- and KA4-type plates gave the best results whereas KA-2 gnd gold-plated were adequate down only to upper fmol range. Use of a DropStop hydrophobic surface layer gave improved sensitivtiy in the 50-100 fmol range. Sinapinic and ferulic were comparable on different plates, the latter better on stainless steel, the former on DropStop.

It is generally indicated that small crystal homogeneity works best for MALDI spectrum quality and sensitivity, but results here show that larger crystals with higher local concentrations of analytes improve sensitivity. Slower evaporation on DropStop plates provide better crystals; slower crystallization may also help in salt exclusion.

The MALDI peaks of rhEPO are quite broad (RFWHM ~ 15). With desialylation, there is a shift in the peak maxima down by 3-6 kDa, which indicates a loss of 10-20 sialic acid residues (MW 291 Da). When the sialic acids are removed with their attached alkali salts there is a signficant resolution enhancement (R ~ 190). Hence the broad peak is the microheterogeneity caused by sialic acid presence producing unresolved signal. 8-10 individual well-separated peaks are then observed which represent permutations of O- and N-glycosylation. The 370 Da mass difference between the peaks indicates differences in N-acetyllactosamine (365 Da). The various peaks could be assigned to 1-2 tri- and 2-3 tetraanntenary N-glycan forms of EPO-α and -β. Another series of peaks separated by 150 Da on the main peak might be differences in fucosylated and non-fucosylated forms (fucose 146 Da), expressed to lesser degree in CHO cells.

N-deglycosylation produced molecules with only O-glycosylation, but the spectrum indicated variable degrees of sialylation, so the protein was treated with both neuraminidase and PNGase F. With both enzyme treatments, the very predominant peak is [M]+ at m/z 18519.9 with significant peak tailing. A slight peak at baseline at m/z 18157.6 represents the completely unglycosylated form. When EPO-α is treated only with PNGase F, several peaks around m/z 18500-1900 are seen: m/z 19110.3 with two sialic acids on the O-glycan, m/z 18817.1 with one sialic acid on the O-glycan, m/z 18533.9 (not labeled), and the non-glycosylated one.

MALDI-MS spectrum is different with reductive alkylation then PNGase: a two sialic acid O-glycan product is seen at m/z 19189.7. The spectrum of NESP was quite complex, with PNGase F treatment still showing mono-N-glycosylated envelope of peaks with a maximum of m/z 21959.0. IEF-separated isoforms were processed to MALDI-MS

Qian W-J, Monroe ME, Strittmatter EF, Jacobs JM, Kangas LJ, Petritis K, Camp II DG, Smith RD (2005) J. Proteome Res. 4, 53-62.

Probability-Based Evaluation of Peptide and Protein Identifications from Tandem Mass Spectrometry and SEQUEST Analysis: The Human Proteome

Proteome samples from three human-derived samples were generated: blood plasma, a human mammary epithelial cell (HMEC) line 184 A1L5, and human hepatocyte cell line Huh-7.5. Cell lysates are denatured in 8 M urea in 50 mM NH4CO3 pH 8.2 and reduced in 10 mM DTT for 1 h 37°, followed by alkylation in 40 mM iodoacetamide 90 min RT, shaking in the dark. Samples are diluted 8-fold in 50 mM NH4CO3, and digested in Promega porcine trypsin with 1:50 (w/w) trypsin:protein. Samples are then boiled 5 min and placed on ice. In addition a tryptic peptide mix of 17 pure proteins is produced: proteins are BSA, bovine casein (contains 4 caseins), ovalbumin, horse myoglobin, bovine lactoglobulin, bovine cardiac anhydrase, bovine Hb, chicken lysozyme, bovine ubiquitin, bovine catalase, rabbit G3PDH, and bovine ribonuclease 1-A. For offline SCX, peptides are reconstituted in 1.0 ml of 10 mM HCOONH4, 25% MeCN pH 3.0 (solvent A) and injected on Polysulfoethyl A 200 in 4.6 mm column at 1 ml/min. Solvent B is 500 mM HCOONH4 with 25% MeCN pH 6.8. The gradient program is 0-50% over 40 min and then 50-100% for 10 min. 35-70 fractions are taken and lyophilized. The 17-protein peptide mix was analyzed 12 times. RPLC-MS/MS was then done using an LCQ Deca XP ion-trap MS (Thermo Finnigan). The capillary column is slurry-packed 5 µm Jupiter C18 (Phenomenex) into 150 µm i.d. (360 µm o.d.) × 65 cm fused silica (Polymicro Tech). Mobile phase is 0.2% acetic acid and 0.05% TFA in water (solvent A) and 0.1% TFA in 90% MeCN (solvent B). The SCX fractions are dissolved in 50 µl 25 mM HCOONH4 pH 8.0, and 10 µl injected. Gradient is exponential, increasing to 70% B over 150 min. MS is operated in data-dependent MS/MS mode (m/z 400-2000) with full MS scan followed by three MS/MS scans and normalized collision of 45%. MS/MS spectra are searched against human IPI database and the reversed database with SEQUEST algorithm. Searches included the fixed modification of carbamidoyl-cysteine. Finally the count of unique peptide identifications from the reversed database (NN) was divided by the count from the normal database (NR) to get the false positive rate (=NR/NN).

The number of MS/MS spectra generated from LC-MS/MS analyses of the SCX fractions (run in duplicate) is shown in the table:

Proteome LC-MS/MS analyses MS/MS spectra
human plasma 140 470,000
HMEC lysate 69 230,000
Huh-7.5 lysate 74 250,000

Spectral data are submitted to normal and reversed databases by SEQUEST. Xcorr and ΔCn are used to examine correlation between peptide scores and false positive rates. Xcorr is cross-correlation score between actual and predicted MS/MS spectrum, and ΔCn is relative difference between correlation score for top-matching peptide and second-best match. Usefulness of a reversed database for yeast proteomes has been discussed elsewhere. The count of unique peptide identifications from a reversed database (NR) that pass the filtering criteria is an estimate of the number of false positives. Since the count of unique IDs from the normal database is the count of true positives plus the number of false positives, and the false positive rate is defined as the proportion of false positives among all positives (true and false), then the rate = FP/(TP + FP), NR = FP, and NN = TP + FP; thus the rate = NR/NN. As verification of this model, searching including the 17 known protein peptide mix with nonhuman sequences.

Table 1 shows a list of the count of true and false positives from the normal and reversed databases. The data shows that the count of FP and the FP rate agree between the two dbases. Most false peptide assignments result from random matching. This means searching against the reversed dbase gives a reliable estimation of the FP count.

The FP rate was evaluated for peptide IDs from the three proteomes based on several different parameters include peptide ion charge states, tryptic cleavage states (full vs. partial), Xcorr, and ΔCn. The estimated proportion of FP was plotted against ΔCn for different Xcorr scores greater than a certain value (1.5, 1.8, 2.1, 2.4) both for human plasma and HMEC lysates with doubly charged fully tryptic peptides selected. The FP rate was then normalized between the two proteomes and plotted against ΔCn. The plots had the same pattern: the FP rate decreases as the cutoff value of ΔCn increases. A polynomial fit revealed y = 33.183x2 −11.931x + 1.1036 with residual (R2) = 0.9943, where y is the normalized FP rate and x is ΔCn.

Delany J, Floyd ZE, Zvonic S, Smith A, Gravois A, Reiners E, Wu X, Kilroy G, Lefevre, Gimble JM (2005) FASEB J.   DOI:10.1096/fj.03-1100fje

Proteomic Analysis of Primary Cultures of Human Adipose-Derived Stem Cells: Modulation by Adipogenesis

Notes are located here

Möhring T, Kellmann M, Jürgens M, Schrader M (2005) J. Mass Spectrom. 40, 214-226.

Top-Down Identification of Endogenous Peptides Up to 9 kDa in Cerebrospinal Fluid and Brain Tissue by Nanoelectrospray Quadrupole Time-of-Flight Tandem Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. Recent work on protein and peptide biomarker patterns revealed the difficulties in identifying their molecular components, which is indispensable for validation of the biological context. Cerebrospinal fluid and brain tissue are used as sources to discover new biomarkers, e.g. for neurodegenerative diseases. Many of these biomarker candidates are peptides with amolecular mass of <10 kDa. Their identification is favourably achieved with a top-down approach, because this requires less purification and an enzymatic cleavage will often not yield enough specific fragments for successful database searches. Here, we describe an approach using quadrupole time-of-flight mass spectrometry (TOFMS) as a highly efficient mass spectrometric purification and identification tool after off-line decomplexation of biological samples by liquid chromatography.After initial peptidomic screeningwith matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI) TOFMS, the elution behaviour in chromatography and the exact molecular mass were used to locate the same signals in nanoelectrospray measurements.Most of the peaks detected inMALDI-TOFMS could be retrieved in nanoelectrospray quadrupole TOFMS. Suitable collision energies for informative fragment spectra were investigated for different parent ions, charge states and molecular masses. After collision-induced dissociation, the resulting fragmentation data of multiply charged ions can become much more complicated than those derived from tryptic peptide digests. However, the mass accuracy and resolution of quadrupole TOF instruments results in high-quality data suitable for determining peptide sequences. The protein precursor, proteolytic processing and post-translational modifications were identified by automated database searches. This is demonstrated by the exemplary identifications of thymosin beta-4 (5.0 kDa) and NPY (4.3 kDa) from rat hypothalamic tissue and ubiquitin (8.6 kDa) from human cerebrospinal fluid. The high data quality should also allow for de novo identification. This methodology is generally applicable for peptides up to amolecular mass of about 10 kDa from body fluids, tissues or other biological sources.

Zehl M, Allmaier G (2005) Anal. Chem. 77, 103-110.

Instrumental Parameters in the MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometric Analysis of Quaternary Protein Structures

Chicken avidin is homotetramer strong in association that has alkaline pI. It has a high affinity for biotin. It has 128 amino acids with estimated calculated weight of 14,342.14 Da. Iti is glycosylated on Asn-17, but glycan not really analyzed. MALDI glycoprotein analysis will resolve 11 masses ranging from 15,396.66 to 15965.08 Da, with 41 and 162 Da differences indicating differenes in hexoses and N-acetylhexosamine units. The tetramer is stable in wide range of pH and temperature: association stablized by hydrophobic contacts, hydrogen bonds, salt bridges.

MALDI was a AXIMA-LNR and AXIMA-CFR ToF from Shimadzu Biotech-Kratos Analytical with 1 GHz TDC, using 20 kV accelerating with delayed extraction time set. Pulse width of laser is 4 ns with 150 µm dia. spot aim.

Spectra were acquired by spotting with 2,6-DHAP in 25:75 MeCN:20 mM ammonium acetate. The tetramer had the greater intensity compared to the monomer. Also 2+ and cluster ions were detected. Because of carbohydrate microheterogeneity, a broad peak width was seen. Average mass of the assembly was 63914 Da, which is higher than the expected 63292 Da with the isoform of (Hex4HexNAc)2(Hex7HexNAc2)2 accounted for. Possibly from the specific and nonspecific association with low neutral MW substances this shift is caused. Peak broadening and mass shift is seen in ESI-MS spectra of assemblies, particularly if desolvation is incomplete.

When sample was prepared in 25 mg/ml 2,6-DHAP in THF and completely different spectrum with a series of cluster ions up to 200,000, all 1+ ions representing subunit associations that are not natural.

Equine liver ADH is a homodimer, each subunit with two Zn2+ atoms. Subunit is 374 amino acids with N-acetylserine N-terminus, and theoretical mass of 39846.4 Da. MALDI mass measurement average was 39861.8 which 0.04% off. The homodimer was more intense than the monomer, with the benefit of ammonium acetate improving desorption and ionization.

Bovine liver catalase was tried with both TFA-containing matrix (2,6-DHAP saturated in 25% MeCN in 0.1% TFA) and only the monomer was seen. When ammonium acetate was used instead the aposubunit peak and holosubunit (polypeptide with heme b) is seen. Also seen is the intact subunit assembly.

Repeated irradiation did not reveal a first shot phenomenon since some residual peak of the oligomer was always seen. To determine effect of laser pulse energy, a single spectrum was made from 50 unselected laser shots with both continuous and delayed extraction tried. An optical density filter on the laser was adjusted from 90 to 170 by steps of 10 (arbitrary units) corresponding to exponential energy increases from 6.3 to 60 µJ. Peak intensity correlated with input laser energy with saturation reached at about 150 on laser wheel (~34 µJ). At laser energy threshold virtually on the subunit assembly was detected while increases in laser energy result in monomeric subunits and cluster ions being seen. Cluster ion formation with higher laser energy is likely. These results are seen with continuous or delayed extraction.

As for cluster ions, low laser energy pulses show formation of clusters with multiple intact assemblies whereas higher energy pulses for clusters made of multiple monomeric subunits. The 2M+ assemblies reach maximum intensity ratios at lower energy pulses compared to clusters ion of nonassemblied subunits (3suunit+) likely because of high energy pulse disrupting association of the intact assembly while cluster ion formation still occurs. The reason that matrix/solvent did not cause preformed clusters is that these were not present at lower energy pulses.

Delayed extraction time allows for enhanced resolution by allowing internal energies of ions to even out and reducing possibilities of collisions that cause change in resolution. However, the time delay permits in-source decay as well. Delay times of 416, 588, and 832 ns were applied. This variation had little effect on cluster ion or intact assembly peak intensity compared to laser energy as the variable. While no trend was seen with intact assemblies, cluster ion intensity decreased with increasing delay time. These data indicate that laser-induced dissocation occurs prior to any effect of delayed extraction time.

Use of reflectron mode is not warranted with high mass ions. No resolution enhancement is found and sensitivity and S/N are decreased. Nonetheless reflectron can be used when metastable fragmentation of the ion is suspected. Spectra of avidin show no change in mass and thus no in-source instability of subunit association.

Churchward MA, Butt RH, Lang JC, Hsu KK, Coorssen JR (2005) Proteome Sci. 3, 5.

Enhanced Detergent Extraction for Analysis of Membrane Proteomes by Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis

RBC extracts can be screened using 1D SDS-PAGE to determine the effects of extraction reagents, the effects being compared to controlled extractions with detergents like CHAPS and SDS. Band III was seen in SDS extracts at ~110 kDa, but not with CHAPS; so was a band at 28 kDa. Detergents showing improvements in the ability to extract more proteins than CHAPS included L-lauryl lysophosphatidylcholine (LPC), the N-methylglucanamide detergents MEGA 8, 9, and 10, and the sulfobetaine-based detergents ASB-14 and SB 3-10. Natural source lipids lysophosphatidylethanolamine (LPE), lysophosphatidylglycerol (LPG), LPC from egg, lysophosphatidylserine (LPS) from bovine brain, and cardiolipin from bovine heart were generally of limited general usefulness, largely because they are charged at neutral pH and would interfere with IEF and difficult for the purposes here.

RBC membranes were extracted in a 2DGE buffer containing 4% CHAPS or a 1-2% total detergent (CHAPS is one of the few detergents soluble at such a high concentration). Extraction with LPC and MEGA 10 showed improvement in the maps compared to CHAPS. The maps with SB 3-10 were similar to the CHAPS, but this detergent is not too soluble in high urea. Use of ASB-14 did not improve the results found with CHAPS or SB 3-10, contrary to previous reports.

Experiments were now tried with 3% CHAPS and 1% of another detergent, being either LPC or MEGA 10, and using membranes of RBCs, mouse brains, or mouse liver. With CHAPS and LPC, spot densities were improved and there was some reduced horizontal streaking in the intermediate MW range. Some areas of the gel clearly revealed more proteins. Band III was a prominent spot, and there wasa 2.2-fold increase in spot density for a string of spots compared to the CHAPS gel. Three more spots are seen with 3% CHAPS:1% LPC. Maps of RBC membranes extracted with 3% CHAPS:1% MEGA 10 were equivalent with 3% CHAPS:1% LPC and 4% CHAPS. The combination of 3% CHAPS:0.5% LPC:0.5% MEGA 10 did not really improve upon 3:1 CHAPS:LPC, although it was still an improvement over CHAPS alone, with a density increase of 1.7-fold. LPC addition alone enhances recovery and resolution on 2D gels.

These experiments were only done on RBC membranes, and so it was necessary to test perhaps more complex tissue types. The four extraction conditions (4% CHAPS, 3% CHAPS:1% LPC, 3% CHAPS:1% MEGA 10, 3% CHAPS:0.5% LPC:0.5% MEGA 10) were tried. All results were similar to those found for RBC membranes. Spot number, density and resolution was better with CHAPS:LPC compared to CHAPS alone.

Wu L, van Winden WA, van Gulik WM, Heijnen JJ (2005) Metab. Engin. 7, 302-310.

Application of Metabolome Data in Functional Genomics: A Conceptual Strategy

REVIEW.

ABSTRACT. A gene with yet unknown physiological function can be studied by changing its expression level followed by analysis of the resulting phenotype. This type of functional genomics study can be complicated by the occurrence of silent mutations, the phenotypes of which are not easily observable in terms of metabolic fluxes (e.g., the growth rate). Nevertheless, genetic alteration may give rise to significant yet complicated changes in the metabolome. We propose here a conceptual functional genomics strategy based on microbial metabolome data, which identifies changes in in vivo enzyme activities in the mutants. These predicted changes are used to formulate hypotheses to infer unknown gene functions. The required metabolome data can be obtained solely from highthroughput mass spectrometry analysis, which provides the following in vivo information: (1) the metabolite concentrations in the reference and the mutant strain; (2) the metabolic fluxes in both strains and (3) the enzyme kinetic parameters of the reference strain. We demonstrate in silico that changes in enzyme activities can be accurately predicted by this approach, even in silent mutants.

Ram RJ, VerBerkmoes NC, Thelen MP, Tyson GW, Baker BJ, Blake RC 2nd, Shah M, Hettich RL, Banfield JF (2005) Science 308, 1915-1920.

Community Proteomics of a Natural Microbial Biofilm

ABSTRACT. Using genomic and mass spectrometrybased proteomic methods, we evaluated gene expression, identified key activities, and examined partitioning of metabolic functions in a natural acid mine drainage (AMD) microbial biofilm community. We detected 2033 proteins from the five most abundant species in the biofilm, including 48% of the predicted proteins from the dominant biofilm organism, Leptospirillum group II. Proteins involved in protein refolding and response to oxidative stress appeared to be highly expressed, which suggests that damage to biomolecules is a key challenge for survival. We validated and estimated the relative abundance and cellular localization of 357 unique and 215 conserved novel proteins and determined that one abundant novel protein is a cytochrome central to iron oxidation and AMD formation.

Hu S, Xie Y, Ramachandran P, Ogorzalek, Loo RR, Li Y, Loo JA, Wong DT (2005) Proteomics 5, 1714-1728.

Large-Scale Identification of Proteins in Human Salivary Proteome by Liquid Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry and Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis-Mass Spectrometry

The human salivary proteomes has a mix of proteins and peptides that maintain oral cavity homeostasis. About 80 such proteins have been identified. This compares to about 1000 proteins in plasma (human). A more global analysis was sought by taking whole saliva from healthy, non-smoking male in morning 2 h AFTER eating and rinsing water with mouth. 1 µl/ml saliva of Sigma inhibitor cocktail was used and sodium vanadate added to 1 mM. Saliva having a 5 ml volume was obtained and and centrifuged at 1300 g for 5 min, then centrifuged again at 14,000 g for 15 min at 4°. Bradford showed a protein concentration of 350 µg/ml. Samples are divided into 1 ml aliquots and stored at −80°.

LC-MS/MS. Samples were fractionated using centrifugal ultrafilters: they were first concentrated on YM-10. YM-10 retentate and filtrate were then concentrated on YM-3. Fraction 1 represents filtrate from the YM-10f/YM-3f where r=retentate and f=filtrate and the serial order of filtration is shown. Fraction 2 is the YM-10f/YM-3r. Fraction 3 is YM10r. For 0.5 ml saliva, the final volumes are 50 µl for the retentates (fracs 2 and 3) and 400 µl for the one filtrate (frac 1). 200 µl of f1 was dried in vacuum centrifuge then stored at −80°. The other 200 µl was given 40 µl MeCN and 50 µl trypsin and incubated 37° overnight. f2 and f3 are treated with 10 mM DTT 30 min, then 50 mM iodoacetamide 30 min in dark. 10 µl MeCN and 50 µl 20 µg/ml trypsin added for overnight digestion at 37°. Samples are dried after digestion and stored −80°. LC-MS/MS was done with nano-LC system (LC Packings) coupled to Protana electrospray interface and QSTAR XL (ABi) quadrupole ToF MS. Samples are passed to PepMap C18 5 µm (300 µm × 1 mm) for 5 min in 3% MeCN + 0.1% formic acid + 0.01% TFA. Samples are then injected on to PepMap C18 5 µm (75 µm × 150 mm) for separation at a flow of 180 nl/min. A program starts with 5% solvent B to 60% B in 55 min, then to 95% B in 0.1 min, then dropped to 90% B for 15 min, and then prepared 15 min for next run (solvent A = 5% MeCN + 0.1% FA + 0.01% TFA, solvent B = 95% MeCN + 0.1% FA + 0.01% TFA). A PicoTip 8 µm tip was used for ESI at 2000 V. Resolution is 5000-1000. Dynamic exclusion reduces repeat peptide analyses. Identification was through MASCOT and Pro ID (ABi).

2DGE and MALDI-MS. 150 µl whole saliva was treated with 10% TCA/90% acetone/20 mM DTT at −20° for 2.5 h. After spinning 14 krpm for 15 min, pellet was washed in cold acetone with 20 mM DTT and then resuspended in rehydration buffer. IEF was done on 11 cm pH 3-10NL IPG strips (Bio-Rad) and the 2nd dim was 12.5% precast using the Dodeca. Gels were stained with SYPRO Ruby. After imaging and analysis, spots were cut using spot cutter and then depositing in 96-well plate; digesting was on MassPREP and then analysis on M@LDI-LR using CHCA matrix. Additionally an ABi nano-LC ESI Q-ToF was used in MS/MS mode to get sequencing info. Data was searched against human database via MASCOT and Spectrum Mill (Agilent).

Fraction 1 (< 3000 Da by ultrafiltration) was run on LC-MS/MS, half undigested, and the other half on another run with trypsin digestion. Fraction 2 (between 3000 and 10000 Da) and Fraction 3 (> 10000 Da) were digested with trypsin. Each analysis was done 3 times. The LC run is 90 minutes long, although most peptides elute within 50 min, with MS/MS analyses between 10-50 min. 600 MS/MS spectra were produced in Fraction 1 data alone, and 800 and 1700 for fractions 2 and 3, respectively. For every Fraction 1 sequence produced, there was a database match. For Frac 2 and 3, > 10% of spectra had no peptide: could result from posttranslational modifications (glycosylation). Of the 3100 MS/MS, about 600 were reliable for database searching.

One example is of a Fraction 1 precursor +2 peptide with m/z 659.85 (note mass accuracy is 19 ppm). The MS/MS spectrum produced the range of bm and yn fragment ions to identify a proline-rich peptide GPGFVPPPPPPPY, derived from salivary proline-rich peptide P-B. Another MS/MS of the m/z 593.36 precursor (2+) produced sequence GLSTESILPR, originating from lacrimal lipocalin, a fairly common salivary protein. Totaled, 79 proteins were identfied from Fraction 1 (only 26 could be found with the trypsin digests however, whether enzymatic digestion was a factor in the search or not). With Fraction 2, 19 proteins were identifed, and with Fraction 3, 205 proteins. When removing redundant assignments, a total of 266 proteins were identified, with about 2.0-2.5 peptides used per protein. At least 46% of the proteins were matched with 2 or more peptides. Insofar as reproducibility, the sample was analyzed on three different days. With the triplicate studies, 65% of the proteins were identified in all three studies.

2DGE was done with SYPRO Ruby staining, revealing 300 spots total. Of these 105 spots were actually excised from the gel, destained and then digested in situ. Fragments were extracted from gel piece and then run on either MALDI-MS or LC-MS/MS. Spot 43 produces several peptides in the m/z 800-4000 range (resolution = 14,000, mass accuracy ~30 ppm). 24 spectral peaks were matched with 51% coverage to salivary amylase, confirmed by LC-MS/MS of this spot. 64 distinct proteins were identified (more than reported previously using this approach for the salivary proteome). 21 of these proteins (33% of the MALDI total) had already been identified by the shotgun approach. Hence perhaps both should be used when characterizing the proteome.

Campostrini N, Areces LB, Rappsilber J, Pietrogrande MC, Dondi F, Pastorino F, Ponzoni M, Righetti PG (2005) Proteomics 5, 2385-2395.

Spot Overlapping in Two-Dimensional Maps: A Serious Problem Ignored for Much Too Long

In using 18 × 20 cm 2D gels loaded with minute amounts of protein from biopsies, we observed 264 spots instead of the usual 750 spots when loading standard amounts. This would be a minimal number with colloidal Coomassie stained gels as opposed to silver stained. Of the 264 spots, 85 were found to be up- or down-regulated in the tumor tissue. These were eluted for LC-MS/MS and 74 of them could be identified. 52 of the 74 were found to be single proteins, 14 had two polypeptides, 6 had three, 1 had 4, and another had 5 peptides.

To estimate the degree of overlapping of spots, there is a statistical procedure that can be applied. The 2D gel map is divided into a proper number of strips (4) so that each strip contained 20 single components. For each 1-D separation, the statistical procedure was applied to estimate the count of proteins present in each strip and the sum yielded the total number in the map. In a strip, p is the total number of detectable spots, m is the total number of single components (must by ≥ p). For four strips, the p values are 21, 18, 19, and 16, with corresponding m values of 28, 21, 31, and 23, for a total of 74 spots containing a total of 103 (single) components. The degree of overlapping (γ) is p/m = 71%.

Bruschi M, Seppi C, Arena S, Musante L, Santucci L, Balduini C, Scaloni A, Lanciotti M, Righetti PG, Candiano G (2005) J. Proteome Res. 4, 1304-1309.

Proteomic Analysis of Erythrocyte Membranes by Soft Immobiline Gels Combined with Differential Protein Extraction

ABSTRACT. Improvements in proteome analysis of erythrocyte membrane proteins by two-dimensional electrophoresis are here reported. In particular, a differential extraction procedure was set up allowing separation of integral membrane proteins from peripheral species. Moreover, the use of dilute Immobiline gels (down to as low as 3% T matrix) permitted a better penetration and transfer inside the gel of proteins with large M(r). These protocol modifications, combined with sample delipidation and alkylation prior to electrophoresis, which prevented generation of homo- and hetero-oligomers following disulfide scrambling phenomena, allowed the display of more than 500 spots in the pI/M(r) plane. Among those, noteworthy was the presence of high levels of filamentous proteins, such as alpha-spectrin and ankyrins, or integral membrane proteins, such as band 3, band 4.1 and 4.2, not displayed or barely present in other maps exploiting immobilized pH gradients in the first dimension. Accordingly, our results show that this 2D mapping technique is a valuable tool in exploring pathologies related to genetic defects associated to membrane proteins.

Heremans K (2005) Braz. J. Med. Biol. Res. 38, 1157-1165.

Protein Dynamics: Hydration and Cavities

REVIEW. Cell lips, proteins and nucleic acids are sensitive to high temperature. Hyperthermophile bacteria adapt using ether lipids instead of more hydrolysis-sensitive ester lipids in mesophiles. There is a correlation between the unfolding of proteins and the inactivation (death) kinetics of microorganisms, indicating that proteins are the major targets in temperature-sensitive loss of life. Chaperones are proteins induced by heat found in hypertheromphile crude cell extracts whose function is to assist in folding during protein synthesis.

A new archeal species called Strain 121 is found to grow at 121°C. Survival at 130°C is for 2 h and 121°C for 1 h.

Microbial cells can bear a max pressure of 100 MPa, although motility, transport, cell division, cell growth, DNA synthesis, transcription, translation are all affected at lower pressures. Much depends on the state of the organism. Many have the ability to withstand high temp and pressure by going into a dehydrated or a sporulated state. In that way, pressures beyond 600 MPa and even 1 GPa have no effect, and organisms can survive from −253°C to 151°C.

Bridgman observed that a pressure of several hundred MPa will transform an egg white from raw to cooked look. It is basically an aqueous solution of protein, and pressure-induced coagulation becomes easier at low temperatures. Other studies have shown that during hard boiling of an egg, the yolk solidifies at a higher temperature than the white, while the reverse is for pressure when the white solidifies after the yolk.

A P vs. T (pressure vs. temperature) diagram has been developed for the generalized protein. An ellptical curve shows the phase transitions, the curve resulting from a Taylor expansion of the free energy difference between unfolded and native state; the second order terms make a substantial contribution. The volume change is dependent on both pressure and temperature (for gases, usually just pressure):

ΔV(p,T) = ΔV° + Δα(T−T0) −β(p−p0)

ΔV° refers to reference conditions. Δβ is a compressibility factor difference, and Δα is a difference of the thermal expansion factor. The correlation between enthalpy and volume change of the unfolding transition accounts for the elliptical phase diagram, with the major axes being the line where ΔH = 0 and ΔV = 0, and regions of the diagram involving ΔH either >0 or <0, and the same for ΔV. The diagram shows that pressure stabilizes the protein against thermal unfolding. In many cases the thermal denaturing transition temperature is raised with increased pressure.

Fluorescence spectroscopy indicates that heat-induced folding may arise from an exposure of protein core to water, while pressure-induced unfolding occurs from pressure-mediate penentration of water into protein matrix and then chain-chain interaction disruption.

Studies of water-soluble synthetic polymers with the main chain interacting hydrophobically and the side chains hydrophilically show that at low T and P, polymers are random coil (homogeneous one-phase). There is a formation of 2nd phase at high T or P. Polymers show aggregation in the 2nd phase, reduced by detergents, but which does not affect any change in the transition T or P points. Phase transition states monitored by IR also show similar results for gelatinazation of starch.

The partial molar volume of a protein is probably the sum of the partial molar volumes of the atoms, cavities, and hydration sphere (Kauzmann). Volume of atoms is independent of pressure and temp, but not so for the other two terms.

Dodds ED, Hyun JA, Hagerman PJ, Lebrilla CB (2005) J. Proteome Res. 5, 1195-1203.

Enhanced Peptide Mass Fingerprinting Through High Mass Accuracy: Exclusion of Non-Peptide Signals Based on Residual Mass

MOWSE scores are probalistic molecular weight search values reported by MASCOT. They are logarithmic transforms of the random match probability:f SM = −10 log(P) where P is the probability that the protein has been identified through a random guess. Factors involved in score calculation include searches optionally involving variable amino acid modifications, tolerance of missed proteolytic cleavage, and tolerance of mass error, count of proteins in the database, count of peptides matched, relative frequency of occurrence of peptide masses, and count of unassigned peaks in submitted query.

Sequence coverage usually less than 50% even under most favorable circumstances. Reasons why no assignment made to other peaks: unknown posttranslational modifications, variable modifications caused by sample preparation, mutations or splice variants, errors in database catalog used to predict masses, zero to low ionization efficiency (no peak to match a predicted peptide).

Algorithms are developed to refine PMF peak lists such as those making use of an isotopomer distribution fitting based on avg amino acid elemental composition (the averagine residue). Poisson statistics can be use do extract monoisotopic peptide masses. Iterative, successive rounds of peak list refinement to optimize outcome of PMF searches has been suggested. Combining multiple peak lists to arrive at a representative list have been tried.

Monoisotopic masses of peptides are normally distributed about specific fractional values for given nominal mass.

Torres MP, Thapar R, Marzluff WF, Borchers CH (2005) J. Proteome Res. 4, 1628-1635.

Phosphatase-Directed Phosphorylation-Site Determination: A Synthesis of Methods for the Detection and Identification of Phosphopeptides

Phosphoproteins were digested and then incubated with IMAC beads. The IMAC was made by getting 0.5-2.5 µl metal-free nitrilotriacetic acid beaded agarose with ~425 beads/µl in compact reactions columns 35 µm frit, USB Corp., and washing with ultrapure water, then incubating with 30 µl 50 mM ferric(III) nitrate in 12 mM HCl three times, rinsing with 30 µl water, then 30 µl 0.1% acetic acid. Peptides are diluted to 40 µl with 50 mM acetic acid and then incubated shaking at RT overnight. Unbound material is washed with 30 µl 0.1% acetic acid, 30 µl 30% MeCN/0.1% TFA, and 30 µl 0.1% acetic acid. Final volume is reduced to 5-10 µl and 0.25-0.4 µl of slurry (20-70 beads or 5-10% of total bead slurry) is spotted to MALDI plates. Alkaline phosphatase at various concentrations in 100 mM ammonium bicarbonate is spotted in identical volume (0.25-0.4 µl) with peptide or IMAC-bound peptides. After incubation time, a 0.5-0.8 µl satd CHCA matrxi in 50% MeCN + 0.1% TFA is spotted. As an alternative, CHCA in 50% MeCN/0.1-1.0% phosphoric acid was tried. A Bruker Daltonics Reflex III MALDI ToF was used with AnchorChip plate; for phosphatase optimization, and a ABi 4700 MALDI ToF/ToF for other work.

One method for phosphatase treatment is to incubate 0.75-1 h at 37° with 1 U ALP and then clean peptide over POROS R3 reversed phase resin, then do MS. For on-target digestion on plates, incubation times must be reduced to compensate for evaporation and enzyme quantities would be reduced to deal with possible suppression effects. Different enzyme dilutions were mixed in buffer in equal volumes with the model phosphopeptide PKA-I. Matrix addition stops the reaction since a test reaction was done with adding matrix first then the ALP and no dephosphorylation was seen. Different dilutions of enzyme affected the matrix crystallization (1:10 dilution of enzyme had significant inhibition effect on crystallization, but 1:100 enzyme did not). Complete dephosphorylation is found with 1:10 and 1:100 (0.25 and 0.025 U respectively), but ion signals from 1:10 are much less intense. All reactions were within 5 minutes. Note with 1:500 it could be seen that reactions were incomplete. Since only a 0.6 µl volume is added, it is fully evaporated in 5-6 min, and so dephosphorylation should be completed at a rate of 500 fmol/min.

KDIR-4 phosphopeptides were bound to immobilized Fe(III); a control using uncharged IMAC beads was also done, and beads spotted (20-70 beads per spot). KDIR was seen only on charged IMAC beads and its phosphate disappeared with phosphatase treatment. Ionization was seen only when the laser is aimed directly at the beads in peptides not treated with ALP. In an earlier study with MALDI-QToF the matrix caused elution from the beads, although the matrix was different (2,5-DHB) since DHB was better than CHCA. When peptides were ALP-treated, the better ionization was when the laser is aimed the edges of bead clusters, indicating that either the phosphatase reaction or ammonium bicarbonate buffer caused elution.

The KDIR-4 phosphopeptide on the IMAC beads shows a m/z of 1702.7. This peak is not detected after sequentially spotting beads followed by ammonium bicarb without phosphatase. When phosphatase was in the ammonium bicarb buffer, KDIR-4 dephosphorylation is seen. IMAC beads remaining in the compact column were washed with ammonium bicarb buffer and no peptides was found in wash solution (passed through C18 zip-tip to desalt); KDIR-4 phosphopeptide does bind to C18 zip-tip in ammonium bicarb buffer. No peaks are seen from IMAC beads washed with ammonium bicarb, nor after re-equilibration of beads with 0.1% acetic acid. These results appear to show that there is a strong immobilization of phosphopeptide to Fe(III)-charged IMAC beads which is irreversible with acetic acid and which thus prevents ionization from beads. This can be overcome by using the phosphatase treatment.

Proline effect, Fragmentation, FD

Harrison AG, Young AB (2005) J. Mass Spectrom. 40, 1173-1186.

Fragmentation reactions of deprotonated peptides containing proline. The proline effect

In previous work by AGH, [M-H]− deprotonated ions of ProVal and AlaPro were studied and the major fragmentation involved loss of CO2 for forming a2 and y1 ions. The Pro-Ala and Pro-Val peptides are studied here using a Q-ToF. Spectra containing m/z 113 and 72 were not expected in high energy CID of Ala-Pro, nor for m/z 141 in Pro-Val. For Pro-Ala under CID at 20 eV, six ions are produced, with m/z 141 being an a2 ion and m/z 88 being a y1 ion. In MS3 spectrum of a2 produces three ions at m/z 47.4, 100, and 15.2. For Pro-Val, also six ions with m/z 169 being a2 and m/z 116 being y1. Four ions from a2 are at m/z 100, 59.1, 13.9, and 9.4. Loss of CO2 accounts for a2, and elimination of Pro accounts for y1. The reaction scheme for the disintegration of the a2 ion is depicted with a proton from the N-terminal proton moving to the α-C carbanion formed in a2. This then leads to a break break of the α-C and carbonyl carbon-carbon bond and simultaneous break of peptide (amide) bond with formation of 1-pyrroline (also 3,4-dihydro-2H-pyrrole, CAS 5724-81-2) and CO, both neutral losses. What remains is an R1CH2NH− anion detected as m/z 72 if R1 is CH3 of Pro-Ala or m/z 100 if R1 is isopropyl group of Pro-Val. The elemental composition of m/z 113 in the Pro-Ala fragmentation should be [C5H9N2O]−, which is an elimination of H2C=CH2 from a2 ion. Similarly the elimination of H2C=CH2 in Pro-Val should produce a [C7H13N2O]− ion. This elimination of ethylene would be possible if the anionic proline ring has a C2-C3 carbon bond break to produce an enamine N-terminus with the α carbon branched with ethyl anion, leading to ethylene loss and the carbanion left on the α-C.

The next study is with a Pro-Gly-Gly tripeptide and the product ion spectrum of its a3 and b2 products. Five product ions are seen in a 20 eV fragmentation: a3, ′′b2, a2, a3−P, and y1, with m/z values of 184, 153, 127, 87, and 74, respectively. The a3 ion was subjected to further fragmentation and produced a ′′b2 ion by loss of CH3NH2; it also loses 57 Da to form an a2 ion, and also a Pro residue to create m/z 87 peak the base peak. Others have reported that N-terminal residue is lost from the a3, and that ′′b2 is formed from neutral amine loss. Glycine loss from a3 has not been reported before, and it apparently involves elimination of imine and CO. The ′′b2 m/z 153 fragments to lose NH3, CO, and [H2, CO].

PGG exchangeable hydrogens were changed with deuterium to make the d4 molecule to obtain the [M-D]− spectrum. Results show that the ′′b2 ion has one labile hydrogen, the a2 has two labile H atoms, and a3−P has 3 labile hydrogens. There is a signal at m/z 89 showing incorporation of only two labile H atoms. Some differences in fragmetnation pathways from previous reports might be related to the type of dissociation (CID vs. FAB). Ionization of peptide methyl esters is different for FAB and ESI: for ESI it is deprotonation of amide nitrogen but for FAB involves the α-carbon. Such schemes must account for this.

[M-H]− CID spectra of PVG and its a3 ion show primary fragmentation to a3 and y1. Additional ions develop from a3. Peak at m/z 183 involves a C3H7 side chain loss from a3, followed by neutral loss of CO to form m/z 155. Ion a3 fragmentation leads to ′′b2 and formation of a2 and lose of N-terminal Pro to form m/z 129.

The spectrum of APG and its a3 and y2 product ions were examined. The [M-H]− major products are a3, y2 and y1. Cleavage at Ala-Pro amide bond to produce y2 and charge retention on C-terminus contrasts with findings of deprotonated tripeptides having only H (Gly) or alkyl side chains which do not form these ions. Signal at m/z 127 indicates that either Ala is lost from a3 or that y2 loses CO. As the product spectrum of the y2 ion (deproonated PG) has similarites with PA and PV dipeptides [M-H]− spectra with loss of ethylene from a2 (m/z 127) to form m/z 99 ion. The [M-H]− and [M-D]− were examined to show formation of y1, y2, and m/z 141 (loss of CO2 from y2, and possible loss of Gly from a2). Others have reported GPA at high energy producing y2 and minor formation of y1 and the m/z 141 fragment. With deuterated peptide, y1 retains a labile H and y2 retains two label H.

Tripeptide AAP was next studied and its a3 and ′′b2 product spectrum also. [M-H]− products are loss of CO2 to form a3 and a y1 deprotonated Pro. The route to ′′b2 is by loss of neutral pyrrolidine from a3. In addition a m/z 87 ion indicates c1, formed from ;a3. CID activation of ′′b2 leads to m/z 124, 113, 111, and 97 which are respectively NH3 loss, CO loss, loss of H2, C, and O, and then loss of C2, H4, and O.

The tripeptide LAP and its a3 and ′′b2 product spectra were checked. Again the [M-H]− involve loss of a3 and y1, and loss of pyrrolidine leads to formation of ′′b2 from a3. The ′′b2 further fragments with loss of NH3 to m/z 166, loss of CO to m/z 155, loss of [H2,C,O] to m/z 153, and loss of [C2,H4,O] to m/z 139. A [′′b2-NH3]− at m/z 166 loses CO2 to produce ion at m/z 122. The [M-H]− and [M-D]− spectra were compared: this shows that ′′b2 (m/z 183) retains two label H atoms, and y1 ions retain one labile H atom, and a3 has three labile H atoms as expected.

Product ion spectrum for tripeptide AFP [M-H]− show two primary pathways forming a3 and y1 ions. Product ion spectrum for a3 indicates loss of pyrrolidine to form ′′b2, but a benzyl radical is lost leading to an ion at m/z 197 (side chain radical loss is often seen). From ′′b2 there is a minor loss of ammonia forming a m/z 200 ion and a benzyl anion m/z 91, but major fragment is a m/z 97 ion resulting from neutral (or neutrals) whose loss is 120 Da. Elemental composition of these neutrals would be C8H8O, which mostly likely is C7H8 (toluene) + CO.

In looking at all ′′b2 fragmentation, the following patterns are seen:

  1. With an N-terminal Pro, a labile H is retained in ′′b2 ion. If there is primary amine at N-terminus the ′′b2 ion incorporates two labile H atoms The labile H atom incorporated to ′′b2 are from the N-terminal amine.
  2. With the ′′b2 a peak showing neutral loss of NH3 is evident, meaning that there is free amino group in the ′′b2 ion.
  3. CO loss from ′′b2 represents a major fragmentation pathway, which is followed by elimination of H2. Moreover with [′′b2-CO]− ion there is loss of R2H where R2 is a side chain of the 2nd amino acid of a tripeptide. With Ala-Phe-Pro, C7H8 is lost from the [′′b2-CO]− to make a m/z 97 base peak ion, and there is a complementary [C7H7]− ion. Similarly for Leu-Ala-Pro there is loss of CH4 but no loss of C4H10 butyl side chain of Leu. The [′′b2-CO]− from Gly-Leu-Sar has an abundant ion [′′b2-CO-C4H10]− m/z 83 but the peptide Leu-Gly-Pro shows only a minor formation of the m/z 83 ion.

The ′′b2 structures are not fully determined. Others have proposed the structure HNCH2C(=O)N−CH=C=O. Calculations using ab initio suggest a cyclic structure however: HNCH2C(-*)=N-CH−=C(-O-*)=O (the two asterisk join). The simplest ′′b2 derived from Gly-Gly-Xxx has a computational structure of the six-membered ring HN(-*)CH2C(=O)-N−-CH2-C(-*)=O which as 9.5 kcal/mol lower energy. Deuterium studies however rule this structure out and another not shown.

In tripeptides, ′′b2 ion formation less through a a3 parent. Mechanism starts with loss of CO2 leaving carbanion on α-C of 3rd residue. The proton from amide N of 2nd residue moves to neutralize the α-C of 3rd residue, leading to amide tautomer form (C=N with oxyanion), and the 1st residue oxyanion forms nucleophilic addition to 2nd residue for a oxazolone 5-membered ring with an amide (C-N) bond break between 2nd and 3rd residues. The negative charge is delocalized in the ring (as the ′′b2 ion now), probably on the α-C of residue 2. This mechanism is also consistent with deuterium studies. In another scheme, the a3 parent sees the proton coming from the N-terminal amine N (not the second residue), and the N-terminal anionic N shows nucleophilic addition to 2nd residue carbonyl C, which forms a nice 6-membered ring with the 2nd-3rd residue amide bond break and either deprotonation of a -CH2- or -NH- group in the ring to form ′′b2 ion (ring is diketopiperazine). However, this pathway would most like lead to deprotonation of the -NH- in the ring, and retention of only one labile H atom, not consistent with deuterium results, so the oxazolone ring mechanism seems more likely. Further ′′b2 fragmentation is speculated to involve CO2 loss, which has been shown for the ′′b itself, but the spectrum shows a loss of 44 Da, but this is due to CO + CH4: the oxazolone ring in ′′b2 first loses C=O with ring break and carbionic enamine on residue 2 with the charge (now the [′′b2-CO]− ion): this can lead to a ring formation by N-terminal N atom with α-C in the anionic enamine and to loss of H2 as the ring stabilizes the anion (probably on αC carbanion of 1st residue), or with proton transfer from N-terminal N atom against leading to ring but with loss of 2nd residue side chain and a proton to form same ring.

The 4-residue Ala-Ala-Pro-Ala and its y2 ion had their deprotonated spectra analyzed. The [M-H]− major fragment ion is y2. An Ala4 peptide as well as other side chains that are only alkyl have only minor formation of y2 from deprotonated precursor. This y2 is similar to spectrum from Pro-Ala, which has equal probability of having one or two labile hydrogen atoms, indicating two pathways to y2. Schemes are shown that show how one and two labile H atoms can be part of the y2 ion product.

The 5-residue Ala-Ala-Pro-Ala-Ala was subjected to [M-H]− ESI-MS. In this case a y3 and [y3-CO2]− are prominent ions, and cleavage in on amino side of Pro. The CID spectrum of deprotonated A5 shows y3 as very minor. Also there is a c2 ion as well with AAPAA, where the charge goes to the N-terminal side. The 4-peptide GPGG CID spectrum however gives an unexpected weak y3 signal; the major ion is actually a4 which fragments further. This is likely because at least two amino acids N-terminal to Pro are required probably to stabilize the oxazolone or diketopiperazine neutral rings will form. These are proven with Xxx-Pro-Yyy and Xxx-Yyy-Pro studies.

The CID [M-H]− spectrum of peptide VGVAPG has y2 as its major ion, again showing a pathway N-terminal to Pro residue. A series of c ions are also produced: m/z 115 (c1), 172 (c2), 271 c3, and very weak 342 (c4).

The proline effect has been seen in [M+H]+ and [M+nH]n+ (i.e, single and multiply protonated peptides with Pro). With VGVAPG a dominant y2′′ and b4 ions are proof (the significant b3 is because of b4 continued fragmentation). Also [M+H]+ in tripeptides Xxx-Yyy-Pro produces signficant y1′′ ions. In addition there must be two amino acids N-terminal to the Pro residue. Studies of [M+H]+ ions of Xxx-Pro-Yyy show more cleavage on amide bond on the C-side of Pro and this N-terminal side. With GPGG, the cleavage is [M+H]+ → b2 → ay2 → P (proline iminium). The b2 ion is major for APLG too. The proline effect may be due to proton affinity for Pro or because of the strain required to form a bicyclic oxazolone with fragmenting on C-side of Pro. Whe Pro is residue 2, formation of yn′′ neutrals imine and CO are formed (requires higher energy). With deprotonated peptides however these neutrals are likely a ketene than an imine + CO. The mechanism is likely to involve the ability of Pro to stabilize the negative charge with its secondary amine as opposed to a primary amine, enabling the favored break at the N-terminal side of Pro. CID MS of

Xie H, Rhodus NL, Griffin RJ, Carlis JV, Griffin TJ (2005) Molec. Cell. Proteomics 4, 1826-1830.

A Catalogue of Human Saliva Proteins Identified by Free Flow Electrophoresis-Based Peptide Separation and Tandem Mass Spectrometry

Whole unstimulated saliva was taken from healthy female. 1 ml was taken and spun 25000 g 30 min at 4°., assayed by BCA (=1.05 mg). HEPES pH 8.0 was added to 100 mM and TCEP to 5 mM. 20 µg trypsin was added and left overnight at 37°. Peptides are collected on SepPak, and dried by vacuum centrifugation after elution. The BD Biosciences ProTeam free flow electrophoresis (FFE) system was used to separate peptides, which are dissolved in 250 µl of FFE separation buffer and then fractionated by FFE into 96- well microplates (described previously). A microelectrode was used to immediately measure pH in each FFE fraction (Fisher Accument combitrode). 50 µl (about 10%) aliquot is taken and processed for MS. An automated Michrom Bioresources, Inc Paradigm MS4 System was used: each FFE fraction loaded on Paradigm Platinum Peptide Nanotrap precolumn (150 µm × 5 cm, 0.4 ml volume) at 50 µl/min in buffer A. 5 µm, 200-Å Magic C18AG C18 resin was packed into 75 µm × 12 cm. Peptides are eluted with 10-35% buffer B over 1 h, then isocratically at 80% B for 5 min at constant 250 nl/min flow. This goes to electrospray on Thermo LTQ linear ion trap MS with voltage 2000 V and collision energy at 29%, scanning in m/z 400-1800 range, with four MS/MS scans for four most abundant precusors detected in a single MS scan. Fill time of ion trap was 50 ms maximum, and precursor m/z were excluded for 30 s before MS→MS/MS switching. Databases for MS/MS spectra were searched using TurboSEQUEST (Thermo) against the non-redundant human International Protein Index (~50,000 protein sequences, a reverse version of database is also available). Mass accuracy tolerance of 2.0 for precursor ion, with Met oxidation as a differential modification. Interact software tool used organize/view match results. False positive rates were determined. Shimura et al used to calculate predicted pI values of sequences.

Results. Since initial fractionation of peptides based on pH separation using FFE, it will be interesting to see how pI-predicting programs compare to pH-measured fractionation. First sequence matches were filtered using Peptide Prophet, which computes a probability p for the match. A strict p ≥ 0.90 threshold match level was used. Fig 1A is a plot of measured pH and computed pI vs FFE fraction number, with a plot of the number of peptides in each fraction (max found was about 200 in one fraction). Plot does show a correlation or correspodence between average of the computed pI of each sequence found in a fraction, and the measured pH of the fraction, although the variation was larger on the alkaline end with respect to average computed pI; thus confidence of computation may not apply in all pH ranges. A large number of unique peptides elute in the pH 3.5-5.0 region, and only a very few peptides in the pH ~7-8 range (similar to a preparative IEF study).

Fig 1B plots the false positive rate FPR (%) against a probability score. A filter is applied as to the ΔpH between calculated peptide pI value and the FFE fraction (measured pH) in which the peptide elutes. False matches are scored if random computed pI values are observed, and these are eliminated in the filter. The initial filter is high (ΔpH ± 0.5), a tolerance optimal based on FFE-based IEF resolution. The p score threshold can be reduced in this filtering step while maintaining low 1% FPR. Optimal p threshold should differ for each dataset analyzed. For this dataset, reduction of p to 0.76 could be done with ΔpH filter applied. A second-step filtering used a lower p threshold of 0.2 and peptide pI with ΔpH ± 0.5 filter; the protein would only be catalogued only if match by ≥ 2 unique peptide sequences. With first-step filtering, 433 proteins were identified in peptide matches with p ≥ 0.76. 181 of the proteins had two matches of peptides; the rest only one match. Another four proteins were added in second step.

Baczek T (2005) Curr. Pharmaceut. Anal. 1, 31-40.

Improvement of Peptide Identification in Proteomics with Use of New Analytical and Bioinformatic Strategies

REVIEW. Reports on modalities for achieving high resolution separation of proteins prior to PMF or de novo sequencing. This review contains serious errors about methodology of preparation of peptides (to be trusted?).

The Sequest algorithm was developed in 1994 by Yates and co-workers. It assumes that amino acid sequences can be inferred from tandem mass spectra. The algorithm automates the inference by enumerating candidates from the database that match the observed peptide's mass. Sequences are checked against the spectrum by a preliminary score and the first nonmatches are removed. More extensive cross-correlation scoring is used, and this evaluates the sequence-derived theoretical spectra. This compares against the observed spectra and sequences are then ranked. Statistics accumulate help to classify matches. Difference between normalized cross-correlation functions and the first and second ranked results (ΔCn) is used to indicate a correctly selected peptide sequence. Cross-correlation score between observed fragment spectrum and theoretically predicted one (Xcorr) the preliminary score bsed on count of ions in MS/MS spectrum matching the experimental data (Sp), the rank of the particular match during the preliminary scoring (RSp) and the ions value (I) describing how many of the detecte (observed) match the theoretical ions for the peptides are then listed.

Post-db search evaluation include the use of learning algorithm called a support vector machine (SVM). SVM distinguishes between correctly and incorrectly identified peptides in looking for subtle patterns in a complex data set. It requires an appropriate training set of MS/MS data, and the analysis does a better match between MS/MS and theoretical sequences. In cases where SVM scores are low, the user needs to control noisy or poorly fragmenting spectra which could compromise peptide identfication. Additional study with artificial neural network (ANN) has been proposed. ANN works much like the human brain: it is compact group of connected, ordered layers able to process information. There are three types of layers: input, one or more hidden, and then an output. Elements in the network are artificial neurons and each element connects with a different strength called a synaptic weight. The important feature of ANN is its learning ability: learning ability is determined by alteration in synaptic weight values for connections applying a specific algorithm. The most commonly used algorithm is the back-propagation training algorithm. Learning in the use of that algorithm involves analyzing error between the current and desirable output and then altering synpatic weights to move toward the desirable output. In analzying MS/MS spectra of a tryptic digest of a yeast extract using LC-ESI-MS/MS, each individual peptide was characterized by its peptide MW and peptide charge (MW and CH, resp.) and Sequest-generated values (Xcorr, ΔCn, Sp, RSp, and I) and atom-structure-calculated values of pI, change in charge with pH at the pI (dz/dpH), and hydrophobicity (H). Using these values in a training set, an ANN could be constructed assign an MS/MS spectrum as good or bad and eliminate its consideration in further analysis.

Prediciting a peptide's retention time on chromatography columns has been studied extensively in connection with known important parameters of a peptide such as amino acid composition. Retention coefficients were determined for each of the amino acids and end groups, derived from experimental evidence of amino acids themselves. Many groups reported, all giving varying values however. The influence of sequence too was studied. One group found that presence of a binding domain in an amphipathic α-helical peptide produces greater retention than predicted by other models, so amino acid composition may rank high.

QSRR, or quantitative structure-retention relationships were obtained using statistically derived relationships between chromatographic parameters and descriptors of molecular structure. In the derivation, the logarithm of the sum of the retention times of amino acids composing the peptide, log SumAA, the logarithm of the van der Waals volume of the peptide, log VDWvol, and the logarithm of the calculated n-octanol-water partition coefficient, clog P, to come up with the following equation:

tR = 8.02 (± 2.04) + 14.86 (± 0.93) log SumAA − 5.77 (± 1.16) log VDWVol + 0.28 (± 0.06) clog P

There are four terms in the equation and each has a significance level of p = 1 × 10−4, 6 × 10−29, 3 × 10−6, 3 × 10−6, with a total significance in the equation of p < 5 × 10−55 for n = 101 peptides used in the studies, a multiple correlation coefficient of R = 0.963, standard error of estimate s = 0.97, and F test ratio = 411.

Ji C, Guo N, Li L (2005) J. Proteome Res. 4, 2099-2108.

Differential Dimethyl Labeling of N-Termini of Peptides After Guanidination for Proteome Anaylsis

Guanidination and reductive amination are chemistries with a long history. In this report a first step is taken to block the ε-amino groups of Lys using O-methylisourea at high pH. After guanidination, dimethyl labeling of the N-termini of the tryptic peptides with either d(0),12C- or d(2),13C-formaldehyde. This adds 28 or 34 Da to each peptide. The guanidination converts Lys to homoarginine, adding 42 Da to it, and does not at all modify the N-terminus, probably because of steric hindrance from the R group. The increased basicity of the Lys probably improves peptide ionization for MS.

Myoglobin was used as a model to determine labeling efficiency. 100 µl of 0.5 mg/ml Mb was heated to 95° for 10 min, cooled and 10 µl 1 M sodium bicarbonate added to adjust pH to ~8.5. Mb was digested overnight at 37° at a 1:50 (w/w) enzyme/substrate ratio. Digests are stored at −78°. For guanidination, 10 µl of 2 M NaOH is added to irreversibly inactivate trypsin. 40 µl of 2 M O-methylisourea in 100 mM NaHCO3 and adjusted to pH 11 with 2 M NaOH. This is incubated 37° for 2 h or 65° for 10 min. The reaction was stopped and pH adjusted to 8 with 10% TFA. 15 µl of 2 M NaBH3CN was added and vortexed. 3 µl of 4% (w/w) either d(0),12C or d(2),13C formaldehyde. After vortexing mixtures are left at 37° for 60 min. 3 µl of 1 M NaHCO3 was added to consume excess formaldehyde. Note that it is critical that the dimethyl labeling be done under a hood. MALDI MS was done with treated peptide using a Bruker Reflex III MALDI TOF with 384 multiprobe inlet and 337 nm nitrogen laser with 3 ns pulse in positive ion mode featuring delayed extraction. Two-layer sample deposition was used in preparing target plates, with first layer 20 mg/ml CHCA matrix in 20% MeOH/acetone and second layer a saturating CHCA solution in 30% (v/v) methanol/water. Second layer was mixed in 4:1 matrix:analyte with dilute and acidified analyte. 0.5 µl of first layer is deposited and dried, then 0.5 µl of sample and second layer, containing 5 ng of Mb digest (~300-500 fmol). After the 2nd layer was air-dried, three × 1 µl water was used to wash the dried layers.

Whey fractions of skim milk were labeled in a similar way. About 1 mg proteins in 30 µl was diluted 1/50 with ultrapure and then ultrafiltered with Microcon-3 (3000 Da cutoff). Whey was prepared using a report in literature. caseins (making up 80% of total protein) were prepared by acidifying milk to pH 4.6 with 2 M acetic acid and then spun out in microfuge for 10 min (max speed). Supernatant was dried in 2 ml siliconized vial to 100 µl. Reductive alkylation with DTT/iodoacetamide was done. Acetone precipitation was done to remove low MW reactants (it was precooled to −80° then added to final 83% (v/v); vortexed 1 min; held at −20° for 2 h; microcentrifuged at 4° for 10 min max speed. Pellets were solubilized by adding 5 µl of 1% SDS and vortexing. The solution was then diluted to 0.05% SDS and adjusted to pH 8.5 with 10 µl 1 M sodium bicarbonate. 2.5 µl of 1 mg/ml trypsin and 5 µl 20 mM calcium chloride were added for overnight digestion at 37°.

For Mb, 15 peptides were seen in unlabeled Mb treatments whereas 20 peptides were seen with labeling. Sequence coverage for the tryptic, guanidinated, dimethylated peptides was up to 96.2% compared to a coverage of 58% for unlabeled. The 5 extra peptides were all the result of labeling, with signal intensities of labeled peptides comparable to unlabeled. With some Lys-containing peptides increased intensity is only seen with guanidination: homoArg increases basicity of peptides. When Gly is the N-terminal amino acid, partial guanidination is observed largely because the absence of a bulky R group. Keeping reaction temperature to ≤37° will also help to minimize the unwanted N-terminal guanidination where it might occur (the use of 10 min at 65° as opposed to 2 h at 37° was found to result in no side reaction as well).

As for the completeness of the reactions, spectra show that all peptides have increased shifted masses indicating that guanidination and dimethyl labeling are quantitative. Peptides guanidinated alone and those reacted as a combination show completeness of reaction. The absence of signal differences in the MALDI spectra indicates that dimethyl labeling does not change the basicity of the peptides.

An isotope effect is observed with respect to chromatography of labeled peptides. There is a slight difference in retention times between the deuterated and non-deuterated times. The peak separation between d(0),12C- and d(2),13C-formaldehyde labeled peptides was 1 s on peaks which are 20-25 s wide on half height. Deuterium tags are added to charged site of peptide and these do not usually interact with a nonpolar phase anyway, and the addition of 4 deuterium atoms does not generally create a significant istope effect.

CID spectra were generated from unlabeled, light labeled, and heavy-labeled peptides using the peptide YKELGFQG. One major difference is seen between the native/untreated/unlabeled spectra and those in which guanidination occurs: fragment ions stand out better in labeled treatments. The signal intensities of the a1 ion are substantially increased 10-fold, which easily distinguishes it from immonium ion. It is possible that resulting b1 ions form a stable alkylated immonium ion a1 in losing a molecule of CO. For some fragment ions, the count of b ions increased with labeling.

Skim milk proteins were used because they are less complex than serum and have high abundance proteins which overwhelm low abundance proteins. Differently labeled proteins were combined and injected on to microbore LC-MALDI-MS/MS (ABi/MDS-Sciex QSTAR Pulsar QqTOF equipped with orthogonal MALDI source). The theoretical quantitative ratios should be equal to 1. All peptide pairs with good signal-to-noise were selected for CID, making 56 peptide pairs. From these 14 proteins were unambiguously identified from the sequence info. In some cases, peptide cleavage was not along tryptic sites (nonspecific cleavage). Lys guanidination did not interfere with MALDI MS/MS analysis. The measured ratio for the heavy-light pairs was 1.02, close the theoretical 1.00. thus the error is 2.0%, and relative standard deviation is 4.6%, well be 15% used as a threshold in quantitative bioanalysis. Phosphopeptides eluting at 33 and 35 min in the gradient were sequenced in MS/MS easily. The heavy-light ratio was 1.01.

The milk proteome is dominated by six gene products, four caseins (α-S1, α-S2, β and κ), β-lactoglobulin, and α-lactalbumin which are 95% of the protein. Identification of minor proteins requires removing caseins by acid precipitation from whey. 2DGE of the whey shows several isoforms of low abundance lipocalin-type prostaglandin D synthase. Still a great deal of caseins were present. Others have tried immunoadsorption to remove caseins followed by 2DGE and microsequencing, which helped to identify BSA, lactoferrin, ans serotransferrin. The use of a high capacity of microbore LC as opposed to capillary LC will provide accurate quanitation because of an increased signal-to-noise (gain of 104). Here 8 low abundance proteins were identified, among them osteopontin-K and cyclic dodecapeptide for the first time in mature bovine milk.

The steps for peptide sequencing in 2-MEGA labeling are:

  1. digest the protein with protease (trypsin)
  2. block Lys residues by guanidination with O-methylisourea
  3. split guanidinated reaction equally into new reaction vials and label these with d(0),12C-formaldehyde and d(2),13-formaldehyde
  4. combine the peptide reactions
  5. analyze on combined material on microbore LC-MALDI MS
  6. select peptide pairs for CID
  7. overlay spectra of pairs and compare to delineate derived fragment ions from N-terminal (a and b ions).

The theoretical masses of the a1 peptide are given in the table below for an N-terminal residue having one of the 20 amino acids. When no labeling occurs, the a1 ion signals in low mass region rarely show up or are indistinguishable from immonium ion signals from other amino acid residues in the sequence. In contrast labeled peptides have strong, distinguishing signals for a1 ions in the low mass region, with unambiguous fingerprinting of the N-terminal residue.

An example is studied with a peptide with retention time of 43 min. The peptide pair with m/z 1165.58 and 1171.62 shows good CID MS/MS spectra with identifiable b and y-series ions, and an a1 of 164.10 and 170.11, respectively. The N-terminal residue can be assigned Y right away. The separate MS/MS spectra are overlaid to show the labeling mass difference, further verifying any b- and y series whose signal-to-noise might be small. The b-series indicates PVEPFTER. Put together the YPVEPFTER is searched with BLAST and sufficient to hit on bovine β-casein, conforming to expectations of a milk protein. Note that an Ser→Arg 137 transformation is observed, explaining generation of a tryptic site. Another variant (polymorphism) was seen in β-lactoglobulin with a Met→Val 23 conversion.

N-terminal amino acid residues Unmodified a1 mass Modified a1 mass
+H412C2 +D413C2
Alanine (A) 44.050 72.081 78.113
Arginine (R) 129.114 157.145 163.177
Asparagine (N) 87.006 115.037 121.069
