Aspartic acid (D) 88.040 116.071 122.103
Cysteine (C)* 133.056 161.087 167.119
Glutamic acid (E) 102.056 130.087 136.119
Glutamine (Q) 101.071 129.103 135.135
Glycine (G) 30.034 58.066 64.098
Histidine (H) 110.072 138.103 144.135
Isoleucine (I) 86.097 114.128 120.160
Leucine (L) 86.097 114.128 120.160
Lysine (K) 101.108 171.161 177.193
Methionine (M) 104.053 132.085 138.117
Phenylalanine (F) 120.081 148.113 154.144
Proline (P) 70.066 84.081 87.097
Serine (S) 60.045 88.076 94.108
Threonine (T) 74.061 102.092 108.124
Tryptophan (W) 159.092 187.124 193.155
Tyrosine (Y) 136.076 164.108 170.139
Valine (V) 72.081 100.113 106.144
* Side chain of cysteine was blocked by iodoactemide.

Gilar M, Olivova P, Daly AE, Gebler JC (2005) Waters Posters

Development of Orthogonal Separation Methods for 2D-HPLC (MS/MS) Analysis of Peptides

In a 2D separation, the theoretical number of resolved components, or peak capacity, is described as P2D = P1 × P2 where Pn is the number of resolved peaks in dimension n. This is true only in LC when the modes are ideally orthogonal. Retention times for 196 tryptic peptides were obtained in a 1D-LC-MS. To describe the orthogonality a geometric approach was used with a surface area of retention plots. Retention maps are normalized by the equation:

RTi(norm) = RTi − RTmin
RTmax − RTmin

where RTmin and RTmax are the retention times of the first and last eluting peptides, and thus the equation evaluates to a value in the range 0 to 1. The 2D space is then divided into 14 × 14 bins for the total peak capacity of 196.

To make the map, construct a multilined grid with normalized retention of the 1st D and 2nd D plotted on the vertical and horizontal axis, respectively. Divide the range 0-1 in 0.1 units, giving a 10 × 10 separation space with peak capacity being 100. Suppose the peak plots all fall on a 45° line, covering the 10 squares that make up the line. Thus 10% of the normalized area is used, but the 1st and 2nd dimensions do not really differ with respect to chromatographic separation, and are thus not orthogonal. In another system, suppose that the plot points are all over the map. Where a point falls, the square is said to be used. If 63 of the squares are used, 63% of the normalized area is covered, and the orthogonality is considered to be 100%.

In a completely random distribution of 100 points, 63% of the map should be covered. Since orthogonality lies between 0-100% in a space from 10 to 63

O % = 100 × ∑bins − √Pmax
0.63 × Pmax

where ∑bins is the total count of bins with at least one plot point in them and Pmax is the total count of all bins representing the 2D peak capacity. Practical peak capacity can be deterimed from the mean peak width w represent the 4 × σ spanning the peak and in the useful gradient time tg.

NP = P1 × P2 × ∑bins
Pmax
P1,2 = 1 + tg / w13.4%

Five protein digests of MassPREP standard proteins were produced and run in 1D-LC-MS, and then 2D plots were made from a combination assessment: phenyl × C18, pentafluorophenyl × C18, C18 @ pH 10 × C18 @ pH 2.6 (formic acid and ammonium formate), SEC (using YMC diol 4.6 mm × 75 cm 60 Å column) × C18, HILIC × C18, and SCX × C18; all columns not specified for dimensions were 2.1 × 150 mm, with a 200 µl/min flow, 40° column temp (SCX was 30°), using solvent A = 0.2% formic acid and solvent B = 100% MeCN, and when RP used 0.8% MeCN increase per min gradient over 50 min. SEC was 20% MeCN in 40 mM ammonium formate. HILIC went from 90% MeCN down by 0.8% per minute. SCX was a PolyLC polysulfoaspartamide with 25% MeCN constant with 40-300 mM ammonium formate pH 3.25 gradient.

2D space was divided into a 14 × 14 bin. Of the six 2D maps made, the first had no orthogonality (no difference between phenyl and C18). The modified phenyl column showed only slightly more orthogonality. Doing C18 at different pH had better orthogonality. When the 1st D had different physicochemical separation principles, orthogonality was very much improved. Ultimately there was a strong effect of pH in separation and improved orthogonality.

Results allow several conclusions:

  • RP × RP 2D separations show low orthogonality. It was not useful to change ion-pairing buffer composition, or alter the RP stationary phase (say from phenyl to C18). The best orthogonality in a RP × RP trial was with pentafluorophenyl × C18.
  • Peptides are ionizable, and so pH is perhaps the best way to alter selectivity. Acidic (pH < 5.5) allowed better retention for RP modes when the peptides are acidic, and basic peptides are retained when the pH is basic.
  • Size exclusion (SEC) produced decent orthogonality with some interaction with the stationary phase. Some hydrophobic peptide loss is observed.
  • HILIC × RP modes had the highest orthogonality. A silica-based Atlantis HILIC produced some of the best recovery. A secondary interaction with silanols produced cation-exchange behavior.
  • SCX using NaCl is not compatible with MS, and ammonium formate increases were adequate. Higher charge density (charge-to-mass) often showed longer retention (2+ short peptides retained longer than 2+ longer peptides). 2+ and 3+ peptides tended to cluster in a smaller region of 2D separation space, reducing overall orthogonality of a SCX × RP system.

Gedcke DA (????) ORTEC® Application Note 58 (AN58)

How Histogramming and Counting Statistics Affect Peak Position Precision

Mass spectra are effectively histograms (or frequency distributions), in which ions falling at a certain m/z (or class of ion) are counted within that position or class, and the spectra is constructed as the counts at each class (m/z) against the class (m/z). A histogram is a plot in which the horizontal access is separated at equal intervals and each interval is an index into an array. The vertical axis represents the probability of recording an event in each interval. But in creating histograms, the setting of the interval size will affect the resolution or accuracy of measuring a peak position in the spectrum. These counting statistics are significant. In TOF mass spectrometers, time digitizers decide the interval. The same is true for any system using a counter in a time or pulse/amplitude/energy domain.

The number of events counted over a duration with a time domain exhibits a statistical fluctuation described as a Poisson probability distribution:

P(N) = μN e−μ
N!

P(N) is the probability of counting N events in a single measurement. As the count increases and the values of N are averaged, the value of N approaches the mean μ of the distribution. The standard deviation can be computed as:

σN = √μ = √N

Thus N is an adequate accurate estimate of μ. The precision of measurement is often expressed as a percentage of N, which is σN / N × 100% = 100% / √N. For N = 1, σN% = 100.0%. For N = 100, σN% = 10.0%. For N = 10,000, σN% = 1.0%. And for N = 1,000,000, σN% = 0.1%.

Many spectra have narrow peaks and the positions of those define the physical quantity to be measured. The peak centroid can affect the final m/z determination of an ionized molecule. To evaluate the proper position, the bin interval (channel) of the spectrum analyzer should be a fraction of the extent or range of a peak (peak start to stop). In a figure shown, the bin width interval is 5% of the standard deviation, with is almost 1% of the entire peak span. The horizontal axis is calibrated to read such that

xi = k i

where xi is the calibrated value for the center of the ith bin, and k is the calibration factor.

When the peak area is normalized to unity, the peak now represents an empirical probability that a single even will be measured with a particular value xi, and so the peak is a probability distribution for xi. The mean is computed to be

x =  ∑i  xi yi
N

where yi is the number of events counted in bin i, and N is the total number of events forming the peak, ∑i  yi. The mean is the centroid of the peak, and will be the determined value for the peak on the x axis.

The standard deviation for the probability distribution will be:

σx2 ≈ s2 =  ∑i   yi (xi − x)2
N − 1

(The denominator is N − 1 because x has to be calculated from the N values, and this removes one degree of freedom.

What is the effect of the bin width on the error in measuring the peak centroid. Consider a Gaussian peak with the shape having the form

y =  exp [−(x − XC) 2 / 2 σx2 ]
√2 πσx2

This can be plotted on Excel spreadsheet, with XC set to zero and x values computed in units of the standard deviation. A bin width of 0.05σx, small enough to create negligible errors in conversion. The bin overlapping the centroid of the peak is centered at x = 0 and the remaining bins extend up to ±8.2 σx about the centroid. The value of the equation above is computed for the center of each bin and multiplied by the bin width, which is the value of yi for each bin. Note that the accuracy of this calculation was off by the exact value of 1.000 with an error of 7 × 10−10.

The error introduced can be analyzed by adjusting the bin width. Suppose only two bins form the peak, and their adjacent boundary coincides with the centroid. If bins are not symmetrically positioned then the calculated centroid is offset from the true centroid. One can determine the offset by choosing different bin widths and sliding the bins across the centroid in 8 steps, with step size being one-eighth of the bin width. The centroid of the resulting histogram is evaluated and compared to the true centroid. The bin widths used were 0.2, 0.4, 0.8, 1.0, 1.2, 1.6, 2.0, 2.4, and 3.2 of the σx. These were divided 2.35 to produce the ratio of the FWHM to the bin width, and thus are the number of bind that span the FWHM of the peak. One can plot the maximum centroid error as a percent of the FWHM against the ratio of the FWHM/(bin width). When the count of bins spanning FWHM exceeds 1.5, the max error in the centroid due to bin width is < 0.01% of the FWHM. As the bin count across FWHM increases, so does the error decrease steeply. Beyond 2 bins, the error is so miniscule that precision of Excel in determining the small differences begins to limit accuracy of the calculation.

Does the error from bin width selection or the error from counting statistics dominate? Create a plot with log event counts against the bin width as a proportion of the FWHM. One can plot a reverse sigmoidal line in which the errors of the two sources are equal. Below and to the left of this sigmoidal line the random error of counting statistics will dominate, whereas above and right of the curve the systematic error from bin width is dominant. A spectrometer will usually acquire 5 or more than the 107 event counts in a peak to be analyzed. The horizontal limits of the rectangle extend from 0.05 FWHM to about 0.33 FWHM in the typical operating range; this means from 3-20 bins spanning the FWHM. Since the operating range box defined by these falls below and to the left of the curve, the random error from counting statistics dominates in causing centroid error.

The general presumption is that all bin widths are equal, but in practice bin widths will be varied in the spectrometer. The variation is called Differential Non-Linearity (DNL), and percent DNL is calculated as:

%DNL = ± Wmax − Wmin × 100%
Wmax + Wmin

Wmax is the maximum bin width and Wmin the minimum. High quality spectrometers have a DNL within ±1%, meaning the widest bin is no more than 1% wider than the average bin width, the narrowest no more than 1% smaller than the average. To investigate bin width-dominant error, and odd-even and random pattern were investigated. An average bin width equal to 0.4 σx was used in both patterns, corresponding to 5.9 bins spanning the FWHM of the Gaussian peak. With odd-even pattern, the %DNL is ±12.5%, and the centroid error is 4.7 × 10−12% of the bin width 8.1 × 10−13% of the FWHM, with an equivalent N = 2.8 × 1027. With the random pattern, the %DNL is ±1.3%, the centroid error is 0.28% of the bin width 0.047% of the FWHM, with an equivalent N = 820,000. In the odd-even pattern the bin widths alternated between being 12.5% narrower (for odd) and 12.5% wider (even) than the average. Since this produces even spacing between bin centers, the contribution to centroid error is negligible although DNL is high (even extreme) at 12.5%. For the random error, the change in bin width was limited to ±1.3% but each succeeding bin was changed randomly. The centroid from the random DNL pattern is small and can be ignored up to ca. 820,000 events.

FD

Paizs B, Suhai S (2005) Mass Spec. Rev. 24, 508-548.

Fragmentation Pathways Of Protonated Peptides

REVIEW. Fragmentation within the mass spectrometer depends on a number of factors including amino acid composition, peptide length, method of excitation, time scale of instrument, ion charge state, and others. Fragmentation ideally in low energy collisions results in b and y ions that cleave along the peptide bond, but also neutral losses of water and ammonia occur. In addition to actual MS/MS spectral observation, spectra can be generated in silico which predict peaks based on isotopic abundances. A top-down strategy is a statistical approach based on systematic assessment of large databases containing MS/MS spectra of protonated peptides to derive fragmentation rules. The bottom-up approach does a systematic investigation of the major pathways of fragmentation of protonated peptides to increase knwoledge of dissocation chemistry.

Mobile Proton Model. In this model protonated peptides activated under low-energy collision conditions will fragment mainly by charge-directed reactions. Protonation sites exist in various functional groups of the peptide. Some are more or less energetically favorable. With the internal energy of ions increased by collision, less energetically favorable sites can accept a proton. Charge-remote fragmentation (e.g., the aspartic acid effect) can occur. Molecular orbital calculations show protonation of amide nitrogen leads to weakening of amide bond, while protonation of amide oxygen makes amide bond stronger than in neutral species. Generally protonation is the least favorable on the amide N, while it is much more thermodynamically favorable on amide O or on side chain nitrogens of Lys and Arg. Because it suggests an unstable state to have amide N protonated, from the point of view of decomposition this state is favorable. The mobile proton model suggests that unless protons are sequestered by basic side chains of R and K, protons will move along the peptide backbone and create the likelihood of decomposition.

Experimental evidence of the model comes from deuterium labeling. Results show strong H/D mixing (isotopic exchange) before collisionally activated dissocation of [M+D]+ ions. Tsang and Harriso show facile H/D mixing occurs in D2 and CD4 chemical ionization of amino acids. In peptides lacking Arg, [M+D]+ show high proton mobility between terminal amion groups and the amide N and O atoms. In a study of the peptide FFF, fragmentation produces [M+H]+ and [M+D]+ show complete exchange of added deuterons with labile hydrogens in gas phase. Deuterons move from the amino acid they had labeled to fragments of other amino acids.

The energy required to move a proton from the amino terminus or basic side chain depends on amino acid composition. Dissociation requirements are highest for Arg-containing peptides, decreasing in order of R-containing > K-containing > non-basic peptides. The mobile proton model adequately explains even charge-state dependent fragmentation. In cases where ionizing proton number exceeds number of Arg residues, fragmentation is non-selective or non-specific. When Arg residues ≥ ionizing protons, then fragmentation can occur specifically via the Asp effect. Quantum chemistry has been used to explain the structure and energetics of various protonated forms of model peptides. Transitions between chemical species are explained by internal rotations, proton transfer reactions, etc. Structures and energetics of transition states are determined, then quantum chemical data (relative energies, vibrational frequencies, etc) in RRKM formalism are applied to approximate unimolecular reaction rates and time scale of underlying process. Proton traffic maps can be constructed to show energy required to mobilize additional protons between protonation sites.

Dissociation of bonds in fragmentation depends on energy and kinetic accessibility of the reactive configurations and on the actual rate constants of the bond cleavages themselves. After fragmentation fate of the separating fragments is determined by thermodynamics: fragment with larger proton affinity keeps the added proton responsible for charge-directed dissociation.

Peptide fragmentation pathways (PFPs) likely adhere to the Pathways in Competition (PIC) model. PFPs can be divided into three categories: (1) mechanistic, (2) energetic, (3) kinetic. Kinetics often explains competitive pathways. Protonated peptide dissociation can be divided into either charge-directed or charge-remote PFPs. Ions with low internal energy are generally fragmented by charge-directed pathways although the charge-remote pathways described by the Asp effect and the action of the oxidized Met side chain also work in low energy ions. Charge-directed pathyways can be described as sequence-independent and -dependent pathways. Sequence-independent pathways explain neutral losses, while sequence-dependent explain the alphabet (a, b, c, x, y, z) ions.

The b/y ion series are the most structurally informative and desirable. It requires protonation of the amide N. Several pathways are possible for the protonated amide N. These include the a1-yx pathway. Such pathways require high energy ions however, and lower energy ions break on the peptide bond only through complex rearrangement-type reactions. Functions involved include the oxygen of the N-terminal neighbor amide bond (bx-yz pathway), the nitrogen of the N-terminal amino group (aziridinone and diketopiperazine pathyways), and side chain nucleophiles. These b and y ions can further fragment to b ions (bx → bx-1), a ions (bx → ax), internal fragments and immonium ions. Fragments with larger proton affinity will hold the mobile hydrogen ion (thermodynamics rules). Among the tools that can be used to study the thermodynamics and kinetic of fragmentation, transition state-like structures, isotope-labeling, controlled temperature variation in the fragmentation chamber combined with theoretical evaluations can be used.

Additional theoretical tools requires scanning of potential energy surfaces (PES) of protonated peptides, evaluating the characteristics/state of transition structures from pre-dissociation to dissociations events and assessment of thermochemical quantitite (proton affinities) of final products. PES scanning is used to probe energetic of different protonation sites, charge-solvated and salt-bridge forms. Protein force fields are computed in low energy in molecular dynamics simulations. Current methods involve first determining force fields on neutral (unprotonated) species, then doning dynamics calculations by protonating collection of neutral structures in second step. A probably more practical approach is to use quantum mechanical calculations on various levels with less accurate models and then finish with density functional theory (DFT) on more interesting species that come out of the rough work.

MS/MS ion abundances are determined by kinetics of PFPs. Transition structures belonging to fragmentaiton pathwyas, proton transfer reactions, intramolecular rearrangements, and so are searched for. Moderate basis sets in conjunctionw with DFT for protonated peptide chemistry give good results, mainly because positive charge in ion forces electrons close to nuclei and heterolytic bond cleavages are most important, described by DFT reasonably. With results of quantum chemical calculations, rate coefficients for transitions between minima of PES can be calculated using RRKM method.

Charge-Directed PFPs. Protonated peptides can be cleaved by either rearrangment-type] or direct-bond cleavage. Low energy ions are done by the former class, with exception of a1-yx pathway. Direct bond cleavage typically requires high energy (excited) ions. The bx-yz pathway has the mobile proton on the amide N of residue n, which makes the carbonyl C of residue n - 1 susceptible to nucleophilic bond formation. The carbonyl O of residue n - 2 obliges, creating two products, an ioniized (protonated) 5-member N-terminal-side peptide (b ion) with oxazolone ring formed from residue n - 1, and a C-terminal side product with N-terminus at residue n. The C-terminal product abstracts the proton from the ring N of the N-terminal product as well to form a y ion in some cases. The proton affinity of the generated fragments can be determined from the relationship ln (bx/yz) ~ [(PAN-term − PAC-term) / RTeff] where bx/yz is ratio of abundances of the fragment b and y ions, PAN-term and PAC-term are proton affinitis of neutral fragments, and Teff is the effective temperature. Mechanistic considerations explain what is observed. CID spectra of protonated C6H5CO-Gly-Gly-OH showed b-type ions and this matches the CID spectra of protonated 2-phenyl-5-oxazolone which supports oxazolone structure stabilizing b ion formation. Study of N-methylated peptides (e.g., H-Gly-Sar-Sar-OH) the formation of y1 ions from the b2-y1 pathway is not possible since the oxazolone product has a fixed charge and no proton to share with the leaving H-Sar-OH. The spectrum is dominated by b2 ions; y1 only appears when high energies are input, originating probably from secondary fragmenation of y2 ions.

There is a linear relationship between log (y1/b2) and PA of C-terminal amino acid for protonated tripeptides with series Gly-Gly-Xxx. Fragmentation leads to a b2 ion (protonated 2-aminomethyl-5-oxazolone). Linearity of log(y1/b2) and Xxx PA by using above equation: PAN-term (PA of 2-aminomethyl-5-oxazolone) is constant while PAC-term is varied, which makes the equation linear. Similar results fround for other peptide series: Gly-Xxx-Phe, benzoyl-Gly-Gly-Xxx, and benzoyl-Xxx-Gly-Gly.

Diketopiperazine PFPs. Like the others, this starts with protonation of an amide N. Starting at the N-terminal residue (n), the n+1 amide N is protonated (mobile proton). This leads to trans-cis isomerization of the peptide bond. The residue n amino N is re-protonated, but with the geometric bond change, it is brought closer to the n + 1 and n + 2 peptide bond: the n + 2 amide N takes the proton, making the N-terminal amino N nucleophilic, and so it attacks the carbonyl C of residue n + 1, resulting in a 6-member diketopiperazine ring composed of residues n and n + 1, with product peptide having residue n + 2 as new N-terminus. It also takes the proton, and so a yz-2 ion is produced (where z was original length). PA values of cyclic peptides are lower than those of linear, explaining why the leaving linear peptide abundance is prominent. This mechanism is not limited to n - 2 diketopiperazine formations. It requires N-terminal amino N attack on the carbonyl C of the protonated amide bond, which can be between the 3rd and 4th, 4th and 5th, and 5th and 6th residues, leading to cyclo-tri-, cyclo-tetra-, and cyclo-pentapeptides. Studies with Leu-Gly-Pro (for neutral fragment reionization) show that the neutral counterpart to y1 ion formatin is the diketopiperazine derivative.

Amide Oxygen PFPs. Protonation of amide O atoms is more favored compared to amide N atoms. Others have proposed that b and y ions form not as a result of amide N protonation. Suppose amide O of residue n is protonated. This makes the amide O of residue n - 1 attracted to the carbonyl C containing the amide bond O now protonated. A 5-membered ring is formed, followed by a 1,1-elimination reaction with a protonated oxazolone on the N-terminal fragment and linear C-terminal fragment. Without proton transfer, the b ion is formed, and with it, the y ion is formed. PES investigations for a large number of protonated peptides (GGG, GGP, AGG, GAG, GGA, GGGG, AAAAA) shows that 5-membered rings made of amide O-protonated species exist but are not energetically favored. The 1,1-elimination requires bond rearrangements to create a 4-membered highly strained ring which has a very large energy barrier. In larger peptides the barrier could be reduced with catalysis of proton transfer step involving basic sites of the peptide. It is unlikely that such ion formations proceed by such a pathway.

Dissociation of N-terminal Amide Bond in Underivatized Peptides. Charge-directed dissociation of N-terminal amide bond differs from cleavage at other amide bonds. Most dissociations of low energy ions happen by the rearrangements already described rather than by direct bond cleavage. Here the a1-yx pathway is described as the exception. If a rearrangement is posited since the only available backbone nuclephile is the N-terminal amino group, the aziridinone pathway is described, with a highly strained 3-membered ring. Either the a1-yx or aziridinone pathways can be inhibited by acetylating the N-terminal amino group. For the a1-yx pathway the proton travels to the n + 1 amide N. A direct bond cleavage occurs as an immonium (a1) ion attempts to form (H2N=CH-R), becoming the charged group, with a neutral loss of carbon monoxide (CO). If there is proton transfer, then the yx-1 ion forms. Whether proton transfer occurs depends on a number of factors: internal energy distribution of ion population, PA of fragments (this can be approximated by the ln (a1/yx) ~ [(PANterm − PACterm)/RTeff] relation.) Studies with dipeptides and small peptides show yx ions with added proton as well as H-atom attached to N-terminal nitrogen, with migration. Neutral fragment reionization studies with AA dipeptide strong show ions dominated by MeCH=NH imine as a neutral counterpart to y1 ion.

Aziridinone PFPs. This is simply an attack of a nucleophilic uncharged amine at the N-terminus on the carbonyl C of its residue so long as the amide bond has been protonated on the amide N. A 3-membered aziridinone ring forms taking the proton with it, and this eventually leads to CO neutral loss with a1 ion formation. However, in the case of proton transfer, the y ion is formed. Energetically and kinetically such a pathway is far less favored than a1-yx. However, some experimental evidence could be explained by the aziridinone pathway based on some dipeptide studies with Val-Xxx, where Xxx is varied and proton affinities are known.

Charge-Directed Amide Bond Cleavage by Attack of Nucleophilic Side Chains. The effect of some reactive side chains in directing cleavage cannot be underestimated. Nucleophilic-based cleavage will involve His, Glu, Asn, Lys, and Arg. The mobile proton charges the amide bond with the nucleophile on the side chain of the residue on the N-terminal side. This creates a cyclic intermediate effectively being the b ion. This must be distinguished from the bx-yz pathway in which the carbonyl O of residue n - 1 attacks the carbonyl carbon to form the 5-membered oxazolone ring. For His residues, a clear histidine effect is seen so long as the protons added is larger than the number of Arg residues present. His has a high PA and is likely charged in gas phase low energy ions. With His as a nucleophile, the b ion is a bicyclic, and there is an association long enough for proton transfer to allow distribution of protons to either product ion. The His effect has been studied by varying the C-side adjacent residue, by alkylating the imidazole ring, and so on. MS/MS spectra of of 2+ ion RVYIHPF shows b5 and y2 ion pairs dominate, indicating both proton transfer and His effect. for the substitution of Pro for Ala (RVYIHAF), dominance of b5 and b6 are found, explained by PA difference for PF and AF dipeptides. If alkylation of ring is done, a bx2+ ion dominates, indicating proton transfer does not occur.

The amide side chains of Gln and Asn contribute to fragmentation as well. The side chain amide O atom nucleophilically bonds to its carbonyl C on the carboxyl side of the protonated amide bond to form a cyclic isoimide and the leaving C-terminal portion. With proton transfers, either b or y ions are formed. b2 ions derived from N-acyl Gln and Asn methyl esters were studied using MSn and ab initio techniques. The b2 ions fragment further to produce CO and CH2CO, which indicate oxazolone and isoimide forms. Ab initio calculations indicate the oxazolone is more stable than isoimide, although the Gln form difference is smaller (~2 kcal/mol) than for the Asn form (~11 kcal/mol). Study with GQG peptide using MSn shows b2 further fragments which includes CO neutrals and a Gly residue. The CO loss suggest classical oxazolone while latter indicates isoimide. Studies of peptides with a QG motif, name jQGb where j is any amino acid and b is any except G indicates Gln-based cleavage mechanism.

With Lys and Arg side chains, if mobile proton gets to a Lys-Xxx amide bond, the Lys side chain can form a caprolactam. Lys-Gly and other derivatives have been studied under MS. An ion with m/z 129 probably represents the caprolactam. The dipeptide has been studed using quantum chemical and RRKM calculations as well. Studies with b2 ions indicate that there is no CO loss and only the caprolactam is avaialble. Ab initio indicates oxazolone less stable than caprolactam. The peptide GGKAA was examined using ion trap MS: b3 ion was formed more abundantly than YGGFL. The GGKAA b3 ion loses H2O and GG with no dissociation signs (loss of CO and bx → bx-1) suggestive of oxazolone intermediate. With Arg side chains, there is a great deal of evidence that it too forms a 6-membered ring structure with a methyl diamine substituent.

Loss of Small Neutrals. MS/MS spectra provide much evidence of the loss of small neutrals such as water and ammonia. In low energy conditions [MH-H2O]+, [MH-NH3]+, [yz-H2O]+, [yz-NH3]+, [bx-H2O]+, [bx-NH3]+ result from charge-directed pathways. Water loss can occur from C-terminal, D and E carboxyl groups, from backbone amide O atoms, and Ser and Thr side chains. Ammonia loss can occur from Arg, Lys, Asn, and Gln. What mechanisms are proposed for neutral losses? When lost from the C-terminal COOH, one mechanism is proposed in which the n - 1 carbonyl O atom is protonated; this makes it nucleophilic, and it attacks the carboxyl C atom of the terminus. A concerted reaction of the COOH hydroxyl with the mobile proton causes loss of water, and the C-terminal amino acid forms a 5-membered oxazolone ring. Experiments with 18O and blocked carboxyl group show for instance that the peptide TRKR dehydrates exclusively at the C-terminal COOH group. This mechanism also explains water loss from Asp and Glu side chains although there is a different cyclic product. Peptides or their y ions that have Glu at the N-terminal position show significant side chain water loss, which involves pyroglutamate formation. MS/MS of [18O2]-RPPGF peptide shows dehydration occurring primarily through loss of H216O involving backbone amide O atoms. MS/MS/MS spectra show the oxygen comes from the carbonyl of amide bond nearest to N-terminus. It was shown that b4 from GGGG and b5 from GGGGG do not have oxazolone structures, expected if dehydration involves C-terminal COOH. MS/MS of methylated GGGG indicates water elimination by an amide O atom on backbone. Dehydration of Ser and Thr is thought to occur when the mobile proton bonds to the hydroxyl, forming a cationic leaving group; the amide O atom of the previous residue bonds to the methylene, creating the water loss, and forming a 5-membered ring in the case of Ser, 6-membered for Thr.

Ammonia loss comes strictly from side chains of basic amino acids and amides. From Lys side chains it occurs through SN2-type reactoins. 15N-labeling experiments show strict elimination, although there is position dependence. When Lys is at N-terminus, the amino terminus attacks the delta-methylene of the side chain, with formation of the 6-membered pipecolic acid at N-teriminus; this is more kinetically favored than an amide O atom attack. Unfavorable entropic factors prevent amino terminal attack of Lys side chain not at the terminus. Theoretical methods were used to determine mechanism for Arg. Its protonated guanidino function is capable of multiple tautomer formation: -NεH-C(NηH3+)(Nη′H) or -Nε-C(NηH3+)(Nη ′H2). In this case ammonia loss probably proceeds via SN1-type reaction. Finally, the amide O atom (probably on the residue) attacks the guanidinyl carbon to form an 8-membered ring with ammonia loss. With Gln and Asn, then N atom of the amide side chain is protonated. If the residue is N-terminal Gln, then pyroglutamate is likely since the amino terminus is a good nucleophile. If Gln or Asn are within the peptide, attack of the amide carbon is probably from peptide backbone amide O atom.

Continuing Fragmentation. Fragmentation is not limited to bond dissociations of the parent peptide. Ions in the b and y series can fragment further to smaller b and y ions. y Ions have no special structure, so their continued fragmentation can follow bx-yz, a1-yz, etc. PFPs. b Ions have the oxazolone ring and so follow additional specific fragmentation such as CO elimination by the bx→ax pathway and formation of smaller b ions by the bx→bx-1 pathway. Doubly protonated tryptic peptides show have weak b ion signals in triple quads or Q-ToF from initial fragmentations; this is likely because of b ion subfragmentation is more favored in these systems. Singly charged y ions from initial fragmentation are more likely to be seen on MS/MS spectra because of apparent stability, probably because added protons on the C-terminal side are sequested by Lys and Arg residues of tryptic peptides.

Subfragmentation of b ions. Higher b ion fragmentation of GGGG, GGGGG, and YGGFL have been studied. b3 and b4 ions are likely to fragment in a sequence-dependent way to form lower b ions. There are strong indications of formations of oxazolone rights particularly in penta-Ala homopolymer. A mechanism has been proposed in which an amide O atom on the N-terminal side is nucleophilically attracted to the -C=N+- moiety in the oxazolone ring. This actually leads to formation of an aziridinone tricyclic ring with the C-terminal residue of the bx ion, and a bx-1 ion is formed with another oxazolone ring. This particular reaction had an activation energy of 77 kcal/mol, too high for mass spectrometers under low-energy. A pathway of bx→ax→bx-1 requires 40 kcal/mol internal energy, but metastable ion studies show the bx→ax reaction occurs with a substantial release of kinetic energy (T½ = 0.3-0.5 eV), indicating that the bx→ax→bx-1 pathway is unlikely as there are low KER values. Another group using stored waveform Fourier transform and double resonance techniques with quadrupole ion-trap showed that 50% of b3 ions of Leu-enkephalin originate from b4 ions directly under moderately energetic conditions, and so the bx→bx-1 pathway is yet unknown.

The bx→ax pathways produce ion pairs differing by 28 Da and this helps the identification of the b ion series, as these immonium (ax) ions point to their parent b ions. Protonation of the N atom in the oxazolone ring leads to weakening of -O-CO- bond and CO elimination by a concerted pathway, which requires breaking of two covalent bonds of the cyclic bx ion to form a linear ax ion. Activation energies for the bx→ax paths of HCO-NH-CH2CO+, MeCO-NH-CHMeCO+, NH2-iBuCH-CO-NH-CH2-CO+, and NH2-CH2-CO-NH-iBuCHCO+ b2+ ions are 29, 30.5, 34.6, and 30.3 kcal/mol, respectively. In general bx→bx-1 and bx→ax dissociations are the main pathways.

Internal fragment formation requires cleavage of at least two backbone amide bond and leads to inos of underivatized N- and oxazolone or immonium C-terminus. In low energy collision spectra these fragments appear when y ions are present in unusual abundance. It occurs very frequently with peptides containing Pro and His (see discussion below of this effect). Formation of these has been studied using YGGFL and des-Arg-substance P in product ion scanning mand reaction intermediate scanning modes. Certain yz ions fragment further. In des-Arg-subP, the Lys-Pro amide bond cleaves (Pro effect) with axy8 and bxy8 formation. N-terminal residue immonium ion formation comes down from the a1-yz and b2→a1 pathways, although immonium ions in the low mass range may also originate from amino acids in other positions. Internal immonium ion (Ix) formation comes two pathways: ax ions fromed from bx-yz and bx→ax fragment to produce ax-1 and Ix.

While the Asp and His effects clearly result from chemical activity which can be shut down by chemical modification (Asp esterification, for ex), the Proline Effect works by altering other pathways leading to dominance of a few ions, especially in the bx-yz and diketopiperazine pathways. Peptides AAPAA and AAAPA were found to produce abundant y3 and y2 ions, respectively, and this is because of a high PA by Pro. Peptide VAPLG forms abundant y3 ion, whereas Val-Ala-NMeAla-Leu-Gly and Val-Ala-Pip-Leu-Gly produce significant b3 ions. VAPLG and VA-Pip-LG differ by only a methylene group, and the other peptide is N-methylated, indicating an N-methylation effect. Simple proton affinity differences cannot account for this. A b3 ion formation on C-side of Pro requires formation of highly strained bicyclic [3.3.0] moiety. However, if the residue is Pip, a less strained bicylic [4.3.0] moiety is formed; in the other case, N-methylation dictates fragmentation. The tripeptide GPG shows a dominant b2 ion which contains a bicyclic [3.3.0] moiety. We contend that there is no special Pro effect on cleavage of N-terminal amide bond and that this cleavage is described by the a1-yz pathway. The dipeptide VP conforms to a1-y1 fragmentation rules in that y1 is favored at low energies (PA of Pro higher than imine derived from Val). At C-terminal of tripeptides it may have a special effect: in LGP tripeptide, the majority of y1 ions form via the diketopiperazine pathway whereas with GGG and GGL, y1 ions form from a b2-yl pathway.

In cyclic peptides because there is no free amino terminal, pathways that involve internal amide bond dissociation dominate. The initial fragmenation is by loss of CO and production of a sequence ion: bxn-m and yzn-m where n is the N-side amino acid and m is the C-side amino acid of the amide bond broken. Prior to fragmentation, an amide O atom is protonated with mobilization to an amide N atom creating the high potential energy. Ring opening is following by oxazolone formation of the new C-terminus. Linearized peptide can cause bx→ax formation (CO loss) with formation of a lower b ion (bx→bx-1). With N-methylation on residue n, amide bond cleavage then occurs between residues n and n + 1, producing and N-methylated oxazolone ring; this ring degrades further with lose of CO (bx→ax) or by losing the resiude (bx→bx-1).

Charge-Remote PFPs. The aspartic acid effect is seen to produce abundant b ions on the C-side of Asp residues. Investigations of Asp-Pro and Asp-Xxx in MALDI MS shows great lability. If Asp is esterified, b ion formation produced by this effect is eliminated. The Asp75-Met76 bond in Hb alpha chain undergoes this effect particularly for 11+ and 12+ ions. In ubiquitin the 11+ ion fragments easily into the b527+/y244+ ion pair, because of the presence of Asp-52.

Kiri AN, Tran H-C, Drahos KL, Lan WK, McRorie DK, Horn MJ (2005) J. Biomolec. Techniques 16, 369-377.

Proteomic Changes in Bovine Heart Mitochondria with Age: Using A Novel Technique for Organelle Separation and Enrichment

Bovine hearts from 3-8 mon young and 18-24 mon adult were harvested and whole hearts rapidly frozen in liq. nitrogen for storage. Tissue was then thawed at 4° in PBS. 100 g myocardium free of connective and vascular tissue was homogenized in blender in 0.5 L 0.5 M sucrose buffered with 20 mM HEPES pH 7.2, 5 mM MgCl2, and inhibitors (Roche Complete); blending was 30 sec high, 30 sec low. Material was filtered through 4 layers cheesecloth, then spun 750 g 10 min to remove nuclei. Pellets were resuspended in extraction buffer and blended and re-spun again. Supernatants are combined and diluted 2-fold in 20 mM HEPES pH 7.2, 5 mM MgCl2 so that sucrose is now 0.25 M.

An Alfa Wasserman pCFU continuous-flow ultracentrifuge was equipped with PKII 800 ml rotor and loaded with 20 mM HEPES pH 7.2, 5 mM MgCl2, 0.25 M sucrose buffer using peristaltic pump. Air bubbles are removed by spinning at 20000 rpm and pumping buffer up through bottom. The rotor is stopped and a higher density solution is introduced to the bottom (60% sucrose in buffer) at 10 ml/min. The rotor is accelerated to 3500 rpm to create the linear gradient. Acceleration continues to 20000 rpm and then the homogenate is loaded. Material from the top is recirculated to the bottom at 35000 rpm permitting light particles to get into gradient. Banding occurs for another 2 h at 35000 rpm. When stopped, the rotor is fractionated by collection from the bottom. 1 ml from each fraction was kept unfrozen, while the rest was deep-frozen.

Continuous flow ultracentrifugation was pioneered by Norman Anderson in the 1960s and commercialized by Alfa Wasserman. Sample is first put into the unmoving rotor. Spinning is started and a gradient forms vertically along the wall. A continuous flow is provided to allow particles to enter and move to equilibrium point. The centrifuge is stopped without loss of the formed gradient. A refractometer (Milton Roy) was used to verify the formation of a gradient (samples could have been weighed too). Anti-Tom20 antibody was used in western blotting of each of the fractions, revealing the mitochondria banded across about 10 fractions (8-17) from 1.11 to 1.18 g/ml. Results seem to indicate that adult mitochondria are slightly more dense than those from young hearts.

Fractions from the adult and young heart ultracentrifuge spin were then run on 2D gels (strips from 3-10, 5-8, 7-10) in triplicate. Replicate gels showed 144 matching spots between identical fractions from young and adult in one faction. For the young, there were 103 unique spots in one fraction, 190 in another. Significant differences exist in the protein mapping profiles based on age.

pCFU will separate and enrich on the organelle subtype. Heart mitochondria and subtypes were separated based on shape and densities. Comparisons were then made on spots between densities but within the same age group, and the number of matched spots were significantly greater than between age groups but at similar densities. NanoLC-ESI-MS/MS was used for selected spots that differed by at least 2-fold expression. Proteins found in Adult fraction 9 and 12 but not in the young bovine animal were NADH dehydrogenase (ubiquinone) Fe-S 3-30 kDa, desmin, a D-Asp oxidase-like enzyme, voltage-dependent anion channel 2, thymidine kinase bovine herpesvirus 4; identified from a pH 5-8 IPG. Protein in the young bovine fractions 9 and 12 but not in adult were translation elongation factor EF-Tu precursor, caldesmon, thymidine kinase, Ig λ light chain, and enoyl-CoA hydratase precursor. For proteins present in both with 2-fold differences in both fractions of both ages, these were four proteins greater in adults: NADH dehydrogenase (ubiquinone) Fe-S protein 1-75 kDa; S chain S, bovine heart cytochrome C oxidase at fully reduced state; serum albumin precursor; casein alpha-S1. The next four proteins are greater in the young animal: E Chain E, structure of bovine F1-ATPase covalently inhibited with 4-chloro-7-nitrobenzofuran; adenylate kinase 2; multicatalytic protease complex, macropain, proteosome subunit 13 peptide; bovine viral diarrheal virus.

Williams B, Cornett S, Crecelius A, Caprioli R, Dawant B, Bodenheimer B (2005) Proceeedings of The ACM 43rd Annual Southeast Regional Conference 1, 137-142.

An Algorithm for Baseline Correction of MALDI Mass Spectra

A new baseline correction (background subtraction) algorithm is presented, particular to compensate for convex shapes that occur to signal in the low end of the mass range. The spectrum is first divided into local areas, and then local areas are divided into windows. Then the minima are found in the windows. The local area range is changed adaptively to ensure that minima lying on peaks are not selected. A function for the set of minima is then derived to produce the final baseline.

Windows within local areas are constructed so that a polynomial is fit through median points. If too many medians lie above the polynomial, a peak is detected and the local area expands. As an example suppose a local area of 1000 is started at m/z 20,200. The local area is divided into 20 windows, each being 50 units wide. The median signal is then computed in each of the windows. Within the local area, a polynomial line is drawn that fits the median points created in each window. The count of median points above and below the first iterated line is determined. If too many points lie above the line, then the local area is increased until a percentage of local medians are below the polynomial or that lie within a distance ε from the polynomial. Medians above the distance ε are discarded; remaining medians are added to list of baseline points.

Finding the Offset.

  1. Define a window size of fixed width w, to be stepped across the spectrum. In practice a value of 1000 m/z units averages out the noise fairly well.
  2. Initialize the location of the window w_loc to the start of the spectrum.
  3. Set current intensity curr_int equal to the mean intensity of m/z values in the first window.
  4. Move the window w m/z values such that w_loc = w_loc + w.
  5. Set previous intensity prev_int = curr_int, and then set curr_int to mean intensity of the moved window.
  6. Repeat the last previous two steps until prev_int > curr_int, which means that the previous window contains essentially a peak intensity.
  7. An area to search for the window of highest intensity will be startsearch = w_loc − 2 × w, and the limit endsearch = w_loc.
  8. A window having width w is started at startsearch.
  9. The window within the search region is moved one m/z unit, and the mean of intensity values in the window is evaluated. The window having the highest mean value is tracked.
  10. The median of the window having the highest mean intensity is evaluated, and used as the starting point for the baseline algorithm.

Calculating the baseline. The baseline will follow the determined median values for each window. If windows do not span peak widths, the baseline will be radically shifted or altered, and so to avoid this, and adaptively expanding window is employed. This adaptive expansion is employed in the following algorithm:

  1. Set loc_area to the intial local area size, init_loc_size; it should be as small as possible but large enough so as not to be far less than typical peak width. In practice a init_loc_size = 1000 works as a tradeoff between precision and speed.
  2. The local window size loc_wind = loc_area / num_wind (number of windows). In practice num_wind set at 20 is reasonable.
  3. Now set loc_area = num_wind × loc_wind.
  4. Find m/z x and intensity y of the medians in the window (xi, yi) where i = 1 to num_wind.
  5. Fit a fourth order polynomial, P, to the medians using least squares to solve a system of linear questions at points (xi, yi). The 4th order polynomial compromises speed and smoothness.
  6. Let yi = P(xi). Count the number of points at which yi − y′i > ε, i.e. the number the medians computed in step 3 that are above the tolerance. Use of an ε of 5% is reasonable.
    1. If the medians above the polynomial exceed 25% of the points in the local area (num_wind), then all median points in the local area are discarded. The local area size is then increased by init_loc_size and step 2 is resumed. The local area expands until < 25% of point lie distance ε above the fitted polynomial line.
    2. Otherwise, add the median points which are < distance ε above the polynomial to the set of baseline points, then continue to step 6.
    The value of 25% is selected as it represents a value that ignores points lying on peaks without compromising speed.
  7. Reset local_area to init_loc_size. Move to next local area, and repeat steps 2-5 until end of spectrum is reached.
  8. The baseline is calculated by fitting the exponential y = aebx + cedx to the set of data points using least squares.

Higgs RE, Knierman MD, Gelfanova V, Butler JP, Hale JE (2005) J. Proteome Res. 4, 1442-1450.

Comprehensive Label-Free Method for the Relative Quantification of Proteins from Biological Samples

Biological fluid samples for biomarker discovery were studied by LC-MS/MS using different modalities. 50 µl rat serum is albumin-depleted (Montage, Millipore) then treated with 2% iodoethanol and 0.5% triethylphosphine in MeCN in 8 M urea in pH 11 0.1 M ammonium bicarbonate for reduction-alkylation. Treated to Worthington trypsin 1:50 (w/w) overnight assuming 50% protein depletion. The LC-MS/MS setup is a Surveyor autosampler with MS HPLC pump (Thermo-Finnigan) with tryptic digests (10 µl) injected to Zorbax SB300 1 × 50 mm C18 RP (Agilent) at 50 µl/min. with 10-95% B gradient over 2 h with 0.1 min to 100% B, 5 min at 100% C, 0.1 min to 10% B, equilibrate for 17 min. Solvent A is 0.1% FA, solvent B is 50% MeCN + 0.1% formic acid, C is 80% MeCN + 0.1%FA. All effluent was sent to electrospray on LCQ Deca XP + ion trap MS (ThermoFinnigan) Source is +4.0 kV, sheath gas 20 units, capillary 150°. Maximization of the +2 charge ion of angiotensin was done. Data collection is triple play mode: centroid parent scan with 3 microscans 200 ms maximum injection time, profile zoom scan with 3 microscans and 200 ms max injection time, centroid MS/MS with 3 microscans and 400 ms max injection time. Dynamic exclusion were set to repeat count of one, exclusion list duration of 2 minutes, and rejection widths of -0.75 m/z and +2.0 m/z. Relative collision is 35% and exclusion width of 4 m/z.

Agrawal GK, Thelen JJ (2005) Proteomics 5, 4684-4688.

Development of a Simplified, Economical Polyacrylamide Gel Staining Protocol for Phosphoproteins

The Pro-Q Diamond phosphoprotein stain for gels from Molecular Probes is quite costly. The procedure given by the manufacturer has been modified after 1 year in production. The modification was essentially to the fixation (recommended now to be overnight, as opposed to 90 min-to-overnight). The latest revision indicates use of a fix that is 50% MeOH/10% acetic acid as opposed to 45% MeOH/5% acetic acid. Changes to destaining and washing protocols are also modified in the revisions. All these continuing revisions suggest that optimization is still an open question. Although various destains have been reported, the best ones contain MeCN which help to remove background quickly. The latest and best destain is 20% MeCN in 50 mM sodium acetate, pH 4.0, which is done four times for 30 min each.

Peppermint Stick phosphoprotein MW markers from Molecular Probes were loaded in serial 2-fold dilutions from 1000 down to 2 ng and run on a 1D gel; the markers have two phosphorylated proteins (ovalbumin and β-casein at 45 and 23.6 kDa, resp.) and four nonphosphorylated proteins (β-galactosidase, BSA, avidin and lysozyme at 116, 66.2, 18.0, and 14.4 kDa). It was found that a 3-fold dilution of the recommended ProQ Diamond stain still gave a fluorescence intensity equivalent to the rest: there was no change in sensitivity, fluorescence intensity or linear dynamic range. Staining time was also checked (2, 6, 12 h) and staining longer than 2 h did not alter the results; this is unlike many typical total protein stains in which longer incubation times typically improve the results because the stain has different kinetics with different amino acids. A time course was done on fixation (1, 6, 15 h) and 1 h was found sufficient. The standard (manufacturer) and modified protocols were compared using the markers ovalbumin and β-casein, and plots of fluorescence vs. protein amt were virtually identical.

The advantages of the modified protocol (diluted stain reagent) are: (1)

FD

Cooper TJ, Talaty ER, Van Stipdonk MJ (2005) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 16, 1305-1310.

Novel Fragmentation Pathway for CID of (bn − 1 + Cat)+ Ions from Model, Metal Cationized Peptides

Short Comm.. The peptides AAAG and A(βA)AG were ionized in presence of Li+ in ESI-MS/MS with CID. Prominent in the product spectra were ions at m/z 238 [b3 + 17 + Li]+, 220 [b3 − 1 + Li]+, and 192 [a3 − 1 + Li]+. Peaks at m/z 277 and 260 corresponded to neutral loss of H2O (18 amu) and a combination of H2O and NH3 loss (35 amu) were also found for AAAG but not the βA-containing peptide. Loss of H2O in combination with NH3 or not might occur by nucleophilic attack of N-terminal carbonyl oxygen on the n + 1 carbonyl carbon. Absence of these two reaction products for the βA peptide consistent with mechanism in which cyclization and intramolecular bonding involves less kinetically and entropically favored 6-member ring and with earlier study of influence of amino acids on generating [bn + 17 + Cat]+ products.

The [b3 − 1 + Li]+ from AAAG and A(βA)AG is the lithium-cationized oxazolinone. The most prominent dissociation pathway for [bn]+ and [bn − 1 + Cat]+ is CO elimination to produce [an − 1 + Cat]+. A scheme shows the mechanism by which that can be accomplised. MS3 spectra are presented with the m/z 220 [b3 − 1 + Li]+ presented. Most abundant was m/z 192 [a3 − 1 + Li]+ for both AAAG and A(βA)AG, being a loss of CO (28 amu). Additionally for AAAG peptide showed an m/z 149 ion while A(βA)AG showed a m/z 148, losses of 71 and 72 amu, respectively. The 72 amu is equivalent to loss of a C-terminal Ala (71 amu) plus one. We compared 4 peptides with the motif AxAG where x = β-Ala, γ-aminobutyric acid, ε-amino-n-caproic acid, and 4-aminomethylbenzoic acid. In all cases, the [b3 − 1 + Li]+ had an increasing tendency to lose 72 amu and less so the 28 amu CO.

The peptide motif A(ε-Cap)-x-G was tried, where x was Val, Gly, Gly−1−13C, and Gly−15N. For Val, there was a 100 amu loss product ion (= mass Val + 1) at m/z 190; for Gly, there as a 58 amu loss product (= mass Gly + 1) at m/z 190 and a -44 amu loss ion (m/z 204). These ions were also found for the Gly−1−13C. With the 13C isotope, neutral losses were 29, 45, and 59, namely all +1 for each of the product ions, which indicates its loss and which carbon is affected. For the 15N-labeled glycine, the dominant product ion shifted by 1 to m/z 149, which indicates the labeled nitrogen is retained in the product.

For the m/z 262 (A-εCap-AG) to m/z 190 transition, formation of a nitrile with loss of 3-membered ring CH3CH(O)C=O α-lactone. Formation of αlactones was suggested as a dissocation pathway for Ag+-cationized phenylalanine. Other product ions include -44 and -45 amu ions (latter in the 13C-labeled amino acids. This suggests a neutral loss of CO2 from the oxazolinone ring. The m/z 218 ion that forms might by a 2H-azirine (3-membered) ring. This 44 amu loss is seen only for AxGG peptides, in which the stability of the neutral α-lactone is the key to the formation of a nitrile product. 2H-azirines are more stable than anti-aromatic 1H-azirines; 2H-azirines can be isolated at low temperature, whereas α-lactones cannot be.

Thus the [b3 − 1 + Li]+ ion fragments in several ways: (1) loss of α-Ala residue mass to produce [b2 − 1 + Li]+, (2) CO neutral loss to produce [a2 − 1 + Li]+, (3) ejection of an α-lactone to produce lithiated nitrile, (4) elimination of CO2 to produce Li-cationized 2H-azirine.

FD

Wells JM, McLuckey SA (2005) Meth. Enzymol. 402, 148-185.

Collision-Induced Dissociation (CID) of Peptides and Proteins

Most commonly used activation method in tandem MS of peptides and proteins is energetic collisions with neutral target gas (rather than neutral better to use chemical non-reactive?). This is called collision-induced dissociation (CID).

When J. J. Thomson was undertaking the first studies of mass spectrometry he observed gas-phase CID in his parabola mass spectrograph. Summary of early work on CID was published (Cooks, 1995). Closely related to CID is metastable ion dissociation. Tandme MS has been very useful in identification and characterization of ions and complex mixture analysis where collision product product ions with understanding of fragmentation theory. Other dissociation methods include surface-induced dissociation (SID) and photo-induced dissociation (PID) but CID is far easier to implement. 20 years ago the emergence of both MALDI and ESI was reported for biomolecule analysis.

Use of technique has outpaced the understanding of its mechanisms. The energy transfer mechanisms that operate during collisions of large (> 1000 Da) possibly multiply charged with small target gas atoms or molecules are not as well understood as they are for smaller ions.

Figures of merit for CID are outlined here of how peptides/proteins dissociate as function of CID conditions uses:

  1. Time over which activation occurs relative to time for unimolecular dissociation or rearrangement
  2. Amount of energy deposited during activation
  3. Distribution of deposited energy
  4. Variability of deposited energy
  5. Form of deposited energy (vibrational vs. electronic)
  6. Time scale of instrument used (kinetic window within which dissociation reactions must occur in order to be observed)
  7. Efficiency of CID process in terms of cross section of rate constant

First figure of merit, time scale of activation, refers to how fast energy is deposited in ion relative to how fast energy equilibrates through degrees of freedom of ion, how fast it dissociates or rearranges, and how fast energy is removed by cooling processes such as deactivating collisions or photon emission.

Salih E (2005) Mass Spect. Rev. 24, 828-846.

Phosphoproteomics by Mass Spectrometry and Classical Protein Chemistry Approaches

REVIEW. Generally phosphorylation occurs at a low level, perhaps too low to be observed without sensitive methods such as radiolabeling. Use of pulse-chase experiments are informative for cell/tissue culture based experiments with 32P. 32P-γ-ATP mixed with cell lysates or in the presence of purified or enriched protein kinases can be used. Proteins are isolated, identified, digested and radiolabeled peptides separated by TLC or HPLC. N-terminal sequence analysis is then done using Edman method. This was the classical approach to identifying phosphorylated residues. A problem is that P-Ser residues degrade in the Edman method.

Meyer et al. (1993) used a method in which they achieved the β-elimination of phosphate from P-Ser and P-Thr residues with alkaline medium and then add a thiol (e.g., ethanethiol). The peptide is marked and stabilized and then isolated by the usual methods above (digestion, resolution of peptide by chromatography, then Edman sequencing). Unfortunately, such methods are quite insensitive. Sensitivity can be improved however when radiolabeled thiol agents (e.g, 1-S-[3H]carboxymethyl-dithiothreitol, or [3H]CM-DTT). This reagent can actually enable qualitative, and relative and absolute quantitation of proteins for cell-labeling studies. In addition non-labeled form of CM-DTT and its precursor DTT were used to study P-Ser and P-Thr-containing phosphoproteins analyzed by MALDI-MS. Note that in using thiols, a mono- and di-thiol approach might be taken. Dithiols present the possibility of linking other components (affinity tags like biotin, or thiol-reactive radiolabeled components such as deuterated iodoacetamide or ICATs (also deuterated). Recently ECM phosphoprotein studies led to a rapid ID of the complete topographical distribution of in vivo and in vitro phosphorylation sites of bone sialoprotein (BSP). All the phosphorylation sites were determined using a combination of approaches: [32P]ATP in vitro using Edman sequencing, [14C]-CM-DTT after base-catalyzed elimination and Edman sequencing, and MALDI-MS. It is not enough to identify phosphorylation but it is essential to indicate the number of moles P per mole peptide per site.

A monophosphorylated peptide and its unphosphorylated form will differ in mass by exactly 80 Da. When doing peptide mass fingerprinting, the assumption of a phosphorylated peptide can be factored in during database searching for the purpose of identification. Moreover, the report comes back that the ID was made because phosphorylation was assumed. In this way, a protein is marked as potentially phosphorylated.

Immobilized-metal affinity columns (IMAC) with Zn2+, Fe3+, and Ga3+ at the center have a particular affinity for phosphate. Peptides can be run over the column and the many bound peptides not washed off are likely to be phosphorylated. Unfortunately the affinity for phosphate is not all that specific: peptides with a high number of acidic, histdine, and cysteine residues also bind. If analyzed on MALDI-MS, a phosphatase-treated sample will also need to be run to look for peak shifts that are relevant. Alternatively direct sequence analysis may be necessary. However a recent IMAC approach by Ficarro et al (2002) eliminated nonspecific binding, with a large number of phosphopeptides site-identified.

Radiolabeled proteins have also been 2-D gel-separated followed by autoradiography. These proteins can be excised, digested and MALDI-MS-analyzed.

Additionally high-affinity anti-P-Tyr antibodies can be used to enrich P-Tyr-containing proteins and peptides. It is less effective for P-Ser and P-Thr-containing proteins and peptides.

Vogel RF, Pavlovic M, Hrmann S, Ehrmann MA (2005) Brazilian J. Med Biol. Res. 38, 1247-1252.

High pressure-sensitive gene expression in Lactobacillus sanfranciscensis

High hydrostatic pressure (HHP) is used in food processing is intened to inactivate (kill) bacteria and viruses without loss of the desirable nutritent or aesthetic properties. Bacteria in their vegetative form are usually killed, but those in (endo)sporulating conditions resist. Kinetics is such that a small resistant fraction may survive HHP. Lactobacillus sanfranciscensis DSM 20451T is grown at 30° in mMRS pH 6.1 medium and cells harvested in exponential phase. Cells are transferred to fresh 30° medium and subjected to pressuures of 80 MPa for 60 min, at pressure rate increase of 30 MPa/min. 2D gels were run in pH 3-10, 4-7, 4.5-5.5 and 5.5-6.5. MALDI-MS and N-terminal sequence was provided through a service (TopLab). In addition genomic DNA was isolated by Lewington et al using DSM 20451 strain; shotgun libraries were made in E coli DH5α using E. cloni™ and plasmid psmart-HCAmp (Lucigen) using partial digest (BsuRI, AluI) and sonicated DNA. Random sequencing of 100 inserts and inserts of 2000 clones were PCR-amplified and spotted to silylated microscope slides to form array. Hybridizations were done according to Huang et al with cDNAs labeled with Alexa Fluor 555 from untreated cells and AlexaFluor 647 from pressure-treated cells.

Five experiments to grow and pressure-treat cells were performed, and proteins from them run on 2DE. 16 proteins were identified as having their expression altered by pressure; of these 9 showed 2- to 12-fold increase while 7 proteins were reduced by 50% or more. N-terminal sequencing was done on internal peptides of four proteins. BLAST analysis showed two proteins P1 and P2 had homology to ribokinase and ATP-dependent protease ClpL. Sequences of P9, P13, and P16 showed homology to general stress protein GroEL (hsp60), EF-Tu, and GA3PDH, respectively. "Reversed genetics" was used to find and code genes. P1 is a 540 amino acid proteiin coded by 1620 bp segment with calculated mass of 58 kDa, larger than any known ribokinase. The first 308 aa show homology to ribokinase and the latter 232 to ribose-5-phosphate isomerase.

DNA microarrays were used to analyze transcriptome. 750 spots were judged quality spots and showed that mRNA levels of genes or operons was affected in 48. 6% of genes showed 2-fold or more induction, and 1% showed repression at 2-fold or more. The phosphoketolase xpk gene showed no affect of HHP and was used in reference for using real-time PCR. Real-time PCR was used as an independent confirmation of the microarray data. The most upregulated gene was an ORF with a DEAD-ATP-dependent helicase motif (3.9-fold increased)

Eiceman GA, Karpas Z (2005) 2nd Ed., (Boca Raton: Taylor & Francis)

Ion Mobility Spectrometry

BOOK (350 pages). Ion mobility spectrometry (IMS) involves characterizing chemicals substances by the velocity of their gas-phase ions in an electric field. A swarm of ions are introduced to voltage gradient or electric field (V/cm) and attain a constant drift velocity (cm/s) at ambient pressure in a gas, usually air, and the velocity is proportional to electric field:

vd ∝ E, vd = kE

where k has units of cm2 / [V-s]. Velocity applies only to swarm and not to individual ions. For swarms of ions from 14 to 500 amu, velocities are 1-10 m/s in electric fields of 150-300 V/cm at temps from 25-250° C. Mobility coefficients would be 0.8-2.4 cm2/V-s and are normalized to T=273 K and P=760 torr:

k0 = k(273/T)(P/760)

A sample is put in the gas phase into a portion of the drift tube called the reaction region. In this region, some of the sample molecules get ionized. An ion shutter is activated to draw the ionized (not neutral) molecules into the drift region part of the tube. In this they have a constant velocity and strike a detector at the other end. Drift tubes have a 4-20 cm length usually. At ambient pressure and temperature, a swarm with k0 = 2 cm2/V-s moving at 4 m/s in a E=200 V/cm field should take 15 ms to complete travel time when the tube is 6 cm long. The mobility spectrum is often presented as detector response (current or voltage) vs. drift time (in milliseconds). When ions collide with detector, they become neutralized, causing a current flow of 10-1000 pA, which becomes amplified and transformed to a 0-10 V full range.

The mobility spectrum often contains selectivity that includes fragmentation and peak shape (performance measure).

Original ionization sources were 10 mCi 63Ni beta electron emittes with 17 keV mean energy. These collide and ionize atmosphere gas and release secondary electrons. Ion-molecule reactions with N2, O2, and H2O vapor causing formation of H+(H2O)n and O2−(H2O)n. These are reactant ions which then ionize sample (M) ions colliding with them. The reaction becomes part of a cluster that includes displacement.

M + H+(H2O)n → MH+(H2O)n → MH+(H2O)n−x + x H2O

The cluster ion might be stabilized by collision with another M, or third body collision usually from supporting atmosphere, with loss of water adducts.

History. From 1850 to 1938 represents the period of innovation and discovery. Early researchers found that conductivity in air developed by formation of electrons and gaseous ions. X-rays focused on gases made them ionized: Rutherfored measured mobility of ions formed by x-rays within two years of the discovery of x-rays. Additionally, radioactivity and ionization by flame and UV light could be observed. By 1938, there was much data on ions formed in gases and their mobilities, and effects of temperature, pressure and gas purity. Also clusters of ions formed with polar neutral molecules was studied. For dried gases, positive ions had an envelope of molecules. For negative ions, mobilities were altered when placed in water vapor.

Achievements made included Langevin's findings on the collisional nature of mobility, and role of attractive forces on effective collision cross sections. Another important advance was pulsed injection of ions using a shutter; today a linear field with two-shutter design would be employed. Additionally an understanding of electric fields and gas pressure on mobility of ions in gases was important. For example, mobility was found to be independent of the E/N (field voltage/gas pressure) ratio up to several Td (1 Td = 10−17 V/cm2); beyond 2-4 Td, mobility becomes dependent on E/N.

In 1948 Lovelock was studying if breezes were related to human illness so he developed a vapor anemometer to look at changed in wind direction or speed. A radioactive source ionizes the air space between two electric field plates or grids, and changes in the current that might be caused by a breeze or wind can be detected. Some of this technology became part of electron capture detection (ECD).

Gas phase ion-molecule reactions at elevated (atmospheric) pressures were an interest in 1950s experiments looking at radiolysis of air, and in reactions at Earth's upper atmospheric layers. These studies were facilitiated by identifying ions produced in flames and corona discharged using mass spectrometers. Shahin at Xerox sampled ions in corona discharge using pinhole orifice of MS to look at chemistry of photocopiers and laser printers. This occurred at same time as study of ion-molecule reactions in chemical ionization mass spectrometry. Kebarle looked at reactions and kinetic of these reactions at elevated pressures.

Drift tube design was also changed. One was a stack of electrically isolated rings with linear electric field established by voltage divider. They created a system called Plasma Chromatography. IMS and ion chemistry in air at ambient pressure has complicated charge-transfer reaction and ion cluster formations. While it might be fused with an MS, the mobility spectrometer did not have much analytical value.

Cottingham K (2005) Anal. Chem. 77, 227A-231A.

Versatile TOFMS

PRODUCT REVIEW. TOF instruments are superior in exact mass determinations which solve problems and determine structures. Accurate mass measuments to four decimal places narrow down identities of unknowns and can set elemental compositions. TOFs are now choices for biomarker discovery where as FTMS, sector, and triple quads had been used earlier.

Reflectrons. With the use of reflectrons (ion mirrors) resolution can be improved, but that an intended effect is to refocus ions of different energies. The analogy is of the bicycle race: really fast guys missed the turn, had gone too far, then turned around. The slower ones made the turn, and so at one point the fast and slow racers are together for just a moment, which is how the reflectron works. Reflectrons can actually work as single- or dual-stage reflectons, which are one- or two-constant field regions separated by grids. Quadratic and curved field reflectrons have more complex fields. Dual-stage reflectrons have higher mass resolution than single stage, but the single stage can focus a broader range of energies. The curved field reflectron is similar to the single stage but has a higher bandwidth; it is efficient as focusing fragment ions. Reflectrons usually have grids, but there are gridless reflectrons; grids show a change in field at the end of the drift tube similar to hitting a curb, but gridless systems are not at any advantage since ions can deviate if entering at an angle or off-axis.

Since TOF relies on a pulse, it is often mentioned with MALDI. These are thus axial TOF systems. With orthogonal TOF systems, a continous stream of ions as produced by electrospray can be sampled into a ToF. However, atmospheric pressure MALDI can now be used, in which formed ions enter the MS in a continuous stream and are orthogonally sampled.

Some ToF systems have the ability to rapidly alternate between ESI and APCI modes such at the Water's LCT Premier. Agilent's LC/MSD ToF system simultaneously ionizes using ESI and APCI. JEOL recently pioneered Direct Analysis in Real Time (DART)

Simpson DC, Smith RD (2005) Electrophoresis 26, 1291-1305.

Combining Capillary Electrophoresis with Mass Spectrometry for Applications in Proteomics

REVIEW. In capillary electrophoresis (CE), the techniques with the greatest potential are capillary zone electrophoresis (CZE) and capillary isoelectric focusing (CIEF). In interfacing to MS, the predominant is by ESI, although MALDI has been used too. The CE-separated interface usually requires supplemental fluid, if only to make it compatible with ESI since background electrolyte (BGE) for CZE may not be ideal. However, when no supplemental fluid is required, sensitivity is clearly higher. A problem occurs with differences in BGE and supplemental fluid, coupled with low EOF (typical for peptide and protein separations) in which moving ionic boundary complicates separation process. The first attempts did not use supplemental fluid, but now most do with a design of the sheath flow made by Smith et al (1988). Lee et al introduced a liquid junction interface. When ESI current is greater than CZE current there is optimum sensitivity: this is achieved by using as narrow possible capillaries in the CE phase. Early uses of CE with no sheathing used capillaries tapered by 40% HF etching and then silvered to convert CE terminus to ESI emitter; SF6 is used to suppress corona discharge. This achieved resolution of tryptic digests of cytochrome c of bovine, equine, and Candida krusei type with capillary of 10 µm i.d. and 150 µm o.d. In another design, the capillary tip is ground and the tip coated with gold to make an electrical connection, which was tested using protein standards and shown to have 100 h lifetime on the ESI emitter. While greater narrowing of the tip improve ESI performance, a back pressure builds up that results in mixing.

Monti M, Orrú S, Pagnozzi D, Pucci P (2006) Biosci. Rep. 25, 45-56.

Interaction Proteomics

REVIEW. Genome sequencing projects are leading to the prediction of coded sequences (proteins) for which if they exist have unknown function. Much protein identification is done using classical approaches such as 1D/2DGE-MALDI-TOF-MS and/or 2DLC-ESI-MS/MS. Functional approaches use a bait-prey approach. Alternatives to two-hybrid system including cloning the protein with a tags both large and small (GST as large; FLAG, hemaglutanin (HA), c-myc, poly-His-tail, or biotinylated). Tagged bait then immobilized to agarose beads derivatized with the anti-tag ligand (glutathione, anti-epitope Abs, nickel ions, streptavidin, etc). Entire cellular extract or extracts of specific organelles (when appropriate) ae incubated with immobilized bait. After washing away unbound material, interacting proteins are elutded, fractionated on SDS-PAGE, stained and examined by MS for protein ID. This was used for ZnF224, and 82 kDa Zn finger belong to Krüppel-like Zn-finger proteins family (KRAB), one of largest classes of transcription factors. Protein has 45-aa box A of Krüppel-associated box (KRAB) domain at N-terminus, an evolutionarily conserved doman, and 19 Cys2His2 Zn-finger motifs at C-terminus. The protein binds to AldA-NRE negative regulatory element, found in human aldolase A gene promoter; it inhibits transcription throuhg the binding to the element DNA by the 45-aa KRAB-A domain with Zn fingers. It is presumed that interacting proteins would inhibit or regulate the activity of ZnF224. Full-length cDNA of ZnF224 and a deletion mutant ZnF224-M1 (only 8 Zn fingers) were fused to GST C-terminus and purified on glutathione-Sepharose. this bait is then linked to GSH-activated beads. Nuclear 293 cell extracts are incubated with GST-beads which retains proteins nonspecifically interacting with GST-beads and matrix. This pre-incubated extract is then incubated with GST-ZnF224 immobilized bait. Several washes are done, the beads eluted, then run on SDS-PAGE followed by colloidal Coomassie staining. Samples of extracts purified once and twice with GST-bait as well as samples preincubated with GST only and also the unbound protein fraction were analyzed on gel. A problem occurs when both the sample and controls identical bands. Since total cellular extracts are used, this creates non-physiological interactions of proteins normally segregated in different organelles. Another problem is that bait-prey interactions occur in vitro, so there is always a possibility that interactions are not physiological.

Using another fishing strategy, randomized oligonucleotides immobilized on a support can be used to bind to any protein to the NRE of aldolase gene promoter, eventually identified as ZnF224. To confirm the specificity recombinant wild-type ZnF224 and deletion mutants were prepared and incubated with AldANRE in band shift experiments, where the wt caused shifting and deletion mutants did not. A CAT reporter was set up in a plasmid using ZNF224 with tow AldA-NRE upstream and the expression of ZNF224 caused negative modulation of the CAT reporter in dose-dependent manner.

Immunoprecipitation. To answer questions involving fishing strategies, the gene for the bait is modified to include epitope tags to commonly available antibodies (FLAG, HA, c-myc, etc) then transfected into cognate host cell. As protein complexes form naturally within the cell (not in vitro), cell extracts are produced and immunoprecipitated with anti-tag antibodies bound to solid phase. These are then run on SDS-PAGE followed by protein ID by MS. This strategy was used

Shen H, Cheng G, Fan H, Zhang J, Zhang X, Lu H, Liu C, Sun F, Jin H, Xu X, Xu G, Wang S, Fang C, Bao H, Wang Y, Wang J, Zhong H, Yu Z, Liu Y, Tang Z, Yang P (2006) Proteomics 6, 528-537.

Expressed Proteome Analysis of Human Hepatocellular Carcinoma in Nude Mice (LCI-D20) with High Metastasis Potential

ABSTRACT. We report for the first time an expressed proteome for human hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in nude mice model. Most cases of human liver cancer are HCC with highly metastatic ability. Therefore, the early prediction or diagnosis and effective treatment are the key points of research. We have previously successfully established a human HCC nude mice model (LCI-D20) with high metastasis potential. To understand better the tumor biology of HCC it is worth to explore the relativity of all expressed protein profiles in the LCI-D20 HCC nude mice model. With advanced proteomics technologies, we have carried out a proteomic analysis with following stages: protein sample preparation of cancer tissue, including total cellular extraction and sequential fractionation, 2-DE and 2-D LC separation, ESI/MALDI-MS/MS identification, as well as data-dependent bioinformatics. The identified proteins were classified bioinformatically respective to their function, biological process and intracellular localization. Some important proteins found in HCC, e.g. metabolism enzymes, proteins regulating cell motility, signaling proteins, and heat shock proteins, are discussed in terms of their metastasis.

Saha RP, Bahadur RP, Chakrabarti P (2006) J Proteome Res. 4, 1600-1609.

Interresidue contacts in proteins and protein-protein interfaces and their use in characterizing the homodimeric interface

ABSTRACT. The environment of amino acid residues in protein tertiary structures and three types of interfaces formed by protein-protein association--in complexes, homodimers, and crystal lattices of monomeric proteins--has been analyzed in terms of the propensity values of the 20 amino acid residues to be in contact with a given residue. On the basis of the similarity of the environment, twenty residues can be divided into nine classes, which may correspond to a set of reduced amino acid alphabet. There is no appreciable change in the environment in going from the tertiary structure to the interface, those participating in the crystal contacts showing the maximum deviation.
