Contacts between identical residues are very prominent in homodimers and crystal dimers and arise due to 2-fold related association of residues lining the axis of rotation. These two types of interfaces, representing specific and nonspecific associations, are characterized by the types of residues that partake in "self-contacts"--most notably Leu in the former and Glu in the latter. The relative preference of residues to be involved in "self-contacts" can be used to develop a scoring function to identify homodimeric proteins from crystal structures. Thirty-four percent of such residues are fully conserved among homologous proteins in the homodimer dataset, as opposed to only 20% in crystal dimers. Results point to Leu being the stickiest of all amino acid residues, hence its widespread use in motifs, such as leucine zippers.

Sun W, Gao S, Wang L, Chen Y, Wu S, Wang X, Zheng D, Gao Y (2005) Molec. Cell Proteomics XX, xxxx-xxxx.

Microwave-Assisted Protein Preparation and Enzymatic Digestion in Proteomics

BSA was digested with trypsin using different protocols. The standard protocol involves 10 mM DTT reduction at 57° for 1 h, alkylation with 55 mM iodoacetamide for 30 min, then 16 h digestion with 0.5 µM trypsin in 25 mM ammonium bicarbonate. Variations on the use and timing of these steps were tried, including MAPED, or microwave-assisted protein enzymatic digestion. In MAPED, a container with 1.0 L water is placed beside sample vials to act as a sink for most of the microwave radiation of an 850 W device. The oven is turned on for 1 minute.

When the spectra of the standard and MAPED protocols are taken, they are nearly identical, indicating that 1 min of microwave energy can substitute 16 hours of digestion time! Attempts to remove or eliminate use of the Cys-modifying protocols were tried: elimination of iodoacetamide alkylation, and decreasing the DTT reduction time to 5 min but in boiled water while also not doing alkylation gave similar spectra to the standard and the MAPED with DTT/iodoacetamide with 60/30 min treatments. 1DLC-ESI-MS/MS showed that the count of MS/MS spectra were similar for the 4 samples injected at 100 fmol. A sample that completely eliminated DTT reduction however showed significant reduction in MS/MS spectra.

To ensure that this was not limited to BSA as the specific protein treated, a human urinary protein mixture was tested. Proteins were run on a 1D tricine gel and visualized before and after standard and MAPED digestion treatment. Under MAPED, most proteins above 14 kDa disappeared and some new bands appeared below 14 kDa. Some proteins had not fully digested, being at 31 kDa or so. In 2DLC-ESI-MS/MS the count of proteins identified using ≥ 2 MS/MS spectra were 153 for the standard protocol, and 139 for MAPED, with 2333 and 2541 MS/MS spectra for standard and MAPED treatments respectively. Thus the MS/MS spectra were lower for MAPED by 8.5%, but this was not significant. Similar results with respect to protein identification were see with 1D tricine gel or 2DLC-ESI-MS/MS. As the gel showed a difference in efficiency between MAPED and standard protocol for some proteins, other variables were tried: prolonging reduction from 5 to 30 min, increasing digestion from 1 to 15 min, digesting with Lys-C then trypsin, but there was no improvement. Hence MAPED probably obtained the same digestion efficiency.

With proteins in solution, MAPED works, but what about in-gel? BSA was run on SDS-PAGE and then subjected to digestion in-gel using standard protocol for 19.5 h digestion time and MAPED for 25 min. Extracted peptides were then run on 1DLC-ESI-MS. Previously it was reported that only 50% of peptides could be recovered. Identified MS/MS spectrum number from 300 fmol BSA by 1DLC-ESI-MS should be about 20; in this study the standard protocol generated about 11 spectra (55%), similar to a previous report. With MAPED, about 14 spectra (70%) were recovered.

A yeast lysate was then run, which shows a good 5 thick bands which can be cut and prepared in-gel. Proteins with more than three MS/MS spectra that were identified are shown in the table. For bands 1-3 (higher MW), the number of identfied proteins was the same for standard vs. MAPED, but higher for MAPED with proteins of lower MW.

Cortese MS, Baird JP, Uversky VN, Dunker AK (2006) J Proteome Res. 4, 1610-1618.

Uncovering the unfoldome: enriching cell extracts for unstructured proteins by acid treatment

ABSTRACT. A method to enrich cell extracts in totally unfolded proteins was investigated. A literature search revealed that 14 of 29 proteins isolated by their failure to precipitate during perchloric acid (PCA) or trichloroacetic acid (TCA) treatment where also shown experimentally to be totally disordered. A near 100 000-fold reduction in yield was observed after 5% or 9% PCA treatment of total soluble E. coli protein. Despite this huge reduction, 158 and 142 spots were observed from the 5% and the 9% treated samples, respectively, on silver-stained 2-D SDS-PAGE gels loaded with 10 microg of protein. Treatment with 1% PCA was less selective with more visible spots and a greater than 3-fold higher yield. A substantial yield of unprecipitated protein was obtained after 3% TCA treatment, suggesting that the common use of TCA precipitation prior to 2-D gel analysis may result in loss of unstructured protein due to their failure to precipitate. Our preliminary analysis suggests that treating total protein extracts with 3-5% PCA and determining the identities of soluble proteins could be the starting point for uncovering unfoldomes (the complement of unstructured proteins in a given proteome). The 100 000-fold reduction in yield and concomitant reduction in number of proteins achieved by 5% PCA treatment produced a fraction suitable for analysis in its entirety using standard proteomic techniques. In this way, large numbers of totally unstructured proteins could be identified with minimal effort.

Torres MP, Thapar R, Marzluff WF, Borchers CH (2006) J Proteome Res. 4, 1628-1635.

Phosphatase-directed phosphorylation-site determination: a synthesis of methods for the detection and identification of phosphopeptides

ABSTRACT. Phosphopeptides can be difficult to detect and sequence by mass spectrometry (MS) due to low ionization efficiency and suppression effects in the MS mode, and insufficient fragmentation in the tandem MS (MS/MS) mode, respectively. To address this problem, we have developed a technique called Phosphatase-directed Phosphorylation-site Determination (PPD), which combines on-target phosphatase reactions, MALDI MS/MS of IMAC beads on target, and hypothesis-driven MS (HD-MS). In this method, on-target dephosphorylation experiments are conducted on IMAC-bound phosphopeptides, because dephosphorylated peptides have, in general, higher MS sensitivities than the corresponding phosphopeptides. The detected dephosphorylated peptides are sequenced by MS/MS, which identifies the potentially phosphorylated peptide and the total number of Ser, Thr, or Tyr residues that could hypothetically be phosphorylated within that peptide. On the basis of this information, a mass list containing every possible phosphorylation state of each observed peptide (where 1 HPO(3) = 80 Da) is used to direct MALDI-MS/MS on the phosphorylated peptides bound to IMAC beads at each theoretical mass from the list. If the peptide is present, the resulting MS/MS spectrum reveals the exact site(s) of phosphorylation in the peptide. We have demonstrated the applicability of PPD to the detection of in vivo phosphorylation sites on the Drosophila Stem Loop Binding Protein (dSLBP), and the complementarity of this new technique to conventional MS phosphorylation site mapping methods, since the phosphorylation sites in dSLBP could not be detected by other methods.

Horn A, Kreusch S, Bublitz R, Hoppe H, Cumme GA, Schulze M, Moore T, Ditze G, Rhode H (2005) Proteomics 5, 0000-0000.

Multidimensional Proteomics of Human Serum Using Parallel Chromatography of Native Constituents and Microplate Technology

ABSTRACT. A versatile, multidimensional, and non-denaturing proteome separation procedure using microplate technology is presented, yielding a digitized image of proteome composition. In the first dimension, the sample under study is separated into 96 fractions by size exclusion chromatography (SEC). In the second dimension, the fractions of the first dimension are transferred by the liquid-handling device CyBi-Well (CyBio AG, Jena, Germany) to 96 parallel anion exchange chromatography columns. In this way the proteins are conserved in their native states and are distributed in 2400 liquid fractions with high recovery rates and sufficient reproducibility. The resulting fractions are subjected to protein quantitation and identification. Spectrophotometrical and immunological methods and enzyme activity measurements are used for quantitation. To identify proteins, the fractions are subjected to MALDI-MS, and their tryptic digests to both MALDI- and LC-ESI-MS/MS. All preparation steps except the first are applied in parallel to sets of multiples of 96 samples. The procedure may be refined by adding more separation steps and may be adapted to various protein amounts and to various proteomes. Moreover, the method offers the opportunity to investigate functional protein complexes. The method was applied to separate the normal human serum proteome. Within 255 fractions exhibiting the highest protein concentrations, 742 proteins were identified by LC-ESI-MS/MS peptide sequence tags.

Johnson RS, Davis MT, Taylor JA, Patterson SD (2005) Methods 35, 223-236.

Informatics for Protein Identification by Mass Spectrometry

ABSTRACT. High throughput protein analysis (i.e., proteomics) Wrst became possible when sensitive peptide mass mapping techniques were developed, thereby allowing for the possibility of identifying and cataloging most 2D gel electrophoresis spots. Shortly thereafter a few groups pioneered the idea of identifying proteins by using peptide tandem mass spectra to search protein sequence databases. Hence, it became possible to identify proteins from very complex mixtures. One drawback to these latter techniques is that it is not entirely straightforward to make matches using tandem mass spectra of peptides that are modiWed or have sequences that diVer slightly from what is present in the sequence database that is being searched. This has been part of the motivation behind automated de novo sequencing programs that attempt to derive a peptide sequence regardless of its presence in a sequence database. The sequence candidates thus generated are then subjected to homology-based database search programs (e.g., BLAST or FASTA). These homology search programs, however, were not developed with mass spectrometry in mind, and it became necessary to make minor modiWcations such that mass spectrometric ambiguities can be taken into account when comparing query and database sequences. Finally, this review will discuss the important issue of validating protein identiWcations. All of the search programs will produce a top ranked answer; however, only the credulous are willing to accept them carte blanche.

Delahunty C, Yates JR 3rd (2005) Methods 35, 248-255.

Protein Identification Using 2D-LC-MS/MS

ABSTRACT. Multidimensional liquid chromatography techniques have been coupled to tandem mass spectrometry to provide a robust method to identify proteins in complex mixtures. Data acquisition is interfaced directly with search algorithms for identiWcation through cross-correlation with databases. This review describes the most recent advances in methodologies for protein identiWcation by mass spectrometry and describes the limitations of the application of the technologies.

America AHP, Cordewener JHG, van Geffen MHA, Lommen A, Vissers JPC, Bino RJ, Hall RD (2005) Proteomics 5, 0000-0000.

Alignment and Statistical Difference Analysis of Complex Peptide Data Sets Generated by Multidimensional LC-MS

ABSTRACT. A method for high-resolution proteomics analyses of complex protein mixtures is presented using multidimensional HPLC coupled to MS (MDLC-MS). The method was applied to identify proteins that are differentially expressed during fruit ripening of tomato. Protein extracts from red and green tomato fruits were digested by trypsin. The resulting highly complex peptide mixtures were separated by strong cation exchange chromatography (SCX), and subsequently analyzed by RP nano-LC coupled to quadrupole-TOF MS. For detailed quantitative comparison, triplicate RP-LC-MS runs were performed for each SCX fraction. The resulting data sets were analyzed using MetAlign software for noise and data reduction, multiple alignment and statistical variance analysis. For each RP-LC-MS chromatogram, up to 7000 mass components were detected. Peak intensity data were compared by multivariate and statistical analysis. This revealed a clear separation between the green and red tomato samples, and a clear separation of the different SCX fractions. MS/MS spectra were collected using the data-dependent acquisition mode from a selected set of differentially detected peptide masses, enabling the identification of proteins that were differentially expressed during ripening of tomato fruits. Our approach is a highly sensitive method to analyze proteins in complex mixtures without the need of isotope labeling.

Nielsen J, Oliver S (2005) Trends Biotechnol. 23, 544-546.

The Next Wave in Metabolome Analysis

ABSTRACT. The metabolome of a cell represents the amplification and integration of signals from other functional genomic levels, such as the transcriptome and the proteome. Although this makes metabolomics a useful tool for the high-throughput analysis of phenotypes, the lack of a direct connection to the genome makes it difficult to interpret metabolomic data. Nevertheless, functional genomics has produced examples of the use of metabolomics to elucidate the phenotypes of otherwise silent mutations. Despite several successes, we believe that future metabolomic studies must focus on the accurate measurement of the concentrations of unambiguously identified metabolites. The research community must develop databases of metabolite concentrations in cells that are grown in several welldefined conditions if metabolomic data are to be integrated meaningfully with data from the other levels of functional-genomic analysis and to make a significant contribution to systems biology.

FD

Barlow CK, McFadyen WD, O'Hair RAJ (2005) J. Am. Chem. Soc. 127, 6109-6115.

Formation of Cationic Peptide Radicals by Gas-Phase Redox Reactions with Trivalent Chromium, Manganese, Iron, and Cobalt Complexes

The formation of cationic radical ions of peptides in the gas phase involves the following scheme: (i) neutral peptide P is introduced into gas phase coordinated to metal ion M with bound auxiliary ligand L; (ii) CID leads to homolytic bond cleavage, with reduction of the metal and oxidation of peptide to produce cationic peptide radical P+•; (iii) peptide radical can be isolated and subjected to CID to probe its chemistry/structure. For example, [CuII(dien)-YGGFLR]2+ will produce the YGGFLR+*• radical. Since Cu(II) is an oxidant in peptides and amino acids, it was thought that trivalent transition metals might be better complexes of peptides from which to probe by CID. Experiments were done on Finnigan MAT model LCQ Q-IT MS. 100 µl of 1 mg/ml peptide is mixed with 100 µl of 1 mg/ml metal complex in final 1 ml in MeOH. The ligand is salen (N,N'-Ethylenebis(salicylimine), MW 263.8), so a [M(salen)(P)]+ complex results.

The [CrIII(salen)YGGFLR]+ CID spectrum is show and it shows many small molecule losses from the peptide. Peaks at 18, 35, and 60 Th less than the parent mass indicate H2O, H2O + NH3, and H2O + NH=C=NH, respectively. The NH=C=NH originates from the R side chain. Also in the spectrum is the peptide-free metal-ligand complex [CrIII(salen)]+ with the peptide appearing as a cationic radical, P+•, although it low abundance. With salen derivatives as ligand there is only minor differences in CID spectra. [CrIII(salenNO2)(P)]+ produced enough P+• so that it could be further fragmented. CID of [CrIII(salenOMe)(P)]+ does not yield radical cation but just liberates the neutral peptide.

With [MnIII(salen)(P)]+ complex the bound peptide no longer shows a 60 amu (H2O+NH=C=NH) loss. The complex [MnIII(salenX)(P)]+ dissociates to [MnIII(salen)]+ and both neutral peptide P and radical cation P+•. An two hydrogen atom loss species [MnIII(P-2H)]+ ion complex is seen, indicating neutral ligand salenH2X is lost with two protons. The nature of the loss is controlled more by X than by the peptide. [MnIII(salenNO2)YGGFLR]+ produces only P+• and some additional fragment ions. [MnIII(salenCl)(P)]+ is similar but [MnIII(salenCl)]+ and [MnIII(P-2H)]+ are in low abundance. Compeition between forming neutral peptide P and cationi radical P+• in salenX is governed by X electron-withdrawing capacity (NO2 > Cl > H > OMe) which favors radical cation formation over that of the neutral peptide. The nature of the peptide structure P also a factor: thus GGGFLR favors loss of the neutral peptide while YGGFLR and WGGFLR are

With FeIII complexes, the dominant product is P+• and its subfragmentation ions From the peptide YGGFLR p-quinomethide and from WGGFLR 3-methyleneindolenine are lost, something also noted with CuII complexes. Fe(III) appears to make the peptide more prone to fragmentation than Mn(III) through homolytic cleavage than heterolytic bond cleavage for any particular ligand or peptide. Unlike for Mn(III), [FeIII(P-2H)]+ is not present at all. There is loss of water and of 60 amu (H2O + NH=C=NH). The peptide radical is more likely to undergo subfragmentation when the ligand X is electron-withdrawing.

Co(III) complexes of peptide provide a different kind of reaction, and the sequence of the peptide is more significant for the peptides used here. More radical cations are generated for [CoIII(salenX)YGGFLR]+ with additional subfragmentation. The radical also loses 44 and 45 amu which are not seen with other metal complexes. These correspond to CO2 and •CO2H. CID of [CoIII(salenX)GGGFLR]+ do not produce GGGFLR+• in spectra except as the extensively subfragmented evidence of it to produce [M-CO2]+• and [M-•CO2H]+.

In summary Mn and Fe are better than Cr and Co at producing cationic peptide radicals although all metals produce it to some degree. Dissociation of the complex in Cr leads to neutral and radical peptide, with subfragmentation dominating. This indicates that the barrier to dissociation from Cr may be higher and puts the complex in a higher energetic state necessary to achieve dissociation, but with more fragmentation.

Lange E, Gröpl C, Reinert K, Kohlbacher O, Hildebrandt A (2005) Pac Sym Proceed    

High-Accuracy Peak Picking of Proteomics Data Using Wavelet Techniques

The algorithm proposed here starts by dividing the mass range into 10 Da boxes, but not in a way that a division occurs along a peak. The wavelet transform in each box is then computed. From the maximum position in the wavelet transform every peak centroid, height and area can be estimated. With these parameters the raw data peaks using an asymmetric sech2 and asymmetric Lorentzian function. Improvement of fit quality comes from correlating the resulting peaks with the experimental data can be increased in an optional optimization step. This can be important if neighboring peaks overlap so strongly that they cannot be fit well individually, and if resolution of the experimental data is low.

The algorithm works as follows:

for all mass spectra s in experiment do box_list = splitSpectrum(s) for all boxes b in box_list do peak_list = [ ] wb = continuousWaveletTransformation(b) while getNextMaximumPosition(wb, b, x0) do (xl,xr) = searchForPeakEndpoints(b, x0) c = estimateCentroid(xl,xr) h = intensity(x0) (Al, Ar) = integrateAreas(xl,xr) f = fitPeakShape(Al,Ar,x0,h) push(f,peak_list) removeRawDataPeak(xl,xr,b) wb = continuousWaveletTransformation(b) end while optimizePeakParameters(peak_list, b) end for end for

In decomposing the spectrum, division of the mass spectrum into boxes at point x if and only if intensity y is smaller than a given noise threshold, or a minimum is searched using a moving average method. When no minimum is inside a certain search radius x does belong to a peak of sensible width, and so the division is made at x.

Continuous wavelet transform Ws(b) of a signal s at position b is defined as:

Wψ sa(b) = (1/√a) ∫−∞∞ s(x)ψ[(x−b)/a] dx

with wavelet ψ and the dilation parameter a. The Marr wavelet is chosen for ψ:

ψ(x) = (1 − x2) exp (x2 / 2) = d2/dx2 exp(−x2/ 2)

because for symmetric peaks the maximum position in the CWT coincides with the maximum position in the data and is a good first estimate even for asymmetric peaks. In peak picking the scale of the wavelet (and its width) should correspond to the typical width of peaks. ψ can only be described by a few data points on this scale, and the convolution of wavelet and signal can be computed efficiently with pre-tabulated values of ψ.

In searching for peak endpoints there is a difficulty with effects of noise or the overlapping of peaks occurs. Peak intensity will not drop below a threshold when the next peak's area of influence is reached. From the maximum, the algorithm moves both left and right until either a minimum is reached or the intensity falls below a pre-defined noise threshold.

le Guezennec X, Brinkman AB, Vermeulen M, Denissov SG, Gazziola C, Lohrum ME, Stunnenberg HG (2005) BJU Int. 96 (Suppl 2), 16-22.

Targeted Discovery Tools: Proteomics and Chromatin Immunoprecipitation-On-Chip

ABSTRACT. Despite the availability of several completely sequenced genomes, we are still, for the most part, ignorant about how genes interact and regulate each other within a given cell type to specify identity, function and cellular memory. A realistic model of cellular regulation based on current knowledge indicates that many interacting networks operate at the epigenetic, transcriptional, translational and post-translational levels, with feedback between the various levels. Proteinprotein and proteinDNA interactions help to define which genes may be activated in a particular cell, and determine whether external cues cause activation or repression. New technologies, e.g. proteomics using mass spectrometry, high-density DNA or oligonucleotide microarrays (chips), and chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP), provide new and exciting tools for deciphering the pathways and proteins controlling gene expression. Analysis of these pathways offers new insight that aids targeted drug development.

Fandiño, Rais I, Vollmer M, Elgass H, Schägger H, Karas M (2005) J. Mass Spectrom. 40, 1223-1231.

LC-Nanospray-MS/MS Analysis of Hydrophobic Proteins from Membrane Proteins from Membrane Protein Complexes Isolated by Blue-Native Electrophoresis

ABSTRACT. The application of two-dimensional electrophoresis for the identification of hydrophobic membrane proteins is principally hampered by precipitation of many of these proteins during first-dimension, isoelectric focusing. Therefore new strategies towards the identification and characterization ofmembrane proteins are being developed. In this work we present a direct and rapid approach from blue-native gels to mass spectrometry, which allows the analyses of complete complexes and prevents protein aggregation of hydrophobic regions during electrophoresis. We combine blue-native gel electrophoresis and liquid chromatographynanospray-iontrap tandem mass spectrometry to analyze the composition of oxidative phosphorylation complexes I, III, IV and V from bovine-heart mitochondria as a model system containing a number of highly hydrophobic proteins. Bands from blue-native gels were subjected either to in-gel or to in-solution tryptic digestion. The obtained peptide mixtures were further analyzed by liquid chromatographytandem mass spectrometry and the corresponding proteins were identified by database search. From a total of 86 proteins, 67 protein subunits could be identified including all highly hydrophobic components, except the ND4L and ND6 subunits of complex I. We demonstrate that liquid chromatographytandem mass spectrometry combined to blue-native electrophoresis is a straightforward tool for proteomic analysis of multiprotein complexes, and especially for the identification of very hydrophobic membrane protein constituents that are not accessible by common isoelectric focusing/sodium dodecyl sulphate gel electrophoresis.

Feldmann RE Jr, Bieback K, Maurer MH, Kalenka A, Bürgers HF, Gross J, Hunzinger C, Klüter, Kuschinsky W, Eichler H (2005) Electrophoresis 26, 2749-2758.

Stem Cell Proteomes: A Profile of Human Mesenchymal Stem Cells Derived From Umbilical Cord Blood

ABSTRACT. Multipotent mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) derived from human umbilical cord blood (UCB) represent promising candidates for the development of future strategies in cellular therapy. To create a comprehensive protein expression profile for UCB-MSCs, one UCB unit from a full-term delivery was isolated from the unborn placenta, transferred into culture, and their whole-cell protein fraction was subjected to two-dimensional electrophoresis (2-DE). Unambiguous protein identification was achieved with peptide mass fingerprinting matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF-MS), peptide sequencing (MALDI LIFT-TOF/TOF MS), as well as gel-matching with previously identified databases. In overall five replicate 2-DE runs, a total of 2037 6 437 protein spots were detected of which 205 were identified representing 145 different proteins and 60 isoforms or post-translational modifications. The identified proteins could be grouped into several functional categories, such as metabolism, folding, cytoskeleton, transcription, signal transduction, protein degradation, detoxification, vesicle/protein transport, cell cycle regulation, apoptosis, and calcium homeostasis. The acquired proteome map of nondifferentiated UCB-MSCs is a useful inventory which facilitates the identification of the normal proteomic pattern as well as its changes due to activated or suppressed pathways of cytosolic signal transduction which occur during proliferation, differentiation, or other experimental conditions.

Wheelock AM, Buckpitt AR (2005) Electrophoresis 26, 4508-4520.

Software-Induced Variance in Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis Image Analysis

ABSTRACT. Experimental variability in 2-DE is well documented, but little attention has been paid to variability arising from postexperimental quantitative analyses using various 2-DE software packages. The performance of two 2-DE analysis software programs, Phoretix 2D Expression v2004 (Expression) and PDQuest 7.2 (PDQuest), was evaluated in this study. All available background subtraction and smoothing algorithms were tested using both data generated from one single 2-DE gel image, thus excluding experimental variance, and with authentic sets of replicate gels (n = 5). A slight shift of the image boundaries (the cropping area) caused both programs to induce variance in protein spot quantification of otherwise identical gel images. The resulting variance for PDQuest (CVmean = 8%) was approximately twice that for Expression (CVmean = 4%). In authentic sets of replicate 2-DE gels (n = 5), the experimental variance confounded the software-induced variance to some extent. However, Expression still outperformed PDQuest, which exhibited software-induced variance as high as 25% of the total observed variance. Surprisingly, the complete omission of background subtraction algorithms resulted in the least amount of software-based variance. These data indicate that 2-DE gel analysis software constitutes a significant source of the variance observed in quantitative proteomics, and that the use of background subtraction algorithms can further increase the variance.

Proteins used were the pooled lysis-lavage of the airway epithelium of male rats. Five 2D gels were run on sampling of the pool on IPG 4-7 and 6-9 strips. A Multiphor II was used for IEF using EPS 3501 XL power supply. 500 µg protein is mixed in 350 µl of rehydration buffer (7 M urea, 2 M thiourea, 0.5% TX-100, 4% CHAPS, 2% Calbiochem inhibitor mix, 65 mM DTT, 1% IPG buffer for the strip with orange G tracking dye, using 18 cm 4-7 strips. Electrophoresis program: 0-50 V in 1 min, 50 V 1 h, 50 to 1000 V in 3 h, 1000 to 3500 V in 3 h, and 3500 V for 19 h, giving 75 kV-h total. Second dimension was on 10% Duracryl gels using Hoefer ISO-DALT at 10° with 14 mA per gel until dye front reached edge in about 18 h. Fixation was in 20% EtOH/7% acetic acid for > 1 h. Basic range 18 cm IPG pH 6-9 strips were rehydrated in special DeStreak buffer with 2% protease inhibitor and 1% IPG buffer for pH 6-11 range with 700 µg protein spiked with DeStreak and diluted to 350 µl with lysis buffer without the IPG buffer. Samples are loaded using a paper bridge method with 5.5 cm paper wick on anodic end with IEF performed using program 0 to 1000 V in 2.5 h, 1000 to 3500 V in 2.5 h, then 21 h at high voltage for total 80 kVh. Rhinohide-type acrylamide gels were run on the 2nd dimension. Staining is with SYPRO Ruby; after destaining and soaking water in dark, gels were scanned with Typhoon (Molecular Dynamics); fluorescence material is always wiped with isopropanol to remove background on glass platen; gels are scanned 600 PMT with 200 µm pixel size. File format is GEL which is variant of 16-bit TIFF, with square root rather than linear data storage and better at preserving the 100,000-fold dynamic range of Typhoon, Storm, and FluorImager systems.

A single 2D image file of the pH 4-7 range is cropped once (Imagequant) then copied five times without modification. These should be identical image data files. Another image of the basic pH range gel was produced with 5 copies. Spot detection and matching are done as described below. In addition, a single gel image is produced with 5 copies, then each copy cropped; cropped copies are similar but not identical. This is done because it represents better an authentic replicate set in which cropping area differs between gels. Finally, in another set, five 2D gels are produced from a single sample, representhing an authentic experiment.

For all the image experiments described above, analysis was by Phoretix Expression v2004 and by PDQuest 7.2. The procedure of Marengo et al for PDQuest was used with all available background subtraction and filtering algorithms used. Automatic spot detection was first done with careful manual editing to eliminate spots matched incorrectly. Delete/add/auto-split/ and auto-merge of spots were the only semi-automatic editing tools used to minimize subjectivity. The Expression software allows detecting and matching of spots without background subtraction; 3 subtraction algorithms are available: "mode of non-spot", "lowest on boundary", "average on boundary" after spot matching and editing. PDQuest always uses background subtraction with a floating ball algorithm and applying five different smoothing filters (median, weighted mean, power mean, contra mean, and adaptive) as well as a no-smoothing option. The background subtract is kept at 21-27 for all gels and for spot detection, sensitivity=10, size=3, min peak=700, and the speckle and streak filters are applied. Spot volumes are exported to Excel with computation of average, SD, and CV for each spot and normality of CV distributions tested by normality plots and Shapiro Wilks W test. CV distributions are reported as median, interquartile range, and range.

Both PDQuest and Expression reported 0.0% median, IQR, and range for gel images that are 5 copies of the same cropped image for all matched spots. Depending on the smoothing filter, matched spots ranged in count from 742 (power mean) to 938 (contra mean), with 921 spots with no smoothing. The count of matched spots was 1312 spots for all modes of background subtraction on Expression. Since all gel images were identical, spot count in PDQuest thus depended upon the use of a particular smoothing filter.

Valmu L, Kalkkinen N, Husa A, Rye PD (2005) Biochemistry 44, 16007-16013

Differential Susceptibility of Transferrin Glycoforms to Chymotrypsin: A Proteomics Approach to the Detection of Carbohydrate-Deficient Transferrin

Human recombinant TRF was altered to change glycosylation sites Asn-413 and -611 to Asp residues and expressed in BHK cells and purified to homogeneity (verified by ESI-MS, anion exchange chromatography, and urea gels). Immunoreactivity and spectroscopy for Fe-binding presence also show TRF. rhTRF-NG (nonglycosylating) was treated with chymotrypsin and peptides seen on MALDI. Sequencing on LC-MS/MS was done, reporting some missed cleavages of the protease. Repetive digestion confirmed the missed cleavage pattern; MALDI coverage was 40.8%. TRF exists as a bilobar globular protein and sites on the C-terminal half were preferentially cleaved while N-side cleavage was on the linking sequence and N-terminus.

C8 RP column separation of peptides of glycan and non-glycan recombinant digested 2 h show differences in patterns. 1 pmol of TRF-NG and TRF was digested with 30 min chymotrypsin and separated on 0.75 µm × 150 mm C18. A > 10-fold difference is seen in the TRF-NG to TRF sample, with the glycans protecting the TRF against digestion. The differnces in digestion were found in both an HPLC (detection OD214) and in MALDI. The laser energy setting on the MALDI was higher for TRF compared to TRF-NG peptides, probably because a lower yield of peptides was obtained from digestion. Some low intensity peaks were detected for TRF-NG, one at m/z 1690.472, probably the [M+H]+ ion of the 413-427 peptide (this contains the Asn→Asp413) substitution. A peak at m/z 1464.239 would be the [M+H]+ ion corresponding to 609-622 peptide and have the 611 substitution; this was missing in the TRF sample. Signal-to-noise for these peptides with altered Asn sites were 3-5 (mean 3.87) and 4-6 (mean 5.15), respectively.

LC-MS/MS of 10 lower intensity peaks was done. Sequencing was difficult for the 609-622 peptide since its ionization efficiency was a problem (using chymotrypsin rather than trypsin to obtain certain positive ions). The 413-427 produced good MS/MS spectra; its parent ion at m/z 845.86 [M+2H]2+ gave good MS/MS with 32 eV collision energy (and it contained a Lys residue) and good b product ions. A sequence of SDNCEDTPEAG is readable with a C-terminal flanking dipeptide of YF, and an N-terminal dipeptide of DK is seen. N-terminal sequencing of the peptide revealed DKSDN, as additional evidence.

Krokhin OV, Ens W, Standing KG (2005) J. Biomolec. Tech. 16, 427-438.

MALDI QqTOF MS Combined with Off-Line HPLC for Characterization of Protein Primary Structure and Post-Translational Modifications

PRG03 is a lyophilized sample said to contain 5 pmol unknown protein with two phosphorylated peptides at substoichiometric levels, and included a contaminant. It was suspended in 50 µl 0.2% formic acid. 0.5 µl was mixed 1:1 with 150 mg/ml DHB matrix in 50% MeCN and deposited on MALDI target. 5 µl (containing 500 fmol) was used for LC-MALDI. PRG04 is a sample with 3 closely related proteins with 3 pmol each, with possible contaminants; it was dissolved in 0.1 M ammonium bicarbonate, and one-sixth of it was reduced 10 min in 30 mM DTT (57°) and then alkylate 30 min in dark at room temp in 50 mM iodoacetamide, then dialyzed against 100 mM AmBicarb for 6 h in 7kDa MWCO tubing from Pierce. This was digested in sequencing grade Promega trypsin 1:50 for 12 h 37°. After drying, material was resuspended in 5.5 µl of 0.5% TFA. 0.5 µl was used for MALDI and the balance of 5 µl was run on micro-LC fractionation followed by MALDI MS or MS/MS. Three isoforms of carbonic anhydrase were identified as components of the unknown sample, but intensities were extremlely low; as a control commercial bovine carbonic anhydrase isoform I was prepared in 0.5% TFA to contain 3 pmol, and then processed as PRG03 and PRG04 above.

Chromatography was in two configurations: a micro-Agilent 1100 was setup for PRG03 and PRG04 analysis, with 5 µl injection on to 150 µm × 15 cm Vydac 218 TP C18 5µm and eluted with gradient of 1-80% MeCN containing 0.1% TFA over 60 min at 4 µl/min. OD214 was monitored with 500 nl flow cell. 65 µm PEEK and 50 µm fused silica was used for pre- and post-column connections, respectively. To column effluent a Microtee P775 (Upchurch) was connected with flow of DHB at 0.5 µl/min. This was deposited at 1 min intervals on movable gold targets. Most peptides elute inside 40 min

Uetz P, Yu-An D, Zeretzke C, Atzler C, Baiker A, Berger B, Rajagopala SV, Roupelieva M, Rose D, Fossum E, Haas J (2006) Science 311, 239-232.

Herpesviral Protein Networks and Their Interaction with the Human Proteome

ABSTRACT. The comprehensive yeast two-hybrid analysis of intraviral protein interactions in two members of the herpesvirus family, Kaposi sarcomaassociated herpesvirus (KSHV) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV), revealed 123 and 173 interactions, respectively. Viral protein interaction networks resemble single, highly coupled modules, whereas cellular networks are organized in separate functional submodules. Predicted and experimentally verified interactions between KSHV and human proteins were used to connect the viral interactome into a prototypical human interactome and to simulate infection. The analysis of the combined system showed that the viral network adopts cellular network features and that protein networks of herpesviruses and possibly other intracellular pathogens have distinguishing topologies.

Ulintz PJ, Zhu J, Qin ZS, Andrews PC (2005) Molec. Cell. Proteomics xxx, yyyy-zzzz

Improved Classification of Mass Spectrometry Database Search Results Using Newer Machine Learning Approaches

Better methods for checking/confirming correctness of db search results are required. SEQUEST scores of 2+/- tryptic peptides set an XCorr > 2.2 and δCn of at least 0.1. There is not wide agreement. The X!Tandem algorithm incorporates the hypergeometric distribution of Sadygov and Yates on the frequency of fragment ion matches from a peptide sequence database while the Poisson distribution has been put forward by Geer et al. Additional algorithms take as input the MASCOT or SEQUEST search results and classify them as correct or incorrect. These include PeptideProphet and QScore. PeptideProphet assesses validity of MS db search results using supervised and unsupervised learning to improve sensitivity than methods using scoring thresholds. This paper attempts to show the latest machine learning methods for classification, including tree-based ensemble methods such as boosting and random forest.

One popular method for peptide identification is PeptideProphet mixture model approach. A discriminant score function F(x1,x2,...xS) = c0 + c1x1 + ... cSxS is defined for xi search scores having ci weights. A Gaussian distribution is modeled to the discriminant scores corresponding to correct peptide assignment, and gamma distribution is used to model asymmetric discriminant scores belong to wrong peptide assigments. The scores are represented by p(x) = rf1(x) + (1 − r)f2(x) where f1(x) and f2(x) represent density functions of two types of discriminant scores and r is the proportion of correct identifications. With each new test dataset the EM algorithm will estimate the probability that the peptide identified is correct.

Choice of discriminant score function F is crucial. The weight ci values are derived so as to maximize between- vs. within-class variation under the multivariate normal assumption of the training data. This means training data and test data are generated from same source. When new discriminant score sets are generated and should be classified one must retrain the ci weight values using new corresponding training set. Because of several variables (instrumentation, protocol, database, searching software) it is not unusual to see different results. As to modeling distributions, there is no valid reason to prefer normal or gamma distributions for the two types of discriminant scores. Indeed gamma distribution may be better at modeling positive and negative scores of the Mascot algorithm.

Determining correct and incorrect peptide assignments is a classification problem, or supervised learning. Methods such as CART, SVM, random forest, boosting and bagging exist. SVM is good for small sample size situations with large feature spaces.

Boosting is a procedure that combines many weak classifiers to find a final powerful classifier. In a two-classification setting, suppose xi is a vector of input variables, which in this case are scores and attributes of an individual MS db search result produced from an algorithm such as SEQUEST, and yi is the output coded as −1 or 1, indicating correct or incorrect assignment. Suppose an algorithm that builds a classifier T(x) using weighted training samples to that when there is new input x, T(x) produces a prediction taking one of two values {−1, 1} and so classifier T(x) is a decision tree. Boosting occurs by starting with equal-weighted training samples and building classifer T1(x). If a training sample is misclassified, an incorrect peptide being assigned to the spectrum, the weight of the sample is increased (boosted). A second classifier T2(x) is built with training samples using new weights but which are not equal. Misclassified samples have their weights boosted again, and the procedure iterates M times. Hundreds or even thousands of classifiers are built this way. The final score is assigned for an input x which is a linear (weighted) combination of classifers, with high score being that the sample is correctly assigned and a low score an incorrect hit.

Random forests is similar to boosting but an ensemble that combines many decision trees. The trees grow differently however in three ways. 1. The method randomly selects with replacement n samples from the original training data instead of assigning different weights to training samples. 2. Instead of considering all input variables at each split of the decision tree, a small group of input variables on which to split are randomly selected. 3. Each tree is grown to the largest extent possible. When classifying a new sample from an input, the input is run down each of the trees in the forest, with each tree giving a classification (vote). The forest chooses the classification having the most votes over all the trees in the forest.

Support vector machine (SVM) is another learning technique. It makes a non-linear classification boundary in the original input space by constructing a linear boundary in a transformed version of the original input space. Dimension of transformed space can be very large and infinit in some cases. The computation is achieved through a positive definite reproducing kernel to give inner product of the transformed space. SVM finds the hyperplane in the transformed space separating two classes by the biggest margin. It has produced less false positives and negatives than other approaches. A weakness is that SVM only estimates the category of classification, whereas the assignment probability p(x) is of interest itself, where p(x) = P(Y=1|X=x) is the posterior probability of sample being in class 1 (correctly identified peptide). Another drawback is that the kernel and cost, tuning parameters, are not easily selected.

An ESI-MS dataset was used in this study. MS/MS spectra from 22 LC-MS/MS runs on a control sample of 18 known proteins mixed in various concentrations was used with a ThermoFinnigan ion trap MS generating the dataset. There were 37,044 spectra obtained for [M+H]+, [M+2H]2+, and [M+3H]3+ parent ions. Each spectrum was searched by SEQUEST on human database. Top-scoring peptide was retained for each spectrum, and top hits againt known 18 proteins labeled as correct. 2757 (7.44%) of peptide assignments were found to be correct.

A MALDI dataset was generated from 300 purified recombinants gel-purified by 1D SDS-PAGE. Band plugs were subjected to in-gel digestion, and serially diluted to generate realistic spectra, peptides cleaned by C18 ZipTip. Digestions were spotted in 4 replicates on MALDI targets and MS/MS spectra with ABi 4700 Proteomics Analyzer obtained. The most abundant ions were selected from each replicate and with previously selected peaks excluded until MS peaks could no longer be detected. Up to 24 MS/MS spectra were obtained for each standard protein. Results from 158 of the protein standards were generated for the dataset. Testing and training datasets were generated by using Agilent Spectrum Mill with trypsin as enzyme and oxidized Met and pyro-Glu as variable modifications searched against NCBInr-human dataset. The NCBInr database was altered to replace entries corresponding to protein standard with annotated entries that include the N-term affinity (T7 or 6xHis) tag, and appending E coli K12 sequences since E coli was the recombinant host. Tolerances of 0.7 Da for precursor and 0.3 Da for fragment ion search were used; minimum matched peak intensity was 40%. 11764 search results were found from 4340 spectra (up to 5 top ranking hits). 1044 were true positives and 111 of these were not top-ranking.

The .out files from SEQUEST and .spo files from SpectrumMill are parsed into simple text row/column format for use in pattern classification algorithms in Python-coded modules. Only the top hit was parsed for each SEQUEST spectrum, and for the MALDI set the top 5 ranking hits. Attributes from SEQUEST assignments include typical parameters of the SEQUEST algorithm: Sp, Sp rank, deltaCn, XCorr and other statistics of the report: total intensity, number of matching peaks, fragment ion ratios. Length is included in the attributes since PeptideProphet uses it when normalizing the XCorr attribute against peptide length. Other attributes include factors related C-term residue (K='1', R='2', others='0'), and count of prolines and arginines. The Mobile Proton Factor (MPF) is calculated to be

(1.0 × R) + (0.8 × K) + (0.5 × H) / charge

MPF is measure of mobility of protons in peptide and theoretical measure of ease of fragmentation in gas phase. Smaller MPF values indicate higher mobility whereas relative nonmobility is indicated when MPF ≥ 1. The RKH refer to counts of residues in the peptide affecting its basicity, and coefficients are reflective of relative basicity normalized to the dissociation constant pKa 12, 10, and 5.9, respectively. The charge is the charge of the parent/precursor to indicate count of free protons available to assist charge-directed fragmentation.

SpectrumMill attributes are based on the search platform SpectrumMill which works from ProteinProspector script sets. It is a non-probabilistic score, independent of database size. Increases in score correlate with peaks matching theoretical fragment ion types with penalty for unmatched peaks. Peak intenstity and peptide length affect score. Scoring system accounts for all fragment ion types and neutral losses, along with internal and immonium ions. Scored Peak Intensity (SPI) is second primary scoring measure reflecting percentage of total peak intensity matching predicted fragment ion masses. The Background Cleavage Score (BCS) is the count of cleavage events that generate b or y ions; the unused ion ration (count of unused ions over count of total ions after peak thresholding) is measure of amount of signal not accounted for in match. The delta parent mass measures the difference between observed and experimental peptide precursor masses.

One training and one testing dataset were constructed for the ESI-SEQUEST and MALDI-SpectrumMill datasets by random selection. For all results the evaluation was done on a test so without overlap on training set. 2/3 of data were used for training, and 1/3 for testing. SEQUEST .out files for each test set are placed in separate diretcory and processed with the out2summary.c script for making the PeptideProphet html input file, which was run with default parameters. The R language packages for boosting and random forest approaches was used.

Kalia A, Gupta RP (2005) Crit. Rev. Biotechnol. 25, 173-198.

Proteomics: A Paradigm Shift

REVIEW. Genomics yields sequence information but we do not know the biology of proteins coded by these sequences to predict many functional aspects of proteins just from the sequence info. In June 2000 the full sequence was presented by Collins and Venter five years ahead of schedule. Inventions and discoveries that helped included Hunkapiller's 1998 creation of a laser beam-decoding instrument, and a shotgun sequencing technique from Venter in 1999. The next new movement is functional genomics, in which we try to making functional sense of the genome sequence. The genome codes for 30,000-50,000 genes making 100,000 different proteins (owing to alternative splicing). There are trillions of cells in the body, with 46 chromosomes present in a 8 µm space in cells. With a 3.15 Gb genomic size, that it about 150 million bases per chromosome. The DNA could be stretched out 2 meters. About half a million proteins undergo posttranslational modifications.

Jones P, Cote RG, Martens L, Quinn A, Taylor CF, Derache W, Hermjakob H, Apweiler R (2006) Nucl. Acids Res. 34, D659-D663.

PRIDE: a public repository of protein and peptide identifications for the proteomics community

ABSTRACT. PRIDE, the PRoteomics IDEntifications database (http://www.ebi.ac.uk/pride) is a database of protein and peptide identifications that have been described in the scientific literature. These identifications will typically be from specific species, tissues and subcellular locations, perhaps under specific disease conditions. Any post-translational modifications that have been identified on individual peptides can be described. These identifications may be annotated with supporting mass spectra. At the time of writing, PRIDE includes the full set of identifications as submitted by individual laboratories participating in the HUPO Plasma Proteome Project and a profile of the human platelet proteome submitted by the University of Ghent in Belgium. Bylate 2005 PRIDE is expected to contain the identifications and spectra generated by the HUPO Brain Proteome Project. Proteomics laboratories are encouraged to submit their identifications and spectra to PRIDE to support their manuscript submissions to proteomics journals. Data can be submitted in PRIDE XML format if identifications are included or mzData format if the submitter is depositing mass spectra without identifications. PRIDE is a web application, so submission, searching and data retrieval can all be performed using an internet browser. PRIDE can be searched by experiment accession number, protein accession number, literature reference and sample parameters including species, tissue, sub-cellular location and disease state. Data can be retrieved as machine-readable PRIDE or mzData XML (the latter for mass spectra without identifications), or as human-readable HTML.

Jones P, Cote RG, Martens L, Quinn A, Taylor CF, Derache W, Hermjakob H, Apweiler R (2006) Nucl. Acids Res. 34, D659-D663.

MitoP2: the mitochondrial proteome database now including mouse data

ABSTRACT. The MitoP2 database (http://www.mitop.de) integrates information on mitochondrial proteins, their molecular functions and associated diseases. The central database features are manually annotated 15 reference proteins localized or functionally associated with mitochondria supplied for yeast, human and mouse. MitoP2 enables (i) the identification of putative orthologous proteins between these species to study evolutionarily conserved functions and path- 20 ways; (ii) the integration of data from systematic genome-wide studies such as proteomics and deletion phenotype screening; (iii) the prediction of novel mitochondrial proteins using data integration and the assignment of evidence scores; and (iv) systematic 25 searches that aim to find the genes that underlie common and rare mitochondrial diseases. The data and analysis files are referenced to data sources in PubMed and other online databases and can be easily downloaded. MitoP2 users can explore the relation- 30 ship between mitochondrial dysfunctions and disease and utilize this information to conduct systems biology approaches on mitochondria.

Asara JM, Zhang X, Zheng B, Christofk HH, Wu N, Cantley LC (2006) J Proteome Res. 5, 155-163.

In-Gel Stable-Isotope Labeling (ISIL): A Strategy for Mass Spectrometry-Based Relative Quantification

ABSTRACT. Most proteomics approaches for relative quantification of protein expression use a combination of stable-isotope labeling and mass spectrometry. Traditionally, researchers have used difference gel electrophoresis (DIGE) from stained 1D and 2D gels for relative quantification. While differences in protein staining intensity can often be visualized, abundant proteins can obscure less abundant proteins, and quantification of post-translational modifications is difficult. A method is presented for quantifying changes in the abundance of a specific protein or changes in specific modifications of a protein using In-gel Stable-Isotope Labeling (ISIL). Proteins extracted from any source (tissue, cell line, immunoprecipitate, etc.), treated under two experimental conditions, are resolved in separate lanes by gel electrophoresis. The regions of interest (visualized by staining) are reacted separately with light versus heavy isotope-labeled reagents, and the gel slices are then mixed and digested with proteases. The resulting peptides are then analyzed by LC-MS to determine relative abundance of light/heavy isotope pairs and analyzed by LC-MS/MS for identification of sequence and modifications. The strategy compares well with other relative quantification strategies, and in silico calculations reveal its effectiveness as a global relative quantification strategy. An advantage of ISIL is that visualization of gel differences can be used as a first quantification step followed by accurate and sensitive protein level stable-isotope labeling and mass spectrometry-based relative quantification.

Ingvarsson J, Lindstedt M, Borrebaeck CA, Wingren C (2006) J Proteome Res. 5, 170-176.

One-step fractionation of complex proteomes enables detection of low abundant analytes using antibody-based microarrays

ABSTRACT. Antibody-based microarray is a novel technology with great promise within high-throughput proteomics. The tremendous complexity of all proteomes will, however, pose major technological challenges, especially when targeting low-abundant analytes that remains to be resolved. In this paper, we have shown that antibody microarrays readily could be used for screening of low-abundant low molecular weight analytes in complex proteomes by optimizing the sample format. Focused antibody microarrays, based on human recombinant single-chain Fv anti-cytokine antibodies on Ni2+-NTA functionalized glass slides or black polymer Maxisorp substrates, and crude cell supernatants from activated dendritic cells, containing low levels of secreted cytokines, was used for evaluation. The proteome was pre-fractionated based on size in a simple one-step procedure using centrifugal filter devices of various molecular weight cutoffs. The results showed that the generation of a nondiluted low molecular weight (LMW) fraction, corresponding to less than 2% of the original protein content, was critical for the successful screening of cytokines in the sub pg/mL range. The reduced complexity of the LMW fraction significantly improved the assay sensitivity, by improving the fluorescent tagging step and/or reducing the nonspecific binding to the substrates.

Thongboonkerd V, Chutipongtanate S, Kanlaya R (2006) J Proteome Res. 5, 183-191.

Systematic evaluation of sample preparation methods for gel-based human urinary proteomics: quantity, quality, and variability.

ABSTRACT. We performed systematic evaluation of 38 protocols to concentrate normal human urinary proteins prior to 2D-PAGE analysis. Recovery yield and pattern of resolved protein spots were compared among different methods and intra-/inter-individual variabilities were examined. Precipitation with 90% ethanol provided the greatest protein recovery yield (92.99%), whereas precipitation with 10% acetic acid had the least protein recovery (1.91%). In most of precipitation protocols, the higher percentage of applied organic compounds provided the greater recovery yield. With a fixed concentration at 75%, the urine precipitated with acetonitrile had the greatest number of protein spots visualized in 2D gel, whereas the acetic-precipitated sample had the smallest number of spots. For the intra-individual variability, the first morning urine had the greatest amount of total protein but provided the smallest number of protein spots visualized. Excessive water drinking, not caffeine ingestion, caused alterations in the urinary proteome profile with newly presenting spots and also proteins with decreased excretion levels. As expected, there was a considerable degree of inter-individual variability. Coefficients of variation for albumin and transferrin expression were greatest by inter-individual variables. Male urine had greater amount of total protein but provided smaller number of protein spots compared to female urine. These data offer a wealth of useful information for designing a high-quality, large-scale human urine proteome project.

Rauch A, Bellew M, Eng J, Fitzgibbon M, Holzman T, Hussey P, Igra M, Maclean B, Lin CW, Detter A, Fang R, Faca V, Gafken P, Zhang H, Whitaker J, States D, Hanash S, Paulovich A, McIntosh MW (2006) J Proteome Res. 5, 112-121.

Computational Proteomics Analysis System (CPAS): an extensible, open-source analytic system for evaluating and publishing proteomic data and high throughput biological experiments

ABSTRACT. The open-source Computational Proteomics Analysis System (CPAS) contains an entire data analysis and management pipeline for Liquid Chromatography Tandem Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) proteomics, including experiment annotation, protein database searching and sequence management, and mining LC-MS/MS peptide and protein identifications. CPAS architecture and features, such as a general experiment annotation component, installation software, and data security management, make it useful for collaborative projects across geographical locations and for proteomics laboratories without substantial computational support.

Nettikadan S, Radke K, Johnson J, Xu J, Lynch M, Mosher C, Henderson E (2006) Molec. Cell Proteomics 19 Feb 2006 xxx-xxx.

Detection and Quantification of Protein Biomarkers from Fewer Than Ten Cells

The substrates are silicon wafers patterned by reactive ion etching (RIE) and diced into 4 mm squares (chips), then ultrasonicated in water and absolute EtOH for cleaning, sputter-coated with 5 nm chromium and 10 nm gold with dual gun ion beam sputterer operating at 4 mA and 7000 eV. Reactive amine surfaces were created on the gold coat by immediate immersion in prolinker B (Proteogen) in chloroform for an hour. Surfaces are washed in chloroform, then acetone, blown dry with nitrogen and stored under nitrogen. Mouse and goat antibodies to PSA are used for capture and detection, respectively. Rat and biotinylated anti-IL-6 are used for capture and detection, respectively. Fluorescence is generated by secondary antibodies (donkey anti-goat Texas Red) and Alexa 594 strepavidin. Alexa 488 rabbit anti-rat IgG is used to tag capture antibodies. Ultramicroarrays are made with a NanoArrayer, a system including microfabricated print cartridges (surface patterning tools, SPTs), having precise motion and environmental control to transfer atto- to femtoliter volumes from reservoir on the SPT on to a surface. Protein is deposited as a 1:1 mix (20% glycerol + 0.2 mg/ml n-octylglucose)

Capture antibodies are deposited in ultramicro domains and immobilized using amine-reactive chemistry. Antigens were captured and detected using sandwich assay and immunoflourescence microscopy. Direct imaging rather than scanning of ultraminiaturized arrays makes data collection rapid and automatic internal control with respect to instrument variability. Mouse anti-PSA and rat anti-IL 6 ultramicroarrays were constructed adjacent to each other, both arrays with a 3 × 6 format and 15 µm pitch and spot size of 5-8 µm dia. Anti-rat IgG was Alexa 488-conjugated and also cross-reacts with mouse IgG. Fluorescent images show that capture antibodies bound only to expected locales.

Detection sensitivity of the anti-PSA ultramicroarray was compared with multiple PSA capture chips. Chips were incubated with serial log dilutions of PSA, with 3 chips per concentration. The net (raw − background) fluorescence and data averaged (at least 15 datasets in the average). Results show detection of PSA by the ultramicroarray at 10 pg/ml from 1 µl, attomole sensitivity shown. LNCaP cells produce PSA constitutively. Ten replicate 2-fold serial dilutions wre done starting from 2000 cells per well and these incubated 24 h. Media from each cell dilution was pooled and stored. Small volume of pooled media is mixed with PBST buffer (1:1)

Taylor AM, Holst O, Thomas-Oates J (2006) Proteomics 6, xxx-xxx.

Mass Spectrometric Profiling of O-linked Glycans Released Directly From Glycoproteins in Gels Using In-Gel Reductive β-Elimination

For this work, 1 mg dry mucin (rich in O-linked glycans) from bovine submaxillary mucin Type I-S was

López-Ferrer D, Ramos-Fernández A, Martínez-Bartolomé S, García-Ruiz P, Vázquez J (2006) Proteomics 6, xxx-xxx.

Quantitative Proteomics Using 16O/18O Labeling and Linear Ion Trap Mass Spectrometry

Standardized protocols for trypsin digestion with heavy oxygen have not really been described. Methods vary from sample prep to pH of digestion to presence of salts and organic solvents. BSA was dissolved in 8 M urea with 25 mM ammonium bicarbonate and 10 mM DTT pH 8 for 60 min at 37°. After reduction, iodoacetamide was added to 50 mM and this incubated at room temp in dark for 45 min. A 4-fold dilution was made before addition of trypsin at 1:25 overnight at 37°. 1% TFA was added and then sample lyophilized. When labeling was done 5 µg BSA 5 µl 20% MeCN, 5 µl 100 mM ammonium acetate pH 6.75, 5 µl 50 mM CaCl2, and 0.2 µg trypsin was added. The mixture is then dried in vacuum centrifuge quickly. To the sample is added 5 µl H216O or H218O (Sigma, 95%) in 20% MeCN, and incubated 37° for 24 h. 1% formic acid is added to stop labeling.

The assumption is that one 18O is incorporated into the COOH of the C-terminal tryptic peptide. The following equation helps to understand the ratio of light to heavy isotope from the first five peaks of an isotopic cluster:

ratio( 16O ) = I0
18O
I4 − M4 I0 + I2 (1 − M2 ) − (1 − M2 ) M2 I0
M0 M0 M0 M0

where I0, I2, and I4 are the relative intensities of the 1st, 3rd, and 5th peaks in the cluster, and M0, M2, and M4 are the theoretical relative intensities determined from the relative abundance of the natural isotopes of C, O, H, N, and S.

BSA was treated in trypsin and examined by MALDI-ToF. Without use of calcium salts and organic solvents, complete incorporation of at least one 18O was seen in some peptides. Adding calcium improved the labeling efficiency. With the addition of an organic component (MeCN or DMSO), a complete incorporation of at least one 18O was seen. Lowering the pH to 6.75 did not help. Problems with the use of DMSO included its artifactual reactions with amine groups and N-termini and its lower degree of purity and difficulty in removal, so MeCN was preferred in the final reaction.

The use of mildly acidic conditions through sample processing did not cause back-exchange of 18O to 16O. Quenching the sample with formic acid and storage in 18O-water at −20°. It was not possible to incorporate two 18O atoms as achieved by other researchers. There is some information specific to the use of ion trap mass spectrometers, settings for resolution.

Extracts from the nuclear proteome of stem cells were labeled during digestion and the labeled sample analysis online by HPLC-LIT MS, and the selected peptide MS/MS. SEQUEST was used to search fragment spectra databases. Most peptides showed incorporation of > 95%. Completely unlabeled peptides had not C-terminal basic residue and represented those not digested by trypsin.

Labeled and unlabeled samples were mixed in different proportions to examine the linearity of the method. A plot of percent 18O labeling vs. percent labeled sample revealed a high degree of correlation (r 2 = 0.9958).

High resolution scanning modes of ion trap MS are not used in quantitative proteomics, so the robustness was tested in large-scale peptide analysis. Two MSC cell cultures were prepared and nuclear extracts and protein concentrations adjusted. 10 µg each of the nuclear extracts were trypsinized, desalted, dried and then subject to labeling either with or without heavy isotope with trypsin present in the optimized protocol. An RP-HPLC method with 5 hour gradient was used rather than a multidimensional setup with SCX column. 8000 high-res scans were done with the ion trap spending much time in MS/MS mode, identifying 390 peptides with a false discovery rate (FDR) lower than 5%, and 308 peptides with FDR < 1%. 227 and 183 peptides were unique, respectively. Most identified proteins were related to DNA/RNA replication, binding, and transcriptional regulation. For proteins identified with FDR <5%, 221 had good ZoomScan spectra to allow quantitation (196 with FDR < 1%), with 135 unique proteins (120 with FDR < 1%). This method could find quantitative differences of 0.5 or 2-fold at a 95% confidence level.

Xue Y, Li A, Wang L, Feng H, Yao X (2006) BMC Bioinformatics 7, 163 (11 pages)

PPSP: Prediction of PK-Specific Phosphorylation Site with Bayesian Decision Theory

Protein phosphorylation one of most common posttranslational modifications, playing crucial role in many biological processes: transcription, translation, mitosis/cell cycle, neurite outgrowth, cell signalling. Protein kinases (PKs) target specific sites having a consensus sequence flanking with canonical motif. Consensus motifs for 30 PKs have been reported. But a consensus motif is sufficient but not necessary condition for phosphorylation in vivo. Many hypotheses have suggested that specificity is conferred by co-complexes of PK with substrates, subcellular co-localization, interaction with modular docking sites, phosphopeptide-binding mechanisms, and so on. Many PKs are held to a scaffold protein, or to the substrate itself at a docking site distinct from the phosphorylation site

Larsericsdotter H, Jansson Ö Zhukov A, Areskoug D, Oscarsson S, Buijs J (2006) Proteomics 6, 0000-0000.

Optimizing The Surface Plasmon Resonance/Mass Spectrometry Interface for Functional Proteomics Applications: How To Avoid and Utilize Nonspecific Adsorption

The yeast two-hybrid (Y2H) system is a means for mapping protein interaction networks and large scale screening of those interactions. Limitations include the difficulties of revealing multiple component interactions, those not involving proteins and interactions involving post-translational modifications or built from multiple peptide chains. Chip-based technologies have emerged to cover part of the deficit of Y2H. Surface plasmon resonance (SPR)-based biosensors will detect mass changes on a sensor surface when ligand in solution binds to a surface-immobilized receptor, thus showing molecular interaction. The technique typically involves ligand fishing with a receptor of interest. Biacore 3000 is a chip system with that purpose in mind. The bait molecule is immobilized on a sensor surface and potential targets are mixed with it. MS-compatible buffer is used to wash away unbound without disturbing the interaction.

SPR. Polarized light is sent to a prism at an angle causing reflection rather than refraction. The prism is placed at the underside of a sensor chip. Mounted on the fluidic side of the sensor chip are immobilized receptors. Flowing over the receptors on the chip is a buffer solution containing potential receptor ligands. The sensor chip is composed of gold layer that is electrically conducting. The glass of the sensor surface has a high refractive index, while the buffer flowing past as a low refractive index. A detector is set up to monitor the signal of reflected light. When the light strikes the glass, an evanescent wave is generated, corresponding to the electric field vector of the light wave. This wave interacts or is absorbed by the conductive layer of electrons in the gold foil, and this results in electron charge density waves (plasmons) being formed. These plasmons result in a reduction in the intensity of the reflected light. The angle of the incident light where resonance is maximum and at which the reflected intensity is therefore minimum is a function of the refractive index of the solution close to the gold layer on the opposing facee of the sensor surface.

One problem with chip-based affinity separations and microfluidic devices is the high nonspecific adsorption where surface area to volume ratio is quite large. Nonionic detergents are usually used to reduce this effect, but these are MS-incompatible. Salts are usually present because they stabilize target-ligand interaction, but complicate MS analysis.

As a model for this study BSA is used because of its very high nonspecific adsorption to many surfaces. FITC-BSA was dissolved in HBS-N buffer (10 mM HEPES pH 7.4 + 150 mM NaCl) and injected at 1 mg/ml into four flow cells for 5 min @ 10 µl/min into a Sensor Chip CM5 mounted into Biacore 3000. Different wash solutions and MS-compatible buffers were then used.

Walz A, Stühler K, Wattenberg A, Hawranke E, Meyer HE, Schmalz G, Blüggel M, Ruhl S (2006) Proteomics 6, 1631-1639.

Proteome Analysis of Glandular Parotid and Submandibular-Sublingual Saliva in Comparison to Whole Human Saliva by Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis

Two female and two male, all healthy, provided all samples used in the project; protein ID was from one of the females. Saliva samples were kept on ice. Saliva was filter through 5 µm and then through 0.2 µm to remove bacteria. Specific secretions from parotid were obtained by Lashley cups by stimulating tongue with 2% citric acid. The cups were then used to block parotid and cotton wool rolls used to isolate sublingual area; a 50 ml syringe with sterile silicon tube then used to get the SMSL saliva. Amicon Ultra with 5000 Da cutoff were used to desalt and concentrate, providing final 5-25 mg/ml protein. BCA assay was used to assess protein. Samples were stored at −80°.

IEF was on pH 3-10 NL 18 cm strip rehydrated with 300 µg protein in a 350 µl buffer of 7 M urea, 2 M thiourea, 2% CHAPS, 1% DTT, 1% 3-10 ampholytes. PRP-1 was a gift and used as a control (10 µg was dissolved in buffer and run). Strip rehydration was active (30 V overnight), followed by run start at 200 V for 60 min, 500 V and 1000 V over 1 h, then a 30 min sloped rise to 8000 V, holding for 3 h. 2nd dimension was in 12.5% T, 3% C gel (EttanDALT, Amersham), run at 1 W/gel over 16 h at 25°.

2-D gels of whole saliva were run and stained in Coomassie Blue R-250 (fix was 20% TCA for 60 min then staining in 0.1% R-250 in 40% EtOH/10% acetic acid for 2 h). In the middle of the gel at 60 kDa is salivary amylase and there are proline-rich proteins. PRPs are diffuse pink spots in the acidic region (pI 3.2 - 4.9). Other at the 20-37 kDa level appear in the pI 5.3-6.2 region are are PRPs. In the basic region, very near pI 10, a spot at 25 kDa and one at 70-75 kDa appear, staining pink like PRPs. These spots only appear if the saliva is filtered with a 0.2 µm membrane. 192 spots were picked from the gel and digested with trypsin. 131 were identified by MALDI-MS. Cyclophilin B (pI ~9.5/17-18 kDa) was seen, as was prolyl-4-hydroxylase (pI 4-5/65 kDa), acidic PRP, basic PRP, and the proline-rich glycoprotein at pI 10/70-75 kDa. The salivary amylase and PRPs are the major/dominant proteins.

Specific glandular secretions were done. 58 parotid gland spots were analyzed and 43 identified. 63 spots from submandibular-sublingual (SMSL) were analyzed and 53 identified. Most spots were identical. 5 proteins found in parotid not detected in whole saliva: HSPC059 (pI 6-7, 25 kDa), Igα-2 heavy chain (pI 4.5-5, 55-60 kDa), Igκ light chain VLJ region (pI 7.5-8, 25 kDa), lactoperoxidase (pI 7.5-8, 80 kDa), salivary acidic proline-rich phosphoprotein 1/2 precursor (pI 4, 33 kDa). In the SMSL saliva spots were found not seen in the whole saliva: CST1 (pI 6.5-7, 15 kDa), cystatin S (pI 3.5-4, 17-20 kDa), histatin 1 (pI 5-6.5, 10-12 kDa), MUC7 (pI 3, 120 kDa), and 0508206A peptide PA, a PRP (pI 8.5-9, 13-15 kDa). Lower amounts of salivary amylase were in the SMSL secretions; also PRG and basic PRPs were not in the basic pI region.

PRP-1 was purified and run on 2DGE. Two pink spots at a pI ~4.5 and ~22 kDa were revealed. MS and MS/MS spectra indicated salivary acidic proline-rich phosphoprotein 1/2 precursor (PRP-1). These spots were distinguished from those in the whole saliva and specific gland secretions. Additional peptide of 2136 Da was not present in purified PRP-1. MS/MS spectra showed it to be PRP type Db (gene PRH1). This is missing a 21-aa repeat in the PRP-1 precursor. In that MW range, from pI 3.2-6.2 there are spots seen in a horizontal line which are Db protein spots.

In parotid more acidic PRPs are seen of this PRP precursor in the pI 3-4 range. N-terminus of the PRPs is not detectable in MALDI because it is too large (not enough cleavage sites).

Samples from a single patient were collected on three different days to see how the gel pattern might change. The pattern rarely changed for whole saliva, and parotid and SMSL secretions.

Samples from different individuals were then analyzed. There were clear differences both for whole saliva and for particular secretions.

Zhang X, Scalf M, Berggren TW, Westphall MS, Smith LM (2006) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 17, 490-499.

Identification of Mammalian Cell Lines Using MALDI-TOF and LC-ESI-MS/MS Mass Spectrometry

Except for BHK21, all cells are grown in RPMI-1640 + 1% Gln, 1% pen-strep, and 15% FBS. BHK21 cells are grown in DMEM/F-12 with 5% FBS and 60 µg/ml pen-strep. K562 cells from ATCC are a human myelo-monocytic continuous line derived from chronic myelogenous leukemic patient. About 1 million cells are pelleted (1600 rpm/5 min at 5°). the pellet is resuspended in 100 µl 10 mg/ml DHB (after washing twice with it). These are then spotted on MALDI target. Large number of discrete peaks appear in the m/z 1000 to 20,000 range. The same peak pattern is observed no matter what the passage (three successive and 20 discontinuous on K562 cells). Even with changes in protein expression because of growth conditions and nonsynchronized cell growth cycles, a distinct mass spectral signature is constant.

SDS-PAGE was also done, with a BSA band (from culture medium) apparent and several less intense bands in the 30-60 kDa region. High intensity ions were all below 22 kDa. The only peak above 22 kDa with any intensity was the 66 kDa. Ions at higher m/z are not observed because of less efficiency of ionization and lower detection efficiency of the instrument.

DHB may be a better matrix than CHCA or SA as it stabilizes cell membranes and eliminates salt effect. CHCA produced matrix interference in the m/z to 0-10,000 range, less so with SA in the 0-5000 range. Pure DHB was best, but a mix of DHB and SA also was acceptable.

Cells are infiltrated with matrix and then centrifuged. It is possible the treatment causes lysis of cells with loss of protein in the supernatant.

Efrat A, Hoffmann F, Kriegel K, Schultz C, Wenk C (????) no journal    

Geometric Algorithms for the Analysis of 2D-Electrophoresis Gels

Computational geometry techniques can be appled to image analysis with respect to spot detection and gel matching. Algorithms used to implement the CAROL 2-DE analysis software system are explored. With spot detection, problems arise such as interpreting twin spots, streaks, and complex regions representing a union of ellipses. In particular there is the problem of dealing with saturated stains as well.

Wong DT (2006) J. Am. Dental Assoc. 137, 313-321.

Salivary Diagnostics Powered by Nanotechnologies, Proteomics, and Genomics

Saliva as a biofluid with diagnostic and health surveillance potential is about five years away. Saliva contains steroid hormones and HIV antibody which can provide useful information. Efforts are being made to use saliva to test IL-1 genetic allele composition to susceptibility to oral pathogens and lectin staining for oral risk. The anatomy of the salivary gland duct will be important. The gland is surrounded by a vascular-rich set of blood vessels. From the blood and surrounding interstitial space, acinar cells of the gland culdesac actively transport selective compounds into the duct, and there is passive diffusion of lipid soluble compounds, a simple filtration of selected compounds, and the active transport of sodium ion (Na+) also moves water into the duct. As the duct proceeds from the acinar area, the cells are more cuboidal and these duct cells transport the sodium out to make the saliva hypotonic.

OFNASET is the Oral Fluid NanoSensor Test. This is intended to be a handheld automated system that will allow simultaneous multiple salivary biomarker analysis for identified biomarkers. 309 proteins have been found in the human saliva which might be important diagnostically. In addition there is a transcriptome with about 3000 mRNA species, in which 180 commonly occur in the healthy patients. Consider patients with oral cancer. In particular four genes (IL-8, Orn decarboxylase, spermidine acetyltransferase, and IL-1β) could be used to distinguish between cancer and healthy patients, with sensitivity and specificity of 91% (ROC=0.95).

Govorukhina NI, Reijmers TH, Nyangoma SO, van der Zee AGJ, Jansen RC, Bischoff R (2006) J. Chromatog. A xxx, xxx-xxx.

Analysis of Human Serum by Liquid Chromatotgraphy-Mass Spectrometry: Improved Sample Preparation and Data Analysis

LC-MS dataset complexity can approach 100 million data points if the spectral resolution is 0.1 amu in the m/z domain and the run time is about 2 h (7000 data points). Preprocessing algorithms reduce complexity and multivariate statistics reduce dimensionality.

Serum was obtained and stored at −80° for long term, short term at −20°. Serum from a single cervical cancer patient with squamous cell carcinoma antigen-1 (SCCA-1) level of 2.2 ng/ml (by ELISA) was used. 60 µl of serum was diluted with 180 µl of 20 mM pH 7 sodium phosphate and passed through 1 ml Bio-Rad Aurum Serum Protein column

Miller CS, King CP Jr, Langub M, Kryscio RJ, Thomas MV (2006) J. Am. Dental Assoc. 137, 322-329.

Salivary Biomarkers of Existing Periodontal Disease: A Cross-Sectional Study

Saliva is produced by three major pairs of glands and hundreds of minor glands in the mucosal surfaces of the mouth. The secretions contain proteins made both by the duct cells as well as those transported from the blood (other sources/systems).
