Blood, serum, serum products, gingival crevicular fluid (GCF), electrolytes, epithelial and immune cells, microorganisms, bronchial products, are present.

Some markers that are present should be indicators of disease, such as periodontitis. IL-1β is a proinflammatory cytokine that stimulates adhesion molecule expression and which encourages an inflammatory response. Matrix metalloproteinase 8 (MMP-8) is involved in collagen matrix degradation, so that polymorphonuclear leukocytes can gain entry during acute stages of periodontal disease. OPG is a glycoprotein is a decoy receptor which also inhibits osteoclast differentiaton, binding the receptor activator of the NF-κB ligand (RANKL).

Adults (age > 18 y) in good health but with 20 or more erupted teeth were enrolled through advertisements. 12 men and 16 women with existing generalized moderate-to-severe periodontitis were part of the study. Enrollment criteria:

  • At least 30% of peridontal probing caused bleeding
  • At least 20% of probing depths were 4 mm or more
  • At least 5% of periodontal sites had interproximal clinical attachment loss (CAL) greater than 2 mm and radiographic bone loss was seen in posterior vertical bitewing films

Controls were 29 healthy adults of similar age, race, sex with no BOP in less than 10% of periodontal sites, had probing depth of 5 mm or greater in less than 2% of sites, had no probing depth ≥ 6 mm in any site, had CAL of > 2 mm in < 1% of periodontal sites, and had not radiographic bone less in any posterior bitewing view. Patients with histories of alcoholism, liver or kidney dysfunction, inflammatory bowel disease, granulomatous disease or immunosuppression or undergoing organ transplantation or cancer therapy were excluded. Pregnancy, use of antibiotics or immunosuppressants within last 6 months and many other exclusion criteria are detailed in the text.

Saliva were collected from whole sample, unstimulated, by expectoration. Patients first wash with tap water, then spit into sterile tubes. Samples are immediately iced, then aliquoted and stored −80°. Samples are all processed within 6 months.

The three salivary biomarkers described above were then assayed using ELISA or EIA for IL-1β, MMP-8, OPG in duplicate. Kits were from R & D Systems or ALPCO Diagnostics.

Table 1 provides all the patient characteristic data (age range, mean age, sex, race, smokers, drinkers, and the evaulation of the gums with the four parameters (probing depths, CAL, bleeding on probing).

Leptos KC, Sarracino DA, Jaffe JD, Krastins B, Church GM (2006) Proteomics 6, 1770-1782.

MapQuant: Open-Source Software for Large-Scale Protein Quantification

Tryptic peptide samples of BSA, chicken conalbumin, bovine lactoperoxidase, E. coli tryptophanase, human acid glycoprotein, rabbit aldolase, yeast phosphoglucose isomerase were purchased and made up in 5% MeCN + 0.1% formic acid. A ThermoElectron HPLC gradient pump, LCPacking autosampler, and LCQ Deca XP + IT MS (ThermoElectron) were used. A 75 µm capillary was pulled and filled with 15 cm of Magic C18 to 15 cm length (5 µm 200 Å AQ-type). Mobile phase is 0.1% formic acid (solvent A) and 0.1% FA in MeCN (solvent B), using a 5-35% B gradient over 130 min with 85 µl/min flow and 35-95% B rate over 30 min at 125 µl/min. 1, 3.3, 10, 33, 100, 333, and 1000 fmol BSA was used in calibration. Low resolution analysis were done with four scans: 3 scans in a full profile with m/z interval of 0.067 that included one MS/MS scan per MS scan for quantification (q-experiments) purposes, and then one scan in centroid mode with acquisition including five MS/MS scans per MS scan for sequencing (s-experiments) purposes. There were about 3500 MS scans with a single chromatographic run. The high resolution MS runs were done on a hybrid linear IT/FTICR (ThermoElectron LTQ-FT) Signal acquisition for each data point was triplicated and included two MS/MS scans in centroid mode for each MS scan in full profile mode (average m/zinterval = 0.0048). These were used for both quantification and sequencing. A different chromatography (steeper gradient, shorter program) was used, and there were ~1300 MS scans per run.

An application programming interface provided by ThermoElectron was used to extract the LC/MS data into a structure called OpenRaw. The OpenRaw structure holds archives of full scan MS and the higher order CID spectra (MSn), in addition to the usual identifying information about the experiment.

The MapQuant program will find unique organic species and quantify their relative abundance from an LC-MS experiment. Data from the experiment is formatted as a 2-D map which shows a grayscale image. The gray levels represent a 3rd dimension in which intensity data from the scans as a chromatogram is combined with the intensity data of the mass spectrum. The 2-D plot itself has m/z values on the ordinate and the retention time on the abscissa. The separation dimensions are orthogonal as they describe two independent properties of the peptide: mass and hydrophobicity (as a function of retention time on a reversed phase column). MSView, Spectromania, MosaiquesVisu are commercial programs and MSight is a free program to look at large datasets but methods are not sufficiently transparent (open source).

To produce the map, the following steps are taken:

  1. smoothing by convolution
  2. watershed segmentation
  3. peak finding and fitting
  4. peak clustering
  5. peak refinement (i.e., deconvolving by fitting and subtracting) and deisotoping

The algorithms are ANSI C and the CLI (MQParser) was developed with bison. The MapQuant functions can be assembled into scripts readable by MQParser.

An experiment is a data structure with information about a single LC/MS run, with retention times and constituent MS scans, and the instrument m/z sampling resolution. A scan is a sampling unit in the chromatography dimension that points to one mass spectrum, and each scan has a time value. The mass bin is the sampling unit of the instrument when it measures the m/z of the ions. The 2-D map is the matrix with rows and columns coinciding with the intensity values of the mass spectra and the mass chromatograms of the experiment. The segment map is a region in the 2-D map in which a segmentation operation was done; segmentation is done to partition the map into tractable segments. A peak is a local maximum in a 2-D map. A fitted peak (FPeak) is a peak fitted to a particular mathematical model. An isotopic cluster is a cluster of fitted peak representing candidate co-eluting isotopic clusters. A peak group is a cluster of fitted peaks representing candidate co-eluting isotopic clusters. And a peak group map is the minimal 2-D map required to fit the estimated number of isotopic clusters that a peak group might contain.

Data filtering is done, particularly smoothing by convolution since this helps to detect local maxima (peaks). Convolution functions include box-car, Gaussian, and Savitzky-Golay. With the low resolution spectrometer a Gaussian was done on the retention time dimension: the width of the filter has an SD which is the average SD of the peaks. The average peak SD will not change significantly among numerous runs of the same dataset since it is dependent on chromatographic gradient.

The 2-D map is segmented using a watershed segmentation algorithm because it is computationally too expensive to fill all 2-D peaks simultaneously. The algorithm takes the noise-filtered map and produces a 2-D labeled non-grayscale map in the form of a mosaic. The segment is demarcated by a rectangular circumscribed boundary which can be used to cut the segment out of the map. Well-resolved peaks usually get their own segment, while overlapping peaks get grouped into a common segment. A morphological image opening operation is done in the overlapping peaks cases, prior to the segmentation. Confining overlapping peaks into same segment is required during peak fitting since it is more accurate with simultaneous fitting.

Peak detection is done subsequent to segmentation. Local maxima are searched in every segment map, and their positions used as seeds for the peak- (curve-) fitting algorithm. Peak detection makes use of mathematical morphology such as the structuring element. A structuring element is a small binary image N that an image operater (^) takes as input along with the image of interest I, producing a binary image T:

T = I ^ N

Within the structuring element N is a sub-element Ni with a value = 1 if it is to be used in deciding which points neighboring each data point in the map are to be used in the image operation. A data point sk is a local maximum only if the value of tk = 1:

tk = { 1 if { ∑ i Λ(sk, sk Ni } = |N|,
0 otherwise

where Λ(p, q) = 1 if p ≥ q, or 0 otherwise, and |N| = ∑ i. A threshold for abundance is set to avoid detection of maxima representing noise; a threshold is set based on the mean, median, or standard deviation of the 2-D map with and without considering zero values. In this particular study the threshold is set to the median plus two or three average absolute deviations from the median, depending on the spectrometer. Candidate peaks are compiled into a list and fitted as a sum of curves described by a single equation. In a segment map if n candidate peaks, and if each peak is fitted as curve C, the whole segment-map is fitted as ∑ i n Ci. Each peak was fit with a 2-D Gaussian (gaussioid), which is bivariate with respect to retention time (r) and m/z (m), described by:

f(m, r; A, r0, m0, σm, σr) = A  e−(r − r0)2/2σr2 e−(m − m0)2/2σm2
2πσmσr

Five parameters will be fitted for each peak: abundance (A), retention-time centroid (r0), m/z centroid (m0), and the SD of the gaussioid in the retention time (σr) and m/z (σm) dimensions.

Wyatt MF, Stein BK, Brento AG (2006) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 17, 672-675.

Investigation into Accurate Mass Capability of Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry, with Respect to Radical Ion Species

Malmstrom L, Marko-Varga G, Westergren-Thosson G, Laurell T, Malmstrom J (2006) BMC Bioinformatics 7, 158-182.

2DDB - A Bioinformatics Solution for Analysis of Quantitative Proteomics Data

Typically MS/MS data is searched using SEQUEST or MASCOT with the sequence data produced. SwissProt has about 172,000 sequences as of spring 2005 and NCBI has its nonredundant database with 2.3 million unique sequences and includes GenBank, SwissProt, EMBL and DDBJ. For each protein it becomes possible to store its MS spectra and mass and pI. Data management becomes an issue. PEDRo is a data schema for the storage and sharing of proteome data, and intends to integrate many proteomics technologies; developed as data information exchange technology. PRIDE works along the same lines. Accession number use becomes a problem since each database has its own primary key for record access.

2DDB is implemented using Perl 5.8 as an object-oriented library using a CGI script to manage the user interface. It is a relational database although some data exists outside in the filesystem. It runs on Gnu/Linux. Tables in the DB range from experimental meta-data tables with results from statistical and bioinformatical analysis. The amino acid sequence is the core around which the data work. A sequence will have one or more accession numbers (keys) associated with it, usually from the common annotated databases (SwissProt). The sequence is database independent and so can be compared if it is the accession number. The accession number based on sequence allows grouping of related sequences.

In typical PMF using MS work, the sequence coverage of identified/matched peptides is low. Two sequences differing by only one or more amino acids can be identified or not disambiguated. Suppose a composite sequence, which is denoted by a multi-sequence identifier (MID) is created based on a seed sequence, and any sequences similiar (95% identical) to the seed become part of the MID which accounts for all possible peptides. Clearly the MID will group together polymorphisms and sequence fragments. The MID definition is based on sequence identity and not on evalues so it is possible to obtain the data needed to create MIDs in incremental steps, caching previous results in a lookup table, which is updated weekly for a manageable computational cost. The first detected sequence becomes the seed for the MID, with longer sequences preferred when multiple sequence belonging to same MID is imported at once.

Core data model has a few fundamental tables. The Experiment table contains several fields, with the key field id, and fields name, description, aim, conclusion, experiment_type, start_date and finish_date. Essentially there is enough information to describe a sample uniquely as it passes through separation, identification, and a database search. A protein in 2DDB is a connection between an experiment and a protein sequence. Sequences are stored in another table as they can be associated with more than one experiment that identified them.

Additional tables are necessary, as demonstrated. For example, an experiment uses an SCX and RP before spotting on to MALDI plate. Each spot on the plate is represented as a locus in the locus table. Spectra are then acquired and placed in a ms_spectra table, one or more of which may be associated with the locus. Peaks, likely representing peptides, are then selected for fragmentation. A peptide sequence is derived and a protein ID is made (by SEQUEST or MASCOT, as an example). The mzXML format has been specified and its use increases.

The locus can also be more than a spot on a MALDI plate. It can be a gel spot from a 2DE gel. 2DDB allows for the matching of master gels.

2DDB also works with the amino acid sequence and all the analyses involving sequence: secondary structure prediction, transmembrane domain prediction, signal sequence prediction. Functional and structural (secondary and tertiary) annotations with respect to domains and sequences are stored in other tables. The information is both experimental and predicted. Relations between sequences (sequence homologies/similarities, structural and functional similarities) are annotated. Gene Ontology terms are used.

Protein Explorer is a data analysis tool in 2DDB. The user defines a subset of proteins identified from one or more experiments in a protein list. A set of proteins is called a project. The proteins in the list can then be grouped (into GroupSets) in a number of ways: Composite GroupSet containing MIDs, Experiment GroupSet in which proteins were grouped by experiment, Process GroupSet to indicate function (splicing, DNA repair, etc.), Component GroupSet (nuclear vs. non-nuclear), Regulation GroupSet (regulated vs. non-regulated proteins). Groups and group sets reduce data complexity.

Data Normalization and Statistics. 2DGE data accumulates and is full of spot intensities. It then becomes necessary to normalize between intensities of different gels for comparison. Normalization helps to bring out possibilities of differences in expression.

Application. In one study human lung fibroblasts were stimulated with TGF-β1, lyesed, and proteins reduced and labeled with ICAT, then digested. Peptides were separated on LC-MS/MS in five independent experiments. 4731 spectra were obtained and assigned to 1825 unique peptides. From the 1825 peptides, 1568 proteins were identified, and all data imported to 2DDB. Protein count was reduced to 1517 MIDs by sequence alignment and grouping with 95% sequencing identity explaining all peptides.

To obtain 2DDB, see the project homepage which can also be found at Sourceforge. It runs on Linux and requires MySQL 4.0 or higher.

Blonder J, Yu L-R, Radeva G, Chan KC, Lucas DA, Waybright TJ, Issaq HJ, Sharom FJ, Veenstra TD (2006) J. Proteome Res. 6, 349-360.

Combined Chemical and Enzymatic Stable Isotope Labeling for Quantitative Profiling of Detergent-Insoluble Membrane Proteins Isolated Using Triton X-100 and Brij-96

Membrane proteins from mixture of high complexity were tagged with ICAT while proteins and oxygen isotopes as peptides, detergent-resistant membrane microdomains (DRMMs) were obtained from RBL-2H3 cells were dually labeled in this way. DRMMs are obtained from cells lysed in 0.5% w/v Brij96 or 1% w/v TX-100 in a Tris-saline buffer with PMSF, vanadate and other inhibitors present. A short spin to remove intact nuclei and then an ultracentrifugal spin (400,000 g, 4 h) to get membranes (VTi 65.2) using sucrose discontinuous gradients (40, 30, 5%). Collected from top in 0.4 ml fractions for 13 total. Frac 2-7 are pooled (low density) and BCA is done, pelleted at 400,000 g for 1 h, stored −80°. 100 µg membranes from TX-100 are labeled with 12C9-ICAT and light water, and the Brij96 isolatd DRMMs with heavy ICAT (13C9-ICAT and heavy water). Membranes brought to solution in 1.5 ml 25 mM ammonium bicarbonate (pH 7.9) then pelleted 100,000 g 1 h; repeated two more times to remove detergent. The pellet is then solubilized in 200 µl 50 mM ammonium bicarbonate containing 60% MeOH, using vortexing and sonication. TCEP-HCl is added to 1 mM at left 37° 30 min. This is transferred to vials with the ICAT in 20% µl MeCN, left 37° for 2 h. Two exocellulose-packed SEC columns in 60% buffered MeOH are used to remove salts. The ICAT-labeled proteins are digested 1:20 w/w trypsin/protein in same ammonium bicarbonate buffer. After proteolysis heavy ICAT-labeled digest was lyophilized and labeled with H218O using trypsin-catalyzed exchange in 100 µl 80% 25 mM ammonium bicarb and 20% MeOH, with 1:20 trypsin:protein ratio; stopped by boiling 3 min in water, cooling, then added PMSF to 1 mM. Peptides are then analyzed on LC-MS/MS using QIT MS. The mass difference between heavy and light doubly charged pair will be m/z 6.53, labeling of both ICAT and heavy oxygen water. An example is shown for R.C*SSILLHGK.E and the heavy form (R.C*SSILLHGK^.E) of an Na/K-ATPase, and the ratio is 1.

Labeled peptides were then run on nanoflow-RPLCC-LIT-FTICR-MS using SCX to compare TX-100 and Brij96-extracted proteins. 7105 peptides matched to 783 unique proteins. 609 proteins were quantified by the 16O/18O ratio alone and 32 proteins from the dual labeled fratction, and 97 proteins from both. Certain proteins are markers for DRMM (TEC-21, a cell-specific raft marker). Cys-containing proteins make up a small percentage, so relative to just the oxygen-labeled, these should be a smaller proportion. Only 129 proteins were seen by ICAT-heavy oxygen alone. But 32 were seen in the biotin-affinity elution not found in heavy oxygen alone; this is likely because the purity obtained with avidin column eliminates interference by higher abundance peptides with detection of lower abundance peptides. A fragment spectrum of KYNFFCQGTRS orgininating from fatty acid elongase is seen for both TX-100 and Brij96 isolated material, with a heavy-to-light ratio of 0.31. This shows a greater ability of TX-100 to isolate the protein.

25 of 609 proteins identified in the oxygen-labeled fraction have no Cys and would not be identified by ICAT use. A subset were identified strictly from heavy Oxy labeling and the different detergent extractions compared. DAD-1 (defender against cell death) is a 112-residue membrane protein needed for cultured cell survival, containing two Cys residues. With trypsin digestion both C residues are contained in 49-aa peptide with mass 5355 Da, usually outside mass detection range. The protein was quantified instead from 17 shorter tryptic peptides with the heavy Oxy labeled fraction, as opposed to the heavy Oxy/ICAT fraction. The biotin-free heavy Oxy and biotin-labeled heavy Oxy fractions can be compared. Seven proteins were compared in this way, with good correlations in abundance ratios using either detergent to isolate the proteins. In contrast conventional heavy Oxy and ICAT labeling in two separate experiments could have been done, but more starting material and effort (labor) would be required. With simultaneous use of heavy Oxy and ICAT labeling in a single sample there is less time and more efficient quantitative profiling, as collecting the avidin flow through (unbound) heavy Oxy fraction can be utilized, while the dually labeled heavy Oxy-ICAT biotin-tagged allows a look at a smaller complement, with lower abundance proteins seen in the same sample with single prep.

From Table 2 data, RBL-2H3 cells express a high level of Thy-1 (GPI-anchored protein) which interacts with Lyn and forms detergent-insoluble complexes. Both Lyn and Thy1 were quantified by multiple peptides, in which they ranked 22nd and 36th in 738 unique proteins ranked by identified peptides per protein. Examination of heavy Oxy and heavy Oxy-ICAT fractions in the MS/MS spectra show that Lyn was enriched more greatly with Brij-96 extraction, and these were seen in both heavy Oxy, and heavy Oxy-ICAT fractions. Additionally western blotting with anti-Lyn primary against fractions obtained from low density sucrose gradient fractions which were treated separately with TX-100 and Brij-96. Protein abundance ratio deviating from 1 were statistically significant, according the nonlinear least squares regression used to determine differences where ratios were 2 SD above or below mean.

77 proteins showed greater abundance with Brij-96 and 533 proteins were better with TX-100. Hence more DRMMs (63%) are isolated with TX-100 compared to Brij-96. Many of the proteins found in TX-100 are not membrane proteins at all (for example, many ribosomal proteins are quantitated; some cross-contamination with different subcellular fractions is unavoidable). Mean abundance ratio (Brij-96/TX100) for non-DRMM proteins is 0.29, indicating a great capacity of TX-100 to solubilize nonDRMM proteins as well.

Pasini EM, Kirkegaard M, Mortensen P, Lutz HU, Thomas AW, Mann M (2006) Blood 108, 791-801.

In-Depth Analysis of the Membrane and Cytosolic Proteome of Red Blood Cells

RBCs as cells were highly purified and controlled for purity (see Mat. Meth). using automatic counting of WBCs and reticulocytes. There was 1 WBC per million RBCs, no granulocytes, monocytes, or reticulocytes. Improvements in cell enrichment were 1000-fold. Digestion of RBC membranes with enzyme alone resulted in identification of 35 protein. 95 proteins were found with use of EtOH solubilization/precipitation (band 3 hits went from 6 to 36, but spectrin α and β peptide fell from 45 to 11 and from 36 to 12, respectively. Sodium carbonate and EtOH extraction were tried on different levels (one get the membrane-associated and the other the integral proteins). With greater concentrations of carbonate, more loosely associated proteins (e.g., Rab, annexins A11 and A4) are extracted, while integral membrane proteins are unchanged. No difference however between membrane- and GPI-anchored proteins with carbonate extraction. A 100 mM carbonate solution alone will decrease count of identified protein compared to EtOH/carbonate combination, but saturated carbonate reveals more proteins. Removal of the cytoskeleton using a special procedure reduces identificaton of cytosketelon and associate proteins, but also reduces the glycolytic protein hit numbers. Further study shows that with exception of GA3PDHase, the glycolytic enzymes maybe be loosely associated with membrane as the membrane skeleton to ankyrin. This binding is sensitive to band 3 Tyr phosphorylation and oxidation.

Nesvizskii AI, Roos FF, Grossman J, Vogelzang M, Eddes JS, Gruissem W, Baginsky S, Aebersold R (2006) Molec. Cell. Proteomics 5, 652-670.

Dynamic Spectrum Quality Assessment and Iterative Computational Analysis of Shotgun Proteomic Data: Toward More Efficient Identification of Post-Translational Modifications, Sequence Polymorphisms, and Novel Peptides

The scheme of this work is to produce peptides from a complex mixture and get LC-MS/MS spectra. A database search then makes use of SEQUEST, Mascot, X Tandem and so on. Results are statistically validated with PeptideProphet. The probabilities are used to assemble a training dataset of assigned (p > 0.9) and unassigned (p < 0.1) spectra. Then for each MS/MS spectrum numerical descriptors of the spectrum are obtained and statistical classifier developed. Classifier is applied to all unassigned spectra to find those of high quality.

Titulaer MK, Siccama I, Dekker LJ, van Rijswijk ALCT, Heeren RMA, Sillevis Smitt PA, Luider TM (2006) BMC Bioinform. 7, 403 (16 pp).

A Database Application for Pre-Processing, Storage and Comparison of Mass Spectra Derived From Patients and Controls

Comparison of mass spectra from patient and control groups is not reported. Bruker Daltonics makes available a raw MS free induction decay for peptide profiling (http://cabigcvs.nci.nih.gov) in the RProteomics project featuring use of R language. Software described here will provide storage of mass spectra and analysis results. Database holds all metadata.

CSF samples were obtained with each sample run in duplicate, and each replicate spotted 3 times on AnchorChip target plate and measured three times with MS, thus producing 18 replicate spectra for each sample. Some measurements were zero raw fid files and no data; if less replicates are used, then data quality can be affected; 7 or more spectra should be obtained for robust statistical comparison.

Titulaer MK, Siccama I, Dekker LJ, van Rijswijk ALCT, Heeren RMA, Sillevis Smitt PA, Luider TM (2006) BMC Bioinform. 7, 403 (16 pp).

A Database Application for Pre-Processing, Storage and Comparison of Mass Spectra Derived From Patients and Controls

Wong RL, Amster IJ (2006) J. Am. Soc. Mass Spectrom. 17, 1681-1691.

Sub Part-Per-Million Mass Accuracy by Using Stepwise-External Calibration in Fourier Transform Ion Cyclotron Resonance Mass Spectrometry

FT-ICR MS was developed by Comisarow and Marshall and provides the highest mass accuracy over a broad m/z range, as well as the highest mass resolution. Even peptide elemental composition possible. Typical accuracy is in the 1-10 ppm range, although sub-ppm precision is possible too. External calibration is more difficult because of a space-charge effect caused by the count of trapped ions, which results in frequency shifting. Ion counts fluctuation in LC-MS can vary by 2-3 orders of magnitude. Ultrahigh accuracy is obtainable with internal calibrant use, but ion counts need to be kept low to avoid data scattering. However some sensitivity is lost. Some have included ion intensity in the calibration equation:

( m )i = A + B + C + Ii
z fi fi2 fi2

Here fi is the measured cycltron frequency for a calibrant, Ii is the ion intensity, and A, B, and C are regression fitting parameters where A accounts for the magnetic field effect, B accounts for global space-charge effect, and C is for the local space-charge effect. The local space-charge effect is a frequency shift induced by ions of the same m/z wheras the global effect is everything but the local. The modified equation improves internal mass accuracy by 1.5-6.7-fold, depending on mass range and ion excitation radius.

Yanes O, Nazabal A, Wenzel R, Zenobi R, Aviles FX (2006) J. Proteome Res. 5, 2711-2719.

Detection of Noncovalent Complexes in Biological Samples by Intensity Fading and High-Mass Detection of MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometry

Human carboxypeptidase A (CPA) was tested with three inhbitors: potato carboxypeptidase inhibitor (PCI), leech carboxypeptidase inhibitor (LCI), and tick carboxypeptidase inhibitor (TCI). These were added to extracts of leech Hirudo medicinalis. Spectra are shown with CPA and inhbitors mixed 1:1 in the unrefined mixtures. The fading of intensities is clearly demonstrated with PCI at m/z 4298 (600 fmol/µl) LCI at m/z 7395 Da (900 fmol/µl), and TCI at m/z 7935 Da (600 fmol/µl). As CPA is added in increasing amounts, PCI clearly fades, with the signal disappearing almost completely at 1:1. No other protein signals fade at all. Free CPA itself in the high mass range could not be detected.

Khan A, Packer NH (2006) J. Proteome Res. 5, 2824-2838.

Simple Urinary Sample Preparation for Proteomic Analysis

Urine samples were collected from healthy male over 6 week period in the presence of a protease inhibitor (AEBSF, aprotinin, leupeptin, bestatin, pepstatin A, and E-64 used for mammalian tissues, Sigma, 1 µl/ml) and stored −80° in 20 ml aliquots. One 20 ml sample is thawed and spun 1500 g 10 min RT; the supernatant is collected and pellet containing broken cells, tissues and other solid sediments discarded. Precipitation of proteins is done with a 1:5 urine-to-solvent ratio using acetone, EtOH, MeOH, MeCN, 50:50 acetone:EtOH for the solvents; these are left overnight at 4°. Ultrafiltration then acetone precipitation is also done, using 3000 MWCO Amicon series 800. After the overnight precipitation, centrifuging is 4000 g for 40 min at 10°. In a serial precipitation step, proteins are pptd with MeCN at pH 6.2. The supernatant is −20° fro 2.5 h in 100 mM Tris base, increasing pH to 9.4. Pellets are resuspended with 5 mM TBP, alkylated with 10 mM acrylamide, desalted in centrifugal ultrafilter 5000 MWCO. Desalting was required because conductivity was too high. Ultrafiltering also removed TBP, acrylamide, and Tris. Precipitated proteins are rehydrated in 200 µl, and Bradford assay is done. 200 µg protein was loaded on 11 cm IPG strips pH 3-5, 4-7, 6-11 and these focused. 2nd dimenion is 6-15% gradient gels (all gels and strips from Proteome Systems Ltd). ProteomIQ Blue was used for staining. Images were obtained with UMAX PowerLook III flatbed at 300 dpi. Images are uploaded into Progenesis Discovery 2005.

The urine of the healthy subject contained 450-fold by weight more pre-precipitation sediment than precipitated protein (in a 20 ml sample, 90 mg vs. 200 µg, the latter determined by Bradford). Six different solvents were tried and triplicate 2-D gels were run. MeCN-pptd spots produced the highest mean number of spots (567 ± 12 [SD]), followed by EtOH (442) and MeOH (365). 1:1 acetone:ethanol and ultrafiltration/acetone pptn produced less spots (range 233-365). Highest resolution was with MeCN-pptd urine also. Serial/double precipitation with MeCN first at urine pH then at alkaline pH with analysis of pellets produced 707 then 133 spots. The 2nd precipitate did not reveal new spots (based on spot position). These data were from the healthy male subject.

More protein spots were seen with an ovarian cancer patient urine, with 1098 spots in a first ppt and 707 in the alkalinized urine ppt. Some new spots were observed in the 2nd ppt.

The proteome profile was checked with urine collected during different times of the day, and also between days (four days over a 6 week period). Most proteins have a pI 4-7 with fewer in the alkaline. Greater resolution is seen in the medium range strips pH 3-5, 4-7, 6-11, than the broad range. Spot counts of triplicate gels differed significantly: morning: 798; afternoon: 703; evening: 729. More variation was seen with the between-day proteome in the long term: the first 3 urine samples were all morning urine samples while the last 6th week one was an afternoon sample.

MALDI ToF was done with a Shimadzu Kratos Axima CFR using 10 Hz laser firing rate. Internal mass calibration was on tryptic autolytic peptide (m/z 842.51) and ACTH peptide (m/z 2466.2). As a control, mass signals were subtracted from signals of gel plugs taken outside the IPG strip. Spots were excised with Schimadzu Biotech Xcise robotic system. Plugs are washed; digestion is with 5 µg/ml trypsin overnight at 30°. Peptides were desalted and concentrated with C18 ZipTips, then spotted. The db search MS Fit in ProteinProspector and IonIQ PMF (Proteome Systems) is used to search SwissPROT, NCBI, or Owl with 50 ppm tolerance and one missed cleavage, with modifications including Cys, oxidized Methionine, methylated Lysine. In general a minimum of 4 peptides matching were considered, but if modified and unmodified matches were present, a minimum of 3 peptides were considered. If too many missed cleavages were present (more than 50%), the identification was ruled out. Also a match was ruled out if peptide spectral intensities were less than 50% of highest intensity peptide. If more than 33% of the matched peptides were reported as modified, an identifcaiton was ruled out. Identification was acceptable for proteins > 60 kDa if at least 10% sequence coverage was found; between 30-60 kDa, sequence coverage must be at least 20%. Generally if matches involved modified and unmodified peptides, the match was acceptable.

MALDI MS analyses were run on the pH 3-5, 4-7, and 6-11 gels. 395 proteins from 178 genes were identified with several proteins repeatedly identified. 339 proteins (45 in pH 3-5, 272 in pH 4-7, 22 in pH 6-11) from 159 genes (16, 125, 18 in respective pI ranges) were seen in these gels. 37 proteins (for 29 genes) had more than one spot. Of the 339 porteins, 63 (19%) are membrane-associated, 181 (53%) are cytoplasmic or secreted, 11 (3%) are both membrane-associated and cytoplasmic or secreted, and 83 (25%) are not determined for subcellular origin. Further classifications as to renal or plasma origin are made.

Grove H, Hollung K, Uhlen AK, Martens H, Faergestad EM (2006) J. Proteome Res. 5, 3399-3410.

Challenges Related to Analysis of Protein Spot Volume from Two-Dimensional Gel Electrophoresis As Revealed by Replicate Gels

Twenty gels were run and silver-stained in two batches of ten, and 16 were analyzed after removing 4 gels due to problems with distortions and staining. Reference gel for spot matching is from first batch, with mix of two samples from first extraction. Spots are fuzzier in the outer regions of gels, more elongated, or missing compared to those in center. Saturation of some spots caused underestimation of the spot volume. Average spot count for 18 cm pH 4-9/12.5% 2D gel was 720 ± 120. Automated matching without manual editing between sample and reference gives 402 ± 63 pairs, and manual editing produces 460 ± 60 pairs.

770 spots on the reference gel are matching to spots on other 2D gels. For 702 of the 770, these spots are missing in one or more gels before manual editing, and after editing, 645 of 795 spots contained one missing spot. there are 42% missing values total. Thus 150 protein are matched to a spot in all gels. A distribution of the count of protein spots vs the number of missing value per protein spot shows the maximum count of missing values is 15. Four spots were selected at random for analysis. Spot 561 was present in all 16 gels, while spot 25, 485, and 793 were missing in some.

If missing values are the result of biological differences, they should either be present or absent in all gels produced of a sample. None of the highlighted spots showed complete presence or absence of spots, so biological differences could not account. Thus the differences arise from technical errors or limitations.

What caused missing values in the gel images? A partial least square regression (PLSR) analysis was done with information about the images as predictor variables (X). Information included experimental design, total number of spots and spot intensity, spot volume, and spot area. The response (Y) is the count of missing values (MV) on each gel. A correlation-loading plot is drawn of the PLSR analysis. First component accounts for 77% of validated variability, and the 2nd component accounts for 4%. Predictor variables at the right-hand side of the plot that are close the MV component, are those components that would correlate positively with MV, while those on the left-hand are negatively correlated: measured total intensity, volume, area and saliency (a measure of the spot's curvature). These parameters indicate that staining procedure is an important source of missing values, since the lower the perceived level of staining, then the lower the total intenisty, volume and area and the higher number of missing values. A high saliency value reflects a more defined spot and a lower value indicates a spot is more likely to be background or artifact. In addition mean volume percent of matched protein spots for each gel was positively correlated to response (significantly). When gels are faintly stained some of the faintly stained proteins are lost (undetected), and this tends to give a higher mean volume of proteins that are detected and matched. Again staining intensity parameter is reflected here.

We plotted the number of missing values against a sensory evaluation of the amount of staining in 13 gels. Three gels were excluded because of smears and streaking that made evaluation difficult. Even gels with optimal staining contain missing values (the best gel from the plot has 200 missing values). Thus staining alone is not responsible for missing values. Technical variations that relate to staining and the separation of spots create problems for the image analyzer. A very faint spot at the detection limit in four gels was used, two from each sample and two from each batch. Spot presence or absence is highly dependent upon both staining and the system capable of detection. In one image, the failure to find a spot was a combination of the staining and of being able to separate proteins. The main peak (spot 726) has a shoulder detected as a separate protein (spot 955) in two gels of the first batch, but was not detected in either of the samples from the 2nd batch. Another possibility occurs that a poor gel alignment accounts for the missing spot. Global alignment can get most spots but locally there can be a failure; alternatively too flexible an alignment could cause erroneous groups of different isoforms or even different proteins.

Protein was separated into four groups on the basis of missing values they contained. A plot of the frequency of proteins vs their spot volumes (also log transformed) was performed. Examination of the distribution shows that protein variables with many missing values do not have a volume distribution different from those protein variables with few or no missing values. This shows that missing values are not solely found in low abundance values but also in high volume proteins. An F-test shows that portein variables with no missing values had significantly higher protein volumes than those with missing values. This can also be seen in the log transformed plot.

Does the location of missing values in gels. for each spot the distribution of missing values was shown in a gel schematic view. This showed that proteins without any missing values were mostly centered within the gel, while those with higher counts of missing values were on the edges, probably due to alignment problems.

How can a gel be handled with missing values? One option is to leave them out, but this requires knowledge of how they come to be missing. Some statistical tests however cannot be done without complete data sets, while others are weakened if missing values are factored in. Inserting a missing value as zero would skew results if it is missing because of technical error. Use of a background value can help in situations where software fails in identifying a line that separates adjacent spots. Yet another option is to estimate the missing value, something used for DNA microarray experiments. And yet another option is to exclude protein variables that have any missing data, a very harsh treatment that might exclude important analyses. And another option is to circumvent the problem by not using spot detection but to analyze the gel images as spectra after preprocessing and alignment. This looks at each pixel.

Multivariate Data Analysis. Principal component analysis (PCA) can require complete data sets or the removal or estimation of missing values with some implementations. PCA does not require normally distributed data, but transformation to normal data can help interpretation (indeed, standard deviatin of the untransformed variables increased with mean value, but transformation results in a standard deviation becoming independent of mean value). Data transformations of this kind are discussed in Gustaffson et al and Meunier et al. Again interpretations are easier in PCA when data is normally distributed and SD independent of mean. PCA was done on data with different levels of missing values with or without standardization. (gives each variable equal variance when standardization is used). Score and loading plots from PCA are given in the figure; changing the number of missing values has little effect on analysis. Score plots for the first two principal components are given. Loading plots are not changed by reducing the count of missing values in the PCA. In the first component all analyses show separation between samples in first component. If PCA is done without standardization the separation between samples is more distinct for all gel then PCA done with standardized protein variables. With standardization only a few abundant proteins guide the models of the scoring plots; with standardization there was no problem with the model at any rate. With standardization, both low-abundant and abundant protein have identical chance of influencing the first principal components. While this may be good if it puts low abundance at a higher level, it also risks increasing the effect of noisy data. Without standardization, proteins with the largest variability dominate the analysis; in fact proteins with highest spot volumes also show the greatest variation.

Data for some of the experiments was subjected to a shifted log transformation. The score plots show the same result for the analysis as the result where standardized data was used.d

Miller I, Crawford J, Gianazza E (2006) Proteomics 6, 5385-5408.

Protein Stains for Proteomic Applications: Which, When, Why?

REVIEW. Coomassie Brilliant Blue was first used in 1963 and is a sulfonated triphenylmethane. It binds in acid to protein using electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions. The G250 form was first tried in TCA and left in dilute acetic acid where it forms a colloid in 12.5% TCA which has a low background in gel but strong signal with protein. The best preparation is in the presence of phosphoric acid and ammonium sulfate.

Fast Green FCF is a dye that is more suited to staining proteins in an IEF gel since it does not stain ampholytes whereas CBB does (see Gorovsky et al. (1970) and Allen et al. (1980).

Silver stains are generally acidic or alkaline. The latter is produced as a diamine complex of silver nitrate using ammonia and sodium hydroxide. Development is then in a dilute acidic solution of formaldehyde. Acidic methods use silver nitrate in water or weakly acidic solutions with development in HCHO at an alkaline pH. Methods are in four phases: (i) fixation, (ii) sensitization, (iii)impregnation of silver as its nitrate or ammoniac, and (iv) image development in dilute carbonate (acidic staining) or citric acid (alkaline staining). The ammoniacal silver may be better for basic proteins, but staining reproducibility depends on ammonia concentration (storage) and generally works better with a piperzzine diacrylamide crosslinker and thiosulfate polymerized within the gel.

The first fluorescent dye to be used was fluorescamine but its results are variable since it detects free amino groups. 2-Methoxy-2,4-diphenyl-3[2H]furanone (MDPF)is more sensitive and stable and has also been used for 2D gels [see Jackson et al. (1988)]. SYPRO Red and Orange were the first in the noncovalent SYPRO family but are not selective for polypeptides. These dyes excite at 300 nm and at visible wavelengths, detect as little as 1-10 ng and staining is reversible. SYPRO Tangerine will work in nonfixative solutions permitting electroblotting, electroelution and zymography. SYPRO Ruby is a ruthenium metal chelate binding to basic amino acids and in contrast to other dyes, does not intercalate into SDS micelles, binding instead by direct electrostatic interaction by a mechanism similar to Coomassie colloids.

Epicocconone is the reactive component in Deep Purple Total Protein Stain and a nonfluorescent azophilone that becomes fluorescent when interacting with protein. It is quite sensitive and linear over four orders of magnitude, but has a photostability lower than that of SYPRO Ruby and shows an 83% loss of flourescence after 19 min of UV transillumination compared to 44% for SYPRO Ruby. It is thought to work by binding the SDS tail which is bound to protein.

Negative stains are those with colorless or transparent protein bands on a semi-opaque or white gel background. Immersion in copper chloride or (to lesser degree) copper sulfate for 5 min produces reverse staining with sensitivity similar to CBB or silver. This pattern is reversed and less sensitive in nondenaturing gels. Proteins are not fixed—the copper is removed with EDTA—and can be eluted. Other negative stains have been tried with cobalt, nickel, zince and other heavy metals, and zinc chloride has better sensitivity and reaction speed. A zinc imidazole stain exploits the ability of proteins to bind Zn2+ and that of imidazole to react with the unbound Zn2+ to produce the deep white zinc imidazolate, with cleared portions around the protein. The stain is quite reversible, and zinc ion also reacts with several modified groups on proteins as well. These reverse stained gels can be toned to make more permanent staining by a redox reaction with ferricyanide/o-toluidine, the white background now made deep blue and the protein bands still colorless and transparent.

Dowsey AW, English J, Pennington K, Cotter D, Stuehler K, Marcus K, Meyer HE, Dunn MJ, Yang G-Z (2006) Proteomics 6, 5030-5047.

Examination of 2-DE in the Human Proteome Organisation Brain Proteome Project Pilot Studies with the New RAIN Gel Matching Technique

The Human Proteome Organization (HUPO) Brain Proteome Project (BPP) launched two pilot studies to standardize techniques for phenotyping patient and mouse models. Brains of C57/Bl6 mice at three developmental stages (E16, postnatal day 7, postnatal 54-56) were studied for both proteome and transcriptome analysis. 5-10 different samples (no pooling) for each stage. Human brain from autopsy from epilepsy biopsy to compare post-mortem protein stability was done. Samples are are obtained and distributed centrally to participants with no restriction on protocol with respect to 2D on materials or methods nor software analysis. A total 140 2D gels and 266 image were generated. To revalidate all these varied images from varied methods, a subset of these gels were analyzed with a fully automatic gel matching algorith: Robust Advanced Image Normalization (RAIN). It does not require prior spot detection. The sample image is warped directly to the reference image.

2-DE remains the preferred core technology because of relative ease of use and ability to identify changes in PTMs that alter both pI and relative mass. There still remains a problem of co-migrating spots even on large gels and even factors unrelatd to loading of relatively low-abundance proteins results in streaking or tailing. The dynamic range of 2-DE is large in assessing expression although the faintest spots will be hard to distinguish from noise.

Image processing follows a pipeline of (i) noise reduction/background subtraction, (ii) spot detection and modelling and expression quantification, (iii) spot matchning to remove geometric deformation, (iv) identifying differential expression (statistical outliers), (v) creating federated 2-DE databases. With respect to spot matching and detection, a wide variety of approaches are used: iterative closest point, alignment method, geometric hashing, and robust pattern matching. Only robust pattern matching interleave image warping directly. With feature matching, a large number of candidate transforms need to be evaluated due to combinational explosion when each arc (drawn between two points) in the point pattern is mapped onto every arc in the target point set. To reduce the search space, arc reduction techniques such as Delaunay triangulation are regularly used.

Manual matching is done when complex spot matching methods fail. These are pre-pended to compensate for severe geometric distortions. The TT900 S2S GUI does smooth landmark-based image warping with a facility to export warp parameters and images into a proteomics analysis package. This takes 20-30 min per gel pair. It is better to focus on use of the raw pixel values with the features of spot shape, streaks, smears, tails and other background structures normally removed in spot detection. The Z3 algorithm incorporates pixel level information comparing rectangular image regions with each containing a few spots. MIR (Multi-resolution Image Registration) and work by Gustafson et al. use registration techniques without use of spot detection. In these, protein diffusion (geometric and intensity distortion attributed to experimental uncertainty) is eliminated, while intrinsic differences are retained. Source image Is is aligned to reference image Ir constrained by M which is the space of allowable transformations (mappings) on Is guided by similarity measure function sim, a maximal value when images are optimally aligned:

argmaxm∈M sim(Is º mθ, Ir)

Note that (f º g)(x) = f(g(x)). The maximum argument is found by an optimization procedure on parameters Θ of the mapping function m, which transforms each pixel location in the sample to a correspoinding location on the reference image space. M has a tradeoff in finding a transformation with the highest similarity yet ensures it is realistic. In MIR a multi-resolution approach is used in which low-resolution imaes are used to make initial matches with single bilinear mapping, then finer and finer images are analyzed with subdivision of the bilinear mapping to become more deformable. The similarity measure is normalized cross-correlation. Between MIR and Z3, MIR took the same time and scored 29 out of 30 times better with an expert quantifying the number of misregistered spots. Woodward et al have recently used wavelets as an alternate formalism of multi-resolution analysis in which only a sub-band of image frequencies (range of deformations) are kept at each iteration.

Although these algorithms have the highest possibility of fully automated gel matching, it is possible to make further improvements:

  1. accurate protein expression quantification is impossible on warped gels because image-based registration algorithms in current form do not output a smooth warp or ensure spot volumes remain consistent, and thus quantification is only applied to unwarped originals.
  2. intensity inhomogeneities between gels are well know and suppressed with statistical techniques with assumption they follow a Gaussian distribution.

What about the significant variability even between technical replicates with respect to spot volumes? Current software does not correct for expression bias related to pipetting, electrophoresis and staining errors, but relies on extrapolation of the background variabilty of spot areas.

Rabilloud and then Gustafson et al. reported a spatial dependence in protein quantification error over externally Studentized residuals in three representative gel sets known as bias-field modeling. Bias-field information cannot be extracted on individual gels, so analysis is done relative to a second gel. In normalizing spatial trends during between-treatment comparisons, some biological conditions might be concealed. As an example, a higher degree of proteolysis can decrease spot volumes in full-length proteins enlarging in degradation fragments. Still bias-field modeling for image registration is better posed than bias-field modelling for expression quantification.

RAIN objectives. The objective of RAIN is to remove systematic geometric and intensity distortions in the 2-DE process, with direct analysis of gel images. RAIN is an image-based method to register simultaneously and bias-field correct 2-D gel pairs with smoot volume-invariant multi-resolution B-spline transformation. A sum-of-squared-residuals similarity metric and Limited Memory BFGS optimizer are used. It includes processing of expression intensities to normalize out systematic intensity inhomogeneity between gels, in order to ensure accurate post-quantification. Expression can then be accurately quantified using SEA (statistical expression analysis) or conventional techniques.

B-splines were introduced by Schoeberg (1946) being connected piecewise polynominal of order n. A smoothness constraint is imposed on each connection for spline continuity and its n−1 derivatives, and thus a k segment spline is defined by k + n parameters. B-splines were chosen to optimize geometrical transformations for image registration as each coefficient has a locality of effect of n+1 segments or less at the ends. The Oslo algorithm allows the subdivision of the B-spline curve without path alteration to increase the parameters and thus deformability. Modelling geometric deformation and bias-fields requires piecewise surfaces, not segment-wise curves; B-splines are linearly separable so this is a simple extension. Two B-spline surfaces are required to model smooth deformation in the x and y axes.

Imaging warping corrects for optical distortion and not physical distortion in 2DE, introducing protein overexpression in stretching and under-expression in contraction. To preserve invariance of the spot volume the intensity of each warped pixel is weighted by a change in density. This is achieved by considering the Jacobian, a set of partial derivatives of the mapping with respect to the coordinate axes. The derivatives correspond to the change in density along respective axis, and the determinant of the Jacobian is the total change in volume. When intensities of the warped image are normalized by the determinant at each pix, the integrated optical density of each protein spot is constant even after warping. For normalization to be realistically smooth, the B-spline surface must be at least 3rd order, which means partial derivatives are 2nd order and the change in density is thus continuous. With previous techniques 1st order transformations were done (piecewise bilinear mappings and Delaunay triangulation, and are discontinuous at piece boundaries leading to spot distortions for spots lying across boundaries.

The bias-field correction technique of Lai and Fang is suitable for extracting spatial bias from a list of spot matches in 2DGE. But it is feature-based and requires good manual verification of the spot lists. Bias-field correction is integrated in RAIN into the image registration phase by modelling multiplicative and additive bias-fields by separate 3rd order B-spline surfaces. A multiplicative bias-field βU represents a smooth variation in contrast over the image, while the additive bias-field βV provides the same for image brightness:

IU,V(x, y) = (I(x, y) + βV(x, y)) • eβU(x, y)

Additive bias-field and multiplicative bias field each act in turn on

McCulloch CA (2006) Periodontol. 2000 40, 173-183.

Proteomics for the Periodontium: Current Strategies and Future Promise

REVIEW. Periodontal tissues are multicompartmental groups of interacting cells and matrices providing continuous support, attachment, proprioception and protection for the teeth. Currently there is no catalog of the total expression complement of matrix and cellular proteins in any alveolar bone, cementum, gingiva and periodontal ligament.

Urfer W, Grzegorczyk M, Jung K (2006) Pract. Proteomics 1-2 48-55.

Statistics for Proteomics: A Review of Tools for Analyzing Experimental Data

REVIEW. Proteomics experiments belong to two categories. Either it is to study protein expression differences in certain sample groups (distinct disease classes) or it is to study relationship between the proteins themselves. In the first category data is acquired usualy protein expression profiles. Multiple hypothesis testing is done as part of the statistical analysis. Most samples are taken at a fixed time, and so addition of another variable makes the statistics less complicated. As for the second category, it is usually desirable to group proteins with respect to their expression profile; this grouping might be by hiearchical ordered clusters or networks. In the former, proteins with similar expression profile appear in the same cluster. With networks there is also information about directed interactions between proteins. Many methods applied to microarray can also be applied to this aspect of proteomics.

Preprocessing. Because raw data is usually not normally distributed, the lognormal distribution may be a necessary transformation. Usually expression values in the higher quantity will have bigger variances, but after the transformation, variances are quite uniform. Additionally there is the preprocessing of the calibration of expression values from a replicated experiment. This calibration eliminates technical variation so that only biological variation is assessed.

Blackler AR, Klammer AA, MacCoss MJ, Wu CC (2006) Anal. Chem. 78, 1337-1344.

Quantitative Comparison of Proteomic Data Quality Between A 2D and 3D Quadrupole Ion Trap

The 2D quadrupole ion trap (2D-QIT) is a radiofrequency (rf)-based instrument. The multipole-based form is used in hybrid instruments such as FTICR, ToF, and TQ systems, but it is also standalone. The LTQ from ThermoElectron is one system, based on standard 3D-IT (its LCQ instrument). The LCQ has ring electrode with two end caps, but the LTQ has segmented hyperbolic quadrupole with three distinct axial segments. The quadrupole analyzer creates a 2D rf field, and then discrete dc voltages applied to different axial segments to contain the ions axially in the center segment. Slits cut into two of the center rods facilitate radial ion ejection and detection at two electron multiplier detectors. Many scan functions and electronics operate in similar manner to the 3D IT in which resonance excitation is used to isolate the ion, activate it, and then do mass analysis. But unlike the 3D there are performance advantages with the 2D IT:

  1. there is no rf field in ion injection axis for ions to overcome before entering trap, and so trapping efficiency from external ion source is improved and this result in faster ion injection time and contributes to rapid duty cycle;
  2. the linear configuration of mass analyzer results in larger volume (space) to improve total ion capacity before space-charge effects degrade analysis; moreover radial ejection is a design improvement as opposed to axial ejection in the 3D trap. Radial ejection allows for use of two detectors also, resulting in doubling of detection efficiency
  3. the LTQ has an approx 3-fold increase in ion ejection rate relative to the LCQ while having the same resolution: this should improve qualitative identification of peptides by automated µLC-MS/MS.

In a perofmrance comparison, E coli strain OP50 is cultured in LB media in log phase and bacteria pelleted and lysed in French press in a buffer of 50 mM ammonium bicarbonate pH 8.5 at 1000 psi. Lysates are microfuged at 14,000 rpm for 30 min at 4°. After assay, proteins are reduced in 5 mM DTT (30 min, 60°) and then alkylated with 15 mM iodoacetamide (30 min, 25° in dark). Protein is then put in Rapigest and 2 mM CaCl2 and digested with modified trypsin at 1:30 (w/w) overnight in 37° (with shaking). 0.2 M HCl is added and this is incubated 37° for 45 min. Sample microfuged for 4 min and supernatant obtained.

Ramachandran P, Boontheung P, Xie Y, Sondej M, Wong DT, Loo JA (2006) J. Proteome Res. 5, 1493-1503.

Identification of N-Linked Glycoproteins in Human Saliva by Glycoprotein Capture and Mass Spectrometry

REVIEW. Multiple Affinity Removal System is a chromatographic system for removing high abundance human proteins typical in body fluids: albumin, transferrin, haptoglobulin, α-antitrypsin, IgA and IgG. For analyzing glycoproteins, Zhang et al. oxidized the oligosaccharides and coupled them to hydrazide. PNGase F was then used to release the protein part on the column, and the proteins identified by mass spectrometry. CA125 and CA15-3 are cancer biomarkers which have glycosyl modifications, and it is believed that the modification signifies the potential for metastasis. Hydrazide binding can be a way to reduce proteome complexity and enrich for this class of biomarkers. Using enrichment methods, Zhang identified 6 proteins whose expression differed between cancer-containing and normal mice. Liu and coworkers identified more than 300 N-linked glycoproteins in plasma.

Salivary proteome is rich particularly in O- and N-linked glycoproteins such as mucins (Muc5B, Muc7) and Pro-rich glycoproteins. Mucins are O-linked and constituting 70-80% of total protein weight. Lectin probes have shown presence of basic Pro-rich to be O-glycosylated. Salivary amylasse is N-glycosylated.

For this study N-linked glycoproteins were studied. Salivary proteins were treated with PNGase F and O-Glycanase and run on 1D gels and illuminated with Pro-Q Emerald, revealing many N-glycosylated with PNGase F-treated alone and those with both glycanases. Many bands on the 1D gel still appear in the PQ-E stain, indicating that deglycosylation was far from complete. Lower MW bands were scene with a re-staining of SyproRuby, indicating a large amount of deglycosylation nonetheless.

On 2D gels, proteins previously identifed in another report showin PQ-E staining: polymeric immunoglobulin receptor, α-amylase, Prolactin-Inducible Protein, carbonic dehydratase, zinc α-2 glycoprotein.

Deglycosylated proteins reveal and acidic shift with reduced MW (faster migration): The acidic shift is due to formation of Asp from Asn residues as the PNGase F works in this way. Some spots in gels were excised, trypsin-digested and peptides analyzed on LC-MS/MS: identifications were found for transferrin, amylase, PIP, zA2G, and pIg-R precursor. This confirms effect of hydrazide-coupled enrichment.

Other enrichment methods included EtOH precipitation and isolation of proteins by pI. pI-based enrichment improves 2D work allowing sample overloading and MS analysis (the Zoom IEF-fractionator was used here). Once proteins were isolated into zoom disks they were oxidized with periodate in a pH 5.5 coupling buffer, added to glycerol (reacts any unreacted periodate), dialyzed in coupling buffer, passed over hydrazide agarose with column washed to remove unbound proteins, then glycoproteins as hydrazones digested with trypsin. Free peptides are not attached to sugars. PNGase F is then added to columns which removes the peptides bound as hydrazones. All peptides from both fractions are run on LC-MS/MS. during database searching, the sequence N-X-(S/T) was imposed on the search as it is N-linked consensus site, with 1 Da added to reflect the difference between Asn and Asp. Note that washing of the agarose column prior to the first trypsin digestion was modified from the original report.

Desalted peptides are run on the LC-MS/MS. One peptide identified is neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin.

Song J, Patel M, Rosenzweig CN, Chan-Li Y,Sokoll LJ, Fung ET, Choi-Miura N-H, Goggins M, Chan DW, Zhang Z (2006) Clin. Chem. 52, 1045-1053

Quantification of Fragments of Human Serum Inter-α-Trypsin Inhibitor Heavy Chain 4 by a Surface-Enhanced Laser Desorption/Ionization-Based Immunoassay

ITIH4 is acute phase 120 kDa plasma glycoprotein made in liver. The family is multi-chain, but ITIH4 is single chain because C-terminus lacks DPHFII consensus for bikunin assembly via glycosaminoglycan bridges. there is a 120-residue Pro-rich region with species- and tissue-specific domains.

Antibodies to three synthetic peptides (H4NT, H4CT, and H4CT-S) of human ITIH4 fragments were produced by attaching to keyhole limpet hemocyanin and injected to rabbits with a standard 69-day protocol. The antibodies were collected with protein-A and affinity chromatography (Pierce Biotech). In addition polyclonal in rabbit to whole ITIH4 and a mAb (clone 1A4) were prepared. The mAb recognizes an epitope in the 35 kDa C-term fragment.

Hamberg A, Kempka M, Sjdahl J, Roeraade J, Hult K (2006) Anal. Biochem. 357, 167-172.

C-terminal ladder sequencing of peptides using an alternative nucleophile in carboxypeptidase Y digests

Edman chemistry can be used to generate a ladder of peptides whose mass can be determined by mass spectrometry (see Chait et al, 1993). Chemical degradation similar to Edman N-sequencing has been reported by others. For example, alkylation of the C-terminus and its reaction with isothiocyanate have been reported by Boyd et al. (1992) (see also Samyn et al, 2000). Unfortunately, the chemistry requires stops at 3-5 cycles and consumes nanomoles of sample in the process. Mass spectrometry produces alternative ladders by use of CID (with collision gases like argon), ECD, or ETD with the mass spectrometer. Zong et al (Nat Biotechnol, 2004) recently reported ladder sequencing uisng microwave-assisted acdi hydrolysis with MALDI-MS. Use of enzyme-catalyzed C-terminal sequencing is complicated by various rates of hydrolysis, with gaps in the sequence.

CPY has broad substrate specificity with high sequence coverage in ladder sequencing. However Hayashi et al (1975) did studies with dipeptides hydrolyzed by CPY and found that the specificity constant kcat/Km differed by 1000-fold for the variety of substrates. Incomplete ladders are usual. Amines added to the reaction mixture act as competing nucleophiles. In the reaction scheme with peptide WXYZ with Nu as the nucleophile, the nucleophile displaces the C-terminal residue in a transpeptidation step: WXYZ + Nu ↔ WXY-Nu + Z. The next step is the slow hydrolysis of Nu: WXY-Nu + H2O ↔ WXY + Nu. This cycle repeats for each successive C-terminal displacement. Two sets of products actually buildup: one are the normal hydrolysis products (step 2 and the enzymatic) and aminolysis products (step 1). Eleven aminolytic candidates were tested as nucleophilic agent candidates were also tested with an ACTH 7-38 peptide digested with CPY. The largest number of amino acids were obtained using 2-pyridylmethylamine (2-PMA); since the amino group of 2-PMA is closely positioned to the ring nitrogen, this typically reduces the pKa of the amino group, as the negative charge is delocalized in the pyridyl ring. Nevertheless the amino group is a good nucleophile at the lower pH, better than water, and so the n - 1 C-terminal group carbonyl in the peptide bond is acted upon by the amino group. Enzyme binding would be difficult, and so peptides created by aminolysis are resistant to further enzyme action.

Sample mass spectra are collected. Aminolyzed peptides will have a different mass compared to hydrolyzed (the difference between 2-PMA and water is 90 Da). The mass shift plus the mass of glycine is equal to the mass of phenylalanine, and this could cause errors in data interpretation.

FD

Mujezinovic N, Raidl G, Hutchins JRA, Peters J-M, Mechtler K, Eisenhaber F (2006) Proteomics 6, 5117-5131.

Cleaning of raw peptide MS/MS spectra: Improved protein identification following deconvolution of multiply charged peaks, isotope clusters, and removal of background noise

With large datasets from LC-MS/MS work, the b- and y-ions are the ions of interest since they represent fragmentation at the peptide bond. Many peaks are repeated shifted signals resulting from natural isotope distribution. High resolution instruments can distinguish isotope clusters. ESI helps the process in that multiply charged ions of large molecules are brought into measuring range.

In some cases, MS/MS spectra are so bad that selection criteria are used to judge a spectrum as interpretable vs uninterpretable. Clearly no time is wasted with those judged bad. Current methods have found a too high false positive rate on uninterpretability: that is the spectra were actually interpretable when they were judged not interpretable. A problemm is that with many software packages, such as the MASCOT Distiller, which optimizes peak location and intensity, the algorithms used are not published.

Spectra used in this clean-up procedure should be centroided, peak-list transformed. Four independent procedures can be performed on these spectra: (i) detection of multiply charged peaks; (ii) removal of latent periodic noise (including de-isotoping); (iii) removal of high frequency random noise; (iv) detection of un-interpretable spectra.

In evaluating how background peaks can be selected for removal, we can use the analogy of electric signal processing in which a series of peaks in the mass spectrum is a signal compounded with noise after transfer through an information channel, from which the original signal is to be recovered. Example synthetic spectra were created to illustrate the technique. For example isotope clusters as equidistant spacing of peaks are the source of latent periodicity in the signal and would thus show up as maxima in the signal frequency spectrum. Fourier transformation shows this to be true in example MS/MS spectra. The dimishing signal of isotope clusters correlates with signal dampening in the transform.

With noisy spectra there is a large number of low intensity peaks. To MASCOT-interpreted peaks random noise was added artificially. Adding a low-pass filter which removes high frequency part of the signal frequency spectrum removes the artifically added noise. These applications would remove chemical or electronic noise from a spectrum but would not identify b- and y-ions. An algorithm which incorporates knowledge of chemical decay processes would assist in the ion determination process.

MS/MS spectra are also complicated with ions superimposed upon each other which have different charge states. Generally the spectral intensities within the isotope cluster are a function of the natural isotope abundances of carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen, oxygen, and sulfur. Prior to spectrum analysis, the general form (etalon) of isotope cluster patterns is pre-computed for double and triple-charged fragments. While theoretical intensity patterns for larger ions is more complicated, it is computable. Rather than maintain a table, the Wehofsky polynomial approximation in which the relative intensity of the nth isotope variant peak (in a pattern of N ≤ 7 peaks; k = 6) is

I(n, M) = A(n) + ∑(j = 1 to k) Bj(n)Mj

where M is mass corresponding to first, monoisotopic peak in the cluster (n = 1). Its relative intensity is assumed to be 1. A(n) and B(n) are fitting parameters. The distance between peaks in the isotope cluster will be 1/z Da and the pattern length is (N − 1) / z Da. The etalon pattner is complemented, that is, made dense with a total of 20(N − 1) / z − N + 1 additional peaks with a 50 mDa m/z step and each intensity linearly interpolated from two surrounding pattern-defining peaks with masses M + (n − 1) / z and M + n / z. Intensity patterns have been tabulated with accuracy of 100 Da.

Every peak in the experimental spectrum is assumed to be starting point of an isotope cluster pattern. The mass window with the length of target signal is densified after each such peak with linearly interpolated additional peaks in 50 mDa steps. Addition of further peaks (a transformation to a semianalog signal) compensates for small inaccuracies in resolving position of isotope-variant peaks by the instrument's software. A correlation coefficient is calcuated between observed intensities from pre-computed pattern. High correlations (between 0.95 and even 0.99) show reoccurrence of target signal in computed pattern. Multiply charged clusters that are detected are converted to a singly charged monoisotopic peak (deconvoluted). In rare cases an ion's triply and doubly charged peaks are found, the one with the higher coefficient is used. There is no inspection of coefficient values between singly and multiply charged states of the same ion.

So long as no very low intensity peaks are within ~0.25 Da of major intensities, this algorithm works well. Such peaks arise as random noise or from transforming continuous signal to centroided discrete signal. Small interfering peaks between the main isotope cluster peaks are merged with the closest main peak before densification, which is a procedure for reversal of small peak creation. A weight-direcgted graph G(V,E) is constructed for peak merging where V is the set of vertices which is the set of all m/z values in the window, and a directed edge eIj ∈ E is added between the two vertices vi, vj ∈ V if the distance d between peaks vi, vj is less than a user-defined accuracy value. Direction of the edge is defined to be from vi to vj if intensity(vi) < intensity (vj). The weight wi of an edge eij is actively removed from the graph and its intensity added to vertex vj, then edges to other vertices can also vanish. Through systematic enumeration (e.g. with topological ordering), and edge-free subgraph is computed without large computational cost which fulfills condition that the sum of weights of actively removed edges is minimal.

Because this procedure relies heavily on the resolution and accuracy of measurement of isotope members and the correlation to an etalon. There is also the high likelihood that very dense noise in spectra will be seen as multiply charged ions deconvoluted to a single charge ion representing the noise. Some false positive predictions might arise:

  1. aggressive baseline suppression affects relative intensities of peaks in an isotope cluster and reduces correlation with predefined etalon
  2. interfering peaks overlaying an isotope cluster result in a low correlation and prevent detection of the multiply charged cluster when those interferences have a high intensity leading to low coefficient, or the interferences disappear in the peak merging algorithm (if of low intensity).
  3. Some interpretable ions are close in mass (e.g., y-NH3 and y-H2O differ by 1 Da) and could create false impression of isotope cluster if relative intensities are commensurate with the etalon; results of real applications show this to be rare

Measuring correlations between observed and calculated MS/MS is useful really only for multiply charged peak clusters since the probability of find unrelated peaks in spectrum which differ by 1 Da is high. Thus for de-isotoping the correlation analysis is not useful. Assume the mass spectrum is a signal with intensity being amplitude and the m/z being the time domain (true for ToF-measured masses). Single-charged ions can be described by a periodical function with periodicity ~1 Da. The transform produces a power spectrum in the frequency domain where re-occurring elements are recognized. Reoccurrences of high amplitudes at multiples of a base frequency fB in the transform can be seen, and another Fourier transform can be applied to find fB. Suppression of periodically reoccurring intensity maxima in power spectraum can remove latent periodical noise including minor isotope variant peaks; this has been reported for removing chemical noise in MS fingerprints of small organic and inorganic compounds.

The MS/MS spectrum (S) is converted to discrete Fourier transform Y by taking the N-point fast Fourier transform Y − FFT(S,N). The value N is N = 2n + 1, where n is the smallest integer > log2[(xmax−xmin)/0.05]. Values xmax and xmin are largest and smallest m/z values in spectrum. The power spectrum (a measurement of power ast various frequencies) is PS = Y • Y*/N. The power spectrum is quasi-periodic with period length that of fB and determined by transformation in which power spectrum is signal in a time domain. Removal of re-occurring elements is done with multiband reject filter, which is created by Yulewalk method of auto regressive moving average (ARMA) spectral estimation. Yulewalk designs recursive infinite impulse response (IIR) digital filters using least-square fit to specified frequency response. Frequencies required by Yulewalk method are calculated by applying median filter to power spectrum (with 300-500 discrete points and computing second power spectrum to obtain most prominent frequence of first power spectrum. Created IIR filter then filters the MS/MS spectrum in time domain. Filtered spectrum might have negative intensity or some new postive intensity signals.

Noisy spectra also have many superfluous peaks densely distributed over the entire mass range. Assuming this random noise has a high frequency of occurrence, a Butterworth IIR low-pass filter is applied to spectrum in time domain. Normalized stop frequency of filter is in range of 0.5 to 0.9 (best result obtained with stop frequency of 0.8) Empirical threshold of 99.99% applied to remove all signals which have lost intensity above this threshold from the raw spectrum.

The power spectrum can also be used to determine which MS/MS spectra are not worth evaluating. Hard-to-interpret MS/MS spectra whose two properties: (i) first power spectrum has very low amplitudes for low frequencies (ii) finding the most prominent frequency in 2nd power spectrum can be ambiguous (several similarly high peaks). If so, the background removal cannot be done and the mass spectra must be checked. As fB is derived from 2nd power spectrum, the position of expected minima and maxima in 1st power spectrum is computed. Are the real minima and maxima within a half period to the expected? If the shift is more, then de-isotoping will be halted. Large shifts between real and expected maxima and minima usually indicate bad spectra. The periodcity of the spectrum is also tested and a coefficient of dispersion (Cd) of peak distances in the power spectrum are calculated as the ratio of the std. dev. of peak distances (s) to the mean valuve of the peak distances (x-bar):

Cd = s / x-bar

A Cd that approaches or is close to zero indicates good coincidence of distances between maxima and respectively minima of consecutive periods with the exxpected distancee (equal to period length). With quasi-periodic but shifted spectra, it is more complicated. If Cd is not larger than 3.3 (empirically derived threshold), the algorithm predicts the MS/MS spectra cannot be analyzed. This is generally the case with the database search software (no protein hits found or hits with low confidence).

In most cases, new software should be evaluated against a large panel of sample spectra which cover the range of possible noise in real spectra, but these are not available. MS Cleaner was tested with known proteins. 100 fmol of BSA, ADH or TRF were used. Original and cleaned spectra are scored and compared. Results of these tests show that the MS Cleaner-processed specta to remove background had increased scores on protein hits. Cleaning reduced the number of peaks considerably, which explains why scores would improve. About 5-10% of spectra were judged bad and not scored: in only 1 case of 626 was MASCOT able to find the protein from a spectrum judged uninterpretable. With the Cleaner program for every 10 spectra uninterpretable before Cleaning, one spectra is returned to interpretable status. In one example of 100 fmol of BSA, 373 peaks are seen in the MS/MS spectra, 83 are recongized as background and removed, leaving 290 peaks. MASCOT did a better job of finding b and y ions.

MASCOT can find multiply charged peaks. The whole BSA dataset was manually analyzed. MASCOT interpreted two peaks as doubly charged that had a remnant isotope cluster. MS Cleaner found seve doubly charged clusters, of which two were found by MASCOT. The other 5 are noise peaks.
