Condensin is a set of two complexes involved in chromosome binding for mitosis during the compacting of chromosomes. Two ATPase units of structural maitenance of chromosomse (SMC0 famly are Smc2 and Smc4, shared between condensin I and II. A set of other proteins (kleisin and CAP proteins) are also involved. Antibodies to Smc2 were used to immunoprecipitate HeLa cell extracts and then SDS-PAGE was done with Ag staining. A solution digest for LC-MS/MS was also done. Bands for Smc2 and Smc4, and six non-Smc proteins were found. Original, MS-cleaned, and bad spectra were submitted to MASCOT MS/MS Ions Search against a small database and against nonredundant that included all proteins and then all human proteins. MASCOT was used to search a database of only 146 sequences. Each of the 8 condensin subunits had an increase in MASCOT score (8.2%) and peptide matches increased 4.8% after cleaning. Only kleisin-β showed a 2% reduction in sequence coverage after cleaning: this was likely due to a single petpide match generated by a single MS/MS spectrum that visually appears to be of low quality. MS Cleaner judged is noninterpretable because it had very few significant peaks above baseline. This artifact is result of low frequency suppression in the PSPS-graph and can be avoided by slightly reducing the threshold fBT = 12.

MASCOT Distiller is the one commercial product able to clean backgrounds. Making scientific explanations about differences in performance are not possible since the algorithms are not public. In one test, Distiller increased scoring in one protein but decreased it in two others. MS Cleaner did it in half the time and all scores increased in the three cases. In the large condensin dataset Distiller halted on a run-time error.

Song J, Patel M, Rosenzweig CN, Chan-Li Y, Sokoll LJ, Fung ET, Choi-Miura N-H, Goggins M, Chan DW, Zhang Z (2006) Clin. Chem. 52, 1045-1053.

Quantification of Fragments of Human Serum Inter-α-Trypsin Inhibitor Heavy Chain 4 by a Surface-Enhanced Laser Desorption/Ionization-Based Immunoassay

Inter-α-trypsin inhibitor heavy chain 4 (ITIH4) is a plasma glycoprotein with Mr 120,000 mostly made by liver in acute phase. Other members of the ITI family can assemble as multisubunits, but ITIH4 lacks a DPHFII consensus on the C-terminal end for bikunin assembly and is a single chain. It has a proline-rich region from G6111 to Q730, ~120 residues long with species- and tissue-specific domains. It is a target of plasma kallikrein (pK), which may produce bioactive peptides from it. pK divides it into a 85 kDa N-terminal doman and 35 kDa C-terminal part. The N-terminal fragment is then divided into a 57 kDa N-terminal part and 28 kDa C-terminal, which contains the P-rich region, but the 28 kDa is not detectable and is probably quickly degraded into smaller peptides. Others have shown that ITIH4 cleavage fragment is a biomarker for ovarian cancer: it is M658-F687 with m/z 3272, and this encompasses the pK-released, bradykinin-like P662-R688 fragment within the P-rich region.

For this study sera from 178 patients is obtained: 40 healthy women, 40 with stage III or IV (23 + 17, resp.) ovarian cancer, groups of 19 patients with stage 0, I, II, or III (3, 5, 8, and 3 cases, resp.) breast cancer, and patients with stage I, II, or III colon cancer (1, 10, 8 cases resp). In addition there are cases with prostate and pancreatic cancer, and diabetes. Plasma EDTAK2 were also collected in some cases of testing. Monoclonals H4NT, H4CT, and H4CT-S were prepared against human ITIH4 fragements: H4NT was prepared against synthetic peptide CKIPKPEASFSPR, H4CT against synthetic CMNFRPGVLSSRQLGPGPPDVPDHAAYHPF (proline-rich), and for H4CT-S synthetic CLGLPGPPDVPDH which contains a sequence within H4CT in the middle. Note that all peptides contain N-terminal Cys and were conjugate to keyhole limpet hemocyanin, then injected into rabbits using a 69-day protocol (used by SynPep). Antibodies were purified by protein-A and by affinity chromatography. In addition rabbit antiserum was made and mAb 1A4 prepared against the 35 kDa C-termainal fragment.

Immunoblots were prepared from 1D gels and probed with the various antibodies. The 120 kDa intact ITIH4 and the 85 kDa N-terminal fragment are recognized by H4NT, H4CT, and H4CT-S. The rabbit antiserum detects the 120 kDa protein and the 85 and 57 kDa fragmentsl. MAb 1A4 recognizes the 120 and C-terminal 35 kDa fragments. Using these antisera, it can be shown the serum of (ovarian) cancer patients results in a rapid loss of the 120 kDa protein.

A ProteinChip used in SELDI analysis was used for the anti-synthetic peptide antibodies in an immunoassay. With H4CT, detection of the antigenic peptide (m/z 3273) and a series of larger and smaller peptides with a potential C-terminal cleavage and sequential N-terminal truncation was seen. The pattern seen indicates that ITIH4 is cleaved at R688 and splits into an 85 and 35 kDa fragment. With H4NT, a major peptide at m/z 3157 is found with no other fragments, indicating relative stability. This fragment is in a domain with alternative splicing (missing G621-Q650) which is derived from a longer variant (isoform 1) of ITIH4. Cleavages at N615 and R644 seem to be targets in the Pro-rich region and these are trypsin and chymotrypsin consensus sites. Curiously H4CT-S recognizes fragments different from H4CT, although it contains it, and this indicates the conformamtional differences occur that partially block eptitope recognition by H4CT-S.

Protease inhibitors had little effect on intensity and on pattern of fragmentation. Longer incubations decreased overall intensity but did not alter pattern. 4° C temperatures had higher intensities than room temp. Freeze-thaw cycles counting up to 10 followed by incubation for different times (1, 3 h and overnight) showed no obvious effects on intensity and pattern of fragmentation. Neither the immunblot or SELDI immunoassay could detect cleavage of intact 120 kDa protein in freshly collected healthy control serum also subjected to these procedures. Thus sample handling and processing do NOT account for fragmentation and all such observations are related to biological processes in vivo well before collection occurs.

Samples from different disease groups were recorded using the SELDI-based immunoassay. Both intensity and mass peaks are examined statistically. Some fragments are increased and decreased depending on cancer. Fragmentation pattern actually varied with the type of the disease. One or all of fragments recognized by H4CT are significantly decreased in ovarian and pancreatic cancer, while several H4CT-detected fragments are increased in breast and prostate cancer and in diabetes. The m/z 3156.6 fragment bound by H4NT is decreased in pancreatic cancer but significantly increased in prostate cancer. ROC analysis was done and significance could be shown for the use of these tests.

Xia Y, Chrisman PA, Erickson DE, Liu J, Liang X, Londry FA, Yang MJ, McLuckey SA (2006) Anal. Chem. 78, 4146-4154.

Implementation of Ion/Ion Reactions in a Quadrupole/Time-of-Flight Tandem Mass Spectrometer

Accelerated Article. Deprotonated perfluoro-1-octanol [PFO-H]− is an efficient proton transfer reagent that does not form adducts or fragments protein/peptide cations. 200 µM PFO solutions form dimer 1- anions as seen in netative mode ESI. These dimer anions allow for use of higher Q2 quadrupole RF than for monomer anions, which in turn permits storage of high m/z ions.

Proton transfer reactions are done in a Q2 LIT (4 mTorr nitrogen) on proteins ranging from 5-66 kDa (insulin, ubiquitin, myogloblin, serum albumin). The PFO anions reduced proteins to 1+ and 2+ states. Resolution was 8300 for [M+H]+ of insulin, although heavier proteins cannot even see isotopic clusters. As for sensitivity, ability to detect ions is based on magnitude of RF amplitudes (both radial and axial) during ion/ion reactions, which define the m/z range over which ions of opposite polarity can be stored simultaneously. The other is the detector's response to high m/z ions. With previous 3-quad/LIT instruments, upper limit of sensitivity is m/z ~33,000; this had an RF amplitude of 185 V (Vr) during mutual storage and the Mathieu q value for m/z 33,000 is 0.00748 (RF angular frequency Ω 650 kHz, field radius r0 4.17 mm). [more on this paper]

FD

Shek PYI, Zhao J, Ke Y, Siu KWM, Hopkinson AC (2006) J. Phys. Chem. A 110, 8282-8296

Fragmentations of Protonated Arginine, Lysine and Their Methylated Derivatives: Concomitant Losses of Carbon Monoxide or Carbon Dioxide and an Amine

An MDS SCIEX API 3000 ESI TQ MS/MS is used. Amino acids and derivatives are made up to 100 µM in 50% MeOH with 0.1% acetic acid; dimethylated amino acids at 100 µM in sodium acetate. Nitrogen is the collision gas. DFT calculations using hybrid B3LYP method (using Becke's 3-parameter exchange functional and correlation functional of Lee/Yang/Parr) with 6-31G* basis set for calculating optimized geometries and energetics. Critical points are described by harmonic frequency calculations, intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations used to establish which two minima associated wtih given transition state. Zero-point energies and thermal corrections come from DFT calculations and used to determine relative enthalpies at 298 K. Entropy terms then included to obtain free energies.

CID spectra of [Arg+H]+ was done and found to agree with previous reports. At low energy NH3 neutral loss from side chain to produce 158 Th ion. With higher energy, the α-NH2 substitutes guanidine to produce N-protonated proline at 116 Th. Computational chem has been used to examine the proposed mechanisms. Besides major products, an ion at 130 Th, a mass loss of 45 Da. These losses can be [C,H3,N,O] or [C,O2,H] type. Deuterated Arg with 8 D atoms shows the 130 Th ion to shift +5 to 135 Th, and so the neutral loss contains three exchangeable protons. A precursor ion scan show that the 130 Th product come from a 175 Th ion. The 158 Th ion does not fragment in a way to produce the 130 Th. Together this eliminates the [C,O2,H] as the 45 Da mass. The most plausible explanation is that the [C,H3,N,O] type is respresented by NH3 and CO. 15N-labeling of α-amino group shows that the NH3 loss to form 130 Th ion is from this function. The sequence indicates that protonated Arg first loses CO, then loses the guanidinyl NH3, then the α-amino NH3. The 130 Th is quite stable in low CID energies and probably an aldehyde, 1-butanal with guanidinyl function on δ-carbon. Higher CID energies of the 130 Th iod give products at 71 and 70 Th, and lower abundance ions at 60, 88, 43, and 112 Th. H/D exchange studies and best theoretical guesses are that the 71 Th ion is a cyclic oxonium with no exchangeable protons, and formed by nucleophilic substitution by carbonyl O atom on δ-carbon, guanidine leaving. Protonated guanidine could be 60 Th ion, with a very high proton affinity. The 70 Th ion would be the product of two losses: first of H2O from protonation of carbonyl O atom of the aldehyde, in which the internal amine -NH- on δ forms 5-membered ring, with loss of carbodimide, and then the ring hydroxyl is lost as water, with the ion 1-pyrroline left. Carbodiimide has low proton affinity and H/D exchange shows no 46 Th as would be expected in deuterated precursor if it were the 43 Th ion. Instead the 43 Th ion is likely an isopropyl cation.

N,N-dimethylarginine. Methylation increases basicity of primary amino groups and increases likelihood of charge location on this atom in CID spectra. A 158 Th product is found in spectra, indicating that there is a neutral loss of (CH3)2NH. Losses of NH3 from any function are not seen. Most abundant ion is 144 Th which is guanidine loss, which becomes N,N-dimethylproline. 15N-labeling shows a 145 Th product which is 15N,15N-dimethylproline. In the Arg precursor a 130 Th ion consistent with loss of CO then the α-amino NH3 was observed. With dimethyl-Arg and loss of CO and of dimethylamine, this 130 Th ion is still observed, additionally verifying that the NH3 or dimethyl-NH3 loss is from this function. Two abundant product ions are 100 and 114 Th fomre from losses of CO2 (46 Da) and HN=C(NH2)2 (103 Da) and CO2 plus dimethylamine (89 Da). Precursor analysis of these products shows only protonated N,N-dimethylArg. The methyl ester of N,N-dimethylArg does not show these neutral losses, which means CO2 loss requires a mobile proton. CO2 loss is not seen with protonated Arg or Lys, but as in dimethylArg it is seen in α-methylated Lys. The indication is that basicity increases in α-amino group lower energy for the formation of zwitterion and this is the semi-transition stabilized for CO2 loss. With the methyl ester, the zwitterionic tautomer is not formable and the two channels to CO2 loss are eliminated. See more regarding theoretical/computational chemistry below.

Trimethyl-Arginine. A charge is now fixed on the molecule. Most abundant is product ion 114 Th, resulting from loss of trimethylamine [(CH3)3N] and CO2. Second most abundant is 158 Th, which is only the loss of 59 Da trimethylamine. The loss of guanidine, also an ion of 158 Th, is ruled out using 15N-labeling of the α-amino group. Ions at 130 and 116 Th did not contain 15N, the former being the 130 Th ion described above, and the 116 Th being protonated proline formed from trimethylamine and carbodiimide loss.

Lysine and methylated ε-nitrogen derivatives. For these precursors, dissociations are most from ε-carbon amino group. All form the 130 Th ion, which is postulated to be protonated pipecolic acid formed by nucleophilic substitution between α-N and ε-C, forming the ring. Also postulated is a 84 Th ion [C5H10N]+. with 46 Da loss by combined CO + H2O. Pipecolic is the 6-member ring compared to 5-membered proline. Lower abundance ions represent 17 and 45 Da losses, being loss of NH3 and CO + NH3. NH3 loss results in 144 Th and 158 Th for the mono- and dimethylated ε-amino lysine, but no loss for the trimethylated amino group. Additionally there is a 116, 130, and 144 Th for all three methylated forms, indicating a CO loss. Note that 130 Th form is isobaric with protonated pipecolic acid: to prove some of the abundance of the 130 Th from dimethylated precusor is not just pipecolic acid, d4-derivative (179 Da) was used and the two product ions separated. Methyl esters of the e-amino methylated forms do not show CO + NH3 loss.

α- and ε-amino methylated derivative of Lys. Methylation of α-amino group in Arg promoted its loss as a function; methylation of ε-amino in Lys promoted its loss. So what happens in competitive dissociation for tetramethyl-Lys (Me4Lys, dimethylated αN, dimethylated ε-N), pentamethyl-Lys (Me5Lys, dimethylated α-N, trimethylated ε-N), and hexamethyl-Lys (Me6Lys, trimethylated on both amino groups)? For Me4Lys, CID spectra were obtained for it, the 15Nα-labeled, and a d2-labeled. Most abundant is a 158 Th ion resulting from dimethylamine loss. The 15N-labeled molecules shows peaks at 158 and 159 Th, and so there must be a loss of dimethylamine which is 14N- and 15N-labeled. In the deuterated molecule, there is an ion at 159 Th, corresponding to ND(CH3)2. The abundance ratio was 1:2 for the 158:159 Th ions, indicating twice as much 15N-labeled product ion. Thus the dimethylated ε-amino group is more than twice as likely to be lost, probably because of its higher proton affinity. With protonation it becomes a better leaving group as a result of nucleophilic substitution from α-amino group., forming the 158 Th dimehtylpipecolic acid which then loses 46 Da (H2O and CO) to produce N,N-dimethyltetrahydropyridinyl ion at 112 Th. As for the 158 Th ion containing 14N, its continued dissociation indicates that it is not the dimethylpipecolic acid: it produces a 130 Th ion, probably a loss of 28 Da CO (established both with CID of 158 Th and by precusor scanning for 130 Th ion). With protonation of α-amino, then loss of 15N-dimethylamine, a carbocation forms which would be destabilized by COOH, making this mechanism unlikely. More likely is the attraction of the carbonyl O atom to produce a 3-member lactone with terminal protonated dimethylamino group with m/z 158. CO would be eliminated as a result of steric strain to produce ionic aldehyde at 130 Th. Deuterated Me4Lys indicates that aldehyde ion has one exchangeable proton, consistent with this mechanism. Second most abundant is 114 Th ion, 89 Da less in mass than Me4Lys. Loss of CO2 and dimethylamine would produce this, but parent ion discovery for 114 Th shows that 158 Th ion does not fragment to produce this ion (in other words, elimination of dimethylamine does not precede CO2 loss). The dissociation is seen for Me5Lys and more prominent for Me6Lys. With Me6Lys, ion at 128 Th is most abundant, with neutral loss of CO2 and trimethylamine (totals 103 Da). Relative abundance shows that the loss of trimethylamine in Me6Lys is equally likely for the α- and ε amino groups. This is also shown in 15Nα-labeled, with equal abundances of 172 and 173 Th peaks. Parent ion discovery on 144 Th shows that only peak 172 Th results in CO elimination, which is the ion still containing the dimethylated side chain, which means that the side chain amino displaces the carboxyl group. The second loss of trimethylamine then occurs. Ions at 129 Th represent loss of the side chain amino (14N) while ions at 128 Th would be the α-amino (15N), and abundance is in a 3:2 ratio, indicating again a greater likelihood of α-amino loss. The scheme is that loss of side chain amino results from nucleophilic substitution from O atom on COO−, with formation of 6-hexanolactone and a 2-trimethylamino group (α-N presence). In contrast, α-amino (15N) trimethylamine loss is promoted by also by the O atom in carboxyl group to form a propanolactone with 2-trimethylbutylamino function; this promote CO elimination in the strained ring. These lactones would not be prone to lose CO2, so loss of CO2 must precede any trimethylamine loss. In such a case, a zwitterionic (two positive, one negative) hexamethylpentadiamine would be created. if there is no charge relocalization, the side chain amino group would be lost to form a trimethylamino-cyclopentane ion with mass 129 Th (since the side chain nitrogen is 14N). If there is rapid charge relocalization with proton shifting (1,4 proton transfer), the same trimethylamino cyclopentane ion forms, but with mass 128 Th, since the leaving group is 15N-labeled α-amino. With the 3:2 ratio, it shows that there is a proton shift, but immediate formation is slightly more likely.

Computational estimations. Energy profiles were calculated for protonated Arg and the Nα,Nα-dimethylArg. A previous report also looked at protonated Arg at B3LYP/6-31G* level. Reactions are shown for loss of NH3 and also both CO and NH3 together. The canonical structure of protonated Arg is its lowest energy isomer, with salt-bridged form being 10.0 kcal/mol higher. From salt-bridged, an O atom on carboxyl leads to nucleophilic substitution with Cα-N bond lenghtening in preparation of NH3 leaving. This leads to a lactone with propylguanidinium solvated by NH3. NH3 migration to guanidinium gives a lower energy complex. To lose CO, the O atom making the nucleophilic substitution to Cα continues to bond to it, coupled with lengthening of the Cα-CO bond. Transition and intermediate states are energetically consistent.

Beck HC, Nielsen EC, Matthiesen R, Jensen LH, Sehested M, Finn P, Grauslund M, Hansen AM, Jensen ON (2006) Molec. Cell. Proteomics 5, 1314-1325.

Quantitative Proteomic Analysis of Post-translational Modifications of Human Histones

Eukayotic DNA compacted in nucleosomes composed of octamers of core histones:

  • two heterodimeric formations of H2A and H2B
  • a heterotetrameter of H3 and H4
  • Joined by histone H1 and linker DNA to form chromatin.

Gene activation involves posttranslational modifications of core histones affecting their affinity for DNA and ability to form nucleosomes. N- and C-terminal ends are modified by methylation, acetylation, phosphorylation, ADP-ribosylation, ubiquitination, and sumoylation. The histone code specifies a combinatorial system whereby covalent modifications occurs. Lys acetylation seems to be a major part of the code: acetylation is correlated with high transcriptional activity whereas deacetylation (hypoacetylation) is involved in transcriptional silencing. Histone acyltransferases (HATs, histone acetylases) and deacetylases (HDACs) have been identified. Hyperacetylation of H3 and H4 occurs with HDAC inhibition, and genes are expressed that induce growth arrest, cell differentiation, apoptotic cell death in cultured tumor cells. Several HDACs have been found to have pharmacological properties that inhibit tumors in animal models. Proteomic study of histones recently showed 20 novel covalent modifications in calf thymus histones H2A, H2B, H3 and H4, and showing more uniform modification than understood; modifications would affect DNA binding to nucleosome lateral surface. Many histone modifications determined by western blotting with site-specific antibodies. MS-based methods have no limitations compared to western analysis.

Human small cell lung cancer (SCLC) carcinoma OC-NYH cells are grown in 150 cm2 flasks (Nunclon) in RPMI-1640 with 10% FCS + 100 U/ml pen-strep in 5% CO2 humidified atmosphere. HDACi PXD101 at 0, 0.1, 0.3, 1.0, 3.0, and 10 µM were added when cell were 10 million per flask, and cells incubated additional 24 h before harvest. Cells are pelleted and wash in cold PBS, lysed in 10 mM TrisHCl, pH 6.5, 50 mM sodium bisulfate, 1% TX-100, 10 mM MgCl2, and 8.6% sucrose at 4° using 20 strokes Dounce with tight pestle. Nuclei were recovered at 2500 × g 10 min at 4°. Pellet is washed again in 10 mM TrisHCl pH 7.4 + 13 mM EDTA. Pellet was resuspended in 100 µl ice-cold 0.4 M sulfuric acid, left 1 h 4°, then centrifuged 2500 g for 10 min. Supntant is transferred to clean tube and 1 ml ice-cold acetone added with overnight incubation. This is centrifuged, the pellet air-dried, then resuspended in water, and protein assessed by Bradford. 5 µg purified protein boiled in SDS sample buffer (+DTT), run on 4-12% NuPAGE Bis-Tris gels, transferred to nitrocellulose; antihistone antibodies probed 4° overnight, then HRP-conj goat antirabbit 45 min, detection by chemiluminescence (Amersham ECL Plus). Rabbit anti-human pAbs to histone H2B, H4, acetyl-Lys5 H2B, acetyl-Lys12 H2B, acetyl-Lys15 H2B, acetyl-Lys20 H2B, acetyl-Lys16 H4 all from Upstate Cell Signaling solutions. Also pAbs from Serotec for acetylated Lys-5, -8, -12, -16 for H4. SDS-PAGE-separated protein bands for histones excised, trypsinated in-gel, removing Coomassie G-250 and R-250. q-Real Time PRC: total RNA extracted from OC-NYH cells with Trizol using standard protcol; RNA sample quality check by EtBr-stained agarose gels. 5 µg treated with TaqMan Reverse Transcription system using random hexamers in 50 µl. First strand synthesis was 25° 10 min, then 37° 2 h. TaqMan Gene Expression assays for β-actin, p21C1P1/WAF1, cyclin A2 labeled with reporter dye FAM on 5' end, and TAMRA quencher on 3' end were used. qPCR was done in 20 µl with 9 µl 50× diluted cDNA, 1 µl probe, 10 µl TaqMan Universal PCR Master Mix. ABi 7500 Real-Time PCR system programmed 2 min 50°, 10 min 95°, then 40 cycles of 15 s 95°/60 s 60°. All cDNA samples triplicate per experiment, and three experiments done. The Pierson et al DART-PCR method was used to calculate absolute number of cDNA molecules. Relative expression of p21 and cyclin A2 genes was found by multiplying values by amount of endogenous control beta-action and normalizing to drug untreated sample. Mass Spectrometry: QToF Ultimate or Q-ToF micro MS used. The LC Packings UltiMate with Switchos2 and Famos options were a nano-flow HPLC with 100 nl/min flow rate using homemade 2 cm capillary (75 × 360 µm) filled with (Dr. Maisch GmbH) ReproSil-pur AC-C18 3 µm in which peptides are loaded and then 30 min gradient 0→l50% B (A = 0.5 % acetic acid, B = A + 80% MeCN), and this is inline to an 8 cm column with 50 × 360 µm. Mass resolution was 5000-7000 for QToF micro and 8000-10,000 for QToF Ultima, temp source = 80° and desolvation gas 60 L/h. DDA was set to three most abundant ions using a 1 second MS mode scan in range m/z 350-1500 and 2 second MS/MS mode scan m/z 50-2000, with 30-second dynamic exclusion. NaI was used for external mass calibration (error < 50 ppm, but 15 ppm in m/z 50-2000); spectral processing using smooth 9/3 SavitzyGolay and 4 channel/80% centroid top centering. MS/MS data exported to PKI and a MASCOT 2.0 and VEMS 3.0 server used for peptide identification. Database was all known human histone variants and query set for tryptic peptides (up to 7 missed cleavages); 0.3 Da tolerance for MS, and 0.6 Da for MS/MS ions. Fixed modification was carbamidomethylated Cys, wil variable mods are ox-Met, acetyl-Nterm, acetyl-Lys, methyl-Lys and -Arg, dimethyl-Lys and -Arg, trimethyl-Lys, P-Ser and -Thr, ubiquitinated-Lys. Quantification: from the data of the MS/MS analysis, peptides with modified Arg or Lys could be quantified using VEMS 3.0 software, which is able to identify proteins, assign PTMs, align and calibrate LC-MS/MS data insofar as grouping retention times and masses. This is done by looking at isotope cluster intensities from the LC-MS data (6 samples in triplicate). For doing normalization only peptides if they had CV < 30%, where CV = standard deviation divided by mean of the ion intensities. Four internal standard peptides for each LC-MS/MS run (6 × 3 runs) had their intensities averaged, and then dividing the highest valued mean by the mean of the 17 remaining means to obtain the scaling factors for data normalization. Tukey multiple comparison test was done to find significant differences in ion intensity between peptides in different groups; used also to analyze qRT-PCR results. Single factor ANOVA used to determine if the 6 treatment means were not significantly different; pairwise posthoc mean comparison in which H0: μA = μB where A = 1 and B is an integer ranging from 2-6 corresponding to 6 different groups. The Tukey test generates a q value for each of the 6 treatment group in each modified peptide identified: intensity from HDACi treatments is compared to intensity from control untreated. The q value = [ mean of treatment group − mean of control/untreated ] / standard error. If q > 4.75 (q0.05, 12, 6 for α = 0.05 significance level for 12 degrees of freedom and 6 groups) then treatment group significantly different from control. Significance analysis of microarrays (SAM) was used to identify peptide showing significant abundance changes with HDACi treatment. SAM analysis tests overall significance of difference in peak intensity in different run by compensating for multiple testing.

guanidination, quantitative proteomics

Warwood S, Mohammed S, Cristea IM, Evans C, Whetton AD, Gaskell SJ (2006) Rapid Comm. Mass Spectrom. 20, 3245-3256.

Guanidination chemistry for qualitative and quantitative proteomics

Many protein samples generated from 1D and 2D gels where the excised spot is digested with trypsin and peptide masses analyzed in 800-3000 Da range for peptide mass fingerprint. Tandem MS can be used to get sequence tags for helping database searches. Peptides with C-terminal Arg show superior detection compared to peptides with Lys residues. This is related with the greater stability of gas phase ions of Arg. By converting Lys to homoArg using O-methylisourea a guanidination of Lys occurs with enhanced detection of tryptic peptides. This paper attempts to show the ability to do relative quantification using the less expensive [15N]O-methylisourea forms.

[15N2]O-methylisourea was synthesized from [15N2]urea using a 6-h method involving DMSO heating then stirring in acetone and finally diethyl ether; this produces an ~1 ml of a 0.5 M solution. A factor-dependent cell-Paterson mix (FCDP) was extracted and 1 mg protein separated on 2DGE. 46 spots were selected for analysis, with varying mobilities and intensities. A MASCOT search was done on MALDI-MS masses obtained by in-gel trypsin digest. Results of the searches were compared using digests that had been guanidinated and those which had not. With unmodified peptides 36 proteins had significant MOWSE (molecular weight search) scores, but this increased to 42 with the guaninidinated peptides. In fact MOWSE scores were increased for the majority of proteins, with number of peptides matched and sequence coverage improved. Much of the improvement in results was related to enhanced detection in which signals representing noise may have been eliminated in spectral processing becuase they fall below a 10% relative intensity cut-off. It might overlook useful data but the approach was done to facilitate high throughput.

One spot (44) was identified only with a significant MOWSE score after guandination, when 7 peptides (compared to 3) were matched with 24% sequence coverage (compared to 12%). Spot 17 (tropomyosin) was significant in MOWSE before and after guanidintation, but 13 instead of 9 peptides were matched and sequence coverage was 41% instead of 29%.

There are some cases where relevant peaks are qualified in the database search without guanidation by which fall below relative intensity cutoff after guanidination. This happened for an Arg-containing peptide in one spot. If the database search is allowed to combine the pre- and post-guanidinated list of qualified peptides, it increases sequence coverage, peptides matched and MOWSE scores.

By using heavy methylisourea ([15N2]-O-methylisourea), it is possible to get relative quantitation along with better signal response. The tryptic digestions are done and then the light and heavy methylisourea modifications are done, on different samples. Thereafter the samples are combined, desalted. (Desalting is with C18ZipTips. Modified samples are dried down, dissolved in 10 µl 0.1% TFA. Tips are pre-wetted with MeOH and then in 50% MeCN twice, then five in-and-out with 0.1% TFA. Sample is passed in and out 5-10 times to ensure binding. Tips are washed twice with 0.1% TFA. Peptides on tips are then eluted with 80% MeCN + 0.1% TFA three times.) Again the MALDI-MS shows better detectability of Lys-containing peptides, which now appear as doublets; not so for the Arg-containing. One problem is that the mass difference is only 2 Da, which means that the monoisotopic mass of the molecule in one sample is part of the isotopic cluster. To determine the relative quantification, it might be necessary to factor in natural abundances in elemental compositions.

In an initial assessment of this approach, 1 pmol/µl BSA was modified with light and heavy methylisourea in ratios mixed from 1:10 to 10:1. Samples were analyzed by MALDI-MS in triplicate. In addition two separate experiments were done. Seven peptides with C-terminal Lys were evaluated (m/z 965.4, 1016.4, 1056.6, 1205.6, 1347.7, 1637.8, 1681.9) with no missed cleavage although m/z 1637.8 has a mid-chain Arg, and m/z 1681.9 is C-terminal Arg with midchain Lys. Data show good agreement between observed and expected heavy and light isotope ratio in relative intensities, which good CV values except at the extremes of the mixed ratios. Proteins from FDCP cell lysates were separated on 2DGE using 250 and 500 µg and stained on Coomassie blue. Entire spots were selected for exicision and digested then guanidinated. The 500 µg sample was treated with [15N2]-O-methylisourea and the 250 µg sample treated with [14N2]-O-methylisourea. 15 spots were so treated. Data show that the expected isotope ratio of 2:1 for 500:250 µg was observed.

Proteins were analyzed from rat liver cells in three different modalities: (i) liver tissue, (ii) hepatocytes immediately after primary explant isoltion, and (iii) hepatocytes at 24 h and 48 h after culture. All samples were seaprated on gels. Guandination was done to enhance sensitivity. Relative quantiation using guandination showed that fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase (identified using MS/MS) shows a 13.6% reduction in expression between freshly isolated hepatoctyes and 48 h after culture. The densitometric analysis reveals a spot decrease of 40% however. This may be the result of saturation of the spot during staining. However, accuracy and precision of differential isotope labelling at peptide level might be due to variability in protein digestion and peptide recovery. Another protein β-actin was analyzed and found to increase in abundance between liver tissue and 24 h in culture.

Of interest was the fact that guanidinated C-terminal Lys peptides are not detected above noise level in ESI MS but are in MALDI MS. However, based on the MALDI-MS result, a precurors ion was selected on m/z 998.5 ± 0.75 to filter on [M + 2H]2+ ions containing both light and heavy modifired variants of the undetectable peptide. The CID MS/MS spectrum gives a spectrum of modest quality, and the y ion search shows a sequence of VAPEEHPVLLTEAPLNP*K, indicating a correct assignment. In addition, the y ions appeared as doublets, and theya all had similar ratios of relative intensities, giving high confidence for use of the MS/MS spectrum for relative quantification. The data show a 35% increase in β-actin in the cultured cells compered to freshly isolated, whcih compares to a 30% value estimated from densitometry of the gels.

Witje D, de Jong AL, Mol MAE, van Baar BLM, Heck AJR (2006) J. Proteome Res. 5, 2033-2038.

ProteomIQ Blue, a Potent Post-stain for the Visualization and Subsequent Mass Spectrometry Based Identification of Fluorescent Stained Proteins on 2D-gels

Fluorescent dyes are used where quantitation is desired with low abundance or low detection analytes. However for spot excision a robotic device is required since fluorescence is not visible during cutting. Manual excision can only be done with fluorescent staining by using various strategies, which include aligning gel with printed scan image, putting gel on UV box (not possible with the CyDyes), post-staining with silver, running separate preparative gels with Coomassie. None of these reproduce quality and sensitivity of fluorescent staining, and protein id and quant should be done from same gel. This method describes a post-staining which is a reformulation of the Neuhoff et al colloidal Coomassie Blue. ProteomIQ Blue colloidal Coomassie is sold by Proteome Systems (Woburn MA). Bacteria were lysed in 0.2% SDS in 28 mM TrisHCl and 22 mM Tris with 200 mM DTT, boiled 10 min/100°. A solutioin of 200 U/ml DNase, 0.25 mg/ml RNase, 476 mM Tris HCl, 24 mM Tris, and 50 mM MgCl2 and left on ice 10 min. 500 µl sample is mixed with 500 µl MeOH and 125 µl CHCl3, mixed 30 min at 1800 rpm. The tube was spun for 10 min at 20,800 g. Pellet washed 1 ml MeOH, and spun again. The pellet was solubilized in 7 M urea, 2 M thiourea, 1% ASB, 1.2% Destreak, 1% carrier ampholytes. This is stored at −80° after protein assay. NHS ester derivatives of Cy2 and Cy3 dyes are used to label the proteins: 150 µg protein mixed with 400 pmol CyDye DIGE Fluor freshly dissolved in DMF, left in dark 30 min, quenched by addition of 1.0 µl 10 mM L-Lysine and left on ice 10 min. Samples are sonicated four cycles of 5 s each, iced at intervals, then mixed 35° for 30 min and then centrifuged 20 min at 20,080 g. IEF is done in pH 3-10NL or pH 4-7 in 450 µl rehydration buffer with 150 µg to a 24 cm strip. Total run is 60-65 kVh with 50 µA current limit, at 20°. The 2nd dimension was done on 12.5% SDS-PAGE with strips sealed in 1% agarose and gels run at 5 W per gel for 15 min, the 17 W per gel until tracking dye reaches gel bottom.

Gel Staining. Gels are fixed ing 10:7% MeOH:MeCOOH for 30 min, then in Sypro Ruby (1:2 dilution as recommended by Krieg et al) overnight in dark. Before post-staining with ProteomIQ Blue or silver, gels are incubated in 25:10% MeOH:MeCOOH for 60 min if ProteomIQ Blue, and in 40:10% EtOH:MeCOOH overnight if silver. After MeOH:MeCOOH for ProteomIQ, gels are washed 60 min in water, 60 min in MeOH:MeCOOH, then 1 min in water, and then overnight in ProteomIQ Blue. For plain Coomassie staining, gel are stained overnight in 45/10% MeOH:MeCOOH containing 0.2% CBB G-250 and then destained in 45:10% MeOH:MeCOOH.

Imaging. CyDye- and SYPRO Ruby-stained cells aer immaged with a Molecular Imager FX with 0.1 mm resolution and middle sensitivity; the 488 nm laser is used for Cy2 and 532 nm laser for Cy3 and SYPRO Ruby, then processed with Quantity One v 4.4.0 (BioRad). Silver, Coomassie and ProteomIQ Blue are scanned on a ImageScanner and processed with PDQuest v 7.3.1. Some spots are excised and digested in-gel with trypsin. For MS in the Bruker Biflex III in DE and reflectron mode, calibration of mass scale was against trypsin autolysis products [M+H]+ 2211.1 and a keratin 9 fragment at [M+H]+ 2705.2 Da.

Results.

Salmonella

Shi L, Adkins JN, Coleman JR, Schepmoes AA, Dohnkova A, Mottaz HM, Norbeck AD, Purvine SO, Manes NP, Smallwood HS, Wang H, Forbes J, Gros P, Uzzau S, Rodland KD, Heffron F, Smith RD, Squier TC (2006) J. Biol. Chem. 281, 29131-29140.

Proteomic Analysis of Salmonella enterica Serovar Typhimurium Isolated from RAW 264.7 Macrophages: Identification Of A Novel Protein That Contributes To The Replication Of Serovar Typhimurium Inside Macrophages

Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium (STM) causes gastroenteritis in humans and lethal systemic infection in BALB/c mice lacking host-resistant factor natural resistance-associated macrophage protein 1 (Nramp1, Slc11a1). The symptoms resemble typhoid fever in humans for the mice. STM invades microfold (M) cells in Peyer's patches after oral ingestion and is taken up by phagocytes adjacent to the M cells. FRom there it moves through lymphatic system and replicates in macrophages in liver and spleen. This work tries to identify proteins involved in colonigzation of macrophage using an accurate mass and time (AMT) tag approach to identify STM proteins obtained from RAW 264.7 macrophages with or without functional Nramp1, taken at different time points of infection.

Methods. STM cells are lysed using Mini-Bead Beater-8 (BioSpec) at maximum speed for 5 min at room temperature. 0.1 mm zirconia/silica beads are used in 2 ml sterile microcentrifuge tubes. Extracts are centrifuged 15,000 g for 5 min. Protein concentrations are determined. Urea (7 M), thiourea (2 M), and DTT (5 mM) are added. These are incubated at 60° for 30 min. Samples are diluted in 0.1 M ammonium bicarbonate 10-fold containing 1 mM CaCl2 and then treated 1:50 (w/w) trypsin:protein for 3 h at 37°. Peptides are desalted on Supelco SCX columns then concentrated on SpeedVac. A BCA protein assay is done on the peptides and digested stored frozen at −80° after flash freezing. For LC/MS studies samples are analyzed on ThermoElectron LTQ ion trap system interfaced to ultraHPLC system using C18 reversed phase separation. Peptides masses are obtained in MS mode and CID MS/MS spectra also obtained. SEQUEST is used to make identifications. Washburn et al minimal SEQUEST scores were required for confidence to bring them into the final database: in addition a minimal discriminant score of 0.5 (on 0-1 scale) was required. Samples were also analyzed on 9.4 T FTICR MS (Bruker Daltonics) after reversed phase nano HPLC with identical conditions. Analysese were in triplicate. Data included retention time, signal abundance (peak area), monoisoptic mass (charge state + m/z value). A match between AMT tag base from LTQ and FTICR data was judged to be 5 ppm of peptide mass and normalized retention time of 5%. All proteins qualified if at least three of their peptides were identified. The count of peptides identified for a protein was divided by the total number of peptides determined from same sample to give estimate of relative abundance of each identified protein in the sample. OmniViz 3.8 was used to generate heat maps. The relative risk (RR) of each data set from LC-FTICR is calculated as RR = (RRL − RRT)/RRL from number of matching AMT tags with a tight error window (RRT) of ±5 ppm and ±3% normalized retetnion time to number matching in a more broad error window (RRL) of ±10 ppm and ±6% normalized retention time. Overall false postive rate of peptide identification is estimated by averaging relative risks of all FTICR data sets.

Results. Bacteria were isolated from their macrophage hosts in which they internalized in order to capture the proteome that enables them to infect the hosts. Two extraction methods were used. Method 1 is physical and uses gentle physical disruption while maintaing organelles that contain the bacteria. Method 2 is a fractional solubilization of host membranes while preserving detergent resistance of bacteria. WT (N−) macrophages were collected 2 h after infection. In both methods, cells are washed with HBSS; all steps that follow are kept 4° cold. For Method 1 ml per culture well of 20 mM HEPES-KOH 250 mM sucrose, 0.5 mM EGTA pH 7.2 to suspend cells and then passed 30 times through an Isobiotech ball bearing homogenizer having a clearance of 12 µm. Homogenates are spun 400 g 5 min. Supernatants are frozen in liq nitrogen, thawed at room temp, diluted with 3 vol homogenization buffer, then spun at 12,000 g 1 min. Pellets are resuspended in homogenization buffer, loaded on to 12% sucrose cushion, spun 1700 rpm for 45 min. STM are taken from bottom of tubes in 100 µl of 0.1 M ammonium bicarbonate pH 8.4. For Method 2, HBSS-washed cells are lysed 30 min in 1 ml/well with 0.1% SDS, 1% (v/v) acidic phenol, 19% EtOH. Lysates from wells are pooled and spun 5000 g 20 min. Pellets are washed twice with HBSS, then suspended in 0.1 M ammonium bicarbonate.

Vesicles from Method 1-isolated macrophages were examined using electron microscopy. (Bacteria are diluted in 1 ml 0.1 M cacodylate pH 7.2, washed twice in this buffer, fixed in 1% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M cacodylate at 4° for 2 h. Cells are washed three times in buffer, then treated with 1% osmium tetroxide for 1 h. Cells are again washed three times in cacodylate, then dehydrated with increasing EtOH series, with three 100% EtOH washes for 10 min each. Cells are treated with 1:1 EtOH:LR White resin (EMS), washed three times with LR White 15 min each. Cellular material is transferred to gelatin capsules filled with LR White and polymerized at 60° overnight. Hard blocks are cut on ultramicrotomes (Ultracut UCT) to 70 nm thirckness, which are mounted on 200 mesh copper grids with Formvar film sputtered with carbon. Sections are post-stainted with 1% uranyl acetate and lead citrate for contrast. Imaging was on JEOL 2010 HR transmission EM at 200 kV. Images are collected on CCD camera.) EM results show large counts of vesicle-like structures from organelles within macrophages that were co-isolated with STM cells. Only 34% of the proteins identified came from the bacteria, while the rest were mouse origin. EM images show a cleaner preparation of bacteria and fewer vesicular remnants from macrophages. The MS analysis shows 2 in 3 of all identified proteins are bacterial. 74% of proteins found in Method 1 were found in Method 2.

The (N−) RAW 264.7 macrophages are infected rapidly and are viable for up to 24 h. IN contrast (N+) RAW 264.7 cells make Nramp1 and they can rapidly clear bacterial cells from their environment. Both mouse and bacterial proteins from N− and N+ cells were identified using FTICR-MS. Several time points post-infection were analyzed, and the count of bacterial proteins declines with time (to be expected). However after 24 h postinfection in N+ macrophages when 95% of bacteria are killed, 40% of proteins are bacterial. A total of 16,245 peptides were identified in all samples from N− and N+ macrophages. The false positive rate was 4% for peptide identification. 66% of identified peptides (10,649) were from 315 bacterial proteins and the balance of (5596) peptides were from 371 mouse proteins. The levels of mRNA associated with 296 of 315 bacterial proteins (94%) have been previously studied in N− macrophages and correlated. About half of bacterial proteins were identified with 20 or more peptides per protein; only 16% of macrophage proteins were identifed with peptide abundances at that level, indicating better enrichment of bacteria.

Most of the identified proteins whose abundance does not decrease hours after infection have housekeeping functions: biosynthesis and metabolism of amino acids, carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleotides, energy production, and other cellular processes. Nine bacterial proteins are part of pathogenicity islands (SPI-1, -2, and -3) and they were changed in the time course. 11% of proteins are unknown or unclassified to function. 27% of mouse proteins could not be assigned functions.

STM DnaK and mouse α-tubulin were found in abundance in every sample. Commercial antibodies to these proteins permits western blotting. These confirm the LC-MS findings for STM DnaK. Both peptide counts from LC-MS and WB show that α-tubulin shows a dramatic increase at 24 h postinfection. This is consistent with finding that vesicles containing Salmonella form microtubules around them during infection.

39 proteins (12%) found in LC-MS analysis were found on in samples 2, 4, and/or 24 h postinfection. Previsou gene epxression profiles foiund in bacteria from N− macrophages show that 17 of the gens (43%) are upregulated when bacteria infect macrophages. Of the 39, 7 are virulence factor including IHFα (STM1339), IHFβ (STM0982), MgtB (STM3763), OmpR (ST3502) SitA (STM2861), SitB (STM2862), SodCI (STM1044). SerA (STM2062), and IHFα and IHFβ are seen only in N+ macrophages. To confirm upreguatlion of IroN (STM 2777), PhoN (STM4319), and STM3117 were tagged with FLAG epitope 3-fold: IroN is a TonB-dependent siderophore receptor protein; STM3117 has no known function but might be a virulence factor; PhoN is a nonspecific acid phosphatase and is a positive control under regulation of PhoP/PhoQ two-component system. WB show that the three tagged protein increase in expression after entering macrpojhages. This increase is seen after 2 h postinfection in STM3117 and PhoN, peaking at 4 h. The increase in IroN is detectable only at 4 h. The LC-MS and WB results agree as to quantitation.

As IroN, Mn2+ transporter components SitA/B, and Mg2+ transporter protein MgtB are all upregulated, the bacteria are sensing divalent metal ion limiting conditions in the vacuole. PhoN and MgtB are regulated by PhoP/Q which is known to be activated after infection of macrophages. Increases in OmpR also indicate that T3S of SPI-2 is upregulated. One of functions of OmpR is to regulate SsrA/B, which in turn regulates T3S of SPI-2 expression. No other SPI-2 proteins were found (consistent with other expression profiles). T3S is translocated into the cytoplasm of host cells.

Nramp1 is a divalent metal transporter made by infected host cells. Nramp1 is recruited into the vacuole with bacteria present within. Nramp1 action will induce a response. It should be noted that IHFα and IHFβ and SerA were observed only when bacteria are taken from N+ macrophages. SodCI, Upp (STM2498) and STM3117 are found in bacterial expression only from N− macrophages. IHFα, IHFβ, SodC are involved in bacterial virulence. IHFα and IHFβ associate as a heterodimer called integration host factor, and is a DNA binding protein, regulating bacterial expression of genes in SPI-1 through SPI-5. SodCI is one of two periplasmic superoxide dismutase (Cu,Zn-dependent) limiting the oxidatiave burst of NADPH oxidase in the vacuole in an attempt to neutralize antibacterial ROS formed in the vacuole. If sodCI is inactivated in bacteria, they fail to proliferate in mouse spleen. SodCI is absent in bacteria isolated from N+ macrophages and thuse Nramp1 may affect the ability of SodCI to associate with Cu/Zn cofactor. Upp (uracily phosphoribosyltransferase) regulates entry into pyrimidie salvage pathway commonly induced by starvation conditions, while SerA (D-3-phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase) regulates cellular levels of 3-phosphoglycerate from serine; neither has clear role in pathogenesis.

Potein STM3117 is seen in LC-MS only from N− macrophages and is in greater abundance than in N+ macrophages. It is tagged with 3 × FLAG epitope and WB confirms quantiative findings of LC-MS relative to N+ macrophages. The same is true for STM3118 and STM3119, indicating these three proteins are part of an operon. Using a λ-phage recombinase system, STM3117 gene was deleted during expression. Bacteria are able to invade macrophages, with similar numbers of bacteria seen in both N− and N+ macrophages. However, bacteria cannot replicate inside N− macrophages, and thus may be necessary for colonization. STM3117 also gives no advantage to bacteria in resisting killing and clearing in N+ macrophages.

Chevallet M, Luche S, Rabilloud T (2006) Nat. Protoc. 1, 1852-1858.

Silver staining of proteins in polyacrylamide gels

Proteins can bind to silver but in doing so they reduce the reactivity of silver to reduction chemistry. This explains why there is a hollow or doughnut appearance in the spots/bands of proteins. All staining protocols do the following: fixation which eliminates interfering chemicals; sensitization, followed by rinsing to improve sensitivitiy and contrast; impregnating silver either with its nitrate or its ammonia complex form; rinsing and development; the stopping of development before excessive background occurs.

Silver nitrate methods are simplest, have moderate compatibility with MS. They come in rapid and slower modes (expense of quality in rapid mode). Background staining is seen when room temperatures are too high (> 30°). Basic proteins are less efficiently stained than acidic ones. Silver nitrate methods are best choice when multiple gels must be stained and consistency is required.

Silver ammonia complex do not work well with cold solutions (should be 20-25° or above). Basic proteins are stained better than for acidic proteins. Only gels made in Tris-glycine or taurine buffer systems can be stained (bicine/tricine systems have backgrounds). Polymerization must be with 70 µl TEMED, 500 µl 10% hypo (sodium thiosulfate pentahydrate), and 700 µl ammonium thiosulfate per 100 ml gel mix, all added sequentially.

Some important considerations are 1D vs 2D gels. The latter contain carrier ampholytes which require removal with vigorous fixation. Silver-ammonia complex staining requires the use of fresh, in-house cast gels, and does not work well with commercial gels. Also fixes with aldehydes (formaldehyde, glutaraldehyde) do well to improve fixation and sensitivity and uniform staining, but are not MS-compatible. Fixation processes that use a long time are good at improving the image, but they lead to peptide loss and recovery for MS. The use of fast vs slow protocols should favor slow protocols when gel replicates are made and consistency is desired; faster protocols are okay when the gel will be processed for MS and when image replication is not critical. Room temperature consistency is vital too: generally room temp should stay between 20-30° for the best results.

The following selection procedure should work well:

  • Use Protocol A for fast and sensitive visualization where only a few gels per series, with no special needs afterwards
  • Protocol B is a slow silver nitrate method ideal for large series of gels over extendded time period, maximal consistency and good linearity
  • A variation of Protocol A is done when sensitive detection but no quantiation giving maximal sequence coverage in MS work: this is the ultrafast staining to help prevent decreases in peptide recovery
  • Protocol C provides sensitivity, linearity, and is MS compatible: this is aldehyde-free silver ammonia
  • Protocol D gives excellent sensitivity, without requirements for quantitation or MS-compatibility. This is standard formaldehyde-based silver ammonia staining

In general a batch of 3-5 gels of 20 cm × 16 cm × 1.5 mm can be incubated at once in a 1 L solution of each step. This is a solution:gel volume ratio of ≥ 5. 500 ml solution is used for 1 or 2 gels of this size. At least a 5:1 solution:gel ratio should be used. The gels must also float freely. In general a batch processing (multiple gels in a container) can be used for every step where the time period ≥ 5 min.

A rigid plastic sheet should be used for changing solutions, which can be used to press gels down and hold them. When adding solution it is advisable to keep the gels pressed so that the pouring of the new solution does not cause gel breakage.

Reagents.

  • Ethanol. 95% or absolute EtOH can be used without volume correction, but denatured alcohol cannot be used.
  • Water. Resistivity must be > 15 MΩ-cm.
  • Silver nitrate. A stock solution is usually 20% (w/v) and stored in dar place (refrigeration is both dark and cold). Alternatively a titrated 1 M solution (e.g., Riedel de Haen) can be used.
  • Ammonium hydroxide. A titrated (5 M) concentrated stock is recommended. When stored in fridge, stable for months.
  • Sodium thiosulfate. A good pro-analysis grade pentahydrate can be used. A 10% stock solution can be made and kept at room temp for up to a week.
  • Napthalene disulfonate. Existing as several isomers (acid or sodium salt), the 2,7-isomer (Acros) is recommended but the 1,5-form (Aldrich) is okay too.
  • Formaldehyde. The 37-40% solution is used. It should not be stored low temperatures (cold environments cause polymerization).

With respect to equipment, a rocker and not orbital shaker should be used. It should be capable of rocking 30-60 strokes per minute. Containers can be glass or plastic, although plastic containers should be rinsed in acetone then alcohol to remove plasticizers. The area of the container should be 20% larger than the area of the gel.

Working Solutions.

  • Tetrathionate Sensitizer (1 L). 3 g potassium tetrathionate + 50 g potassium acetate in 500 ml water. Bring the water to 700 ml, then add 300 ml EtOH. This solution must prepared freshly (day of use).
  • Silver-Ammonia. 475 ml of water is placed in flask with strong magnetic stirring. 7 ml of 1 N NaOH is added, then 7.5 ml of 5 N ammonium hydroxide, followed by 12 ml of 1 N silver nitrate. A brown precipitate appears during silver nitrate addition, but it should disappear in a few seconds. If the brown precipitate persists, it indicates that ammonium hydroxide is exhausted (adding more NH4OH is useless as sensitivity will drop). The ammonia-silver ratio is critical for good sensitivity; it is typically 3:1. These solutions must not be allowed to dry out, or an explosive azide can form. Unused ammoniated silver must have NaCl or ascorbic acid to precipitate silver and deactivate it.
  • Developer for AgNO3. Prepare 3% potassium carbonate. For each liter prepared, add 250 µl 37-40% formaldehyde and 125 µl 10% sodium thiosulfate pentahydrate. Formaldehyde and thiosulfate must be added within 1 h of use.
  • Developer for Ammoniated Silver. 0.35 mM citric acid with 1 ml formalin per liter. Development of both image and background is more rapid than with silver nitrate. Thiosulfate helps to reduce the background but cannot be used in developer as for silver nitrate, and so it must be preincubated in the gel itself. The developer must be prepared day of use, and formaldehyde not added until 1 h before use.
  • Stop solution for nitrate. 4% Tris + 2% acetic acid. Must be fresh on day of use.
  • Stop solution for silver nitrate (alternative). 0.5% (v/v) ethanolamine and 2% acetic acid. Must be made on day of use. Add ethanolamine to water, then add the acetic acid. Do not mix concentrated chemicals together.
  • Silver destaining. Prepare 30 mM potassium ferricyanide and also 100 mM sodium thiosulfate solution (both must be prepared on the day of use). Mix equal volumes and use within 30 min.

Imaging and Mass Spectrometry. In all cases, imaging should be done within a few hours (or at least same day). If mass spectrometry is to be done, imaging analysis and spot excision should be complete within 24-48 hours. Keep the gel in 1% acetic acid until spot cutting is complete. For even longer term storage of the gel, soak the gel in 20% glycerol and remove all the water. Keep the gel in an airtight container at 4°.

Protocol A.

  1. Fixation. All gels are fixed in 30% EtOH + 10% MeCOOH. The initial fix must be 30 min long. Fixation can occur for 24 h, with at least one solution change. In an ultrafast fixation of only 30 min, recovery for MS is better, but there might be strong chromatic effects (yellow, orange, grey, brown spots), which makes image analysis difficult. Longer fixation (three changes over 30 min each) gives better staining, but lower sequence coverage. To remove carrier ampholytes, an 18 hour fixation is necessary.
  2. EtOH-only & water rinsing. Gels are rinsed in 20% EtOH for 10 min each. Then two times for 10 min in water.
  3. Sensitization. Gel is now soaked for one minute only in 0.8 mM sodium thiosulfate; this is 0.02% or 20 mg/100 ml of the pentahydrate salt. This solution can be recovered if it will be used for more gels during that day.
  4. Rinse. Rinse in double the usual volume of water two times, each for 1 minute.
  5. Silvering. Place in 12 mM (0.2%) silver nitrate. While gels might appear yellow, this does not affect quality. Time of incubation can be from 20 min to 2 h.
  6. Development. Prepare 40 g Tris and 20 ml acetic acid per liter as the stop solution. Make sure the stop and plenty of water is ready. Recover the silver nitrate carefully. Pour in a small amount of water (do not cover the gel): it is only to rinse out some silver nitrate solution. Pour out the water. Pour in 10 gel volumes of water (do not be slow, but do not break the gel). Rock 10 seconds by hand. Pour it out. Pour in a small amount of developer (about 1.5 depths of the gel). Rock for 10-15 seconds. If cloudiness develops (it might be yellow or brown), pour it out quickly. Quickly pour in 3 gel depths of developer. You MUST be rapid in pouring out and pouring in! Do NOT allow the gel surface to remain exposed for any length of time, or else surface deposition and background may occur. Allow development to proceed but not so the background accumulates. If after 45 minutes nothing appears, then nothing is detectable. Discard developer (cannot be re-used).
  7. Stopping. Pour in stop solution. Leave at least 30 min. Can be left up to 2 h (but not necessary). Wash gels 30 min each in water.

Protocol B.

  1. Fix gels in 30% EtOH + 10% acetic acid for 60 min. Change fix and leave overnight.
  2. Sensitize in tetrathionate solution described above for 45 min.
  3. Rinse two times for 10 min each in 20% EtOH
  4. Rinse four times for 10 min each in water
  5. Incubate in 0.2% silver nitrate as described for Protocol A.
  6. Develop the spots/bands as described in the Development step in Protocol A.
  7. Stop the development as described in Protocol A. Image and process the gel for MS as in Protocol A.

Protocol C.

  1. Fix gels in 30% EtOH + 10% MeCOOH + 0.05% (50 mg/100 ml) naphthalene disulfonic acid. Three times for 30 minutes each (rapid method) or 30 min + overnight two-time incubation will work. To make sure low MW region is cleaned of ampholytes, fixation must be 18 hours long (MS peptide recovery is at risk).
  2. Rinse gel in water six times for 10 min each.
  3. Incubate 30-60 min in silver ammonia complex solution
  4. Rinse three times in water, 5 min each
  5. Use the acidic developer solution above to develop the image. It takes 5-10 min. The most intense bands appear inside 1-2 min.
  6. Stop development in the ethanolamine stop solution. Keep in the solution for 30-60 min.
  7. Rinse in several changes of water before drying or doing densitometry.

Protocol D.

  1. Place the gel in water, and let is rinse for 5-10 min.
  2. Let gel incubate 1 h in 20% EtOH containing 10% (v/v) formalin
  3. Rinse twice in water, 15 min each
  4. Sensitize in 0.05% naphthalene disulfonate overnight.
  5. Rinse six times in water, 20 min each
  6. Incubate 30-60 min in silver-ammonia.
  7. Rince three times in water, 5 min each.
  8. Develop in acid developer. It will take 5-10 minutes, and the most intense spots/bands appear inside 1-2 min.
  9. Stop in ethanolamine stop solution, leaving it incubate for 30-60 min
  10. Rinse water several times before imaging.

For destaining spots or bands, the solution described above is used to cover the cut-out gel and should be complete inside 5-10 min. With the same volume used to destain, rinse five times with water, 5 min each. Soak gel pieces in 0.2 M ammonium hydrogencarbonate (NH4HCO3) for 20 min. Then repeat the five times rinse with water for 5 min each. The gel pieces can be processed or stored at −20° until processed.

Troubleshooting.

  • If metallic silver (mirroring) occurs on the gel, this is likely due to glass plates not being cleaned well enough.
  • Pressure marks show the present of finger prints or oils on gloves. Use powder-free nitrile gloves, and minimize handling of the gels directly with gloves.
  • If a brown or black precipitate persists in the silver-ammonia solution, the new ammonia reagent solution must be purchased.
  • No development: if no bands/spots are seen, it could be because the silver solution or developer solution was made wrongly. If so, stop development, and rinse ten times with water, 30 min each, then re-start the procedure from the sensitizer step.
  • Weak image or slow development: especially with silver-ammonia step, the temperature of the solution is critical. Make sure that the water is pre-warmed (if necessary) to between 18-25°.
  • Gel is yellowed in background: this indicates a problem with the thiosulfate. Get new/fresh reagent.
  • The black cloud appears during development and leaves a deposit on the gel. Normally it should dissolve quickly with shaking. If not, the thiosulfate is exhausted. Change it.
  • What about a gel with bad background? Stop development and rinse the gel. Destain with 3 g/L potassium ferricyanide and 6 g/L sodium thiosulfate (better is ammonium thiosulfate) and with 1% ammonia (10 ml/L). Should be made just before use (will have green-yellow color). After removing the background, rinse several times with water until background is gone. Rinse 5 times with water, 30 min each, then stain using protocol A, starting at sensitization step.

This is the first in a series of documents containing notes (more than abstracts but less than the full published reports) on the data and results in papers relevant to research on methods and methodologies in proteomics, or in which proteomics is used as a tool. The (HTML) titles for these documents are:

  • Notes on the Literature in Proteomics (Vol 1: 19xx-2006)
    [this document: ProteomicsLit(19xx-2006).html]
  • Notes on the Literature in Proteomics (Vol 2: 2007-)
    [document: ProteomicsLit(2007-).html]
